authors: Srinivas Yallapu, Tanuja Moturi, Vijaya Prazna Sireesha Paramata, Bala Sai Parasa, Sai Nagesh Matta, Sai Ram Manupati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive framework for the detection, categorization, and stage identification of brain tumors utilizing MRI imagery. The proposed approach integrates advanced image enhancement, feature extraction, and classification strategies. Initially, MRI scans undergo adaptive Wiener filtering to suppress noise and improve visual clarity. Subsequent feature extraction is performed using a radial Basis Function (RBF) neural network to capture key tumor characteristics. A Support Vector Machine (SVM) model then classifies tumor types- specifically meningioma, glioma, and pituitary adenoma. For tumors detected, a combination of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)and K-Means clustering is applied to determine tumor stages, categorized as early, intermediate, or advanced. This multi-stage design ensures reliable classification and supports clinical decision -making by offering stage-wise insights. The integrated model demonstrates improved diagnostic precision, efficient processing, and enhanced reliability for medical imaging-based tumor evaluation.

title: Design and Optimization of a Bufferless On-Chip Network Architecture Based on Physically-Isolated Bidirectional Rings
authors: Yuxin Sha
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: With the evolution of multicore systems and increasing chip integration, traditional NoC architectures based on bus and mesh topologies face challenges in scalability, power efficiency, and area overhead, particularly under high-load, high-concurrency conditions. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a bufferless NoC architecture based on a physically-isolated bidirectional ring topology. The design incorporates separate Tx-Ring and Rx-Ring paths for requests and responses, combined with a four-level addressing scheme to achieve fine-grained routing and path mapping. The bufferless approach simplifies router microarchitecture and reduces resource consumption, while arbitration and scheduling mechanisms ensure efficient and collision-free data transmission. Simulation and structural analysis show that the proposed architecture improves communication latency and bandwidth utilization under constrained physical resources. The architecture provides a practical and scalable solution for low-power, mid-scale SoC systems and offers reference value for future energy-efficient interconnect designs.

title: Design Challenges and Optimization Strategies for High-Speed Connector Test Fixtures
authors: Qingfeng Lin, Dao Lin, Lei Deng, Yihong Qi
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Advanced Interconnects (WAI)
abstract: With the evolution of communication protocols such as PCIe and Ethernet toward higher speeds, test fixtures— the intermediate interconnect tools for verifying connector performance—face stringent challenges in core metrics: insertion loss (IL), crosstalk, and skew. This paper analyzes the technical bottlenecks of current test fixtures in high-frequency scenarios, relates them to recent protocol roadmaps (e.g., PCIe Gen6/Gen7 and 112G/224G Ethernet), and proposes practical future design optimizations.

title: FlexPhys: A Workshop Cookbook for Operationalizing Data Physicalization Research Questions
authors: Bahare Bakhtiari, Aurélien Tabard, Sowmya Somanath, Charles Perin
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: We introduce FlexPhys, a cookbook that researchers can use to operationalize data physicalization research questions through workshop design. While guidelines exist for running workshops in educational contexts, designing a data physicalization workshop when the goal is to answer research questions is an ad-hoc process for which little guidance exists, but for which many choices must be made (e.g., in terms of materials, tools, and data). We draw from our experience designing data physicalization workshops and from reviewing three existing workshops, to distill the cookbook's core ingredient (context and goal) and eight additional ingredients related to making (material, tool, technique), data encoding (data type, variable, mark/unit), and interactivity (interaction, sensory modality). We then show how FlexPhys can be used to describe and compare physicalization workshops, and to generate workshops that address specific data physicalization research questions.

title: A Novel Real-Time Dynamic DEA Approach for Decision Support Under Uncertain and Evolving Operational Conditions
authors: Jamaluddin, Syahril Efendi, Poltak Sihombing, Tulus
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Measuring operational efficiency in dynamic and uncertain environments is a major challenge in modern decision-making systems. This study proposes a new approach, Incremental Stochastic Dynamic Data Envelopment Analysis with Real-Time Streaming Adaptation (ISD-DEA-RT), which integrates dynamic DEA, incremental optimization, and real-time data streaming into a single adaptive efficiency evaluation framework. Unlike conventional dynamic DEA models, which still rely on batch data, this approach enables direct updates of efficiency scores when new data becomes available, without reprocessing the entire historical dataset. Additionally, operational uncertainty is explicitly accommodated through interval-based uncertainty bounds, resulting in more robust and realistic efficiency measurements that account for data variability. The developed model was tested through a numerical example demonstrating ISD-DEA-RT's ability to update efficiency quickly and accurately while maintaining result stability amid operational fluctuations. This research contributes methodologically to the development of more responsive and practical dynamic DEA models and has the potential to be applied across various industrial sectors requiring real-time efficiency monitoring under uncertainty.

title: Sensitivity Analysis of a 300 MHz Twisted Pair RF Coil for Capturing Conductivity Changes in a Dynamic Anthropomorphic Head Phantom
authors: Yifeng Qian, Pia P. Sanpitak, Lucia I. Navarro De Lara, Lawrence L. Wald, Molly G. Bright, Laleh Golestanirad
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This study investigates the feasibility of using a twisted pair transmission line RF coil, resonating at 300 MHz, to detect minute changes in local electrical conductivity resulting from increased cerebral blood volume (CBV) associated with neuronal activity. Functional activation—such as during visual, motor, or cognitive tasks—leads to heightened neuronal activity and metabolic demand, which in turn increases CBV by up to 20 %. This change alters the tissue conductivity in the activated cortex, enabling conductivity-sensitive measurements, such as electrical impedance, to serve as a potential mechanism for non-invasive monitoring of brain function. We evaluate this method using a dynamic anthropomorphic head phantom with a perturbation cavity and controlled saline flow, monitored by a 300 MHz RF field generated by a small, tuned RF coil based on an established MRI transmission line coil design. Experimental results demonstrate that the RF coil can successfully track conductivity changes of up to 3.2% in the phantom. Although this sensitivity falls short of detecting the expected 1.0% conductivity change during functional activation, the results validate a platform for future improvements in detection sensitivity.

title: Dynamic Impact Assessment of Large-Scale Network Systems Based on Graph Convolutional Networks
authors: Xiaoyu Yue, Zhonghang Song, Chenyang Yu, Mingyang Fang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Large-scale networks play a pivotal role in modern urban engineering systems, driving economic growth, social connectivity, and environmental sustainability. However, traditional analytical methods struggle to address their inherent complexity and dynamic interdependencies, particularly under disruptions such as failures or evolving demands. Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs), with their ability to model spatial-temporal relationships and propagate dynamic impacts across interconnected nodes, offer a transformative approach to these challenges. This study proposes a multi-model framework integrating GCNs, clustering algorithms, and genetic algorithms to optimize Baltimore's network. A GCN-based prediction model analyzes the cascading effects of the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse, revealing a 31.3 % improvement in global network efficiency (E_“global”) post-reconstruction and a 29.6% reduction in community segregation (I_c) in West Baltimore. For pedestrian facilities, a hybrid queueing model dynamically adjusts pedestrian-vehicle signals, reducing average detour distances by 40 % near the US-40 highway and increasing pedestrian coverage by 56 %. A genetic algorithm optimizes bus stop distribution, achieving <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 0 - 1 0 0 \%}$</tex> coverage in underserved residential clusters and reducing commuter travel times by 20 %. These data-driven solutions demonstrate how advanced graphbased learning and optimization techniques can mitigate urban mobility challenges, enhance stakeholder equity, and foster resilient systems.

title: A Cost-Effective NFC-Based Tap-and-Pay Payment System
authors: Allen Thomson, Smera C, Rohini V
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Rapidly emerging contactless payment methods have totally transformed the economic landscape by ensuring a convenient and efficient means to standardize price structures. Presented in this work is a Tap-and-Pay Payment System which is based on Near Field Communication (NFC) that would substitute the traditional Point-of-Sale (POS) terminals. This device utilizes NFC technology to allow merchants to take payments with only a smartphone, eliminating costly hardware. We provide a comprehensive discussion on the system's architecture, its security properties, the implementation issues faced, and performance evaluations thereof, as well as an investigation into serving SMEs by enhancing the access of digital payments and propagating inclusive finance. Future enhancements include enriching functionalities such as multi-currency support and offline transaction capabilities.

title: Action Key Frame Compression and Accurate Decoding Algorithm Based on Complex Domain Residual Network and Number Theory Spectral Analysis
authors: Wang Kangle
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: This research is conducted within the context of efficient multimedia information transmission. At the framework level, this model proposes an action key-frame compression and accurate decoding algorithm (CNR-NSA) based on complex domain residual networks and number-theoretic spectral analysis. This algorithm considers the practical challenge of compressing and restoring high-frequency keyframe information in action-intensive videos. Algorithmically, this model first designs a multi-scale complex convolutional residual network (MS-CResNet). The designed MS-CResNet applie the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \times 1,3 \times 3$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \times 5$</tex> complex convolution kernels to concurrently extract local and global spatiotemporal features. Furthermore, a residual iteration mechanism ensures gradient stability. This model also designs a multi-layer number-theoretic spectral decomposition module and combines the Euler functions, Smarandache functions, and generalized least common multiple functions for joint modeling. Subsequently, multi-layer frequency-domain mapping is performed on the residuals to obtain frequency sparsification and key frequency enhancement. Local frequency correlations are captured through spatiotemporal-spectral coupling matrix modeling. The decoding stage includes inverse arithmetic coding, inverse spectral mapping, and inverse complex domain transform. This transform enables high-fidelity motion recovery. In comprehensive experiments, this paper constructs the ActionKey-1K dataset. At the same time, the UVG and UCF101 datasets were used for verification as a supplement. The method was compared with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\times 265$</tex>, DCVC, SRVC and latent ConvLSTM methods. The experimental results show that the BD-Rate of CNR-NSA on the three datasets reached <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-34.5 \%, \mathbf{- 3 0. 2 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{- 3 1. 0 \%}$</tex>, respectively. This result shows significant bitrate saving capability; at medium bitrates, the MS-SSIM of ActionKey-1K is 0.937 and the VMAF is 88.3, while the MSSSIM and VMAF of the UVG dataset are 0.934 and 88.0, respectively. In addition, CNR-NSA achieves low computational complexity and high decoding throughput (FPS) while also ensures high compression performance.

title: A Technological Review of Digital Twin-based Co-Simulation Framework for Back Support Exoskeletons in Precision Agriculture
authors: Gurjeet Kaur, Irshad Qureshi, Ashutosh Bagde, Sujal Zade
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Digital twin (DT) technology enables comprehensive design and simulation of biomechatronic systems, particularly wearable exoskeletons for agricultural applications. This paper presents a technological review of existing algorithms and modelling methodologies in DT-based co-simulation frameworks for lumbar support exoskeletons, integrating multibody dynamics (MSC ADAMS), control simulation platforms (MATLAB/Simulink), and structural validation through finite element analysis (FEA). It evaluates established control strategies such as Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) and Sliding Mode Control (SMC), while also introducing novel hybrid adaptive control (HAC) algorithms for posture support. Sensor fusion techniques, including IMU and EMG-based feedback loops, are critically analysed to enable real-time performance tuning. The review outlines how DT bridges the virtual-physical divide, reduces design iterations, and enables personalised assistance in precision agriculture.

title: Automatic Morphology Landmark Detection in Marine Biotas: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Matthew Martianus Henry, Kuncahyo Setyo Nugroho, Rudi Nirwantono, Baruna Kusuma, Bens Pardamean
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ICoAIT)
abstract: Species identification is essential in taxonomy to study the biodiversity in marine biotas. However, traditional and geometric morphological study is laborious, which can be alleviated with machine learning or deep learning methodology. In this research, a systematic literature review (SLR) is conducted to study machine learning and deep learning applications in marine biota morphology (landmark) detection. There are 21 manuscripts examined from the Scopus database and Google Scholar, comprising nine invasive and 12 noninvasive studies. Fish are the most observed marine biotas, followed by crustaceans and other species. This SLR identifies the standard pipeline for marine biotas landmark detection: data augmentation, calibration, object localization, and landmarking using machine learning or deep learning models. Additional preprocessing steps include pose normalization, color enhancement, and image or frame selection. This SLR also observed that the heatmap-based landmark detection approach suffers from multi-object occurrence in a single frame in noninvasive studies, leading to misplaced landmarks. This SLR proposes the utilization of instance segmentation for better localization to address this problem, ensuring that only one object is presented to the landmarking model. Besides instance segmentation, the exploration of Transformer-Based landmarking models and the initiative to propose a novel architecture are recommended future research suggestions, which are still rarely done in the collected studies. To the best of our knowledge, this study is the first to systematically review the current advances of automatic morphology landmark detection.

title: Application Progress of Deep Learning Dynamic Pruning and Model Compression Techniques in Medical Image Analysis
authors: Sicheng He
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: The rapid growth of medical imaging data, driven by the development of CT, MRI, PET and other technologies, has made deep learning methods, especially convolutional neural networks (CNNs), widely applied in medical image analysis. However, the high computational complexity and large hardware demands of deep learning models pose challenges for practical deployment. This paper first introduces the concept and methods of dynamic pruning and model compression in deep learning, including regularization-based and structure-sparsity approaches. Then, data-driven and robustness-enhanced pruning methods, such as synaptic strength pruning and spiking neural network optimization, are summarized and compared. Finally, the challenges faced by deep learning pruning and compression techniques in medical imaging are outlined, and potential future research directions are proposed.

title: Group Identification of Electric Vehicle Users for Stimulating District-Scale Photovoltaic Surplus Power Utilization
authors: Fumiaki Osaki, Yu Fujimoto, Akihisa Kaneko, Masataka Mitsuoka, Yasuhiro Hayashi, Yasuhito Miyazaki, Kensuke Murai, Kenta Suzuki
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The integration of EV charging and PV surplus power is crucial for efficient renewable energy utilization. However, uncontrolled charging can stress distribution networks, while PV surplus remains underutilized. This study proposes an inductive charging strategy by EV aggregator that leverages smart meter and probe data to align charging demand with PV surplus power at district scale. EVs are classified into subgroups based on mobility patterns, and optimal EV groups are identified for targeted charging induction. Numerical simulations show that the method effectively increases PV utilization and reduces excess charging demand, with stabilized performance as EV adoption grows. This study demonstrates the potential of inductive EV charging to enhance PV surplus utilization.

title: Stacking Ensemble Learning for High-Accuracy Classification and Analysis of Darknet Traffic using the CIC-Darknet2020 Dataset
authors: K. Manikandan, R. Palanikumar, R. Saravanan, M. Shenbagaraj, J. Sujith Ayyanar, K. Rajasathiya, R. Saravanakumar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: The “darknet,” a section of the internet that consumers often do not perceive as accessible for machine-tomachine communication, is sometimes mentioned by cyber intelligence organizations. Evaluating the possible risks to the network must precede any initiatives to enhance its defenses. This study introduces a unique method for machine learning classification called stacking ensemble learning, aimed at assessing and categorizing darknet data. This study attained a 98% accuracy rate in differentiating between Darknet and benign traffic using ensembles of artificial intelligence methodologies and the recently released CIC-Darknet2020 dataset. It had a 97 % success rate in accurately identifying the specific program type accountable for the Darknet traffic. To further our understanding of Darknet traffic patterns, we used a game-theory-based approach to assess the outcomes of the features' influence on machine learning models. The dataset's producers have confirmed that our analysis is unprecedented, to the best of anyone's knowledge.

title: Research on Transformer Fault Diagnosis Method Based on Feature Optimization and SOA-BP Neural Network
authors: Shaoyang Zhao, Anqi Yao, Chentao Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: In order to solve the problem that the redundancy of gas features in power transformer fault diagnosis will interfere with the parameter optimization process, and then affect the diagnosis accuracy, this paper proposes a fault diagnosis method based on feature optimization and BP neural network optimized by Seagull Optimization Algorithm (SOA) for dissolved gas analysis (DGA). Firstly, a 14-dimensional feature set was constructed by gas ratio method and sum normalization method. Secondly, the Random Forest (RF) algorithm is used to rank the importance of features and select <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 ~ k e y}$</tex> features to reduce the interference of redundant information on the model. By comparing the diagnostic performance of support vector machine (SVM) and BP neural network, the results show that BP neural network has better classification ability after feature selection. Particle swarm optimization (PSO), Seagull optimization algorithm (SOA) and Condor optimization algorithm (BEO) were further introduced to optimize the parameters of BP neural network. The experiment showed that the diagnosis accuracy of SOA-BP neural network was the highest <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(86.67 \%)$</tex>. Compared with the original BP neural network, PSO-BP and BEO-BP, the improvement is 10.25 %, 5.00 % and 3.34 %, respectively. The correctness of the method is verified by experiments.

title: Enhanced Hybrid Clustering and BAT-Optimized Deep U-Net for Next-Generation E-Commerce Product Recommendation
authors: V. Jenifer, T. Kamala Kannan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: In the age of online commerce, product recommendation systems are a critical element in improving user experience and improving sales. In this study, the researcher suggests a powerful and smart product recommendation system that uses developed feature engineering, hybrid-clusters, deep learner, and ranking techniques to make effective recommendations. First, Multivariate Additive Independent Component Analysis (MAICA) is used to perform effective feature extraction, i.e., isolate independent latent variables of a complex high-dimensional dataset. Then, hybrid clustering algorithm based on the HAC and K-Means is executed to cluster similarity of product features and consumer interests and improve the accuracy and stability of the cluster. In order to further improve the feature set, Multi-Heuristic BAT Optimization Algorithm is introduced, which optimises the extracted features in order to achieve better learning results. A Deep Multi-layer U-Net Classifier is the core predictive model by which global and local patterns in data are captured to predict product relevance accurately. Lastly, the system uses the ranking-based recommendation strategy to rank and recommend the products that most suit the user intent and interests. The goal of this integrative approach is to be more successful than traditional recommendation methods in accuracy, scalability, and personalization. The relevance and accuracy of the recommendation has been established by experimental evidence and has proven useful in establishing the suggested system as a competitive solution in real-time, intelligent e-commerce recommendation. It is suggested that the following actions will be taken during the working process: adding user feedback loops and extending the framework to multilingual and multimodal data inputs.

title: Optimal Scheduling of Battery Energy Storage Systems for Minimizing Voltage Violations and Line Congestion in a Distribution Network
authors: Anuj Kumar Rao, Vishnu Menon, Venkatesh Sarangan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The rise in energy demands and concern over climate change have led to the large-scale integration of renewable energy sources in the electricity grid. However, this transition imposes various technical challenges, such as voltage violations, line congestion, and power quality issues in the distribution network. To address these challenges, an optimal power flow (OPF) model with second order cone programming (SOCP) formulation for optimal scheduling of the battery energy storage systems (BESS) has been proposed to simultaneously minimize voltage violations, line congestion, BESS degradation, and power loss in a balanced distribution network. If the capacity of the BESS is not sufficient to completely mitigate the voltage violations and line congestion, the magnitude and time intervals of the voltage violations and line congestion are also determined. Further, the proposed model gracefully deals with the non-convergence of power flow solutions and is scalable in terms of both network size and operating conditions. The proposed model is tested on a modified IEEE 33 bus and modified IEEE 906 bus networks. The results highlight the performance of the model in minimizing voltage violations and line congestion in the distribution networks.

title: A Unified Hierarchical Digital Twin Platform for Synergistic Management of Low-voltage Electrical Network Components
authors: Hossein Nourollahi Hokamabad, Cheikh Elkebir Sidi Lekhel, Tala Hemmati Shahsavar, Pedro P. Vergara, Oleksandr Husev, Juri Belikov
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper introduces a hierarchical framework for developing Digital Twins (DTs) of low-voltage electricity network components using a unified, modular approach. In this architecture, a core, component-agnostic DT with essential functionalities serves as the foundation, enabling the creation of component-specific DTs by layering relevant features on top. For example, an energy storage DT can integrate a state-of-health estimator block, while a building DT incorporates a solar PV DT, battery energy storage DT, and the building’s electricity network block. This modular approach unifies and simplifies development, enhances scalability, and ensures compatibility within complex DT systems.

title: Carbon-Aware Computing: Redesigning Algorithms for a Greener Future
authors: Soham Mungle, Rajendra Rewatkar, Atharva Motewar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: The rise in computational pressure in the data centers, cloud, and edge has resulted in rising energy and carbon footprint. Although much focus has been on hardware efficiency and the use of renewable energy, algorithmic redesign is a close and highly effective way of looking at sustainability. In this paper, carbon-conscious computing gets reviewed with special reference to the alcoholic approaches to workload scheduling, offloading tasks, resource provisioning, and carbon footprint estimation. The most notable case studies are Google carbon-intelligent workload management, GreenScale edge-cloud scheduling, CASPER distributed web-service provisioning, market-driven edge AI optimization and the Green Algorithms footprint analysis tool. These approaches prove to have the ability to reduce emissions by up to 70 percent without affecting performance, latency, and cost. Other challenges that have been pointed out in the study include challenges in intermittency of renewable energy, computational overhead, and lack of standardized carbon measures. The future of the AI-based scheduling is predictive, further combination with the carbon markets, and cross-layer optimization of devices, edge, and data center. Carbon aware redesigning of algorithms is depicted as an important move towards making computing systems greener and more sustainable.

title: The Lower Ionospheric Response to the Great American Solar Eclipse (April 8, 2024) from Observation by the VLF Receivers Network Deployed Across the Totality Path
authors: Oleksiy Agapitov, Mark Gołkowski
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: During the total solar eclipse in the United States on April 8, 2024, we observed the amplitude and phase of VLF signals from five U.S. Navy VLF transmitters using a novel geometry of VLF receivers deployed along and across the totality path. Nine receiver sites (four of them inside the totality path) were deployed to collect the data in different transmitter-receiver configurations relative to the totality path, which intersected with the radio propagation paths from the Cutler, MA (NAA, 24 kHz) and the LaMoure, ND (NML, 25.2 kHz) Navy transmitters. The transmitters themselves experienced 98.7% (NAA) and 68% (NML) solar obscuration at 75 km altitude. The novelty of the observations is the near-total obscuration of one of the transmitters and observations of several radio propagation paths closely aligned to the path of totality. This configuration enabled observations of the effects of the Moon's shadow progression from Texas to Maine for over three hours on a total of 27 radio paths (with coverage from 55% to 100%) with transmitter-to-receiver distances ranging from 780 km to 7700 km. Both positive and negative (5–10 dB) amplitude changes were observed by receivers throughout the eclipse period. The observed phase changes were mostly negative. The unique observations of VLF propagation along the totality path produced a temporally dynamic quasiperiodic response in amplitude that can be used to determine the gradients and spatial scales of the eclipse effect on the lower ionosphere. For observations within 780 km of NAA, the eclipse produced a 13 dB surge in amplitude.

title: Traffic-Electricity Network Coupled Model for Optimal Scheduling of Electric Vehicles under High Penetration of Renewable Energy
authors: Weizhe Qin, Tianyi Yu, Desen Kirli, Aristides Kiprakis
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: High renewable energy penetration and widespread electric vehicles (EVs) adoption present significant challenges for both the traffic systems and electricity network. This study develops a coupled traffic–distribution network model that integrates origin–destination flows, road impedance, and power constraints to better reflect real-world dynamics. An enhanced Sparrow Search Algorithm is proposed to coordinate EVs charging and discharging, incorporating battery limits, travel behavior, and distribution network constraints. The simulation results demonstrate that, compared to baseline charging strategies, this proposed approach reduces voltage deviations, transmission line losses, and both EV and power system operating costs. Furthermore, renewable utilization improves due to better alignment between EV charging demand and renewable generation peaks. These findings highlight the value of coordinated EV scheduling in leveraging EVs flexibility to improve system stability and resilience under high renewable penetration, while respecting individual travel plans to preserve users’ convenience.

title: A Meta-Learning Framework for Short-Term Wind Power Forecasting with SCADA and Weather Data
authors: Antonis Zakynthinos, Vasilis Michalakopoulos, Elissaios Sarmas, Vangelis Marinakis
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: Forecasting wind power accurately remains a critical challenge in integrating renewable energy into modern power systems. In response to this challenge, this paper presents a hybrid ensemble learning framework for wind power point forecasting, combining multiple Machine Learning regressors through a meta-learning strategy. The approach leverages historical SCADA measurements, weather forecasted data and physically derived theoretical power curves to enrich the feature space. A diverse set of base models, including linear, tree-based, and gradient boosting regressors, are trained on a unified dataset, and their predictions are subsequently used to train a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) meta-learner. This stacked ensemble methodology captures both the individual model strengths and their inter-dependencies, leading to improved generalization. Experimental results, based on a real-world dataset from a Vestas V52 wind turbine in Ireland, demonstrate that the meta-learner consistently outperforms the individual regressors in terms of accuracy, achieving <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> scores of 0.99. This proves that this study offers an effective solution for improving short-term wind power forecasting.

title: Optimization and Characteristic Analysis of Double Stator Magnetic Field Modulation Motor with Auxiliary Teeth and Split Teeth
authors: Tao Wang, Libing Jing, Zeyu Min
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: The dual-stator permanent magnet direct-drive motor boasts advantages such as high torque density and high efficiency, making it a good alternative to traditional low-speed, high-torque transmission systems. Based on the theory of magnetic field modulation, this paper puts forward a double stator magnetic field modulation motor (DSMFMM)with split teeth and split teeth in concentrated winding to realize the design requirements of direct drive of wind power generation. The inner and outer windings of the motor are configured with a 9-slot and 8-pole concentrated winding, which effectively reduces the end effect and copper loss. In addition, both the inner and outer stators adopt the structure of split teeth and auxiliary teeth, which play the role of magnetic field modulation and can effectively reduce the magnetic flux leakage. In this paper, the theoretical expression of air gap magnetic field is deduced by magnetic circuit method, and its working principle is expounded in detail. The no-load performance and output torque characteristics of the motor were quantitatively compared. On this basis, based on the response surface method, sensitivity analysis method and multi-objective genetic algorithm (MOGA), the motor is optimized in different degrees. Finally, a prototype is manufactured and subjected to testing. Simulation and experimental findings confirm both the viability of the motor and the efficacy of the multi-level optimization design approach that has been proposed.

title: Design and Analysis of Low Power TSPC-based Serialiser and Deserialiser for On-Chip SerDes Transceivers
authors: Asish P.G., Arya S. Patil, Premananda B. S.
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: High-speed data communication relies on efficient Serialiser and Deserialiser (SerDes) transceivers to achieve optimal performance, low latency and efficient bandwidth utilisation. Design challenges include high clock power consumption, redundant switching activity and high propagation delay. The implementation of a three-stage pipeline architecture, clock division strategy and correct data line sequencing in the Serialiser circuit efficiently achieves 8:1 parallel-to-serial data conversion using a modified True Single Phase Clocking Double Edge Triggered flip-flop (TSPCDETFF) block. Double-edge triggered sampling reduces required clock frequency by half with the implementation of positive and negative edge-triggered flip-flops in the deserialiser circuit. The deserialiser ensures <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1: 8$</tex> serial to parallel data conversion. An improved clocking scheme is introduced and can run up to a frequency of 3.533 GHz. The design minimises average static leakage power dissipation by 38.3 %, average switching power consumption by 31.4 % and lowers propagation delay by 37.2 %. A 57 % reduction in PDP shows an overall enhancement in speed and power efficiency of the circuit. The circuits are implemented using Cadence Virtuoso in CMOS 90 nm technology node and simulated in Cadence Spectre with a 1V supply voltage.

title: Healthcare Security using Federated Learning and Explainable AI with Secure Aggregation
authors: Mukhila R, Sundhari M, Nandeta S, S. Pavithra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Cyberattacks are continuously hitting more healthcare systems, and with weaknesses in digital hospital infrastructure exposing sensitive patient data and critical clinical processes, it is becoming a serious issue. Conventional centralized security solutions often fail because healthcare systems must comply with strong privacy regulations, have custodial access to their own data, and require real-time decision-making capabilities. To solve these problems, this paper proposes FED-XAI-SEC, a Federated Explainable AI Security Framework for healthcare networks. The main goals are to protect data privacy and ensure that threat detection can be made collaboratively among remote hospital hubs, along with providing transparent and understandable alerts that are compliant with healthcare practices and regulatory obligations. The technology uses federated averaging and secure aggregation to build local Random Forest intrusion detection models without transferring sensitive data. TreeSHAP(SHapley Additive exPlanations) is employed for feature-level explainability, while a Bayesian optimiser balances latency and secrecy-rate tradeoffs at the edge. Evaluation reveals that the system delivers up to 96% accuracy and an F1-score of 0.96, with inference latency consistently less than 100 milliseconds per warning. Privacy is enforced using (ϵ < 3)-differential privacy to comply with standards such as HIPAA(Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act) and GDPR(General Data Protection Regulation). This study presents a practical, clinician-friendly method for secure, explainable, and legally acceptable AI implementation in healthcare cybersecurity.

title: MS-SegFormer: A Lightweight Road Image Segmentation Method Based on Improved SegFormer
authors: Jiaqi Kan, Juan Yin
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Environmental perception technology necessitates the deployment of road image segmentation models in autonomous driving systems. Due to limited computational and storage resources on edge computing devices within autonomous driving systems, there is an urgent demand for lightweight models capable of balancing segmentation accuracy and inference speed. Based on the above problems, this paper proposes a lightweight road image segmentation method based on the improved SegFormer, MS-SegFormer, which is based on the basic framework of SegFormer, replaces the backbone network with MobileNetV3-small, which meets the requirements of lightweight, while incorporating a SimAM parameter-free attention mechanism after the MLP layer to improve feature representation. Experimental validation conducted on the Cityscapes dataset demonstrates that MSSegFormer achieves a 6.6% improvement in mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) and reduces model parameters by approximately 54.8 % compared to the baseline SegFormer model. These results substantiate that MS-SegFormer effectively balances segmentation accuracy and inference speed for image processing models on edge devices, thereby validating the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Optimal Virtual Power Plant Investment Planning via Time Series Aggregation with Bounded Error
authors: Luca Santosuosso, Sonja Wogrin
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This study addresses the investment planning problem of a virtual power plant (VPP), formulated as a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) model. As the number of binary variables increases and the investment time horizon extends, the problem can become computationally intractable. To mitigate this issue, time series aggregation (TSA) methods are commonly employed. However, since TSA typically results in a loss of accuracy, it is standard practice to derive bounds to control the associated error. Existing methods validate these bounds only in the linear case, and when applied to MILP models, they often yield heuristics that may even produce infeasible solutions. To bridge this gap, we propose an iterative TSA method for solving the VPP investment planning problem formulated as a MILP model, while ensuring a bounded error in the objective function. Our main theoretical contribution is to formally demonstrate that the derived bounds remain valid at each iteration. Notably, the proposed method consistently guarantees feasible solutions throughout the iterative process. Numerical results show that the proposed TSA method achieves superior computational efficiency compared to standard full-scale optimization.

title: A Transient Stability Analysis Method for Grid-Following and Grid-Forming Hybrid Systems
authors: Tianhao Wei, Changsong Chen, Yuanhao Zhong, Tao Zou, Xin Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: Grid-following (GFL) and grid-forming (GFM) hybrid systems combine the advantages of both GFL and GFM converters, making them an ideal configuration for future renewable energy power plants. However, transient instability remains a critical concern for hybrid systems and requires further analysis and resolution. Therefore, this paper analyzes the transient stability of hybrid systems by using the Lyapunov direct method. First, a transient large-signal model of the hybrid systems is derived. Subsequently, the energy function of hybrid systems is derived and then used to estimate the system's critical clearing time (CCT), thereby analyzing the system's transient stability. Simulation results demonstrate the accuracy and effectiveness of the proposed analytical method.

title: Adaptive Attention and Ensemble Learning in the Multi-Stage Classification of Alzheimer's Disease
authors: T. Saravanan, M Chandraprabha
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Deep learning has significantly enhanced medical image processing, particularly in recognizing complex disease patterns. This study presents a hybrid paradigm for classifying Alzheimer's disease (AD) into four stages utilizing MRI images. Using a GoogLeNet model based on transfer learning and enhanced with a Dynamic Attention Module (DAM) to focus on key brain regions, a 98 % accuracy rate was achieved. To further improve robustness, an ensemble method consisting of GoogLeNet-DAM, ResNet50, and EfficientNetB0 was developed using a weighted average strategy. Medical professionals may now safely, effectively, and remotely diagnose and monitor AD thanks to the model's implementation as a local cloud application. The proposed method provides a very accurate and practical substitute for clinical application by balancing predictive accuracy, data confidentiality, and computer efficiency.

title: Design and Construction of a 200km/h DWPT System Circular Experimental Platform
authors: Junjie Xu, Yong Li, Shunpan Liu, Junjiang Liu, Yuhang Liu, Zhengyou He
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: With the development of the dynamic wireless power transfer (DWPT) technology, the influence of the coils relative speed on circuit response is attracting increasing attention. However, due to the starting and braking processes of moving vehicles, the straight-track experimental platform requires the installation of additional transmitter coils to simulate higher speeds. This design will inevitably occupy too much installation space. To address the above limitations and simulate fast-moving DWPT systems within a limited space, a design scheme for the circular experimental platform is proposed in this paper. Additionally, to ensure device reliability and minimize eddy current loss, the rotation radius, magnetic coupler, and information communication of the experimental platform are considered and designed. Then, a DWPT circular experimental platform, which could satisfy the simulation requirements for speeds up to 200 km/h, is constructed, and its circuit responses are tested under different speed conditions.

title: Research on Autonomous Line Patrol and Obstacle Avoidance of Robot Dogs Based on Multimodal Perception and Collaborative Grasping System of Robot Arm
authors: Yunqi Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: This study aims to address the key challenges faced by quadruped robots in integrating autonomous navigation and operational tasks in complex environments. This article proposes a novel robotic dog system framework that can achieve autonomous line patrol, dynamic obstacle avoidance, and precise robotic arm collaborative grasping. Its core lies in a robust multimodal perception system. The system architecture integrates visual, LiDAR, and IMU data to achieve a comprehensive understanding of the environment and accurate estimation of the robot's own state. A key innovation of the system is the use of a hierarchical decision-making process to coordinate the movement and operation of robotic dogs. In terms of navigation, the system adopts an improved AI algorithm combined with real-time sensor feedback for line patrol, while utilizing a variant of dynamic window method (DWA) for local path planning and obstacle avoidance. The collaborative grasping module utilizes visual servoing and force feedback technology to achieve precise object interaction, and optimizes the workspace and grasping stability of the robotic arm through posture adjustment of the robot base. The experimental results show that the system can achieve a 95% success rate in line patrol and obstacle avoidance in cluttered paths, and an 85% success rate in specified object grasping tasks. Compared with the baseline method, it has improved task completion time and energy efficiency by 15-20%. This study provides a comprehensive system framework to enhance the autonomy and practicality of robotic dogs in diverse application scenarios.

title: Few-shot Learning Diagnosis Method with Semantic of Composite Faults in RF Circuits
authors: Kunping Wu, Zhen Liu, Bing Long, Pengbin Yang, Jingyuan Wang, Hang Geng
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Aiming at the difficult problem of sample scarcity in the composite fault diagnosis of RF circuits, this paper proposes a few shot learning method based on a semantic matrix. The method constructs a feature layer and a semantic layer. In the feature layer, a cascade architecture of variational mode decomposition (VMD) and convolutional neural network (CNN) is used to extract highly discriminative time-frequency features from RF time-domain response. In the semantic layer, a semantic matrix generation algorithm based on greedy search is designed to construct a single-fault semantic matrix through uniqueness constraints and combinatorial anti-resistant constraints. A composite fault modeling is carried out using the bit or operation. The mapping of single-fault samples from the feature layer to the semantic layer provides basic features, and a few number of composite fault samples are used to model the relationship from single-fault semantics to composite fault semantics. A greedy search algorithm is used in the testing phase to obtain the optimal matching of the composite fault components. Experiments show that the diagnostic accuracy is improved by 13.34% with only 2 samples for each type of composite fault.

title: Accelerating the take-up of LEVs in emerging markets. Findings from Southeast Asia
authors: Stefan Werland, Shritu Shrestha, Kanya Pranawengkapti
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Motorised light vehicles, particularly two- and three-wheelers, play a crucial role in mobility and urban logistics across emerging economies, especially in Southeast Asia. While these vehicles offer resource-efficient transportation, their reliance on fossil fuels contributes significantly to air and noise pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. Electrification of these fleets presents a viable pathway to sustainable mobility. Despite growing attention to electric cars, Light Electric Vehicles (LEVs) remain underrepresented in policy and investment strategies in the region. This paper uses a socio-technical transition framework to analyse barriers to LEV adoption and proposes strategic action areas to accelerate their uptake. Key challenges include high upfront costs, limited charging infrastructure, lack of standardisation, and fragmented regulatory frameworks. The study draws on empirical data from surveys, interviews, and regional stakeholder engagements conducted during the development of ASEAN Guidelines on LEVs. It identifies five critical action areas: standardisation, financial and non-financial incentives, stakeholder collaboration, strategic policy frameworks, and incorporation of monitoring and evaluation measures. The findings underscore the need for coordinated public-private efforts, harmonised standards, and time-bound policy targets to unlock the environmental, social, and economic benefits of LEV adoption in Southeast Asia.

title: Robust Monte Carlo Framework for Optimizing EV Fleet Maintenance: Balancing Stochastic Degradation and Lifecycle Cost
authors: Md Al Hasib, Ibrahim Adamu Tasiu, Mariya Akter, Hongyi Zhou, Jin-Wei Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: Electric vehicle (EV) battery degradation is a critical determinant of performance, cost, and longevity, particularly within diverse fleet operations. While extensive research exists on state of health (SoH) estimation and remaining useful life (RUL) prediction, few studies present a unified framework that explicitly connects stochastic degradation dynamics with comparative maintenance cost modeling across heterogeneous EV usage sectors. This paper addresses this gap by proposing a Monte Carlo-driven simulation framework that integrates an exponential SoH degradation model perturbed with Gaussian noise, analytical RUL forecasting, and economic models for both preventive and corrective maintenance. The simulations reveal pronounced degradation disparities across private EVs, taxis, and buses, with commercial fleets exhibiting accelerated aging. For instance, bus batteries reach the 80% SoH threshold in only 41.8 days, compared to 424.3 days for private EVs. The framework captures RUL variability under uncertainty, enabling robust predictive decision-making. A comparative strategy assessment demonstrates that preventive maintenance triggered at a SoH threshold of 0.85 consistently minimizes total lifecycle cost, achieving 49% - 57% savings over run-to-failure strategies. These findings offer actionable insights for fleet managers to optimize asset utilization, for original equipment manufacturers to design usage-specific battery packs, and for policymakers to formulate evidence-based fleet sustainability guidelines.

title:
Robust H
                    <sub>∞</sub>
                    Control of PMSG-based Wind Energy System Based on a Dual-purpose Kalman Filter
authors: Veeranna Kuruva, Vinu Thomas, Amir H. Abolmasoumi, Bogdan Marinescu
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper proposes a dual-purpose Kalman filter designed to enhance the robust control of a grid-connected Permanent Magnet Synchronous Generator (PMSG)-based wind energy system. The Kalman filter is employed to achieve two main objectives: (1) to estimate the non-measurable dq-frame PMSG stator currents, which are then used to directly compute the rotor position on the generator side, and (2) to remove the measurement noise from all estimated dynamic states for the full system (PMSG, DC-link voltage, LCL filter) and to attenuate high oscillations in the modulating signal to avoid saturation. Most of the existing methods estimate speed and then integrate it to obtain the rotor position, but an unknown initial position leads to inaccurate results. This paper proposes an alternative approach to calculate the position of the rotor, which relies on the estimation of dq-frame currents in conjunction with the measured stator currents. The estimator is integrated into an LMI-based robust H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">∞</inf> MIMO control scheme, where the controller ensures stability, tracking, and disturbance rejection. Real-time OPAL-RT simulations validate the approach by comparing estimated and actual rotor positions. The control scheme is intended for future hardware implementation as a part of the Dynamic Virtual Power Plant concept in the H2020 POSYTYF project.

title: A Comprehensive Data Model for Resilience Assessment in Industrial Production Systems
authors: Anh Minh Augustino Doan, Akshay Sasikumar Nair, Maximilian Steinmeyer, Emmanouil Bakopoulos, Lorenz Fink, Adane Kassa, Elena Urkia, Kosmas Alexopoulos, Thomas Trautner, Martin Manns, Joachim Metternich, Matthias Weigold
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: Resilience is becoming an increasingly important factor in industrial production systems due to growing risks of disruption across all levels. This paper presents a semantic data model that supports the assessment of resilience in supply chains, shopfloor environments, and individual resources. The study builds on a review of key resilience concepts and current assessment methods. From this, a set of core data requirements is derived.An evaluation of existing standards, such as those from the Industrial Digital Twin Association and the OPC Unified Architecture, shows that current models do not fully meet these requirements. To address this gap, the paper introduces a knowledge graph-based model structured around three main domains, namely: employee, incident and simulation, and the industrial production system. The proposed model allows for consistent and scalable resilience assessments across different production levels and data types. It contributes to the development of datadriven methods for improving the resilience and adaptability of industrial production systems.

title: A Semi-Analytical Multi-Objective Optimization of Outer-Rotor PM Machines for eVTOL Propulsion Systems
authors: Zhe Guo, Xinggang Fan, Yongze Miao, Dawei Li, Yuheng Zou, Qi Chu, Ronghai Qu
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: In order to simultaneously achieve low-speed high torque density and high efficiency in eVTOL direct-drive propulsion systems, an outer-rotor permanent magnet (ORPM) machine is proposed and optimized by semi-analytical multi-objective fast finite element method (FFEM). First, the initial pole-slot configuration and structure of this ORPM machine are discussed. Next, based on the machine loss model, a loss calculation platform is established by using a fast finite element and semi-analytical algorithm. Then, the multi-physics and multi-objective optimization design goals, including torque, torque ripple, and efficiency, are defined for this ORPM machine, with corresponding objective functions and constraints established. Furthermore, optimization calculations are performed using the NSGA-II algorithm, yielding the Pareto front of optimal solutions. Finally, results demonstrate that compared to conventional finite element simulation, the proposed method reduces single-run simulation time by nearly 52%, increases torque density by 27%, and improves overall efficiency by 1%. Compared to traditional finite element methods (FEM), this semi analytical method significantly enhances the computational efficiency for machine loss.

title: A Comparative Study of SMOTE Preprocessing for Fraud Prediction in Mobile Banking Transactions
authors: Rezka Norhafizah, Silvia Ratna, Muhammad Muflih, Erfan Karyadiputra, Galih Mahalisa, Haldi Budiman
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: The high growth rate of mobile banking services has greatly boosted the volume of transactions, as well as the vulnerability to fraud. The high class imbalance in mobile banking transactions makes it difficult to detect fraud, as fraudulent events are less than 0.2 per cent of all transactions. This paper assesses the efficacy of the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) as a class imbalance mitigation method and its effect on the performance of fraud detection. Using the PaySim dataset, four machine-learning classifiers, including Random Forest, XGBoost, Logistic Regression, and K-Nearest Neighbors, were evaluated with and without using SMOTE. The findings show that the ensemble models were always more effective than the more parsimonious classifiers; in particular, the Random Forest with SMOTE added to it had the highest F1-score (0.9973), precision (0.9988), and recall (0.9957). XGBoost using SMOTE achieved an F1-score of 0.9942 and ROC-AUC of 0.9992. Conversely, Logistic Regression and KNN, although with better recall (0.9799 and 0.7249, respectively), had significantly lower values of precision (0.0689 and 0.1228) and a high rate of false positives. Moreover, SMOTE significantly decreased the training time of Random Forest by 89.44 s to 2.97 s, which increased the efficiency of the computations. These results support the fact that the integration of SMOTE and ensemble classifiers is a powerful and scalable method of detecting fraud in mobile banking settings.

title: MC-INR: Efficient Encoding of Multivariate Scientific Simulation Data using Meta-Learning and Clustered Implicit Neural Representations
authors: Hyunsoo Son, Jeonghyun Noh, Suemin Jeon, Chaoli Wang, Won-Ki Jeong
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: Implicit Neural Representations (INRs) are widely used to encode data as continuous functions, enabling the visualization of large-scale multivariate scientific simulation data with reduced memory usage. However, existing INR-based methods face three main limitations: (1) inflexible representation of complex structures, (2) primarily focusing on single-variable data, and (3) dependence on structured grids. Thus, their performance degrades when applied to complex real-world datasets. To address these limitations, we propose a novel neural network-based framework, MC-INR, which handles multivariate data on unstructured grids. It combines meta-learning and clustering to enable flexible encoding of complex structures. To further improve performance, we introduce a residual-based dynamic re-clustering mechanism that adaptively partitions clusters based on local error. We also propose a branched layer to leverage multivariate data through independent branches simultaneously. Experimental results demonstrate that MC-INR outperforms existing methods on scientific data encoding tasks.

title: New Order Type and Benefit Compensation Model for Utilizing Energy Storage in European Day-Ahead Electricity Markets
authors: Juha Koskela, Kimmo Lummi, Antti Rautiainen, Pertti Järventausta
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The price of electricity has fluctuated strongly in the European electricity day-ahead market in recent years, and in some areas the variation within a day has been very high. The fluctuation is problematic for electricity consumers and for both production and consumption investments. Energy storage could stabilize the day-ahead electricity market, but the problem is the prediction of the timing of charging and discharging and the strong cannibalization of their economic profitability, which is also desired from energy storage. This paper presents a proposal for a new order type for bidding in the day-ahead electricity market, in which the price-setting algorithm would determine the optimal timing for the use of energy storage. In addition, a benefit compensation procedure linked to the new order type is proposed, which would prevent cannibalization and increase the attractiveness of the day-ahead market for energy storage. This could stabilize the price fluctuation of the day-ahead market.

title: Crime Data Prediction using Machine Learning
authors: V.V.A.S.Lakshmi, M. Chidananda, T.Asha Gayathri, U.Venkateswarlu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Making our communities safer is the straightforward but impactful foundation of this dissertation. It focuses on developing a machine learning model that can assist in forecasting potential crime scenes and times, allowing us to take action before damage is done. This work urges us to reframe safety as care, support, and astute intervention before things go wrong, rather than as punishment after the fact. This study not only provides a new tool by fusing technology and empathy, but it also points to a new direction where data helps us understand people and public safety is a shared, compassionate responsibility.

title: EMCA-CASNet: Integrating Multi-Scale Convolution and Attention for Multi-View 3D Perception
authors: Chengcheng Zheng, Xinjie Zhou, Wenhui Hu, Weiwei Liu, Ke Xiao, Hao Zhang, Hualin Ren, Penglin Dai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Product Compliance Engineering - Asia (ISPCE-ASIA)
abstract: Multi-view camera-based 3D perception has achieved significant progress in enabling autonomous driving. Nevertheless, several critical challenges remain. First, the underutilization of multi-scale features and limited semantic representation capacity impede the accurate extraction of discriminative object characteristics across different scales. Second, the conventional self-attention mechanism in decoders suffers from high computational complexity and low inference efficiency, which severely compromises real-time performance and practical deployment. To address these limitations, we propose EMCA-CASNet, a novel multi-view 3D perception framework that effectively integrates multi-scale convolution with spatial-channel attention mechanisms. Specifically, we introduce the Enhanced Multi-scale Convolutional Attention Module (EMCAM), which jointly incorporates channel and spatial attention, enhances hierarchical feature representation through multi-scale convolutions with residual connections, and thereby improves object perception across scales. Moreover, we design a lightweight Convolutional Additive Self-Attention (CASAtt) module that replaces standard self-attention by leveraging additive fusion of spatial and channel-wise attention. This enables efficient computation in both sequence and channel dimensions, significantly reduces computational overhead, and preserves effective modeling of feature interactions. Finally, extensive experiments on the nuScenes dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework for 3D perception.

title: Adaptive Inverter Frequency Support in Low-Inertia Grids with Varying Synchronous Generation Units
authors: Georgios Georgiades, Eleni Tekki, Charalambos Charalambous, Christos Frangeskou, Christos Panayiotou, Lenos Hadjidemetriou
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The shift towards renewable energy sources has accelerated in recent years, mainly due to global efforts to mitigate climate change effects. However, the growing penetration of inverter-based resources (IBRs) and the decommissioning of synchronous generators (SGs) have introduced significant challenges to frequency stability during power imbalances. Unlike SGs, conventional IBRs lack inherent inertia and droop characteristics, making the system more vulnerable to rapid frequency deviations and limiting its frequency recovery capability. This work proposes an adaptive coordination scheme for enabling frequency support from grid-following inverters during disturbances. The control scheme emulates virtual inertia, frequency droop, and damping capabilities, with its parameters dynamically adjusted according to the system’s operating conditions, particularly the level of available rotating inertia and the droop support provided by committed SGs. The aim is to enhance frequency performance in scenarios with low rotating inertia and high renewable energy penetration. The methodology is validated through simulations, based on realistic scenarios from the Cyprus power system, demonstrating that the proposed scheme allows the inverter to mimic the behavior of SGs and improve frequency response across various operating conditions.

title: An Amplitude-phase Consistency Test Method Based on apFFT and its Logic Implementation
authors: Yangbin Wei, Shuangqing Xu, Hao Li, Zhigang Wang, Guangkun Luo, Jiahao Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: With the development of modern science and technology, the amplitude and phase consistency of digital T/R module affects the signal processing accuracy and performance of the whole system. Efficient, accurate and real-time testing and calibration should be realized in the process of development, calibration and application to ensure the stable and reliable operation of the system. However, the traditional test method relies on a test system composed of multiple professional instruments, which cannot meet today's fast and convenient test requirements. In order to achieve the above goal, this paper proposes a method of amplitude and phase consistency testing based on all-phase FFT analysis. This method improves the testing accuracy of amplitude and phase consistency by using the characteristics of phase invariance and spectrum leakage suppression of all-phase FFT analysis method. In addition, the implementation of this method in Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) is described in detail. At the same time, this paper also tests each module of the test method through simulation and experiment, and analyzes the test results of important steps, which verifies the feasibility of the method.

title: Calibration of simple transient electric field probe and circuit-based waveform reconstruction
authors: Guangxiao Luo, Yizhe Zhang, Yuhang He
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Advanced Interconnects (WAI)
abstract: To improve the transient electric field measurement, this study proposed a circuit-based method to calibrate the simple transient E-field probes and to reconstruct the time-domain waveform. Two probes with different structure were designed: the 1<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">st</sup> probe with a partially shielded structure and the 2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">nd</sup> probe with a cylindrical monopole structure. An open strip-line TEM cell and a TEM cell were made for probes calibration respectively. By comparison with the results of the CST MWS and tests, transmission parameter of circuit model including the probes and calibration setups was validated. Then, a time-domain reconstruction method was proposed, the recovered E-field waveform matching the reference result well.

title: CLSHA-YOLOV8: YOLOV8 Based on Cross-Layer Single-Head Attention for Object Detection in UAV Images
authors: Jian Wang, Zechen Zhang, Hao Zhou, Xinqi LI, Jiafu Chen, Lihui Zhou
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: A YOLOv8 object detection network based on crosslayer single-head attention (CLSHA-YOLOv8) is proposed to address the challenges of detecting small and occluded objects in UAV images. The network incorporates a cross-layer single-head attention (CLSHA) module, which efficiently allocates attention by guiding lower-layer feature maps through higher-layer feature maps and calculating single-head attention using partial channels. This design enhances the model's global context-awareness, facilitates the inference of occluded object locations, and effectively controls computational costs. Furthermore, the module improves the detailed representation of objects by introducing residual connections for specific channels in the low-level feature maps. This enhancement contributes to higher <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$m A P$</tex> for small objects. Experiments on the VisDrone2019 dataset demonstrate that the proposed network achieves enhanced performance in detecting small and occluded objects.

title: New Services Based on Remote Sensing for Improving Event Prediction and Resilience Enhancement of Critical Infrastructures
authors: Salvatore Stramondo, Maurizio Pollino, Marco Cardelli, Marco Di Tullio, Raffaele Scarano, Vittorio Rosato, Fabio Pistella
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Disaster Management and Risk Reduction are relevant topics for Critical Entities Resilience (CER), aiming at reducing the impact of natural disasters and human activities. In recent years, the frequency and intensity of natural disasters have increased, leading to devastating socio-economic impacts at global scale. Consequently, there is a clear need for advanced datadriven approaches to disaster management and risk reduction. Directive on CER in EU is going to impose more accurate and effective measures to protect critical infrastructure from being severely damaged by environmental events, also by supporting more proactive strategies based on event's prediction and appropriate alerting. New technological platforms (i.e., Decision Support Systems) have been realized enabling to cope with the CER Directive requirements. The work reports on validation and test of new services, specifically tailored from Public Authorities, for better dealing with events and predicting the localization of expected damages on infrastructure and buildings via remote sensing data analysis.

title: TDI: A Trust-Based Distributed Incentive Scheme to Promote Information Propagation
authors: Yuxin Liu, Ziyi He, Anfeng Liu, Xingxia Dai, Qingyong Deng, Zhetao Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Many studies on trust relationship establishment in Social Networks (SNs) have assumed that the trustworthiness of partners can be identified by participants through interaction. However, in practice, participants not only struggle to discern the trustworthiness of their counterparts but also find it difficult to effectively determine whether the messages they spread are Useful Messages (UMs) or Malicious Messages (MMs). Therefore, designing an efficient information propagation scheme that promotes UMs dissemination while blocking MMs remains a challenging issue in real-world SNs. In this paper, we propose an efficient Trust-based Distributed Incentive (TDI) scheme that aligns with actual SN practices. First, an effective Bidirectional Trust Identification (BTI) approach is proposed to verify the trustworthiness of messages and participants without assuming that interacting participants can evaluate each other's trustworthiness. In BTI, the trustworthiness of participants is evaluated based on their evaluations of trusted participants and reliable messages, while the trust of messages is verified through feedback from trusted participants, laying a foundation for trust information propagation. Then, a Trust-based Message Forwarding (TMF) mechanism is proposed to facilitate the dissemination of trusted messages while blocking the forwarding of low-trust messages. Finally, a Proactive Trust Evaluation (PTE) mechanism is introduced to accelerate and effectively obtain participants' reliable evaluations. Specifically, some UMs are disseminated as Probing Messages (PMs) to accurately evaluate the trustworthiness of participants based on whether they evaluate them truthfully. Extensive simulations demonstrate that the TDI scheme outperforms the existing main schemes in terms of accurately identifying message trust, increasing UMs dissemination, blocking the spread of MMs, and purifying SNs.

title: Quantifying the Impact of TLE Ageing on LEO IoT Link Reliability
authors: Daniel Commey, Kamel Abbad, Matilda Nkoom, Griffith S. Klogo, Lyes Khoukhi, Garth V. Crosby
publish: IEEE Networking Letters
abstract: Two-Line Element (TLE) sets are the ubiquitous ephemerides for propagating Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite trajectories. However, their predictive accuracy degrades rapidly over time, a phenomenon known as TLE ageing. For power-constrained Internet of Things (IoT) devices relying on precisely scheduled, brief communication links, this degradation leads to missed passes, severely compromising network reliability. This letter rigorously quantifies this critical effect on the Starlink constellation. By analyzing over 2.8 million pass events for 150 satellites observed from four geographically diverse ground stations, the study demonstrates that the missed-pass probability undergoes a critical transition, increasing from less than 1% to over 3% as TLE age increases from 6 to 12 hours. This establishes a critical operational requirement for TLE updates at intervals of 6 hours or less to maintain high-reliability services (e.g., >99%).

title: Learnable Temporal Sparse Memory iTransformer: Revisiting Sparsity and Memory in Transformers
authors: Polycarp Shizawaliyi Yakoi, Xiangfu Meng, Chunlin Yu, Victor Adeyi Odeh, Danladi Suleman, Yongqin Zhang, Xiaoyan Zhang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Transformer-based models for time series forecasting have advanced considerably, yet many approaches treat attention sparsity and memory mechanisms as separate strategies. In this extended work, we revisit these paradigms and present LTSMiTransformer, a unified architecture that integrates Learnable Temporal Sparse Attention (LTSA), a Memory-Augmented Module (MAM) and a unified embedding strategy that enhances feature representation across heterogeneous datasets to improve efficiency, scalability, and generalization in long-horizon multivariate time series forecasting. LTSA employs a trainable threshold to dynamically filter irrelevant time steps, reducing attention complexity from O (L²) to O (L log L), while MAM encodes long-term patterns into a compact memory bank with gated updates, enabling persistent context retention without uncontrolled memory growth. Unlike prior models, these components are jointly optimized to balance sparsity and memory in a coherent training framework. This extended work provides new theoretical analysis of LTSA’s sub-quadratic efficiency and MAM’s convergence behaviour under sparse gating. Comprehensive robustness tests under noise, missing values, and temporal imbalance, along with evaluations on eight diverse datasets from finance, energy, weather, and traffic, demonstrate LTSMiTransformer’s accuracy, generalizability, and compactness. The theoretical proofs, ablation studies, and robustness evaluations included show that the LTSMiTransformer achieves a strong balance between scalability, interpretability, and generalization across diverse datasets. This paper significantly expands our earlier CNIOT 2025 conference papers by adding new theoretical results, deeper joint-training analysis, and wider empirical validation. All source code and datasets are available on GitHub to support reproducibility.

title: Conformalized Generative Bayesian Imaging: An Uncertainty Quantification Framework for Computational Imaging
authors: Canberk Ekmekci, Mujdat Cetin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Imaging
abstract: Uncertainty quantification plays an important role in achieving trustworthy and reliable learning-based computational imaging. Recent advances in generative modeling and Bayesian neural networks have enabled the development of uncertainty-aware image reconstruction methods. Current generative model-based methods seek to quantify the inherent (aleatoric) uncertainty on the underlying image for given measurements by learning to sample from the posterior distribution of the underlying image. On the other hand, Bayesian neural network-based approaches aim to quantify the model (epistemic) uncertainty on the parameters of a deep neural network-based reconstruction method by approximating the posterior distribution of those parameters. Unfortunately, an ongoing need for an inversion method that can jointly quantify complex aleatoric uncertainty and epistemic uncertainty patterns still persists. In this paper, we present a scalable framework that can quantify both aleatoric and epistemic uncertainties. The proposed framework accepts an existing generative model-based posterior sampling method as an input and introduces an epistemic uncertainty quantification capability through Bayesian neural networks with latent variables and deep ensembling. Furthermore, by leveraging the conformal prediction methodology, the proposed framework can be easily calibrated to ensure rigorous uncertainty quantification. We evaluated the proposed framework on magnetic resonance imaging, computed tomography, and image inpainting problems and showed that the epistemic and aleatoric uncertainty estimates produced by the proposed framework display the characteristic features of true epistemic and aleatoric uncertainties. Furthermore, our results demonstrated that the use of conformal prediction on top of the proposed framework enables marginal coverage guarantees consistent with frequentist principles.
