title: Quadrature System Fault-Tolerant Control Based on Dual Phase-Shifting of Current and BEMF for Position Sensorless PMSM Drives With Single-Phase Current Sensor
authors: Peilin Han, Wei Wang, Minghao Tong, Wei Hua, Ming Cheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: In position sensorless permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) drives, current sensors play a critical role. But they are susceptible to malfunctions, which severely compromises system stability and control performance. Therefore, in this article, a quadrature system fault-tolerant control (QS-FTC) strategy based on dual phase-shifting of current and back electromotive force (BEMF) is proposed for current sensor fault in position sensorless PMSM drives. Under a specific stationary coordinate system, the healthy phase is always reflected by <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\alpha}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{\prime}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-axis, while the other two phases are combined and reflected by <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\beta}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\beta}^{\prime}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-axis. Sliding mode observer (SMO) is utilized to obtain the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\alpha}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{\prime}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-axis estimated BEMF, and a modified quadrature signal generator (M-QSG) is employed to calculate the quadrature signal of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\alpha}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{\prime}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-axis BEMF. Hence, no <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\beta}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\beta}^{\prime}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-axis value is involved in the position estimation process. Meanwhile, the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\alpha}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{\prime}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-axis current loop comprises <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\alpha}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{\prime}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-axis actual current and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\alpha}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{\prime}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-axis reference value from the speed loop. Furthermore, the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\beta}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\beta}^{\prime}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-axis feedback current and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\beta}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\beta}^{\prime}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-axis reference current are generated by a virtual BEMF motor model and the M-QSG, reconstructing a new quadrature reference system. With the proposed FTC, the actual current tracking accuracy is not only independent of BEMF or position estimation error, but also unaffected by motor parameter variations. The mathematical derivation and experimental results verify the effectiveness of QS-FTC.

title: Integrated Minimum Mean Squared Error Algorithms for Combined Acoustic Echo Cancellation and Noise Reduction_supp1-3648802.pdf
authors: Arnout Roebben
publish: N/A
abstract: In many speech recording applications, noise and acoustic echo corrupt the desired speech. Consequently, combined noise reduction (NR) and acoustic echo cancellation (AEC) is required. Generally, a cascade approach is followed, i.e., the AEC and NR are designed in isolation by selecting a separate signal model, separate cost function, and separate solution strategy. The AEC and NR are then cascaded one after the other, not accounting for their interaction. In this paper, an integrated approach is proposed to consider this interaction in a general multi-microphone/ multi- loudspeaker setup. Therefore, a single signal model of either the microphone signal vector or the extended signal vector, obtained by stacking microphone and loudspeaker signals, is selected, a single mean squared error cost function is formulated, and a common solution strategy is used. Using this microphone signal model, a multi-channel Wiener filter (MWF) is derived. Using the extended signal model, it is shown that an extended MWF (MWF<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ext</sub>) can be derived, and several equivalent expressions can be found, which are nevertheless shown to be interpretable as cascade algorithms. Specifically, the MWF<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ext</sub> is shown to be equivalent to algorithms where the AEC precedes the NR (AEC-NR), the NR precedes the AEC (NR-AEC), and the extended NR (NR<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ext</sub>) precedes the AEC and post-filter (PF) (NR<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ext</sub>-AEC-PF). Under rank-deficiency conditions the MWF<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ext</sub> is non-unique. Equivalence then amounts to the expressions being specific, not necessarily minimum-norm solutions, for this MWF<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ext</sub>. The practical performances differ due to non-stationarities and imperfect correlation matrix estimation, with the AEC-NR and NR<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ext</sub>-AEC-PF attaining best overall performance.

title: Distributionally Robust Coordinated Road-Waterway Hydrogen Transport for Low-Carbon Energy Supply in Smart Cities
authors: Yingping Cao, Ziqiang Wang, Kuan Zhang, Chaojie Li, Hong Tan, Muhammad Muzammal Islam, Shuangqing Su, Massimo La Scala
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: This paper proposes a distributionally robust coordinated road-waterway hydrogen transport strategy to enhance the utilization of remote renewable energy sources (RESs) for low-carbon energy supply in cities. In this strategy, solid-state hydrogen storage serves as an intermediary to transport RESs from remote regions to meet the energy demand of urban hydrogen energy storage systems (HESSs). Moreover, a renewable-to-hydrogen production control method that integrates dynamic programming is developed to suppress the output ripple of conventional two-stage single-phase inverters, enhancing both the energy conversion efficiency and the production rate of green hydrogen for stable shipping transportation. A road-waterway hydrogen distribution routing and scheduling model is developed to guarantee a precise spatio-temporal match between hydrogen supply and demand of HESSs. The coordinated road-waterway hydrogen transport optimization problem is formulated as a two-stage distributionally robust optimization problem to cope with uncertainties of hydrogen demands. Comparative results have validated the superior performance of the proposed strategy in enhancing remote RES accommodation and improving the stability of low-carbon energy supply for cities.

title: Deep Learning Approaches for Multi-Label Classification of Ophthalmic Diseases: A Systematic Review and Future Directions using Retinal Images
authors: Seetharam Rekhapalli, Sai Chaitanya Kumar Gunupudi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Ophthalmic diseases are a major contributor of blindness and visual impairment globally. Effective treatment and halting the progression of the disease depend on an early and precise diagnosis. Recent developments in Deep Learning (DL) have shown enormous promise for automated multi-label classification of ophthalmic diseases using retinal images. This work provides a thorough analysis of 20 research studies published between 2022 and 2025 that focus on DL-based multi-label diagnostic models for retinal image analysis. The reviewed works cover a variety of eye conditions such diabetic retinopathy, glaucoma, age-related macular degeneration, and other abnormalities of the retina. Neural networks with convolutions (CNNs), attention-based models, and other DL architectures and hybrid networks, are discussed in terms of their methodology, performance metrics, and clinical applicability. The review highlights the challenges faced in multi-label classification, such as data scarcity, class imbalance, and model interpretability, and discusses strategies employed to address these issues. By synthesizing recent advancements, this paper provides insights into the potential of DL to improve diagnostic accuracy, assist ophthalmologists in decision-making, and ultimately enhance patient outcomes.

title: AC-GAN-Based Efficient Image Transmission in the Noisy Channel
authors: Yu Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: The rapid growth of digital image and video data has made efficient image compression and transmission a critical research topic in the field of communications. In noisy environments, traditional compression methods often lose details during the process, resulting in poor image recovery. To address this issue, this paper proposes an image compression and transmission system based on Auxiliary Classifier Generative Adversarial Networks (AC-GAN). The system compresses images into low-dimensional feature vectors and transmits them through noisy channels, then reconstructs the images at the receiver using AC-GAN. Experimental results demonstrate that the method maintains high recovery quality even under a low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of −10 dB, proving its strong noise resistance in challenging environments. The proposed approach provides an effective solution for image transmission in high-noise scenarios.

title: Compact Dual-Cavity Horn Antenna for Ku-Band SatCom Systems
authors: Sena Sarıkazal, Bartu Ilgaz, İsmail Şişman, Tugba Haykir Ergin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This paper presents the design and performance evaluation of a compact dual-cavity horn antenna for Ku-band satellite communication (SatCom) systems operating across the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10-15 \text{GHz}$</tex> frequency range. The proposed antenna integrates a WR-75 to circular waveguide transition and is fabricated using a low-loss PEC material to ensure high radiation efficiency and structural compactness. The design addresses key challenges in modern SatCom applications, including minimizing reflection losses, preserving radiation symmetry, and achieving a lightweight and space-efficient profile suitable for mobilityconstrained platforms. Simulation results demonstrate a return loss below <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{- 1 4 ~ d B}$</tex>, a VSWR of approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 3}$</tex> at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2 ~ G H z}$</tex>, a peak gain of 15.6 dBi, and side lobe levels around -19.6 dB. The antenna maintains a 3-dB beamwidth of 32.2° and achieves radiation efficiency close to 90 %. These results validate the antenna's capability to deliver high directional gain and wideband operation, making it a promising candidate for nextgeneration satellite payloads with stringent SWaP (Size, Weight, and Power) requirements.

title: Predicting EV Charging Station Load by Applying LSTM Techniques
authors: Apostolos Valiakos, Alexios Lekidis, Papageorgiou Elpiniki
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: In recent years, the growing number of Electric Vehicles (EVs) has underscored the necessity for efficient management of charging station resources. Accurate prediction of EV charging demand is pivotal for optimizing infrastructure utilization and enhancing user satisfaction, and developing a smart charging strategy to reduce EV inconvenience. This paper introduces a method for investigating various Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural network architectures to forecast shortterm load demand at individual charging stations, leveraging the temporal time dependencies of EV charging patterns. Standard and bidirectional LSTM networks are implemented, and the results are evaluated based on widely adopted and open-access datasets with an extensive number of EV charging sessions. The findings from this paper suggest that LSTM-based models can significantly improve the accuracy in the integration of EV charging stations in the electricity grid as well as facilitate strategic infrastructure planning.

title: A Calderon Preconditioner for Large Ground Planes with Arbitrary Contours
authors: Adam Abazi, Jean Cavillot, Christophe Craeye
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Many applications involving antenna and antenna arrays require the presence of a large planar ground plane. The size of the ground plane usually scales in the tens of wavelengths, which represents a heavy burden in terms of computational resources. In this paper we apply the Method of Moments (MoM) combined with a Calderón preconditioner. We ensure the regularity of the refined mesh by using an initial rectangular mesh with rooftop basis functions. The regularity of the refined mesh allows for the application of the Calderón preconditioner in an iterative solver which exhibits linear and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N \log N$</tex> complexities regarding memory and matrix-vector multiplication, respectively. These complexities are enabled by the Toeplitz-Block BlockToeplitz (TBBT) structure of the MoM matrices which allows for the use of the fast Fourier Transform (FFT) in the matrix-vector multiplications. The operations are carried out at the level of the half basis function in order to include the half basis functions that the preconditioner requires on the edges of open structures. An additional simple algebraic multiplication allows to modify the mesh in order to simulate ground planes with arbitrary contours.

title: CyberHealth Blockchain-Enabled AI System for Securing and Sharing Patient Records in Multi-Hospital Environments
authors: Chandra Sekhar Kubam, Bhasker Reddy Ande, Nitin Mukhi, Goutham Rayapati, Kalyana Krishna Kondapalli
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Healthcare institutions may find it easier to manage patient data with the help of Electronic Health Records (EHRs). However, it also introduced systems multitasking issue, hindrance to system privacy, and security of sensitive data. In response to these issues, The work presents CyberHealth, a decentralized and integrated AI and blockchain-based system in a multi-hospital environment. CyberHealth uses blockchain technology to make data immutable and transparent, besides ensuring security of data. Also, artificial intelligence (AI) provides predictive health analytics and decision support and undertaking administrative chores. All at once, these technologies improve the performance of a healthcare institution. Additionally, they contribute to better patient care, operational efficiency, and data security. The system uses smart contracts that checks if access and updates to data comply with RBAC. The platform includes Optical Character Recognition (OCR) and AI to make data management easy and secure patient data sharing. A prototype of CyberHealth was made and tested which has given strong evidence of its ability to protect sensitive patient data, increase interoperability and reduce data breach risks. As per the outcomes, CyberHealth can improve management of healthcare data and help in seamless exchange of data between establishments. Also, provide a scalable and secure solution for up-gradation of healthcare systems. The healthcare data safety and security system has positive potential in the real world.

title: Tool Life Prediction Method Based on TCN-Informer
authors: Zhaoxi Zhang, Min Huang, Huaichao Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Against the backdrop of intelligent manufacturing, precise prediction of tool life is crucial for ensuring machining accuracy and efficiency. Aiming at the problem that traditional methods have limited accuracy in tool remaining useful life (RUL) prediction, this paper proposes an algorithm model integrating time-domain and frequency-domain features with a TCN-Informer cascade for tool RUL prediction. First, eight time-domain features (such as mean and standard deviation) and four frequency-domain features (such as amplitude spectrum mean and variance) are extracted from the PHM tool dataset. Features with a Spearman correlation coefficient higher than 0.8 with the maximum tool wear are screened through Spearman correlation analysis to construct an input dataset with high representational capability. Second, the causal convolution and dilated convolution of TCN are used to capture the local temporal dependencies and long-distance correlations of signals. Combined with the sparse self-attention mechanism of Informer to solve the computational complexity problem in long-sequence processing, it realizes global modeling of the dynamic features of tool wear. Experimental results show that on the C1, C4, and C6 tool datasets, the coefficient of determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) of the model exceeds 0.997, and the root mean square error (RMSE) and mean absolute error (MAE) are significantly lower than comparative methods such as CNN-LSTM and Informer, demonstrating remarkable advantages in prediction accuracy and generalization ability. This method provides great help for tool health management. It can assist in formulating scientific tool replacement strategies by monitoring feature changes in real time, which is of great significance for improving machining efficiency and accuracy. In future research, multimodal data fusion and lightweight model design can be further explored to adapt to the needs of complex industrial scenarios.

title: Towards Robust NILM: A Unified Seq2Point Benchmarking Framework with Balanced Model
authors: Yash Mahajan, Ruichang Zhang, Mustafa A. Mustafa
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: NILM estimates appliance-level power consumption from household aggregate power data, offering insights into energy consumption without intrusive sub-metering techniques. Although deep learning-based sequence-to-point (Seq2Point) models are becoming increasingly popular, no unified framework exists for fair and reproducible evaluation across datasets and appliance types. We address this by developing a modular bench-marking pipeline, incorporating standardised data pre-processing and consistent training and evaluation procedures. The toolkit supports three major public datasets (UKDALE, REFIT, ECO) and multiple Seq2Point variants. In addition, we propose a novel architecture, Seq2Point Balanced. It integrates a variety of regularisation techniques and architectural simplifications to significantly reduce the parameter count by 94% (1.8 million vs. 30 million), whilst improving robustness and generalisation. Experiments show that Seq2Point Balanced achieves competitive and often superior performance, particularly in noisy and cross-domain scenarios. The model demonstrates strong fine-tuning capabilities. The toolkit is publicly released to support reproducibility at: https://github.com/ymahajan1612/seq2point-update.

title: Design and Evaluation of Polarization Switching Reflective Electromagnetic Surfaces Across Microwave to Terahertz Bands
authors: Dwi Andi Nurmantris, Zulfi, Achmad Munir
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This paper deals with the design and evaluation of Reflective Electromagnetic Surfaces (RES) for polarization switching across three frequency bands: microwave band, millimeter wave (mm-Wave) band, and terahertz (THz) band. The polarization switching discussed here involves the reflection of linearly polarized incoming waves, where the reflected waves can be switched between linear polarization and circular polarization. The simple principle underlying the design of RES for polarization switching lies in the upper layer of the unit cell structure, where three switches integrated into the diagonal slot act as perturbation activators and eliminators. In OFF-state condition, the perturbation function is active, producing circularly polarized reflected waves. While in ON-state condition, the perturbation function is eliminated, resulting in linearly polarized reflected waves. Simulation results show that the proposed method can be successfully applied to configure RES for polarization switching across three frequency bands. In addition, experimental verification conducted in the microwave band demonstrates agreement between simulation and measurement.

title: Optimization of Mobile Energy Storage Vehicle Dispatch Based on EV Charging Load Prediction
authors: Jiayu Ma, Shengguo Zhang, Jiaran Zhu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: With the popularity of electric vehicles and the limited coverage of fixed charging stations, the charging demand of the EVs poses new challenges to grid operation and energy scheduling. Aiming at the problems of long waiting times for electric vehicle charging, low service rates of fixed charging piles, and long charging distances in urban areas, this paper first forecasts the charging load of electric vehicles. It then schedules mobile energy storage vehicles to provide charging based on the load forecasting results. Three scheduling algorithms are compared: a reinforcement learning-based algorithm, an adaptive large neighborhood search algorithm, and the Ant Colony Optimization algorithm. Through simulation experiments, the performance of the three algorithms in key indicators such as service rate, waiting time, total driving distance, and system efficiency is compared. The results show that the adaptive large neighborhood search algorithm performs best in most scenarios, particularly in service efficiency, waiting time, and operational control.

title: Scenario-Based Threshold Control of Energy Storage Systems for Peak Shaving
authors: Katharina Kaiser, Markus Kreft, Ludger Leenders, Angelos Selviaridis, Gabriela Hug
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Power flows in distribution grids are increasing due to the electrification of transportation and heating, and a growing share of distributed generation. Battery energy storage systems (BESSs) can reduce the stress on the grid and defer grid upgrades by shaving local power peaks. In this context, this work develops, implements, and validates a peak shaving algorithm for a real-world utility-owned BESS. First, it proposes and compares a robust and a stochastic formulation for computing the peak-shaving threshold in simulations. The results indicate that the robust formulation with five scenarios performs best for the given transformer station. In the subsequent real-world experiment, the approach achieves 55.6% of the ideal daily reduction with perfect foresight, demonstrating that the approach effectively shaves power peaks in practice.

title: Building AI-Ready DevOps Platforms: Operationalizing SageMaker and Bedrock in a Multi-Tenant Cloud
authors: Sandeep Reddy Bobbala
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Building AI-Ready DevOps Platforms towards the use of SageMaker and Bedrock the requirement of scalable, secure, and efficient DevOps platforms becomes some of the most relevant ones. Meddling with the creation and implementation of multi-tenant clouds such as A, B and C be represented models, the transformed features by using Principal Component Analysis (PCA) provides two high-propensity offerings such as minimizing a loss function and Gradient-based optimization. This document describes how to combine such services into a multi-tenant cloud setting so that to establish AI-compatible DevOps systems. To this integration we peep into cloud environment, implementation system and issues revolving around reliability score. The combination of theoretical discussion and real-world case studies will provide us with the chance to provide insights into the best practices of both creation and maintenance of AI-powered DevOps platforms. The outcomes suggest the functionality possibilities, i.e. the possibility of being more scaled, more resourceful, and streamlined processes of deploying models nationally. However, the privacy of data in the inference latency, Resource utilization and cost control of multi-tenant system such concerns are also discussed. Finally, the paper ends with a set of recommendations on how to overcome these obstacles and outline future research in the field of AI-enabled DevOps platforms.

title: Water Contamination Detection with Machine Learning and WSN
authors: Shalini S, Arpitha Vasudev, K Deepa Shree, Yamini G, Keerthana Shankar, Mangala H S
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Water scarcity and contamination are growing global challenges. They are caused by factors like over extraction, industrial growth, and climate change. Traditional water quality monitoring methods rely on periodic sampling and lab analysis. These methods are often slow and limited to specific areas, making them inadequate for spotting real-time contamination events. At the same time, falling groundwater levels endanger long-term water security. Existing forecasting methods do not have the accuracy and scalability needed for effective management. This research work introduces a framework that uses real-time sensing and data-driven analytics to improve water resource monitoring and prediction. Key water quality parameters are continuously measured with embedded Wireless Sensor Networks. The data is sent to a centralized cloud interface for visualisation and timely alerts. Meanwhile, historical groundwater level data is analysed using supervised machine learning algorithms, including Linear Regression, Random Forest, and Gradient Boosting. This analysis helps identify trends over time and forecast future availability. The proposed method shows high accuracy in both detecting anomalies and predictive modelling. It offers a strong and scalable solution for sustainable water resource management.

title: Influence of the Operating Point Determination of Power Flow-Controlling Devices on Congestion Management
authors: Muriel Krüger, Denise Götschenberg, Albert Moser
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper examines the influence of two different approaches for establishing the operating points of power flow- controlling devices (PFCDs) on congestion management. Therefore, the following two methods for setting the operating points of High Voltage Direct Current (HVDC) systems and Phase-shifting Transformers (PSTs) are presented: an AC angle control for HVDC systems and a pre-optimization approach for HVDC systems and PSTs. These two approaches are compared with a reference calculation wherein the PFCDs are initially set to zero. The key results indicate that both methods achieve savings of 35.3% to 39% in congestion management volume compared to the reference. Furthermore, these similar savings achieved by both approaches are attained despite significant differences in the resulting HVDC operating points, which in some hours even exhibit reversed flow directions.

title: Uncertainty Analysis of Relative Intrinsic Error for Non-invasive Tube Voltage Meter in Mammography Diagnosis
authors: Taiwei Shi, Siming Guo, Yang Yang, Ji Wang, Jianwei Huang, Bin Guo, Dehong Li, Zhijun Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: The accurate measurement of tube voltage plays a crucial role in the imaging quality of mammography diagnosis. Based on the measurement model and methodology of tube voltage, this paper evaluates the measurement uncertainty of the relative intrinsic error for a non-invasive tube voltage meter used in mammography diagnosis. The main sources of uncertainty components considered in the evaluation process include the standard measurement system, traceability of the reference standard, annual stability of the standard, instrument reading resolution, and measurement repeatability. By synthesizing these components according to their relationships, the uncertainty of the calibration result is determined, and the final expanded uncertainty is found to be 2.0%.

title: Research on Physical Simulation Method for Broadband Impedance of Power Cables Based on LC Cascaded Circuit
authors: Junhan Wu, Yefei Xu, Xiang Ren, Jilong Peng, Jianjun Yuan, Haoran Tian, Xueming Zhou, Enjia Tian, Kai Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: Broadband impedance spectroscopy technology is widely used for diagnosing power cable defects. However, constructing realistic cable testing platforms is challenging due to multiple voltage levels, long distances, and high costs. This results in insufficient hands-on training for personnel and a lack of calibration standards for testing instruments. This paper proposes a physical simulation method for cable broadband impedance based on LC cascade circuits: Following DL/T 838 and GB/T 3956 standards, the distributed parameters per unit length for 10kV to 500kV cables (including the main body, joints, and terminals) are calculated. Through discrete LC units and cascading, the broadband impedance of long-distance cables is reproduced. Taking a 500kV/50km XLPE cable as an example, 193 LC units (L=38.681μH, C=40.296nF) can simulate the 10kHz to 400kHz frequency band, with an equivalent bandwidth of 1.466kHz. The actual simulation device has been tested and proven to be feasible. The standardized laboratory platform established through this method supports talent training and instrument calibration, addressing core bottlenecks in operations and maintenance.

title: Benchmarking Neural Training Approaches for DCOPF: Supervised, Hybrid Physics-Informed, and Unsupervised Physics-Informed
authors: Mamoun Lyes Hennache, Maad Alowaifeer
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Neural networks offer a promising approach for accelerating solutions to the optimal power flow (OPF) problem. However, achieving predictions that are both optimal and feasible remains challenging; a trade-off typically exists between optimality and feasibility. Many approaches for training neural networks for this problem have been proposed. This paper benchmarks three neural training approaches for the DCOPF problem: a) a supervised approach, b) a hybrid physics-informed approach, and c) a fully unsupervised, physics-informed approach. All three approaches are evaluated under a unified pipeline across three IEEE test cases (case5, case57, case300), using consistent architectures, datasets, and metrics. Results show that the supervised approach offers good optimality but suffers from constraint violations. The unsupervised approach delivers relatively good feasibility but suffers in terms of optimality. The hybrid approach offers the most balanced trade-off between optimality and feasibility, making it a practical option.

title: Explainable AI in Healthcare: A Systematic Review of Methods for Interpretable Machine Learning
authors: Himanshu Pant, Garima Joshi, Bhupesh Rawat, Janmejay Pant, Devendra Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: The adoption of artificial intelligence (AI) in healthcare has led to breakthroughs in disease diagnosis, treatment planning, and patient monitoring. However, the black-box nature of many AI models poses a significant barrier to clinical adoption. Explainable AI (XAI) offers a solution by making model decisions transparent and interpretable to healthcare professionals. This systematic review examines the state-of-the-art XAI techniques applied in healthcare, categorizing them by model-specificity (intrinsic vs. post-hoc), data type (images, text, tabular), and clinical application. We analyze 125 peer-reviewed studies published between 2018 and 2024 across key medical domains. Our findings highlight trends, challenges, and future directions, emphasizing the need for user-centric and domain-specific interpretability. This review serves as a comprehensive reference for researchers and clinicians seeking to implement interpretable AI solutions in healthcare.

title: A Rule-based Algorithm for Cost Benefit Analysis of Household Photovoltaic Plant with Battery Energy Storage System
authors: Tomislav Markotić, Damir Šljivac, Danijel Topić, Matej Žnidarec, Zvonimir Šimić
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper presents a rule-based energy management algorithm designed to optimize the operation of battery energy storage systems (BESSs) in households by minimizing power exchange with the grid at the point of common coupling (PCC). The algorithm enables the evaluation of various system configurations, including different battery capacities, photovoltaic (PV) generation profiles, and electricity tariff structures. It also supports the implementation of a newly introduced four-tariff system, derived from Croatia’s existing dual-tariff model, while incorporating current feed-in compensation schemes. The methodology is validated through twelve case studies across two households, utilizing hourly load and PV generation data, battery parameters, and tariff structures. Finally, a sensitivity analysis assesses the impact of investment costs, electricity tariffs, and feed-in compensation rates on the return on investment (ROI) for BESS, focusing on Case study 5.

title: Judgment as Coordination: A Joint Systems View of Visualization Design Practice
authors: Paul C. Parsons, Arran Ridley
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: Professional visualization design has become an increasingly important area of inquiry, yet much of the field’s discourse remains anchored in researcher-centered contexts. Studies of design practice often focus on individual designers’ decisions and reflections, offering limited insight into the collaborative and systemic dimensions of professional work. In this paper, we propose a systems-level reframing of design judgment grounded in the coordination and adaptation that sustain progress amid uncertainty, constraint, and misalignment. Drawing on sustained engagement across multiple empirical studies—including ethnographic observation of design teams and qualitative studies of individual practitioners—we identify recurring episodes in which coherence was preserved not by selecting an optimal option, but by repairing alignment, adjusting plans, and reframing goals. We interpret these dynamics through the lens of Joint Cognitive Systems, which provide tools for analyzing how judgment emerges as a distributed capacity within sociotechnical activity. This perspective surfaces often-invisible work in visualization design and offers researchers a new conceptual vocabulary for studying how design activity is sustained in practice.

title: Feature Engineering and Gradient Boosting for Fine-Grained Power Forecasting in Smart Cities
authors: Hassan Rehan, Rana Ahmed Ali, Muhammad Bilal Shoaib Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE 19th International Conference on Open Source Systems and Technologies (ICOSST)
abstract: Proper short-term prediction of the energy is critical towards maximizing operational performance, minimizing energy wastage, and stability of the smart grid systems. This paper presents a proposed machine learning system controlling machine utilization on an electrical power base, using engineered long-term and statistical predictors along with a gradient boosting model to forecast predictable electrical power use with high resolution (10 minutes). The approach combines the attributes of calendar and roll statistics aggregates so that the model can adequately derive cyclical demand and short-run consumption dynamics. In contrast to time series or deep learning models, the proposed approach has interpretability, computational efficiency, and deployment preparedness as their priority. The model shows a high predictive accuracy in several metrics such as an R 2 of 0.88 and RMSE which is low thus showing that the model is effective at different load conditions. The findings point to the real-life relevance of interpretable, data-driven prediction systems in assisting real-time decision-making, demand response policies, and energy optimization in current urban infrastructures.

title: Preservation of the Mechanical Properties of Multimodal Tissue-Mimicking Phantoms
authors: S. Di Meo, D. Diaferia, A. Cannatà, G. Matrone, M. Pasian
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Tissue-mimicking phantoms are essential tools in the development of new biomedical equipment, enabling testing of new technologies in a controlled environment. A good tissuemimicking phantom should be low-cost, should not include toxic components and should have stable properties over time. An ideal phantom should also mimic multiple properties of the tissues simultaneously. This paper focuses on phantoms emulating both the dielectric and mechanical properties of human tissues, particularly of the breast. Specifically, a low-cost strategy based on the use of sunflower oil is investigated to preserve both dielectric and mechanical properties of phantoms (previously proposed by the authors to mimic the characteristics of the breast) over ten days. These phantoms, based on mixtures of water, sunflower seed oil, dish detergent, and gelatin, have already demonstrated the best technique for preserving dielectric properties for up to ten days, through complete oil immersion. In this work, oil preservation is further analyzed, particularly for maintaining the mechanical properties of the phantoms. Mechanical properties (stress-strain curves from which Young's modulus was calculated) of different samples emulating the properties of neoplastic and low-density healthy tissue were measured. Results show that oil is a cost-effective and safe candidate for preserving both the dielectric and mechanical properties of tissue-mimicking phantoms.

title: A Novel Detection Method of Rail Insulation Defects based on FFC-Swin-Transformer
authors: Feilong Liu, Wei Liu, Shuangrui Yang, Zhuoxin Yang, Yuning Tang, Songyuan Li
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: As urban rail transit grows, stray current seriously threatens the safety of power systems and oil/gas pipelines. Rail-to-earth insulation the key to control stray current. Aiming at the problem that it is difficult to detect and locate the rail insulation defects of DC traction power supply system, a novel rail insulation defect detection method based on the FFC-Swin-Transformer is proposed. By establishing a four-layer "catenary-rail-SCCN-earth" equivalent circuit model and integrating multi-train operation conditions, a rail potential dataset is efficiently generated via parallel computing. Time-domain signals of rail potential are converted to frequency-domain features using Fourier transform, and the fused time-frequency information is fed into an improved FFC-Swin-Transformer network to achieve accurate detection of rail insulation states. Experimental results show that after training on 22496 sample groups, the model achieves a test accuracy of 82.95%, effectively identifying section insulation defects and exhibiting promising engineering application potential.

title: Decentralized Orchestration Framework for Distributed AI Deployments across Fluid Computing Environments
authors: Diego Cajaraville-Aboy, Ana Fernández-Vilas, Rebeca P. Díaz-Redondo, Manuel Fernández-Veiga
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: Fluid Computing has emerged as a promising paradigm for enhancing massive and heterogeneous resource management across the Cloud-to-Edge continuum for Internet of Things (IoT) and artificial intelligence (AI) applications. Despite its advantages, research into the optimal deployment of distributed applications across fluid scenarios remains scarce, and existing centralized frameworks cannot exploit emerging AI-native features nor model realistic multi-domain deployment scenarios. This paper presents an innovative provider-based architecture for the optimal orchestration of distributed AI services in fluid environments under 6G network capabilities. The proposed hybrid solution includes robust and scalable decentralized orchestration for the placement of cross-provider workloads without a central broker, as well as leveraging autonomous decision-making devices through distributed task offloading techniques. The proposal was tailored to a Decentralized Federated Learning deployment, serving as a use case in settings with strict privacy and security requirements. This approach was adopted to illustrate the viability of the proposal by deploying large distributed AI services in 6G-like networks.

title: TLV-HGNN: Thinking Like a Vertex for Memory-Efficient HGNN Inference
authors: Dengke Han, Duo Wang, Mingyu Yan, Xiaochun Ye, Dongrui Fan
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Heterogeneous graph neural networks (HGNNs) excel at processing heterogeneous graph data and are widely applied in critical domains. In HGNN inference, the neighbor aggregation stage is the primary performance determinant, yet it suffers from two major sources of memory inefficiency. First, the commonly adopted per-semantic execution paradigm stores intermediate aggregation results for each semantic prior to semantic fusion, causing substantial memory expansion. Second, the aggregation process incurs extensive redundant memory accesses, including repeated loading of target vertex features across semantics and repeated accesses to shared neighbors due to crosssemantic neighborhood overlap. These inefficiencies severely limit scalability and reduce HGNN inference performance. In this work, we first propose a semantics-complete execution paradigm from a vertex perspective that eliminates per-semantic intermediate storage and redundant target vertex accesses. Building on this paradigm, we design TVL-HGNN, a reconfigurable hardware accelerator optimized for efficient aggregation. In addition, we introduce a vertex grouping technique based on crosssemantic neighborhood overlap, with hardware implementation, to reduce redundant accesses to shared neighbors. Experimental results demonstrate that TVL-HGNN achieves average speedups of 7.85× and 1.41× over the NVIDIA A100 GPU and the state-of-the-art HGNN accelerator HiHGNN, respectively, while reducing energy consumption by 98.79 % and 32.61 %.

title: Enhancing Acoustic Data Analysis with the Burg Method: Results and Implications
authors: Meshram Devendra M, Pushpa Mala S, Sadasivan S
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: The Burg Maximum Entropy Method (MEM) is a parametric technique employed in spectrum analysis, which was utilized in this study for the estimation of acoustic intensity. This study aimed to investigate the distinctiveness of integrating Burg MEM with acoustic vector sensor (AVS) measurements and to demonstrate the efficacy of MEM in extracting significant spectral features from complex acoustic environments. For this study, ship-based measurements of the acoustic signature of a low-flying platform over the sea were selected for the analysis.

title: Liver Tumor Classification in CT Images Using Prognostic Assimilate Learning Classifier (PALC)
authors: D. Anandkumar, S. John Justin Thangaraj, C. Alamelu, M. Vallikkannu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is one of the most prevalent and deadliest cancers worldwide, largely due to its asymptomatic development and difficulty in early detection. Accurate classification of liver tumors as benign or malignant is critical for selecting appropriate therapy and determining prognosis. Computed Tomography (CT) is widely used for liver tumor detection because it generates high-resolution cross-sectional anatomical images. However, manual classification still poses challenges due to inter-observer disagreement and the complex morphology of tumors. In this paper, we propose a novel classification method based on the Prognostic Assimilate Learning Classifier (PALC), a robust feature-based approach that enhances diagnostic accuracy while reducing computational cost. The proposed framework consists of four main stages: Image pre-processing using a Gaussian filter to reduce noise, Tumor region segmentation using the Linear Iterative Clustering Algorithm (LICA), Texture feature extraction using a subspace method and Gray Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM) descriptors, Final classification using the proposed PALC model. Validation was conducted on a set of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0 ~ C T}$</tex> images annotated by a panel of clinical experts using experimental validation. The PALC model demonstrated strong generalization performance, achieving a classification accuracy of 97.5%, precision of 96.8%, recall of 97.2%, and a very low false classification rate of 1.4%. The average processing time of 13.3 ms per image on the test set suggests that the proposed method is suitable for real-time clinical application. Comparative analysis with traditional classifiers such as Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Principal Component Analysis (PCA) further confirms the efficiency and scalability of the PALC model. Overall, the proposed approach offers a practical and reliable tool for automatic liver cancer classification in biomedical imaging systems.

title: CSFS: Enhancing Industrial Threat Detection Performance with Covariate Shift Adaptation and Shap-Powered Feature Selection
authors: Tuyen T. Nguyen, Hung T. Nguyen, Minh D. Nguyen, Hai H. Le, Hoa N. Nguyen
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: Industrial control systems are the backbone of critical infrastructure, yet they are increasingly becoming targets of sophisticated cyberattacks. AI-based threat detection systems are a promising approach, but their performance often degrades significantly in real-world operational environments due to data drift, particularly covariate shift. To address this challenge, the paper proposes a comprehensive and adaptable threat detection framework. The novelty of the method lies in two main points: (1) a hybrid feature selection technique called CSFS (Covariate Shift Adaptation and SHAP-powered Feature Selection), which combines adaptability to data distribution changes and the interpretability of SHAP to select the most stable and effective features; and (2) a robust ensemble architecture based on weighted voting of multiple AI models to maximize accuracy and enhance resilience against adversarial attacks. The proposed framework has been tested thoroughly using two key datasets for industrial networks: Modbus/TCP and IEC 60870-5-104. The results show that our method not only significantly improves detection accuracy but also maintains stable performance, outperforming state-of-the-art methods when faced with changes in the network environment.

title: A Preliminary Study for a Compensated Large Spherical Reflector Antenna Using Sub-Reflectarrays
authors: L. Olmi, R. Nesti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: The radio telescopes with the largest collecting areas, the Arecibo (no longer operational) and FAST telescopes, have a spherical main reflector, mainly because of its ease of construction and its inherent wide-angle beam scanning capability in terms of the number of beam-widths scanned, while maintaining the integrity of the radiation pattern. The inherent spherical aberration, however, causes considerable performance degradation. These telescopes therefore use different methods to compensate for the spherical aberration, but they both require complex and expensive (moving) mechanical components. This article extends to large spherical reflectors a method to compensate for the spherical aberration based on the use of sub-reflectarrays. A microstrip reflectarray is a planar, inexpensive, passive device with unique capabilities of controlling reflection phases. By exploiting this property, a reflectarray can be employed as an auxiliary phase corrector, and the phase errors caused by spherical aberration can be compensated. In this article we discuss and simulate the operation of a sub-reflectarray on an Arecibo-like antenna at X-band, and then show that great performance improvement can be achieved for both no scan and moderate electronic scan cases.

title: GPU Side-Channel Attack Resilience: NIST 2.0 Risk Management and Governance Strategies Assessment
authors: Shreekant Salotagi, Nelson Lungu, Mahendra H N, Bibhuti Bhusan Dash, Tanvir H Sardar, Sudhansu Shekhar Patra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: GPU side-channel resilience is essential for data-intensive and high-performance computation. Modern systems increasingly use GPUs; therefore, strong cybersecurity is needed to secure sensitive data and ensure computational reliability. This research examines GPU side-channel attacks— including timing, power analysis, and cache attacks—and integrates the NIST Cybersecurity Framework (CSF) 2.0 risk management and governance concepts to meet the important requirement for security. A safe and reliable shader execution architecture to prevent these vulnerabilities is defined. This unique approach targets GPU side-channel vulnerabilities with cutting-edge countermeasures and math. It is shown that NIST CSF 2.0 risk-aware management and adaptive governance may build resilience. Quarterly or more frequent security updates to boost defences against changing threats may be needed.

title: Comparative Evaluation of Random Forest and KNN on Privacy Preserving Synthetic Medical Data Generated By CTGAN
authors: Nisha K, P.Joyce Beryl Princess
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Privacy concerns in healthcare data sharing have driven the adoption of generative models for synthetic data creation. To ensure both statistical fidelity and privacy preservation, the Conditional Tabular GAN (CTGAN) is used in this study to create synthetic medical records using the Pima Indians Diabetes dataset. We compare Random Forest (RF) and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) classifiers that are evaluated on actual medical records and trained on synthetic data. Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) tests are used to evaluate privacy, accuracy and ROC-AUC are used to examine usefulness, and classifiers that can distinguish between actual and synthetic data are used to investigate detectability. According to experimental data, RF outperformed KNN in the synthetic-to-real transfer task, achieving an accuracy of around 0.79 and a ROC-AUC of 0.86, while KNN acquired an accuracy of approximately 0.74 and a ROC-AUC of 0.80. Tests of detectability showed that the ability to differentiate between actual and synthetic data was still only moderately successful (RF accuracy ~0.83, KNN accuracy ~0.78), suggesting a trade-off between privacy and utility. These results show that CTGAN-generated synthetic data can facilitate trustworthy machine learning in the medical field, with RF providing more robustness than KNN.

title: A Broadband Miniature TEM Cell for IC EMC Measurement over 8 GHz
authors: Chenghao Lan, Yusheng Hu, Yaoquan Ou
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Advanced Interconnects (WAI)
abstract: The upper limited operating frequency of the traditional transverse electromagnetic (TEM) cell for integrated circuit (IC) electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) test is only about 1 GHz. With the ever-increasing frequency of IC or other electronic devices, higher operating frequency TEM cell is required. In this paper, an modified miniature TEM cell as well as the measuring method are presented. The overall structure of the proposed miniature TEM cell is similar to the traditional TEM cell, but its bottom has a rectangular aperture whose size is of the same order of magnitude as the device under test (DUT), or is completely open. The miniature TEM cell is directly covered on the IC of the working printed circuit board (PCB) for EMC testing. The design of the measuring device is described in detail, and whose electromagnetic performances are analyzed by numerical method. Since the size of the TEM cell is significantly reduced, its operating frequency can reach above 8 GHz. In addition, there is no need to make a special PCB board, and online measurement is realized.

title: Knowledge-Data Dual-Guidance and Progressive Transfer: A Novel Method for Cross-Condition Fault Diagnosis of Diesel Engines
authors: Yanzhuo Lin, Yu Wang, Mingquan Zhang, Xiangze Li, Ruijie Hu, Cheng Zhu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Product Compliance Engineering - Asia (ISPCE-ASIA)
abstract: To address the ‘domain drift’ issue causing degraded diagnostic model performance under variable operating conditions in diesel engines, this paper proposes an interpretable transfer learning diagnostic framework. Through an innovative four-layer feature engineering system, this framework deeply integrates mechanistic knowledge with data-driven methods, effectively tackling the challenge of ‘operating condition-fault coupling’. Core contributions include: (1) a knowledge-data dual-driven multi-level feature engineering approach embedding physical knowledge into the feature space, enhancing model robustness and interpretability; (2) a progressive transfer strategy based on Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD), guiding knowledge transfer sequence by quantifying domain similarity to effectively avoid negative transfer; (3) A unique feature mapping mechanism transforming high-dimensional engineered features into six-dimensional physical features with explicit physical meaning, achieving transparency in model decision-making. Through rigorous leave-one-out cross-validation, this framework elevated the average diagnostic accuracy across diverse operating conditions from 71.94% to 96.24%, while significantly reducing performance fluctuations. This demonstrates its efficacy, generalisation capability, and interpretability within complex scenarios.

title: Deep Learning-Based Classification Framework for Detection of Insomia Sleep Disorder
authors: Ippili Mouneshha, N Siva Naga Malleswari, Kondaveeti Rohini
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Sleep disorders particularly insomnia has significantly impact mental and physical health. Traditional diagnostic methods like polysomnography (PSG) are resource-intensive and rely on manual evaluation, limiting efficiency. By focusing on CAP Phase B, a critical recovery phase during sleep, the model enhances diagnostic precision, capturing subtle transitions and disruptions associated with sleep disorders. To tackle this issue, we propose a deep learning approach-based classification framework utilizing multimodal physiological signals EEG, EMG, and ECG. Three hybrid model like CNNLSTM, CNN-BiGRU, and CNN-BiLSTM are developed to enhance spatial and temporal feature extraction. The models are trained and evaluated using the CAP Sleep Database from PhysioNet. Among them, the CNN-BiLSTM model attains a top classification accuracy of (99.99%) outperforming CNN-BiGRU (96.69%) and CNN LSTM (94.46%). The integration of convolutional and bidirectional networks significantly improves detection accuracy, making the proposed method a promising tool for automated insomnia diagnosis.

title: Field Study of Network Impedance in the Range from 2 kHz to 9 kHz in Japan
authors: Hiro Nakayama, Naotaka Okada
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Discussions are currently underway regarding harmonic limits for the range from 2 kHz to 9 kHz, which are not included in the IEC standard but will be standardized in the future. For this discussion, it is important to evaluate harmonic currents and consequent voltage distortion based on the network impedance, which includes not only the distribution line but also the effect from loads in operation, such as consumer equipment connected to the same distribution line. The reasonable adoption of international standards requires basic understanding of network impedance from 2 kHz to 9 kHz in Japan. This paper presents the field study of network impedance in Japan. In this study, the network impedance seen from the 100 V socket at 58 sites in service areas of seven distribution system operators (DSOs) was measured. The cumulative 95% values calculated from the measurement results fall below the impedance of the single-phase artificial mains network (AMN) for the 230 V systems currently discussed in the IEC, within the frequency range from 2 kHz to 9 kHz.

title: A Typology of Data Concepts and Contexts in Clinician-Patient Communication
authors: Sarah Dunn, Areti Manataki, Tara Capel, Bach Inria
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: This paper presents a typology of concepts and contexts to inform the design of medical data visualizations for clinician-patient communication. As the accessibility, ubiquity and complexity of personal medical data grows, so does the need for patients to understand and interpret it correctly. Based on interviews with 19 healthcare professionals and analysis of current patient communication materials, our typology captures i) the diverse types of medical data communicated; ii) the features clinicians need patients to recognise and understand about these data; iii) contextual information required; iv) motivation for communicating data to patients; and v) current common visualization techniques. In doing so it identifies and defines the key dimensions of data-communication scenarios relevant to data visualizers working with patient data. We apply the typology to classify real world clinical scenarios and through doing so, illustrate how the typology can inform data visualization when designing communication aids for clinicians.

title: Speak to Write Assistive Device for People with Writing Disability
authors: Nishanth Aithal, Leena Chandrashekar, Vipula Singh, Sanjana Aradhaya A, Sai Pavan G
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Assistive writing aids include hand grips, digital pens and specialized keyboards, while high-tech tools include robotic arms, eye movement-controlled device, speech-to-text software, and many more. Even while each has advantages and disadvantages of its own, an assistive technology that can translate speech into text and the hand writing that resembles those of a human is necessary. In this paper, we propose a realtime, Speak to Write Assistive Device (SWAD) which is portable and compact. The device has a Raspberry Pi processor interfaced with microphone, speaker, pen mounting assembly, motors and control buttons. The processor is programmed to connect with AWS Cloud for the Transcribe service. The AWS Transcribe cloud service incorporates for noise or echo cancellation and linguistic correctness features. A feedback mechanism for ensuring accuracy is taken care by the record and play feature of the assistive device. The performance of the device is tested with a sample voice message and hand written document is produced.

title: Impact of storage systems participating in energy markets on distribution grids
authors: Lucas Lafaye, Rémy Rigo-Mariani, Marie-Cécile Alvarez-Herault, Vincent Debusschere
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper studies the impact of a battery storage system connected to a distribution source substation and participating in the Day-Ahead (DA) or Frequency Containment Reserve (FCR) energy markets. The supply of these products results in charge/discharge power profiles added to the natural profiles of the source substations to which these storage systems are connected. These profiles are uncorrelated with the electrical uses initially present in the connection zone and can therefore lead to unexpected technical constraints. This paper thus quantifies the impact of storage facilities operating on wholesale markets and connected to the distribution grid through a selection of metrics. In particular, the number of tap changes of the on-load tap changer is significantly impacted by the participation of the source-connected storage operator in the DA market, which is less the case with FCR.

title: Interface for Operating a Parts Inspection Machine in the Automotive Industry
authors: Isaías Mendes Machado, Rafael de Magalhães Dias Frinhani, Rodrigo Duarte Seabra, Lina Garcés
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: This work presents the development of a human-machine interface (HMI) for a parts inspection machine in the automotive industry. The current application is obsolete and unstable and needs to meet several business functional and cybersecurity requirements. Faced with the cost of proprietary solutions, this research aims to develop a low-cost and customized HMI for operating the machine and meeting new requirements. The interface proposed adopts free software for creating screens, data persistence, and communication with automation elements. The validation of the solution regarding usability and user satisfaction occurred in simulated and real environments. The results show the acceptance of the new HMI, considered more efficient and robust than the legacy one. This case exemplifies the viability of free software for developing low-cost automation solutions, contributing to introducing Industry 4.0 concepts in the company studied.

title: Energy Planning the Efficient Way: A Multi-Criteria Tool Supporting EE1st-Compliant Regional Energy Planning
authors: George Konstantopoulos, Sofia Natalia Boemi, George Yiannakis, Vlasios Oikonomou, Andriana Stavrakaki, John Psarras
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: Regional energy planning is pivotal for advancing both national and EU climate objectives, particularly amidst escalating climate challenges and the urgent need for a sustainable energy transition. Energy efficiency is central to achieving the EU's climate ambition which is reaffirmed in the recently revised Energy Efficiency Directive (EU/2023/1791). The directive strengthens the legislative framework for the application of the “Energy Efficiency First” (EE1st) principle, which mandates that cost-effective energy efficiency measures should be prioritized over supply-side investments in energy generation and infrastructure. Despite its policy prominence, embedding the EE1st principle into regional and local planning remains complex. Key challenges include amongst others: lack of awareness and understanding, and lack of technical knowledge and competence. To support this policy-to-practice transition, the REGIO1st project - co-funded by the LIFE Programme - has developed the REGIO1st Planning Framework and accompanying tools to assist regions in aligning their energy strategies with the EE1st principle. Cornerstone to this framework is the Regio1st Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) tool. This tool assists planners in evaluating and prioritizing energy interventions using a transparent, evidence-based methodology grounded in environmental, technical, economic, and social criteria. It also facilitates structured stakeholder feedback, enhancing legitimacy and acceptance of energy strategies. Currently being piloted in six European regions, the REGIO1st Framework is tailored to accommodate diverse regional conditions and planning cultures. This paper presents the conceptual foundations and methodological design of the REGIO1st MCDA tool, exploring its role in facilitating the application of the EE1st principle within a participatory decision-making context. Early insights from pilot implementation are shared, highlighting practical benefits, encountered barriers, and recommendations for wider adoption and refinement.

title: Dynamic Matrix Headlight Illumination Strategy for Robust Object Detection in Automated Vehicles
authors: Nathalie Müller, Mirko Waldner, Torsten Bertram
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: The contribution at hand presents a novel, selective dynamic sampling-based control strategy for matrix headlights to enhance the camera object detection in automated driving systems. The approach is based on continuously sampling the illuminated environment with different luminous intensity distributions created by the matrix headlights. By this, the neural network for camera object detection identifies the most suitable illumination for the current situation to detect traffic objects optimally. The approach is applicable in real-time in dynamic environments, avoiding flickering for human road users and working without prior knowledge of the environment or the objects. The hardware requirements are limited to cameras and matrix headlights, allowing for widespread use. The approach is evaluated across diverse dynamic scenarios, generating 4,130 samples for robust statistical analysis. The results in the simulation show that the novel approach outperforms human-focused luminous intensity distributions with a mean average precision of 0.88 compared to human-focused luminous intensity distributions like low beam, with only a mean average precision of 0.31. In challenging situations, e.g., larger distances to the objects, the approach improves the mean average precision by 37.5% compared to the best-scoring classic luminous intensity distribution high beam. Even when the ego vehicle is driving, the novel approach achieves a mean average precision of between 0.75 and 0.85, outperforming all other luminous intensity distributions and significantly increasing the safety of automated vehicles.

title: Advantages and FDTD Integration of Focused Beams for RCS Computations
authors: Joseph E. Diener, Atef Z. Elsherbeni, Veysel Demir
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Electromagnetic scattering simulations are essential for radar cross-section (RCS) analysis, stealth technology, and remote sensing applications. Traditionally, uniform plane waves (UPWs) have been used as incident fields in numerical simulations. However, UPWs do not completely reveal RCS features of complex shaped targets. We aim to highlight the advantages of using focused beams such as Gaussian, Laguerre-Gaussian (LG) [2], and Bessel beam in scattering simulations and discuss their integration into the FiniteDifference Time-Domain (FDTD) method for accurate RCS computation of large targets.

title: A Novel Approach for Facial Emotion Recognition: Deep CNN Feature Extraction Combined with ML Models
authors: Aryan Gahlaut, Chirag Rana, Anil Singh Parihar, Sumit Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Facial expression recognition (FER) serves as a fundamental component of human-computer interaction, showing its influence on computing, and behavioral analysis. The proposed work here recommends a hybrid architecture of deep learning model with machine learning based classifiers to enhance emotion classification using the FER2013 dataset of 48×48 grayscale face images for seven emotions. Extensive preprocessing operations such as normalization, CLAHE-based contrast stretching, and data augmentation are carried out, followed by class balancing using Random Oversampling and SMOTE. A deep CNN is trained to acquire deep features, and the features from its dense layer are again processed with SelectKBest for reducing the dimensions. These characteristics are subsequently ensembled through machine learning based classifiers like Random Forest, XGBoost, and LightGBM for classification pupose. Experimental testing reveals that the hybrid CNN + XGBoost model delivers better performance, with accuracy of 72.96% for oversampling on training data only and 86.69% for oversampling on the entire dataset. Macro-averaged precision of 0.7446, recall of 0.7106, and F1-score of 0.7243 are also enhanced to 0.8670, 0.8669, and 0.8667, respectively. These results show that a hybrid deep learning-ensemble method combined with proper management of class imbalance has the ability to greatly enhance the robustness of FER systems and provides very powerful potential for real-world emotion-aware applications.

title: Drone-based Agricultural Weed Detection and Growth Monitoring
authors: Devarasetti Shivamani, Shaik Mohammad Eliyas, V. Nagamani, V Nagendra, V Sankarnath, A.N.P.P. Anantha Lakshmi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Crop health and weed infestation are essential issues in contemporary agriculture as they affect yield, cost and sustainability. Conventional forms of weed detection and growth measurement are laborious, prone to errors and they cannot offer timely interventions. Current automated systems, despite their effectiveness with certain conditions, tend to be scaled down in size, have reduced accuracy in a wide range of environments and are not integrated with crop monitoring. To fill these research gaps, this paper introduces a new drone-based precision agriculture system integrating high-resolution images, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) to detect weeds, the use of the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) to assess crop health, and the use of the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) to make growth predictions. The suggested system had a weed detection accuracy of 92 percent with a F1-score of 0.92 and a stable prediction of NDVI based growth with a mean absolute error of 0.03. Web interface-based real-time visualization also provided improved decision-making to farmers. This is because of the enhanced efficiency, reliability and sustainability in utilizing the weed detection and growth monitoring system as a single system resulting in minimizing herbicide usage and resource optimization in precision farming.

title: Modeling the Evolution of Plasma-Fragments Clouds from Hypervelocity Impacts for Remote Characterization of Small Space Debris
authors: Yun Zhang, Nilton O. Renno, Cheng Li, Mojtaba Akhavan-Tafti, Tsige Atilaw
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Current ground-based observation systems face significant challenges in detecting space debris and meteoroids smaller than 10 cm. Hypervelocity impacts (HVIs) of these small objects at relative speeds ranging of 1–1 5 km/s for debris and 11-73 km/s for meteoroids, pose serious risks to spacecraft [1]. These collisions involve complex phase transitions and ionization processes that convert substantial amounts of kinetic energy into heat and electromagnetic radiation. To investigate these effects, we performed numerical simulations of hypervelocity collisions and the subsequent evolution of the plasma-fragments clouds generated by the collisions. Our results indicate that HVIs generate rapidly evolving plasma clouds that emit nonthermal electromagnetic radiation across a broad spectrum with characteristics that vary based on the impact velocity and the material composition of both the projectile and the target. The high-temperature droplets and solid fragments generated by the collisions emit thermal radiation in infrared and optical bands. Our link budget analyses suggest that both the thermal and non-thermal emissions from HVIs can be leveraged for remote, ground-based, detection and characterization of small, otherwise untrackable, space debris and meteoroids.

title: Lightweight Deep Learning Framework for Energy-Efficient Intrusion Detection in Edge Computing Environments
authors: Mala K, Pooja Shree A R, Bharath Kumar Chakrad, Chandana E, Tejalakshmi T S, Varun H M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: This research presents a novel energy-efficient Intrusion Detection System (IDS) specifically designed for resource-constrained edge computing environments. The proposed framework integrates Separable Convolutional Neural Networks (SeparableConv1D), Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE), structured pruning, and Quantization-Aware Training (QAT) to achieve optimal performance with minimal computational overhead. Experimental evaluation on the NSL-KDD dataset demonstrates 93% accuracy with a precision-recall AUC of 0.8859 and ROC-AUC of 0.9129. The optimized model contains only 94,408 parameters (92,872 trainable), representing a significant reduction in computational complexity while maintaining high detection performance. The framework addresses class imbalance issues inherent in cybersecurity datasets and enables real-time threat detection on edge devices with limited processing capabilities.

title: Early Stage Skin cancer Diagnosis with RBFNs: A Feature – based Segmentation and Classification using Deep Learning
authors: P.Rama, Pravin R. Kshirsagar, R Thiagarajan, Tan Kuan Tak, Sivaneasan Bala Krishnan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Skin cancer is one of the most common forms of cancer in today's society. It is easier to treat if diagnosed in the early stages. Evaluating clinical and tissue samples are quite labor intensive and costly and runs the risk of human error. In this paper, to examine an Automated Skin Cancer Detection Using Radial Basis Function Networks (RBFNs) and describe in detail the processes and methodologies employed, as well as classification and data pre-processing in the context of RBFNs, including the various stages of feature extraction, segmentation, and classification. In the RBF preprocessing steps, data is normalized and noise is removed using RBMs, and reduced in dimensions. During feature extraction, the lesion's irregularity, coloration, and diameter were analyzed. A Fuzzy Clustering Segmentation method improves accuracy to a great extent by differentiating lesions from the skin that covers them. RBFN classification is based on the extracted features, and this method has proven most effective in dealing with complex, nonlinear classification problems, theorized by many to problematic to solve. Out of a total of 4500 dermoscopic images, the identified technique, when evaluated, surpassed conventional classifiers such as Convoluted Neural Networks (CNNs) and Support Vector Machines (SVMs) with an accuracy of 92.7%.

title: The Missing S: Securing the Model Context Protocol
authors: Michelle Hamjaya, Anthony Sai Richardo, Darren Leonard, Franz Adeta Junior
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ICoAIT)
abstract: The Model Context Protocol (MCP) standardizes AI models’ integration and interaction with external tools and resources.
