However, its rapid adoption, particularly in allowing custom server and tool development, introduces significant security vulnerabilities, with command injection emerging as a dominant threat, accounting for 43% of observed vulnerabilities in popular MCP servers. While existing research has highlighted these dangers, focused investigation into their detection and mitigation, specifically within the MCP environment, remains limited. This research addresses this gap by evaluating the performance of five transformer-based models, such as BERT, RoBERTa, ALBERT, DistilBERT, and ELECTRA, for detecting command injection attacks in MCP environments. The dataset for this study was curated from real-world MCP server usage, public prompt injection datasets, and custom-created examples specifically designed to cover diverse MCP-specific command injection attack vectors. Our findings found that transformer-based models demonstrate an exceptional performance against command injection attacks, with all evaluated models achieving validation accuracy exceeding 98.8%. Among these models, DistilBERT emerged as the highest performing model, achieving 99.92% validation and test accuracy. By integrating real-world MCP usage with a broad spectrum of targeted attack vectors, the dataset established a robust foundation for training models capable of effectively mitigating command injection threats within the MCP ecosystem.

title: Attention-Enhanced DQN Scheduling for Multi-Link Devices in Synchronous N-STR Wi-Fi 7 Networks
authors: Ahmed Abdelreheem, Cormac Sreenan, Ahmed H. Zahran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: WiFi 7 IEEE (802.11be) introduced Multi-Link Operation (MLO) that enables its devices to communicate over multiple links to support evolving latency-sensitive and high-throughput applications. However, MLO requires advanced scheduling algorithms to optimize the operation. This paper models WiFi 7 scheduling as a constrained Markov Decision Process that optimizes throughput, delay, latency and fairness while capturing access constraints and traffic dynamics. We also develop an attention-enhanced Rainbow Deep Q-Network (DQN) scheduling framework that combines multi-head attention, distributional Q-learning, and prioritized experience replay. Simulation results show up to 2.3× throughput improvement, 6× delay reduction, and marked gains in packet drop rate and spectral efficiency over baseline Round Robin scheduling.

title: Optimization of the High-Speed Train Grounding System Under Lightning Strike Conditions
authors: Chongxuan Yang, Chuan Lin, Anyong Qing
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: As China's high-speed railway network has surpassed 42,000 kilometers in total length, operational challenges including harmonic distortions, voltage fluctuations, and grounding loop currents have raised considerable concerns regarding power system stability and train operational safety. This study focuses on the optimization of the grounding system in high-speed trains to improve operational safety and reliability. By developing an equivalent circuit model of the "catenary-train-track" system, simulation analyses are carried out to evaluate the impact of various grounding configurations under lightning strike conditions. An improved Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO) is applied to optimize grounding resistance parameters, achieving an effective balance between peak overvoltage and overcurrent. The results demonstrate that the proposed optimization approach can mitigate overvoltage and overcurrent issues under the tested operational scenario.

title: Can Experiencing AI-Driven Service Bolster Trust and Engagement in E-Commerce
authors: Muhamad Arief Erdavit, Nicholas Salim
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: The rapid expansion of AI-powered e-commerce has reshaped how consumers interact with digital platforms. This study investigates how AI service experience defined by responsiveness, empathy, transparency, and personalization impacts customer trust and engagement. Drawing on signal theory and relationship marketing, we propose that trust partially mediates this relationship. Using data from 451 Indonesian e-commerce users and analyzed via WarpPLS, results confirm that positive AI experiences significantly enhance trust and engagement. Trust emerges as a critical psychological mechanism, converting efficient AI interactions into emotional and behavioral commitment. These findings offer practical implications for designing AI systems that foster transparency and emotional intelligence in digital commerce.

title: Policy-Aware Generative AI for Safe, Auditable Data Access Governance
authors: Shames Al Mandalawi, Muzakkiruddin Ahmed Mohammed, Hendrika Maclean, Mert Can Cakmak, John R. Talburt
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: Enterprises need access decisions that satisfy least privilege, comply with regulations, and remain auditable. We present a policy aware controller that uses a large language model (LLM) to interpret natural language requests against written policies and metadata, not raw data. The system, implemented with Google Gemini 2.0 Flash, executes a six-stage reasoning framework (context interpretation, user validation, data classification, business purpose test, compliance mapping, and risk synthesis) with early hard policy gates and deny by default. It returns APPROVE, DENY, CONDITIONAL together with cited controls and a machine readable rationale. We evaluate on fourteen canonical cases across seven scenario families using a privacy preserving benchmark. Results show Exact Decision Match improving from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 / 14$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$13 / 14(92.9 \%)$</tex> after applying policy gates, DENY recall rising to 1.00, False Approval Rate on must-deny families dropping to 0, and Functional Appropriateness and Compliance Adherence at 14/14. Expert ratings of rationale quality are high, and median latency is under one minute. These findings indicate that policy constrained LLM reasoning, combined with explicit gates and audit trails, can translate human readable policies into safe, compliant, and traceable machine decisions.

title: Investigation of the Impact of Constant Magnetic Field on Fixed Balise
authors: Meng Tianxu, Bai Yingjie, Gao Zhiqiang, Liu Dong, Ding Geng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: The balise transmission system is a point-type information transmission system that facilitates the transmission of information from ground equipment to on-board equipment through balise.The balise can transmit either fixed (fixed balise) or variable (controlled balise) uplink data to the on-board equipment. However, under specific environments, balise may be exposed to strong magnetic fields, such as in high-speed maglev systems where low-frequency magnetic fields are the primary form of electromagnetic emission. To address this issue, this paper analyzes the performance degradation of fixed balise in a constant magnetic field environment and proposes corresponding anti-interference methods, providing a reference for optimizing the immunity of fixed balise.

title: Design and Analysis of MEMS Micro-electromagnetic Actuator Based on Genetic Algorithm
authors: Mo Yang, Weirong Nie, Baolin Cheng, He Wang, Yun Cao, Jiong Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: To realize relatively large displacements of MEMS micro-actuators, a micro-electromagnetic actuator made based on deep reactive ion etching(DRIE) and MEMS-casting process is presented. Single and double layer micro-electromagnetic actuators are proposed and theoretically analyzed. According to the application requirements of the coils, a multi-objective optimization based on the modified NSGA-H genetic algorithm was carried out to obtain the structural parameters of the micro-electromagnetic actuator. Numerical simulations were then performed to analyze the magnetic induction intensity of a single-layer coil without a core, a double-layer coil without a core, and a single-layer coil with a core. The variation of the attraction of each coil to the permanent magnet with distance was also analyzed. The results show that increasing the number of coil layers improves the driving capability of the coil when there is no core. With the addition of a core, driving capability is significantly enhanced compared to having no core.

title: A Web-Based Food Ordering Platform- Quickbites using MERN Stack
authors: Darshan R, Arati Chabukswar, J Ranjith Vivek, Sneha B N, Sashi Kiran M, Swimpy Pahuja
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: A web-based food ordering platform is designed to enhance the dining experience on university campus. Built on the MERN stack (MongoDB, Express.js, React.js, and Node.js), which addresses challenges like long wait times and operational inefficiencies. The system offers role-based authentication for students and stall owners. Students can browse menus, place orders, customize meals, view nutritional details, and make secure online payments. Stall owners can manage menus, track orders in real time using Socket.io, and analyze sales trends. The platform integrates secure payment gateways to support various payment methods like UPI and cards. Additionally, it enables preordering and scheduling orders, ensuring convenience for users during peak hours. By streamlining operations, reducing queues, and providing nutritional transparency, the platform improves efficiency, fosters healthier eating habits, and enhances user satisfaction for both students and stall owners.

title: Antenna Simulation Verification for Low-Frequency Radio Astronomy
authors: L. Kalkman, D.S. Prinsloo, M.J. Arts
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This paper describes the verification of the noise performance of a low-frequency active antenna, without a ground plane, simulated above a homogeneous half-space. To verify the simulated noise performance the power spectrum, of an active antenna prototype, measured outdoors over multiple days, is used. The processing framework to derive the equivalent isotropic receiver noise temperature from these measurements using the external noise temperature of the antenna is presented. The results show the impact that the sky model, used to determine the external noise temperature, can have on the derived equivalent isotropic receiver noise temperature. The best agreement between simulations and measurements is found using the Global Sky Model of 2008.

title: Reconfigurable Origami Nonlocal Scatterer for Analog Computing
authors: Enzong Wu, Haochen Yang, Xiaomeng Li, Bo Zhou, Hongsheng Chen, Zuojia Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This study explores the design and application of reconfigurable origami nonlocal scatterer for analog computing. By leveraging the geometric properties and reconfigurability of origami structures, combined with the nonlocal effect in metamaterials, we achieve analog computing, such as solving differential-integral equations, through dynamic adjustments of origami configurations.

title: Interoperability of Grid-Forming Inverters in Microgrids During Faults
authors: Rutger Kersjes, Yıldırım Derin, Nataly Bañol Arias, Thiago Batista Soeiro
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: As inverter-based resources increasingly dominate modern power systems, including microgrids, ensuring stable and reliable operation during normal and abnormal operation becomes essential. This paper investigates the interoperability of grid-forming inverters in microgrids by examining the behavior of inverters operating under combined control methods and fault-ride through (FRT) strategies when interconnected during symmetrical fault events. A dynamic microgrid model is developed, incorporating grid-forming primary controls (droop and virtual synchronous generator (VSG)) and FRT mechanisms (current magnitude saturation (CMS) and virtual impedance (VI)). The study compares these control methods under symmetrical faults, highlighting their impact on system stability, fault recovery, and power sharing. Results show that primary control and FRT methods influence system behavior during normal operation and during and after faults, with more stable performance observed in homogeneous systems. Droop control with CMS outperforms VSG with VI for the specific study case.

title: Fault Ride-Through Control Strategies for 100% Converter-Based Power Systems in the Presence of Constant PQ Loads
authors: Pardis Pariz, Hamed Heydari-Doostabad, Terence O’Donnell
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: As interest in converting from traditional systems to fully converter-based systems increase, converter Fault Ride-Through (FRT) capability becomes critical for maintaining stability in such systems. This paper presents a comparative study of FRT strategies in a 100% fully converter-based system consisting of grid forming converters (GFM), grid following converters (GFL) and different types of loads (constant impedance and constant power). Simulation results in MATLAB/Simulink illustrate that loads with the same power but different characteristics can significantly affect fault recovery performance, as can the current limitation method used in the GFL. Constant PQ loads exhibit negative impedance behavior, which can lead to instability if not properly managed. The results also show that the hybrid current limiting method in the GFM demonstrates better performance across varying load conditions.

title: Green AI: A Dynamic Framework for Energy-Efficient Inference on Kubernetes
authors: Payal Godhani, Ajay Bhat
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Kubernetes has proven to be one of the most powerful platforms for containerization, offering unique features such as flexibility, scalability, and fault tolerance. The orchestration platform's ease of use and impressive orchestration capabilities have driven its widespread adoption in the machine learning domain for inferencing and training. However, Kubernetes has its own set of challenges with respect to its default resource configuration. Its inefficient CPU resource utilization has led to high power consumption during AI inferencing [1]. This paper conducts research on the energy efficiency of Kubernetes in the context of machine learning and also proposes a dynamic framework that aims at reducing the power consumption of the inferencing workload by adjusting the CPU allocation in real-time on an AMD cluster. The framework configures the containers to their most optimal CPU allocation settings on the Kubernetes cluster while maintaining the workloads latency thresholds defined by the service level agreement. We describe a holistic solution that can be leveraged by all the inferencing workloads using Kubernetes, taking into account the inferencing performance and its power consumption. We discuss the results of a tree-based XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boost) inferencing workload where the power consumption was reduced by 75 % as compared to the default settings for the SLA used in this research. We show that by introducing a dynamic CPU-allocation framework, we can see significant improvements in the power consumption for machine learning inferencing workloads on Kubernetes clusters without substantially compromising inferencing performance. This research also highlights that Kubernetes potential is not just limited to container orchestration but is capable of dynamically optimizing energy usage in cloud-native AI applications. This research contributes to the growing need for more sustainable and greener AI deployments, especially in the age of generative AI.

title: A Real-Time System for Drowsy and Drunk Driver Detection
authors: Bryan S. Bataluna, Kevin G. Leysa, April Rose A. Zaragosa, Patrick D. Cerna
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Driver drowsiness and alcohol impairment are leading causes of road accidents globally, necessitating reliable, non-intrusive detection systems. This study develops a real-time, computer vision-based application to identify signs of driver impairment by analyzing facial features. The system utilizes the Dlib library to detect 68 facial landmarks and calculates the Eye Aspect Ratio (EAR) to monitor eye-blinking patterns. A threshold of 0.25 is used to classify the driver's state as “Alert” or “Drowsy/Drunk.” Implemented with OpenCV and a Tkinter graphical interface, the solution processes webcam feeds or static images efficiently. Results demonstrate high performance, with the system achieving 92.4% accuracy, 94.6% recall, and an average processing speed of 50–70 ms per frame, proving its viability for real-time use. The study confirms that a lightweight, geometric-feature-based approach can offer a cost-effective and accessible alternative to computationally intensive deep learning models. This work provides a practical foundation for enhancing driver safety and can be deployed on standard hardware, making it particularly relevant for broad adoption and future integration with additional modalities like yawning detection.

title: Twinax Cables at 448 Gb/s: Challenges and Solutions
authors: Yuming Zheng, Lei Deng, Yuping Tan, Yihong Qi
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Advanced Interconnects (WAI)
abstract: Electrical links at 448 Gb/s are increasingly constrained by cable insertion loss, higher-order-mode (HOM) excitation, and intra-pair skew. This paper reviews recent advances in twinax cables and, for 448 Gb/s PAM4 lanes with Nyquist near 112 GHz, analyzes these constraints and their design implications. Design approaches are presented to reduce loss, raise the HOM onset frequency, and mitigate skew to meet end-to-end compliance.

title: AI Driven Self Healing Software Architectures for Automated Code Diagnostics and Repair
authors: C. Maddilety, Gondiparla Lokesh, A. Vani Vathsala, Madhavaram Swapna, K. Samunnisa, M Bhavsingh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Modern software systems deployed in safety- critical and real-time environments demand continuous operation and resilience to unforeseen faults. Traditional fault-handling mechanisms rely on reactive, rule-based strategies and manual debugging, which are insufficient for dynamic, autonomous systems. Inspired by biological repair mechanisms, this study proposes a self-healing software architecture capable of autonomous fault detection, diagnosis, and patching at runtime. The primary objective of this research is to design and evaluate a biologically inspired, AI-driven framework that performs real-time software fault recovery with minimal human intervention. The proposed architecture integrates a transformer-based fault localization engine with a neural patch synthesis model trained on the ManySStuBs4J dataset. Runtime fault detection and control are handled through a modular feedback mechanism that ensures safe patch deployment and rollback. Evaluation is conducted using the Defects4J and ManySStuBs4J datasets across 395 real-world bugs and over 150,000 bug-fix pairs. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed system achieves a fault localization accuracy of 88.6%, patch generation success rate of 74.2%, and patch correctness rate of 68.3%, while maintaining a mean patch generation latency of 310.4ms —substantially outperforming state-of-the- art baselines including GenProg, DeepFix, and RLRepair. This architecture advances the state of autonomous software repair by combining biological principles with machine learning, enabling scalable, low-latency, and deployable self-healing capabilities for mission-critical applications.

title: Common Tropical Diseases Prediction by Using Machine Learning
authors: Gunawan Wang, Rakha Gusti Wardhana, Farida Sibuea, Anderes Gui, Deshinta Arrova Dewi
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: The recent AI development has provided effective solutions to address current problems and improve decision making process. The article takes a case study in Data and Information Centre (Pusdatin) Ministry of Health (MoH), to address common recurring diseases that faced by Indonesian in large area. Those diseases are selected such as: Tuberculosis (TBC), Pneumonia (toddler), Diarrhea, and Dengue fever (DB). Those diseases are the common diseases in tropical countries, where they frequently cause major shortages in healthcare facility to serve the patients. Since 2020, MoH has encouraged the intensive use of AI technology to improve data analysis and use them to support decision-making process. MoH has promoted the adoption of latest IT technology such as: Big Data, Internet of Things (IoT), Cloud computing and AI technology to improve healthcare infrastructure and decision support system. The article applies the common Machine Learning (ML) algorithms in business applications, such as: Logistic Regression, Random Forest, Support Vector Machine (SVM), Decision Tree, and XGBoost. The use of Machine Learning algorithms is expected to improve the accuracy of disease data modelling and prediction; and also examine the hidden patterns within the data. The ML simulation shows decision tree algorithm has the highest results for diarrhea and TBC, and followed by Random Forest (Pneumonia) and XGBoost (DB).

title: Inverse Problems and Qualitative Theory of Three-Dimensional Polynomial Dynamical Systems
authors: Yury V. Shestopalov, Azizaga H. Shakhverdiev
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This paper provides a brief outline of the methods of analysis and elements of qualitative theory of autonomous dynamical systems (DSs), particularly, splitting three-dimensional quadratic polynomial DSs, with application to the electromagnetic field theory and solution of certain classes of inverse problems for DSs. Closed-form solutions are obtained of reconstructing initial data for the addressed DS families using the introduced notion of initial sets and mappings that couple the data sets.

title: Quantum Convolutional Neural Network for Coffee Plant Disease Diagnosis
authors: Savitri Kulkarni, Shashidhar V, P. Deepa Shenoy, Venugopal K. R
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: In modern agriculture, high crop yields and food security depend on early and accurate identification of plant diseases. Deep learning (DL) models like convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have successfully classified plant disease using leaf images. Classical models are adequate for small-scale applications but inefficient for large-scale applications because of their high processing requirements and difficulty in handling highdimensional data. To overcome these challenges, this study proposes the Quantum Convolutional Neural Network (QCNN) by leveraging the Cirq library to introduce quantum circuit simulation. The QCNN model is trained on the Kaggle coffee plant dataset and JMuBEN Mendeley. Quantum Fourier transforms (QFT) are used to preprocess the input images for enhanced quality and to find regions of interest (ROI) for disease lesions. The empirical results prove that the QCNN has drastically improved the model's performance in each phase of the epoch when compared with the traditional CNN model. In the training phase, the QCNN accomplished 96.98 %, whereas the CNN achieved 88.95 % for 150 epochs. Similarly, an effective performance is accomplished during the testing phase by QCNN with 95.89% in comparison with the CNN performance of 85.77 %. Hence, this work emphasizes the power of QCNN in faster training and analytical capabilities using entanglement and superposition in the quantum domain.

title: Distributed Optimization Approaches for Coordinated T&D Generation Expansion Planning
authors: Nahid-Ur-Rahman Chowdhury, Gregorio Muñoz-Delgado, Natalia Alguacil, Javier Contreras
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper presents two practical distributed algorithms designed to solve the coordinated generation expansion planning (CGEP) problem for both transmission and distribution (T&D) systems. The CGEP problem addressed, framed as a scenario-based linear programming instance, is solved here using the Analytical Target Cascading (ATC) and the Auxiliary Problem Principle (APP). Both solution approaches not only preserve the information privacy of T&D planners but also guarantee finite convergence to optimality. Limited information on the interface nodes connecting the T&D systems is exchanged which allows decomposing the problem into independent subproblems for each T&D planner. The effectiveness of both algorithms is assessed using a 36-node test system, showing a reasonable trade-off between solution quality and computation times for a practical setting.

title: A Wideband S-Domain Algorithm for Microwave Imaging Within Resonant Chambers Using Dispersive Eigenfunction Expansions
authors: Amir Attar, Joe LoVetri
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: We investigate the incorporation of data collected over a wideband of frequencies into the microwave imaging process. We use S-domain transfer-function representations of the data as well as the spatial resonant eigenfunctions of the unloaded and loaded imaging chamber. The field within the chamber is represented as a series expansion over the eigenfunctions wherein the coefficients of the expansion are S-domain functions. In this way, the previously developed Non-Iterative Eigenfunction Inversion algorithm is extended to utilize a wideband of frequencies. Moreover, the formulation is applicable to full vectorial imaging scenarios. A numerical study is performed to evaluate the potential benefits of using resonant chambers, especially with regard to using data close to the resonant frequencies of the loaded and unloaded chambers.

title: Noise Tolerance of Scatterer Information Estimation Method Using the Numerical Data of Backward Transient Scattering Waves
authors: Keiji Goto, Toru Kawano, Mahiro Kitaguchi, Ryosuke Seito
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: In this study, we investigate the noise tolerance of the scatterer information estimation method for both <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{E}$</tex> - and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{H}$</tex> polarizations when an ultra-wideband (UWB) pulse wave is incident perpendicularly on a two-dimensional coated cylinder. The estimation method utilizes numerical data of the direct geometric optical ray (DGO) and reflected geometric optical ray (RGO) series, which comprise the backward transient scattering waves when a line source and an observation point are situated at different positions. The scatterer information dealt with in this study is the relative permittivity and thickness of a coating medium layer, in addition to the outer radius of the coated cylinder. The estimation formulas employed in this estimation method are derived using the time-domain Fourier transform method (TD-FTM) and the amplitude intensity ratios (AIRs), defined as the ratio of the peaks of adjacent backward transient scattering waves. The estimates are obtained by substituting the numerical data of the response waveforms into the estimation formulas and performing iterative calculations. The discussion in this study focuses on the noise tolerance of the estimation method by adding noise to the signal data of the response waveforms. It is clarified that the noise tolerance of the estimation method employing TD-FTM and AIRs is equivalent to that of the conventional method, namely the estimation method using the time-domain saddle-point technique (TD-SPT) and AIRs.

title: Research on Distributed Communication Algorithm Optimization of Urban Rail Transit CBTC System Simulation Test Platform
authors: Hao Shen, Xiaodong Chen, Haichao Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: The stable operation of the urban rail transit CBTC system is of great significance to urban transportation, and the performance of the distributed communication algorithm of its simulation test platform is the key. The existing algorithms have deficiencies in real-time performance and reliability, which affect the accuracy and efficiency of the test. To this end, this paper proposes an ADRRO algorithm based on adaptive dynamic routing and redundant data optimization. The algorithm uses real-time network status monitoring to dynamically plan routing paths and avoid congested links. At the same time, it uses data fingerprint technology to accurately identify and optimize redundant data transmission. In the simulation environment built by NS-3, different network scales, loads and topologies are set for comparative testing. The results show that compared with the original algorithm, the ADRRO algorithm reduces the average data transmission delay from 450 milliseconds to 300 milliseconds, a decrease of 33.3 %; the packet loss rate is reduced from 7 % to 4 %, a decrease of 42.9 %; the network throughput is increased from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2 M b p s}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 8 M b p s}$</tex>, an increase of 50 %. This shows that the ADRRO algorithm effectively improves the platform communication performance, builds a solid technical support for the research and development, testing and verification of the CBTC system, and effectively promotes the safe and efficient development of urban rail transit. In the future, in-depth research can be conducted from the perspectives of integrating emerging network technologies, optimizing complex environment performance, and enhancing hardware compatibility.

title: Sediment Level Detection and Alert System for Reservoirs
authors: Ajith.B. Singh, Dushyanth K, Hemanth S, Jeevan Prasath D
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Reservoir sedimentation gradually lowers storage capacity and harms operational performance. This paper introduces an IoT-based dual-sensor system that features an ultrasonic distance sensor and a bed-mounted pressure plate (20 kg load cell + HX711), controlled by an ESP32 microcontroller. This setup offers continuous, verified measurements of sediment buildup. The data is processed and sent via MQTT to a ThingSpeak cloud dashboard for real-time viewing and archived trend analysis. When thresholds are breached, automated email alerts are triggered through IFTTT. A scaled-tank prototype and repeated lab tests validated this approach: the depth and pressure signals showed strong complementary behavior (correlation <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{r} \approx$</tex> -0.92). The ultrasonic unit had an average error of approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 1.5 \text{cm}$</tex>. The load-cell readings maintained about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 2 {\%}$</tex> accuracy, and the combined sensor logic reduced false positives by about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30-40 {\%}$</tex> compared to single-sensor operation. The total alert latency was recorded at under 10 seconds with standard Wi-Fi, and continuous operation used approximately 500 mA at 12 V, showing it can work well with modest solar power. The results show that using sensor fusion and IoT visualization creates a solid, practical way to detect and manage reservoir sedimentation early, allowing for proactive maintenance and improved water-storage reliability.

title: Research on Android Malware Detection Based on Deep Neural Networks
authors: Yuhan Hou
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: The widespread adoption of the Android system has made it a prime target for malware attacks. Traditional detection methods struggle to cope with the variants and complex behaviors of malware. This paper proposes an Android malware detection model that integrates multi-source feature extraction with deep neural networks. The model comprehensively utilizes features from static code, dynamic behavior, and resource files, leveraging the feature learning and classification capabilities of deep neural networks for detection. The experiments were conducted using the MalDroid 2020 dataset. The results demonstrate that the model performs exceptionally well in terms of accuracy, recall, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex> score, and AUC-ROC curve. The overall classification accuracy reaches 94.367 %, recall is 93.517 %, F1 score is 0.935, and the AUC value is 0.988. It outperforms models such as decision trees, support vector machines, and random forests. This model can effectively address the challenges of Android malware detection and provides technical support for safeguarding mobile user information security.

title: Self-Evolving Middleware for Cyber Threat Detection in Smart IoT Ecosystems Using Cycle-GANs and Bio-Inspired Optimization
authors: T. Sathish, Gokul Chandrasekaran, Sami Askar, Geetha R, Nitin Bhardwaj, M.Siva Ramkumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: The rise of cyber-attacks in smart Internet of Things (IoT) settings has necessitated scalable and efficient attack detection mechanisms. This work introduces SelfEvolving Middleware for Cyber Threat Detection in Smart IoT Ecosystems Using Cycle-GANs and Bio-Inspired Optimization (Cycle-GANs-TLCO). Network traffic traces are first fetched from the IoT-23 and Edge-IIoT datasets. Preprocessing through Confidence Partitioning Sampling Filtering (CPSF) is accomplished to remove noise, balance attacks, and scale the dataset to improve learning. The Gooseneck Barnacle Optimization Algorithm (GBOA) is utilized for the selection of discriminative network traffic features, while being computationally light. For the detection of cyber-attacks, the Unsupervised Cycle-Consistent Generative Adversarial Network (UCCGAN) is implemented with adversarial learning for pinpointing subtle attacks. Hyperparameters are further tuned with Termite Life Cycle Optimization (TLCO) to better improve model accuracy and stability. Experimental evaluation evinces an increment in attack detection accuracy by 17.85%, 23.41%, and 29.74% against state-of-the-art competitors. The deployment of the middleware showcases an enhancement of CPU use by only 2.1%, with memory usage increasing to 0.42 GB, to maintain resource efficiency. Power consumption is minimized by 15.9% and 11.2% on NVIDIA Jetson and Raspberry Pi, respectively, to reinforce the feasibility for real-time use in IoT security applications.

title: Optimization-Based Design of Dielectric-Only Transparent Smart Electromagnetic Surfaces
authors: L. Bricco, M. Beccaria, S. Ayaz, P. Pirinoli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: In the recent years, the design of a passive, transparent electromagnetic surfaces has become more and more attractive for several applications, as for instance the enhancement of Outdoor-to-Indoor communication. To avoid the use of metallization, which could compromise both optical transparency and radiation efficiency due to ohmic losses, a purely dielectric, multi-layer configuration is investigated here. In particular, some results on the optimization of the unit cell used to discretize the surface are presented: a simplified model is adopted for its characterization, and the presence of a glass layer is introduced to take into account the effects eventually introduced by the window on the surface performance. Preliminary results confirm that the adopted multi-objective optimization strategy allows to strongly improve the unit cell features, and therefore that of the entire surface.

title: Comparison of MoM Solvers for Analysing Wire Coupling
authors: William R. Dommisse, Matthys M. Botha, Thomas Rylander, Jan Carlsson
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Accurate electromagnetic scattering and radiation analysis of wires is an important capability for tasks such as antenna design, antenna placement and electromagnetic compatibility studies. This paper compares analysis methods based on the method of moments (MoM), for the full-wave analysis of wire structures. Three solvers are considered: (i) the exactkernel thin-wire MoM; (ii) a recently developed wire macro basis function (MBF) MoM; and (iii) the Rao-Wilton-Glisson (RWG) basis MoM for general surfaces in three dimensions. The latter provides for reference results. The other two are aimed at reducing computational cost through being specialised to wire structures. Presented scattering and radiation analysis results, demonstrate the necessity of incorporating sufficient generality in wire current flow modelling, to compute scattering, crosscoupling and impedance accurately.

title: Comparative Study of Chatbot Architectures Using LLMs and RAG: Evaluating FAISS-Based Knowledge Retrieval Schemes
authors: Herlawati Herlawati, Ben Rahman, Rahmadya Trias Handayanto, Prima Dina Atika, Dwipa Handayani, Maimunah Maimunah, Endang Retnoningsih, Syahbaniar Rofiah, Didik Setiyadi
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: The use of Large Language Models (LLMs) for chatbot applications is currently widespread. The availability of various models with specific characteristics tailored to different needs has made these models increasingly popular. However, challenges remain, particularly the high computational resource requirements, such as the need for a Graphics Processing Unit (GPU). This has led to the need for optimization through emerging technologies, one of which is Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG). RAG allows users to avoid resource-intensive fine-tuning processes. Several RAG methods are already in use, such as Facebook AI Similarity Search (FAISS), Weaviate, Elasticsearch, Qdrant, etc., but the implementation techniques vary widely and still require experimentation to achieve optimal performance while minimizing computational demands. This is especially important considering that chatbots are often integrated into web servers, which are typically focused on web programming rather than artificial intelligence (AI). This study evaluates several chatbot schemes utilizing RAG with a FAISS index for a Question and Answer (Q/A)-based chatbot. The model used is a lightweight one with minimal GPU requirements, namely Gemma:2b-Instruct. The tested schemes include: (i) a single FAISS index, (ii) a single FAISS index with special chunking, (iii) two FAISS indices handling Q/A and non-Q/A in a serial manner, and (iv) two FAISS indices handling Q/A and non-Q/A in parallel. Experimental results show that using special chunking to handle Q/A improves accuracy, and the use of two FAISS indices in parallel minimizes the dominance of the Q/A index over the non-Q/A index.

title: Big Data-Driven Trip Duration Prediction in Urban Transportation Systems
authors: Elias Dritsas, Maria Trigka, Phivos Mylonas
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: This study presents a machine learning (ML)-based approach for trip duration prediction using a large-scale mobility dataset from New York City (NYC) yellow taxi, incorporating both raw and engineered features to model spatiotemporal and fare-related factors that influence trip duration. Six regression models, including Linear Regression (LR), Support Vector Regressor (SVR), Random Forest (RF), Gradient Boosting (GB), XGBoost, and Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), were trained and evaluated using standard metrics, namely, Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), and Coefficient of Determination <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(R^{2})$</tex>. The RF model achieved the best performance, with an MAE of 53.83 s, an RMSE of 143.38 s, and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> score of 0.929. These results demonstrate the suitability of ensemble tree-based models for predictive analytics in intelligent transportation systems and outline future directions for enhancing performance using contextual and real-time data streams.

title: SCIGENT: Multi-agent for End-to-end Question Answering on Scientific Knowledge Graph
authors: Dieu-Hien Nguyen, Nguyen-Khang Le, Shinobu Hasegawa, Minh Le Nguyen
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: Effective question answering over scientific literature demands up-to-date knowledge, a challenge exacerbated by the rapid growth of publications. Traditional Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) methods, reliant on text-based retrieval, struggle with structured knowledge inherent in knowledge graphs. We introduce Scigent, a multi-agent platform for end-to-end question answering over scientific knowledge graphs, addressing the challenge of dynamic entity resolution and SPARQL query translation from raw user queries. Unlike traditional methods, Scigent operates in open-ended scenarios, resolving entities and relationships in real-time. Alongside this, we present Scigent-QA, a benchmark built on DBLP and ORKG knowledge graphs, to evaluate end-to-end question-answering systems. This benchmark provides a comprehensive testbed for assessing real-world applicability and robustness. Additionally, we release a full pipeline for constructing and continuously updating scientific knowledge graphs, ensuring the system remains current with emerging publications. This work advances knowledge-driven AI, enabling robust and scalable solutions for complex scientific queries. Empirical results demonstrate that Scigent, when used with popular large language models, achieves up to 65 % accuracy on the end-to-end evaluation of Scigent-QA, proving its practicality for real-world applications.

title: Edge Computing-Oriented UAV Aerial Image Stitching Based on Adaptive ROI selection and Improved FLANN
authors: Xiaoyong Sun, Bei Sun, Hanxiang Qian, Shaojing Su, Runze Guo, Peida Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Developing real-time and efficient drone image stitching methods is of great significance for ensuring the safety of drone low altitude flight and accurate situational awareness under unknown conditions, in order to better address the susceptibility of drone aerial images to changes in lighting, rotation, and scale. In order to meet these challenges, this paper proposes a UAV image mosaic method based on adaptive ROI selection and improved FLANN processing in edge computing architecture. This method utilizes ROI adaptive segmentation of the region to be feature extracted, and combines SIFT feature extraction with an improved FLANN feature matching algorithm to achieve effective stitching in four typical scenarios.

title: An Adaptive Hybrid Deep Learning Framework for Android Malware Detection
authors: M. Sravani, R Vijaya Prakash
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: This study proposes a hybrid deep learning framework for Android malware detection integrating static and dynamic analysis. Using multimodal IoT datasets containing textual, image, and audio features, a CNN-RNN-Transformer model is developed for accurate malware classification. Preprocessing, feature fusion, and advanced optimization improve detection accuracy and robustness against encrypted traffic. Experimental results on a curated encrypted IoT Android dataset demonstrate superior performance, achieving 95.1% accuracy, 94.5% precision, and 94.2% recall, outperforming existing baseline methods. The proposed approach highlights the potential of multimodal fusion and deep neural architectures in enhancing the resilience and adaptability of malware detection systems to real-world encrypted environments.

title: Data-Driven Educational Management in Higher Education: Predictive Modeling of Student Learning Outcomes Using Artificial Intelligence
authors: Heny Pratiwi, Muhammad Ibnu Sa'ad, Eko Junirianto
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: This study aims to develop an artificial intelligence (AI)-based predictive model to support higher education management in enhancing learning effectiveness. Specifically, the research focuses on analyzing student engagement data collected from a Learning Management System (LMS) to predict academic outcomes in the form of final exam scores. A quantitative research design was applied, utilizing machine learning-based predictive modeling techniques. The dataset consists of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> student records and includes features such as video watch duration, quiz attempts and scores, forum participation, and assignment completion rates. Three machine learning algorithms-Random Forest, Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Artificial Neural Network (ANN)-were evaluated and compared. The results indicate that the Random Forest algorithm outperformed the others (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}} =0.81$</tex>, RMSE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=7.12$</tex>, MAE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=5.46$</tex>), with quiz scores and assignment completion emerging as the most significant predictors. These findings highlight the strategic potential of integrating AI models into academic decision-making systems to enable early identification of at-risk students and deliver personalized learning interventions. Through this data-driven approach, higher education institutions can improve academic service quality, student retention, and adaptive instructional planning.

title: Study on Contact Arc Suppression through Optimizing Catenary Structure
authors: Chongxun Wang, Hongyi Zhou, Md Monirul Islam, Menglin Li, Huanghao Ye
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: Electrical contact failure in the pantograph-catenary (PC) system frequently leads to the formation of contact arcs, which can significantly compromise the current collection quality. In this paper, the methods of arc suppression through optimizing the catenary structure are tried. First, the mechanism of contact arc in PC system is analyzed based on sliding electrical contact theory, and a probability algorithm of contact arc is proposed. Then, the PC dynamic structure model is established in order to obtain some key parameters of diverse catenary structure. Finally, the contact arc rate is computed, and suppression methods are evaluated under various parameters of the PC system based on this metric. This study provides a foundation for assessing electrical contact quality in pantograph-catenary systems in future research.

title: Unsupervised Sparse Imaging in 3D mmWave SAR with Physical Priors
authors: Junjie Xu, Zhihao He, Chou Wang, Bing Liu, Hailing Xiong, Zhen Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Product Compliance Engineering - Asia (ISPCE-ASIA)
abstract: Three-dimensional millimeter-wave synthetic aperture radar (3D mmWave SAR) enables high-resolution near-field imaging with strong penetration capabilities. However, image reconstruction remains challenging under sparse or noisy sampling conditions, especially for frequency-modulated continuous-wave (FMCW) systems. Conventional physics-based algorithms often rely on strong prior assumptions and exhibit limited performance in such scenarios. Meanwhile, most deep learning approaches are supervised and designed primarily for 2D reconstruction tasks. To overcome these issues, we propose mmDecoder, an unsupervised neural network for 3D SAR image reconstruction that incorporates physical priors within a decoder-only architecture. The model learns directly from raw echo signals without ground truth labels and employs L1 regularization for structural sparsity, thereby improving reconstruction quality. Extensive evaluations on public datasets show that mmDecoder outperforms both traditional methods and untrained neural networks under low sampling rates, demonstrating its robustness and practical potential for real-world radar imaging applications.

title: CAMP: Consensus and Inference-driven Decentralized Multi-Agent Path Finding
authors: Wenbin Chen, Haoxiang Zhao, Longfei Zhang, Mengwei Li, Bingyi Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Product Compliance Engineering - Asia (ISPCE-ASIA)
abstract: The throughput of intelligent warehousing systems benefits from efficient Multi-Agent Path Finding (MAPF) solutions. In recent years, existing research has focused on distributed decision-making schemes, which offer superior scalability compared to non-learning-based methods. However, balancing long-term planning with short-term coordination remains challenging. To address this, we propose the Consensus and Inference-driven Decentralized MAPF Framework (CAMP). Specifically, we introduce a consensus-aware module that embeds diverse observations into a unified consensus representation to enable coordination under decentralized execution. Furthermore, the CAMP framework integrates a dynamic inference module that leverages environmental features to predict dynamic changes in the environment, thereby facilitating foresighted decision-making. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that the proposed CAMP framework improves task completion throughput by at least 15% within the same time period compared to existing approaches.

title: Robustness Analysis of MPC-based Voltage Control in Distribution Grids Under Uncertainties
authors: Philip Kvesić, Sarra Bouchkati, Alexander Och, Andreas Ulbig
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The increase in distributed energy resources presents new challenges for the operation of distribution grids. Maintaining grid stability, particularly voltage regulation, requires new control methods to address these challenges. A promising approach for voltage regulation in active distribution grids is Model Predictive Control (MPC). While MPC offers the flexibility and responsiveness needed to manage the dynamic and uncertain nature of active distribution networks, its robustness against uncertainties remains underexplored. This work proposes a centralized MPC formulation for voltage regulation in distribution grids, with a focus on analyzing its robustness against uncertainties such as measurement and forecast errors, as well as communication failures. Case studies conducted on a SimBench low-voltage (LV) grid demonstrated the method’s robustness to the aforementioned uncertainties. To further advance the assessment of robustness, additional studies are required, particularly those that test the limits of the control framework across a broader range of test cases.

title: Factors Influencing the Success of Early-Stage Digital Startups in Indonesia
authors: Sofian Lusa, Myrza Rahmanita, Rahmat Inkadijaya
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: This study examines the factors influencing the success of early-stage digital startups in Indonesia using a quantitative approach. Through a survey of 150 participants from various sectors of the startup ecosystem and fuzzy-set Qualitative Comparative Analysis (fsQCA), the research identified critical factor combinations contributing to startup success. The analysis revealed that founder programs, bootstrapping (self-funding or alternative early-stage financing), and regulation and governance are the most critical factors, appearing in both high-success configurations. The first configuration (Digital Talent * Founder Programs * Bootstrapping * Regulation) achieved 87.54% coverage with 0.957 consistency, while the second configuration (Founder Programs * Incubators * Product-Market Fit * Bootstrapping * Regulation) achieved 85.67% coverage with 0.956 consistency. These findings provide evidence-based insights for policymakers and practitioners to foster digital startup success through targeted interventions in founder development, financial support mechanisms, and regulatory frameworks.

title: Improving Minority Class Detection using Intelligent Undersampling Technique
authors: Shaheen Layaq, T.Sampath Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Imbalanced datasets create a notable obstacle for machine learning models, which frequently results in prediction bias favoring the majority class and inadequate detection of essential minority samples. This paper introduces an Intelligent Undersampling Technique designed to enhance minority class detection while retaining the fundamental characteristics of the majority data. The proposed method IDR_IUT (Imbalance Data Reduction using Intelligent Undersampling Technique) strategically calculates the uncertainty score for all the instances of majority dataset and sort instances according to their uncertainty score. Later, retain majority samples whose calculated uncertainty score is less than user selected threshold and drop remaining samples as there are far from the decision boundary, thereby reducing data redundancy and enhancing decision boundary clarity. Experiments were carried out on Software Defect Prediction dataset extracted from PROMISE repository using classifier such as Naive Bayes. The results shows that IDR_IUT consistently attains higher precision, accuracy, recall, specificity, and F1 score, and balanced accuracy is compared with earlier undersampling methods (CBUS, IDRUS), with a notable increase of up to 93% in minority class detection. These results suggest that intelligent undersampling serves as an effective preprocessing strategy for building robust and equitable predictive models in imbalanced learning contexts. IDR_IUT algorithm was implemented using python programming.

title: Research on the Fusion of Deep Learning Algorithms for Intelligent Control of Electromechanical Systems
authors: Jinhua Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: With the rapid development of industrial automation, the demand for intelligent control of electromechanical systems has become increasingly urgent. Traditional control algorithms are difficult to effectively process the complex dynamic data in the operation of electromechanical systems, resulting in poor control accuracy and real-time performance. To this end, this paper proposes a dynamic adaptive attention optimized convolutional long short-term memory network (DA-ACLSTM) algorithm. The algorithm enhances the ability to extract key data features of electromechanical systems through a dynamic adaptive attention mechanism, and optimizes the convolutional long short-term memory network structure to improve the processing efficiency of data spatiotemporal characteristics. Taking the precision CNC machine tool servo system as the research object, 1000 sets of operation data are collected to construct an experimental data set, and the test is carried out in the constructed simulation experimental environment. The experimental results show that compared with the traditional LSTM algorithm, the DA-ACLSTM algorithm reduces the mean square error by 42.3 %, the mean absolute error by 38.6 %, and the response time by 27.5 % in position control; compared with the ordinary convolutional neural network, the mean square error in speed control decreases by 35.8 %, the mean absolute error by 32.1 %, and the overshoot by 22.4 %. The experiment fully verifies the effectiveness and superiority of the DA-ACLSTM algorithm in the intelligent control of electromechanical systems, and provides a new technical solution for the intelligent development of electromechanical systems.

title: Research on Automatic Assembly Detection Algorithm of Mechanical Parts Based on Machine Vision
authors: Wenhao Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: In the context of intelligent transformation of mechanical manufacturing industry, automatic assembly detection technology based on machine vision is of vital importance. This paper proposes an adaptive multi-scale feature fusion detection algorithm, which realizes multi-scale feature extraction by improving ResNet, completes feature fusion with the help of a weighted strategy based on the attention mechanism, and uses Transformer to build a detection decision model. In the experimental stage, an experimental platform equipped with Basler industrial cameras and NVIDIA RTX 3090 GPU was built, and a data set containing 8,000 images was constructed, with training, validation, and test sets divided into 8:1:1. The algorithm was compared with HOG+SVM, YOLOv5, and Faster R-CNN. The results showed that: in terms of detection accuracy, the algorithm reached 98.9%, which was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 3. 5 \%}$</tex> higher than HOG+SVM's <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 5. 4 \%}$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8. 2 \%}$</tex> higher than YOLOv5's 90.7%, and 6.8% higher than Faster R-CNN's 92.1%; the recall rate was 98.1%, leading the comparison algorithms by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20.3 \%, 6.9 {\%}$</tex>, and 5.7% respectively; the F 1 value reached 98.5%, with a significant advantage. In terms of detection speed, the algorithm only takes 115 ms to process a single image, which is similar to YOLOv5 and significantly better than other algorithms. The experimental data fully shows that the algorithm has achieved a good balance between high precision and high efficiency in the automated assembly detection of mechanical parts, and has strong practicality.

title: Peak Power Demand in Apartment Buildings: Insights from Smart Meter Data and Building Characteristics
authors: Aki Kortetmäki, Juho Ylipaino, Kari Kallioharju, Juha Koskela, Kimmo Lummi, Pertti Järventausta
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Accurately estimating peak demand in apartment buildings is essential for properly sizing electrical connections and distribution boards, yet current guidelines in Finland often lack precision, especially when accounting for modern appliances and building technologies. This study combines technical data from 164 apartment buildings with hourly electricity consumption data from 2015 to 2021 to assess peak demand behavior across three levels: aggregated apartment loads, common-area loads, and total building consumption. Results are presented as area-based values (W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) to support early-phase engineering estimates. Key findings include significantly higher peak demands in buildings with apartment saunas and heat pump systems, as well as clear patterns in peak timing—most frequently occurring in winter months and during weekends. This study provides updated benchmarks and practical tools for electrical designers, updating and refining outdated estimation practices which are still based on guidelines from the 1980s. The results highlight the urgent need for modernized, data-driven methods for peak demand estimation, and call for further research on the influence of outdoor temperature, building structures, ventilation systems, equipment levels, occupant behavior, and emerging loads such as electric vehicle charging.

title: A Novel Transformer-Based Fuzzing Framework for Industrial Control Protocols
authors: Yingzi Wu, Qin Qi, Jingyi Hu, Rao Kuang, Zengwang Jin, Junyi Ding, Ping Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Product Compliance Engineering - Asia (ISPCE-ASIA)
abstract: With the increasing reliance of power grids and critical infrastructure on Industrial Control Systems (ICS), the security of Industrial Control Protocols (ICPs) has become a growing concern. Many ICPs suffer from inadequate security mechanisms, making them inherently vulnerable to cyberattacks and posing significant risks to system integrity in critical infrastructure. Existing fuzzing techniques are valuable for vulnerability detection, while they often fail to model complex protocol sequences effectively and rely on random mutation strategies, limiting their ability to detect vulnerabilities in intricate systems. This paper introduces SPTFuzz, a novel fuzzing framework designed to address these limitations. By leveraging an enhanced Transformer architecture that incorporates a Spectral-Relational Fusion Mechanism, SPTFuzz captures long-range dependencies and spectral features, enhancing both protocol conformance and the diversity of test cases. Additionally, a mutation strategy based on Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) is employed to dynamically adjust mutation probabilities, optimizing vulnerability detection during fuzzing. Experimental results on the Modbus protocol demonstrate that SPTFuzz outperforms existing approaches, achieving higher test case recognition rates, greater data diversity, and improved anomaly detection.

title: Blockchain-Enabled Energy Swarm Protocol for Peer-to-Peer Smart Grid Communications
authors: Satyanarayana Nimmala, Maragoni Mahendar, Sagar Mekala, Karthik Karmakonda, R Ravinder Reddy, Pallati Narsimhulu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: The increasing decentralization of energy generation via home solar panels and microgrids necessitates safe, scalable, and autonomous peer-to-peer (P2P) energy trading systems. Conventional grid management technologies lack the adaptability and reliability necessary for decentralized contexts. This study presents the Blockchain-Enabled Energy Swarm Protocol (BESP), which combines Ethereum smart contracts with Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to enhance energy trade efficiency and enable the dynamic clustering of prosumers. The protocol guarantees safe, trustless communication, low-latency energy matching, and transparent transaction auditability without dependence on a central authority. The system is assessed using empirical data from the Pecan Street Dataport dataset, which includes high-resolution records of energy usage and solar output from more than 1,000 residences in Austin, Texas. Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) was executed in MATLAB Simulink, whilst smart contracts were deployed and evaluated via Remix IDE and Ganache on a private Ethereum network. Experimental findings indicate that BESP decreases transaction latency by 35.2%, reduces communication overhead by 27.8%, and enhances energy cost efficiency by more than 60% relative to traditional P2P and centralized frameworks. These findings underscore BESP's efficacy in facilitating energy-efficient, secure, and decentralized communications inside smart grids, in accordance with future sustainable infrastructure objectives.

title: Market-Driven BESS Operation: Effects on Voltage Stability and Line Loadings in Distribution Grids
authors: Ahmed Elessawy, Sven Achter, Prashant Pant
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: As utility-scale Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) increasingly participate in electricity markets, understanding their operational impact on distribution network (DN) stability is critical. This study simulates a DN using synthesized BESS power profiles, validated against a commercial BESS engaged in arbitrage (day-ahead and intraday) and Frequency Containment Reserve (FCR) markets in Germany. Voltage regulation and line loading are then assessed across varying grid strengths by placing BESS units at multiple locations within the model. The results reveal a neutral to negative correlation between market-driven BESS operation and grid stability. When connected to strong grid locations, such as co-location with wind turbines (WTs) or at main substations, market-driven operation has minimal impact on voltage and line loadings. In contrast, BESS integration at weaker rural nodes leads to increased line overloading events, especially in summer months. Contrary to the common perception that BESS enhances grid stability, these findings demonstrate that uncoordinated market-driven BESS operation can adversely affect the stability of DNs.

title: IoT-Driven Machine Learning for Pharmaceutical Production Quality Indicators: A Comprehensive Survey
authors: Narne Hemanth Chowdary, P. V. G. D. Prasad Reddy, Suresh Chittineni
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Internet of Things (IoT) refers to a system of networked computing devices that can exchange data through the use of Unique Identifiers (UIDs). The IoT has the ability to improve product quality, boost efficiency, and decrease errors across the various phases of a pharmaceutical product's lifecycle by analyzing the quality indicators. In order to create pharmaceutical products and services with less time, effort, and labor expense, Machine Learning (ML) algorithms have been increasingly common manufacturing in the past few years. There is a growing need and interest in integrating ML and optimization techniques to improve product quality, driven by digitalization, cutting-edge production practices, and vast data availability. Key manufacturing metrics and quality indicators may be continuously monitored, which enables machine learning and deep learning for real-time analysis, predictive maintenance, and automation. In order to gain real-time insights into systems and processes, Digital Twin (DT) technology is utilized across several sectors. Digital twin refers to a virtual representation of a physical object that can shed light on how well the original item is functioning by analyzing their behaviors. This paper proposes a brief literature review on the models that are used for predicting the quality indicators in pharmaceutical production process and also using digital twins for monitoring the functionalities by considering the machine learning interconnected IoT enabled models to reduce faults in the process. This research is helpful for scholars to design new and effective models for efficient pharmaceutical production process.

title: Design and Performance Study of via Interconnection Structures in Multilayer Flexible LCP Circuits
authors: Xiang Gao, Wenbo Wang, Zhenxin Cao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Multilayer flexible LCP substrates have emerged as a cost-effective solution for conformal TR radio-frequency (RF) circuits due to their exceptional flexibility, low-loss characteristics, and high-temperature resistance. In bent multilayer circuit configurations, vertical interconnection structures critically influence cross-layer signal transmission performance, particularly for RF signals. Addressing the development requirements of conformal integrated TR RF circuits, this study designs a vertical interconnection architecture for curved multilayer LCP substrates. Through microwave transmission theory and electromagnetic field simulation software, the RF transmission performance of the via interconnection structure was systematically analyzed. The optimized structure demonstrates superior transmission characteristics with insertion loss <0.3 dB and return loss (S11) ≤−15 dB within the 0-40 GHz frequency band. Featuring simplified fabrication processes and low manufacturing costs, this vertical interconnection solution effectively resolves interlayer connection challenges in multilayer flexed LCP circuit boards, showing significant potential for flexible TR RF circuit applications.

title: Addressing Uncertain Irrigation Decisions Through a Hybrid Rule and ANN-Based System
authors: Muhammad Adib Kamali, Ahsha Aisna Al Wafi, Reinaldi Santana Battung
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ICoAIT)
abstract: Uncertainty in irrigation decision-making and duration prediction remains a significant challenge in tropical smart farming due to the high variability of environmental factors. The existing methods, such as rule-based and fuzzy logic, have been widely used to implement the irrigation prediction due to irrigation prediction due to their simplicity and low computational requirements. The remaining challenge is that these methods often fall short in two key aspects: (1) unable to effectively handle overlapping or ambiguous environmental conditions, referred to in this study as the uncertain decision zone, and (2) yielding static irrigation outputs, typically assigning a fixed irrigation duration regardless of actual field conditions. In such uncertain decision zones, there is no single parameter sufficient to define irrigation needs in a deterministic manner. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a hybrid rule-based and artificial neural network (ANN) approach to improve irrigation accuracy and adaptability. The proposed system utilizes rule-based logic for specific conditions and assigns uncertain situations to the ANN model, which forecasts adjustable irrigation durations that vary according to essential environmental factors rather than relying on static durations. Three approaches were evaluated: (1) rule-based only, (2) ANN-only, and (3) hybrid. Results show that the hybrid system achieved the best accuracy, with an MSE of 5.83 and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.82, compared to the ANN-only model (MSE 8.47, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> 0.76) and the rule-based model (MSE 20.59, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> –0.11).

title: Comparative Techno-Economical Analysis on the Effect of Smart and V2G-Enabled Charging Strategies in Transformer Aging
authors: Aytug Yavuzer, Taeyoung Kim, Antonello Monti
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The rising penetration of electric vehicles (EVs) into the grid presents both challenges and opportunities. To address this and promote advanced charging strategies, this study investigates the effects of various charging methods on transformers and their long-term economic impact on grid owners. The analysis includes uncontrolled charging, smart charging, and vehicle-to-grid (V2G) charging strategies, with an aging model for transformers developed based on the IEEE C57.91 standard. The daily operational cost and annual cost have been analyzed using standard parameters, incorporating the Capital Recovery Factor (CRF). The results demonstrate the effectiveness of smart charging and V2G strategies in optimizing transformer loading and extending their lifecycle.
