title: EEG Artifact Detection in Epilepsy Using Hybrid Deep and Machine Learning
authors: Qindong Yu, Chuan Lin, Chao Wang, Ming Wen
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: Electroencephalography (EEG) for epilepsy inevitably contains artifacts that may obscure epileptiform discharges or, in some cases, provide valuable diagnostic clues. Accurate classification of different artifact types is therefore clinically important. This paper proposes a hybrid artifact classification method that integrates deep learning and handcrafted features. A CNN-CBAM-LSTM network is employed to capture temporal features, while time-domain, frequency-domain, and entropy-based handcrafted features are extracted to complement the representation. The combined feature set is refined using the Relief-F algorithm to reduce redundancy and enhance discriminability, followed by a random forest classifier for final recognition. Experiments were conducted on long-term clinical EEG recordings, including six artifact types: eye movement, muscle, chewing, electrode, blinking, and rhythmic chewing. Results show that the proposed method achieves 97.8% classification accuracy, surpassing existing approaches. By leveraging both the automatic feature learning capability of deep models and the interpretability of handcrafted features, the method demonstrates high accuracy and strong generalization potential for artifact classification in epileptic EEG analysis.

title: Research on the Interpretability of a Mortality Prediction Model for Cardiac Arrest Patients Based on SHAP
authors: Zhengzhen Shen, Xiaolin Deng, Pingping Chen, Huiling Liu, Dingying Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: In-hospital cardiac arrest (IHCA) carries a high mortality risk, making accurate outcome prediction essential for improving resuscitation outcomes. Traditional machine learning models, however, are limited in clinical use due to their “black box” nature. This study built an interpretable mortality prediction model using clinical data from 2, 275 IHCA patients in the MIMIC-IV database. After data preprocessing and feature selection, 78 key features were retained. Eight models, including Random Forest and Logistic Regression, were evaluated, with Logistic Regression demonstrating the best performance. The SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) algorithm was then applied to interpret the Logistic Regression model, highlighting key predictors such as total SOFA score, minimum lactate level, GCS motor response score, total APS III score, and SOFA cardiovascular score. By integrating SHAP with Logistic Regression, this study enhances model transparency and supports clinical decision-making.

title: Grid-Aware Flexibility Operation of Behind-the-Meter Assets: A review of Objectives and Constraints
authors: Elias Mandefro Getie, Hossein Fani, Md Umar Hashmi, Brida V. Mbuwir, Geert Deconinck
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The high penetration of distributed energy resources (DERs) in low-voltage distribution networks (LVDNs) often leads to network instability and congestion. Discovering the flexibility potential of behind-the-meter (BTM) assets offers a promising solution to these challenges, providing benefits for both prosumers and grid operators. This review focuses on the objectives and constraints associated with the operation of BTM flexibility resources in LVDNs. We propose a new classification framework for network-aware flexibility modelling that incorporates prosumer objectives, flexibility sources, and both local and grid-level constraints. This review identifies research gaps in prosumer-centric grid considerations, control strategies, flexibility preferences, and scenarios in the use of BTM resources.

title: SA-CVAE-WGAN: A Method for Simulated Galaxy Image Generation
authors: Jiaqian Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Researching imbalanced small-sample datasets has long been a major challenge in machine learning. Within vast astronomical datasets, observing rare celestial phenomena is highly difficult and costly. Existing models including BigGAN and diffusion models can generate high-resolution images but require enormous computational resources, while simpler models such as Conditional Variational Autoencoder (CVAE) struggle to produce clear images. To address this issue, this paper proposes the SA-CVAE-WGAN model. It integrates the self-attention mechanism and the Wasserstein Generative Adversarial Network with Gradient Penalty (WGAN-GP) framework into the classic Conditional Variational Autoencoder - Generative Adversarial Network (CVAE-GAN), aiming to generate physically sound and visually realistic galaxy images, simultaneously achieving more stable training and lower computational costs. The experimental results presented in this paper encompass three modules: intuitive perception, metric evaluation, and morphological visualization assessment. Findings demonstrate that on the Galaxy10SDSS dataset, the model generates simulation images with excellent visual quality, achieving metrics comparable to large-scale models, while the distribution of simulated images closely resembles that of real images. This research provides a theoretical foundation and practical guidance for developing high-performance, small-scale models for galaxy image generation. As such, it represents a significant contribution to the broader field of astronomical data simulation and analysis.

title: Synthetic Inertia by a Wind Farm-Electrolyzer Unit: Dynamic Optimal Sizing and Service Provision
authors: F. Conte, F. D’Agostino, G. Mosaico, G. Natrella, M. Saviozzi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper proposes a framework based on Model Predictive Control, for the delivery of a synthetic inertia service, coupled with a procedure to dynamically size the inertial response of a unit composed by a wind farm and an electrolyzer. During normal operations, the system meets a continuous demand of hydrogen, maximizes wind generation and gets ready to provide synthetic inertia by optimally sizing the synthetic inertia time constant according to the current unit capability. When a significant frequency drop occurs, according to specific activation rules, the unit provides synthetic inertia with the pre-defined size by coordinating the contribution of the wind turbines and of the electrolyzer. The method is validated through simulations at different wind speed conditions.

title: Comparative Study of Baseline CNNs and Meta-Learning Approaches on PathMNIST
authors: Junia Sam Dani, P.Joyce Beryl Princess
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Deep learning (DL) has transformed medical image analysis, yielding cutting-edge outcomes in tasks including llness detection, segmentation, and classification. These approaches, however, frequently depend on substantial amounts of annotated data, which are hard to come by in the medical field since expert-labeled datasets are few and annotation costs are expensive. A potential approach to get over this restriction is few-shot learning (FSL), which allows models to generalize well from a small number of labeled examples per class. Three typical model families on the PathMNIST subset of the MedMNIST benchmark are thoroughly compared in this study: Transfer learning using (1) Prototypical Networks (ProtoNet), (2) Matching Networks (MatchingNet), and (3) a baseline Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) based on ResNet18. To assess the models' flexibility under various degrees of data scarcity, they are tested in a variety of few-shot scenarios, such as 1-shot, 5-shot, and 10-shot learning. We use a variety of performance parameters, including as accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, Cohen's Kappa, and the Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic curve (AUROC), to guarantee a thorough assessment. The experimental results show that meta-learning approaches, especially ProtoNet and MatchingNet, consistently outperform the baseline in extremely low-data regimes, highlighting their ability to leverage relational inductive biases, while the baseline CNN benefits from increasing training samples and exhibits stable performance in higher-shot scenarios. These results give useful information on the advantages and disadvantages of various FSL paradigms as well as helpful recommendations for creating reliable medical image classification systems in settings with limited data.

title: Goat Weight Recording System with Load Cell and RFID Sensors Using Iot Based Cloud Computing Technology
authors: Nenny Anggraini, Fitri Mintarsih, Mahgrisya Shudhuashar, Luh Kesuma Wardhani, Imam Marzuki Shofi, Nadya Kharima
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Livestock transportation from sellers or farmers to buyers often results in weight changes due to external factors, causing potential disputes and financial losses. Accurate weight data before and after delivery is essential for ensuring fair trade and effective livestock management. This research develops an IoT-based goat weight data collection system using the Prototyping method, integrating an Arduino Uno microcontroller with Load Cell and RFID sensors. The system connects to an Android application and Cloud Computing platform for real-time data transfer and storage. Testing with the Black Box Testing method demonstrated reliable performance, with 32 of 35 scenarios meeting expected results. This solution automates weight measurement and data recording, reducing reliance on manual processes and minimizing human error. It also enables transparent verification of weight changes, preventing fraudulent practices by buyers through cloud-stored records. Beyond transaction accuracy, the system supports broader livestock management, allowing farmers to analyze transportation impacts, optimize feeding schedules, and improve goat health. Data can also be integrated into pricing models to ensure fairness. Overall, the proposed system enhances efficiency, transparency, and trust in livestock trading while providing a scalable approach to modernizing goat farming operations.

title: Human Activity Recognition Leveraging UAV Imagery
authors: S. Vasavi, Himavarshini Bora, Dinesh Murali Nandyala
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Traditional Human Activity Recognition (HAR) systems, commonly used in security and surveillance, have seen significant advancements, including applications involving UAVs to enhance coverage and situational awareness. However, challenges remain in reliably detecting, tracking, and classifying activities across dynamic and crowded environments. This work presents an enhanced HAR system that integrates pose estimation, people tracking, and action classification, leveraging deep learning to address these challenges. Using MediaPipe for precise pose estimation, the system accurately identifies key human body points critical for distinguishing activities. The DeepSORT algorithm, with Kalman filtering, maintains consistent tracking of individuals across multiple frames, even in motion-heavy settings. A ResNet101-based classifier interprets tracked pose sequences to provide accurate activity classification. With an accuracy rate of 97 %, this approach significantly improves performance over traditional HAR systems, providing an effective solution for real-time security and public safety applications.

title: An AI-Driven Framework for Personalized Career Path Recommendations
authors: Senbagavalli M, Gudepu Rakshitha, Sheila Mahapatra, Natuva Bhavana
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: The ongoing and accelerating growth of opportunities in many different industries creates a significant selection challenge for students and professionals when choosing a suitable career path. This challenge is addressed by a Career Recommendation System, a data-driven approach that provides personalized career recommendations based on the user's preferences, educational history, and career goals. Our system uniquely integrates machine learning with a Flask web application to generate customized career paths dynamically. In this paper, we describe the design, development, methods, software configuration, and experimental evaluation of the Career Recommendation System. The system achieved a 95% accuracy rate in recommending relevant career options during trial testing, demonstrating its potential for effective guidance. Additionally, we assess its capability for future adaptation through user feedback and evolving industry trends. The CRS not only benefits its users by offering personalized suggestions but also enhances decision-making through structured roadmaps and subcategory-based recommendations. The CRS bridges the gap between traditional counseling and AI-powered personalized guidance, ensuring relevance in a dynamic career landscape.

title: Image Steganography: A Comprehensive Review of Conventional and Modern Techniques
authors: Sangeeta, Sunita Dhingra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Understanding the concept of image steganography in a fast-changing world is crucial for grasping its significance today and in the future. Image steganography is the art of hiding data, which can be in any form of text, picture, or other media like audio or video, so a person cannot detect it easily with their naked eyes. With the developments in image steganography in early times, this practice has changed significantly, adapting to the changing ground of technology and cyber security. Now, the watermarking scheme is also embedded with image steganography so that the security of the image will be enhanced. These rising strategies (GAN, CNN, deep learning, and artificial intelligence) are crucial for a healthy digital environment. This paper provides a summary of different methods of image steganography. By examining history and modern techniques, this paper reviews the importance of image steganography as a powerful weapon for ensuring privacy, safeguarding intellectual property, and strengthening communication security. Further research is needed to explore new ideas or enhancements in this area for a better future.

title: Efficient Anomaly Detection in Big Data using Improved Random Forest Model
authors: Thirumalaivasan. G, Sudarsan. M, Surya. P, R.Dhanapal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: The system is established as an anomaly detection using different machine-learning techniques to analyze network data during attacks, mostly Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks. The system begins processing data through the Load Data module, which is responsible for feeding the network traffic data from a benchmark dataset into its processes and organizing those data. The loading module can read data from structured data sources, such as databases, CSV, and JSON files, for multi-views of cybercrimes. Proper loading of data ensures that it can be used for further processes, which is essential for a reliable analysis and subsequently for an efficient analysis. The Data Pre-Processing Module works to scrub and refine the original data such that it maintains generality to machine learning classification. This means treating missing values by means of imputation or deletion, encoding categorical variables, either one-hot or through label encoding, and normalizing numerical attributes to prepare them for comparison to one other. Also, removing any other non-predictive features will conserve learning from unnecessary computations and quicken processing. Such adjustments will, therefore, facilitate building a formidable, reliable intrusion detection system. The proposed method allows for DoS threats to be detected from careful analysis of network traffic data augmented with powerful feature engineering, and preprocessing methods. A well-structured dataset adds to the machine learning tool's discrimination of normal versus malicious behavior other than just the employment of standard features or optimization thereof. Thus, this pathway greatly enhances the real-time detection and elimination of threats aiding cybersecurity.

title: Generative AI Performance with DeepSeek: Key Service Quality Attributes from Users
authors: Ashley Tong, Nurhafihz Noor, Zahirah Zainol
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: In the rapidly evolving Generative AI (GenAI) consumer market, DeepSeek, a Chinese artificial intelligence (AI) startup, has emerged as a disruptive force, captured global attention in early 2025 by leading app download rankings and triggering a notable decline in US tech stocks. Amidst widespread media coverage and comparisons against established competitors like ChatGPT, the specific performance attributes of GenAI that matter to users remain underexplored. This study addresses the gap by identifying the key service quality attributes of GenAI that are valued by consumers using DeepSeek. Content analysis on 953 DeepSeek user comments was done using Leximancer to reveal 11 key themes: “AI”, “better”, “app”, “voice”, “feature”, “China”, “using”, “OpenAI”, “accurate”, “update”, and “perfect”. The findings reveal that users highly prioritize attributes such as conversational interaction, multilingual capabilities, and information accuracy, which collectively shape their perception of service quality. Notably, the theme “better” highlights users’ comparative evaluations of DeepSeek against rivals like ChatGPT and Gemini, emphasizing its open-source nature and cost-effectiveness. Meanwhile, themes like “voice” and “feature” underscore the demand for multimodal functionality and continuous innovation, while “China” reflects geopolitical and data privacy considerations influencing user trust. The study extends service-quality perspectives to GenAI by articulating construct-level implications (e.g., multimodality, data-governance trust, comparative value) and translating them into concrete design and governance actions for practitioners. It extends beyond traditional frameworks like SERVQUAL by identifying a set of dimensions unique to AI-driven environments. For practitioners, the findings provide actionable insights for developers and managers to enhance user experience, prioritize feature updates, and address privacy concerns. By aligning GenAI development with consumer expectations, this research supports the creation of more competitive and user-centric AI applications. Future research directions include cross-platform comparisons and longitudinal studies to track evolving service quality standards in the dynamic GenAI landscape.

title: Impact Mechanism and Mitigation Strategy of Pantograph-Catenary Separation on Fault Detection in the Single-Phase Cascaded H-Bridge Rectifier
authors: Xiaoming Xu, Meiqi Wang, Dong Xie, Yutong Zhu, Qipei Qiu, Xinglai Ge
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: This study investigates the adverse impact of pantograph-catenary separation (PCS) on IGBT fault detection in a single-phase cascaded H-bridge rectifier (CHBR). As a critical front-end component in high-speed rail systems, the CHBR is susceptible to voltage and current fluctuations caused by the PCS, which can lead to misdiagnosis in residual-based fault detection. To address this, a mathematical model of the PCS is established to analyze its impact on system states and residual characteristics. Then, an optimized fault detection strategy based on operating condition recognition is proposed. This method dynamically identifies PCS events by monitoring the rectifier's input current and DC-link voltage, thereby blocking the fault detection signal to prevent misdiagnosis. Simulation results confirm the enhanced detection accuracy under various operating conditions, including traction, overvoltage, half-load, and no-load.

title: An Enhanced Convolutional Autoencoder for Multimodel Anomaly Detection
authors: Yihan Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: With the growing demand for anomaly detection in fields such as industrial quality inspection and medical diagnostics, deep learning-based autoencoder methods have demonstrated tremendous potential. This study proposes an Enhanced Convolutional Autoencoder (ECAE) to address image anomaly detection tasks. The model innovatively integrates a multi-scale skip connections architecture and a composite loss function that weights the mean squared error and visual similarity index at a 6:4 ratio, enhancing reconstruction quality through a feature reuse mechanism. Furthermore, ECAE incorporates a triple-modality anomaly scoring system which combines pixel-level reconstruction error, structural similarity measure, and latent space Mahalanobis distance based on robust minimum covariance determinant (MinCovDet) estimation. Experimental results on the MNIST handwritten digit dataset demonstrate that ECAE achieves a detection accuracy of 95.1% and precision of 96.2%, significantly outperforming the other three traditional autoencoder methods. This research provides a high-precision and biologically-inspired solution for industrial visual inspection systems, particularly in precision manufacturing and medical image analysis applications where reliable anomaly detection is critical.

title: AICAWS: Arithmetic Intensity Based Cache-Conscious Adaptive Warp Scheduler
authors: Bo Yuan, Sheng Liu, Zekun Jiang, Jianfeng Cui, Yang Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: General-Purpose Graphics Processing Units (GPGPUs) are crucial for parallel computing in artificial intelligence and big data with their performance heavily relying on efficient warp scheduling. Traditional schedulers, such as Round-Robin (RR) and Greedy-Then-Oldest (GTO), employ static strategies that struggle with adapting to diverse workloads, causing performance disparities across different applications. Prior work has focused on aspects like critical warps and memory access locality but has often overlooked the arithmetic intensity of workloads. Drawing inspiration from the Roofline model and recognizing that different workloads exhibit distinct computational intensities, we propose an Arithmetic Intensity based CacheConscious Adaptive Warp Scheduler (AICAWS). It operates by first analyzing the kernel's static arithmetic intensity through compiler, which serves as a baseline for the hardware. Subsequently, during warp execution, AICAWS dynamically monitors the warp's execution progress, analyzes its runtime arithmetic intensity, and adjusts warp scheduling strategies based on this. Furthermore, AICAWS considers cache locality during warp execution, enabling fine-grained classification of warps based on this. This synergistic mechanism enables AICAWS to effectively hide long-latency memory access operations. Evaluations on diverse benchmarks demonstrate that AICAWS achieves an average performance improvement of 26.3% compared to the baseline scheduler, with a peak improvement of 77.9%.

title: Unmanned Water Quality Monitoring System Based on Millimeter Wave Radar Obstacle Avoidance
authors: Xiaoyu Jing, Zixuan Chen, Jiahao Lu, Chao Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: To address the limitations of traditional water quality monitoring methods in complex environments, a millimeter-wave radar obstacle avoidance unmanned water quality monitoring system has been designed. This system aims to overcome the application limitations of optical and chemical sensors, enabling all-weather, non-contact intelligent monitoring and inversion of water quality parameters. The system uses MIMO FMCW millimeter-wave radar as the core obstacle avoidance sensor. It emits electromagnetic wave signals and receives the echo signals reflected from target objects to determine their distance, speed, and angle. By integrating RVO obstacle avoidance algorithms, the system makes intelligent decisions, achieving autonomous obstacle avoidance and path re-planning with high reliability throughout the day. Users can remotely view data and equipment status via a mobile APP or PC. The system is equipped with a multi-integrated sensor interface designed independently, enabling synchronized monitoring of water quality parameters. This significantly enhances the efficiency and accuracy of water quality monitoring, laying the foundation for the industry's efficient and intelligent development.

title: QUESTA: A Hybrid IRT-Thompson Sampling Algorithm for Adaptive Quizzes Applied to Career Recommendation
authors: Michail Tselepatiotis, Efthimios Alepis
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: In Greece, senior high school students must select a specialized academic field and undertake national examinations that determine university placement. Yet, many students face uncertainty when aligning their interests and skills with future career paths. To address this challenge, we developed a mobile serious game targeting students in the 4th Scientific Field: Economics and Informatics. The system integrates two AI-driven components: a synthetic data-trained machine learning model using Gradient Boosting for initial career field prediction based on interest, and a proposed novel adaptive algorithm called QUESTA that dynamically adjusts a skill-based quiz using Item Response Theory (IRT) and Thompson Sampling. Due to the lack of relevant datasets, we generated a balanced synthetic dataset reflecting student profiles mapped to seven career domains. The system achieved 93% prediction accuracy and was deployed using a scalable cloud-based backend via AWS. Evaluation with 15 high school students revealed high satisfaction, usability, and perceived accuracy of recommendations, with particular strengths in personalization and confidence-building. This study demonstrates how AI-driven adaptivity and gamified design can effectively support personalized career guidance in educational contexts.

title: Wireless Retina Stimulation with Magnetoelectric Nanoparticles
authors: Hadi Mokhtari Dowlatabad, Vitaly Pustovalov, Elric Zhang, Steven T. Walston, Ege Iseri, Kimberly K. Gokoffski, Mark S. Humayun, Sakhrat Khizroev, Salvador Pané, Gianluca Lazzi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Magnetoelectric nanoparticles (MENPs) offer a promising avenue for minimally invasive, wireless neural stimulation by transducing time-varying magnetic fields into localized electric fields capable of modulating neural activity. In this work, we assess the effectiveness of MENPs in stimulating retinal neurons using ex-vivo explants from Thyl-GCaMP6f transgenic rats. Our findings show that MENP-treated retinal tissue exhibited distinct calcium transients in response to pulsed magnetic fields (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20-100 \text{Hz}$</tex>, up to 100 mT), with the most robust responses consistently observed at 50Hz. No such activity was detected in control samples lacking the piezoelectric component. These results validate the capacity of MENPs to elicit targeted neural activation and support their potential as a non-invasive alternative to conventional retinal prosthetics based on electrodes.

title: 5G vs 6G: Advances in Cellular Planning and Their Impact on Population Exposure
authors: Pierpaolo Usai, Danilo Brizi, Agostino Monorchio
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Cellular network planning is a dynamic challenge due to constant technological advancements. Despite evolving generations, wireless signals remain subject to physical constraints like attenuation and diffraction. The transition from 5G to 6G introduces higher frequencies, enhancing capacity but increasing signal loss, requiring innovative solutions like smart antennas. This study compares 5G and 6G coverage in a real scenario, analyzing propagation differences and the need for additional base stations. It also assesses electromagnetic field exposure to evaluate future safety and regulatory implications.

title: CNN-based Epileptic Seizure Detection from EEG Signals
authors: Aaron Ande, P. Joyce Beryl Princess
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: A chronic neurological condition called epilepsy is typified by abrupt, erratic seizures brought on by aberrant brain electrical activity. These seizures may cause injury or other consequences and can vary in severity from mild consciousness loss to severe convulsions. Improving patient safety and care requires quick and precise seizure detection. Electroencephalogram (EEG) recordings are frequently used to track and investigate epilepsy; nevertheless, manual interpretation of these signals is laborious, subjective, and necessitates ongoing professional supervision. In this study, we suggest an automatic method for classifying EEG segments as seizure or non-seizure based on Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). The CHB-MIT Scalp EEG Database, a well-known standard in epilepsy research, was used to train the model. Experimental results indicate that our approach achieves an accuracy of 99%, highlighting its robustness and generalization capability. This framework has the potential to support real-time monitoring and alert systems, thereby reducing diagnostic delays and minimizing the risks associated with epileptic seizures.

title: Model of Fabry-Perot Resonator with Flat Metal and Dielectric Mirrors
authors: Vadym Pazynin, Kostyantyn Sirenko, Wilhelm Keusgen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: We present a model of the classic Fabry-Perot resonator with one of the metal mirrors being replaced by a dielectric mirror. This modification enables efficient filtering of the resonator's eigenmodes without degrading the working oscillation's frequency or quality factor. The results of numerical experiments demonstrate the feasibility of constructing such a quasi-optical resonator whose dimensions exceed the working wavelength by more than an order of magnitude, and which supports a single dominant eigenmode within the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-178 \text{GHz}$</tex> frequency range. The proposed design technique for quasi-optical resonators may be of interest in applications requiring generation and/or selection of oscillations with low phase-noise levels.

title: Comparative Analysis of Individual and Collective Self-Consumption Strategies of PV Equipped Prosumers
authors: Goran Veljanovski, Pande Popovski, Metodija Atanasovski, Petar Krstevski, Aleksandra Krkoleva Mateska, Mirko Todorovski
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative analysis of individual and collective self-consumption strategies in a low-voltage distribution network with rooftop PV-equipped prosumers. Three scenarios are investigated: a base case with no load flexibility, individual prosumer optimization, and a fully coordinated Renewable Energy Community (REC). The optimization problems are formulated as Mixed-Integer Linear Programs (MILPs) with integrated load flow calculations, enabling enforcement of voltage and current constraints to ensure operational feasibility. Simulation results for a representative day show that coordinated load shifting within the REC not only increases local self-consumption but also improves overall network performance. Compared to the base case, voltage deviations are reduced from 15 V to 7 V, network losses fall to one-third of their original level, and the self-consumption rate rises from 57% to 87%, highlighting the effectiveness of centralized appliance scheduling in maximizing the use of locally generated energy.

title: Fault Ride-Through for Hydrogen Electrolyzers
authors: Mohammadhossein Tavanaee, Marc Cheah-Mañe, Oriol Gomis-Bellmunt, Eduardo Prieto-Araujo
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper investigates the Fault Ride-Through (FRT) capability of a Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM) electrolyzer system supported by Supercapacitor (SC) energy storage under symmetrical fault conditions. Three configurations are analyzed: a baseline case without SC integration, SCs directly connected to the DC link, and SCs interfaced via a DC/DC converter. To evaluate the system behavior under these configurations, a dynamic model of the PEM electrolyzer is implemented to capture its transient response. Based on this model, analytical formulas are derived for sizing the energy buffer required to maintain continuous operation during grid disturbances. In parallel, a unified control strategy is proposed to coordinate power flow between the grid, SCs, and the electrolyzer. Time-domain simulations confirm that only the SC-supported configurations maintain uninterrupted hydrogen production during a severe grid voltage sag. The DC/DC-based layout reduces the number of SCs and offers greater control flexibility, while the direct connection provides a simpler solution. These results provide design insight for the robust integration of hydrogen systems into future power grids.

title: Research on YOLOv9 Object Detection Algorithm Based on Multi-Attention
authors: Liyuan Xie, Hongfei Wu, Nianjie Li, Xianzhao Fu, Sai Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: In the context of rapid advancements in deep learning technology, object detection algorithms represented by the YOLO series have been widely applied. However, they still face issues of low detection accuracy and poor detection efficiency in certain fields, urgently requiring new solutions. To address this, this paper introduces an object detection algorithm named “YOLOv9-SpeedPin.” This model builds upon YOLOv9 by incorporating several innovations. Specifically, it replaces the Backbone network with GhostNetV2, modifies the Head to include the GSConv+Slim-Neck module, and substitutes the ADown in the Auxiliary Branch with the HWD module, all aimed at reducing the computational workload of the model. By incorporating the three attention mechanisms of LSKA, GAM, and SENet, the model ensures enhanced precision. YOLOv9-SpeedPin achieves a 4.3% improvement in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mAP}_{50}$</tex> and a 4.8% increase in detection speed. Compared to existing algorithms under the same conditions, this algorithm maintains a higher accuracy advantage. Furthermore, the occurrences of false positives and missed detections are significantly reduced.

title: Tips: Augment Memory Tagging to Defend Against Prefetcher Side Channels
authors: Yubiao Huang, Peinan Li, Huan Qiao, Yunkai Bai, Shiwen Wang, Dan Meng, Rui Hou
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Hardware prefetchers are essential for hiding memory latency and improving performance in commercial processors. However, recent studies have revealed that they can be exploited to launch side-channel attacks that leak sensitive data, recover cryptographic keys, and break the isolation of trusted execution environments. We observe that such attacks closely resemble classic memory safety violations, including buffer overflows, type confusion, use-after-free, and data race. This paper presents TIPS (Tag AugmentatIon for Prefetcher Security), a lightweight extension to the memory safety mechanisms already deployed in commercial processors. TIPS enhances memory tagging to protect prefetchers by enforcing tag-based array bounds, validating pointer types, associating prefetch patterns with their source threads or cores, and suppressing contentionbased interference. Experiments demonstrate that TIPS incurs less than 1.50 % performance overhead and 0.81 % area cost, while providing strong defense against a broad class of prefetcher side-channel attacks.

title: Design and Deployment of an Educational IoT-Based Micro Ecosystem with micro:bit Integration
authors: Dimitris Tsipianitis, Vasilis Koumenteas, Anastasia Misirli, Konstantinos Lavidas, Vassilis Komis
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: With the exponential advancement of technology, the need for education in the fields of science and engineering is more crucial than ever. Students must be introduced to scientific concepts at an earlier age and through more hands-on educational practices, in order to not only build a solid foundation in science and technology but also to develop a genuine passion for turning their ideas into reality. Educational IoT integrated systems offer an innovative methodology that combines fundamental sciences, emerging information and communication technologies, and insights from the study of human behavior. The integration of IoT-based projects into the “digital school” is supported by contemporary learning theories, which assert that knowledge creation becomes more effective when students are actively engaged in constructing products that hold personal meaning. Furthermore, educational IoT integrated systems foster critical thinking, creativity, and resilience by encouraging students to develop their own strategies for addressing challenges under proper guidance. The ultimate objective is to empower students to build functional projects from scratch using smart academic tools that automate the most complex processes, allowing them to first internalize essential concepts with confidence. This paper presents the design and implementation of a simple educational microecosystem, demonstrating how fundamental principles from control systems, the Internet of Things (IoT), and automation can be effectively combined to enhance student learning and engagement.

title: Deep Learning-Based Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring for Identification of Distributed Energy Resources in the Presence of Conventional Devices
authors: Mohammadreza Shekari, Daniel Koster, André Guimaraes Madureira, Geert Deconinck
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The rapid adoption of distributed energy resources (DERs), such as photovoltaic (PV) systems, has introduced significant challenges to electrical distribution networks, especially in monitoring consumption and generation within low-voltage networks at the household level. This paper proposes a novel deep learning method for non-intrusive load monitoring (NILM) to identify DERs within aggregated household energy data. This method uses a sequence-to-point algorithm to differentiate DER energy signatures from overlaying consumption patterns of conventional devices. Findings demonstrate superior performance compared to existing methods in identifying DER contribution, addressing critical gaps in NILM applications for DERs, and providing a solution to enhance the flexibility of households.

title: Secure File Exchange Privacy-Focused Secure File Exchange with Variable-Sized Chunking and Automated Expiry for Scalable Organizational Sharing
authors: Gutla Jessica, Yelisetti Sandeep, Thunuguntla Bhanu Sri Sai Someshu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: With increasing digital use, ensuring safe and effective file exchange between any two parties of the organization has become a challenge. Conventional file-sharing solutions fell short of effectively handling larger files and robust privacy controls. This study provides a safe file-sharing system which uses Automatic File Expiration which enhances the security and confidentiality of data. Variable-Sized Chunking is another feature that ensures maximum storage utilization. The system reduces redundancy and enhances performance by dynamically chunking files via the Rolling Hash Algorithm. We used Time-to-Live (TTL) and Cron Jobs to automate file expiration for easy cleanups. In addition, a log system is always maintained that monitors user activity. This ensures accountability by documenting recent activities such as uploading, downloading, forwarding files, etc., to trace irregularities. We make sure that the right people can send, forward, and download the files in the organization with the help of JWT authentication. By creating bridges between these technologies the platform increases data integrity, security, and compliance that helps in handling large files with ease in an organization. The system achieved an 8.98 % gain in storage efficiency, while maintaining secure access controls and enabling seamless large file handling across enterprise networks.

title: Interactive Web-Based Pandemic Spread Simulator with Agent Mobility and Contact Modeling Using Three.js
authors: P. Ashok Babu, Gurupriya Adurthy, Vydhika Laxmi Tata, Shashi Vardhan Cherala
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: This work introduces a web-enabled framework for comparative epidemic modeling, focusing on COVID-19, Ebola, and Influenza. The system integrates a lightweight browser-based interface, developed with modern web technologies, and a backend simulation engine that applies agent-based modeling to capture disease transmission and progression. The platform enables users to configure outbreak parameters, visualize spread dynamics in a virtual urban environment, and extract quantitative insights. Core epidemiological indicators-such as infection peaks, fatality rates, and recovery trends-were examined by scaling population size while maintaining disease-specific constants. Experimental outcomes demonstrate marked differences in outbreak intensity and healthcare impact across the diseases, with population density emerging as a critical factor in epidemic escalation. By combining interactive visualization with analytical modeling, this study provides a flexible tool for public health assessment, IoT-driven data integration, and policy exploration under diverse epidemic scenarios.

title: Design and Research on LeNet5 Convolutional Neural Network Accelerator Based on HLS
authors: Chengyi Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: This study presents the design and implementation of a LeNet-5 convolutional neural network (CNN) accelerator based on High-Level Synthesis (HLS) technology, focusing on hierarchical architecture analysis and non-linear mapping mechanisms to establish a theoretical foundation for hardware optimization. Modular designs incorporating HLS-specific strategies are developed for convolutional, pooling, and fully connected layers, achieving significant improvements validated through MNIST dataset evaluation: 98.5 % prediction accuracy (matching PyTorch's <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{98.7 \%}), \text{60}$</tex>-microsecond single-frame latency at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{150~MHz,~} \text{56 \%}$</tex> reduction in DDR accesses with 3.2 times computational density enhancement in convolutional layers via Dynamic Window Cache (DWC), 68% logical resource reduction in pooling layers using zero-delay dual buffering and piecewise Sigmoid approximation, and 50 % memory bandwidth reduction with 8 times throughput improvement in fully connected layers through mixed-precision quantization and block-wise MAC operations. The accelerator consumes 1.8 W dynamically with 3.2 TOPS/W energy efficiency, providing an edge-deployable solution that demonstrates superior inference speed, energy efficiency, and resource utilization compared to CPU and RTL baselines.

title: Power Quality Disturbance Recognition Based on Multi-Modal Fusion of 2DCNN-GRU-AT
authors: Zhaojun Wang, Weilong Wen, Jiayang Li, Jihua Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: To enhance the accuracy of power quality disturbance (PQD) identification in smart grids, this paper presents a multimodal fusion classification method that integrates two-dimensional convolutional neural networks (2DCNN), gated recurrent units (GRU), and the self-attention mechanism (AT). First, the temporal data of PQD signals are transformed into two distinct image modalities using Gram Angular Summation Field (GASF) and Markov Transition Field (MTF), followed by grayscale fusion. The fused images are then input into the 2DCNN to extract spatial features, while the perturbed signal is processed by the GRU to capture temporal features. Finally, the extracted features are enhanced and fused using the AT mechanism. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively overcomes the limitations of single-modal approaches by combining information from multiple modalities, significantly improving the accuracy of disturbance recognition.

title: A Machine Learning-Enhanced Satellite Snowfall Rate Product and Its Application in Nowcasting
authors: Huan Meng, Yongzhen Fan, Jun Dong, Yulan Hong, Aaron Jacobs, Carl Dierking, Kris White, Emily Berndt
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Snowfall Rate product is derived from measurements taken by passive microwave radiometers aboard a constellation of Low Earth Orbit satellites. The algorithm consists of two independent components: snowfall detection and rate estimation. Snowfall is detected using a machine learning model trained on global ground observations, while snowfall rate is estimated using a 1DVAR-based algorithm and enhanced with machine learning technique. This product is operationally produced at NOAA in near real-time and has demonstrated its value in winter season nowcasting.

title: Interpretable Leaf Disease Detection in Home Gardens with an Efficient Deep Learning Approach
authors: Muhammad Al Husaini, Hen Hen Lukmana, Muhammad Sidik Asyaky, Rinaldi Rizal Putra, Rita Fitriani, Diana Hernawati
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Home-garden agriculture plays a vital role in household food security but is highly susceptible to crop diseases that can significantly reduce yields. Traditional detection methods are often constrained by subjectivity, dependence on expert knowledge, and limited resources. This study presents an interpretable deep learning framework for leaf disease detection in home gardens, combining EfficientNetV2M with Gradientweighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM). A publicly available dataset was used, with images preprocessed and augmented before training via transfer learning. Grad-CAM outputs were enhanced with bounding boxes to precisely highlight symptomatic leaf regions, providing transparent and user-friendly visual explanations. The proposed model achieved 97% test accuracy, with balanced precision, recall, and F1-scores across classes, demonstrating strong generalization under realistic conditions. By improving diagnostic reliability and fostering user trust, this approach offers a practical, accurate, and interpretable tool for plant disease detection, underscoring the potential of integrating state-of-the-art deep learning with explainable AI for sustainable home-garden agriculture.

title: Research on the Deployment of Smart Home Data Collection Modules Based on DeepSeek Nvidia Jetson Nano
authors: Zhipeng Zhang, Chengyu Wu, Dan Wang, Wenyan Xu, Yuxiang Du, Lingli Zhang, Yuxi Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: This paper conducts research on the deployment of smart home data collection modules based on DeepSeek and Nvidia Jetson Nano, and proposes an adaptive dynamic weight data collection algorithm (ADWDA). The algorithm uses a dynamic analysis mechanism of data features and an adaptive weight adjustment strategy to perceive the data change trend and importance in real time, and dynamically allocate sensor collection weights. The experiment built a smart home simulation environment containing multiple sensors such as temperature, humidity, and light, and used 100,000 pieces of data actually collected as samples to compare with traditional fixed-period collection algorithms and threshold-triggered collection algorithms. The results show that the data collection accuracy of the ADWDA algorithm reaches 98.6%, which is 16.3% higher than the traditional algorithm; the average CPU usage is reduced to 28.7%, and the memory usage is reduced by 21.5%; the data collection delay is shortened to 32 ms, which is more than 60% lower than the traditional algorithm. Experiments show that the acquisition module based on DeepSeek and Nvidia Jetson Nano combined with the ADWDA algorithm significantly improves the efficiency and accuracy of data acquisition while ensuring low power consumption, providing a better solution for smart home data processing.

title: Impact of Hydrogen Electrolysers to Grid Stability
authors: Shailendra Kumar Jha, Irina Oleinikova, Basanta Raj Pokhrel, Andrei Z. Morch
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Deployment of large volumes of hydrogen electrolysers is increasing in the electrical power grid and there is an emerging need to study their integration possibilities in the transmission networks. This paper studies the possibilities and impact of integration of hydrogen electrolysers in the Nordic Grid. Nordic 45 Grid model is simulated in an offline real time environment. Hydrogen electrolysers are modeled and interconnected in the transmission network to analyse the grid ability to withstand the integration. The simulation is conducted for the 2025 and 2030 load conditions, considering the expected hydrogen production from electrolysers by 2030. MATLAB and OPAL RT are used for the real time simulation of the Nordic 45 Grid model in the laboratory. Grid frequency stability and bus voltages are the key performance indicators considered. The implementation of a central frequency controller with sequential operation of multiple electrolysers in the network has also been examined.

title: Implementing a Network Firewall for Constrained IoT Environments
authors: Girish B G, Suresh Kumar H S, Shaik Al Kashifah, Keerthana R, Vinutha TN, Architha KN
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) is rapidly transforming modern society, driving efficiencies and advancements across various sectors, from healthcare to smart homes and industrial automation. However, the vast adoption of IoT devices has created significant cyber security challenges. These devices, often lacking robust security measures, expose users and critical infrastructures to cyber-attacks. High-profile incidents like the 2016 Mirai botnet attack and the 2021 water treatment facility hack highlight the severe risks associated with unsecured IoT devices. This project proposes the development of an advanced firewall system for IoT devices, addressing these vulnerabilities and mitigating potential threats. The firewall solution integrates the ESP-NOW communication protocol, which ensures secure, peer-to-peer communication between devices, reducing reliance on centralized systems and minimizing attack surfaces. By incorporating encryption, access control, and secure data transmission, the firewall offers a proactive approach to protecting IoT ecosystems from unauthorized access and exploitation. This solution is designed to be scalable and adaptable, ensuring its applicability across diverse IoT use cases, from personal devices to critical infrastructure systems.

title: AlumniSphere: AI Driven Web Platform for Dynamic Alumni Relations
authors: Elizabeth Rani G, Jeffina J, Sindhuja R, Hari S M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Alumni engagement is vital for building strong networks, improving career opportunities for students, and fostering lasting connections. However, traditional alumni portals are often outdated, underused, and lack features for meaningful interaction. This proposed work presents Alma-Connect AI, a web-based alumni engagement platform that uses Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) to create a lively and interactive space for students, alumni, and administrators. The system offers role-based access. Alumni can share structured success stories, post job opportunities, and provide mentorship. Students can ask for guidance, explore curated opportunities, and connect with relevant alumni. An AI-powered recommendation engine suggests possible connections, mentors, and opportunities based on skills, industry, and career interests. A Smart Success Story Analyzer pulls key insights from alumni contributions, making them searchable and useful. ML models further boost engagement by recommending personalized career paths and identifying trending skills within the alumni network. The platform includes real-time chat, connection dashboards, and a secure profile system to encourage collaboration. It also has multilingual support, advanced search options, and analytics dashboards for administrators to monitor engagement patterns. By combining Supabase for web deployment with AI/ML-driven recommendations, Alma-Connect AI connects traditional alumni directories with modern professional networks. The proposed system standardizes interactions between alumni and students, improves mentorship, supports career development, and strengthens long-term ties with the institution. Future improvements may include sentiment analysis for alumni feedback, predictive modeling for career outcomes, and closer integration with university learning systems.

title: Combining Large Language Model and Supportive Models for Legal Question Answering
authors: Long Vu Van, Hai Le Hong
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: This paper details the methods proposed by the BAMBOOVN team during their participation in the 5th Automated Legal Question Answering Competition (ALQAC 2025). During the competition we have to resolve two main tasks: Legal Document Retrieval and Legal Question Answering. For the Legal Document Retrieval task we applied an ensemble method: semantic searching with embedding outputs from BGE-M3 transformer model and traditional ranking methods using word information: BM25, TF-IDF supported by a topic classification model. After pre-ranking step we used a relevant classification model to grade the retrieved document as relevant or not relevant. These supportive models (topic/relevant classification) were trained by combining both original data and LLM-augmented data for better accuracy. The final score is combined using tuned hyperparameters and will be compared with an ensemble threshold to get filtered. For the Legal Question Answering task, we have three types of questions: true/false questions, multiple-choices question and free-text question. Suppose that the retrieved document from previous stage is correct, we address this problem by using Large Language Model (LLM) with prompt engineering technique to attain the generalization of LLM on the question answering task. While our approach did not attain the highest scores in the competition, it proved that using LLM-synthesized data within an adaptive pipeline (integrating LLMs with auxiliary models) effectively mitigates data scarcity limitations.

title: Implantable Reconfigurable FSS for Wireless Protection of Implantable Cardiac Devices in the ISM Band
authors: Francesco Lestini, Fabiola Bassano, Gaetano Marrocco, Cecilia Occhiuzzi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This paper presents a novel reconfigurable electro-magnetic shield for securing cardiac Implantable Medical Devices (IMDs) against unauthorized access over the 2.45 GHz Industrial, Scientific, and Medical (ISM) band. The proposed shield is conceived to be permanently implanted and placed above the pacemaker within the subcutaneous pocket, thereby providing continuous protection without affecting patient comfort or device usability. The shield is implemented as a wireless reconfigurable Frequency Selective Surface (FSS) incorporating varactor diodes and Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) Integrated Circuits (ICs) to enable dynamic switching between transparent (ON) and shielded (OFF) states. The FSS unit cell comprises a Jerusalem Cross surrounded by an inductive grid, ensuring polarization-independent operation and parallel biasing of the varactors. Fullwave electro-magnetic simulations of the unit cell inserted in a layered human body model confirm the feasibility of the idea, showing a variation in the transmission coefficient <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S_{21}$</tex> exceeding 28 dB between the OFF and ON states and insensitivity to linear and circular polarization.

title: Robust Attendance Management System Using Face Recognition and Location-Based Verification
authors: Sushma V, Anant Kumar Sahu, Ritesh Kumar, Shlesha, Siddharth Prabhu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Face recognition is increasingly utilized in biometrics, security, and attendance management systems. Traditional manual attendance processes are time-consuming and prone to human error. This study presents an automated attendance system based on facial recognition to enhance efficiency and accuracy. The proposed system employs facial detection, alignment, and identification using Histogram of Oriented Gradients (HOG) for feature extraction and Support Vector Machine (SVM) for classification. A web-based interface enables attendance tracking, student registration, and training data management. The system is developed using Django with an SQLite database for seamless backend integration. Performance evaluation indicates improved accuracy and reduced processing time compared to manual methods. This system is particularly suitable for educational institutions and organizations where security and precision are critical.

title: Integrated Electric Drive and Wireless Charging Architecture for Electric Vehicles
authors: Mahesh Aganti, C. Bharatiraja, P. Sanjeevikumar, Paweł Szcześniak
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: This paper presents a compact and efficient motor drive system integrated with wireless charging for electric vehicles (EVs). Utilizing a series-series (SS) compensated wireless power transfer circuit, the design emphasizes high efficiency, reduced cost, and space savings. A modified bidirectional three-phase inverter serves dual functions: operating as an AC/DC converter during wireless charging and as an inverter for motor drive control, reducing the need for separate components. A DC-DC converter manages battery charging, ensuring proper voltage regulation. Depending on system requirements, the proposed topology supports dual-mode operation, functioning as a 1 kW wireless charger or a 1 kW motor drive. The SS compensation improves power transfer efficiency and minimizes passive component size. MATLAB simulations validate the system’s performance across varied operating conditions. This integrated approach provides a practical and scalable solution for EV power electronics, enhancing functionality, reducing hardware complexity, and promoting efficient energy management in electric mobility applications.

title: EcoDriving based approach to trip speed profile optimization for optimal power consumption of a frugal battery electric vehicle
authors: Vít Pawlik, Petr Denk, Rastislav Toman
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The EcoDriving approach is based on a priori knowledge of the route and its attributes and focuses on optimizing the velocity profile along the selected route. The goal is to optimize the power consumption and the driving time by finding the optimal speed for each section of the route, with consideration of the legal and vehicle limits. This paper deals with the method of optimizing the speed profile along a route for a light frugal electric vehicle for urban use under L5, L6 and L7 category with 6kW powertrain and modular battery configuration. The proposed method is computationally simple and can be run repeatedly to deal with changing traffic conditions.

title: Risk-Aware Contracting Strategies for Electrolytic Hydrogen Projects Facing Grid Congestion
authors: Thomas Swarts, Wouter van Den Akker, Johan Morren, Arjan van Voorden, Han Slootweg
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Electrolytic hydrogen is expected to play a key role in decarbonizing energy systems in Europe. However, such projects face uncertain grid access due to congestion and struggle with financial viability. To address growing grid congestion in the Netherlands, different types of non-firm connection and transport agreements (CTAs) and capacity restriction contracts (CRCs) were introduced, enabling client curtailment in exchange for tariff discounts or per-MW compensation. This paper investigates investment and contracting decisions for electrolyzer projects under these novel contracts using a two-stage risk-aware stochastic optimization model that captures uncertainty in electricity prices and grid access. Results show that risk-averse clients prefer non-firm CTA-85 contracts, which balance tariff discounts with curtailment compensation, while risk-neutral clients favor standard non-firm CTAs. The new contract types can lower the break-even hydrogen price by approximately €0.50/kg compared to firm contracts outside congested areas, and thus improve the business case for electrolytic hydrogen in the Netherlands.

title: Impact of Neighborhood-Energy-Sharing-Systems on Distribution Grids
authors: Carlo Tajoli, Yi Guo, Philipp Heer, Gabriela Hug
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Interconnecting neighboring buildings as a multi-energy system enables efficient sharing of electric and thermal energy. However, the operation of the heating devices according to the users’ goals does not necessarily align with the needs of the distribution grid. In this paper, we propose a bi-level optimization-based approach to assess the impact and benefits of Neighborhood-Energy-Sharing-Systems (NESSs) on distribution grids through demand response programs. The lower-level opti-mization models the thermal dynamics of each NESS, capturing its flexibility to support the distribution grid while minimizing energy costs. The upper-level optimization aims to minimize the curtailment of photovoltaic (PV) generation and space heating loads, subject to grid operational constraints. Numerical experiments highlight the advantages of interconnected, multi-source heating systems in delivering heating demand without compromising user comfort and violating grid constraints.

title: AI - Driven Design Pattern Recommendation System for Enhanced Software Architecture
authors: Sangeeta Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: The ever growing complexity of software systems makes it imperative to use automated techniques in proposing and deploying design patterns to enhance the maintainability, modularity and lessen the coupling of the software. Conventional methods may be mostly based on manual detection or small to medium amount of heuristic-driven tools which may be time consuming, error prone and may not generalize across different code bases. In response to this, we introduce an artificial intelligence-based recommendation system that combines multimodal software representations, knowledge graphs, and self-supervised pretraining to identify, suggest, and generate design pattern refactorings. The system builds a rich repository of design patterns, and quality attributes, trade-offs and transformation rules are represented in a machine-readable form. A high-quality dataset is built by heuristic-based static analysis, expert verification, and synthetic data augmentation using source code, documentation, commit histories, and runtime logs. GNNs and transformer models are used to supplement multi-modal embeddings based on ASTs, control-data flow, dependency networks, and token-level embeddings to reflect structural, behavioral, and semantic nuances. Knowledge graph captures patterns, anti-patterns, and refactoring rules, and makes prescriptive recommendations. Experimental analysis into the Design Patterns Detection Benchmark Dataset shows that the system outperforms the current methods with 92.4-percent precision, 90.8-percent recall, 91.6-percent F1-score, and 93.2-percent accuracy and the shortest runtime of 1.8 seconds. Findings verify the fact that the suggested methodology does not only lead to increased accuracy in prediction, but also to increased practical efficiency, providing a powerful, scalable solution to automated design pattern recommendation and refactoring.

title:
