                    Hash: A Read-Optimized and Resize-Friendly Hashing Index for Persistent Memory
authors: Jinlei Hu, Bo Chen, Miaosong Zhang, Jing Hu, Jianxi Chen, Dan Feng
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Persistent memory (PM) offers a compelling combination of durability and near-DRAM performance, but it also introduces new challenges for hashing indexes. Existing persistent hashing designs prioritize resizing efficiency at the expense of increased query latency, losing the key advantage of hash tables. This paper introduces <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{2}$</tex> Hash, a persistent hashing index redesigned from the persistent cache-line hash table, to balance high read performance with efficient resizing. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> Hash is guided by a migration rule, enabling it to meet both goals through two main contributions: (i) a cooperative and lowoverhead resizing strategy based on split-order hashing, and (ii) a shift-aware search combined with a two-layer bucket layout that enables lock-free reads with only one PM access on average. Furthermore, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{2}$</tex> Hash provides log-free consistency and a nonblocking recovery mechanism. Experimental results demonstrate that <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> Hash achieves up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8.1 \times$</tex> higher search throughput and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.5 \times$</tex> higher insert throughput compared to other persistent hash indexes across a range of workloads.

title: Outdoor Design Image Generation Based on Diffusion
authors: Yuchen Meng, Keyin Zhu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Diffusion-based generative models have demonstrated outstanding performance in high-quality image synthesis. However, challenges persist in terms of structural controllability, computational efficiency, and adaptability to diverse conditional inputs. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes SF-SD (Steady Flow Stable Diffusion), an enhanced diffusion framework that integrates architectural optimizations to improve generation fidelity, structural coherence, and efficiency. The proposed SF-SD model incorporates three key components: a feature compression module that leverages an autoencoder to project high-dimensional image data into a compact latent space, significantly reducing computational and storage costs; a conditional information modeling mechanism that combines semantic cues and structural features via a cross-attention mechanism, enhancing the model's responsiveness to user-defined prompts; and a skeletal control module that utilizes edge-based constraints to preserve object contours and spatial layout during the generation process. To assess its performance, a dedicated high-resolution dataset was constructed, and extensive comparative experiments were conducted against standard Stable Diffusion, conditional-enhanced diffusion models, and GAN-based methods. Quantitative results show that SF-SD achieves superior SSIM, PSNR, and FID scores, while reducing generation time by over 40% and improving semantic alignment. Ablation studies further demonstrate the independent contribution of each module to the overall performance improvement. SF-SD provides a scalable and generalizable framework for controllable image generation under multi-modal constraints. The proposed model is particularly well-suited for applications requiring structure-aware, high-fidelity synthesis within computationally constrained environments.

title: Mpox Risk Forecasting: Integrating Neural Networks and Public Sentiment Analysis
authors: Sumana SG, Monish L, Shaila SG, Sandhya Madhuri, Ananya Shankhdhar, ZA Abdul Ahanaaf
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: The research in infectious disease forecasting has picked up a lot of momentum in recent years with the advent of AI-driven models that offer real-time forecasts. Conventional epidemiological models are limited in their ability to forecast outbreaks because they rely on past data and are not adaptable in real time. The study herein presents a novel approach to Mpox outbreak risk prediction by combining Deep Neural Network (DNN) predictive modelling and public opinion analysis. The DNN model utilizes epidemiological indicators, demographic factors, and spatial parameters for forecasting potential outbreak hotspots with improved accuracy compared to traditional statistical methods. In parallel, we captured public sentiment on Mpox through natural language processing of social media, news stories, and public health alerts. The results of 0.997 accuracy indicate robust correlations between trends in public perception and outbreak dynamics, providing valuable insights into community knowledge and response readiness. This two-way process enables public health professionals not only to predict risk areas but also to understand the social determinants underlying disease spread. The findings demonstrate that predictive modelling in combination with sentiment analysis is a more complete risk assessment strategy, facilitating improved and directed intervention efforts. It is an interventional methodology for surveillance and response that is transferable to other future infectious diseases, illustrating the utility of including social information in epidemiological modelling.

title: ViT-Based Semantic Feature Extraction and Cluster-Based Dimensionality Reduction for Medical Images
authors: Cheng Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: In recent years, remarkable progress has been made in the application of deep learning in medical image analysis. However, traditional convolutional neural networks (CNNS) have limitations in capturing the global context information of images. While Visual Transformer (ViT) has the ability to model long-range dependencies, it is prone to problems such as feature redundancy and insufficient generalization ability on small-scale medical image datasets. To this end, this paper proposes an improved model based on ViT, combining the Semantic attention Filtering and parameter clustering dimension reduction module (TSFS: Transformer with Semantic Filtering and Selection). This method screens out the most discriminative image regions through learnable query vectors and introduces an end-to-end differentiable clustering mechanism, thereby generating compact and information-rich image representations. The results, based on both qualitative and quantitative analyses, demonstrate that TSFS outperforms both CNN and ViT-based transformers in medical image classification tasks.

title: Estimation of PV Generation using Empirical University Campus Data
authors: Debajyoti Biswas, Yashita Jain, Paul Noonan, Anna Mutule, Paula Carroll
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Large university campuses are micro-societies and mini-cities with significant opportunities to lead by example in the clean energy transition. They often used Building Energy Management Systems (BEMS) to monitor and control energy supply and demand. However, this data could be further exploited to provide a better understanding of the performane of renewables in specific geographical regions. In this paper we leverage empirical data from a public university BEMS for research purposes, aiming to provide insights for citizen groups such as energy communities who need support to make long term planning decisions. We evaluate statistical and machine learning models of photovoltaic (PV) power generation from PV arrays on university buildings, and provide a tool to estimate PV generation to support energy community planning decisions.

title: Design and Analysis of Perforated Ground Plane for Mode Conversion Mitigation in High-Speed Differential Channel of Die-To-Die Interface
authors: Hyunwoo Kim, Seunghun Ryu, Sanguk Lee, Seonghi Lee, Dongryul Park, Jinwook Lee, Seungyoung Ahn
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Advanced Interconnects (WAI)
abstract: In this paper, we present a perforated ground plane design that effectively mitigates mode conversion in high-speed differential channels. The proposed design employs perforated ground unit cells (PGUCs) with symmetric geometry and periodic arrangement to achieve uniform return current distribution. Mode conversion analysis using UCIe die-to-die interfaces demonstrates consistent performance around -70 dB across different channel configurations, compared to conventional designs varying from -68.5 dB to -43 dB depending on channel placement.

title: Algorithm for Constructing Educational Dynamic Knowledge Graph and Predicting Intervention Nodes Based on LLM-GNN Fusion
authors: Yixuan Song, Ling Fu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Students encounter multi-dimensional dynamic challenges in the learning process, while traditional student performance analysis, which relies on static data, fails to capture the complex relationships in learning behaviors, resulting in delayed interventions. To address this issue, this paper proposes an algorithm for constructing educational dynamic knowledge graphs and predicting intervention nodes by integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) and Graph Neural Networks (GNNs). The semantic understanding capability of LLMs (such as parsing homework errors and classroom needs) assists GNNs in building a dynamic heterogeneous knowledge graph of “students-knowledge points-teaching resources-interactive behaviors”, breaking the limitations of static data. To make up for the deficiency of GNNs in deep semantic mining, a knowledge-based semantic structure mining module (combined with Qwen2) is designed to improve the accuracy of node representation. In addition, an Integrated One Graph (IOG) module is adopted to unify individual and group classification into the prediction of “key intervention nodes”, enhancing the generalization ability across educational scenarios. Experimental results show that the IOG-CIQAN model achieves an accuracy of over 87 % in tasks such as performance early warning and personalized path recommendation, outperforming traditional machine learning baselines. This study provides an effective technical framework for precise educational intervention.

title: An Agent-Based Assessment of Household Flexibility for Distribution Grid Stability
authors: Bart Overdevest, Hossein Nasrollahi, Ioannis Lampropoulos, Hans Beckers, Wilfried van Sark
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The growth in the adoption of electric vehicles and heat pumps poses new challenges to low-voltage electricity networks due to increased peak loads and local congestion. This paper investigates how implicit (price-based) and explicit (control-based) flexibility mechanisms can be combined at the household level to mitigate these challenges. In this study, an agent-based simulation was developed to model a residential neighborhood in the Netherlands with varying levels of participation in flexibility programs. Results show that implicit flexibility, particularly at moderate levels of adoption, provides considerable cost savings but limited congestion relief. Explicit flexibility is more effective at reducing congestion, especially at high participation levels, albeit affecting comfort and generating additional costs. A combination of the two flexibility strategies eliminates congestion entirely and introduces trade-offs in comfort. This approach offers a robust solution for managing low-voltage grid congestion while optimizing household costs and minimizing distribution system operator compensation for explicit flexibility.

title: Symbolic Infrastructure: A Framework for Transhuman Co-Creation and Knowledge Mediation
authors: Michael Sfakianakis, Maria Elisavet Kampi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: In the age of data abundance, the challenge is no longer access to information, but the capacity to render it intelligible, sensorially meaningful, and culturally resonant. This paper introduces symbolic infrastructure - a new transdisciplinary framework through which aestheticmaterial systems mediate complex knowledge within human-machine ecosystems. Drawing from semiotics, actor-network theory, object-oriented ontology, and transhumanist thought, symbolic infrastructure positions artist-designed interfaces not as visual add-ons, but as active architectures of cognition. Rather than reducing complexity, symbolic infrastructures translate it into experiential formats using digital aesthetics, affective cognition, and multimodal interaction. Interfaces, installations, garments, and visualizations do not merely represent data—they enact data. These symbolic agents function as connective tissues between disciplines and audiences, enabling knowledge to be co-created and inhabited across technological and cultural contexts. The concept is both theorized and tested through Data Landscapes and the Body Silos (2024), an art exhibition developed through sustained collaboration with an AI curatorial assistant. This case study operationalizes symbolic infrastructure as a dynamic system of transhuman co-creation. By foregrounding symbolic infrastructure, the paper proposes a new paradigm for knowledge mediation—one in which digital aesthetics and machine collaboration expand our modes of understanding in the post-digital condition.

title: Machine Learning for Genetic Disease Prediction: A Systematic Review
authors: Eric Savero Hermawan, Gregorius Natanael Elwirehardja, Kuncahyo Setyo Nugroho, Bens Pardamean
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ICoAIT)
abstract: Genetic data has been the focus of identifying diseases for treatment and prevention. Machine Learning (ML) and statistical models are applied for early detection using genetic features. This review has selected 11 studies on ML models to summarize the trends, opportunities, and challenges. Deep Learning (DL) has proven to be one of the most effective ML approaches, achieving an accuracy rate above 80%. Classic ML methods, however, remain relevant, particularly for feature selection or as classifiers when the dataset is limited. The high dimensionality of genetic data highlights the importance of effective feature selection. Although results vary, one study employing an assisted DL approach reported 100% accuracy, demonstrating the potential of combining DL with feature filtering. Overall, ML methods show promise in capturing feature-level nuances. However, they still require feature selection and multimodal data integration strategies to address challenges like limited samples and complex data structures. Future research should continue to explore these directions to improve generalizability and clinical applicability.

title: A Multi-Model AI System for Visual Disorder Diagnosis: Amblyopia as a Case Study
authors: Yamini G, K Deepa Shree, Arpitha Vasudev, Keerthana Shankar, Mangala H S
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Amblyopia, commonly known as “lazy eye,” is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impaired vision, often due to misalignment, refractive issues, or other visual deficits. Early detection is critical to prevent long-term vision impairment. This project proposes a dual model approach leveraging artificial intelligence to enhance amblyopia diagnosis through both image-based and genetic risk analysis. The first model utilizes an image classifier to analyze eye images, identifying physical markers of amblyopia using convolutional neural networks (CNNs) or Vision Transformers. The second model incorporates Random Forest and Naive Bayes algorithms to evaluate genetic predispositions and familial risk factors, offering a probabilistic assessment of a child's susceptibility to developing amblyopia. A hybrid model integrates both the image-based and genetic-risk predictions, producing a unified risk score to improve diagnostic accuracy. This comprehensive diagnostic framework holds potential for early detection of amblyopia and a more personalized, predictive approach to pediatric eye care. By combining visual and genetic data, the proposed method aims to provide clinicians with a robust tool to address amblyopia risk more accurately and efficiently.

title: Volcanic Ash Size and Mass Estimated by Satellite Passive Radiometers: A Comparison Between Two Radiative Transfer Models
authors: F. Romeo, L. Mereu, S. Corradini, L. Guerrieri, S. Scollo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Volcanic clouds are generated during explosive activities and are mainly composed of particles (called tephra), ice particles and gases (such as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO2}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SO2}$</tex>). Tephra come in different shapes and sizes. Among them, fine ash particles (of the order of microns) are dispersed in the atmosphere, representing a natural threat for population and aviation. A prompt characterization of the volcanic cloud properties, in terms of top cloud and advection altitude, Particles Radius (PR) and Fine Ash Total Mass (FATM), typically used to initialize the dispersal models, can help to constrain dispersal models outputs and mitigate the volcanic hazard. In this scenario, satellite sensors are a useful source of data and can be exploited to monitor volcanoes in particular those that are not monitored by a ground based system. Passive thermal infrared radiometers, on board low earth orbit and geostationary satellites, are commonly used to study distally dispersed volcanic clouds due to the different spectral response of silicate and water/ice particles in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8-14 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> wavelength range. In the last 30 years, different Radiative Transfer Model (RTM) algorithms have been implemented to study volcanic cloud properties. These RTM algorithms simulate the top of the atmosphere radiance detected by a passive radiometer, by solving the radiative transfer differential equation under simplified assumptions. Conventional RTM simulate the spectral radiance of two channels centered around 11 and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex>, due to the different absorption behavior of silicate and water particles. The former absorbs more radiation at around <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$11 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex>, the latter at around <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex>. Hence, the spectral difference of these two channels is employed in ash retrieval algorithms. In this work we compare the estimates of PR and FATM obtained from two RTMs. The first is the MODTRAN [1] code, that computes the radiance over a broad band wavelength window (from ultraviolet to thermal infrared), and it is based on the assumption of a homogeneous stratified atmosphere. The second is a RTM fully described in [2], [3] and based on the assumptions reported in [4]. It solves the radiative transfer differential equation considering either one layer or two layers approximation. The FATM and PR are estimated by the two algorithms for two volcanic clouds generated at Mt. Etna (Italy): the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$24{ }^{\text{th }}$</tex> November 2006 and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$23{ }^{\text{rd }}$</tex> November 2013 eruptions. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$24^{\text{th }}$</tex> of November 2006 eruption started at 03:00 UTC from the South East Crater (SEC) and lasted 14 hours. During this event, the volcanic cloud dispersed in the south-southeast direction, and the ash fallout affected the city of Catania and the Fontanarossa international airport, which was temporarily closed, indeed [5]. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$23{ }^{\text{rd }}$</tex> November 2013 eruption was characterized by a lava fountain started at 09:30 UTC from the SEC and lasted for an hour. The eruption generated a magma jet of about 1 km and an eruption column height of 9 km above sea level. The volcanic cloud was distally dispersed in the north-east direction, preserving the Fontanarossa international airport from the tephra fallout [6]. The estimated FATM and PR quantities, show a good agreement between the two models in terms of maps of dispersed volcanic clouds.

title: A Lightweight Visual Deception Detection Method Using Dynamic Images and a Customized SmallCNN–BiLSTM Architecture
authors: Thi Bich Phuong Man, Thanh Ha Le, Luu Tu Nguyen, Thi Duyen Ngo
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: Deception detection has been a topic of interest for nearly a century and has applications in many practical areas such as law, security, and recruitment, where accurately assessing human behavior can lead to better decision-making. Traditional deception detection methods often rely on physiological signals, such as polygraphs, which are invasive and susceptible to bias due to individual differences in physiological characteristics. Meanwhile, visual data is a non-invasive source of information, easy to collect, and contains many non-verbal behavioral cues. Most current visual-based deception detection methods process data at the frame-level using features such as action units and eye gaze, which do not fully take advantage of temporal dynamics. This paper has proposed a lightweight and efficient deception detection method based on visual data, utilizing dynamic images and a SmallCNN-BiLSTM ensemble model for feature extraction and time-series modeling. Specifically, dynamic images help synthesize essential motion information into a single image, reduce noise from irrelevant small movements, and optimize computational cost compared to processing each frame individually. Bi-LSTM enables the capture of temporal dependencies in both directions (past and future), allowing the model to learn a more complete context to distinguish deceptive behavior. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves competitive accuracy, while reducing computational costs and is suitable for deployment in real-world applications.

title: A Lightweight Multi-Scale Convolutional Neural Network-Based Method for ECG Quality Assessment
authors: Hong Chen, Yurong Li, Ning Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: ECG signals are essential for the diagnosis and prevention of cardiovascular diseases. However, these signals are frequently affected by various forms of noise during acquisition, and the presence of low-quality ECG signals significantly impairs the accuracy of both diagnosis and analysis. Consequently, the development of automated algorithms for ECG signal quality assessment is critical to effectively identify high-quality signals. In this paper, we propose a lightweight one-dimensional multi-scale convolutional neural network (1D-MSCNN) that is capable of automatically extracting features without human intervention to efficiently detect ECG signals of acceptable categories. The proposed approach is assessed through two distinct ECG quality assessment datasets, one derived from a self-collected ECG dataset and the other from a publicly available database, while also considering the model's computational complexity. The model achieves accuracy rates of 98.86% and 97.92% on the two test sets, with sensitivities of 97.92% and 100%, and specificities of 99.76% and 95.81%, respectively. The experimental results indicate that the proposed method outperforms current deep learning models with respect to overall performance, and the proposed model has small computational complexity, which balances the classification accuracy and practicality, and has a good application prospect in the ECG quality assessment task.

title: Accelerating Violence Detection: A Comparative Study of Frame Difference and Traditional Methods on UCF Crime Dataset
authors: Saniul Islam Sani, Rashedur Rahman, Zahidul Islam, Siam Tahsin Bhuiyan, Mahmudul Haque, Sefatul Wasi, Sajed Imtenanul Haque, Saadia Binte Alam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Wavelet Analysis and Pattern Recognition (ICWAPR)
abstract: Effective violence detection is crucial for enhancing public safety and preventing harmful events. This paper evaluates two approaches using a ResNet50-LSTM model: normal frame input and frame difference input. Data preprocessing involved using normal frames for one method and computing differences between consecutive frames for the other. Performance was assessed using ROC curves and AUROC metrics. The findings indicate that the frame difference method improves AUROC scores and reduces computational time, making it a more efficient and accurate solution for real-time violence detection.

title: Techno-Economic and Safety Assessment of Plug-and-Play Photovoltaic Systems in Belgium
authors: Sandra Taberner, Simon Ravyts, Marta Vanin
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Plug-and-play photovoltaic (PV) systems offer a simple and accessible alternative for residential power generation. These systems, which integrate a PV panel and a microinverter, can be connected directly to a household socket. This paper evaluates the technical performance, safety, and economic viability of one such system in the Belgian residential context, where plug-and-play PV is allowed for residential use since March 17<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup>, 2025. Laboratory tests were conducted to assess compliance with safety standards, including over/under-voltage protection, and anti-islanding response. Additionally, a cost-benefit analysis was performed using real consumption profiles and dynamic and fixed electricity tariff structures. The results show that while plug-and-play PV systems are limited in capacity, they are financially interesting. However, their profitability strongly depends on installation conditions and user consumption behavior. The system that was tested in our lab displayed compliance with most standard requirements but presented a problematic behavior in terms of harmonic current distortion, which stresses the importance of ensuring the quality of the (cheap) microinverters used for these purposes.

title: Integrated Coaxial Resonator for Reconfigurable Passive Intermodulation Testing
authors: Min Liang, Xiong Chen, Bin Han
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Advanced Interconnects (WAI)
abstract: A coaxial resonator model for Passive Intermodulation (PIM) testing was established in this paper. The model incorporates a probe inserted into the resonator, and a stepped coaxial line is used as the probe to enable application across a wider frequency range. The proposed model features multiple resonance points around the frequencies of 2.62 GHz and 2.69 GHz, resulting in a return loss better than 20 dB within this frequency range. This effectively prevents interference from reflected signals on incident signals, making the model suitable for full-band testing of Band 41.

title: Predictive Quality of Service and Proactive Channel Switching for Time-Critical Wi-Fi Systems
authors: Sebastian Lindner, Marie-Theres Suer, Maja Maschke
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: The upcoming Wi-Fi 8 standard is heading towards reliability, with a strong focus on machine-type communications and time-critical applications. In this work, we present a novel approach to ensure the Quality of Service (QoS) in Wi-Fi systems by leveraging Machine Learning (ML) models for proactive channel switching. We propose two time-series prediction models in this regard. The predictive QoS (pQoS) model assesses the probability of exceeding a packet error rate (PER) threshold in the near future, enabling proactive channel switching decisions during operation. To make an informed decision on which channel to switch to, the Channel Quality List (CQL) model classifies candidate Wi-Fi channels in terms of the expected PER based on sensed radio activity.We evaluate this ML-aided proactive channel switching procedure through simulation of a mobile robotics use case in different interference scenarios. To generate realistic training data, a statistical interferer model has been developed, which generates dynamic traffic patterns and user behavior based on real-world measurements. This model captures the variability in possible interference scenarios, providing a robust foundation for training the ML models, and for evaluating the trained models during simulation.The proposed ML-aided channel switching approach allows the system to quickly switch away from a deteriorating channel quality before the QoS suffers, and to switch to the best channel in terms of PER. The prediction models improve the QoS considerably, where the Packet Error Rate (PER) is reduced by up to 99 % of the PER of a non-switching system in the best cases, and by 95 % even in very difficult scenarios. This work highlights the substantial benefits of employing ML for predictive channel switching in Wi-Fi systems, offering a robust solution to the growing challenge of interference in congested radio environments.

title: Scheduling Concepts for DC Interconnectors in HVAC Distribution Grids
authors: Johannes Kayser, Steffen Schlegel, Dirk Westermann
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This study addresses strategies for DC-based interconnectors within HVAC grids, which face increasing challenges due to renewable energy integration. Unlike conventional grid enhancements, DC technology offers controllability and flexibility. The paper evaluates various scheduling and coordination models involving DSOs and TSOs and introduces a sensitivity-based optimization approach that is validated in a numerical case study using generic grid models.

title: Multi-Objective Capacity Planning for Large-Scale Renewable Energy Bases with Dynamic Source-Load Matching
authors: Mingyi Liu, Haiwang Zhong, Dexu Liu, Xinfei Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The global energy transition is driving large-scale development of renewable energy(RE), with high-voltage direct current transmission from large RE bases becoming a typical approach for RE consumption. However, the strong fluctuation and intermittency of RE lead to persistently high curtailment rates, while also facing source-load mismatches and low RE utilization efficiency. Studying the matching relationship between RE output and load (source-load matching) can fully leverage the complementarity among different RE sources and their positive correlation with load patterns, thereby mitigating source-load mismatch issues. This study proposes a dynamic source-load matching method incorporating time-varying coefficients and establishes a two-stage low-carbon economic capacity planning model for large-scale RE bases, taking into account both planning and operational aspects. Additionally, this research systematically models Concentrated Solar Power (CSP) plants and analyzes the capability of CSP technology to enhance system flexibility. The proposed model effectively mitigates deviations between energy supply and demand, thereby improving RE utilization efficiency, reducing curtailment rates, and offering systematic solutions to resolve source-load mismatches.

title: A Two-Stage LSTM-LightGBM Framework for Time-Series Traffic State Prediction
authors: Kenjie Aaron Gozali, Rainer Dylan Elias, Vincent Liem, Evan Aditya Chandra, Andrew Liemarta, Gilang Raka Rayuda Dewa, Ariana Tulus Purnomo, Muhammad Agni Catur Bhakti
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Urban mobility plays a significant role as the backbone of social and economic growth. However, the high urban mobility that corresponds with high population growth increases vehicle volume. Consequently, the road capacity cannot accommodate the overloaded vehicle volume, resulting in traffic congestion at various levels. Therefore, as an effort to improve human commuting life, this paper proposes a two-stage LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) and LightGBM (Light Gradient Boosting Machine) framework for binary-class traffic forecasting based on time series data. The proposed algorithm constructs an LSTM model to capture the temporal dependencies embedded in sequence vehicle count data, and a LightGBM algorithm is employed for classifying the traffic state into two binary classes: Dense Traffic and Normal Traffic. The evaluation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves an RMSE and MAE of less than 0.2, indicating a time series prediction with minimal error. From a classification perspective, the proposed algorithm achieves an accuracy of 83.4%, outperforming other machine learning algorithms.

title: Inductance Parameter Online Identification of PMASRM Based on Current Harmonics Extraction with Ultra-local Model
authors: Sinian Su, Jianbo Sun, Hongzhe Wang, Yunfan Shen, Haoyuan Zhang, Longyu Zhang, Wenjun Luo, Ronghai Qu
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: The traditional deadbeat predictive current control (DPCC) is renowned for its excellent performance, quick reaction, simplicity, and ease of use. DPCC, on the other hand, is extremely sensitive to changes in machine parameters, and when model parameters diverge from the real values, performance suffers greatly. This issue is particularly pronounced in permanent magnet assisted synchronous reluctance motors (PMASRMs), where the inductance decreases as the current increases. As a result, the DPCC method, which typically measures motor inductance under no-load conditions, will encounter considerable performance degradation with increasing current levels. In order to address this problem, this work proposes a DPCC approach based on the ultra-local model, which only uses system input and output and does not require motor parameter information, hence improving control system robustness. Additionally, to enable real-time motor inductance identification, an improved high-frequency current injection method is put forward, which introduces a current harmonic amplitude extraction link and replaces the low-pass filter with average value filter. By using this method, the accuracy and convergence rate of inductance identification can be greatly enhanced. Finally, the efficacy of the suggested control strategy for PMASRM is confirmed by comparison of simulations.

title: Graphene Oxide Glucose Sensor for Scalable Microfluidic Lab on Chip Integration
authors: Ali Imran, Aadil Nabi Chishti, Yiming Hou
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Diabetes is the global metabolic challenge that demands precise and routine glucose monitoring to ensure proper management and prevent severe health complications. In this research work, we introduce a compact, highly sensitive and energy efficient electrochemical bio-sensor specifically developed for glucose (Glu) detection. The sensor is based on graphene oxide (GO) thin film functionalized by Glu oxidase deposited on a LiNbO substrate, The enzyme facilitates the oxidation of the Glu and releases electrons, which modulate the electrical conductivity of the GO. The device utilizes the exceptional surface sensitivity of GO to generate a reliable current response of 138 pA/mmol/L across the clinical Glu concentration range of 0 to 30 mmol/L. The device requires only a 5 μL fluid sample and operates at a low bias of 0.1 V, making it highly suitable for portable and wearable health applications. By combining biosensing and fluid handling on the existing microelectronic platform, this work paves the way for scalable Lab on Chip systems. The proposed sensor offers high sensitivity, low operation power, and potential for microfluidic integration, addressing the key limitations of traditional glucose monitoring technologies in a smart, efficient and miniaturized system.

title: Towards Trustworthy Healthcare AI: GAN-Augmented Explainable Models with Blockchain-based Data Integrity
authors: N Meenakshisundaram, Sajiv G
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: New developments in healthcare are being propelled by the convergence of AI with safe digital infrastructure. In order to enhance the confidentiality of patient information, the accuracy of diagnoses, and the dependability of models, this research presents a new framework that integrates blockchain technology with Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs). To tackle issues like data scarcity and class imbalance, GANs are used to create and enhance synthetic medical data. At the same time, blockchain enables distributed, immutable data storage, which is crucial in healthcare settings for data integrity and auditability. Results on benchmark datasets show that the framework can accurately simulate real-world scenarios and generate synthetic examples with high levels of realism. Additionally, the method shows remarkable resilience against malicious assaults and data tampering. Future integration with edge AI and smart healthcare communication networks can be achieved with this scalable architecture that prioritizes privacy.

title: Low-Complexity Adaptive MIMO Detection Framework for Next-Generation Wireless Systems
authors: Yamini Komati, Sandanalakshmi Rajendran, Yamini Komati
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: The rapid evolution of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G}$</tex> and upcoming <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 G}$</tex> networks demands low-complexity and energy-efficient MIMO detection techniques that can flexibly support diverse service classes such as enhanced Mobile Broadband (eMBB), ultra-Reliable Low-Latency Communications (URLLC), and massive Machine-Type Communications (mMTC). Conventional detectors-Zero Forcing (ZF), Minimum Mean Square Error (MMSE), and Successive Interference Cancellation (SIC)-offer trade-offs between accuracy and complexity, while Maximum Likelihood (ML) achieves optimal performance at the cost of exponential computational demand. This paper proposes an adaptive MIMO detection framework that dynamically switches among ZF, MMSE, SIC, and ML detectors using a unified cost function integrating Bit Error Rate (BER), Spectral Efficiency (SE), Energy Efficiency (EE), and Computational Complexity (CC). System-level simulations conducted in Keysight PathWave SystemVue for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 8$</tex> MIMO configurations with QPSK and 16-QAM over Rayleigh and Rician fading channels demonstrate near-ML BER with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\sim} \mathbf{4 0 \%}$</tex> lower complexity, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0 \%}$</tex> higher energy efficiency, and 15% better spectral efficiency compared to static detectors. The results validate the framework's capability for serviceaware adaptation across eMBB, URLLC, and mMTC scenarios and its potential for low-complexity VLSI implementation in future <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G} / \mathbf{6 G}$</tex> transceivers.

title: A Heat Pump Optimization-Based Scheduling to Minimize Energy Cost and Ensure Thermal Comfort
authors: Nearchos Stylianides, Lysandros Tziovani, Stelios Timotheou, Lenos Hadjidemetriou
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper presents a novel optimization framework designed to minimize residential heating costs while maintaining occupant thermal comfort. The proposed method employs a data-driven learning algorithm to identify the parameters of a linear building thermal model. The identified thermal model is incorporated into a mixed-integer linear programming formulation, enabling discrete on/off control of the underfloor heat pump system while accounting for dynamic electricity pricing and user comfort constraints. A dual-band comfort model is implemented using soft constraints to balance occupant comfort and electricity cost while ensuring solution’s feasibility. The proposed framework is tested in a simulation environment that emulates the electrical and thermal behavior of a real residential building equipped with a heat-pump system. The proposed dynamic scheduling is compared against two static scheduling scenarios, indicating that the optimization-based strategy can significantly enhance thermal comfort while reducing electricity costs.

title: Adaptive Multi-Node Speech Stream Synchronization Algorithm for Distributed Japanese Simultaneous Interpretation
authors: Li Wang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: With the increasing frequency of the global communication, the demand for high-precision, low-latency cross-language real-time information transmission system budget method is constantly increasing. In the distributed multi-node Japanese simultaneous interpretation system, this is a reality due to network delay, asynchronous sampling, node hardware differences and environmental noise. Therefore, the synchronization problem of multiple speech streams has become a key factor affecting the accuracy and comprehensibility of translation. This paper proposes an adaptive multi-node speech stream synchronization algorithm (AMSS). The core of this research is to solve the speech stream synchronization problem in a distributed environment. This method transforms the speech stream synchronization problem into a multi-objective optimization problem through mathematical modeling and comprehensively considers the time deviation between nodes, spectrum changes and cross-node interference. The purpose of this optimization is to minimize the global synchronization error. The core of the algorithm proposed by Fang includes: (1) discrete wavelet denoising based on waveform domain features. This can ensure the consistency of multi-node signals; (2) introducing a multi-head attention mechanism to capture the cross-node time dependency. This can achieve dynamic delay compensation and signal alignment; (3) constructing a global delay optimization model. This can update the node parameters through gradient descent iteration to take into account the asynchronous characteristics and cross-node noise interference. To validate the effectiveness of the algorithm, this paper constructed the MN-JSI dataset. This dataset simulates a real-world distributed environment with varying node numbers, sampling rate drift, network jitter, and noise interference. Experimental results show that, compared to a Synchformer-style approach, AMSS reduces synchronization error from 22.1 ms to 12.6 ms, and downstream speech recognition error rate from 10.7% to 9.3%, with a latency of 58 ms, maintaining near-real-time processing capabilities. Furthermore, AMSS demonstrates enhanced robustness under varying signal-to-noise ratios and packet loss scenarios. Specifically, in a 16-node scenario, it maintains a synchronization error of approximately 20 ms, demonstrating its scalability and cross-node information fusion capabilities.

title: Brain-Computer Interface of Motor Imagery EEG Signal Using Hybrid GNN-Mamba Networks
authors: Bagja Iskandar Jamil, Esmeralda Contessa Djamal
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: A Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) is a technology that enables a person to interact directly with an external device without relying on muscles, voice, or physical movement. One such intermediate device is the Electroencephalogram (EEG), which captures electrical activity in the brain through Motor Imagery variables or imagined movements. The problem lies in translating Motor Imagery variables from EEG signals when imagining movements such as the right hand, left hand, foot, and tongue. An effective classification method must be able to represent the spatial relationship between EEG channels and the temporal sequence of signals. Previous studies used convolutional methods, such as CNN, RNN, or a hybrid of both, in Motor Imagery classification. However, this method has limitations in capturing spatial relationships between EEG channels or the sequence of time series only. The transformer model for sequential data is less efficient in processing long-duration EEG signals. Therefore, this study aims to develop a Motor Imagery EEG classification model comprising four classes: right hand, left hand, feet, and tongue, by leveraging the advantages of Wavelet and a hybrid Graph Neural Network (GNN)-Mamba architecture. GNN models the spatial relationships between EEG channels in the form of a graph, while Mamba learns temporal patterns efficiently through a State Space Model (SSM) approach. The results of this study, with a final average accuracy of 82.05%, are expected to enhance the performance of Motor Imagery classification, supporting the development of a more adaptive and stable Brain-Computer Interface, which is crucial for real-time applications.

title: Uncertain Mode Surfaces in 3D Symmetric Second-Order Tensor Field Ensembles
authors: Tim Gerrits
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: The analysis of 3D symmetric second-order tensor fields often relies on topological features such as degenerate tensor lines, neutral surfaces, and their generalization to mode surfaces, which reveal important structural insights into the data. However, uncertainty in such fields is typically visualized using derived scalar attributes or tensor glyph representations, which often fail to capture the global behavior. Recent advances have introduced uncertain topological features for tensor field ensembles by focusing on degenerate tensor locations. Yet, mode surfaces, including neutral surfaces and arbitrary mode surfaces are essential to a comprehensive understanding of tensor field topology. In this work, we present a generalization of uncertain degenerate tensor features to uncertain mode surfaces of arbitrary mode values, encompassing uncertain degenerate tensor lines as a special case. Our approach supports both surface and line geometries, forming a unified framework for analyzing uncertain mode-based topological features in tensor field ensembles. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method on several real-world simulation datasets from engineering and materials science.

title: Forecast-Based Heuristic Algorithm for Voltage Magnitude Regulation in Microgrids
authors: Ana Luíza Félix de Souza, Luiza Higino Silva Santos, Marcos J. Rider
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Microgrids play an increasingly important role in the transition toward a decentralized and sustainable power system, enabling the integration of renewable energy sources and energy storage systems. Among the challenges faced in microgrid operation, maintaining appropriate voltage magnitude profiles is crucial to ensure system reliability and efficiency. This paper proposes an improved heuristic algorithm for the operation of battery energy storage systems, to improve the voltage magnitude regulation in microgrids. The proposed method incorporates forecasts of photovoltaic generation and load demand, considering persistence model, long short term memory networks and autoregressive integrated moving average models to anticipate future operating conditions. The improved algorithm was evaluated through simulations in an OpenDSS-based microgrid model and through experimental tests in the LabREI microgrid using real data. The results demonstrate that the forecast-based control strategy outperforms the original approach by achieving lower quadratic voltage magnitude errors and better alignment with the reference voltage magnitude, especially during critical periods such as midday and late night.

title: Preliminary Results on a Hexagonal Lattice Meta-Lens for SatCom on the Move Applications
authors: M. Cavallo, M. Beccaria, G. Giordanengo, G. Vecchi, P. Pirinoli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Preliminary results on the design of a dielectric-only meta-lens with a hexagonal lattice are here presented. The use of such a configuration seems particularly suitable for application requiring a high azimuthal symmetry, as for instance when a beam with a conical scanning must be radiated. This is the case of SatCom On The Move applications: the request of mass market products is recently growing fast, and it pushes the need to develop antenna systems with good performance but characterized by reduced complexity and weight, in alternative to phased arrays. The proposed study represent a first step in the definition of a solution consisting of a feed array with a reduced number of electronically controlled elements and meta-lens located in the the near field, designed to focus and enhance the beam scanning of the field radiated by the primary feed.

title: The Hidden Variables in the Future of Quantum Computing in 6G
authors: Riccardo Bassoli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: 5G has been commercialised and 6G standardisation has just started. The vision of these networks are going to pose unprecedented computing challenges on the infrastructure. To ensure the computing infrastructure is capable to assure the necessary promises, integration between ‘classical’ and quantum computing has started being researched by the industrial and scientific communities in cloud computing scenarios. In the years, various technologies for quantum computing have been developed with different performances and characteristics. Superconducting and trapped-ions have been attracting a lot of attention and investments. That mainly due to the best fidelities, gate times, for the number of computational qubits offered. These quantum computing technologies work at very low temperatures (below some Kelvins) and require cryogenics. Nevertheless, in the history, the success of ICT technologies has also passed through their flexibility, sustainability (e.g., energy usage, cost, scalability). Current cryogenic methods for quantum computing face significant sustainability challenges due to their extreme energy demands and reliance on finite resources. The cooling infrastructure represents one of the most significant sustainability challenge in quantum computing. That is why other solutions like photonic and NV-centre diamond-based quantum computing could offer a suitable alternative to match the requirements of future generation networks.

title: Research on Data Feature Processing Model Based on Hierarchical Analysis and STFT
authors: Yan Liang, Xiaoxiao Liang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: This paper proposes a comprehensive evaluation model of audio formats integrating entropy weighting and Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP), a parameter optimization model based on regression analysis, and an adaptive noise suppression model combining short-time Fourier transform (STFT), focusing on the algorithmic implementation of multidimensional audio feature quantization, coding parameter optimization, and noise intelligent processing. Firstly, the performance ranking of audio formats is realized by constructing an entropy weighting-AHP weighting model, quantifying the indexes such as storage efficiency and signal fidelity, calculating the weights by using a judgment matrix and establishing a Comprehensive Performance Index (CPI) model. Secondly, the Quality Scoring Index (QSI) is introduced, the mapping relationship between parameters and performance is established through regression analysis, and the combination of coding parameters is optimized using linear regression and machine learning methods. Finally, the time-frequency domain noise features are extracted based on STFT, the noise types are identified by combining the minimum statistics algorithm with peak detection, the narrowband noise is suppressed by IIR trap filter, the background noise is eliminated by Wiener filter, and the transient noise is handled by adaptive thresholding. The model system realizes the whole process of processing from format evaluation to noise suppression through the synergy of multiple algorithms, and has the advantages of multidimensional quantitative analysis, scene adaptive optimization and accurate identification of noise types, providing systematic algorithmic solutions for audio processing.

title: Enhancing Lung Cancer Screening by Analysing Clinically Symptoms Using Machine Learning
authors: Sonam Khattar, B Vivek Gowd, Tushar Verma, Bhuvan Batra, Priyanshu Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Lung cancer remains a major global health burden, causing approximately 1.8 million deaths annually, primarily due to challenges in early-stage detection. Although imaging techniques such as low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) offer improved diagnostic accuracy, their use is often limited by cost and infrastructure in low-resource settings. This study investigates the application of artificial intelligence (AI), including deep learning and machine learning methods, to enhance early detection of lung cancer using structured clinical data and chest X-rays. Key methodologies include data preprocessing, feature selection through Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE), and model development using Random Forest classifiers. Evaluation metrics show Random Forest achieved the highest performance with 99% accuracy, precision, and F1-score, followed by XGBoost (96%), CNN (95%), and SVM (92%). These models demonstrated strong reliability in distinguishing between normal and abnormal lung conditions. This study highlights the importance of interpretable and scalable AI solutions in supporting timely lung cancer diagnosis across diverse healthcare environments.

title: QCM Sensors Engineered from Cellulose Nanocrystals/Agar Composites for Enhanced Humidity Sensing
authors: Jianghuan Shi, Weixiang Chen, Jianguo Sun, Feili Huang, Lirong Tang, Bingkun Xu, Weidong Yu, Dilong Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Agar as a renewable resource, which is easy to obtain, inexpensive, biocompatible, has strong anti-interference ability, good stability and excellent humidity linear response, making it suitable for the sensing field. Given that moisture absorption can cause swelling in materials sensitive composed of cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs), the stability of the QCM humidity sensor is compromised under high humidity (97% RH) and may even stops vibrating. In this study, agar was introduced into the cellulose nanocrystal matrix material to form a cellulose nanocrystal/agar (CNCs/Agar) sensitive membrane material through hydrogen bonding. The research results indicate that the addition of agar can improve the linearity of pure CNCs humidity sensor and expand the detection humidity range to 97% RH. The response value is -8655 Hz at 97% RH and the logarithmic linear relationship is R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>=0.99914. The sensitivity is significantly improved to 84.95 Hz/% RH, demonstrating good repeatability and long-term stability, indicating promising application prospects in the field of humidity detection.

title: Day-Ahead PV Power Probability Density Forecasting With GAN-QRCNLSTM Based on High-Resolution Data Reconstruction
authors: Yaoyao He, Xiaolin Chen, Yifan Zhang, Xiaodong Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: In solar energy systems, accurate photovoltaic (PV) power forecasting is intricately linked to meteorological factors. Day-ahead prediction based on similar weather scenarios is pivotal for enhancing forecasting performance. However, existing approaches are constrained by simplistic similar sample selection methods, inefficient utilization of PV datasets, and inadequate attention to generation uncertainty. This study proposes a day-ahead probabilistic forecasting model that improves input quality via a high-resolution multidimensional adaptive similar moment selection. In addition a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) learns the joint distribution of historical measurements and Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP), reducing redundancy and enriching training data. The model employs a multibranch architecture, integrating Convolutional Neural Networks and Long Short-Term Memory networks for spatio-temporal feature extraction. It also leverages Quantile Regression with Kernel Density Estimation to generate multiquantile predictions and comprehensive probability distributions. Experiments on authentic PV datasets demonstrate that the proposed GAN-QRCNLSTM model outperforms baseline models, achieving superior accuracy and robustness, particularly in complex weather conditions such as extreme weather scenario.

title: Primary-Ambient Extraction Using Ambient Phase Estimation With Correlation Constraints
authors: Jiacheng Gou, Jiangnan Liang, Chuang Shi, Ce Zhu, Huiyong Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: One of the key front-end technologies in spatial audio reproduction is the extraction of primary components, which provide auditory cues, and ambient components, which contribute to the atmospheric qualities of stereo recordings. Primary-ambient extraction (PAE) algorithms rely on specific assumptions about the stereo signal model. However, the primary and ambient components extracted by state-of-the-art algorithms often fail to satisfy these assumptions fully. In this paper, we propose a new PAE algorithm called APEC (Ambient Phase Estimation with Correlation constraints), which is grounded in the assumption of uncorrelated primary and ambient components. The APEC algorithm demonstrates higher extraction accuracy and higher diffuseness accuracy than existing methods. Furthermore, we incorporate a timeshift preprocessing step to mitigate degradation caused by time differences in the primary components. Both objective and subjective evaluations confirm the algorithm's superior performance, highlighting accurate primaryambient extraction while preserving diffuseness.

title: CP-Free ODDM over General Doubly-Selective Fading Channels
authors: Yanjun Pan, Jeremiah Wimer, Jingxian Wu, Hai Lin, Jinhong Yuan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: This paper proposes a new orthogonal delay-Doppler division multiplexing (ODDM) system, which is designed to operate without the need of using a cyclic prefix (CP) in the transmitted signals. The CP-free ODDM is enabled by exploiting the unique structures of the ODDM prototype pulses, which are constructed through repetitions of finite-duration elementary pulses. The system eliminates the need of CP by designing a new receiving filter through temporally extending the transmission prototype pulse. The elementary pulse repetition at the transmitter along with the temporal filter extension at the receiver introduce a wrap-around effect in the equivalent channel spreading function in the dealy-Doppler (DD) domain. The wrap-around effect leads to a block-circulant-like structure of the DD-domain channel matrix that is the same as conventional ODDM systems with CP. Thus CP-free ODDM can employ the same receiver as conventional ODDM systems, yet it yields a higher energy efficiency as no energy needs to be allocated for CP symbols. The wrap-around effects are theoretically demonstrated by deriving the exact analytical expressions of the cross-ambiguity functions of practical transmission and receiving prototype pulses. In addition, theoretical analysis of the cross-ambiguity function verifies that the CP-free ODDM waveforms satisfy local bi-orthogonality in the delay and Doppler domains. This bi-orthogonality property along with the wrap-around effects of the channel spreading function enables the design of a low complexity iterative receiver, which performs interference cancellation and coherent matrix combining (CMC) in the delay domain and minimum mean squared error (MMSE) detection in the Doppler domain. The proposed receiver can collect the diversity in both the delay and Doppler domains while simultaneously suppressing the negative impacts of DD-domain intersymbol interference (ISI) introduced by the doubly-selective fading channels.

title: A Review of Next-Generation Sensor Technologies for Human-Machine Interaction
authors: Xiangyu Guo, Tai Fei, Zican Wang, Xiao Xu, Subhas Mukhopadhyay, Amit Bhardwaj, Zhi Jin
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Advances in sensor technologies have substantially reshaped human-machine interaction (HMI), enabling more intuitive, robust, and efficient interactions across diverse application domains including healthcare, robotics, and industrial automation. This review systematically covers next-generation sensing approaches essential to future HMI systems, addressing radar-based sensing, vision-based techniques, haptic feedback and teleoperation, as well as wearable sensors and wireless sensor networks (WSNs). Radar sensors are discussed for their reliability in challenging conditions and suitability for gesture and vital-sign monitoring. Vision-based sensors, incorporating monocular, stereo, near-infrared, and thermal imaging, provide detailed spatial and semantic information vital for gesture tracking and remote physiological monitoring. Moreover, haptic sensors and AI-driven teleoperation techniques are examined for their pivotal roles in enabling safe, precise remote interactions in medical and industrial contexts. This paper further explores IoT-enabled wearable sensors and WSNs, highlighting their application in continuous health monitoring and personalized healthcare. Sensor fusion strategies are discussed, emphasizing their potential to integrate complementary data streams effectively. Cross-cutting challenges such as computational efficiency, sensor integration, ethical considerations, and sustainability are identified and analyzed. By consolidating recent progress and discussing practical implementation issues, this review offers insights into current research trends and outlines key directions for future advancements in sensor-driven HMI systems.

title: Empowering Intelligent Low-Altitude Economy With Large AI Model Deployment
authors: Zhonghao Lyu, Yulan Gao, Junting Chen, Hongyang Du, Jie Xu, Kaibin Huang, Dong In Kim
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications
abstract: Low-altitude economy (LAE) represents an emerging economic paradigm that redefines commercial and social aerial activities. Large artificial intelligence models (LAIMs) offer transformative potential to further enhance the intelligence of LAE services. However, deploying LAIMs in LAE poses several challenges, including the significant gap between their computational/storage demands and the limited onboard resources of LAE entities, the mismatch between lab-trained LAIMs and dynamic physical environments, and the inefficiencies of traditional decoupled designs for sensing, communication, and computation. To address these issues, we first propose a hierarchical system architecture tailored for LAIM deployment and present representative LAE application scenarios. Next, we explore key enabling techniques that facilitate the mutual co-evolution of LAIMs and low-altitude systems, and introduce a task-oriented execution pipeline for scalable and adaptive service delivery. Then, the proposed framework is validated through real-world case studies. Finally, we outline open challenges to inspire future research.

title: Optimization of a Hybrid Graphene–Copper Terahertz Gas Sensor Using Machine Learning
authors: Hamza Ben Krid, Hamza Wertani, Aymen Hlali, Hassen Zairi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Plasma Science
abstract: This work presents a hybrid copper–graphene terahertz (THz) sensor for multigas detection with tunable performance. The design achieves frequency reconfiguration from 5.235 THz for <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu _{c} = 0$</tex-math> </inline-formula> eV to 5.265 THz for <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu _{c} = 0.5$</tex-math> </inline-formula> eV, confirming the strong plasmonic control of graphene. Sensitivity analysis shows values of 405.4 GHz/RIU for CH<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sub>, 816.3 GHz/RIU for CO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>, 847.5 GHz/RIU for H<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>O, and 606.1 GHz/RIU for NH<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>. To further enhance prediction accuracy, an eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) regression model was employed, achieving <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$R^{2} = 0.998$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. After optimization, the sensitivities were improved to 603.0, 960.7, 1003.2, and 604.5 GHz/RIU, respectively. The proposed approach highlights the dominant role of graphene chemical potential in resonance tuning and sensitivity enhancement, establishing a compact and selective platform for advanced THz gas sensing.

title: PASS-based Multi-User Communications: Capacity Characterization and Configuration Strategy
authors: Yuquan Xiao, Xidong Mu, Yuanwei Liu, Qinghe Du, Arumugam Nallanathan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: The fundamental capacity limits of pinching-antenna systems (PASS)-based multi-user communication network are investigated. Two practical pinching-antenna configuration strategies are considered, namely multiple-time discrete activation and one-off continuous sliding. For each strategy, the capacity and rate regions are characterized under the non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) and orthogonal multiple access (OMA) schemes, respectively. 1) For NOMA, the capacity region achieved by the discrete activation is first characterized. In particular, the ideal case with the infinite number of activation times is considered, where the optimal PA activation and resource allocation scheme is derived. It is shown that different user groups or decoding orders are served via time-sharing. Inspired by this result, an inner bound of capacity region is obtained for the practical case with a finite number of activation times. Then, for the continuous sliding case, the inner bound of capacity region is characterized by alternately optimizing the resource allocation and PAs’ continuous positions. 2) For OMA, the rate region is first obtained for the discrete activation case. It is unveiled that multiple users are successively served. Then, by alternately optimizing the resource allocation and PAs’ continuous positions, the inner bound of rate region is obtained for the continuous sliding case. Numerical results demonstrate that i) PASS can significantly improve the capacity performance compared with the conventional fixed-antenna systems; ii) the capacity gain can be further enhanced by using the proposed PA activation and sliding and resource allocation schemes; and iii) the continuous sliding has the potential to outperform the discrete activation in NOMA, whereas the latter performs better in OMA.

title: Dual-IRS Aided Near-/Hybrid-Field SWIPT: Passive Beamforming and Independent Antenna Power Splitting Design
authors: Chaoying Huang, Wen Chen, Qingqing Wu, Xusheng Zhu, Zhendong Li, Ying Wang, Jinhong Yuan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: This paper proposes a novel dual-intelligent reflecting surface (IRS) aided interference-limited simultaneous wireless information and power transfer (SWIPT) system with independent power splitting (PS), where each receiving antenna applies different PS factors to offer an advantageous trade-off between the useful information and harvested energy.We separately establish the near- and hybrid-field channel models for IRS-reflected links to evaluate the performance gain more precisely and practically. Specifically, we formulate an optimization problem of maximizing the harvested power by jointly optimizing dual-IRS phase shifts, independent PS ratio, and receive beamforming vector in both near- and hybrid-field cases. In the near-field case, the alternating optimization algorithm is proposed to solve the non-convex problem by applying the Lagrange duality method and the difference-of-convex (DC) programming. In the hybrid-field case, we first present an interesting result that the AP-IRS-user channel gains are invariant to the phase shifts of dual-IRS, which allows the optimization problem to be transformed into a convex one. Then, we derive the asymptotic performance of the combined channel gains in closed-form and analyze the characteristics of the dual-IRS. Numerical results validate our analysis and indicate the performance gains of the proposed scheme that dual-IRS-aided SWIPT with independent PS over other benchmark schemes.

title: NeeCo: Image Synthesis of Novel Instrument States Based on Dynamic and Deformable 3D Gaussian Reconstruction
authors: Tianle Zeng, Junlei Hu, Gerardo Loza Galindo, Sharib Ali, Duygu Sarikaya, Pietro Valdastri, Dominic Jones
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Imaging
abstract: Computer vision-based technologies significantly enhance surgical automation by advancing tool tracking, detection, and localization. However, Current data-driven approaches are data-voracious, requiring large, high-quality labeled image datasets. Our Work introduces a novel dynamic Gaussian Splatting technique to address the data scarcity in surgical image datasets. We propose a dynamic Gaussian model to represent dynamic surgical scenes, enabling the rendering of surgical instruments from unseen viewpoints and deformations with real tissue backgrounds. We utilize a dynamic training adjustment strategy to address challenges posed by poorly calibrated camera poses from real-world scenarios. Additionally, automatically generate annotations for our synthetic data. For evaluation, we constructed a new dataset featuring seven scenes with 14,000 frames of tool and camera motion and tool jaw articulation, with a background of an exvivo porcine model. Using this dataset, we synthetically replicate the scene deformation from the ground truth data, allowing direct comparisons of synthetic image quality. Experimental results illustrate that our method generates photo-realistic labeled image datasets with the highest PSNR (29.87). We further evaluate the performance of medical-specific neural networks trained on real and synthetic images using an unseen real-world image dataset. Our results show that the performance of models trained on synthetic images generated by the proposed method outperforms those trained with state-of-the-art standard data augmentation by 10%, leading to an overall improvement in model performances by nearly 15%.

title: Remotely Sensed Flood Depth by Emulating Flood Recession Algorithm from Imperfect Extent and Topography
authors: Xinyi Shen, Maopu Xu, Qing Yang, Qingyuan Zhang, Sean Helfrich, Marilyn Yuen Murphy, Zhe Chen, William Straka, Josef Kellodofer
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Flood depth mapping is critical for effective flood management, disaster response, and hydrodynamic model validation/calibration. The bathtub approach that generates flood depth by overlapping remotely sensed flood extent on high-resolution (HR) topography can provide flood depth over vast areas at low cost. However, only a handful such algorithms are available. And none considers the topographic heterogeneity at small-scale and have poor tolerance to input errors. On the other hand, the spatial pattern of inundation can be well explained by the small-scale features only visible from Very High-Resolution (VHR <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 1 ~\mathrm{m})$</tex> topography. To address these challenges, we developed an Emulated Flood Recession Algorithm (EFRA) that physically considers both macro and micro topographic characteristics. Besides the depth value, EFRA also outputs the uncertainty of the estimation. Validated against USGS High Water Marks (HWMs), EFRA yields an RMSE of 1.01 m for depth estimation when 1 m DEM is used. But the error is amplified to 2.83 m when using a 10 m DEM instead. The proposed flood depth estimator could significantly promote the current operational Flood Inundation Mapping (FIM) systems.

title: Common Mode Voltage Elimination and Zero-Sequence Circulating Current Reduction of Parallel Back-to-Back Converters
authors: Reza Farajpour, Mojtaba Sarparast, Jafar Adabi, Mohammad Rezanejad, Edris Pouresmaeil
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Parallel back-to-back converters are highly demanded in many high-power applications such as adjustable speed drive (ASD) systems, which reduce harmonics and improve the power factor and reliability compared to single two-level converters. It is evident that common-mode voltage (CMV) is the root cause of many challenges in ASD systems, such as shaft voltage and bearing damage, which may reduce equipment lifespan. On the other hand, Zero Sequence Circulating Current (ZSCC) leads to an additional current of switches which increases power loss and decreases the current capacity of converters. Simultaneous reduction of these two critical issues has to be considered in any switching strategy. In this regard, this paper presents a switching strategy based on a modified three-level space vector modulation scheme, which completely eliminates the common-mode voltage (CMV = 0 V). Moreover, the proposed switching sequence keeps the ZSCC within a low-amplitude and fully symmetric ripple, ensuring controlled circulating-current behavior without requiring any additional hardware. The method also generates a three-level line voltage and achieves an input-current THD of 3.92%. The simulation and experimental results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Negative Photoconductivity Engineering in High-Sn GeSn/InP Heterostructures Enabling Record-Breaking Photoresponse for Short Wave Infrared Detection
authors: Junfeng Yang, Xiaolong Jiang, Menghui Guo, Yiyuan Fan, Zhiwei Huang, Guanzhou Liu, Jinrong Zhou, Shaoying Ke
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: This work reports a negative photoconductivity short-wave infrared detector based on high-Sn-content germanium-tin (GeSn) alloys. GeSn thin films with a Sn composition as high as 25.2% are achieved on InP substrates via molecular beam epitaxy. This material exhibits an ultrahigh absorption rate of 95.94% across the mid-to-far infrared spectrum (2–18 μm). Its direct bandgap characteristic (0.36 ± 0.02 eV) is confirmed using the Tauc model. Innovatively, by manipulating deep-level trap states, the Negative photoconductivity effect is realized for the first time in a GeSn detector. Under illumination, trap states selectively capture photogenerated holes to form positive charge centers. These centers subsequently trap electrons and accelerate their recombination via Coulomb interaction, thereby significantly reducing the device conductivity. The vertically structured detector designed based on this mechanism achieves record-high responsivity (2.61 A/W) and external quantum efficiency (208.8%) at a wavelength of 1550 nm under a -2 V bias, representing a 65.3-fold enhancement over the highest previously reported values for GeSn detectors. The device simultaneously demonstrates low dark current (5.18 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-4</sup> A) and strong size dependence. Through a synergistic strategy of “material growth – defect engineering – band structure modulation,” this work overcomes the inherent limitations of high dark current and responsivity degradation in conventional GeSn detectors. It thereby establishes a new paradigm for high-performance mid-infrared detection, photonic neuromorphic computing, and intelligent sensing systems.
