title: Mapping and Revealing the River Ice Distribution and Changes in the Three Rivers Source Region From 1990 to 2023 Using Google Earth Engine
authors: Haojie Li, Donghang Shao, Yuzhong Wang, Hongxing Li, Jing Zhang, Zhen Liu, Jian Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: River ice is closely related to hydrological processes, water resource utilization, river hydraulic projects, and navigation systems, and the spatial distribution extent of river ice serves as critical foundational data for studying river ice. The Three Rivers Source Region (TRSR) is a representative high and cold mountain; in this region, river ice is well developed and significantly impacts the river runoff process. However, river ice data in this region are scarce, seriously limiting related research. In this study, a 30-meter spatial resolution river ice extent dataset (1990-2023) for the TRSR was successfully developed by employing the Google Earth Engine (GEE) and Landsat imagery, achieving an overall accuracy of 97.96% and a kappa coefficient of 0.86. The Operational Land Imager (OLI) sensor images resulted in the highest mapping accuracy, followed by the Thematic Mapper (TM) images and Enhanced Thematic Mapper (ETM) images. Notably, in areas with different elevations, slopes, and aspects, the mapping accuracy did not significantly differ. This dataset reveals, for the first time, that the average area of river ice distributed in the TRSR was 2073.0 km2, with a coverage rate of 0.64%, indicating a noticeable downward trend. Additionally, the river ice extent became more fragmented, and river ice was distributed more significantly in high-altitude regions and areas with gentle slopes than in other areas. However, no obvious characteristics regarding the slope aspect of the river ice distribution were observed. This research provides a comprehensive technical framework for large-scale river ice extraction using the GEE platform, and it offers an understanding of the distribution features and changes in river ice in the TRSR and even the broader Tibetan Plateau.

title: AI-Powered Sustainable Wastewater Recycling Systems for Smart Cities Resource Management
authors: T. S. Balaji Damodhar, D Vetriselvi, Rajarajeshwari Kamaja, N. Saranya Devi, P.K.Dhal, C Srinivasan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: In smart cities, sustainable resource management is crucial for preserving environmental integrity and improving economic efficiency. One of the most serious concerns is wastewater recycling, which generally depends on old, energy-intensive processes. To solve this problem, AI-powered systems, notably those incorporating Artificial Neural Networks (ANN), provide a potential solution. This paper addresses the integration of ANN in improving wastewater recycling operations within smart city infrastructure. Using ANN's capacity to learn from big datasets, such systems may dramatically boost the accuracy of real-time monitoring, predictive maintenance, and effective resource allocation. The ANN-based model incorporates data from numerous sensors that monitor crucial characteristics such as water quality, flow rates, and energy usage. Continuous learning allows the system to discover trends, foresee prospective concerns, and deliver actionable insights to decrease operating costs and environmental consequences. Additionally, predictive maintenance offered by ANN aids in avoiding downtime and ensuring the system functions at top performance. By incorporating AI and ANN into wastewater recycling systems, smart cities may achieve a more sustainable approach to managing water resources. This study addresses the possible advantages of this integration, including increased system dependability, resource efficiency, and a decrease in the total environmental impact.

title: SAT-Based Approaches for Two-Dimensional Bin Packing: A Comprehensive Comparison with MIP and CP Methods
authors: Tuyen Van Kieu, Chi Linh Hoang, Khanh Van To
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: The Two-Dimensional Bin Packing Problem (2DBPP) is an NP-hard problem where traditional methods like Mixed Integer Programming (MIP) and Constraint Programming (CP) can be slow. This paper introduces a comprehensive SAT-based framework for 2D-BPP, featuring dual nonstacking and stacking strategies with rotation and symmetrybreaking constraints. We evaluated three solving paradigms: binary search with a standard SAT solver, incremental SAT, and a direct MaxSAT approach. Extensive experiments show that our methods are highly competitive, often outperforming leading commercial solvers-including Google OR-Tools, IBM CPLEX, and Gurobi-on their respective CP and MIP models, establishing SAT as a powerful alternative for this class of geometric optimization problems.

title: Hybrid Bat Firefly Optimization for Real-Time Energy Aware Multi Objective Routing
authors: M. SriRaghavendra, M Archana, M Bhavsingh, Sk. Khaja Shareef, Vidya Sagar Vendrapati, Chappidi Suneetha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: As more logistics systems adopt AI for autonomy, it has become necessary to find solutions that balance cost, energy efficiency, and timely delivery. Traditional algorithms have difficulty working in changing and complex environments because they are not flexible enough to deal with several goals. The study has been designed to build a hybrid algorithm based on Bat Algorithm (BA) and Firefly Algorithm (FA) to make the route optimization process more efficient for autonomous logistics. Thanks to its approach of taking advantages of both BA and FA, the HBFO algorithm can keep a good balance between exploring and exploiting possible solutions. A multi-objective model is developed to decrease the distance traveled, the energy used, and the operation’s expenses. Solomon VRPTW was used for experiments as well as a real-time SmartCitySim dataset. Some examples of metrics are total distance, the energy used, the time you are traveling, and the hypervolume for measuring diversity. From the results, HBFO is better in each metric as compared to standard GA, PSO, BA, and FA. When compared to the best-performing algorithm (BA), HBFO is able to cut route distance by 7.2%, use less energy by 8.1%, and take less time to run by 13.7%. The Pareto front in the hypervolume result of 0.88 is well grouped and varied. With the use of this framework, AI-driven logistics can enjoy more sustainability, efficiency, and improved performance.

title: Analyzing Tourist Perceptions of Bali's Tourism Villages: A Google Review Study Using Lexicon-SVM Approaches
authors: Ni Wayan Sumartini Saraswati, I Putu Gede Suma Wijaya, Emmy Febriani Thalib, I Dewa Made Krishna Muku, I Kadek Agus Bisena, I Wayan Dharma Suryawan
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ICoAIT)
abstract: Tourism is the main sector driving the regional economy, including in Bali which has many leading Tourism Villages such as Penglipuran, Jatiluwih, and Les. Until 2023, there are 238 Tourism Villages in Bali, which show great potential in supporting sustainable tourism and the welfare of local communities. This research analyzes tourist sentiment towards Tourism Villages in Bali using 5,952 Google Maps Review data. The method used is a combination of Lexicon and Support Vector Machine (SVM) with a linear kernel. The classification results polarize 98.66% positive reviews and 1.34% negative reviews, with model accuracy of 91.26%. Despite high performance on the positive class (recall 1.00 and F1-score 0.95), the model is still weak in recognizing the negative class (recall 0.08 and F1-score 0.14) because of an imbalance dataset. The visualization of popular words showed positive aspects such as cleanliness, culture, rice fields, and the friendliness of the people. Meanwhile, tourist complaints include tourist traps perception, crowds, payment issues, and public facilities. The findings provide input for stakeholders to maintain positive attractions and improve negative aspects in order to support higher quality and sustainable tourism of Bali.

title: Implementation of YOLOv11 for Automatic Offside Detection in Football
authors: Ayu Nur Indahsari, Lila Setiyani, Devi Fajar Wati, Solikin
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Offside decisions in football often spark debates and controversies due to the rapid movement of players and the ball, as well as the limited capacity of referees to observe dynamic match situations accurately. These errors can significantly affect fairness and match outcomes. Although the Video Assistant Referee (VAR) system has been introduced to assist referees, it still relies heavily on manual interpretation, which is prone to bias and inconsistency. To address these challenges, this study presents the development of an automatic offside detection system using the YOLOv11 object detection model. Two variants-YOLOv11 Nano (YOLOv11n) and YOLOv11 Small (YOLOv11s)-are evaluated for their effectiveness in detecting offside situations. The methodology includes dataset preparation by collecting and annotating football footage, followed by model training and evaluation. Both models are assessed based on mean Average Precision (mAP@0.5 and mAP@0.5:0.95), inference speed, and robustness across different match scenarios. Experimental results show that YOLOv11n achieves higher detection accuracy, while YOLOv11s demonstrates greater stability across varied conditions. As the first study to apply YOLOv11 for automatic offside detection in football, this research highlights the novelty of integrating state-of-the-art object detection into officiating. The comparative insights between YOLOv11n and YOLOv11s provide valuable guidance for future applications of AI in sports analytics, aiming to enhance fairness, objectivity, and efficiency in referee decision-making.

title: Advanced Deep Reinforcement Learning for Heat Pump Control in Residential Buildings
authors: Gökhan Demirel, Ömer Ekin, Jianlei Liu, Luigi Spatafora, Kevin Förderer, Veit Hagenmeyer
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Residential heating is a significant contributor to carbon emissions. Replacing conventional on/off and heating curve controls with smart strategies is essential for decarbonization. This paper presents eight state-of-the-art control strategies for residential air-source heat pumps in the open-source environment LLECBuildingGym, which emulates the heat pump house at the Living Lab Energy Campus (LLEC). We compare three rule-based controllers (fuzzy, PI, and PID), a model-predictive controller (MPC), and four advanced deep reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms (A2C, DDPG, PPO, and SAC) in a 1R1C thermal building model with continuous heating and cooling control. The model captures nonlinear thermal dynamics using Euler discretization, models sensor uncertainties as reflected Wiener processes and integrates dynamic electricity tariffs. We define single-objective (temperature) and multi-objective tasks that minimize thermal discomfort and energy costs. An extensive ablation study identifies the best performing RL algorithm configuration that reduces cost by 6% compared to rule-based controllers, outperforms MPC by 1% and underperforms MPC with perfect prediction by less than 4%.

title: MVDC and MVAC Comparison for Stability and Frequency Support in Expanding Distribution Grids with Intermittent Resources
authors: Saad Moufid, Jerôme Buire, Nouredine Hadjsaid, Philippe Alibert
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The integration of distributed energy resources (DERs) into medium-voltage alternating current (MVAC) grids presents significant challenges, particularly in hosting capacity limitations. As decentralization efforts increase, MVAC grids become saturated, necessitating expansion to maintain stability and efficiency. This study examines two possible expansion strategies: reinforcing the existing MVAC infrastructure or transitioning to a hybrid network incorporating medium-voltage direct current (MVDC) links. A key focus is on frequency stability, specifically the impact on the rate of change of frequency (RoCoF) and nadir during primary frequency response. To address this, small-signal models are developed and validated, enabling sensitivity analysis to identify key parameters that influence RoCoF and nadir. These models are further validated through Electromagnetic transient (EMT) simulations to demonstrate their accuracy and reliability. An assessment was performed to evaluate the effectiveness of MVDC integration in improving frequency stability relative to traditional MVAC expansion.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Modeling Parameters on BEMT Simulations
authors: Hércules A. Oliveira, Lucas de Paula A. Pinheiro, Orlando Da Silva Santos, Fábio Silva Alves, Joel Alves Da Costa, José Gomes De Matos
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Currently, various analytical models have been proposed to represent the performance of wind turbines as alternatives that require lower computational costs, both in processing time and hardware capacity. These models are particularly relevant for large-scale simulations, feasibility studies, and project optimization, enabling efficient analysis without the need for robust computational resources, such as those required by computational fluid dynamics-based methods. The structuring and customization of these models must be carried out carefully to ensure that the obtained results accurately represent the real behavior of wind turbines. This paper presents an analytical model for evaluating wind turbine performance, detailing the method’s development and discussing the key factors that impact the accuracy of the results. The proposed approach seeks to balance simplicity and precision, offering a viable alternative for technical studies and practical applications in the wind energy sector.

title: Miniaturized Dual-Beam SERF Magnetometer Using Natural Abundance Rubidium
authors: Jianwei Sheng, Ziao Liu, Xiaoyu Li, Zhongyu Wang, Shushan Gao, Jixi Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Due to high sensitivity and compactness, spin-exchange relaxation-free (SERF) atomic magnetometers have found widespread applications. These devices rely on alkali atoms to sense magnetic fields, with <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">87</sup>Rb being the commonly used isotope. However, <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">87</sup>Rb must be extracted from natural abundance rubidium (natRb) through isotopic separation, making it expensive. Replacing <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">87</sup>Rb with natRb reduces the cost to approximately just 1%. Nevertheless, it is generally believed that the isotopic mixture of <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">87</sup>Rb and <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">85</sup>Rb in natRb affects the coherence of the atomic ensemble. Using a dual-beam SERF magnetometer, we systematically compared 3 mm inner-size cubic vapor cells filled with natRb and <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">87</sup>Rb. By optimizing the buffer gas pressure and optical parameters, we demonstrate that the natRb magnetometer can achieve performance comparable to that of the <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">87</sup>Rb magnetometer. Experimental results show that both cells achieved a sensitivity of 4 1T/Hz<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1/2</sup>. These findings demonstrate that natRb can effectively replace <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">87</sup>Rb in miniaturized dual-beam SERF magnetometers, enabling low-cost, high-sensitivity magnetic field measurements.

title: On the Damping Redistribution Mechanism of Angle-Voltage Coupling Dynamics in Power Systems with Hybrid GFM-GFL Devices
authors: Xiaoyu Peng, Xi Ru, Tuo Jiang, Xinghua Chen, Jianxin Zhang, Feng Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper investigates the impact of the coupling between phase-angle and voltage dynamics in hybrid power systems integrated with grid-forming (GFM) and grid-following (GFL) inverters through the extended damping redistribution theory. Due to the differing synchronization dynamics of GFM and GFL devices, the conventional frameworks derived from GFM systems fail to adequately address emerging stability risks caused by angle-voltage coupling in hybrid systems. To bridge this gap, a causal approximation technique is developed to invert the input-output relationship of GFL dynamics, enabling a unified modeling framework for hybrid devices. Then, the study extends the damping redistribution theory to hybrid systems by deriving explicit quantification for total system damping and its dispersion. It is discovered that the damping redistribution mechanism of angle-voltage coupling dynamics still works in hybrid systems. Specifically, the coupling worsens the stability not by changing the total damping, but by redistributing it more dispersively. The proposed methodology is validated through numerical simulations on an IEEE 14-bus system, demonstrating its effectiveness in quantifying angle-voltage coupling dynamics and implications for stability analysis.

title: Research on Intelligent Monitoring Data System of Power System Grounding Using High Conductivity Fiber Materials
authors: Jingjing An, Fang Li, Guoyang Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: This study aims to solve the problem of grounding monitoring in power systems and conducts research on intelligent monitoring data system using high conductivity fiber materials. An adaptive dynamic weight fusion algorithm (ADWFA) is designed to improve data processing accuracy by dynamically adjusting the weights of multi-source data. A 10 kV distribution network grounding model is built based on MATLAB to simulate normal operation and various fault scenarios such as single-phase grounding and two-phase grounding. Sensors made of carbon nanotube fibers are deployed at key locations of the model to collect data. Experiments show that under normal operation, the system controls the monitoring error of electrical parameters such as current and voltage within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 1 \%$</tex>; when a grounding fault occurs, the ADWFA algorithm can identify the fault type within 0.05 seconds, and the positioning error is less than 0.5 meters. Compared with traditional algorithms, the fault identification accuracy is improved by 15 %, the positioning accuracy is improved by 20 %, and the data transmission delay is reduced to less than 50 ms, which effectively verifies the reliability and efficiency of the system and algorithm, and provides an innovative technical solution for grounding safety monitoring of power systems.

title: Multi-Stage Scenario Reduction for Optimal Energy Storage Operation in Real-Time Markets
authors: Robin Bruneel, Panagiotis Patrinos
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The growing share of renewable energy sources in the electricity grid has led to increased volatility in real-time balancing prices. While this volatility creates valuable opportunities for energy storage systems (ESS), the inherent uncertainty of future prices significantly complicates the optimization process. In this paper, we propose a multi-stage scenario-based stochastic model predictive control (SMPC) strategy to optimize the operation of ESS in real-time balancing markets. Central to our approach is a stagewise refinement algorithm, inspired by optimal transport theory. This algorithm constructs non-symmetric multi-stage scenario trees through clustering methods and is benchmarked in a simulation on the Belgian real-time balancing market with a battery energy storage system. Results demonstrate that our approach, particularly when combined with k-means clustering, yields higher profits compared to traditional multi-stage reduction techniques.

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Model for Parkinson’s Stage using Voice and Hand Drawn Image Analysis
authors: Sinduja.R, S.Shanthini, S.Manochithra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Parkinson’s disease (PD) mainly affects speech, motor coordination, and quality of life, which illustrates that precise stage identification is crucial so appropriate treatment can be selected and monitored. The current diagnosing method is dependent on clinical examination oftentimes taking considerable time and resources. To address this problem, this framework introduces a multimodal deep learning framework consisting of speech analysis and motor analysis to accomplish automated stage classification. Hand-Created spiral and waves images are processed by a Vision Transformer (ViT) to identify motor impairment, while voice samples are converted to Mel-Frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs) and classified by a convolutional neural network (CNN). The outputs from the two models are combined at the decision level through majority voting. The system is evaluated using the YOLO Parkinson's voice dataset and an augmented hand drawn dataset from Kaggle. The results show that the CNN achieves an accuracy of 87%, ViT achieves 85%, and the fusion achieves 90.5%, all outperforming unimodal baselines. the prototype is an inexpensive, user-friendly application for AI-Assisted stage prediction in real-time, thus acting as a scalable clinical support tool.

title: The X-ray CT observation of the liberation mechanism of concrete sample under the influence of high voltage pulse
authors: Luokang Dong, Yingjie Fu, Mengbing He, Wei Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: The High Voltage Pulse (HVP) has become an efficient emerging technology for preparing recycled aggregates from waste concrete. An experimental device for crushing concrete using high voltage pulsed was produced by HUST. In order to analyze the disintegration mechanism of concrete sample under the high voltage pulse, this paper uses X-ray CT to examine how discharge channels grow within sample during high voltage pulse fragmentation. The discharge channels have a 'trunk-branch' spatial distribution characteristic. Due to the differing electrical properties of aggregates and cement mortar, primarily manifested in their relative permittivity, the electric field strength changes abruptly at their interface. Consequently, discharge channels always propagate along the aggregate surface. This liberation mechanism enables the high voltage pulse crushing process to achieve a higher degree of dissociation than traditional mechanical methods, while preserving the complete structural morphology of the aggregate within the concrete sample.

title: Incentive-based Coordinated Charging Framework for EVs in Distribution Network with User Preferences
authors: Siti Sufiah Bte Abd Wahid, Yiqiao Xu, Alessandra Parisio
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Due to the rapidly increasing number of electric vehicles (EVs), distribution networks are facing challenges in terms of peak loads and system reliability. To mitigate these impacts, coordinated charging gains substantial attention, which necessitates the incorporation of user preferences to enhance participation and system-level benefits. While many studies have proposed time-flexible delayed charging, this paper proposed an incentive-based coordinated charging framework considering user preferences in terms of the offered flexibility, characterized by state-of-charge (SOC) and charging duration. An optimization problem is formulated to minimize the charging cost and peak load by introducing preference-based indexes for the incentives. Through a formulated metric, we demonstrate the performance of the framework in reducing the charging cost and peak load according to the provided flexibility. With the combination of SOC and time preferences, the comparative analysis verifies that the proposed framework outperforms the benchmarks.

title: ResNet-Based Visual Feature Analysis and System Design for Rural Imagery
authors: Shihui Wang, Adzrool Idzwan Bin Ismail
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Recent advancements in rural development have driven the creation and utilization of large volumes of imagery from diverse rural environments. Efficient classification and analysis of these images are crucial for various engineering and management applications. In this work, we propose a ResNet-based framework that addresses the challenges of rural imagery by integrating data acquisition, preprocessing, deep feature extraction, and automated classification. A multi-label dataset with distribution-oriented annotations is employed to accommodate the inherent complexity of rural scenes and to enhance robustness. Experimental results reveal that the proposed approach accurately captures distinctive visual features in varied conditions, enabling reliable categorization. Furthermore, an interactive visualization module is incorporated to facilitate rapid interpretation of classification outcomes. Overall, this system provides a scalable solution for real-time deployment and can be extended to support rural planning, assessment, and other related processes in a flexible and efficient manner.

title: CAAF-ResUnet: Dynamic Fusion of Attention Mechanisms for Context-Aware Lung CT Scan Segmentation
authors: Thang Quoc Pham, Thai Hoang Le, Khai Dinh Lai, Dat Quoc Ngo, Tan Van Pham, Quang Hong Hua, Khang Quang Le, Huyen Le Duy Mai, Tuyen Nguyen Ngoc Lam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Wavelet Analysis and Pattern Recognition (ICWAPR)
abstract: Segmentation of pulmonary nodules in CT scans is critical for early diagnosis and treatment of lung diseases. Traditional models like U-Net often face challenges with small nodule sizes, and noisy data. To address these limitations, we propose CAAF-ResUnet (Context-Aware Adaptive Attention Fusion ResUnet), which combines Channel Attention and Position Attention using an Adaptive Attention Fusion (AAF) mechanism, controlled by an Adaptive Attention Controller (AAC). Our model achieves commendable performance on the LUNA16 and LUNA-Noise datasets, with Dice Scores of 89.44% and 88.55%, respectively. These results surpass existing methods, demonstrating the model’s ability to prioritize meaningful features and handle noisy inputs effectively. CAAF-ResUnet provides a robust solution for nodule segmentation in challenging scenarios, paving the way for improved diagnostic accuracy in clinical settings. This work emphasizes the importance of adaptive attention mechanisms for medical image segmentation and highlights opportunities for future improvements.

title: Hierarchical Grid-Robust Discretization of the Electric-Field Integral Equation by the Method of Moments
authors: Eduard Ubeda, Juan M. Rius
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Traditionally, the scattering analysis with the Electric-Field Integral Equation of perfectly conducting objects has been carried out through divergence-conforming schemes of discretization, which are numerically convenient because the dominant Kernel contributions are weakly singular. Since the divergence-conforming sets enforce by definition the continuity of the normal component of the expanded magnitudes through the edges arising from the discretization, the analysis can only be applied to objects conformally meshed, with adjacent facets sharing a single edge. In practice, this hampers the flexible analysis of complex structures, which very often need to be modelled through the interconnection of independent meshes. In this paper, we introduce two novel schemes of discretization of the Electric-Field Integral Equation that are based on the expansion of the current through a hierarchical rearrangement of the monopolar-RWG expansion of the current (fully discontinuous at edges). Both schemes manage the zeroth-order scheme of testing in the same manner. The first-order testing scheme, though, is implemented differently in both cases, either through volumetric or through surface testing integrals. We show with RCS-results the accuracy of the proposed schemes in the analysis of a sharp-edged perfectly conducting object.

title: Space-Time Modulated Metasurface-Based EM Tags for Coding Capacity Enhancement
authors: Zihao Ning, Yiwei Wang, Mengmeng Li, Dazhi Ding
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This paper proposes a space-time modulated metasurface-based electromagnetic (EM) tag design for coding capacity enhancement. By combining geometric structure modulation in the spatial domain with dynamic phase modulation in the temporal domain, multi-dimensional control of EM waves is achieved, significantly improving the tag's coding capacity. This work provides a potential technical solution for high-density tag coding in the Internet of Things (IoT).

title: Secure Government Health Data Management Through Blockchain and DBMS Integration
authors: Bahrul Ulum, Paulus Insap Santosa, Lukito Edi Nugroho
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Abstrak-Ensuring the security of government-managed health data is a critical challenge, particularly in centralized systems that are prone to internal and external threats, including unauthorized access and data tampering. This paper proposes a cost-effective approach to enhancing health data security by integrating blockchain technology with the existing relational database management system (DBMS) used in the Teman Mas Abdi application at the Kediri Regency Health Office. In the proposed hybrid architecture, public data such as health facility profiles is maintained in the DBMS, while sensitive private data, including electronic medical records, is stored on a blockchain using BigchainDB. This design enables encryption, immutability, and patient-centric control over personal data. System testing demonstrates that the integration preserves existing infrastructure, minimizes financial overhead, and complies with Indonesia's Ministry of Health Regulation No. 24 of 2022 concerning electronic medical records.

title: Research on Voltage Stability of Distribution Network Based on Forward-Backward Sweep Power Flow Calculation
authors: Jia Xi
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: With the advancement of new power system construction, distributed renewable energy resources (RER) are growing exponentially in distribution networks (DN), causing local node voltage violations. Power flow calculation in distribution networks is essential for voltage stability analysis. This paper uses the forward-backward sweep power flow method to evaluate the voltage stability of reconfigured distribution networks before and after RER integration from multiple dimensions, employing voltage standard deviation, L-index, and voltage-violation nodes. Case studies on an improved IEEE 33-node distribution network using MATLAB/SIMULINK verify the effectiveness of identifying critical lines and peak moments in time and space, which helps optimize operation strategies and guide distributed generation integration.

title: Experimental Assessment of the Performance of an Electron Cyclotron Resonance Acceleration (ECRA) Thruster Operated with Iodine
authors: Samuele Carere, Federico Boni, Guido Lombardi, Victor Désangles
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: The growing demand for compact and efficient space propulsion systems has accelerated the development of alternative propellants and thruster technologies. Iodine is a promising candidate for electric propulsion due to its high storage density, low ionization energy, and significantly lower cost compared to xenon. This work explores the use of iodine in an Electron Cyclotron Resonance Acceleration (ECRA) thruster originally designed for xenon. Thrust, specific impulse, and efficiency were measured using a Faraday probe for iodine and other propellants. The results, however subject to large uncertainties due to the estimation method of ion energy, demonstrate the similar behavior of ECRA thruster between iodine and xenon. Performance uncertainties related to plasma composition are discussed.

title: HaLow Simulator for Dense Wireless Networks
authors: Bruna Toledo Guedes, Célio Vinicius, Neves De Albuquerque, Diego Gimenez Passos, Fernanda Gonçalves De Oliveira Passos
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: This paper presents a HaLow wireless simulator, which provides a simulated environment based on the IEEE 802.11ah standard. The simulator allows generating metrics to evaluate network performance considering groups generated by the Restricted Access Window (RAW) mechanism. Users can also provide grouping configurations through input files for testing with custom grouping algorithms. Evaluation results show that the simulator scales efficiently while maintaining low memory footprint and execution time, even in large-scale network scenarios with 1,000 stations.

title: EmbedRank-LM: Natural Language-Driven Web Element Identification for Automated UI Testing
authors: Trinh Le-Khanh, Quyen Hoang-Van, Pham Ngoc Hung
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: User Interface (UI) testing is crucial for ensuring the functionality and user experience of software applications. Traditional manual UI testing approaches are time-consuming and error-prone, particularly as web applications scale. While automated testing has emerged as a solution, existing methods rely heavily on brittle element locators such as CSS selectors and XPath expressions, which are vulnerable to structural changes in web applications. This paper presents EmbedRank-LM, a novel approach for web element identification using natural language descriptions to reduce dependency on conventional element locators in automated UI testing. The proposed method employs a two-stage process: first, a sentence embedding model selects the top-k candidate elements with the highest semantic similarity to the input description; second, a large language model performs final element selection from the candidate set. An experimental evaluation on a dataset of 300 samples derived from Pasupat et al.'s benchmark demonstrates that EmbedRank-LM achieves 67% accuracy, significantly outperforming baseline methods, including Trinh et al. (42.67%) and AgentQL (59.67%). While EmbedRank-LM exhibits a longer execution time compared to baseline approaches, it demonstrates a substantially lower execution cost, being 18 times more cost-effective than AgentQL, and establishes an advantageous trade-off between accuracy, processing time, and computational cost for practical UI testing applications.

title: Multi-Scene Layered Container Pre-Migration Method for Satellite Task Continuity
authors: Junxiang Qin, Zhi Qu, Xuan Li, Xiaotian Ma, Zhixi Yang, Yufeng Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Frequent handover caused by high-speed mobility in LEO satellite networks seriously affects task continuity and service quality. Aiming at this challenge, this paper proposes a layered container pre-migration method for satellite task continuity. By constructing a layered container model (basic mirror layer, application layer and service instance layer), this method combines the multi-satellite cooperative migration mechanism and the dynamic priority pre-migration strategy to realize the efficient cooperation between lightweight mirror transmission and state hot migration. The experimental results show that compared with the traditional full migration, this method reduces the task interruption time by more than 80%, improves the task success rate by 40%, and optimizes the utilization ratio of network and computing resources by 20% and 15% respectively. The research results provide theoretical and technical support for the task continuity guarantee of LEO satellite network, and are especially suitable for real-time task scenarios such as communication and remote sensing.

title: Illumination-Adaptive ORB Framework with Hybrid Threshold Fusion for Robust River Surface Flow Measurement
authors: Jian Shang, Zhen Zhang, Huijuan Zhao, Juncheng Bao
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Accurate surface flow measurement is critical for environmental sensing systems, particularly in automated river discharge monitoring. While vision-based optical flow techniques offer non-contact advantages over physical sensors, their reliability in field deployments is compromised by natural illumination variations such as dynamic shadows, reflections, and solar glare. Existing feature detection algorithms require manual threshold adjustments under changing light conditions, undermining automation in hydrological applications. This study proposes an illumination-adaptive Oriented FAST and Rotated BRIEF (ORB) framework integrating global Kapur-Sahoo-Wong (KSW) entropy-driven threshold optimization with localized contrast evaluation and Harris corner response filtering. The method dynamically adjusts detection parameters through hybrid threshold fusion, spatial homogenization, and eigenvalue-based geometric stability analysis. Experimental validation on 7,500 river surface images demonstrates 94% detection accuracy under stable lighting, sustaining 82% precision and 68% recall in severe glare conditions. Compared to conventional Scale-Invariant Feature Transform (SIFT), Speeded-Up Robust Features (SURF) , and Features from Accelerated Segment Test (FAST) detectors, the approach reduces edge false alarms by 40–60% and triples valid feature density in low-visibility regions. By eliminating manual calibration and enhancing robustness to photometric interference, this framework enables reliable optical flow tracking for continuous discharge measurement, advancing automated hydrological monitoring through environmental adaptability and computational efficiency.

title: A Directional Scale-based Cosine Similarity Indicator for Adaptive Particle Swarm Optimization
authors: Xing-Yu Wang, Jian-Yu Li, Zhi-Hui Zhan, Jun Zhang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Information Science and Technology (ICIST)
abstract: Particle swarm optimization (PSO) is an effective swarm intelligence algorithm, that solves optimization problems by simulating the behaviors of natural swarms like bird flocks. In the original PSO, the control parameters decide the performance of the algorithm. In present studies, researchers often used distance as the assessment criterion, which brings a dimensional ambiguity and ignores the consideration of the searching direction. To solve this issue, a directional scale-based cosine similarity indicator (DSCSI) has been proposed. This improvement enables the controller to achieve rational adjustments based on the unique directional differences in populations. The proposed indicator was applied in adaptive particle swarm optimization (APSO) and tested on CEC2014 with different dimensional information, compared with five state-of-the-art algorithms. The results of the comparison show that the directional scale-based adaptive particle swarm optimization (DSAPSO) has better performance as the dimension increases than the traditional distance-based APSO.

title: A Hybrid Acoustic-Optical Communication Technique for Ultra-Low Latency Underwater IoT Network
authors: Nellore Kapileswar, Judy Simon
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Underwater Internet of Things (UIoT) has emerged as a promising paradigm for marine exploration, environmental monitoring, offshore infrastructure inspection, and defense applications. However, existing communication technologies for UIoT predominantly rely on acoustic channels, which suffer from high latency, limited bandwidth, and significant energy consumption. Although its data rates are higher, optical communication is badly limited by the limited range of transmission and its susceptibility to turbidity. In order to address these restrictions, this paper introduces a new Hybrid Acoustic-Optical Communication Technique that aims to reach extreme low-latency and high-reliability communication in underwater IoT networks. The suggested solution utilizes the acoustic connection as long-range (low-bandwidth) control signaling and applies dynamic integration of optical channels as short-range (high-throughput) data communications. A real-time channel quality estimation-based adaptive switching algorithm provides ideal usage of the two mediums. The findings of the simulations prove that the hybrid scheme is able to considerably decrease the end-to-end latency, maximize the throughput, as well as extend the lifetime of the network, relative to the traditional acoustic-only systems. This paper establishes the groundwork of the next-generation underwater IoT architectures that can be used to support intelligent and delay-sensitive applications within a dynamic marine system.

title: Research Progress of Precision Current Measurement Based on Quantum Sensing
authors: Liren Zhou, Li Zhu, Yang Pan
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: As one of the core development directions of quantum technology, quantum sensing employs the intrinsic property of microscopic particles to realize the measurement of physical quantities, with the characteristics of high sensitivity, high stability and high accuracy. Compared with the traditional traceability method, applying the quantum effect to reproduce the value, the traceability link is shorter; the speed is faster, and the measurement result is more accurate and stable. This paper focuses on the precision current measurement based on quantum sensing. Aiming at the giant magneto-resistance (GMR) effect, superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) and diamond nitrogen-vacancy (NV) color center, the measurement principle, key technology, performance index and application field are expounded. Fully develop the intrinsic property of quantum; the quantum sensing performance index may exceed the classical measurement limit, which has great application potential and broad prospect in the field of current measurement. It is worthy of attention and in-depth research.

title: Lightweight Architectures for Binary Segmentation of Fresh Mud Deposits in UAV Imagery
authors: M. Guastella, A. D'Alessandro, A. Pisciotta, R. Martorana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Monitoring surface activity in mud volcanoes is critical for understanding fluid-driven geological processes and mitigating associated hazards. This work presents a deep learning-based approach to segmenting nadiral imagery captured by Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), with the aim of identifying fresh mud deposits. Given the scarcity of labeled data and the absence of pretrained models suitable for this domain, we developed custom segmentation architectures tailored to the visual complexity and scale of UAVcaptured volcanic terrain. The proposed models were trained from scratch and evaluated on a dataset collected across active sites in Sicily. Results show that domain-adapted network design enables robust delineation of geologically relevant features, offering a practical framework for automating UAV-based observation in environmental and geohazard monitoring.

title: Forecasting the Future: Exploring the Effectiveness of SARIMA and LSTM Models for Vegetable Price Prediction in Karachi, Pakistan
authors: Syeda Umm E Abiha Rizvi, Maham Tariq Khan, Narmeen Aamir
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ICoAIT)
abstract: Over the span of years, the agricultural sector of Pakistan has faced many challenges, including unpredictable weather patterns, crop diseases, and volatile markets. Accurate price forecasting is a critical aspect of agricultural economics as it enables farmers, policymakers, and retailers to make informed decisions about pricing, distribution, and crop management to increase the efficiency of the agricultural sector. Given the rise to the emergence of Artificial Intelligence, the time series models have emerged as essential tools for predicting vegetable prices. These models can capture the dynamic nature of price fluctuations and help predict future prices accurately. The prediction of vegetable prices in Karachi, Pakistan, has not been extensively researched, prompting the need for further investigation in this area. To address this gap, the following research paper is developed, which aims to conduct a thorough analysis of various time series models, with particular focus on the comparative analysis of SARIMA and LSTM to determine the most effective and accurate model for forecasting future vegetable prices in Karachi, Pakistan. With an aim to analyze two very different time-series approaches for vegetable price prediction and choosing the most efficient one, this paper endorses that LSTM performs better when dealing with large datasets and complex non-linear patterns in price fluctuations.

title: Research on a Filter Defect Detection System Based on Jetson Nano and YOLOv13
authors: Yunfeng Guo, Xiaojuan Wei, Maoyuan Zhang, Run An, Pengcheng Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: To address the issues of low efficiency and high missed detection rates in manual inspection of filters, this study proposes an intelligent defect detection system based on the Jetson Orin Nano platform, aiming to achieve high-precision and high-efficiency recognition of surface defects. The system adopts the YOLOv13 network model, which can effectively identify four typical types of defects: scratches, unclear printing, ink leakage, and missing rubber rings. Host computer software integrating user login, image and video detection, real-time monitoring, and database management functions has been developed, offering good deployability and operational convenience. The system was deployed on the Jetson Orin Nano platform for practical testing. The results demonstrate that the proposed method can effectively identify various defects, with a model accuracy of 92.4% and a single-frame defect detection time of less than 0.01 seconds, meeting industrial real-time requirements. This study provides a feasible embedded solution for real-time, high-precision detection of surface defects in filters.

title: Scaling Up the Sustainability of Photonic Tensor Cores With Device-Circuit-Signaling Co-Design
authors: Ishan Thakkar, Sairam Sri Vatsavai, Venkata Sai Praneeth Karempudi, Oluwaseun Adewunmi Alo
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Photonic tensor cores have grown in popularity over the past few years for accelerating tensor-based kernels found in abundance in deep learning workloads because they offer potentially massive spatial parallelism (across wavelengths and waveguides), subnanosecond-scale start-to-solution latency, and near-dissipation-free dynamic operation. However, several shortcomings severely limit the practically achievable parallelism, processing throughput, and energy efficiency in existing photonic tensor core architectures. For instance, the wavelength-selective analog operation of existing designs makes them highly prone to crosstalk noise and other optical signal penalties and losses. These penalties and losses interplay with an already tight optical power budget, leading to strong trade-offs for achievable spatial parallelism, operating data rate, and analog precision. This paper shows how co-designing low-dissipation, low-noise, and high-speed electro-photonic devices, crosstalk-minimal circuit organizations, and mixed unary/analog signaling methods can overcome these shortcomings to realize photonic tensor cores with scaled-up throughput and operational energy-efficiency benefits for accelerating a variety of deep learning workloads.

title: Implementation of the T5-small Model for Abstractive Text Summarization in SEO Meta Description Generation
authors: Irvan Arif Agustian, Ivana Lucia Kharisma, Gina Purnama Insany, Kamdan, Somantri, Muhamad Muslih
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: In the digital age, content visibility on search engines is crucial, with SEO meta descriptions playing an important role in attracting users' attention. This element is important in attracting users' attention while increasing the chances of interaction. However, the process of creating SEO meta descriptions is still largely done traditionally or manually, making it inefficient and difficult to maintain consistency on a large scale. This study aims to implement the T5-small model to generate meta descriptions and evaluate the model's performance in generating SEO meta descriptions. The method used is fine-tuning the small variant of the Text-to-Text Transfer Transformer (T5) model on a large-scale Indonesian news dataset (Liputan6). This model is trained to summarize abstract texts, with the results formatted as meta descriptions. Quantitative evaluation of the test data shows promising performance, with a ROUGE-1 score of 34.09, a ROUGE-2 score of 18.67, and a ROUGE-L score of 29.37. This study concludes that the fine-tuned T5-small model is an effective and efficient solution for generating relevant and coherent SEO meta descriptions, bridging the gap between advances in AI technology and the practical needs of digital marketing.

title: Estimating Electric Fields from $\mathrm{B}_{1}$ Maps in Circular and Elliptic Cylinders with Deep Learning
authors: Giuseppe Carluccio, Eros Montin, Christopher M. Collins, Riccardo Lattanzi, Daniele Riccio, Giuseppe Ruello
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: In Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), the estimation of the electric fields is important both to accurately estimate the SNR and to assess safety of the MRI scans. Use of deep learning networks can provide quick results by manipulating measurable quantities such as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$B_{1}^{+}$</tex> maps. Analytical solutions can quickly generate a significant amount of data, which is useful to accurately train the networks. Recently, some networks were trained with analytical solutions able to compute the fields in concentric and eccentric circular geometries. In this work we extend these results by also including the scattering from elliptic cylinders. We have compared the performance of three networks, where one is trained with eccentric circular cylinders, one with elliptic cylinders, and one with data from both the previous datasets. We could observe that the networks trained with data from elliptic cylinders are the ones providing the most general results, with up to 16.6 % of maximum observed error, and are able to provide good performance in structures not part of the datasets, such as eccentric cylinders. These datasets can be used to improve the training of networks where the datasets comprise fields scattered from more heterogeneous geometries, computed with numerical solutions.

title: AI-Driven Integrated Logistics Framework for Antimalarial Drug Distribution in Remote Areas
authors: Nelson Lungu, Bibhuti Bhusan Dash, Simon Tembo, Utpal Chandra De, Satyendr Singh, Sudhansu Shekhar Patra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: More than 600,000 people died from malaria in 2022, making it one of the main causes of death in Sub-Saharan Africa. Seasonal disease outbreaks and inadequate infrastructure in isolated areas frequently result in antimalarial medication shortages. For rural clinics, we offer an intelligent logistics framework that systematically predicts demand and schedules medication distribution. Our methodology combines a deep Reinforcement Learning (RL) agent for adaptive routing under uncertainty, a Graph Neural Network (GNN)-based supply-chain optimiser, and a multivariate Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network for demand prediction. By taking geography, vehicle capacities, cold-chain restrictions, and seasonal malaria patterns into consideration, the system simultaneously reduces delivery time and cost while avoiding stockouts. Our model architectures, training protocols, and data sources are all thoroughly described. Real-world data from 247 rural health facilities spread across six African nations (Kenya, Nigeria, Malawi, Uganda, Tanzania, and Zambia) over 24 months is used for experimental validation. Our method reduces average delivery time by 42%, total distribution cost by 28%, and stockout incidents by 34% when compared to a traditional static planning baseline. The normalised error metric for demand forecasts is 92.1%, which is a considerable improvement over the 67.3% accuracy of basic methods. These improvements are highly significant, according to statistical tests (p<0.01). These findings show that antimalarial medication delivery in underserved areas can be significantly enhanced by a fully integrated AI-driven pipeline.

title: Fuzzy Logic for Evaluating the Acquisition of Soft Skills Through Adaptive Scenarios in Game-Based Learning: The Case of EPATHLO
authors: Konstantina Chrysafiadi, Spyros Papadimitriou, Maria Virvou
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: Teaching soft skills in intelligent educational environments remains a significant challenge due to their qualitative, context-sensitive nature. This paper presents a fuzzy logic-based mechanism that adapts game scenarios in response to individual learners' development of soft skills. In particular, the fuzzy logic model represents the ambiguity inherent in evaluating the acquisition of soft skills and provides adaptivity accordingly. Adaptivity is achieved through the automatic selection of the next game task to be delivered to players based on their level of soft skill acquisition. This mechanism has been embedded into EPATHLO, an intelligent educational adventure game designed to teach the HTML programming language and essential soft skills. Real users have utilized EPATHLO, and corresponding case studies are presented. The proposed fuzzy logic-based mechanism constitutes a novel approach to bridging the gap between hard and soft skills training in digital education.

title: Comparative Analysis of Static and Dynamic Cascading Simulators as Data Sources for Machine Learning Model Training
authors: George Paphitis, Mathaios Panteli
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The frequency of cascading failures in power systems is rising, driven by factors such as high renewable energy penetration and extreme weather events. Cascading failure models (CFMs), static and dynamic, help analyze these mechanisms and improve resilience. Recently, machine learning (ML) approaches have emerged to rapidly quantify cascading impacts. This paper compares static and dynamic cascading simulators based on how effectively they generate informative data for training ML models to predict spatial and total load shedding. Furthermore, conformal prediction is applied to assess the trustworthiness of the ML models. Results show that ML models trained on dynamic CFMs achieve nearly three times lower mean absolute error and root mean squared error, with improved coverage and narrower prediction intervals.

title: $\mu\text{STT}$: Microarchitecture Design for Speculative Taint Tracking
authors: Boru Chen, Rutvik Choudhary, Kaustubh Khulbe, Archie Lee, Adam Morrison, Christopher W. Fletcher
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Speculative execution attacks exploit malicious speculation to leak sensitive data via microarchitectural covert channels. Speculative Taint Tracking (STT) is a state-of-the-art hardware mechanism that blocks such threats by tainting data flowing from speculative loads, untainting data once all its dependencies are not speculative, and delaying instructions that create covert channels until their inputs are untainted. However, STT's hardware feasibility remains unclear due to a lack of detailed hardware cost analysis. This paper presents the first in-depth hardware cost analysis of STT and identifies two key challenges: (1) the logic delay of taint propagation, which grows with rename width, and (2) area overhead from instruction delaying, which requires expensive CAM-style logic to enforce speculation safety. To address these, we propose a new microarchitecture for STT, called <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu$</tex> STT. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu$</tex> STT is based on two new mechanisms. First, the Age Matrix is a shallow taint propagation circuit that removes 85% of the logic delay overhead of prior STT designs, while only adding 36 % more area at the default rename width of 8. Second, the impede micro-op implements instruction delaying in a fashion that increases STT's performance overhead by only 5 percentage points (from 16 % to 21 %), while replacing bespoke STT hardware with existing RAW dependency tracking. Together, these contributions reduce STT's hardware complexity and cost in the context of high-end wide-issue processor designs.

title: PriME: PIM-Aware Efficient Compression for Memory-Bound Embedding Layers in sLLMs
authors: Junghyeok Lee, Jihoon Jang, Hyun Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: With the growing demand for on-device AI, increasing efforts have been directed toward deploying lightweight small-scale large language models (sLLMs) on edge and mobile devices to enhance inference performance while minimizing computational cost and latency. As the number of decoder layers in sLLMs decreases, the embedding layer constitutes a substantial portion of the model's overall parameters and memory consumption. Consequently, efficient data compression is crucial; however, existing methods, such as quantization and pruning, drastically degrade accuracy when applied to the error-sensitive embedding layers. Moreover, embedding layer computations exhibit low arithmetic intensity (operations per byte), rendering them memory-bound. This limitation necessitates a shift from conventional von Neumann architectures to processing-in-memory (PIM) architectures. To address these challenges, this paper proposes (1) XOR-based Masking Compression (XMC), a lossless compression algorithm specialized for sLLM embedding layers, and (2) PriME, which integrates XMC with PIM architecture to alleviate memory bottlenecks in embedding layers. XMC enhances zero-bit representation in 16-bit FP data using ADD and XOR masking, achieving an average compression ratio of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.49 \times$</tex> while being implementable with a 3-cycle decompression delay. PriME enables parallel processing of compressed data within PIM, accelerating embedding computations by an average of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.0 \times$</tex> and up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.26 \times$</tex> compared to GPUs, while simultaneously reducing energy consumption by over 30 %, leading to an average energy efficiency improvement of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.29 \times$</tex>. Designed for broad applicability, PriME is compatible with various sLLMs and holds scalability for extension to multimodal small vision language models, demonstrating its versatility for efficient AI acceleration.

title: Security Evaluation of Quantum Circuit Split Compilation Under an Oracle-Guided Attack
authors: Hongyu Zhang, Yuntao Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Quantum circuits are the fundamental representation of quantum algorithms and constitute valuable intellectual property (IP). Multiple quantum circuit obfuscation (QCO) techniques have been proposed in prior research to protect quantum circuit IP against malicious compilers. However, there has not been a thorough security evaluation of these schemes. In this work, we investigate the resilience of split compilation against an oracle-guided attack. Split compilation is one of the most studied QCO techniques, where the circuit to be compiled is split into two disjoint partitions. Each split circuit is known to the compiler, but the interconnections between them are hidden. We propose an oracle-guided security evaluation framework in which candidate connections are systematically tested against inputoutput observations, with iteratively pruned inconsistent mappings. This hierarchical matching process exploits the reversibility of quantum gates and reduces the search space compared to brute-force enumeration. Experimental evaluation in the RevLib benchmark suite shows that only a small number of I/O pairs are sufficient to recover the correct inter-split connections and reconstruct the entire circuits. Our study marks the first thorough security evaluations in quantum IP protection and highlights the necessity of such evaluations in the development of new protection schemes.

title: A UAV-Based Far-Field Measurement System for HF Antennas
authors: Jiale He, Zhenxin Cao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: In this article, a UAV-based far-field measurement system for HF antennas is proposed, which consists of a UAV-mounted transmitter module, a portable multi-channel receiver and a spatiotemporal synchronization. The transmitting module is integrated into a custom-designed long-endurance multirole vertical takeoff and landing (VTOL) fixed-wing UAV. The transmitter employs a broadband normal-mode helix transmitting antenna operates across <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.3-20 \text{MHz}$</tex> (VSWR <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<3$</tex>). The receiver incorporates a 16-channel parallel acquisition system capable of synchronous measurements for up to 16-element antenna arrays. The spatiotemporal synchronization mechanism ensures precise alignment between UAV trajectory data and received signal amplitudes, resolving angular calibration errors below 0.02°. Field tests conducted in maritime environments validate the system's capability to reconstruct individual element and array radiation patterns, demonstrating close agreement with electromagnetic simulations incorporating ship hull and sea surface models. The measured far-field patterns at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.5 / 11.1 / 13.7 \text{MHz}$</tex> exhibited root mean square errors (RMSE) <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<1.06\ \text{dB}$</tex> in the main lobe compared to simulations.

title: Fusion-based Multimodal Deep Learning for E-commerce Product Attribute Classification
authors: Dangeti Siddharth, Tulasi Prasad Sariki
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Product catalog organization has grown to be a significant difficulty due to the quick expansion of online marketplaces. In addition to providing accurate search results, trustworthy categorization is also necessary to support recommendation engines and enhance the general purchasing experience. We present a multimodal deep learning approach, in this study that uses a fusion-based model to merge structured attribute information with product images. To handle noisy and incomplete metadata, we apply preprocessing steps such as one-hot encoding and class balancing, while convolutional neural networks (CNNs) are used to extract rich visual features. Our experiments show that the fusion model consistently outperforms image-only and attribute-only baselines, reaching 84.2% ± 2.1 test accuracy and a macro F1-score of 0.87 across five folds. Techniques like dropout, batch normalization, and data augmentation helped the model generalize better and avoid overfitting. Overall, the results demonstrate that combining multiple modalities improves both accuracy and fairness across imbalanced categories, making the method well suited for large-scale e-commerce catalog management.

title: Approximate Model Predictive Control for Heating of Arbitrary Buildings Without Thermal Modeling
authors: Felix Langner, Sören Riegraf, Jörg Matthes, Veit Hagenmeyer
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Model Predictive Control (MPC) is a promising method for enabling grid-interactive heating in buildings. However, deriving an accurate building model, which is a prerequisite for a successful implementation of MPC, hinders its widespread adoption. The present paper eliminates the need for building-specific modeling by developing an approximate MPC (AMPC) based on a neural network that emulates MPC behavior without requiring a building model. The AMPC is trained on data created by controlling the heating system of 16,000 building models with MPC in response to dynamic pricing. Utilizing data from diverse buildings forces the AMPC to learn building-agnostic decision-making, thereby enabling its application to buildings with unknown dynamics. The AMPC’s control performance is validated on 687 unseen building models for 25 weeks each across different climate zones. Compared to the MPC, 50% of the buildings, the AMPC achieves less than 7% excess cost and less than 2 Kh/d increase in thermal discomfort, while simultaneously reducing the computation time by 95%. For very well-insulated buildings that barely require heating, the AMPC incurs substantial relative cost increases, even though the absolute cost increases are most probably negligible.

title: Simple Method for Complementing Frequency Response of Hydropower Plants with Energy Storage
authors: Bryan Murray, Ángel Navarro Rodríguez, Pablo García Fernández, Cristian Blanco Charro
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: As inverter-based resources grow as portion of installed generation capacity on bulk power systems, synchronous inertia from rotating generators has and will continue to decrease, requiring proportionally more primary frequency response action from hydropower plants. Although hydropower plants are generally capability of increased frequency regulation, it comes at the cost of added wear-and-tear on regulating equipment, particularly gate valves. We estimate lower bounds of total physical inertia on the Spanish power system, and use a swing-equation-based grid model to demonstrate how energy storage systems can offset inverse power responses from hydropower plants while simultaneously reducing cumulative control gate travel distance and improving system-wide frequency response.

title: Optimization and Development of a Ventilation System for Public Toilets based on Toxic Gas Level
authors: Varun Vasudeva, Nikunj Parikh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Public sanitation facilities tend to have very poor ventilation, which can lead to build-up of harmful gases such as ammonia (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{NH}_{3}$</tex>), hydrogen sulfide (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{3} \mathrm{S}$</tex>), methane (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CH}_{4}$</tex>), and carbon dioxide (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex>). Long exposure to any of these gases creates discomfort, but they can pose health risks to users and maintenance workers. We present a study that proposes an intelligent ventilation system using a control unit with gas sensors and a microcontroller to allow real-time measuring of air quality. If the gas levels reach a threshold, the system will automatically activate a DC fan via a motor driver to reduce airflow of gases quickly. We also aimed to improve airflow through the ventilation hole by optimizing the duct properties utilizing Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) to reduce recirculation and stagnant zones. Our prototypes demonstrated large seasonal variation in gas build-up. For example, the results showed higher gas build-up in the facility during peak facility usage, and consequently, relatively higher levels during humid weather conditions than drier weather conditions. The ventilating system, on average, reduced the gas levels <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$80-90 \%$</tex> in each scenario measured. The systems also resulted in a relatively low energy footprint. Overall, these results show the feasibility of low-cost, sensor-based ventilation systems in and around public toilets or, more generally, frames its relevance for the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan in facilitating better access to high standards of hygiene and safety within the facility.

title: Data-Driven Destination Intelligence: From Tourist Reviews to Personalized Recommendations with BERT-CNN Sentiment Analysis for Smart Tourism
authors: Hartatik, R. Rizal Isnanto, Budi Warsito
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: This study proposes a hybrid tourism recommendation framework that integrates a Sentiment Preference Score (SPS), extracted using a BERT-CNN model, into the traditional Collaborative Filtering (CF) approach. The inclusion of sentiment into the model improves model performance. Experiments on Indonesian tourism datasets show that the proposed CF + SPS model achieves superior Precision, Recall, and NDCG compared to the rating-only baseline, especially at the optimal configuration of (0.3, 0.7). The SPS serves as a probabilistic and quantitative representation of user sentiment, enabling more context-aware recommendations. These findings validate that transforming sentiment signals into numeric preference weights enhances both interpretability and personalization in smart tourism systems. This approach contributes to closing the gap in previous research in treating sentiment not only as descriptive data but also offers robust and scalable integration of contextual cues into the recommendation process.

title: MSOD - A Small Obstacle Detection Network for Open-Pit Mining Areas
authors: Jie Wang, Zhangyu Wang, Muzhuo Liu, Haonan Mi, Chendong Yuan, Guizhen Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: With the development of artificial intelligence technology, autonomous driving has advanced significantly, and open-pit mining areas have emerged as one of the important scenarios for the implementation of autonomous driving in recent years. The perception module forms the foundation of the autonomous driving system for mining trucks, among which the detection of small obstacles such as stones and cones is crucial for ensuring driving safety. Currently, small obstacle detection faces problems such as small size, insufficient features, and complex backgrounds. Meanwhile, a single sensor is vulnerable to sensor failure and difficult to deal with occlusion and multi-source noise interference. To address these challenges, this article designs a novel algorithm framework based on feature fusion of LiDAR and camera, combining strategies such as multi-modal data augmentation, feature layer fusion, and temporal modeling to achieve high-precision detection of small obstacles. The problem of feature scarcity is alleviated through multi-scale feature extraction and cross-modal data augmentation, a feature fusion scheme is constructed based on the cross-attention mechanism, and a temporal self-attention mechanism is introduced to realize dynamic association of small obstacles in consecutive frames. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves a mean Average Precision (mAP) of $83.4 \%$ and a NuScenes Detection Score (NDS) of $72.5 \%$ on the self-built dataset. Compared with advanced methods, MSOD significantly improves detection accuracy for small obstacles.

title: Development of a Measurement System and Methodology for Determining Dead Layer Thickness in HPGe Crystals
authors: Zhenzhen Zhang, Chaoya Pang, Kai Jiang, Dixin Yan, Xiaoyu Qie, Can Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: To resolve discrepancies in the source-free efficiency calibration of HPGe gamma spectrometers caused by uncertainties in dead layer thickness, which lead to significant deviations between simulated and experimental detection efficiency results. A Monte Carlo N-Particle (MCNP) model of the HPGe crystal was initially developed to investigate the influence of dead layer thickness variations on detection efficiency across different energy ranges. This analysis guided the design of a photon scanning collimator. By scanning the top and lateral dead layers of the HPGe crystal using the collimator, the specific thickness and uniformity of the dead layers were determined. The acquired data were used to refine the MCNP model by incorporating the measured dead layer parameters. Experimental validation with standard point sources demonstrated that the root mean square (RMS) of the relative deviation between simulated and experimental detection efficiencies was less than 1%, confirming the accuracy of the proposed system and methodology for dead layer thickness measurement.

title: HAPS for Mitigating RAN Traffic Peaks amid Rising Demand and B5G Evolution
authors: Mohamed Amine Mbarek, Michela Meo, Daniela Renga, Greta Vallero
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: The growing demand for mobile connectivity is pushing terrestrial radio access networks (RANs) toward congestion, especially during peak hours in dense urban areas. High Altitude Platform Stations (HAPSs) provide a flexible means to support overloaded base stations (BSs) through aerial traffic offloading. This paper presents a simulation-based framework that evaluates HAPS-assisted offloading under realistic traffic traces, considering baseline and upscaled demand scenarios. We assess packet-level delay, user denial, energy consumption, and infrastructure expansion. Results show that HAPS markedly reduce queuing delay and nearly eliminate user denial under moderate overload, while also lowering operational and capital expenditures by relieving congested BSs. These findings confirm the viability of HAPS as a complementary aerial layer for congestion mitigation, postponing the need for terrestrial densification in the path toward B5G networks.

title: CABENCH: Benchmarking Composable Ai for Solving Complex Tasks through Composing Ready-to-Use Models
authors: Tung-Thuy Pham, Duy-Quan Luong, Minh-Quan Duong, Trung-Hieu Nguyen, Thu-Trang Nguyen, Son Nguyen, Hieu Dinh Vo
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: Composable AI offers a scalable and effective paradigm for solving complex AI tasks by decomposing them into sub-tasks, each handled by ready-to-use models. However, systematically evaluating methods under this setting remains largely unexplored. This paper introduces CABench, the first public benchmark for composable AI, comprising 70 realistic tasks, along with a curated pool of 700 models across multiple modalities and domains. We also propose an evaluation framework to enable end-to-end assessment of composable AI solutions. To establish initial baselines, we provide human-designed reference solutions and compare their performance with two LLM-based approaches. Our results demonstrate the promise of composable AI in addressing real-world challenges while underscoring the need for methods capable of automatically generating effective execution pipelines. This work lays the foundation for future research toward building scalable, efficient AI systems through principled reuse and orchestration of existing models.

title: Minimizing Read Disturb via Localized Page Allocation for Modern NAND Flash-Based SSDs
authors: Joonseong Hwang, Minkyu Choi, Minjin Park, Jihun Yoon, Yoonho Jang, Seokin Hong
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: To meet the increasing demand for higher storage density, modern NAND flash-based SSDs employ Quad-Level Cell (QLC) technology, which stores four bits per memory cell. However, it exacerbates the read disturb issue, where repeated read operations gradually shift the threshold voltages of unselected NAND flash cells. This voltage drift leads to frequent read retries and accelerates device wear, ultimately degrading performance and endurance. To address this issue, we propose Localized Page Allocation (LPA), a novel data mapping scheme that allocates each page to a restricted region of the wordline.
