LPA assigns four consecutive bits in a single page to a single cell. This approach confines read operations to a limited portion of the bitlines, thereby reducing the number of NAND flash cells exposed to read disturb. However, this localized access increases the complexity of sensing operations. To address this challenge, we introduce Progressive Voltage Convergence (PVC) method that adaptively determines the next sensing voltage for each bitline based on its previous sensing result. This fine-grained control reduces the number of sensing steps during read operations. For additional optimization, we employ lossless compression, which reduces the number of sensing steps for the compressed pages. Experimental evaluations using real-world workloads demonstrate that our design improves I/O performance by up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 1 \%}$</tex> and extends endurance by 79% compared to the state-of-the-art techniques. Our design requires minor hardware modifications to the conventional NAND flash chips and the SSD controller, which leads to small area and power overhead.

title: Navigating Diversity in Group Tourism for Itinerary Planning with GNNs: An Indian Contextual Approach
authors: Sanskar S Tare, Maitrey M Bhute, Tanmay A Deshpande, Vimala Devi K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Navigating the burgeoning tourism industry which makes up 11.1% of global GDP in 2024 presents a unique challenge for group travel: orchestrating an itinerary that satisfies the diverse preferences, tastes, and budget constraints of multiple individuals. This activity of curating locations and creating an itinerary can be particularly tedious since sifting through multiple locations and activities is a time-consuming endeavor. Since tourists typically like to travel in groups, the interests of every individual of the group must be considered during itinerary planning. Most existing systems for itinerary recommendation and tourist-spot recommendation cater to individual travelers and fail to take such group dynamics into account, rendering them impractical for use in group excursions. In such a scenario satisfying every individual can be a complex task when various limitations like time, budget and travel constraints are considered. The study attempts to analyze, understand, and automate this using Graphical Neural Networks (GNN) and recommend tour itinerary based on history of place review which acts as an indicator of user preferences, integrating it with constraints to recommend a tour that complies with individual likings. Work proposes a unique ML model based on GNN and compares it with existing systems with documented results to find the suitability of GNN for group-tour recommendations. Furthermore, there is scarcity of data related to India-specific tourist destinations and their thematic categories. The proposed work also tries to create a standardized tourism dataset in Indian context, powered by YFCC100M that can be used for future studies.

title: Gateway-Side Distributed Frame Deduplication for LoRaWAN
authors: Gewu Bu, Nancy El Rachkidy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: Low-Power Wide-Area Networks (LPWAN) are increasingly used in Internet of Things (IoT) applications that require long-range communication and low power consumption. Among LPWAN technologies, LoRaWAN is particularly well suited due to its energy efficiency and wide coverage. However, a major drawback of LoRa is its limited throughput. One of the constraints that reduce the throughput is the duplication of frames decoded by multiple gateways, resulting in redundant transmissions to the network server. To address this issue, we propose a distributed frame deduplication mechanism that offloads the conventional centralized deduplication process in LoRaWAN from the network server to the gateway side. Each gateway maintains a whitelist to determine which frames should be decoded and then transmitted to the network server. Our approach, thus, aims to eliminate redundant frames to be decoded at the gateways. Simulation results show that our approach increases the overall network throughput and the system efficiency (up to 94% compared to only 46% for LoRaWAN for dense networks).

title: Research on the Construction of Coupling Algorithm Based on Improved Particle Swarm Algorithm for Optimizing BP Neural Networks
authors: Junzhe Zhou, Zhuoqun Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: As artificial intelligence advances, machine learning finds diverse applications in the fields of computer vision, medical diagnosis, and financial prediction. However, machine learning is affected by the limitations of hyperparameter adjustment, and it is difficult to complete the prediction task with higher accuracy at a high standard in specific scenarios. Based on this, this paper proposes an improved particle swarm algorithm to optimize the coupling model of BP neural network to improve the model performance and prediction accuracy. First, a particle swarm algorithm based on the theory of good point set and adaptive inertia weights is proposed, and 16 low-dimensional and highdimensional test functions are used to verify the effectiveness of the algorithm; on this basis, the improved algorithm is combined with BP neural network and applied to the power prediction dataset for power load prediction, and performance tests and algorithm comparisons are completed. The findings confirm that the improved particle swarm algorithm enhances the BP neural network model, outperforming the original in four key metrics: mean absolute error (MAE), mean square error (MSE), root mean square error (RMSE), and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) (60.324, 5355.1723, 73.179, 5.2465 %)(94.6607. 12735. 5187,112.8518,8.221 %), and the IPSO algorithm shows good convergence speed and accuracy as judged by the iterative curve. In the future, the IPSO algorithm based on the good point set and variable inertia weight strategy proposed in this paper also has the value and significance to be applied to more operations research scenarios.

title: Real-Time False Data Injection Attack Detection Using Adaptive Random Forest and Sliding Window CUSUM
authors: Sugandh Khanna, Zhiyu Liao, Haiyu Li, James Yu, Zhirun Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: False data injection attacks are a critical threat to modern power grid infrastructure, requiring a detection mechanism that can operate in real-time and adapt to evolving attack patterns. To address this challenge, this study proposes a novel False Data Injection (FDI) attack detection approach that leverages dual-drift detection and adaptive online machine learning, which dynamically learns and adapts to the dynamic characteristics of power system state variations. The proposed approach integrates advanced drift detection using CUSUM control charts with continuous performance tracking via sliding window analysis and the Adaptive Random Forest algorithm. The proposed method achieved an accuracy of 98.59% for detecting FDI attacks when tested on a simplified UK substation with two generators and four feeders simulated using the Digsilent tool.

title: A Note on Different Source Models for Dipole Antennas in Ghz Frequency Range
authors: D. Poljak, V. Doric
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: The paper deals with the influence of the use of three different voltage source models; Delta gap, Magnetic frill and Magntetic current loop to the behaviour of dipole antenna when used in GHz frequency range. The current distribution, radiated field and input admittance are analyzed. Some illustrative numerical results are presented for the case of dipole in free space and in the presence of a lossy half-space, respectively.

title: Power-Dependent Efficiency Model of EV Chargers for Distribution Grid Simulations
authors: Marius Masuch, Marcel Esser, Alfio Spina
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The growing adoption of Electric Vehicles (EVs) and their integration into electrical distribution grids present various challenges. Among others, the efficiency of bidirectional chargers is critical for accurate energy demand forecasting and charging schedule optimisation. This study adapts a mathematical efficiency model, originally developed for photovoltaic inverters, for application to bidirectional EV chargers and incorporates the charging operation into a distribution grid simulation. To account for the power-dependent efficiency of chargers under diverse charging conditions, an approximation based on a step-function is employed. Simulation results indicate that incorporating variable charger efficiency leads to a moderate increase in total EV energy demand (9.4 %) and a minor increase in transformer loading during charging events (0.4 %), while the impact on line loading remains negligible in the considered scenario. The developed variable efficiency model provides a foundation for future research in larger networks with higher EV penetration levels also incorporating functionalities such as Vehicle-to-Grid.

title: Real-Time ECG Analytics and Arrhythmia Detection
authors: Viomesh Kumar Singh, Tanuj Avinash Keshattiwar, Anurag Shankar Nimkande, Ayush Vijay Dhewale, Pravin Sham Pinjarkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Heart-related health problems are a growing concern, with increasing rates being observed across various demographics. Early detection of these abnormalities is vital, as some can indicate life-threatening conditions if left untreated. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is a primary device used to discover patterns within the heart’s electrical signals, which can be analyzed to identify anomalies. Arrhythmia is one such anomaly that can range from harmless to a serious threat. While many arrhythmias are treatable, they must first be accurately detected. Therefore, preventive detection systems are essential. The proposed system is embedded with high predictive capabilities to recognize patterns in an ECG. By leveraging the power of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) integrated with low-cost IoT sensors, a cloud platform, and a mobile application, it balances accuracy, low latency, and feasibility. The effectiveness of a CNN in recognizing ECG patterns stems from its training on the extensive MIT-BIH Arrhythmia database, achieving 96.0% accuracy, 95.3% sensitivity, and a 95.0% F1-score. This study bridges the gap between wearable health devices and AI-powered predictive analytics by proving the viability of automated, clinically viable, and reasonably priced arrhythmia detection systems.

title: Optimized GhostNet–ViT and Attention U-Net Pipeline for Accurate Prediction for Medical Diagnosis
authors: Mirza Ibrahim Baig, Ravi Uyyala, Padmavathi Vurubindi, Anila Macharla
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: The prompt and precise diagnosis of kidney stones is essential in the prevention of serious consequences like infection, chronic kidney damage, urinary blockage, and other life-threatening health issues. For diagnostic purposes on a wide scale, manual processing of CT scans is laborious, prone to mistakes, and inefficient. Using an improved hybrid deep learning architecture, we offer a clinically applicable, completely automated kidney stone diagnosis method in this study. In order to obtain both regional and worldwide picture characteristics, our method combines Ghost Net with Vision Transformers (VIT). Our Attention U-Net effectively separates stone regions from their surrounding anatomical features, allowing for precise segmentation. Using Mobile NetV3, we are able to classify instances as either "stone" or "non-stone," a feat that allows for lightweight and quick decision-making, making it ideal for use on edge devices and real-time systems. Over the course of 10 epochs, with 590 batches per epoch, the system was meticulously trained using a balanced and somewhat larger dataset consisting of 6,000 CT images. A recall of 64.85 %, an F1-score of 64.22 %, an accuracy of 63.50 %, and a precision of 63.59 % were all attained by the revised model. Particularly important in clinical settings where early identification is paramount, the model’s improved recall demonstrates its robustness in reducing false negatives. Visualizations and experimental findings show that the model can reliably generate segmentation masks and detect tiny stones. There is great promise for this hybrid framework to become an integral part of clinical workflows, which would increase diagnostic throughput, decrease radiologists’ workload, and keep diagnostic standards high.

title: Advancing AI Healthcare: RNN for Global Mpox Spread Prediction
authors: Asmita Bhadoria, Sam Varghese, Nidhi Asthana, Gaurav Paliwal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: The global Mpox (Monkeypox) epidemic, declared an international public health emergency, has created an urgent need for reliable predictive models to simulate the disease's spread and inform preventive measures. [1] In the absence of targeted vaccines and specific antiviral treatments, accurate forecasting is crucial for understanding transmission dynamics and implementing timely interventions. This research focuses on applying Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN), particularly Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, to predict the global spread of Mpox by utilizing time-series data and models previously developed for COVID-19 outbreak predictions. [2]To enhance the model's predictive capabilities, we modified the traditional SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infectious-Recovered) framework and integrated it with RNN architectures. Historical case data from heavily impacted countries, including the United States, Brazil, Spain, France, the United Kingdom, and Germany, were used to train the model. The results show that the RNN-based model accurately predicts the number of future cases, with a relative error of approximately 12 % when compared to actual data for December 31, 2022. The total predicted cases globally were 94,567, closely aligning with the reported 83,878 cases. For the United States, Brazil, Spain, France, the United Kingdom, and Germany, the predicted cases were 31,245, 11,689, 7,509, 5,698, 5,487, and 4,328, respectively, with an average relative error of 18 %. Additionally, vaccination scenarios were simulated, revealing that if 30 % of the population were vaccinated with a vaccine having 78% efficacy, the number of cases would reduce by 32 %. This research demonstrates the utility of RNN models in accurately predicting epidemic trends and evaluating intervention strategies. The results provide valuable insights into the potential impact of vaccination and control measures, offering a practical decision-making tool for health authorities in managing the Mpox epidemic.

title: Multi-Hop Load Balancing with Deep Q-Learning for Scalable WSN Deployment
authors: A.S. Narmadha, K. Sivakami, Mettle Priyanka R, Dhanapriya S, Mahalakshmi S, Subaranjana T
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: n large-scale Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs), achieving optimal load balancing across sensor nodes is critical for ensuring energy efficiency, data delivery reliability, and extended network lifetime. This paper introduces a novel MultiHop Load Balancing Framework using Deep Q-Learning (MH-LB-DQL) to address the challenges of dynamic topology, energy constraints, and uneven traffic distribution in WSNs. The proposed model formulates the routing process as a Markov Decision Process (MDP), wherein each node learns optimal multi-hop forwarding strategies by interacting with the environment and adjusting to changing network conditions. By integrating a Deep Q-Network (DQN), each node autonomously learns to select forwarding paths that minimize energy consumption, prevent bottlenecks, and balance the traffic load across neighboring nodes. The model incorporates parameters such as residual energy, link quality, hop count, and buffer occupancy into the reward function to guide learning effectively. Simulation results demonstrate that MH-LB-DQL significantly outperforms conventional protocols such as LEACH, PEGASIS, and EECR in terms of network lifetime, packet delivery ratio, and energy distribution uniformity. Furthermore, the model exhibits high scalability and adaptability in dynamic environments with node mobility and random deployment. The proposed deep reinforcement learning-based load balancing approach offers a robust solution for next-generation scalable WSN applications in smart agriculture, disaster response, and industrial monitoring systems.

title: Att-BKA: A Self-Attention-Guided Black-winged Kite Algorithm for Complex Optimization Problems
authors: Yiting Song
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Swarm intelligence algorithms have emerged to tackle global optimization, valued for their simplicity, scalability, and population-based search mechanisms. Among them, BKA distinguishes itself with a leader-follower strategy and Cauchyperturbed updates, but most of its variants focus on static modifications, lacking the capacity to adaptively guide agents based on global context. To compensate for this limitation, this paper proposes an enhanced swarm intelligence optimizer named Attention-Guided Black-winged Kite Algorithm (AttBKA) which integrates a single-head self-attention mechanism into both the attack and migration phases of the original BKA. This design enables each agent to compute attention-weighted interactions with other individuals by jointly considering positional similarity and fitness quality. Specifically, by designing attention-guided directional offsets in the attack phase, formulating a fitness-aware migration update rule, and incorporating a lightweight learning mechanism to evolve attention parameters dynamically, we enable the swarm to learn more effective behavioral patterns throughout the optimization process. To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed method, we compare Att-BKA against three baselines — the original BKA, along with two ablation variants where attention is restricted exclusively to the attack phase and migration phase, respectively — across 18 benchmark functions spanning four problem classes: unimodal, multimodal, separable, and nonseparable landscapes. The results show that Att-BKA consistently achieves faster convergence, better solution accuracy, and improved robustness across the vast majority of categories. Our analyses not only validate the efficacy of attention-guided updates in swarm optimization but, more critically, present a practical and extensible paradigm for integrating attention mechanisms into population-based metaheuristic frameworks.

title: STOT-USleepNet: A Study of Sleep Stage Classification Based on EEG Signals
authors: Limin Liu, Chenjie Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data and Intelligent Medicine (BDIMed)
abstract: Sleep staging is essential for health monitoring and disease diagnosis, yet traditional approaches often inadequately capture EEG signals’ spatiotemporal dependencies. They typically overlook dynamic spatial correlations across EEG channels and fail to effectively model temporal transitions between sleep stages, resulting in limited classification performance. To address these limitations, we propose STOT-USleepNet, a novel U-shaped fusion network for EEG-based sleep staging. The key innovation integrates Optimal Transport (OT) through a Spatial-Temporal Optimal Transport (STOT) module, which adaptively assigns correlation weights across EEG channels to construct a dynamic, data-driven spatiotemporal map. This module quantifies functional connectivity between brain regions and transition costs between sleep stages. Building on this foundation, we develop an improved dual-branch U-shaped network (USleepNet) to jointly capture time-varying waveform dynamics and the brain’s topological structure. A multi-scale feature interaction mechanism facilitates cross-layer fusion, while a convolutional block attention module (CBAM) at skip connections enhances contextual flow and classification accuracy.

title: High-Jitter Signal Reconstruction via Cubic Spline Interpolation Integrated with Empirical Mode Decomposition
authors: Zhihui Qi, Hongbo Chen, Yang He, Ruikai Li, Wenhao Bai, Tonggang Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: In the processing of high-frequency repetitive signals for equivalent time sampling oscilloscopes, non-uniform sampling caused by clock jitter severely impairs signal reconstruction accuracy. Traditional interpolation algorithms face dual challenges of amplitude distortion and timing deviation when processing high-frequency non-stationary signals. This paper proposes a cubic spline interpolation algorithm based on Empirical Mode Decomposition (EMD). The jitter-contaminated signal is decomposed into Intrinsic Mode Functions (IMFs) and residual components via EMD. Leveraging the mono-component characteristics of each component, piecewise interpolation and reconstruction are performed to overcome the limitations of conventional methods in fitting non-stationary signals. An experimental dual-layer evaluation system is established: spatial accuracy is quantified by Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Mean Squared Error (MSE) for amplitude recovery assessment, while timing accuracy is evaluated using the standard deviation of time interval error and peak-to-peak value of time interval error to measure edge timing deviation. The proposed algorithm demonstrates significant advantages in high-jitter scenarios: at 10 picoseconds and 20 picoseconds jitter levels, MAE is reduce by 78% and 81%, and MSE by 96% and 95%, respectively, compared to traditional cubic spline interpolation. While the standard deviation of time interval error is only 8.5% of the traditional method's value under 10 picoseconds jitter and the peak-to-peak value of time interval error is compressed from 42.2 picoseconds to 6.4 picoseconds, achieving a 6.6-fold improvement in extreme timing deviation control. These results validate the algorithm's dual effectiveness in suppressing amplitude and timing errors in high-jitter environments, providing an efficient solution for high-frequency repetitive signal reconstruction with non-uniform sampling jitter suppression in equivalent time sampling oscilloscopes.

title: Design of LCR Measurement module based on Excitation Tuning and Time Interval Detection
authors: Peng Zhang, Ping Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: This paper presents a dual-mode LCR measurement module capable of measuring resistance, capacitance, and inductance parameters for both passive and active objects. For passive components, a dual-excitation balanced bridge topology is employed, utilizing amplitude-phase step adjustment to achieve rapid convergence to the balanced state. For active port, the measurement of equivalent parameters is realized through phase difference detection based on time interpolation quantization combined with a dual-resonant frequency point localization method. Test results show that the proposed method achieves a resistance measurement range of 100 mΩ to 100 MΩ with an accuracy of ±0.05%, a capacitance measurement range of 1 pF to 1μ" " F with an accuracy of ±1%, and an inductance measurement range of 1μH to 1 H with an accuracy of 2%. The proposed approach can be widely applied in component screening, material analysis, instrument calibration, and integrated circuit testing scenarios.

title: Research on Computer Vision Image Preprocessing and Target Detection Optimization Algorithm Driven by Fully Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Kaixiang Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: In the field of computer vision, traditional object detection algorithms are constrained by their feature extraction mechanisms, making it difficult for detection accuracy to meet the requirements of complex scenarios. Based on the end-to-end characteristics of the Fully Convolutional Network (FCN), this paper constructs a high-precision object detection model. The model forms a multi-stage image optimization system by integrating digital image conversion and preprocessing technologies: firstly, visual images are converted into digital form through sampling, quantization, and encoding technologies; subsequently, efficient extraction and optimization of image features are achieved via operations such as image smoothing, enhancement, and target cropping. In the object detection stage, the FCN is employed for model training, and precise localization and recognition of image objects are realized through the combination of convolutional and deconvolutional layers. Experimental results show that the algorithm performs excellently in dynamic and static image detection tasks, with both accuracy and recall metrics approaching the ideal value of 1. Compared with traditional methods, the detection efficiency is significantly improved, and the detection time is greatly reduced, providing a new technical path for object detection in computer vision.

title: Simulation of Vibration Induced by coil in the preliminary research device of Magnetic Confinement Deuterium-Deuterium Fusion Neutron Source
authors: Tianyu Zheng, Yuan Pan, Bo Rao
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: During the operation of the preliminary research device of magnetic confinement deuterium-deuterium fusion neutron source, the coils generate electromagnetic forces under the action of magnetic fields, which induce vibrations and affect the measurement accuracy of optical diagnostic systems. To investigate the vibration characteristics, a simplified structural model was established based on the design scheme of the device. Using Ansys, electromagnetic and structural simulations were conducted to analyze the vibration behaviors and propagation laws induced by the compression magnetic field, formation region magnetic field, and quasi-steady-state magnetic field on the main machine structure. The results show that the compression magnetic field causes significant vibrations in the vacuum chamber and parts of the quasi-steady coils, and the structural response is significantly slower than the variation of electromagnetic forces. The simulation results provide reference data for the subsequent structural design of the device.

title: A Target-Oriented 3D Reconstruction with Array-Insar Images
authors: Guozhen Cheng, Fengming Hu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar Tomography (TomoSAR) is a standard tool for 3D radar imaging, which overcomes the limitation of 2D geometric distortion by using the baseline diversity. Repeated observations by spaceborne SAR systems over extended periods enable the 3D reconstruction of large-scale static scenes. However, small targets like vehicles exhibit dynamic changes and low coherence, making target-level 3D reconstruction challenging. This study bases on the airborne array InSAR system developed by the Aerospace Information Research Institute, which acquires multi-baseline images in a single flight. A 3D reconstruction algorithm implicit geometric constraints is proposed, significantly enhancing the 3D reconstruction capability for small targets. Experimental results based on real measured data demonstrate that the proposed method can reconstruct partial details of small targets more clearly, achieving high-quality 3D reconstruction.

title: An Enhanced Matrix Completion-Based Interference Mitigation Method for FMCW Radar
authors: Long Zeng, Shuiqiang Yang, Bing Liao, Bin Gu, Zhen Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Product Compliance Engineering - Asia (ISPCE-ASIA)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of cross-interference in frequency-modulated continuous-wave (FMCW) radar for autonomous driving applications. An enhanced matrix completion-based interference mitigation method for FMCW radar is proposed. The method first detects and removes the interference segments in the dechirped beat signal and reconstructs the signal into a Hankel matrix. Then, an inertia-accelerated strategy is incorporated to achieve signal recovery via matrix completion. Extensive validation using both simulated and measured data demonstrates that the proposed method can accurately reconstruct the useful signal, effectively suppress the elevated noise floor in the range spectrum, and preserve weak target information, thereby significantly improving the reliability of automotive radar under interference conditions.

title: AceHomo: Accelerating Privacy Preserving Inference Through Dynamic Level Adjustment
authors: Hongyan Li, Jinkai Zhang, Hang Lu, Xiaowei Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) neural networks has made significant strides in enabling privacy-preserving inference, yet it is frequently impeded by substantial computational overhead. Previous research has largely focused on optimizing neural network operations or managing FHE computation processes to reduce computational cost, but has overlooked addressing the interplay between FHE computation process and neural network characteristics as an integrated system. This paper introduces AceHomo, a novel approach utilizing reinforcement learning to optimize CKKS encryption level consumptions in neural networks, thereby enhancing performance and reducing latency without compromising network accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that AceHomo significantly reduces latency by up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.47 \times$</tex> without compromising the network's inference accuracy. These encouraging results position AceHomo as a promising approach in optimizing FHE neural networks.

title: Autonomous Contract Analysis and Clause Risk Detection using Legal-BERT
authors: S.Jegadeesan, A. Alagu Gomathi, S.Nandhini
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Legal contract analysis is an important, yet time-consuming, task that requires considerable domain knowledge and attention to detail. This paper contributes to the literature on the design and implementation of an Autonomous Contract Review Assistant, an AI-based system using Natural Language Processing (NLP), transformer-based models, and rule-based reasoning to automate the legal contract review process. This system contains modules for clause segmentation, clause classification, risk-exposure or management flags, and identification of missing clauses. Leveraging weakly supervised learning techniques, our system combines heuristic rules of thumb, phrases in certain subject-matter patterns, and the output of pretrained legal language model such as (Legal-BERT) to create probabilistic labels in the absence of sufficient labeled legal data. In addition, we also use semantic similarity search using FAISS to measure the similarity of extracted clauses to template clauses accumulated from social data, which provide us a basis for flagging disallowed or unintended language. The proposed framework is evaluated on the CUAD data set, and on publicly available contracts filed with the U.S. government to create summaries, flag high-risk clauses and missing clauses, and the produce concise summaries with strong precision. This work advances the field of LegalTech by improving efficiency, accuracy, and scalability of legal contract analysis by valid AI-enabled automation.

title: High Frequency Characterization of Ultra-Thin Transparent Films
authors: Bilal H. Mohamed, Wilhelm Keusgen, Markus Widmaier, Holger Bauer, Norbert Fruehauf
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Ultrathin film materials have been investigated in applications such as antennas and phase shifters. There is special interest in optically transparent conductors due to their negligible aesthetical impact. Moreover, ultra-thin films, which are quasielectromagnetic transparent has been applied to the biasing of liquid crystal topologies in the optical domain and it may also be possible to implement the same biasing technology in the RF domain. This paper focuses on the experimental characterization of such ultrathin transparent conductive films, such as ITO and AZO. The characterization is done using CPW lines. Besides, to see the effect of roughness and conductivity, a comparison between aluminium and aluminium-neodymium is done. The effect of those transparent materials when they are placed over a transmission line similarly to the biasing method applied for optical displays is also analyzed. This presents interest for biasing liquid crystal material with the use of such thin conductors in RF applications.

title: Data Driven Approach for Early Risk Assessment of Cardiovascular Disease through Logistic Regression
authors: Warisha Abdullah, Sibghat Ullah Bazai, Saira Akram, Muhammad Imran Ghafoor, Sangeen Chaker Baloch, Uzair Aslam Bhatti
publish: 2025 IEEE 19th International Conference on Open Source Systems and Technologies (ICOSST)
abstract: Heart disease is also a leading cause of mortality in the world and is a major risk factor predisposed by diabetes and smoking. The strategy employed in the conducted study is data-driven in prediction of the risk factors, and the study is aimed at categorizing the diabetes and smoking status, through the implementation of a logistic regression model. The rigorous preprocessing of data, model training and evaluation of the model finely guaranteed transparency and accuracy of predictions. The model developed has the accuracy of $\mathbf{8 1 \%}$ to classify diabetic and non-diabetic or smokers with a precision of $76 \%$. The results indicate that even relatively simple machine learning algorithms can provide reliable information on preventative healthcare interventions. Based on the findings, the early response interventions could be supported by including such prediction models in clinical and population health systems, which would eventually reduce the load of heart disease. The research can be improved by incorporating additional risk factors and more advanced ensemble methods in future enabling the research to be more clinically applicable and predictive.

title: SiGrid: Gridifying Scatterplots with Sector-Based Regularization and Hagrid
authors: Rene Cutura, Hennes Rave, Quynh Quang Ngo, Vladimir Molchanov, Lars Linsen, Daniel Weiskopf, Michael Sedlmair
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: Hagrid is a state-of-the-art space-filling-curve-based method for gridifying scatterplots. However, it exhibits limitations in preserving the global structures of scatterplots with areas of varying density due to the incompatibility of adapting the granularity level of the underlying space-filling curve to regions with different densities. To compensate for this shortcoming, we introduce SiGrid, which combines Hagrid with the Sector-Based Regularization (SBR) technique. SiGrid applies SBR to generate a scatterplot with a more uniform and generally lower density as an intermediate step. This intermediate scatterplot can then be fed to Hagrid for improved results. We quantitatively evaluate SiGrid by comparing it to Hagrid over a set of 502 scatterplots of different sizes, ranging from 50 to 10000 points per dataset, using relevant quality metrics. While generally slower, the results demonstrate that SiGrid outperforms Hagrid regarding the quality metrics of rank-wise neighborhood preservation (trustworthiness), ordering preservation, and pairwise distance preservation (cross-correlation).

title: Agent Attention Meets Diffusion: A Dual-Scale Framework for Medical Image Classification
authors: Xiaohuan Jia
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Medical image classification is a fundamental task in automated diagnosis, yet existing approaches often underperform when confronted with noisy or blurred inputs, limiting their reliability in clinical settings. BPGnet, a novel diffusion-based framework, is proposed to tackle this problem. It utilizes bi-scale prior guidance to improve robustness and classification accuracy in noisy clinical settings. The core of our model is the Hierarchical Conditional Guidance (HCG) module. It operates on two levels: a ResNet-50 enhanced by channel attention extracts global priors, while a lightweight Agent Attention mechanism captures local priors. This dual-scale guidance enables the diffusion process to jointly model structural context and fine-grained lesion details, improving feature discrimination under noise corruption. Extensive evaluations on the HAM10000 (dermatoscopy) and APTOS2019 (retinal fundus) datasets demonstrate that BPGnet achieves state-of-the-art performance, with F1-scores of 0.830 and 0.674, and accuracies of 0.910 and 0.858, respectively. Ablation studies further confirm the complementary benefits of global and local priors, validating the effectiveness of our attention-driven hierarchical design. These results highlight BPGnet's robustness, generalizability, and suitability for real-world medical image classification, particularly in noisy environments.

title: Aquaculture Monitoring: Intelligent Sensing and Control for Maximum Yield
authors: Miranji Katta, Hundi Sudhakar, Kalidindi Lakshmi Divya, M. Damodhar Rao, G. Naga Divya, Yamini Komati
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Aquaculture is vital for global food security, yet conventional monitoring and control methods often result in poor water quality, inefficient resource utilization, and limited yield. This paper presents an AI-driven aquaculture monitoring and control system that integrates Edge AI-based anomaly detection, reinforcement learning (DQN) adaptive control, and a hybrid LoRaWAN/5G-IoT communication framework. A multi-parameter sensor network continuously tracks dissolved oxygen, pH, ammonia, turbidity, and temperature, with Edge AI enabling real-time anomaly detection and rapid corrective actions. Reinforcement learning dynamically optimizes feeding, aeration, and water exchange, while the hybrid communication model ensures reliable, low-latency, and energy-efficient data transfer. Experimental results demonstrate a 75% reduction in system response time, 62.5% improvement in dissolved oxygen stability, 22% higher feed conversion efficiency, 35% reduction in energy consumption, and up to 30% yield improvement over conventional and recent AI-based approaches. Automated feeding lowered feed waste by 70%, and intelligent aeration delivered significant power savings. The proposed framework provides a scalable, cost-effective, and sustainable solution to enhance productivity while reducing operational costs and environmental impact. Future extensions include blockchain-based traceability, drone-assisted monitoring, and offshore aquaculture deployment, advancing the next generation of smart aquaculture technologies.

title: Sharing is Caring: Analysis of Hybrid Network Sharing Strategies for Energy Efficient Multi-Operator Cellular Systems
authors: Laura Finarelli, Maoquan Ni, Michela Meo, Falko Dressler, Gianluca Rizzo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel analytical framework for evaluating energy-efficient, QoS-aware network-sharing strategies in cellular networks. Leveraging stochastic geometry, our framework enables the systematic assessment of network performance across a range of sharing paradigms, including both conventional single-operator scenarios and advanced hybrid strategies that enable full integration and cooperation among multiple mobile network operators. Our framework incorporates diverse user densities, rate requirements, and energy consumption models to ensure comprehensive analysis. Applying our results to real-world datasets from French mobile network operators, we demonstrate that hybrid network sharing can yield substantial energy savings, up to 35%, while maintaining QoS. Furthermore, our results allow us to characterize how the benefits of network sharing vary as a function of the geographical and functional characteristics of the deployment area. These findings highlight the potential of collaborative sharing strategies to enhance operational efficiency and sustainability in next-generation cellular networks.

title: Design of Low Power 2-Bit Comparator Using Transmission Gate Logic
authors: Yashmit Sharma, Premananda B.S., Aviral Chandra
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Comparators are fundamental components in digital systems, where minimizing power, silicon area, and ensuring robust signal quality are critical design goals. This work presents the design and optimization of a 2-bit magnitude comparator using Transmission Gate Logic (TGL), with variants developed by modifying the output stage through dedicated pull-down logic. By designing separate pull-down networks for the output signals, the proposed structures achieve improved voltage swing and reduced power dissipation compared to conventional CMOS designs. The first design employs Gate Diffusion Input (GDI) logic, which reduces transistor count but suffers from partial swing and high-power consumption of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$180.2 \mu \mathrm{W}$</tex>. In contrast, the fully TGL-based comparator achieves rail-to-rail output swing and delivers the power dissipation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$68.5 \mu \mathrm{W}$</tex>, representing a 42% reduction compared to the reference and over 60% savings versus the GDI approach. Delay is also reduced from 90.67 ps in the reference to 75.4 ps in the proposed TGL design, marking a 16.8% improvement. These results confirm the effectiveness of dedicated TGL pull-down logic in enabling reliable, energyefficient comparator architectures for VLSI applications.

title: Helicon Wave-Plasma Interaction in Linear and Toroidal Geometries with Birdcage Resonant Antennas
authors: S. P. H. Vincent, R. Karimov, Ph. Guittienne, C. Sepulchre, P. Quigley, M. Alfazzaa, C. Stollberg, M. Baquero-Ruiz, R. Jacquier, A. A. Howling, I. Furno
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Helicon wave fundamental properties are explored experimentally and numerically in linear and toroidal geometries in the low-temperature plasma devices RAID and TORPEX. The helicon wave-plasma interaction is studied in terms of wave damping, propagation conditions in toroidal geometry, and nonlinear behavior.

title: AutoKNN: An AutoML Web Application for K-Nearest Neighbours Classification
authors: Konstantinos Batsios, Stefanos Ougiaroglou, Charalampos Bratsas
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: AutoKNN is an automated machine learning web application created to facilitate the application of k -Nearest Neighbors classification, particularly for those without programming or machine learning experience. With AutoKNN, users have the ability to submit datasets, create k-NN models, select parameter values, and perform classification tasks via a userfriendly web interface and a corresponding web API. A key feature is its “auto modes”, which automatically determine the optimal value of k and the most appropriate distance metric for each dataset. Users can evaluate model performance, save trained models for future classification tasks, and integrate its functions into external systems via the API, making k-NN classification accessible for a broad audience. To assess user experience, a System Usability Scale evaluation was conducted, with results indicating a very high level of usability and user satisfaction.

title: Visual Fingerprints for Detecting Data Characteristics
authors: Meredith Siang-Yun Chou, Hans-Jörg Schulz
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: Compact visualizations are often used to detect expected and unexpected data characteristics at a glance. The literature uses the terms fingerprints, thumbnails, or sketches for these bite-sized visualizations. To date, these visualizations have not been described in context and their discussion is fragmented across publications. In this paper, we propose the term Visual Fingerprints for these visualizations, highlight the task of visual detection for which they are designed, outline their visual properties, and discuss their commonalities and differences with related concepts. In doing so, we aim to bundle the existing research on these visualizations into a common concept and term that serves as a foundation and stepping stone for future developments in this direction.

title: Value Stacking of Batteries for Multi-Factorial Degradation Through Iterative Quadratic Fitting
authors: Jonatan Ralf Axel Klemets, Lill Mari Engan, Fredrik Håheim Hvaara, Kasper Emil Thorvaldsen, Espen Flo Bødal, Kjersti Berg
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper proposes a method for optimal scheduling of battery services that accounts for battery degradation from multiple factors, such as Depth of Discharge (DoD) and mean State of Charge (mSoC). The proposed method employs a convex and quadratic degradation function based on charging patterns and frequency market participation to iteratively capture the actual degradation cost. Through iterative adjustments to better represent degradation, the method identifies the optimal solution for multi-market operation and value stacking of battery services. Initial simulations demonstrate a 55 % to 70 % increase in profits from spot-price and frequency market participation compared to other methods.

title: Small-Signal Stability Assessment of Low-Voltage DC Networks: Experimental Validation
authors: Qihao Guo, William Norris, Jérôme Buire, David Frey, Patrick Chambon
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper aims to present an experimental testbed using imperix rapid control prototyping solution for studying the small-signal stability of low-voltage DC microgrid (MG). The effectiveness of this testbed is verified by a fundamental one-source, one-load DC MG, which is a straightforward topology that effectively identifies root causes and reveals physical insights of instability without adding unnecessary complexity. The wave-forms related to the poorly damped oscillatory mode can be observed when the system is subjected to an external perturbation. Modal analysis helps to give a comprehensive analysis that highlights potential parameters that impact the system’s stability margin. Different stability enhancement solutions are proposed to damp the poorly damped oscillatory mode.

title: Remote Sensing of Snow from Modeling to Application for Memory of Jeff Dozier
authors: Jiancheng Shi, Lingmei Jiang, Chuan Xiong, Jinmei Pan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: We, as Jeff's students, are stunned deeply sad for lost our friend, mentor and teacher of Prof. Jeff Dozier. Jeff has made his great contributions on the collaboration between U.S and China. His students and student's students have more than 100 already. As his students, we are eternally grateful for the knowledge, inspiration, and mentorship that he provided. His legacy will continue to guide us on our career development and lives. Jeff's legacy will live on for generations. In this paper, we will show some progresses have made on remote sensing of snow and snow hydrology from Jeff's students in China, including 1) radiative transfer of snow and field validation, 2) inversion algorithms developments for snow properties retrieval, and 3) the synergy of remote sensing observation and snow process model for snow melting water estimation.

title: Coordinating Artificial Intelligence and Bitcoin Mining Workloads: A Risk-Aware Distributional Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning Approach
authors: Ioannis T. Thomaidis, Panagiotis G. Giannopoulos, Thomas K. Dasaklis
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: The rapid expansion of Artificial Intelligence (AI) workloads has created substantial energy requirements for contemporary data centers, which generate worries about infrastructure expansion and operational expenses and environmental sustainability. The worldwide shift toward renewable energy creates uncertainties in power supply that lead to grid instability and energy curtailment problems. This paper explores the synergistic convergence of AI compute infrastructure and Bitcoin (BTC) mining as a novel, energy-aware co-optimization framework. We propose a Distributional Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) system that dynamically allocates surplus energy between latency-sensitive AI jobs and highly flexible BTC mining operations. The proposed solution includes essential participants like renewable energy producers, energy management agents, AI clusters and BTC miners operating within a centralized training and decentralized execution paradigm. The simulation demonstrates that our MARL-driven methodology reduces the reduction in renewable energy by up to 65 % while maintaining high BTC mining profitability and stable grid demand and ensuring AI service level compliance. These findings suggest a path toward sustainable, intelligent energy computation ecosystems where AI and blockchain technologies operate not as competitors, but as complementary agents within a unified infrastructure.

title: Establishment of a Weighted Risk Model for Diabetes Among U.S. Residents Based on BRFSS
authors: Chutong Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data and Intelligent Medicine (BDIMed)
abstract: Diabetes mellitus (DM) is a prevalent chronic disease with significant health and socioeconomic burdens. Early identification of individuals at risk is crucial for effective intervention. This study aims to develop a weighted diabetes risk prediction model using classification data from the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS), a large-scale U.S. health survey. A total of 253,680 participants aged 18 to 80 were included, and 21 demographic, socioeconomic, behavioral, and health-related variables were selected. A Random Forest (RF) algorithm was employed to construct predictive models on both original (imbalanced) and enhanced (balanced) datasets. After hyperparameter tuning, the balanced dataset model achieved an ROC_AUC of 0.82 and a Precision-Recall AUC of 0.83, with a recall of 0.80, indicating strong predictive performance. Feature importance analysis revealed Body Mass Index (BMI), high blood pressure, general health status, and age as the most influential predictors. The model demonstrated poor sensitivity on the imbalanced dataset but performed well under class balance conditions. These findings highlight the potential of machine learning models based on categorical survey data for early diabetes risk screening. This approach offers a cost-effective tool to support public health planning, particularly in resource-constrained settings where continuous biomarkers may not be readily available.

title: Augmented Reality in Patient Monitoring System Using Embedded Sensors
authors: V Diana Earshia, B. Sumitra, Temur Eshchanov, Sardor Sabirov, Odilbek Matsapayev, Jushkinbek Yuldoshev
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Everything has changed with the introduction of IoT and other technologies. The implementation of remote and almost instant healthcare monitoring is now a reality. This research focuses on the design of an IoT based solution that combines remotely located sensors, facilitates their integration with processing units, and encodes health information to be transmitted over the Internet in a secure way. The work done allows an individual to draw essential conclusions on the improvement of patient care and systems of healthcare delivery.The ability of the system to function in the real world offers yet another challenge. Despite indicating reliability in controlled testing, additional studies are necessary to assess the system's abilities for prediction in chaotic situations.Testing has shown the user that he will easily get it implemented into his life which is essential if a health monitoring solution needs to be both an effective and sustainable tool within personal or professional lifetimes texts

title: Emotion-Aware Access Control using Mask-Resilient Facial Analysis with Hybrid CNN-Transformer Architecture
authors: Nandani Tejalkumar Rana, Joideep Banerjee
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Traditional access control systems rely solely on identity verification, overlooking the emotional state of individuals attempting entry. In high-security or emotionally sensitive environments, the ability to detect aggression, distress, or instability can serve as a crucial additional safeguard. This paper proposes an emotion-aware access control system that integrates real-time facial emotion recognition (FER) into access decisions, with specific resilience to facial occlusions such as medical or pollution masks. The proposed system employs a hybrid CNN-Transformer architecture trained on augmented datasets to classify core emotional states—including anger, fear, happiness, and neutrality—even when parts of the face are obscured or image quality is degraded. Emotion detection is directly embedded into the access logic, allowing entry for calm or neutral expressions while flagging or denying access for high-risk emotional cues. The system achieves up to 85% classification accuracy in masked scenarios using a YOLOv8-based model, demonstrating strong reliability under occlusion in both lab and real-world conditions. This work introduces a behavioral intelligence layer into biometric access systems, enhancing safety, privacy, and situational awareness.

title: Representative Load Profiles and Low-Voltage Grid Simulations for Austria
authors: Claudia Benesch, Stefan Wilker, Thilo Sauter
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: In the course of the energy transition, the issue of availability of load profiles is still a serious obstacle. Especially in Europe, where the handling of private data is regulated under GDPR and data such as load profiles can be and are interpreted as worthy of protection, the need for reliable alternative sources is evident for future research. In this paper, we present a representative semi-urban low-voltage grid for Austria that was defined based on the current status of social household compositions, for which load profiles were created, and actual roll-out of photovoltaics, heat-pumps and battery electric vehicles. The generated behavior-based load profiles are assigned to an electric grid, which is analyzed and compared to reference values displaying differences in monthly and weekday load patterns. We compare and discuss also selected results of the grid simulations, which exhibit significant differences in the load distribution of the simulated 400 kVA transformer.

title: A Novel Data Generation Method Based on VMD and Ada-Con-DDPM for RF Front-end Fault Diagnosis Under Imbalanced Data
authors: Xinfeng Guo, Zhen Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Multi-channel RF transceiver front-end is a core component widely used in communication, navigation, radar and other fields. The accuracy of fault diagnosis for it affects the safety and reliability of related systems. The data - driven method is a widely used method to its fault diagnosis in recent years. The performance of the method depends on the training data. Nevertheless, constrained by the non-uniform occurrence of diverse faults, the data volumes of each fault type are usually imbalanced, which causes severe decline in the accuracy. To address this issue, we propose a data generation method based on variational mode decomposition (VMD) and adaptive conditional denoising diffusion probabilistic model (Ada-Con-DDPM). First, little sample data is decomposed into intrinsic mode functions (IMFs) by VMD. The DDPM is trained to learn the characteristics of the IMFs. Then, this method creates reference IMFs sets and conditional functions with learnable coefficients vector to guide DDPM to generate data. After generation, a loss function is established to evaluate the quality of the generated data and adaptively optimize the scale coefficients vector. Subsequently, data is regenerated using the optimized results. Through iterative repetition, higher quality training data can be generated. We employ various methods for data generation on a same experimental multi-channel transceiver RF front-end. Results show that the data generated by proposed method has better quality, enabling the average accuracy of trained diagnosis model 5.67% higher than the best traditional method under different imbalance ratio.

title: Comparison of Multi-Source Satellite SEA Ice Concentration Products
authors: Chengfei Jiang, Lijian Shi, Youguang Zhang, Mingsen Lin
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The five sea ice datasets used in this study - NSIDC-IC-25 km, AMSR2-IC-6.25km, OSISAF-IC-10km, OSISAF-IE-10 km, and NSIDC-IC-12.5km - are all capable of capturing the seasonal changes in sea ice extent in the Arctic and Antarctic regions. They successfully capture the typical seasonal cycle of ice growth and melt, with the Arctic reaching a maximum in March-April and a minimum in September and the Antarctic reaching a maximum in September-October and a minimum in February. However, there are significant differences between the datasets in the extent of sea ice, especially during periods of rapid ice formation and melting. The differences between the Arctic datasets are more pronounced, especially during periods of ice freeze-up. The NSIDC-IC-25km product differs most from the others, and the coarser resolution means that more sea areas are identified as sea ice in marginal areas, affecting the identification results. The consistency between the Antarctic datasets is higher (correlation higher than 0.99), and the differences in sea ice extent are smaller, especially during the melting season. Using AMSR2-IC-6.25 km as a benchmark, the data provided by OSISAF are closer to the benchmark and the data provided by NSIDC, and also have a lower RMSD value.

title: Driver Monitoring Systems: Advances, Challenges, and Future Directions in Non-Contact Sensor Technologies – A Review
authors: Anima Rahman, Flora Barber, Milan Lovric, Roger Woodman, Valentina Donzella
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Non-contact driver monitoring systems have gained traction as non-intrusive and non-invasive methods for assessing driver state. This survey reviews camera, radar, microphone, and vehicle-based sensing modalities, examining their operational principles, recent research findings, and integration considerations. Machine learning’s central role in gaze tracking, activity recognition, vital signs monitoring, and driver state prediction, is also explored. The survey highlights key challenges including limited ecological validity, demographic bias, privacy and ethical risks, and the need for real-time performance under edge-computing constraints. It also identifies key future directions, including multimodal sensor fusion, resource-efficient deployment, and integration with automated driving systems. This survey is a scoping review based on structured database searches that maps progress in non-contact driver monitoring, prioritising the latest research in view of rapid advances in sensing hardware, computer vision, and embedded AI. The synthesised findings offer practical guidance for engineers, vehicle manufacturers, and policymakers on deploying robust, privacy-preserving, and real-time driver monitoring solutions to improve road safety.

title: Mechanism Analysis and Experimental Verification for Molecular Structure Influence on Lightning Impulse Performance of Different Ester-Based Oil
authors: Jian Hao, Hongwei Li, Xiong Liu, Han Zhou, Jingwen Zhang, Ruijing Liao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: The lightning impulse characteristics of ester-based insulating oil are critical for ensuring the safety and reliability of high-voltage and large-capacity power transformers. Therefore, this paper focuses on the lightning breakdown characteristic investigations of soybean oil (SO), diisotridecyl adipate (DA), diisooctyl sebacate (DS), PFAE, and isooctyl stearate (IS) based on theoretical computation and experimental validation. First, the microscopic electrical parameters of different structures of ester-based insulating oils were computed by quantum chemistry simulations from an atomic-scale perspective. Then, the difference between microscopic parameters five insulating oils was comparatively analyzed. Furthermore, the impulse insulation strength of five insulating oils was predicted theoretically. Finally, the lightning impulse breakdown voltage (LIBV) with the negative polarity were experimentally tested under the extremely uneven field. Theoretical results show that the difference between the ionization potential (IP), energy gap, excitation energy and electrostatic potential will directly be associated with lightning impulse breakdown characteristics of five insulating oils. The less ester group and unsaturated carbon-carbon double bond, the better the impulse characteristics of insulating oil. The LIBV properties of five insulating oils are obtained, isooctyl stearate (IS) > PFAE > diisooctyl sebacate (DS) > diisotridecyl adipate (DA) >soybean oil (SO). Experiments quantitatively validate that the measured LIBV values agrees with the simulation analysis. This paper provides theoretical guidance for improving lightning impulse characteristics based on molecular structure design.

title: Enhancing Hyperspectral Image Classification with Spectral-Spatial Convolutional FourierKAN Transformer
authors: Zixuan Xue, Zhijing Ye, Boyu Wang, Yuqing Zhang, Chengyong Zheng, Jiangtao Peng
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The dominance of Transformer architectures in hyperspectral image (HSI) classification, driven by their self-attention mechanisms and Multilayer perceptron (MLP), faces critical challenges in mathematical interpretability and spectral redundancy sensitivity. To address these limitations, we propose a novel Spectral-Spatial Convolutional FourierKAN Transformer (S2CFKAT) framework for HSI classification. Unlike traditional MLP, Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN) leverages learnable activation functions to achieve superior approximation capacity and nonlinear expression while enhancing adaptability to unbalanced and small-sample scenarios. In the proposed S2CFKAT, a mixed convolutions module (MCM) is designed for preliminary spectral-spatial feature extraction, combining 3D convolution for spectral and spatial continuity preservation and 2D convolution for spatial detail enhancement. Then, a FourierKAN Transformer (FKAT) architecture is presented that synergizes multi-head self-attention mechanisms with learnable spectral-spatial activation functions. This design enables the adaptive fusion of long-range dependencies (via self-attention) and discriminative frequency patterns (via FourierKAN layers). Further, a FourierKAN Block (FKAB) consisting of dual FourierKAN layers is used to learn complex nonlinear interactions of spectral-spatial features. Finally, a FourierKAN classification head is constructed for label learning through the softmax functions in Fourier space. Comparative analysis of four public HSI datasets demonstrates that the proposed framework, S2CFKAT, exhibits superior generalization capabilities over state-of-the-art deep learning models. In particular, it still maintains high accuracies when classifying small and unbalanced training samples, which shows that our model has good performance and robustness.

title: Determinants of Success for Technology Business Incubators in India
authors: Mohd Tabrej Alam, Rudra Prakash Pradhan
publish: IEEE Engineering Management Review
abstract: Technology Business Incubators (TBIs) have emerged as essential tools for fostering entrepreneurship, innovation, and start-ups, particularly in developing countries like India. Although previous studies focused on targeting individual factors in the incubators, the systematic analysis of multiple factors is only marginally covered due to a lack of national-level data. We have used a multi-dimensional theoretically driven framework focuses on the evaluation of how different variables such as human capital, mentorship, funding access, technological innovation, and institutional infrastructure determine incubator performance, which is established and empirically evaluated. Using data from 300 incubators across six Indian regions (2013–2023), we applied factor analysis followed by panel count regressions (Fixed-Effects Negative Binomial and Zero-Inflated Negative Binomial) that support over dispersion and structural zeros in incubation graduation. Findings demonstrate that scientific capability (e.g., patents), educational intensity, and mentoring are important factors for fostering incubator success. Our proposed model considers science and mentorship, two interconnected pillars upon which startup ecosystems should be developed, which should not only promote theoretical progress but also provide insights relevant to policymakers and practitioners working on the development of entrepreneurial ecosystems in developing countries. This study enhances ecosystem theory by amalgamating mentorship and scientific proficiency, providing evidence-based recommendations for incubator design, regional policy coherence, and globally scalable innovation results.

title: A Survey of Behavior Foundation Model: Next-Generation Whole-Body Control System of Humanoid Robots
authors: Mingqi Yuan, Tao Yu, Wenqi Ge, Xiuyong Yao, Dapeng Li, Huijiang Wang, Jiayu Chen, Bo Li, Wei Zhang, Wenjun Zeng, Hua Chen, Xin Jin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Humanoid robots are drawing significant attention as versatile platforms for complex motor control, human-robot interaction, and general-purpose physical intelligence. However, achieving efficient whole-body control (WBC) in humanoids remains a fundamental challenge due to sophisticated dynamics, underactuation, and diverse task requirements. While learning-based controllers have shown promise for complex tasks, their reliance on labor-intensive and costly retraining for new scenarios limits real-world applicability. To address these limitations, behavior(al) foundation models (BFMs) have emerged as a new paradigm that leverages large-scale pre-training to learn reusable primitive skills and broad behavioral priors, enabling zero-shot or rapid adaptation to a wide range of downstream tasks. In this paper, we present a comprehensive overview of BFMs for humanoid WBC, tracing their development across diverse pre-training pipelines. Furthermore, we discuss real-world applications, current limitations, urgent challenges, and future opportunities, positioning BFMs as a key approach toward scalable and general-purpose humanoid intelligence. Finally, we provide a curated and regularly updated collection of BFM papers and projects to facilitate further research, which is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/yuanmingqi/awesome-bfm-papers</uri>.

title: A Flexible Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning Framework for Dynamic Routing and Scheduling of Latency-Critical Services
authors: Vincenzo Norman Vitale, Antonia Maria Tulino, Andreas F. Molisch, Jaime Llorca
publish: IEEE Transactions on Networking
abstract: Timely delivery of delay-sensitive information over dynamic, heterogeneous networks is increasingly essential for a range of interactive applications, such as industrial automation, self-driving vehicles, and augmented reality. However, most existing network control solutions target only average delay performance, falling short of providing strict End-to-End (E2E) peak latency guarantees. This paper addresses the challenge of reliably delivering packets within application-imposed deadlines by leveraging recent advancements in Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning (MA-DRL). After introducing the Delay-Constrained Maximum-Throughput (DCMT) dynamic network control problem, and highlighting the limitations of current solutions, we present a novel MA-DRL network control framework that leverages a centralized routing and distributed scheduling architecture. The proposed framework leverages critical networking domain knowledge for the design of effective MA-DRL strategies based on the Multi-Agent Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (MADDPG) technique, where centralized routing and distributed scheduling agents dynamically assign paths and schedule packet transmissions according to packet lifetimes, thereby maximizing on-time packet delivery. The generality of the proposed framework allows integrating both data-driven Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) agents and traditional rule-based policies in order to strike the right balance between performance and learning complexity. Our results confirm the superiority of the proposed framework with respect to traditional stochastic optimization-based approaches and provide key insights into the role and interplay between data-driven DRL agents and new rule-based policies for both efficient and high-performance control of latency-critical services.

title: Theoretical Analysis for Interaction Mechanisms in Dual-Electron Beam Slow Wave System
authors: Gaoli Xiang, Zhigang Lu, Jingrui Duan, Zechuan Wang, Yuan Zheng, Zhanliang Wang, Huarong Gong, Shaomeng Wang, Yubin Gong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: A theoretical analysis for dual-electron beam (DEB) slow wave system is carried out. By utilizing the linear theory, the dispersion relations of the DEB system are obtained for both continuous and periodic conditions. The results reveal the interaction mechanism between two electron beams and the slow wave circuit. Specifically, it can be seen as interactions between a single-electron beam (SEB) system and the other electron beam. Then, the impact of electron beam parameters on the interactions is analyzed, which is helpful for practical design and manufacture. This study provides a perspective to understand the interaction mechanisms that take place in the DEB system, filling the theoretical gap in DEB system studies. What is more, it gives a path to study the two-stream instability containing interaction circuits.

title: Sifting Truth From Spectacle! a Multimodal Hindi Dataset for Misinformation Detection With Emotional Cues and Sentiments
authors: Raghvendra Kumar, Pulkit Bansal, Raunak Kumar Singh, Sriparna Saha
publish: IEEE Transactions on Affective Computing
abstract: Misinformation poses a growing threat across media ecosystems, yet research on Hindi, one of the world's most widely spoken languages, remains limited. We introduce a novel multimodal Hindi dataset of 6,544 article–image pairs to advance misinformation detection. Unlike existing English-centric and predominantly unimodal datasets, ours integrates text, images, and affective signals while being carefully cleaned of veracity cues to avoid artefact-driven inflation. Each sample is annotated with sentiment and emotions, making this the first Hindi resource with multimodal and affective dimensions. Through extensive experiments using IndicBART, IndicBERT, mBERT, and Vision Transformer models, we demonstrate the effectiveness of text–image fusion and affective features across multiple configurations. We also analyze the readability characteristics of genuine and misleading articles, providing insights into the linguistic patterns of Hindi misinformation. This dataset establishes a robust benchmark for multimodal misinformation detection and lays essential groundwork for research in Hindi and other low-resource languages.

title: Optimization-Based Data Recovery After False Data Injection Attacks on State Estimators Using Measurements Inertia and Calibrated Predictions
authors: Elham Ommani, Hamed Delkhosh, Hossein Seifi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid
abstract: Information and communication technology brings better operation capabilities for the power grids at the cost of vulnerability against cyber-attacks. The false data injection attack (FDIA) on the state estimator (SE) is one of the intelligent cyber threats, for which different detection and mitigation methods are proposed. Nevertheless, data recovery after the FDIAs as one of the mitigative actions has received less attention in the literature. This paper proposes a data recovery scheme based on optimization to maintain the consistency among recovered variables. Also, the attack region is localized in an enhanced way so that the non-attacked variables will be preserved as much as possible. The optimization combines two important sources of information for accurate data recovery, i.e., measurement data inertia (MDI) and prediction data calibration (PDC). MDI and PDC are formed using machine learning methods (respectively regression and XGBoost) based on online training using recent (e.g., two weeks) power grid data. Such training is demonstrated to be fast enough (less than the data acquisition rate) to provide adaptable accurate data recovery considering different conditions. Extensive experiments are implemented on the IEEE 118-bus test system to verify the correctness and effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Analytical Error Evaluation and Hardware Implementation of Approximate Negation Circuits
authors: Ettore Napoli, Efstratios Zacharelos, Davide De Caro, Gennaro Di Meo, Antonio G. M. Strollo
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Inexact arithmetic units trade precision for improvements in energy efficiency, silicon area, and speed. Most existing designs focus on non-negative numbers and, when used in real applications, rely on Sign and Magnitude (SM) transformations to deal with signed values mitigating most of the advantages obtained in the first place. This work investigates circuits for the approximate negation of numbers in two’s complement (2’sC) format that offer a middle ground in terms of error and energy efficiency when compared to the exact 2’sC negation and the more aggressive one’s complement (1’sC) negation method, thus obtaining a general purpose tool for approximate computing that can be seamlessly integrated into existing designs. The paper demonstrates that by using this tool it is possible to exploit unsigned approximate arithmetic circuits in signed applications, achieving slightly lower error with no additional power compared to the commonly used 1’sC approximation, or significantly reduced error, while still lowering power dissipation relative to exact 2’sC negation. We derive analytical expressions for error characteristics and present a hardware implementation. The resulting versatile technique can be exploited to compute absolute values or to convert SM representations into 2’sC format.We incorporate the investigated circuits into several approximate architectures using a 14 nm FinFET standard cell library. The resulting designs, when compared with 1’sC negation, are able to improve accuracy (achieving up to 30% error reduction in approximate multipliers and 10dB PSNR gain in H.264 video compression) while still reducing the power dissipation.

title: ASTNet: Adaptive Spatio-temporal Transformer for Efficient Video Deblurring
authors: Ying Fu, Chen Zhou, Jianan Tian, Wei Liu, Tao Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: Removing motion blur from videos is a highly challenging task, with existing methods primarily focused on extracting spatio-temporal information from blurred frames and effectively fusing it. Among these, methods based on Transformer have demonstrated particularly outstanding performance in video deblurring tasks. However, the standard self-attention mechanism considers all regions within the feature map, making it difficult to adapt to certain non-uniform blur scenarios. To address this, we propose an adaptive self-attention mechanism that uses the ReLU function and square operation to filter out negative values in attention scores, thereby enhancing the network’s ability to focus on locally severely blurred regions. To accommodate global blurring scenarios, we retain the dense attention branch. To further enable fine-grained feature adjustment, we introduce a bidirectional feature enhancement feed-forward network, which can simultaneously extract spatio-temporal features in both horizontal and vertical directions. We also designed a dynamic feature fusion module to adaptively integrate feature information from neighboring frames to avoid error accumulation during feature fusion. Experimental results on synthetic and real datasets show that the proposed method outperforms the current state-of-the-art methods. The code and dataset are available at https://github.com/Frank-Zhou-01/ASTNet.

title: Scanning Electrical Impedance Tomography for CFRP Damage Detection
authors: Benyuan Sun, Yunzhi Zhou, Hangyu Zhong, Yu Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
