abstract: Carbon Fiber Reinforced Polymer (CFRP) laminates are increasingly used in aerospace and other high-performance applications, but their complex conductivity distribution and large-surface areas in practical use pose significant challenges for real time, online structural health monitoring, typically presenting issues such as inadequate signal transmission efficiency, complex electrode array installation, or insufficient data processing efficiency. To address these challenges, this paper presents a novel scanning measurement strategy and data fusion approach for damage detection of large-surface CFRP with Electrical Impedance Tomography (EIT). Low-dimensional voltage datasets are generated through moving a local electrode array, and these datasets are fused via a Choquet integral framework weighted by Shapley values, which optimally processes overlapping measurement data and reduces the dimensionality of final measurement dataset. Simulations and experiments demonstrate that the proposed method has an image correlation coefficient and sensitivity uniformity comparable to traditional global measurement methods, while greatly shortening the image reconstruction time and improving the algorithm real-time performance. The proposed method holds promise for extending existing EIT systems to large-surface CFRP, providing high precision, enhanced sensitivity, and real-time performance with the minimum of hardware channels.

title: Immersive Virtual Learning Environments and Immersive Technologies: A Grad. Course Case Study: CSCI 6520 (Winter 2025) Group
authors: Bill Kapralos
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: The rapid advancement of immersive technologies, such as virtual reality (VR), augmented reality (AR), and mixed reality (MR), has positioned immersive virtual learning environments (iVLEs) as powerful educational tools across many disciplines. Despite their widespread use and popularity, their effectiveness is often hindered by both educators' limited knowledge regarding their design, development, and application, and the limited knowledge of instructional design by game/interactive media developers. This paper details a graduate course whose aim was to introduce students to iVLEs and their design and development from an interdisciplinary perspective. The course followed a problem-based learning (PBL) approach that emphasized both the technical (e.g., game design) and instructional design aspects inherent in effective iVLEs. The paper begins with a detailed overview of the course followed by an overview of the course projects. Finally, some recommendations are provided to assist those wishing to implement and offer similar courses.

title: Application of Multi Objective Optimization Algorithm in AGV Path Planning and Scheduling of Automated Port
authors: Yi Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: The following paper introduces a novel method for the use of multi-objective optimization algorithms in the planning and scheduling of the Automated Guided Vehicle (AGV) in automated ports. Since automation of ports increases in terms of complexity, management of AGV routes and its schedule becomes a key factor to consider in enhancing efficiency. The proposed method employs the utilization of multi-objective optimization algorithms to solve such problems such as finding the shortest distance, reduced energy consumption, and traffic congestion in real-time. The optimization framework takes into account dynamic port environments and AGV constraints such as obstacle avoidance and load balancing and also the tight schedules that need to be met. Simulation results show that the proposed approach improves AGV fleet performance by a factor of 20 % while maintaining a balance between travel distance and task completion. Comparison with other methods reveals enhanced optimization results in terms of the speed of computation and the accuracy of the solution in comparison with traditional approaches. This research work offers a solid solution to the growing need for efficient AGV path planning in the contemporary advanced port facilities.

title: A Lightweight CAE-CNN Model with Global Max Pooling for Efficient Rice Leaf Disease Classification
authors: Destia Suhada, I Gede Pasek Suta Wijaya, Ida Bagus Ketut Widiartha, Minho Jo
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Rice leaf diseases plays a critical role in agricultural productivity and food security, particularly in countries with high rice consumption, such as Indonesia. This study proposes a lightweight classification model that integrates Convolutional Autoencoder (CAE) and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to classify five types of rice leaf diseases. Unlike previous studies that rely on large pre-trained models, this study focuses on building a custom architecture from scratch, emphasizing model efficiency and simplicity. CAE is used to extract 128-dimensional latent features from input images, which are then classified using a shallow CNN architecture. Global Max Pooling is introduced at the bottleneck stage to reduce the number of parameters without sacrificing performance. The model is trained and evaluated on a dataset containing 7,430 labeled samples and achieves 99.33% accuracy with only 0.41 million parameters. Comparing the suggested model to existing model reveals that the proposed model provides an optimal balance between model compactness and predictive performance, making it ideal for future low-resource deployments.

title: WSSR: Weight Set Segmentation and Recovery for Fault Resilient Transformers
authors: Ntsee Ndingwan, Chengmo Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: The usage of the transformer model architecture has rapidly become a popular choice in fields related to natural language processing, computer vision, and many other applications. These models have rapidly grown in size and complexity, now containing billions of parameters. Due to their high popularity, the integrity of these models becomes a critical concern. Faults such as bit flips in memory could be caused not only by radiation-induced soft errors, electrical disturbances, thermal fluctuations and aging hardware, but also by intentional Bit Flip Attacks (BFAs). While classic fault tolerance solutions such as Error Correcting Codes (ECC) can mitigate such faults to some extent, their application is often constrained by cost, power, or design limitations. To develop a low-cost and effective fault tolerance solution, this work studies the fault resilience of two large-scale transformer models - CLIP-ViT and Google-ViT. Through systematic fault injection, we find that different layers exhibit varying fault sensitivities, and that large-magnitude parameter perturbations correlate strongly with performance degradation. Building upon this insight, we propose WSSR, a lightweight fault detection and recovery method that segments model weights into sets and flags changes in set membership for fault recovery. Our experiments show that WSSR can restore model accuracy to 91.7% and 84.3% of the original for CLIPViT and Google-ViT, respectively, on the ImageNet1K dataset with only 0.87% and 7.37% compute overhead and virtually no storage overhead-making it practical for deployment on resource-constrained systems.

title: Wavelet-Modulus edge Enhancement and Persistent-Homology Features for Crohn’s-Disease Lesion Detection in Capsule Endoscopy
authors: Toshimasa Ogata, Teruya Minamoto
publish: 2025 International Conference on Wavelet Analysis and Pattern Recognition (ICWAPR)
abstract: Crohn’s disease triggers chronic inflammation throughout the gastrointestinal tract, with lesions often developing in the small intestine. Capsule endoscopy (CE) provides a non-invasive window for screening; however, each examination generates thousands of frames that physicians must manually inspect. We propose a training-free pipeline that couples dyadic wavelet-transform modulus (WTM) edge enhancement with topology-aware descriptors (persistence images; PI) and a fractal descriptor (fractal dimension; FD) to discriminate Crohn’s-specific lesions from normal mucosa. Each image is mapped to a 1057-dimensional vector (1056 PI + 1 FD). After standardization (zero-mean, unit-variance scaling) and principal component analysis (75% cumulative variance), a two-layer multilayer perceptron is used for classification. On an augmented set of 800 images (balanced normal/lesion), the proposed method achieves 95.4% accuracy, 95.2% recall, and 96.5% specificity. Rivaling ResNet-50 (95.6%) and VGG-16 (95.3%) while requiring no pixel-level annotation and orders of magnitude fewer parameters. These findings demonstrate that topology-aware, handcrafted features can match those of deep networks and may help reduce missed lesions in clinical practice.

title: Hybrid MEMS-FPGA Architectures with Transformer Models for Real-Time Speech and Language Processing
authors: Pallati Narsimhulu, Rajanikanth Aluvalu, Premkumar Chithaluru
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Speech and language applications require high accuracy and fast response, yet many embedded processors struggle with the growing complexity of modern recognition models. Conventional solutions often produce delays or demand heavy energy use, while large computing platforms reduce portability. This creates a gap for designs that can combine speed, energy efficiency, and scalability in compact devices. This work introduces a hybrid platform that integrates Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) microphones with Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) for speech and language processing. MEMS microphones capture signals with clarity, while FPGA units accelerate intensive tasks. Classical algorithms such as Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC) are applied for feature extraction, and modern approaches such as lightweight Transformer models and compact large language models (LLMs) are deployed on FPGA resources for classification and sequence modeling. The hybrid integration of deep neural network (DNN) and Transformer-based modules allows accurate representation of acoustic and contextual patterns while maintaining real-time response. The platform is evaluated with recognition word error rate (WER), latency, signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) improvement, and energy consumption. Results show that combining MEMS sensing with FPGA acceleration and Transformer-based architectures improves both SNR and contextual understanding while reducing power usage. The system demonstrates significant improvement in latency and WER compared with traditional embedded setups, while remaining suitable for portable and low-energy environments. These findings highlight the value of blending MEMS hardware, FPGA accelerators, and state-of-the-art Artificial intelligence (AI) methods to create a practical path for next-generation speech and language technologies.

title: An Efficient Deep Learning Model for Campus Violence Detection Using YOLOv11s
authors: Khushi Balekundri, Sanjana M., Shruthi U., Lakshmi Harshita Garapati, Raksha H.K.
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) techniques for campus surveillance allow security teams to respond more quickly. These technologies also detect threats in real time, which improves overall campus safety. The technology detects potential risks, such as conflicts, by analyzing movement patterns and interactions. It provides early alerts to prevent things from growing worse. You Only Look Once (YOLO) is a novel object detection algorithm developed to recognize and highlight the instances of violence in video frames. The proposed model uses the Open Source Computer Vision Library (OpenCV) to analyze the input video and offers frame-by-frame annotations. Each scene is classified as either violence or nonviolence that ensures a quick and detailed assessment of potential threats. Training the YOLOv11s model on the custom violence and non-violence dataset has achieved a mean average precision (mAP) of 0.826. The proposed model performs with the best results by identifying 458 instances of violence accurately. The training process has improved the precision, recall, and localization. This means higher confidence and fewer errors.

title: Cause-Aware Multi-Task Learning for Urban Traffic Congestion Prediction
authors: Madala Neeraja, Ravuri Lalitha, Himaja Reddy Tatireddy, Raja Gopal Devarapalli, Mekala Navya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Traffic congestion remains a critical challenge in urban cities, affecting mobility, air quality, and public transport reliability. Most existing studies focus only on predicting congestion severity and overlook the underlying causes and the overall impact of congestion on the environment and commuters. This paper proposes a novel multi-output deep learning framework that simultaneously predicts congestion level (No, Mild, Moderate, Severe), classifies root causes of congestion (Incident, Weather, Roadwork, Normal), and introduces a new Congestion Cost Index (CCI) that combines travel time, environmental impact, and public transport deviation into a single actionable metric. The proposed approach integrates weather, incident, and construction-aware features to provide a holistic view of traffic behavior. By combining deep learning architectures such as TabNet, this framework offers interpretable, real-world insights for smart city traffic management. The results highlight the potential of this approach to enable data-driven decision-making and improve urban mobility planning.

title: Machine Learning for Early Detection of Diabetes: A Systematic Review of Methods, Datasets, and Challenges
authors: Anand Kumar, Hetal Bhaidasna, Ashwini Kumar Jha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Diabetes mellitus is a worldwide health issue that is increasing in prevalence across different populations. Early detection is necessary to prevent complications such as cardiovascular diseases, nephropathy, neuropathy and retinopathy. Traditional diagnostic approaches tend to rely on invasive blood tests, are clinically validated but do not often predict disease progression beyond a clinical metabolic diagnosis. Machine learning (ML) is a relatively new method which has the ability to identify emergent risk pathways that could be representative of diabetic influences on a patient that are not evident but share common patterns in a heterogeneous dataset of clinical, demographic and lifestyle variables, therefore representing new pathways to help manage and monitor risk. This systematic review consolidates the studies to identify early detection of diabetes using ML techniques, including traditional algorithms (logistic regression, decision trees, support vector machines), emerging methods (ensemble methods, deep learning), and hybrid systems that involve Internet of Things (IoT) devices and federated learning. It prioritises datasets (such as the Pima Indian Diabetes Dataset, hospital datasets and local databases), metrics of evaluation (accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and ROC-AUC). Overall, it has found that ML techniques have better predictive accuracy across studies compared to traditional diagnostic methods. Overall, there are many issues facing ML with concerns over data imbalance, interpretability and generalizability across populations. The systematic review presents an indication of mapping trends in methodologies, a discussion about limitations and suggestions for the future including knowledgeable explainable AI and future EHR integration and a privacy-preserving federated learning environment. In summary, the review highlights the potential of ML to improve early identification and support personalized approaches of diabetes management.

title: Flexible Slotted Patch Antenna for Non-Invasive Detection of Blood Glucose
authors: Boutheina Tlili, Nadeen R. Rishani, Miziya Keshkar, Firas Fatani, Mohammed Vaseem, Atif Shamim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Non-invasive monitoring of glucose levels has been gaining significant attention from research and industry to enable painless and continuous glucose monitoring for diabetic patients. Herein, a novel, simple Flexible Slotted Patch Antenna (FSPA) is designed to noninvasively monitor blood glucose levels. The FSPA leverages flexible Polyimide (PI) substrate, allowing it to be worn as a bracelet around the user's wrist. The sensor patch is constructed from silver-printed ink and features slots that mimic blood veins of the human wrist. The sensor has dimensions of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{42} \times \text{50} \times \text{0.125} \text{mm}^{\mathrm{3}}$</tex>. Numerical modeling and theoretical analysis of the FSPA are performed using CST simulation software. The sensor is designed to resonate at a frequency of 2 GHz (ISM band) with simulated sensitivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$90.6 \times 10^{-3} \text{dB} /(\text{mg} / \text{dL})$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$353.4 \text{kHz} /(\text{mg} / \text{dL})$</tex>, when loaded with Cole- Cole model of blood having different glucose concentrations. The performance of the printed prototype is validated using lab-prepared aqueous glucose solutions ranging from 50 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$200 \text{mg} / \text{dL}$</tex>, which shows excellent maximum sensitivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$123.7 \times 10^{-3} \text{dB} /(\text{mg} / \text{dL})$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.263 \text{MHz} /(\text{mg} / \text{dL})$</tex>. The proposed sensor patch paves the way for non-invasive microwave based glucose sensing for practical applications.

title: Fuzzy Logic-Based Optimization of Trouble Ticket System at PT PLN Icon Plus
authors: Yori Wahyu Saputri, Muh Ali Abdillah S, Baso Sain, Aldian Nurcahyo
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: This study proposes a fuzzy-logic-based prioritization system that automates trouble ticket assignment at PT PLN Icon Plus. We implement a Mamdani FIS using two expert-validated inputs (ticket age and customer segment) to produce a priority score that subsequently drives workloadaware distribution at the system level. The data collection method was carried out through the collection of 8,822 historical trouble tickets and complemented with expert interviews to capture operational rules. Three fuzzy models-Mamdani, Sugeno, and Tsukamoto-were evaluated using nonparametric statistical tests (Kruskal-Wallis, Dunn-Bonferroni) and Mean Absolute Error (MAE) against expert-defined prioritization. Mamdani achieved the best performance, yielding the lowest MAE of 0.5 (95% CI: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.45-0.64$</tex>). The implemented prototype successfully reduced the average ticket distribution time by 84.2% and improved the workload balance by 114.2%. This study focuses on Sulawesi and Eastern Indonesia, presents a fuzzy logic-based system prototype that has been empirically tested and demonstrated to significantly enhance the operational efficiency of trouble ticket distribution.

title: Study Action Recognition of Baseline Tennis Stroke Techniques Based on Pose Estimation Using LSTM
authors: Ibnu Asror, Maman Abdurohman, Achmad Rizal, Bayu Erfianto
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Objective motion analysis in tennis is crucial to improve athlete development; however, conventional coaching methodologies are inherently subjective and lack quantifiable metrics. Despite the existence of Computer Vision approaches, the validation of accurate, practical, and non-intrusive methods for detailed baseline stroke classification (forehand vs. backhand) remains limited. This paper proposes a solution to this challenge by systematically implementing and evaluating a framework that integrates pose estimation with long-short-term memory (LSTM). The proposed framework extracts 33 body landmarks from video sequences, which are then processed by a multilevel LSTM architecture. The optimized model demonstrated an accuracy of 0.976 and an F1 score of 0.968 on the test data. These results not only validate the feasibility of the sequential pose-based approach but also establish a strong performance baseline for future digital coaching application development.

title: opENS: an Open Source Connected Inverter for Smart Grid Experimental Validations
authors: R. Le Goff Latimier, G. Jodin, Q. Meyer, H. Ben Ahmed, G. Herault
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Power grids are undergoing the connection of a large number of new, flexible actors, often involving power electronics equipment. The consequences of integrating these new players have turned out to be only partially anticipated. This reaffirms the need for experimental validation, an intermediary stage between simulation and real-life deployment. Current laboratory infrastructures are often limited to testing a limited number of physical assets, which cannot reproduce the interactions taking place in reality. The opENS project therefore offers an original approach enabling the experimental validation of topics that currently can only be addressed through simulation or small scale experiments. It consists in controlled and communicating inverters, which are programmed to replicate the behavior of any actor: power plant, consumer, storage, etc. They are designed to be easily built in large quantities and subjected to fault testing. They are controlled by a communication and supervision platform that monitors the experiment and collects its data. The emulation of power flows in large networks or interactions between numerous inverters can then be conducted on a laboratory scale. This project is open source for its hardware architecture and open data for both the developments made and the data generated.

title: Implementation of SoC Estimation and Charging Method Optimization of Lithium-Ion Battery for Electric Vehicle
authors: S Kalpana Devi, V Kamatchi Kannan, N Dharshini, B V Sai Thrinath, R Sankarganesh, P Ponmurugan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Accurate State of Charge (SoC) estimation and optimized charging are essential for ensuring the efficiency, safety, and longevity of lithium-ion batteries. Traditional methods often struggle to maintain precision due to the complex, dynamic, and non-linear behaviour of batteries under varying operating conditions. This paper proposes a hardware-based system that utilizes fuzzy logic to address these challenges by effectively managing uncertainties in battery characteristics and enabling real-time reliable SoC estimation. This system continuously monitors individual cell parameters such as voltage and temperature, along with overall current, to accurately assess the battery's condition. An adaptive Constant Current-Constant Voltage (CC-CV) charging strategy is employed, which dynamically adjusts the charging process based on the real-time battery state, ensuring efficient and safe charging. Instead of, data-driven or machine learning techniques, the proposed system solely relies on fuzzy inference, which offers a robust, intelligent solution that enhances battery performance, extends operational life, and overcomes the limitations of conventional estimation and charging methods.

title: Leveraging Copernicus Emergency Core Service Products to Support National Institutions in Earthquake Emergency Management
authors: Chiara Casarotti, Ilaria E. Senaldi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Nowadays, emergency relief support is one of the areas where the development of EO-based technologies and products is strongly emphasized and promoted, as it can play a crucial role in the rapid impact estimate on a large-scale basis. A range of operational services is available to EU Member States and participating countries through the Copernicus Emergency Management Service (CEMS). Operating since 2012, CEMS has been activated multiple times, providing products to support the management of major disasters. This discussion analyzes the use of CEMS in the context of seismic emergencies, focusing on how its exploitation can be enhanced and exploring potential development opportunities within the value chain of products and services, possibly tailored to national-scale applications.

title: A Meta-Analytic NLP-Driven Mapping of Fairness in Healthcare AI
authors: Rozita Tsoni, Manolis Koutouzis, Vassileios S. Verykios
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: The constant and rapid evolution of AI is vastly transforming the healthcare landscape. The implementation of new and revolutionary tools is improving the services provided and offering solutions in flexible and effective ways. However, this rapid change does not allow sufficient time for ethical norms and frameworks to develop in a way that ensures fairness and equity. This paper is an attempt to map the existing research concerning fairness in AI in the field of healthcare. An automated approach incorporating NLP methods was adopted for retrieving and filtering relevant systematic literature reviews. The analysis included 11 articles, which were categorized into 5 main topics. Additionally, six areas of suggestions concerning AI in healthcare were identified in the reviewed literature. These suggestions were compared with two important legislative documents: the EU AI Act and the US AI Bill of Rights. Apart from a general alignment, some differences were revealed and discussed. Finally, unresolved issues and prospects for future research were also highlighted.

title: Scalable Deep Learning Frameworks for Cyberbullying Detection in Social Media
authors: Muhammad Imran Ghafoor, Uzair Aslam Bhatti, Valisher Sapayev Odilbek Uglu, Xu Bo, Shah Noor, Saira Akram
publish: 2025 IEEE 19th International Conference on Open Source Systems and Technologies (ICOSST)
abstract: The increased spread of social media networks has compounded the problem of monitoring and controlling cyberbullying, hate speech, and offensive language on a largescale basis. Conventional detection systems are not able to handle the large quantity of unstructured text and multimedia data being created on a daily basis, in addition to guaranteeing privacy and computational performance. The study resolves such difficulties by combining the deep learning Darwens such as convolutional neural networks (CNNs), gated recurrent units (GRUs), and transformer-based frameworks with the big data model that can work with large-scale data like Apache Spark and MapReduce. The suggested method builds upon the principles of distributed in-memory processing and RDD-based anonymization to provide the ability to analyze mass data in a privacy-preserving and high-throughput fashion. Empirical testing indicates that the scalability of the anonymization pipelines and deep learning classifiers together yield high gains in accuracy of detection as well as system performance, especially in the multi-class cyberbullying contexts. Moreover, the framework facilitates cultural flexibility through the integration of sentiment analysis and bias detection modules so that it is robust in various linguistic and social contexts. The findings demonstrate the possibility of implementing end-to-end scalable systems that use AI as a tool to detect cyberbullying in real-time as a technologically sound solution to the challenge of delivering secure, efficient, and socially responsible online communities.

title: Feature Engineering-Empowered MLOps for Smart Grid Failure Prediction Software
authors: Zahra Iranpour Mobarakeh, Paniz MohsenNia, Ehsan Shahi, Saeed Kafshdouzzadeh, Nima Salek Gilani, Alireza Fereidunian, Francisco Jurado, Amin Hajizadeh, Hossein Shahinzadeh
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Unscheduled failures present significant challenges to the reliability of the smart energy distribution systems. This research project reports the complete development and design project for a failure prediction software, aiming at comprehensively analyzing data on unscheduled power failures in four medium-voltage feeders. First, the data of planned and unplanned interruptions, as well as the weather information, are pre-processed. Then, the correlation of the weekly failure with failure characteristics, different scenarios of maintenance activities, and weather characteristics of the relevant week is investigated. Next, the same steps are conducted to check the existence of mutual information between the stated items and weekly failures, followed by a causality analysis on these features. Subsequently, the best fit hyperparameters are derived for predictive modeling of the weekly failures, using grid search in the form of classification. Then the best model with the best performance is selected, based on the different subsets of the extracted features identified in the feature engineering process. Finally, a user interface software is designed to visually present the results of the analyses and predictions. This study not only provides a feature engineering-empowered MLOps software to gain insights into the factors affecting the failures, but also develops tools contribute to improving preventive maintenance strategies and enhancing the reliability of smart grids.

title: Load prediction with hybrid neural networks using data decomposition, dynamics, and financial tools
authors: Edvard Avdevičius, Maik Plenz, Mina Eskander, Detlef Schulz
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Accurate load forecasting is essential for the stability and planning of modern power systems. This paper considers improving univariate time series forecasting without the necessity of third-party data groups. A deep learning of hybrid neural networks framework is proposed that combines decomposition techniques, financial metrics and physical metrics to improve forecasting accuracy. Specifically, the framework combines features such as the Average True Range (ATR), Detrended Price Oscillator (DPO), Hodrick-Prescott filter (HP), Empirical Wavelet Transform (EWT), and CEEMDAN. The methodology is validated through two use cases: annual electricity load forecasting for Germany and annual temperature forecasting for Hamburg. The proposed approach achieves up to 39% improvement in mean squared error compared to baseline models, offering a lightweight and interpretable solution for energy system forecasting.

title: Assessing Popular GAN Models Using Fréchet Inception Distance
authors: Praveenkumar S, Vasudevan N, Nithiyanantham KK, Jeyaprabha A
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) are among the most efficient deep learning architectures, as they generate synthetic data through competitions between two neural networks—a generator and a discriminator. Although GANs provide very realistic outputs, including pictures, stability problems might impede their training process. Three main iterations of GAN exist: Conditional GAN (cGAN), DCGAN, and Vanilla GAN. The Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) is the performance criteria used. By a comparison of produced photos with genuine ones, it assesses realism in the feature space. Because of its label-based method, cGAN shows better control over output during this phase; while, the FID has provided convolution-based DCGAN some edge over Vanilla GAN. By use of FID, these contradictory findings expose the trade-off between the more semantically precise outputs of cGAN and the more stable outputs of DCGAN. This helps every user choose the model best for their situation.

title: Supporting Pipelined Memory Accesses in Processor Synthesis
authors: Essien Taylor, Colin Schilf, Sebastian Phemister, Russ Joseph
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: In deep pipelines, cache accesses must be split over many cycles to accommodate high-clock rates. Given the variable memory access times, the volume of in-flight cache operations, and potential for memory data hazards, implementing the control logic necessary to provide correct operation and maximize performance emerges as a major design challenge. This paper introduces Forecast, a tool for synthesizing deep microprocessor pipelines with support for high-performance cache organizations. Given a functional description of a processor datapath and directives on how to split logic and state accesses into stages, Forecast automatically generates the complete pipeline datapath and fully functional control logic to correctly sequence operations across pipeline stages while maintaining correct operational semantics. Forecast produces logic to enable speculatively scheduled pipelined cache accesses, support buffered stores, and detect and resolve dependencies in the memory system. This tool allows designers to construct deeper pipelined processors with larger capacity and higher throughput caches, improving the performance of these automatically generated processors.

title: Transformer-Based Attention for Gestural Language Identification
authors: M. Daniel Nareshkumar, J. Janish Blessy
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Understanding gestures have become more feasible due to advancements in both computational powers as well as advanced architecture that are able to process sign language. However, majority of the research in continual gestural identification tends to focus mainly on the hand shape while ignoring the orientation of the body. This is mostly because it is difficult to understand spatial information from the complete body. The main issue with LSTM, HMM and traditional SLR are the lack of long-distance understanding and the lack of parallelisation. This research introduces a unique design that overcomes the issues by making use of an attention from the Transformer architecture to better capture the spatial information from the body as well as the gestures due to hand shapes. When tested on the RWTHPHOENIX-Weather Dataset, the suggested architecture achieved a Word Error Rate (WER) of 30.0, which is on par with the most recent stage of technological advancements.

title: Decentralized Adaptive Virtual Impedance Control for Reactive Power Sharing in Single-Loop Grid-Forming Inverters
authors: Md Nurunnabi, Shuhui Li
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Islanded microgrids rely on decentralized droop control of grid-forming inverters to share load without communication. However, reactive power sharing is often inaccurate due to mismatches in line and filter impedances, leading to unequal voltage drops and circulating currents. This paper proposes a fully decentralized adaptive virtual impedance (AVI) control strategy to improve reactive power sharing in a single-loop droop-controlled inverter system. The presented AVI method dynamically adjusts each inverter’s output reactance in real time based on local reactive power errors, effectively compensating for impedance differences and aligning the inverters’ overall impedance seen at the bus. Simulation studies of a three-inverter islanded microgrid show that the proposed decentralized AVI method not only improves reactive power sharing but also enhances voltage stability and power quality by mitigating circulating current effects. The AVI method outperforms standard droop control, offering a lightweight, decentralized solution for improved reactive power distribution under both steady-state and transient conditions.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning Algorithms for Heart Attack Prediction
authors: Erna Haerani, Diah Hidayatul Ula, Linda Sutriani, Alam Rahmatulloh, Irfan Darmawan, Randi Rizal
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Heart attack remains one of the leading causes of mortality worldwide, making accurate and early prediction critical. This research conducts a comparative analysis of four common machine learning algorithms for predicting heart attacks using the publicly available “Heart Attack Analysis & Prediction” dataset from Kaggle. The evaluated algorithms are Support Vector Machine (SVM), Decision Tree, Random Forest, and Gradient Boosting Machines (GBM). The models were trained and tested, with their performance evaluated based on prediction accuracy. The results indicate that the Gradient Boosting Machines model achieved the highest accuracy of 76%. It was followed by SVM with 73% accuracy, while both Decision Tree and Random Forest models yielded an accuracy of 68%. Based on this comparative benchmark, the GBM model is identified as the most effective among the four tested algorithms for this specific classification task, providing a valuable baseline for future research in cardiovascular disease prediction.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning-Driven Nonlinear Scheduling with Dual Decomposition for Intelligent Library Signaling Systems
authors: Ji Kong
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: As smart libraries continue to grow in scale and complexity, traditional static rule-based scheduling methods are no longer able to meet the real-time management needs driven by multi-source data. Therefore, this study proposes a complex scheduling algorithm that integrates deep reinforcement learning, nonlinear constrained optimization, and dual decomposition. This framework is designed to improve resource management and service quality in smart libraries. First, the model constructs a high-dimensional semantic representation of document resources based on a multimodal knowledge graph. This operation enables semantic retrieval, personalized recommendations, and hotspot analysis. Second, the book scheduling and borrowing tasks are modeled as a Markov decision process. Dynamic policy optimization is implemented through deep reinforcement learning. Then, the model introduces a nonlinear constrained optimization model to characterize the resource and energy constraints of heterogeneous nodes. Furthermore, the model combines the distributed dual decomposition method with the optimization to achieve global coordination and distributed computing. Experiments were conducted on the self-developed QNU-Lib-2024 dataset, which contains <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> items, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 5 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> borrowing requests, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 5}$</tex> million environmental sensor data points. Performance comparisons with FCFS, Greedy-Capacity, ILP, and pure DRL models demonstrate the superiority of the suggested algorithm. In terms of numbers, it succeeds in completing tasks with a high rate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(97.5 \%)$</tex>, a fairness index (0.945), resource utilization <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(88.4 \%)$</tex>, energy usage (82.3 kWh), and average reaction time (6.1 seconds). Ablation experiments further validate the key role of nonlinear constrained optimization and the dual decomposition module in reducing the overall energy consumption and improving fairness.

title: Modeling Electroporation Dynamics in Liposomes and Cells Exposed to Nanosecond Pulsed Electric Fields for Optimized Drug Delivery
authors: Carmen Pisano, Laura Caramazza, Vittoria Isoldi, Giulia Risca, Alessandra Paffi, Francesca Apollonio, Micaela Liberti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Nanosecond pulsed electric fields (nsPEFs) are widely used to induce electroporation in biological membranes, enabling drug delivery applications. This work presents a multiphysics numerical study to analyze the electroporation dynamics of liposomes and a single cell exposed to nsPEFs, comparing in vitro conditions with a tissue-embedded scenario. The results highlight the influence of tissue properties on TMP evolution and membrane poration, emphasizing the need for more detailed predictive models to optimize nsPEF-based drug delivery. Developing accurate simulations enables fine-tuning of PEF parameters to maximize therapeutic efficacy while minimizing unwanted effects.

title: Sensor Network for the Assessment of Spatiotemporal Dynamics of the Environmental Exposure of Adaptive Antennas
authors: M. Zahner, D. Haas, T. Ziegler, J. Fröhlich
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Currently installed mobile communication systems at higher frequencies feature adaptive antenna using beamforming techniques. Future mobile communication technologies might include distributed MIMO modes that will lead to even more complex exposure patterns in different environments. To assess the spatiotemporal dynamics of the exposure levels of such scenarios a novel sensor network was designed and validated in different measurement scenarios. Measurements using the sensor network during daily operation and during forced download initiated by smartphones reveal the beam dynamics and electrical field strength distribution generated by the adaptive base station. This measurement setup may be used to systematically evaluate the emissions under daily usage and serves as a base station exposure assessment tool for adaptive 5G antenna configurations and future telecommunication networks.

title: Promoting Cultural Heritage: Deep Learning-Based Temple Recognition for Karnataka Tourism
authors: Vidyashri R Shet, S Thenmozhi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: The preservation of cultural heritage is crucial for fostering tourism and promoting historical significance. This paper introduces SpotSense, a deep learning-based temple recognition system that identifies temples of Karnataka from images and provides tourists with relevant details, including historical background, significance, and route suggestions. Utilizing a ResNet-50 model trained on a curated dataset, SpotSense enhances tourism experience by integrating maps for real-time navigation and offering Kannada language support. The system bridges the gap between cultural exploration and technological advancement, making temple identification more informative, accessible, and engaging. The proposed model achieved an overall accuracy of 84 %, with a precision of 87 %, recall of 89 %, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F 1$</tex>-score of 88 % on the test dataset.

title: Design and Implementation of Acoustic Gunshot Detection Using Machine Learning and Source Localization with Direction of Arrival Algorithm
authors: Madeehah Hameed, Medha Rai, Madeeha Fathima, Ashutosh Srivastava
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Gunshot detection and localization are critical technologies for enhancing public safety and security. Acoustic gunshot detection systems are becoming more feasible due to the availability of low-cost microphones, powerful microcontrollers, and ADCs in modern combat situations and dense forests. This paper aims to detect gunshots in real time using low-cost MEMS microphones. Therefore, this work presents a low-cost sound source localization system using two INMP441 MEMS microphones and a low power microcontroller module ESP32. A Machine learning model – YAMNet, having an accuracy of 83.33% is used to distinguish gunshot sounds from other sounds eliminating false positives. A Direction-Of-Arrival algorithm is implemented to localize the sound source with an angle estimation error of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm {10}^{\circ}$</tex>. Off-the-shelf MEMS microphones are adapted for ESP32 input requirements, achieving real-time localization with less processing time resulting in an edgecompatible real-time system.

title: Intelligent Resource Allocation in Wireless Sensor Networks: A Hybrid Optimization Approach for Energyconstrained Environments
authors: M Sampath Kumar, Sai Srinivas Vellela, Shobana Gorintla, Nallapu Malathi, Thalakola Syamsundara Rao, N Rupa Rani
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) have become an essential infrastructure in a broad series of applications such as environmental monitoring, healthcare, industrial automation, and smart cities. Nevertheless, the inherent weaknesses of sensor nodes, especially with regards to energy supply and processing power are a major impediment to network survival and functionality. This paper provides an intelligent resource allocation system that takes advantage of a hybrid optimization scheme to solve the energy-stressed environment in WSNs. The suggested model is a combination of heuristic algorithms with a machine learning-based prediction methodology to attain effective task scheduling, load balancing, and adaptive power management. Given that global optimization and localized decision-making are incorporated, the framework will result in the minimum energy dissipation and still ensure reliable communication and the accuracy of data. Simulation experiments show that the proposed scheme is superior to the traditional allocation techniques with regards to network lifetime, packet delivery ratio and energy consumption. The paper demonstrates the prospect of hybrid optimization in the development of the future generation of sustainable and intelligent WSN deployments.

title: Predicting the Health Condition About COVID-19 in the Rural Areas using Ensemble of Ensemble Methods
authors: A. Arshad Ahmed, D. Kerana Hanirex
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Healthcare in rural areas faces significant challenges due to limited medical infrastructure, inadequate healthcare facilities, and a shortage of skilled professionals. These limitations make early diagnosis and effective health monitoring difficult, leading to a higher risk of undetected diseases. This study aims to assist medical practitioners and health authorities in enhancing awareness of active COVID-19 conditions in rural areas, with the objective of encouraging early symptom recognition, preventive action, and timely medical intervention. The study utilizes the "COVID-19 Community Vulnerability Crosswalk Rural Profile Report based Hardest Hit Area (HHA) Dataset", which provides an evaluation of the most vulnerable communities in the country. Standard Machine Learning (ML) techniques have been commonly evaluated for healthcare analytics; however they usually take a hit on performance and accuracy in the presence of an imbalanced and varied dataset in the diagnosis of health conditions. To combat this issue, this research presents an Ensemble of Ensemble method (EoE) to improve the predictive performance due to its multi-base learner structure in a stacked set-up. The dataset contains an ample number of attributes including demographics, medical history, and lifestyle factors to allow full analysis of more widespread health conditions. The evaluation includes a systematic comparison of the proposed EoE method against existing ML methods including standard ensemble methods. The experimental results demonstrated that the EoE model has merit as it outperformed existing methods in terms of confusion matrix metrics (accuracy, sensitivity, and precision) indicating EoE could be a beneficial asset for rural healthcare analytics. Findings conclude that the proposed EoE model could be beneficial for early COVID-19 detection and awareness development, ultimately enhancing healthcare accessibility and supporting timely healthcare decision-making for underserved rural populations.

title: Analysis of a Rectangular Metallic Cavity with Meta Surface Walls
authors: R. Shavit
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: In this study, the characteristics and parameters of a conductive cavity in which two of its walls were replaced by metasurface walls with printed conductive elements were investigated. Metasurfaces are the 2D version of metamaterials and are designed as planar periodic structures with unit cell size of less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.1 \lambda$</tex>. The analysis results show the variation in the cavity modes field distribution, resonant frequencies and the quality factor in comparison to the same parameters for a conductive cavity.

title: Survey of Data-Centric Machine Learning Approaches in IoT-Enabled Self-Evolving Smart Environments
authors: K. Kamalakannan, V. Parthipan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Self-evolving smart environments that dynamically adjust to user behavior, environmental changes, and operational demands have emerged as a result of the Internet of Things (IoT) 's explosive growth. Because of the heterogeneity, volume, and temporal volatility of IoT data, traditional model-centric machine learning paradigms frequently perform poorly in these kinds of environments. In-depth research on data-centric machine learning (DCML) techniques that put context awareness, relevance, and data quality above model architectural improvement alone is presented in this work. We investigate real-time adaptive retraining, domain-specific feature engineering, and continuous data validation techniques that allow IoT systems to develop on their own. In order to provide distributed intelligence while preserving privacy and cutting down on latency, the suggested system combines edge computing, federated learning, and reinforcement learning. In comparison to traditional methods, a case study on smart campus energy management shows a 17.8 % decrease in decision latency and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 1. 3 \%}$</tex> increase in prediction accuracy. The results highlight how important lifecycle-aware data pipelines, contextual labeling, and data governance are to maintaining system adaptability.

title: Ai-Driven Automated Evaluation System for Student Performance in Mcq and Essay Assessments
authors: Shilpa Shesham, Manoranjan Dash, A Mallikarjuna Reddy, John Christu Raj Goli, Keerthana Somasani, Srikar Payyaula
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: This paper proposes an AI-powered system for automatic evaluation of student performance on Multiple Choice Questions (MCQs) and essay-type tests. The system employs Leveraging advanced Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques, such as BERT embeddings and also cosine similarity, for precise analysis of student answers. The MCQ module is premapped correct answer-based, and the essay module performs relevance, coherence, grammar, and detail assessment. The system is hosted as a web application using Flask as the backend programming language and MongoDB for database management. Experimental results show that the system obtains (20) accuracy in MCQ eval- uation and (89) accuracy in essay evaluation, which significantly decreases evaluation time compared to human grading. This work is a demonstration of the potential of AI for revolutionizing educational test evaluation systems in terms of providing efficient, unbiased evaluation methods.

title: Ultrathin Metasurface Design for Enhanced Wireless Power Transfer to Deep Tissue Implants
authors: Yibo Pan, Ladislau Matekovits, Yang Yan, Wenjie Fu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This paper introduces a destructive interference-based metasurface design that innovatively addresses multilayer tissue impedance mismatch for wireless power transfer (WPT) to implantable medical devices. Departing from conventional rigid cascaded structures or oversimplified single-layer models, our approach combines a flexible PDMS substrate with a Jerusalem cross resonator to unify air-skin-fat-muscle interface matching through phase cancellation. The key innovation lies in transforming complex multilayer into a single-layer interference problem via composite substrate equivalence, enabling near-zero reflection and near-ideal impedance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.98-0.003 \mathrm{j}$</tex>) at lossless condition. This methodology establishes a new paradigm for miniaturized, biocompatible IMD powering systems.

title: A Hybrid Vision-Driven Ensemble and Goal Programming Model for Potato Crop Yield Optimization and Disease Management
authors: Veena K, Pushpa C N
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Efficient potato crop management requires balancing yield maximization with resource constraints and disease mitigation. This paper proposes a hybrid framework that integrates machine learning, computer vision, and goal programming to support intelligent decision-making in potato cultivation. An ensemble model comprising Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and Linear Regression is employed to predict yield based on agro-environmental factors. Concurrently, a Vision Transformer (ViT) model classifies potato leaf diseases, including early blight and late blight, from image data. The predictions from both models are incorporated into a linear goal programming formulation that optimizes fertilizer and pesticide allocation under a fixed budget. Experimental results show that the proposed system can dynamically adjust input strategies based on real-time disease detection while maintaining a balance between cost and yield. This integrated decision support pipeline offers a scalable solution for precision agriculture, particularly in potato farming, where timely diagnosis and efficient use of inputs are critical.

title: Optimizing Hybrid Black Winged Kite Starfish for Economical Planning of Electric Vehicle Charging Stations in Smart Grids
authors: Natrayan L, Rumana Anjum, K. B. Venkata Brahma Rao, Vipul Vekariya, Madhu B. K, M. SivaramKrishnan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: The accelerating uptake of battery-electric vehicles (EV) imposes distinctive constraints upon integrated smart-grid architectures, chief among which is the concurrency of low capital and operational expenditure with stringent reliability for both home and publicly accessible charging infrastructures. Application of standard optimization methodologies, hindered by the problem's high-dimensional topology and severe non-linear interactions, typically produces costed solutions that prove non-viable when subjected to real-world deployment scrutiny. This paper introduces an original hybrid metaheuristic architecture that synthesises the landscape-exploration strengths of the hybrid black-winged kite (HBWK) algorithm and the iterative pruning property afforded by the starfish optimization (SFO) algorithm. The proposed hybrid system, hereafter referred to as HBWK-SFO, executes an extensive municipal-space exploration, following which an iterative pruning and refinement step is undertaken; the dual-phase architecture retains the computational expenditures within practical bounds, while accelerating convergence to a cost-optimal vicinity characterised by real-world relevance. The architecture is directed by a multi-objective cost-metric defined to aggregate, in multiplicative form, the capital outlay, ohmic loses, bulk-grid reactive-insertion penalties, and average detour experienced by users. Exhaustive validation, applying scenario-generating, smart-grid conventions, reveals that the HBWK-SFO consistently outperforms both classical heuristics and current meta-heuristic best practices, effecting a simultaneous lowering of total expenditure and improvement of operational fulfilment. The resulting empirical acceleration of convergence, operational feasibility and empirical reliability within the scheme qualifies the algorithm as a practical tool for architecting the EV charging-network at scale.

title: Procedural Generation of Communication Networks in Power Systems
authors: Xavier Weiss, Lars Nördstrom, Patrik Hilber, Emre Süren
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Power system communication networks enable operators to remotely monitor and control field equipment. The sophistication of these networks is also increasing as operators continue the trend towards digitization, which is beneficial in integrating distributed energy resources. However, as the attack surface increases in size so too does the risk of cyberattacks. The topology, configuration and composition of communication net-works is therefore confidential since this can provide information to attackers. As a result, the number of benchmarks available for research purposes is limited.A tool for procedurally generating communication network topologies is therefore proposed. While primarily intended as an enabler for public research into communication networks, this tool also allows general insights to be gained into the effect of communication network design on the vulnerability of networks to cyberattacks. The tool includes the ability to encapsulate network characteristics in JSON specification files, which is demonstrated with example Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) and Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) networks. The SCADA network generation is then compared to a real-world case. Finally, the effect of network redundancy on the networks’ cyber resilience is investigated.

title: A Physics-Informed Machine Learning Approach for Non-Intrusive Identification of Residential Photovoltaics
authors: Vihanga Peiris, Awagan Goyal Rameshrao, Jing Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The development of real-time digital twins (DTs) of local area energy systems enables the integration of more distributed energy resources (DERs) into the electric grid and facilitates their efficient management. Digitalisation requires accurate recognition of DERs, which can be achieved by training machine learning (ML) models using a comprehensive labelled dataset that reflects energy penetration from DERs. However, acquiring such a dataset is challenging due to its intrusive nature. Therefore, this research study proposes the use of physics-informed machine learning (PIML) techniques for the non-intrusive identification of residences with photovoltaic (PV) power generation in a local area, using only the aggregated smart meter data of residences and weather data corresponding to the geographical location of the residences. In this paper, a physics-informed algorithm is used to label the smart meter dataset. The study compares the PV identification results obtained by a long short-term memory (LSTM), convolutional neural network (CNN), and K-nearest neighbour (KNN) models using the proposed novel PIML methodology against those from a benchmark LSTM model. The test results show that the proposed physics informed methodology enables the LSTM model to achieve 81% performance accuracy in the context of non-intrusive PV identification.

title: Fake Image Detection Using Biomarkers with Deep Neural Network
authors: Aparana Gurjar, Lavinya Bopche, Abishek Choudhary, Khushboo Khurana
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: The increasing realism of deepfakes presents a major challenge to media authenticity verification. Traditional Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), though effective, often struggle against high-quality fake images. In this paper, we present a hybrid deepfake detection approach that combines CNN-based feature extraction with biologically inspired facial biomarkers, specifically skin tone and texture. We evaluate five deep models-ResNet152V2, Xception, VGG16, SSL-ResNet, and EfficientNetV2L-on the CIFAKE and IFAKEFACE datasets. Our results show that integrating biomarkers with deep learning significantly improves detection accuracy, especially in challenging fake scenarios. This method enhances the robustness of image integrity systems by leveraging both visual and biological cues.

title: CMC: Compound Memory-Computing Architecture for Energy-Efficient CNN Accelerators
authors: Ming Han, Jin Wu, Jian Dong, Ye Wang, Gang Qu
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Data movement contributes significantly to energy consumption in CNNs. To address this overhead, this paper presents the Compound Memory-Computing (CMC) architecture for CNN inference accelerators that integrates both computing logic and weights in look-up tables, eliminating the need to load weights from any storage sources, including external memory, on-chip memory, or on-chip cache. CMC efficiently manages weight matrix values and structures without physical weight storage. Experimental results demonstrate that CMC achieves up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.9 \times$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.5 \times$</tex> energy efficiency gains over state-of-the-art CNN accelerators, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$24 \times$</tex> compared to a typical edge GPU, significantly mitigating energy consumption challenges in CNNs.

title: A Proposed Fault-Tolerant Approach to BPMN Workflow Migration Amidst Update Failures
authors: M. Machrush Aliy Sirojjam Mushlich, Ridi Ferdiana, Ahmad Nashikun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: Business process agility requires updating BPMN models without disrupting running process instances. However, most BPMN engines, including Camunda, face significant challenges in handling such updates. Their architecture typically separates model deployment from instance execution, which can cause inconsistencies in structure, logic, and data during process changes. Existing migration tools rely on static mapping techniques that are often inadequate for handling the dynamic and complex nature of real-world process evolution. This paper proposes the Unified Workflow Strategy, a faulttolerant approach designed to enable seamless BPMN workflow migration, particularly in scenarios involving update failures. Unlike static methods such as Camunda’s Mapping Resolver, this strategy introduces dynamic instance handling based on two migration methods: Skip and Reprocess. The choice between these methods is guided by a structured Decision Matrix, which assesses the type of workflow change, whether minor or major, and the current data conditions of each instance, classified as stable or evolve. The evaluation involved six distinct workflow update scenarios. In all 6 cases, the Unified Workflow Strategy successfully executed dynamic migration, achieving $100 \%$ instance continuity. A conceptual implementation design shows how this strategy works in practice. Initial evaluations using sample migration scenarios indicate that the Unified Workflow Strategy can maintain smooth process flow and keep data consistent, even during complex updates. The results not only validate its corrective effectiveness but also highlight its potential to overcome the limitations of existing tools, offering improved system resilience, reduced downtime, and better compliance in dynamic business environments. While further validation is required, this approach provides a strong foundation for advancing reliable BPMN workflow migration techniques in modern workflow engines.

title: A New Look at Analytical Absorbing Boundary Conditions in the Fdtd Method
authors: Tomasz P. Stefański, Jacek Gulgowski, Kosmas L. Tsakmakidis
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: In this paper, we present a new approach to the derivation of analytical absorbing boundary conditions (ABCs) in electromagnetics. Usually, ABCs are applied at the boundaries of computational domain in order to eliminate spurious reflections at these boundaries which occur in numerical simulations of radiation and scattering problems. As we demonstrate, ABCs originally proposed by Engquist and Majda and later generalized by Trefethen and Halpern can alternatively be derived using the Pauli matrices algebra. For this purpose, the classical wave equation is factorized into two two-dimensional wave equations with first-order time derivatives. Afterwards, suitable approximations (where the wave incidence is assumed to be almost normal to ABC, or the field vector and the wavevector are not exactly orthogonal within ABC) result in one-way wave equations which are applicable as ABCs. In this way, we derive a general set of ABCs, already proposed by Trefethen and Halpern, which includes Engquist and Majda ABCs as special cases.

title: Timing-Driven Multi-Bit Flip-Flop Allocation Utilizing Design-Technology Co-Optimization Techniques
authors: Yeongyeong Shin, Sehyeon Chung, Taewhan Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: It has been well-known that using MBFFs (multi-bit flip-flops) offers a substantial reduction on the dynamic power consumption in digital circuits. However, their big size and limited mobility of their individual flip-flops lead to negative effects on optimizing circuit timing. This work overcomes this fundamental drawback in physical design automation. To this end, we propose two DTCO (design-technology co-optimization) techniques for optimizing timing on MBFF-intensive designs. Precisely, (1) at post-place stage, we make use of the diverse MBFF cell layout structures available with different I/O pin positions in way to remap each MBFF instance to an MBFF structure that is best suited for facilitating optimizing timing on wires, and (2) at post-route stage, we propose to use a new practically feasible scheme of MBFF cell layouts supporting mixed-VTs (threshold-voltages) on individual flip-flops, by which we are able to resolve the timing violations in a fine-grained manner at the cost of much less power overhead than that of the conventional method of VT assignment on MBFF cell instances. In the meantime, through experiments with benchmark circuits, it is shown that in comparison with the final chip implementations produced by the prior MBFF allocation methods i.e., commercial EDA method of MBFF allocation and state-of-the-art MBFF allocation method, Step 1 (i.e., DTCO at post-place) of our DTCO-driven MBFF allocation method is able to reduce the amount of total negative time slack by 11.41% and 10.82% on average, while Step 2 (i.e, our DTCO at post-route) reduces the power consumption of MBFFs by 4.63% over that of the prior methods of conventional VT assignment with no timing degradation.

title: Intelligent Analysis and Alarm Driven Platform for Power Operation Based on Multi-Source Data Fusion
authors: Zhiqi Lei, Bo Li, Mingdong He, Chuangye Zhao, Rijin Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: To address issues such as low efficiency in anomaly detection and potential oversight of critical risks in operations management, we propose the “Intelligent Analysis and Early Warning Platform for Power Operations Based on Multi-Source Data Fusion.” By integrating heterogeneous data sources such as ITSCADA systems, biometric systems, O&M systems, work permits, and bastion host O&M logs, this approach incorporates diverse data objects into a unified time-series-event knowledge graph, thereby enabling real-time monitoring and intelligent analysis throughout the entire process of power system informatization O&M operations. Furthermore, to address risk prediction modeling challenges at the algorithmic level, this paper introduces an enhanced Density Peak-Adaptive Spectral Clustering (DPC-ASC) algorithm, which, without requiring predefined cluster counts, identifies risk clusters for equipment anomalies, human errors, and environmental shifts across diverse scenarios, and these clusters are subsequently converted into interpretable early warning rules. At the same time, the platform implements single sign-on, fine-grained authorization, command-level auditing, and real-time blocking, thus establishing four tiers of security defenses for real-time monitoring of operational activities and dynamic feedback on security incidents, and consequently optimizing the early warning model. In this way, to address current challenges in enhancing the intelligent management and protection capabilities of power systems while improving operational safety and efficiency, this paper presents a novel approach to solving these problems.

title: From Knowledge to Open Innovation: The Roles of Social Media and Innovative Work Behavior in Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs)
authors: Saide Saide, Nurwahyu Alamsyah, Putri Kurnia Illahi, Shongalova Kamar
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: This study explores the interplay between social media technology, knowledge sharing, and innovative work behavior in fostering open innovation within Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs). Drawing on empirical data from 65 SMEs in Pekanbaru, Indonesia, the research employs a quantitative approach using Structural Equation Modeling via SmartPLS to analyze the relationships among five key variables. The findings reveal that social media technology significantly enhances knowledge sharing, which in turn supports open innovation. However, while knowledge sharing positively influences both idea generation and idea realization, only the latter has a direct effect on open innovation. Interestingly, idea generation alone does not lead to innovation unless mediated by idea realization. This indicates that the successful implementation of innovative ideas is critical for achieving meaningful innovation outcomes. The study contributes both theoretically and practically by identifying the mechanisms through which SMEs can leverage social media platforms and internal knowledge flows to access external ideas, create synergies, and implement innovative strategies. For practitioners, this research highlights the importance of encouraging knowledge-sharing behaviors and investing in tools that facilitate collaborative innovation. For academia, the study offers a refined understanding of innovation processes in SMEs, particularly in emerging economies.

title: 5GDHC Field Trials in Sweden: Improving Energy Efficiency Through Optimal Control
authors: Sebastian Schwarz, Hamza Gabbar, Mihaela-Daniela Bielz, Alexander Wallin, Ajdin Halilović, Daniel Stenberg, Antonello Monti
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This work proposes a blueprint concept for the optimization-based modeling and control of 5<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> Generation District Heating and Cooling (5GDHC) systems, with a focus on improving energy efficiency through an optimal control strategy. The strategy enables effective system-level energy management as well as the optimal scheduling and coordination of active balancing assets across 5GDHC systems. To demonstrate and validate the feasibility of the proposed blueprint concept, real-world field trials were conducted on a 5GDHC system in Lund, Sweden. Over a three-week summer period, the control strategy successfully optimized the thermal power setpoints of field-level devices, yielding a 14.7 % improvement in system-level energy efficiency. This improvement was achieved while successfully maintaining thermal grid balance and respecting physical asset constraints. The field trial results offer valuable insights for energy system operators seeking to optimize 5GDHC operation over slow dynamic timeframes by unlocking and leveraging the operational flexibility potential of existing 5GDHC equipment.

title: Reducing Travel Times of Tele-Operated Vehicles Through Connected Road Maps
authors: Ramon Roca, Jad Nasreddine, Daniel Camps-Mur, Paul Salvati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: Over the past decade, exchanging information between application functions and mobile networks has become essential for many services. For automotive applications like teleoperated driving, reliable connectivity and the ability to predict malfunctions are critical. This paper introduces the concept of connected road maps, which integrate network connectivity into navigation maps. This allows remote drivers to avoid areas with insufficient connectivity and select safe routes to their destination. We evaluated the concept using real operator data from an urban area, showing that it provides reliable routes faster than standard navigation tools. A simplified version of the architecture was also successfully demonstrated on a real-life test track. Index Terms—Tele-Operated Driving, 5G, Network exposure API, Network Digital Twin.

title: Prediction of Child Stunting through Machine Learning Models: Strategies for Advancing SDGs in Indonesia
authors: Mikha Dayan Sinaga, Ratna Sri Hayati, Novriza Rahayu
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Stunting remains a persistent public health challenge in Indonesia, affecting nearly one-third of children under five years of age. This condition, characterized by impaired linear growth, results from chronic undernutrition, recurrent infections, and adverse socioeconomic circumstances. Despite various interventions, the prevalence of stunting remains high, underscoring the urgent need for innovative approaches to support early detection and prevention. Machine learning provides the capability to analyze complex and large-scale datasets, offering more accurate prediction of stunting risk and enabling targeted interventions. This study compares the performance of three machine learning algorithms-Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Neural Network (MLP)-in predicting stunting. Using a dataset of more than 5,000 records, each model was trained and evaluated through standard classification metrics including accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, AUC, confusion matrix, and ROC curve analysis. The results indicate that all three models achieved strong predictive performance, with GBM demonstrating the highest discriminative ability (AUC = 0.8231), SVM achieving the highest recall (96.23%), and MLP providing a balanced performance with a competitive F1-score (90.74 %). These findings suggest that machine learning models can effectively support early detection of stunting in Indonesia, with GBM emerging as the most robust overall, SVM suitable for high-sensitivity screening, and MLP offering reliable performance across metrics. The integration of such models into public health systems has the potential to accelerate stunting reduction efforts and contribute directly to achieving Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly SDG 2 (Zero Hunger) and SDG 3 (Good Health and Well-being).

title: Digital Financial Literacy, Risk Perception, and Impulsive Behavior: Investigating Environment of Buy Now, Pay Later (BNPL) in Online Travel Platforms
authors: Muhammad Satura Tirtaatmadja, Niwa Basadirina, Iston Dwija Utama
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: The digital transformation within the financial sector has catalyzed the rapid growth of Buy Now, Pay Later (BNPL) services as a popular alternative payment method, including in the online travel industry represented by platforms such as Traveloka. The research aims to investigate the effect of Digital Financial Literacy (DFL) and Perceived Financial Risk (PFR) on BNPL (buy now pay later) Usage Intention with the mediating effect of Impulsive Buying Behavior (IBB). This study will be examined quantitatively using Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM). The study consisted of 400 respondents of BNPL users using an OTAs (online travel agency) platform. The results show that digital financial literacy provides a positive and significant effect on the intention to engage in using BNPL services, while perceived financial risk provides a negative effect. The study found that the impulsive buying behavior had a mediating effect in both digital financial literacy and perceived financial risk concerning the intention to adopt BNPL. The strongest relationship was found between impulsiveness which determined the intention of engaging in using BNPL; it also showed that emotionally considered factors were more dominant than rational considerations in financial decision making. The findings have implications for developing digital financial literacy education strategies and consumer protection policies in the digital economy.

title: Predictive Analysis of Marketing Campaign Performance and Distribution Channels on Sales of Susu Gunung Products
authors: Eugenia Diva Widodo, Syafira Isna Syalsabila, Julius Poerwanto, Teguh Prasandy
