publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: The Fast-Moving Consumer Goods (FMCG) industry in Indonesia has been rapidly growing due to changes in lifestyle, increasing digital adoption, and rising consumer purchasing power. To address these challenges, companies need to optimize their marketing strategies and distribution channels to enhance market share and product sales. The goal of this study is to analyze the performance of marketing campaigns and distribution channels for Susu Gunung products using a predictive analytics approach. This study utilizes Tableau and Databricks to analyze historical data, digital interactions, surveys, and consumer behavior, and to develop predictive models for forecasting future sales performance. The analysis results show that data-driven digital marketing and modern trade distribution channels significantly impact the increase in sales volume, particularly through e-commerce platforms and physical distribution networks. Based on these findings, it is recommended that Susu Gunung allocate more budget to digital platforms such as Instagram and TikTok, and strengthen distribution channels through e-commerce and modern trade. This research contributes to the development of Business Analytics and predictive analytics applications in the FMCG sector, particularly in improving distribution efficiency and marketing campaign effectiveness to drive more optimal product sales.

title: User-Centric Flexibility Aggregation for the Integrated European Balancing Markets
authors: Estibalitz Ruiz Irusta, Orestis Papageorgiou
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Unlocking the demand response potential of small electricity consumers is crucial to maintain adequate levels of flexibility in future power grids. However, small consumers cannot reach the minimum capacity requirement established by electricity markets and are blocked from participating. This paper proposes a user-centric aggregator that enables demand response providers to specify their minimum acceptable remuneration, promoting fair compensation, and reducing market discrimination. The aggregation process is formulated as an NP-hard optimization problem and solved using a tailored dynamic programming algorithm. The resulting flexibility blocks are submitted to the European platform for manual frequency restoration reserve using three bidding strategies, one of which makes use of the recently introduced complex bidding features. Among all evaluated strategies, we demonstrate that exclusive bidding is the most effective and robust strategy. In addition to surpassing simple and multiple bidding strategies, it also outperforms individual bidding in 77.34% of cases, yielding 110.94% increase in annual user acceptance levels. It is therefore recommended as the most effective approach for aggregators aiming to enhance fairness and market efficiency.

title: Analysis of Legal Text using Juxtaposed Pre-processing for Effective Feature Extraction
authors: Anjali V, N. Shyamala Devi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Legal text processing is a domain that holds an unexplored path, due to the various confidentialities and constraints it may involve. Nonetheless, it is one of the domineering verticals that has methodically evaded technological integration primarily to ensure ethical and security concerns of the data involved. However, while there are still considerations, the need for automated legal text mining has accelerated informed litigative decisions, thereby augmenting the accuracy of rulings, verdicts and enabled refined results in multifarious ways. This paper pivots on accentuating the prominence of pre-processing through the juxtaposed results from two techniques such as the Bag-of-Words (BoW) and Term Frequency - Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) effectuated prior and post pre-processing. Inorder to identify the accuracy of legal text mining, the assiduous steps involved in preprocessing delved in this study entail lowercasing, removal of numbers and punctuation, stopword removal, and stemming. Furthermore, it explores two key feature extraction methods: Bag of Words (BoW) and Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF). Through visualization and analysis, this study demonstrates the impact of preprocessing on feature extraction, and further accelerate the efficacy of legal text mining. The simulations for this indagation are carried out in python, and the results are successfully obtained.

title: Application of Monte Carlo Method in Uncertainty Evaluation of Platinum Resistance Thermometer Sensors
authors: Mingming Wei, Debin Zheng, XiaogangLiu, Taocheng Zhou, Rui Jin, Zongpei Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: In automatic weather stations, platinum resistance temperature sensors play a key role in temperature measurement. To guarantee the accuracy of their measurements, uncertainty analysis and evaluation of calibration results are essential. Traditional GUM (Guide to the Expression of Uncertainty in Measurement) methods have limitations, such as requiring uncertainty components to be similar in magnitude and assuming the output quantity follows a normal or t-distribution. To address these issues, this study applies Monte Carlo Methods (MCM) to evaluate the measurement uncertainty of platinum resistance temperature sensors. The process of MCM uncertainty evaluation is introduced, including single-batch MCM and adaptive MCM methods. MATLAB is used to implement MCM. Experiments are conducted on the HYA-T type platinum resistance temperature sensor from Huayun Company at calibration points of -20 ℃, 0 ℃, 20 ℃, and 50 ℃. The uncertainty of the calibration results is evaluated using the MCM method, and comparisons are made with the GUM method. The results show that the MCM method effectively overcomes the limitations of the GUM method and confirms its applicability in this context. This study provides a broader range of methods for uncertainty evaluation in meteorological metrology.

title: Assessment of EV Aggregators’ Revenue in Day-ahead and Reserve Markets in Japan
authors: Ryuichi Hanada, Shigeru Tamura
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: To achieve carbon neutrality by 2050, the installation of renewable energy is significantly increasing. Due to its intermittency and uncertainty, additional energy storage systems are essential. In this context, electric vehicles are expected to serve as energy storage systems through vehicle-to-grid operations. This study assesses the revenue of electric vehicle aggregators using scenarios based on the actual driving data of vehicle owners and stochastic programming. The proposed approach focuses on optimizing the revenue through electricity procurement from the day-ahead market and the secondary reserve market. The impact of deployment rate of reserve capacity and deployed upward/downward energy on the aggregator revenue are also evaluated. Furthermore, daily prices in the day-ahead market and the secondary reserve market are clustered using X-means clustering algorithm, and the effect of each price cluster on the aggregator revenue is analyzed.

title: UAV Image Classification: A Comparative Evaluation of CNN Models
authors: Nakkala Geetha, Gurram Sunitha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Aerial image classification plays a vital role in applications such as building footprint extraction, water/soil analysis, 3D reconstruction. Accurate classification enables timely decision-making and efficient resource allocation. Traditional methods struggle with high-resolution UAV images due to small object sizes, dense distributions, and variable orientations. Convolutional neural networks are proven effective in extracting hierarchical features and handling complex aerial image patterns. Aerial imagery presents challenges such as rotated bounding boxes, dense distributions, and small object detection. This study demonstrates that deep learning significantly enhances UAV image classification compared to traditional approaches. This research performs a comparative evaluation of five CNN models Faster R-CNN, Cascade R-CNN, Sparse R-CNN, Dynamic Dense Object Detection (DDOD), and Oriented R-CNN—on the DOTA dataset. Experiments include preprocessing, training with consistent hyperparameters, and performance evaluation. highlights that Oriented R-CNN and Sparse R-CNN are most suitable for UAV applications requiring high accuracy and precise localization. DDOD offers a good balance for dense scenes, while Cascade R-CNN and Faster R-CNN serve as benchmarks. This comparative evaluation confirms importance of selecting CNN architectures aligned with dataset characteristics and task requirements in UAV image classification. The analysis highlights model strengths, limitations, and suitability for UAV image classification, providing insights for future algorithm selection and optimization.

title: Understanding Why ChatGPT Outperforms Humans in Visualization Design Advice
authors: Yongsu Ahn, Nam Wook Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: This paper investigates why recent generative AI models outperform humans in data visualization knowledge tasks. Through systematic comparative analysis of responses to visualization questions, we find that differences exist between two ChatGPT models and human outputs over rhetorical structure, knowledge breadth, and perceptual quality. Our findings reveal that ChatGPT-4, as a more advanced model, displays a hybrid of characteristics from both humans and ChatGPT-3.5. The two models were generally favored over human responses, while their strengths in coverage and breadth, and emphasis on technical and task-oriented visualization feedback collectively shaped higher overall quality. Based on our findings, we draw implications for advancing user experiences based on the potential of LLMs and human perception over their capabilities, with relevance to broader applications of AI.

title: A Variable-Scale Diagnosis Method for Gearbox Faults in Wind Turbines
authors: Wei Zhang, Lihua Zhu, Chunrong Hua, Chao Wen, Xiaolan Guo, Lei Ke
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: During wind turbine operation, vibration signals from multi-stage gear meshing in the gearbox exhibit significant overlap, complicating fault diagnosis. Conventional methods require multiple synchronized sensors to monitor vibration and rotational speed at each gear stage, leading to prohibitive hardware costs. This paper proposes a variable-scale fault diagnosis method with the following procedure: First, the output shaft speed is obtained through STFT (Short-Time Fourier Transform) analysis of the signal, followed by angular resampling to convert the signal into the angular domain. Then, cascaded angular resampling is performed according to each stage's gear transmission ratio to adaptively switch scales, ensuring the target gear shaft's meshing frequency remains at integer orders. Finally, angular-domain averaging is applied to filter out interference signals from other gear stages. The proposed method requires only one single vibration sensor to acquire both order spectra and demodulation spectra for all gear stages, enabling comprehensive multi-stage gear fault diagnosis. User feedback confirms the diagnostic results demonstrate high accuracy.

title: Measurement of Electromagnetic Interference Current in Cables Based on BPM Method
authors: Xiansong Chen, Xiude Tu, Yuyan Xie, Yongqian Xiong
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: A redesigned stripline beam position monitor (BPM) is proposed for directional current sensing in unshielded cables. The proposed design achieves broadband impedance matching (10 kHz–100 MHz) through multi-mode analysis (sum, dipole, quadrupole modes) and structural trade-offs, including an enlarged metal sleeve inner diameter (63 mm) for cable versatility. The electrode radius was optimized to 26.6 mm via 3D electromagnetic simulation, finally achieved global impedance matching across multiple operating modes. Directionality was validated through CST simulations and experimental tests with a current-carrying single wire, showing consistent upstream/downstream signal asymmetry over 10 kHz–100 MHz. Signal processing further enabled extraction of current position and relative amplitude. This work establishes a foundation for electromagnetic interference direction detection systems using BPM arrays.

title: Managing Differentiated Secure Connectivity using Intents
authors: Loay Abdelrazek, Filippo Rebecchi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: Mobile networks in the 5G and 6G era require to rethink how to manage security due to the introduction of new services, use cases, each with its own security requirements, while simultaneously expanding the threat landscape. Although automation has emerged as a key enabler to address complexity in networks, existing approaches lack the expressiveness to define and enforce complex, goal-driven, and measurable security requirements. In this paper, we propose the concept of differentiated security levels and leveraging intents as a management framework. We discuss the requirements and enablers to extend the currently defined intent-based management frameworks to pave the path for intent-based security management in mobile networks. Our approach formalizes both functional and nonfunctional security requirements and demonstrates how these can be expressed and modeled using an extended TM Forum (TMF) intent security ontology. We further discuss the required standardization steps to achieve intent-based security management. Our work aims at advance security automation, improve adaptability, and strengthen the resilience and security posture of the next-generation mobile networks

title: AI Integration for Sustainable DevOps & Cloud Interdisciplinary: Framework Optimized Resource Management and Carbon Efficiency
authors: Harish Chamarthi, Mohanraju Muppala
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: The exponential growth of cloud computing and DevOps practices has significantly increased the carbon footprint of digital infrastructure, necessitating innovative approaches to sustainable software delivery. This paper proposes an artificial intelligence (AI)-driven framework that integrates interdisciplinary approaches from software engineering, operational efficiency, and environmental science to enhance sustainability in DevOps pipelines. Our methodology employs reinforcement learning for dynamic resource optimization, predictive analytics for carbon-aware workload scheduling, and an intelligent query fragment caching algorithm to minimize computational overhead. The framework leverages multi-objective optimization to balance performance requirements with environmental impact, incorporating real-time telemetry data from cloud resources. Experimental results demonstrate a potential 30-45% reduction in energy consumption and a 25-40% decrease in carbon emissions compared to conventional DevOps practices while maintaining service level objectives. The proposed architecture provides a scalable foundation for achieving greener software development lifecycle management without compromising operational efficiency.

title: AI Agent-Driven Framework for Data Governance and Privacy in Oracle-based Insurance Systems
authors: Sree Kiran Kanchanapally
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Insurance Data and Data Governance With consumption of data at the core, insurance industry requires strong data governance as well as policies for ensuring privacy of such data. A solution has now been found to this problem by including AI agents in Oracle based insurance systems. In this post will describe how to build a complete AI-driven framework for automation of data governance, including compliance monitoring, access control and privacy preservation within Oracle infrastructure. The framework also empowers insurers to increase data security levels, remain continuously privacy-compliant, and create verifiable audit trails using Oracle's AI capabilities. It also demonstrates the capabilities of AI agents to enhance data classification, consent setting, real-time anomaly detection in insurance data management systems with increased confidence, improved efficiency and better regulatory compliance. But once AI is integrated in insurance systems, not only the operational processes but also how Insurers are able to work and deal with sensitive information will become more trustworthy for a secure, efficient and compliant insurance system.

title: Implicit Solutions for Line Partitions in Electrical Distribution System Restoration MDP
authors: İlker Işık, Ayşenur Uzunalioğlu, Umur Deveci, Murat Göl
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Post-disaster restoration of electrical distribution systems is critical for maintaining essential services and supporting emergency response efforts. The black-start problem—restoring a power grid from total shutdown—poses significant computational challenges due to the complex dependencies and uncertainties involved. Prior work has modeled black-start as a Markov Decision Process (MDP), but these approaches suffer from scalability issues stemming from exponential state space growth. This paper presents a novel method to improve the scalability of black-start MDP formulations by leveraging implicit solutions for line partitions within the network. By identifying network segments with deterministic restoration paths, we compute expected costs without expanding the MDP state space and incorporate them during value iteration. Experimental results on real-world power systems demonstrate a substantial reduction in MDP size while preserving solution optimality, offering an effective and scalable approach to post-disaster power restoration planning.

title: Preliminary Investigation on Inverse Scattering-Based Design of Dielectric Superstrates for Beam Shaping
authors: A. Ciociola, R. Solimene
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to designing dielectric superstrates for beam shaping applications. Utilizing the Method of Moments (MoM) and inverse scattering techniques, it is possible to develop surfaces capable of manipulating the radiating properties of an antenna. The proposed design methodology enables the creation of tailored radiation patterns, enhancing the performance of antennas for several applications. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, highlighting its potential for advanced beamforming applications.

title: Time-Domain Dual Surface Electric Field Integral Equation
authors: Pierrick Cordel, Francesco P. Andriulli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: In this work, we present the first extension to the time-domain of a dual surface electric field integral equation (TD-DS-EFIE) to fix internal resonances of standard integral operators. The proposed approach linearly combines the timedomain electric field integral equation with an additional electric field boundary condition defined on a surface located inside the scatterer. The new dual surface electric field integral equation is proposed as an alternative to the time-domain combined field integral equation, known as a resonant-free formulation, to provide an solutions in highly resonant scenarios.

title: A Pragmatic Approach to Distribution System State Estimation at Low-Voltage Level
authors: Steffen Brieke, Thomas Papenkort
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The growing number of electric vehicle chargers, heat pumps, and photovoltaic systems increases the risk of congestions in the low-voltage grid. To actively prevent and resolve such critical situations, distribution system operators (DSOs) first need to determine the current grid state. However, many low-voltage grids are still unmonitored. This paper presents a simple, yet effective method for determining the optimal number and placement of meters in a distribution grid to reliably detect grid congestions. We propose to monitor only those feeders where voltage or current can exceed their limits. Those can be identified using a load flow calculation (LFC) and applying a critical load distribution based on coincidence factors. Then, meters are placed following simple rules. For the state estimation (SE) itself, the weighted least squares method is used, which is already implemented in common software. This approach is tested on rural and urban grids. For numerous load scenarios, the SE is compared to the LFC. The results show that with only a few strategically placed meters all critical grid situations are detected. Thus, this approach allows DSOs to achieve congestion detection with minimal effort and cost.

title: Sound Localization for Gun-Shot Detection Using Fourier Transform
authors: Gnane Swarnadh Satapathi, Ankita Manjayya Naik, Ashik K, Chirag Shetty, Shreecharan Bekal, Mithesh Kotian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Sound localization, vital for robotics and surveillance, often requires costly systems unsuitable for embedded applications. This study extends an Arduino-based sound direction detection system from four to eight microphones, enhancing 360° angular resolution and accuracy. Using an Arduino Mega 2560 and LM393 microphones, the system employs amplitudebased estimation with weighted interpolation and optional time difference of arrival (TDOA) via cross-correlation, visualized on an OLED display. Sampling at 8 kHz and processing 3000 Hz signals via Fast Fourier Transform, it achieved an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8.2^{\circ} \pm 2.5^{\circ}$</tex> angular error, outperforming the original <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5}^{\circ} \pm \mathbf{4}^{\circ}$</tex>, with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0 \%}$</tex> resolution for 15°-spaced sources. TDOA reduced errors to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.7^{\circ} \pm 1.8^{\circ}$</tex> but was computationally intensive. Noise (50 dB) increased errors to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2. 4}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$</tex>. The low-cost design, validated by recent studies suits educational and hobbyist use, though Arduino's processing limits TDOA feasibility.

title: Temperature Control of Thermostatic Water Bath Based on Gray Prediction and Fuzzy PID Control
authors: Jiyang Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: This study introduces a novel approach by integrating a fuzzy PID control algorithm with a gray prediction model, enhancing the main fuzzy PID controller with an auxiliary gray prediction unit for dynamic parameter adjustment. This method aims to achieve finer temperature control. The simulation outcomes reveal a notable improvement: the integrated gray predictive-fuzzy PID system exhibits an 18.58 % reduction in overshoot relative to conventional PID systems, and a modest 1.25 % improvement over standalone fuzzy PID controls. Furthermore, it shows a significant decrease in adjustment time- 104.396 seconds faster than traditional PID setups and 103.305 seconds quicker than fuzzy PID configurations alone. These findings affirm the effectiveness of the hybrid gray prediction and fuzzy PID methodology in enhancing the temperature regulation of thermostatic water baths.

title: Design and Implementation of a Miniaturized Ground System for MWD
authors: Yang Shen, Zhongli Bao, Hongxu Zhi, Qiang Yu, Shuang Liao, Feng Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: The traditional ground system for Measurement While Drilling (MWD) suffers from issues such as large size, heavy weight, and high cost, which limit their application in confined spaces and complex environments. This paper presents the design of a miniaturized drilling ground monitoring system, which consists of two main components: a ground communication hardware circuit and an upper computer software system. The hardware module includes the power circuit, CAN bus driver circuit, Ethernet driver circuit, and the MCU core circuit, which manages communication and control between the underground system and the surface. The upper computer software provides configuration, data acquisition, and storage management functions for the underground system, ensuring the accuracy and completeness of through verification and recovery techniques. Additionally, the software includes log reading and display features, offering comprehensive monitoring of the underground system's operational status. A testing platform was also developed to validate the system's performance. The test results demonstrated that the system effectively collects, transmits, and analyzes downhole data, ensuring data reliability and integrity through verification methods, thus confirming the system's feasibility for oil and gas exploration applications.

title: Embedding Atlas: Low-Friction, Interactive Embedding Visualization
authors: Donghao Ren, Fred Hohman, Halden Lin, Dominik Moritz
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: Embedding projections are popular for visualizing large datasets and models. However, people often encounter "friction" when using embedding visualization tools: (1) barriers to adoption, e.g., tedious data wrangling and loading, scalability limits, no integration of results into existing workflows, and (2) limitations in possible analyses, without integration with external tools to additionally show coordinated views of metadata. In this paper, we present Embedding Atlas, a scalable, interactive visualization tool designed to make interacting with large embeddings as easy as possible. Embedding Atlas uses modern web technologies and advanced algorithms—including density-based clustering, and automated labeling—to provide a fast and rich data analysis experience at scale. We evaluate Embedding Atlas with a competitive analysis against other popular embedding tools, showing that Embedding Atlas’s feature set specifically helps reduce friction, and report a benchmark on its real-time rendering performance with millions of points. Embedding Atlas is available as open source to support future work in embedding-based analysis.

title: Intelligent Traffic Flow Prediction Using Hybrid Deep Learning Models
authors: R. Tejaswi Kumari, M.Bhavya, J. Anki Reddy, T. Teja Gopi, R. Lalitha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Urban traffic congestion and pedestrian safety remain pressing challenges for modern cities. Traditional traffic management systems, relying on static rules or isolated machine learning models, struggle to adapt to real-time dynamic conditions. This research proposes a hybrid approach that integrates conventional machine learning, deep learning, and multi-agent reinforcement learning to optimize traffic flow, reduce waiting times, and enhance safety. We benchmark multiple models—Linear Regression, Random Forest, XGBoost, LSTM, GRU, and CNN—on traffic flow prediction, with CNN demonstrating the highest accuracy improvement over other baselines. To address real-time control, we design a multi-agent Deep Q-Network (DQN) for adaptive signal management in a synthetic traffic grid, incorporating safety events and pedestrian interactions. Novel evaluation methods such as ROC analysis for safety prediction, congestion class confusion matrices, and explainability through neighbor contribution analysis are employed. Experimental results indicate significant reductions in vehicle and pedestrian wait times, improved safety event handling, and superior predictive accuracy, highlighting the novelty of combining learning-based prediction with reinforcement learning–based control for intelligent traffic management.

title: Towards Real-ESRGAN Refinement for Realistic Image Restoration via Advanced Degradation and Knowledge Distillation
authors: LE Hoai Nam, DOAN Nhat Quang, GIANG Anh Tuan, TRAN Hoang Tung, LE Huu Ton, NGUYEN Hoang Ha
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: Deep learning has become a powerful paradigm for image quality enhancement, yet restoring images degraded by complex real-world factors such as noise, blur, and compression remains challenging. To address this, we propose a framework for realistic image restoration. Our contributions are twofold. First, we design an advanced degradation pipeline that generates diverse and realistic training data through randomized operation ordering, refined parameter ranges, and explicit camera noise simulation. Second, we introduce a lightweight Student model distilled from the original Real-ESRGAN via a Teacher-Student strategy, substantially reducing computational cost while preserving restoration quality. Experimental results demonstrate that our method produces outputs more consistent with human visual perception and generalizes effectively to real-world degradations. This framework offers a practical solution for applications such as photo enhancement, medical imaging, and surveillance analysis. Source code is available at https://github.com/namle24/RealESRGAN_Degradation_KD.git.

title: Multi-Objective Congestion Management in Low-Voltage Grids: Coordinating End-Users and System Operators for Real-World Implementation
authors: Lingkang Jin, Sen Zhan, Haoyang Zhang, Nikolaos G. Paterakis
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Electrical grids face increasing stress during peak events, leading to congestion and reliability concerns. Although user-based flexibility can mitigate these issues, coordination with Distribution System Operators (DSOs) is often limited by lack of the information exchange. This work introduces the Congestion Management Aggregator (CMA), a central entity with access to both user data and DSO forecasts, including electricity prices. Using a multi-objective optimization approach, the CMA coordinates flexible assets to minimize user costs and support the grid during congestion, based on day-ahead prices and forecast data. The strategy was tested in a real-world low-voltage grid in the Netherlands, solving the congestion up to the available potential. Results highlight the importance of minimizing forecast and hardware response errors to enhance control performance.

title: Measurements of Slot-Fed Circularly Polarized Layered Cylindrical Dra for X-Band Applications
authors: Waled Albakosh, Rawad Asfour, Muntadher Alsabah, Salam K Khamas
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: A wideband cylindrical dielectric resonator antenna is introduced for X-band applications. The wideband capability is achieved through the incorporation of a spiral-feeding slot and a dielectric coat layer, both meticulously optimized in terms of dimensions. This innovative configuration excites several higherorder modes, resulting in a broad impedance bandwidth and a wide axial ratio bandwidth. Notably, the antenna delivers an exceptionally high gain of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2. 5}$</tex> dBic. Consequently, the antenna operates efficiently over a frequency range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 - 1 4. 2 ~ G H z}$</tex>, with a close correlation between the measured and simulated results, thereby validating the design's robustness and reliability. This makes the proposed DRA an ideal candidate for various X-band applications.

title: Federated Learning for Privacy-Preserving Seizure Detection in IoT-Cloud Networks
authors: B. Bala Abirami, G. Umarani Srikanth, Swagatha J P
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Epileptic seizure monitoring necessitates streams of sensitive biological data to be tracked constantly, causing privacy risks and scaling problems in cloud-based systems. The current-federated learning methods of detecting seizures lack sufficient characteristics to enable privacy-guarded healthcare applications that need frequency-zone analysis with harmonic frequencies. FedSeize fills these gaps with a new algorithmic approach of extracting facial features in the frequency landscape using harmonic frequencies. The system makes use of deep max-out networks to detect seizures and operate data captured by IoT edge devices that are transmitted to the central hub. FedSeize completes some edge-compute processing steps, and further reduces federated learning communication costs by sending frequency-domain representations of EEGs rather than raw signals, resulting in a 30% lower communicating volume than raw signals at retaining crucial spectral features needed to identify seizures.Using CHB-MIT dataset, the extensive analysis proves that FedSeize outperforms centralized models with 8% in heterogeneous data scenario with 92 % detection accuracy. This approach combining local harmonic processing and federated learning gives a guarantee of adherence to privacy rules, and, at the same time, high familiar criteria in medical practice, establishing the balance between preserving privacy in AI and the possibility of its clinical use in distributed networks of smart healthcare.

title: Fault Localization in Power Systems Using Artificial Neural Networks
authors: Titos Avraamides, Christos Panayiotou, Markos Asprou
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) have proven to be powerful computational tools for various industrial processes, including numerous applications in power systems. This paper employs ANNs to determine the location of a single line-to-ground fault within a transmission line. Two different ANN-based approaches are proposed and examined to determine the most accurate for fault localization. To generate realistic training data for the two ANN-based approaches, fault simulations are performed using DIgSILENT software in the IEEE 9-bus system, considering various fault locations, fault resistances, and measurement noise levels. The performance of the trained ANN model is validated using synthesized data that the ANN model has never experienced considering different fault locations and fault resistances.

title: A Novel Synthetic Battery for Realistic IoT Device Lifetime Prediction
authors: Laura Marie Feeney, Claudia Martinez Alquezar, Christian Rohner
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: Conventional performance evaluation of IoT device lifetime typically considers only the battery state-of-charge and does not take into account the complex dynamics of the battery itself. Here, we present a IoT device lifetime model that more accurately reflects how batteries respond to IoT-typical loads.Our key insight is that an IoT device's power-saving sleep/wake cycle imposes intermittent pulse loads on the battery; the load duration and current depend on the operations(s) performed by the device during each awake interval. Our model therefore predicts the minimum output voltage that will be observed at the battery in response to a given pulse load. This value determines whether the battery is able to meet the input voltage requirements of the IoT device.We have developed an support vector regression (SVR)-based battery model using a dataset consisting of measurements of the voltage response of small lithium titanate (LTO) batteries to over 90K pulse loads. The model predicts the battery's minimum output voltage in response to a given pulse load with an RMAE (Root Mean Absolute Error) of less than 3% over the full operational range of the battery. The accuracy decreases at the more critical lower end of the voltage range, however, falling to ~ 8-10%RMAE.This pulse-response model allows us to create a "synthetic battery" and track its voltage response to a sequence of pulse loads, supporting a more realistic lifetime model where the IoT device fails as soon as the battery's predicted output voltage fails to meet its input voltage requirements.

title: UTEHY-NLU@ALQAC 2025: Dynamic Weighted Ensemble and Adaptive Reasoning for Vietnamese Legal Text Processing
authors: Truong-Phuc Nguyen, Quy-Nhan Nguyen, Manh-Cuong Phan, Chi-Hai Cao, Trinh-Hoai-An Duong, Minh-Tien Nguyen
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: This paper presents our approach to the ALQAC 2025 competition for Vietnamese legal text processing. For information retrieval, we propose an Advanced Dynamic Weighted Ensemble method combining three dense retrieval models with query-specific confidence calculation and dynamic weighting, followed by cross-encoder reranking. For question answering, we develop an Adaptive Few-shot Chain-of-Thought Reasoning approach using Qwen3-4B/8B models with specialized prompting and dynamic classification between extractive and abstractive QA strategies. Our results demonstrate strong performance: 5th place in Legal Information Retrieval (F2-score: 0.8482, 7.51% improvement over single models) and 4th place in Legal Question Answering (97.56% accuracy). Reasoning enhancement provides significant gains, with 5.60% improvement in Multiple Choice and 12.50% in Extractive QA tasks. Our adaptive Free-Text approach outperforms pure strategies by 2.12%, validating the effectiveness of ensemble methods and reasoning-enhanced approaches for Vietnamese legal AI systems.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization Algorithms for Energy Management Systems in Microgrids: A Control Strategy Based on a PHIL System
authors: Saiful Islam, Sanaz Mostaghim, Michael Hartmann
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: In this research a real time power hardware in loop configuration has been implemented for an microgrid with the combination of distribution energy resources such as photovoltaic, grid tied inverter, battery, utility grid, and a diesel generator. This paper introduces an unique adaptive multi-objective optimization approach that employs weighted optimization techniques for real-time microgrid systems. The aim is to effectively balance various factors including fuel consumption, load mismatch, power quality, battery degradation, and the utilization of renewable energy sources. Real-time experimental data from power hardware in loop system have been used for dynamically updating system states. The adaptive preference-based selection method are adjusted based on state of battery charging thresholds. The technique has been integrated with six technical objectives and complex constraints. This approach helps to make practical microgrid decision-making and optimization of dynamic energy systems. The energy management process were also able to maximize photovoltaic production where minimizing power mismatch, stabilizing battery state of charge under different condition. The research results were also compared with the baseline system without optimization techniques, and a reliable outcome was found.

title: Expensa: Offline Mobile App for Personal Expense Tracking
authors: Kinan Sany Luwida, Fannisa Rahmatillah Maulida, Yuda Muhamad Miftah, Jenny Ohliati, Imelda Juliana Br Sibarani
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Conventional paper-based approaches to personal cost management are prone to data loss, inefficiency, and lack adequate analytical support. This research presents Expensa, a mobile application created with the Dart and Flutter frameworks, employing SQLite for local data storage, aimed at facilitating offline spending tracking and monthly budget management. The tool allows users to monitor daily expenses, set budgetary constraints, and receive notifications when approaching a specified threshold. Expensa was developed through the stages of data collection, application development, and testing. The program was subjected to Black Box testing across eight scenarios, achieving a 100% success rate in essential areas. A user acceptance survey involving 36 participants, assessed using a 5-point Likert scale, revealed a satisfaction rate of 84%, indicating the application's considerable usefulness and relevance. Expensa presents several advantages over existing financial programs, such as comprehensive offline capabilities, prompt budget alerts, and a user-centered interface. These characteristics make it particularly advantageous for individuals in areas with limited internet access or those seeking a clear and efficient tool for financial management. This study contributes to the domain of personal finance technology by identifying gaps in mobile spending monitoring and meeting the growing demand for accessible and user-focused financial tools.

title: NN-based NMPC Control law approximation for Maximal Wind Energy Extraction in wind turbines
authors: Fei Xie, Dongran Song
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: To reduce the computational burden of online Nonlinear Model Predictive Control (NMPC) for Maximum Wind Energy Extraction (MWEE) in wind turbines, this paper proposes a neural network-based approximation method for NMPC control laws. The study investigates the principles of MPC for maximum wind energy capture, designs the prediction model's input/output parameters and structure, analyzes the impact of training data characteristics (average wind speed, turbulence intensity(TI), prediction horizon) on approximation effectiveness, and provides data-driven support for optimal model selection through comparative analysis of different network architectures. Results demonstrate that turbulence intensity and average wind speed data significantly impact model performance, while prediction horizon data exhibits minimal influence. Training with mixed turbulence level data substantially enhances model generalization capability (achieving up to 19.5% RMSE reduction), whereas mixed prediction horizon data yields limited improvement (9.6% reduction). This study proposes a neural network-based MWEE-MPC control method, providing a novel approach for real-time efficient wind turbine control under complex wind conditions.

title: Feature Selection via Synergistic Integration of Feature Correlation and Neighborhood Decision Mutual Information
authors: Wanting Wang, Eric C.C. Tsang, Weihua Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Wavelet Analysis and Pattern Recognition (ICWAPR)
abstract: The explosive growth of high-dimensional data presents significant challenges in addressing the curse of dimensionality, where feature redundancy and non-monotonic evaluation in feature selection remain critical issues. This paper proposes a novel feature selection method that integrates feature correlation and neighborhood decision mutual information. We design a dual-criterion evaluation mechanism: leveraging mutual information to measure feature relevance and constructing a non-monotonic framework based on neighborhood decision information. Guided by this theory, the UDI-MI algorithm is developed to dynamically identify discriminative features and filter redundant ones through adaptive thresholds. By integrating decision information measures with exponential decay of mutual information, the algorithm balances classification performance and feature independence. Experimental results demonstrate that the method effectively reduces computational complexity, maintains high classification accuracy, preserves the non-monotonicity of feature subsets, and performs excellently in comprehensive evaluations.

title: IoT-based Wildlife Intrusion Detection and Alert System using Sensor Fusion and AI for Agricultural Protection
authors: Shaik Rabbani Basha, G. Sushma, Syed Nafees Ahamed, P. Venkateswarlu Reddy, Venkat Rao Pasupuleti, D. Ganesh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: The electrocution of animals is so agonising that they lose their lives in the forest strip and farmlands creating immeasurable wastage of resources and threatening the lives of mankind. This makes people lose crops, cows property and even lives. This will result in this zone having to be always maintained to keep away wild animals. With regard to this problem, we have tried to establish a system that would oversee the field. In that sense, it will detect intrusions around the field first with the help of sensors, next capture the image of the intruders and classify them with the help of image processing, and the final step will involve taking corresponding measures depending on the kind of invader. Last, GSM informs the farm owner and the forest officials.

title: ISAR Algorithm for Detecting Target Scatters: An Enhanced Range-Doppler Approach with Interference Suppression
authors: Tashreeq Chellan, Lanche Linden Grootboom
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to Inverse Synthetic Aperture Radar (ISAR) imaging through the development of the Interference-Suppressed Peak Detection Enhanced Range-Doppler Algorithm (ISPD-ERDA). Critical challenges in scatterer detection and target mapping using a rotating turntable configuration is addressed, introducing advanced interference suppression techniques and enhanced peak detection methods. The algorithm demonstrates exceptional performance in multi-target scenarios and complex geometry mapping, achieving radial errors below 1 % for single targets and effective separation of multiple targets. Through comprehensive experimental validation using various target configurations including wires, cylinders, and rectangular cuboids, ISPD-ERDA's improvements over traditional RangeDoppler approaches in both accuracy and reliability has been demonstrated.

title: Thick Data Analytics in Healthcare: Integrating Qualitative Insights with Machine Learning
authors: P. Allirani, Soma. Prathibha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Thick data analytics integrates qualitative and contextual research methodologies with computational approaches to extract meaningful insights, particularly in complex domains like healthcare. Thick data emphasizes depth, narrative, and context, which makes it especially useful for patient-centric research in contrast to standard big data techniques that depend on numerical and statistical analysis of vast datasets. To better comprehend patient emotions, interactions, and concerns, this study investigates the use of thick data analytics in the healthcare industry by utilizing social media data, such as Twitter chats. The suggested system builds conversation graphs to simulate conversations and uses community recognition techniques, such as Walk trap, Louvain, and Edge Betweenness, to find connected conversation clusters Additionally, machine learning methods like Node2Vec assist in node classification and association prediction, while anomaly detection approaches assist in identifying odd sentiment patterns. Feature Isomorphism Discovery and other transfer learning strategies improve adaptability by updating models in response to the emergence of new data streams. Timeline analysis and effective visualisation are made possible by tools such as Neo4j. This system defines the proper boundaries for big data analytics through its approach to unite quantitative and qualitative data. The understanding of patient narratives receives strong support from thick data organization with graph-based analytics and machine learning. The transformation of qualitative insights into healthcare intelligence leads to enhanced decision-making through this procedure.

title: The Regularized Wiener-Hopf Method Applied to EM Scattering Problems Involving Entire Unknowns
authors: Vito Daniele, Guido Lombardi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This work presents a robust approach for addressing Wiener-Hopf equation problems involving entire unknown functions with exponential phase factors. The proposed technique deals with the factorization problem using a system of regularized integral equations. The effectiveness of the method is demonstrated through a practical electromagnetic application: the scattering of a plane wave by a thick slot that can be arbitrary filled by stratified media.

title: Investigation of Network Code Compliance for Electric Vehicle Onboard Chargers in Denmark
authors: Laiz Souto, Kristian Sevdari, Oliver Gehrke, Kai Heussen
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The increasing penetration of distributed energy resources in power grids poses significant challenges for grid operators. For a safe operation, inverter-based generators must comply with network code on requirements for generators (low voltage ride-through as well as start-up and reconnection). However, these requirements evolved at a different pace from the actual operating performance of distributed generation and storage technologies, such as solar photovoltaic inverters and electric vehicles (EVs). Thus, compliance with these requirements is not guaranteed. In this paper, the start-up and reconnection requirements of EVs are evaluated over a range of voltage and frequency disturbance scenarios. Tests have been carried out at SYSLAB, part of Technical University of Denmark (DTU) over a range of operating conditions using EVs from different manufacturers. Tested operating conditions include reconnection to the grid at different voltage and frequency set-points ranging from 360 to 440 V and 48.5 to 51.5 Hz. The results indicate that the tested components do not fully comply with the ride-through and cease-of-operation requirements, which may pose serious risks to safe power grid operation, especially as the uptake of these technologies increase.

title: Early Determination of Autism Spectrum Disorder by an Improved Multi-Layer Perceptron with Adam Optimization Process
authors: Sreenivas Reddy Sagili, Vinoth B, Ohmshankar S, Yuvaraj V, Smitha Vas P, Keerthana N V
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: One of the primary means of treatment and support for children diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) that leads to significantly improved developmental outcomes is the early detection of this condition. A multi-layered neural network model that uses the Adam optimizer is proposed in this paper to provide accurate, quick, and energy-efficient characterization of the ASD in persons using behavioral and clinical features. The system proposed initiates a phase of preprocessing that extensively involves data normalization and the management of missing entries so that the input for training is of good quality. The process of selecting features is performed using a correlation-based filtering method to achieve a higher model performance by reducing dimensionality. The main point of this work is represented by deploying a reformed Multi-Layer Perception (MLP) scheme that is in line with the adaptive learning rates given by the Adam optimizer, thus providing a great boost in speed in getting to the solution and not going into local minima. Training and testing of the developed samples, which can be sourced online, allows results to be compared and analysis to assess the detection performance of Decision Trees, SVMs, and basic MLPs without adaptive optimization to be greatly improved. Higher precision, recall, and AUC scores achieved by the introduced approach confirm it as one of the reliable tools for the early detection of autism. In addition, this approach enables not only an improvement in classification accuracy but also the robustness and generalizability of results among different populations, thus being a significant assistant in healthcare diagnostics.

title: Improving Power System Frequency Response with Converter-Based Resources: A Measurement-Based Analysis
authors: Tomislav Baškarad, Ninoslav Holjevac, Igor Kuzle
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper investigates the potential of converter-based generation, such as photovoltaic (PV) systems and battery energy storage, to enhance power system frequency response. The analysis introduces a method for quantifying the improvement in frequency nadir when converter-based resources participate in frequency control. The method is based only on real frequency measurements. Two system models are considered: a base power system without converter-based support, and the same system with integrated converter-based generation. By deriving expressions based solely on frequency and power measurements, without requiring detailed system parameters or generator transfer functions, the proposed approach offers practical applicability for real-world systems. Overall, the proposed methodology enables system operators to assess the contribution of converter-based resources in supporting frequency stability and helps in determining reserve levels for RES in low-inertia power systems.

title: Robust Predictive Control for Dual Three-Phase PMSMs via Cost Function Optimization
authors: Zhian Qu, Shuanghong Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: Parameter mismatches in dual three-phase permanent-magnet synchronous motors (DTP-PMSMs) can induce harmonic currents and torque pulsations that severely degrade system performance. To mitigate the degradation of model predictive control (MPC) under parameter mismatches, a robust MPC scheme based on cost-function design is proposed. First, the effects of distinct parameter mismatches on the system’s electrical and mechanical responses are analyzed. Subsequently, a parameter-sensitivity function is introduced to identify, during voltage selection, the voltage vector with minimal sensitivity to parameter perturbations, thereby enhancing robustness. Furthermore, a virtual-voltage-vector technique is incorporated to reduce reliance on weighting-coefficient tuning and to alleviate the computational burden. Evidence from simulations verifies the feasibility and efficacy of the proposed approach, with the adverse impact of parameter mismatches markedly suppressed.

title: Internet of Things-Enabled Cyber Threat Detection in Self-Driving Vehicle Networks Using a Hybrid Deep Learning-Based Security Model
authors: Mohammed Maray
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Information Science and Technology (ICIST)
abstract: This The rapid advancement of autonomous vehicles has revolutionized modern transportation, integrating intelligent systems that rely heavily on the Internet of Things (IoT). These vehicles are equipped with numerous IoT-enabled sensors and communication modules to ensure real-time decision-making, route planning, obstacle avoidance, and vehicle-to-everything (V2X) communication. The cybersecurity-related balance of data communication methods utilized in autonomous vehicles may increase more exposure in the data communication procedure among these vehicles and IoT devices. Securing autonomous vehicle systems (AVS) is dominant to ensure the safety and trustworthiness of autonomous transport. Cybersecurity recognition includes the execution of innovative threat detection devices to recognize and moderate potential cyber-attacks. Applying a combination of anomaly recognition, machine learning (ML) and encryption methods, these systems can able to monitor network traffic, detect strange patterns, and quickly respond to any malicious actions. The exclusive tasks modeled by autonomous vehicles like the requirement for real-world decision-making and the huge extent of data produced, need robust and adaptive cybersecurity methods. To resolve these issues, this manuscript proposes a novel Cybersecurity Detection using a Hybrid Deep Learning Approach for Self-Driving Vehicle Networks, named CDHDL-SDVN technique in IoT. The CDHDL-SDVN technique aims to recognize cyberattacks in self-driving vehicle networks using a hyperparameter-tuned ensemble deep learning (DL) model. At the initial stage, the CDHDL-SDVN technique utilizes a linear scalar normalization approach for data pre-processing. Besides, an artificial gorilla troops optimizer (GTO)-based feature selection process is performed to reduce the high dimensionality problem. Moreover, the cyberattack detection is performed by employing an ensemble of long short-term memory (LSTM), deep extreme learning machines (DELM), and gated recurrent units (GRUs) models. At last, the hyperparameter tuning of DL models is accomplished by using an artificial ecosystem-based optimization (AEO) approach. A series of tests were accomplished to test the performance of the CDHDL-SDVN technique. The experimentation validation of the CDHDL-SDVN technique attains a superior accuracy value of 98.61% over existing techniques in enhancing cybersecurity in self-driving vehicle networks.

title: Smart Assessment and Enhancement of Indoor Environmental Quality in Cultural Heritage Buildings
authors: Marina Solovyeva, Emmanouela Bikaki, Sokratis Divolis, Evangelos Spiliotis
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: Historical buildings represent the cultural identity of both communities and individuals. When these buildings remain in active use, balancing the preservation of heritage assets with the assurance of indoor environmental quality presents a significant challenge. Due to their diverse functions and characteristics, different building spaces may be subject to varying levels of protection, adhere to different standards, and permit distinct types of interventions. This paper presents a comprehensive service designed to monitor, evaluate, and improve thermal, visual, and acoustic comfort, as well as indoor air quality. The service supports energy managers in identifying areas that require attention and prescribing targeted improvements. Leveraging sensor data and a recommendation engine aligned with international standards, it facilitates in-depth assessments and promotes smart, heritage-sensitive interventions.

title: Metasurface-Based Circular Polarization Conversion for a Patch Antenna at 5.8 GHz
authors: Zahra Hamzavi-Zarghani, Behrooz Rezaee, Wolfgang Bösch, Ladislau Matekovits
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a circularly polarized antenna system operating at 5.8 GHz. The objective is achieved by designing a linearly polarized patch antenna integrated with a metasurface, which functions as a polarization converter. The considered metasurface converts part of the incident wave on it into the orthogonally polarized scattered field. The combination of the patch antenna and the metasurface resulted in circular polarization with a realized gain of 5.1 dBi. The distance between the antenna and the metasurface was optimized to provide the required phase shift for the effective realization of circular polarization.

title: Performance Testing of the Hybrid Inverter Drive in a Practical Application
authors: Reiko Raute, Cedric Caruana
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Recently, the Hybrid Inverter Drive (HID) has been developed that automatically goes into to bypass operation when the motor is operating at the grid frequency. The grid voltage synchronization algorithm facilitates a seamless switchover between inverter and direct grid-connected bypass mode without impacting the running motor operation. This technology targets to increase the energy efficiency of electric drive systems applications that require to use variable speed operation at certain times, but also operate at grid frequency for considerable durations. This paper presents the results of the HID operating in a real application. The paper shows the anticipated energy savings of the considered application and use of the HID. Additionally, it illustrates that employing the HID not only conserves electrical energy but also reduces grid current harmonic distortion, thereby enhancing grid power quality.

title: Fast and Faithful Edge Bundling for Large and Complex Networks
authors: Xingjue Jiang, Seok-Hee Hong, Amyra Meidiana, Xianyuan Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: Edge bundling reduces the visual complexity of drawings of dense graphs by clustering "compatible" edges. However, existing edge bundling methods often have high computational complexity, leading to scalability issues. This paper presents a new framework for fast edge bundling and faithfulness metrics for large and complex graphs using spectral sparsification, which sparsifies a graph G into a subgraph G′ with O(nlogn) edges, preserving the spectrum of G. We first present a general framework FEB (Fast Edge Bundling) utilizing spectral sparsification to improve the efficiency of existing bundling methods while maintaining a similar quality of bundling. We then present FBQ (Fast Bundling Quality) framework for proxy bundle faithfulness metrics, to measure how FEB faithfully preserves the ground truth structure in the original edge bundling, with two variants, FBQ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">JS</inf> (utilizing Jaccard Similarity) and FBQ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">SQ</inf> (utilizing sampling quality metrics). Extensive experiments using various real-world networks demonstrate the efficiency of the FEB framework, with 61% runtime improvement over the original edge bundling methods without sparsification, while maintaining a similar quality by FBQ quality metrics and visual comparison.

title: Investigating Active Impedance in Arrays with Varying Size using Accelerated MoM
authors: Harald Hultin, Lucas Åkerstedt, B. L. G. Jonsson
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: A new, accelerated MoM solver is presented and it is here used to investigate the convergence of active element impedance. The results show that the active impedance of the center element in a sufficiently large finite array is close to that of an element in an infinite array, as is known. The size requirement for this to hold will be investigated and compared to previously published works. The theory and methods behind the effective MoM solver will also be presented.

title: A Dynamic Priority-Aware Task Offloading and Resource Allocation Strategy Assisted by RSU-Relay in Vehicular Edge Computing
authors: Dun Cao, Yuan Su, Wenqian Wang, R. Simon Sherratt, Jin Wang
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: The rapid advancement of the Internet of Vehicular has enabled a wide range of vehicular applications, intensifying the demand for low-latency and high-efficiency computation. However, the limited onboard computing capabilities and the highly dynamic nature of vehicular networks present significant challenges for task offloading and resource allocation. To tackle these challenges, Vehicular Edge Computing (VEC) incorporates Roadside Units (RSU) not only as computing nodes but also as relay nodes capable of multi-hop task forwarding, effectively extending the offloading scope and mitigating transmission constraints in sparse or high-mobility scenarios. Moreover, due to the diversity of task demands and fluctuating resource availability, it becomes essential to dynamically adjust task priorities to ensure timely task completion and efficient resource utilization. In this paper, we propose a novel Computing Offloading and Resource Allocation strategy under Relay Collaboration (CORA-RC). CORARC exploits the dual roles of RSU as computing and relay nodes to extend the offloading range and improve flexibility, while jointly optimizing task offloading, dynamic priority adjustment, and resource allocation. Simulation results demonstrate that CORA-RC ensures the timely completion of security-related tasks while effectively reducing the average task delay, thereby achieving the lowest average weighted cost among all compared strategies.

title: Ultra-High-Speed Motor With Enhanced Cooling for Cordless Vacuum Cleaners
authors: Anton Dianov, Hyeon-Myeong Woo, Xiaodong Sun, Rui Yang, Jiawei Xiang, Yuriy Vagapov
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: Recent advancements in battery materials have significantly improved their charge-to-weight ratio providing fast progress in battery-dependent technologies and expanding the market for cordless devices in particular. Cordless vacuum cleaners have become especially popular due to enhanced convenience compared to wired models. This growing demand has boosted research activity toward further size and weight reduction. As a result, motors and impellers have been considerably scaled down to just a few centimeters in diameter, while the operating frequency of ac voltage applied to energize the motors is now increased to exceed 2 kHz. However, the reduced size and mass of the motor metal components have negatively affected cooling efficiency, making heat dissipation a major challenge in the development of compact, high-speed motors. To overcome this thermal issue, this paper proposes a novel motor design having a six-pointed star-shaped stator with toroidal windings placed at its vertices. This configuration increases the stator surface area ensuring the improvement of the heat dissipation. Moreover, the enlarged spacing between windings improves cooling conditions allowing the motor to conduct higher current through the stator windings without overheating. A working prototype of the proposed motor was developed and tested to evaluate its performance and thermal characteristics. An experiment-based comparative analysis with commercial vacuum cleaner motors showed that the prototype outperformed them in both operational and thermal parameters confirming the effectiveness of the proposed concept.

title: Effect of Environmental Temperature and Humidity on the Detection of Alcohol Denaturants using Metal-Phenolic Film-Coated Quartz Crystal Microbalances_supp2-3622641.xlsx
authors: Karekin Dikran Esmeryan
publish: N/A
abstract: The illicit alcohol trading is a serious global problem, because about 25%–C40% of all spirits distributed worldwide are adulterated, causing dozens of deaths and hundreds of hospitalizations among the adolescents and young adults. The battle against the counterfeit alcohol consumption can be won by the incorporation of a miniature metal-phenolic film-coated quartz crystal microbalance (MPF-QCM) into a wireless portable electronic device for point-of-use analysis of fermented beverages, but the impact of psychrometric conditions on the detection of denatured alcohol is still unclear. We address this lack of knowledge by analyzing the resonance response of two nominally identical 5 MHz MPF-QCMs toward alterations in the temperature and humidity, while in such conditions examining their detection efficiency to the saturated vapor of methanol, ethanol, isopropanol, or mixtures of these alcohols. The implementation of more than 180 experimental cycles reveals that the as-prepared MPF-QCMs are not substantially affected by the ambient atmosphere, and even in highly humid environments, a resolution of 3.6 mg/L methanol is reachable, which is close to the dose inflicting blindness (3.2 mg). The sensors are also capable of differentiating submilliliter and milliliter volumes of two toxic denaturants in ethanol (resolution of ~0.13/100 mL) based on changes in the volatility of the background solution, generating proportional resonance frequency upshifts with respect to the baseline and shortened reaction times. This outcome confirms the strong potential of our technology for repeatable and reliable real-world assessment of the quality of various alcoholic drinks, helping to prevent the intoxication with counterfeit alcohol.

title: Suppression of Surface Discharge in Atmospheric Air by Corrugated Barrier Structure Fabricated Using 3D Printing
authors: Daigo Komesu, Hiroshi Morita
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Surface discharge is generated along the interface of insulators under a high electric field and is a critical issue for high-voltage equipment. Surface discharge propagation can be effectively suppressed by barriers on the surface of the insulator. Such barriers are widely used in high-voltage equipment, such as outdoor insulators and bushings. In recent years, advancements in three-dimensional (3D) printing technology have enabled the fabrication of insulation resins with more complex structures. This technology allows for the creation of more effective barrier structures to suppress surface discharge. In this study, the relationship between corrugated barrier structures and surface discharge characteristics is investigated. Samples with varying barrier widths and depths were prepared using 3D printing, and the partial discharge inception voltage (PDIV) and flashover voltage (FOV) on the insulator surface are measured for each sample. For the PDIV, samples with larger barrier widths and larger barrier depths show higher values, while for the FOV, samples with smaller barrier widths show higher values. This paper presents the comparison and analysis of the differences in electric fields and discharge propagation paths caused by the barrier structure.

title: Improving Dynamic Response in Wireless Power Transfer Receiver Buck Converters via DC-Link Peak Voltage-Based Loop Control
authors: Baichuan Zhang, Shuai Dong, Xiangyu Chen, Xin Gao, Chunbo Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: In wireless power transfer (WPT) systems employing series–series or dual-sided LCC compensation, the receiver-side buck converter exhibits a current-source characteristic, resulting in a right-half-plane (RHP) zero in its power-stage small-signal model. This RHP zero imposes a fundamental tradeoff between control bandwidth and system stability, often leading to slow transient response or oscillatory behavior under conventional control schemes. To address this challenge, this article proposes a dc-link peak voltage-based loop control. Frequency-domain analysis demonstrates that the proposed method effectively decouples the dominant poles from the RHP zero, enabling the design of a higher crossover frequency to improve dynamic response. A type-III compensator is employed to shape the loop gain, achieving a 4 kHz crossover frequency with a 50<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> phase margin. Simulation and experimental results validate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy, confirming its capability to enhance dynamic performance. These findings highlight the potential of the proposed method for high-performance WPT receiver applications.

title: A Terahertz SAR Motion Compensation Method Based on Adaptive Aperture Decomposition and SFLS
authors: Jialu Liu, Jin Li, Rui Min, ShunJun Wei, Yiming Pi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Terahertz synthetic aperture radar (THz SAR) has gained widespread attention in recent years due to its advantages of high frame rate and high resolution. With the increase in carrier frequency, the motion compensation accuracy of SAR systems has become more demanding, and the difficulty of motion compensation has increased accordingly. High-precision motion compensation for THz SAR remains an urgent problem to be solved. To address this issue, this paper proposes a THz SAR motion compensation algorithm based on adaptive sub-aperture segmentation and SFLS. First, the long aperture data is adaptively segmented into sub-apertures. After coarse compensation, the SFLS algorithm is used to estimate harmonic vibrations, effectively correcting the azimuth error incoherent accumulation and severe defocusing caused by high-frequency harmonic vibrations. The proposed algorithm's effectiveness and reliability are validated through simulation data and airborne measured data

title: Generation of Seamless Seasonal NDVI Products from Multi-Source GaoFen Images
authors: Wenli Huang, Yuting Tao, Wenxia Gan, Dekun Lin, Huanfeng Shen
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Vegetation holds a crucial position in ecosystems, and the normalized differential vegetation index (NDVI) is one of the main parameters for depicting surface vegetation cover. However, the problem of radiometric differences exists in NDVI products derived from multi-scale and multi-source remote sensing images. To address this issue, a reference based framework for regional high-resolution seasonal seamless vegetation index products was constructed. The main steps include edge outlier removal, geometric alignment, RPC correction, pan-sharpening, resampling, data chunking, NDVI normalization, and result mosaicking. Partially, a region-to-region moment matching method was introduced into the referenced relative radiometric normalization framework. The framework proposed in this study effectively reduces the inter-scene radiometric differences in suburban and urban scenes. Significantly, it also demonstrates better normalization effects for images from different sensors with different features. Compared with MODIS and GaoFen-1 NDVI products, the products generated in this study show significant advantages. In conclusion, this study provides applicable situations and parameter setting suggestions for different normalization methods, as well as a local high-resolution NDVI product, which is important for refined regional vegetation research.
