title: Phase-coded FMCW Laser Headlamp for Integrated Sensing, Communication, and Illumination
authors: Shuanghe Liu, Tongzheng Sun, Xiang Shu, Jian Song, Yuhan Dong
publish: IEEE Photonics Technology Letters
abstract: In this paper, we present an integrated sensing, communication, and illumination (ISCAI) system based on a phase-coded frequency modulated continuous wave (PC-FMCW) laser headlamp. The system unifies three key functionalities of gigabit-per-second data communication, high-resolution radar sensing, and adaptive driving beam (ADB) illumination. Phase-coded communication signals are embedded into frequency modulated continuous wave (FMCW to enable communication while maintaining sensing capability. To improve target perception, we develop a track-before-detect algorithm using a multidimensional Hough Transform (MHT). By decomposing the four-dimensional (4D) detection problem into two-dimensional (2D) projections, applying AND-logic fusion to suppress clutter, and using a rolling window for trajectory reconstruction, the algorithm achieves robust detection of weak and maneuvering targets. Simulation results demonstrate a 1 Gbps data rate, centimeter-level ranging accuracy (3.8 cm), and low tracking deviation (1.6787 units), highlighting the feasibility of deploying the proposed ISCAI system for intelligent connected vehicles.

title: Quantifying the Economic Loss and Operational Implications of Air Pollution on Grid-Connected PV Systems in the Arabian Peninsula: A Machine Learning-Based Analysis
authors: Mohammed A. Bou-Rabee, Fajer M. Alelaj, Hussain Al-Sairfi
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The Arabian Peninsula is one of the regions in the world with the highest potential for solar energy development in the sense that the levels of solar irradiance are very high, making it an ideal site to install photovoltaic (PV) systems. However, this huge potential is seriously undermined by enduring environmental problems, especially the high levels of airborne particulate matter and anthropogenic pollutants that together reduce the intensity of the sun and contribute to the rapid soiling of PV modules. Though the current literature has largely concentrated on the quantification of the technical performance instability of PV systems caused by soiling phenomena, the associated extensive analysis in terms of quantifying the technical losses into quantifiable economic and operational effects on a regional level is strikingly lacking in the literature. This study builds a combined machine learning system in order to quantitatively measure the economic losses attributable to air pollution for utility-scale, grid-connected PV systems across the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) member states. We developed and strictly tested a Random Forest regression model with a remarkable coefficient of determination (R 2 ) of 98.24 that was trained on a large dataset of meteorological parameters, real-time air pollution data (PM2.52.5, PM1010, SO22, NO22, O33, CO) and the most important operational features of solar panels that occurred between 2018 and 2020. With the help of this validated predictive model, we conducted an advanced counterfactual analysis by modeling the potential power production under hypothetical conditions of clean atmosphere benchmarks. We show that air pollution is one of the contributors to the loss of 8.5% to 12.3% of annual energy production in the region; or more simply, it is a significant loss that can translate to huge financial fines, which can significantly affect the economics of projects. In addition, we propose a new data-driven predictive cleaning scheduling algorithm that proves capable of cutting operational expenditures (OPEX) by up to 25 percent relative to traditional calendar-driven cleaning schedules. The findings are empirically based, critical to renewable energy investors, utility grid operators, and policymakers, and they categorically highlight the significant economic necessity to set up wide-ranging air pollution reduction measures, even as operation and maintenance (O&M) protocols in arid, dust-prone geographical settings run to their optimum.

title: NLSDR-Net: A Lightweight Nonlocal Spatial Disparity Refinement Network for Robust and Real-Time Stereo Matching
authors: Rongxiao Wang, Shuyu Liu, Mao Tian
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Accurate and real-time disparity estimation from stereo images is crucial for many intelligent applications, such as autonomous driving, robotic navigation, and augmented reality. Although many advanced stereo matching networks have been proposed in recent years, they typically focus more on the quality of the reconstructed disparity maps and overlook the reconstruction efficiency. In this paper, to balance the accuracy and real-time performance, we propose a lightweight nonlocal spatial stereo disparity reconstruction network (NLSDR-Net), which effectively incorporates an adaptive nonlocal spatial disparity map refinement (ANLS-DMR) subnetwork and CGI-Stereo architecture to achieve robust and real-time disparity map prediction. The main contribution of the proposed NLSDR-Net is the ANLS-DMR subnetwork, which consists of a context-guided cost volume super-resolution module to generate a robust geometric spatial similarity feature, and an adaptive nonlocal spatial disparity propagation module that refines the initial disparity map by adaptive learning of the disparity residuals from the image feature, disparity prior, and geometric spatial similarity feature, to produce more accurate disparity prediction results. Five publicly available datasets, i.e., Sceneflow, KITTI stereo, Middlebury 3.0, ETH3D, and Vaihingen stereo, were adopted to assess the performance of NLSDR-Net. The comprehensive experimental results illustrate that NLSDR-Net can achieve more robust disparity map estimation results than the existing state-of-the-art real-time stereo matching architectures. Specifically, compared to the current real-time stereo matching CCAStereo architecture, NLSDR-Net can produce more accurate disparity prediction results in terms of the “D1-all” score (1.77% vs. 1.95%), while maintaining a competitive computational efficiency (14.7 fps vs. 17.5 fps) on the KITTI 2015 test set. The source code is available at https://github.com/maotianwhu/NLSDR-Net.

title: TSR: Classifying and Scheduling of IoT Tasks in Heterogeneous Cloud-Fog Computing Environment
authors: C Veena, Naramula Venkatesh, A Pramod Raj, G Swapna, K Venkateswarlu, Santhosh Kumar Medishetti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: This research introduces a novel task classification and scheduling framework for IoT applications in heterogeneous cloud–fog computing environments, leveraging the Trees Social Relations (TSR) Optimization Algorithm. The proposed TSR-based scheduler is designed to minimize makespan, reduce energy consumption, and maximize throughput, addressing the challenges of dynamic workloads and resource heterogeneity. Extensive simulations conducted in the iFogSim environment using the real-world Tesla workload demonstrate that TSR achieves superior performance compared to traditional metaheuristics such as Genetic Algorithm (GA), Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). Specifically, TSR reduces makespan by 21.6%, lowers energy consumption by 24.3%, and enhances throughput by 19.7%, thereby ensuring more efficient utilization of fog and cloud resources. These findings highlight the effectiveness of TSR in meeting the QoS requirements of IoT applications while promoting sustainable computing in fog– cloud ecosystems.

title: Evolutionary Multitasking with Second-Order Knowledge Information for Community Detection
authors: WenMing Yue, Hong Zhao, Xu-Hui Ning
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Information Science and Technology (ICIST)
abstract: With the exponential growth of social network users, community detection (CD) is a pivotal task in the analysis of complex networks, focusing on identifying tightly-knit groups of nodes. Community structures in complex networks usually have complex characteristics such as overlap, dynamics, locality, etc., which poses new challenges to traditional CD methods. Some traditional CD methods often struggle with accurately detecting communities and achieving high-quality divisions due to the intricate and diverse nature of these networks. To overcome these challenges, this paper introduces an Assisted-task based Evolutionary Multi-Task optimization method for CD (A-EMTCD) in complex networks. In A-EMTCD, the inclusion of assisted task provides supplementary information that effectively guides the objective of community detection. To facilitate seamless knowledge transfer between the primary and assisted task, we designed an efficient knowledge crossover mechanism (KCM) to enable the exchange of valuable information between different target tasks. Additionally, an innovative knowledge-based population initialization (KPI) strategy is proposed that leverages second-order neighborhood information of the target network. The KPI strategy informs the node selection during the individual encoding process, resulting in a higher quality initial population. Extensive experiments conducted on various real-world datasets demonstrate the superior effectiveness of our proposed A-EMTCD method compared to the state-of-the-art methods.

title: Migration of HV-MOS Buck Converter Design to LV-MOS Variant - Challenges in Aging EOS Verification
authors: Anurupa Ghosh, Anshu Jain
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: This work explains an attempt to reuse an HVMOS 3.5V to 1.8V Buck Converter Circuit for creating one with LV-MOS devices, for ensuring quick turnaround in Design Validation checks within same specification criteria. While the functionality was retained after device migration in Pre-layout design, Aging EOS Reliability Verification required some changes in switch network of the Buck Converter. The Paper presents this migration change starting with an Introduction, followed by description of HV-MOS Buck Converter Circuit, Aging Electrical Over Stress concept, and then goes on to describe migration steps, followed by Results and Conclusion.

title: Comparative Analysis of SVR and Random Forest Classifiers for Short-Term Buy Signal Prediction in Indian Equities
authors: Sridhar Udayakumar, E.Anbalagan E. Anbalagan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: In the ever-changing and constantly evolving Indian stock markets, identifying consistent short-term buy signals is extremely important for successful trading strategies with profit emphasis. This research compares two of the most commonly used supervised learning models, SupportVectorRegression (SVR) and RandomForestClassifier (RFC), to predict short-term bullish price movements in selected Indian stocks. Using historical daily data from 2022 to 2025 for multiple NSE-listed stocks, technical indicators such as Exponential Moving Averages (EMA10, EMA50), Relative Strength Index (RSI), and MACD components were computed as predictive features. A 5% profit target in 60 days generated actionable buy signals. After conducting experiments, the Random Forest consistently outperformed the SVR, achieving the highest individual stock accuracy of 89.3% (SDBL.NS) and a higher overall average accuracy of 81.54%, compared to the SVR's accuracy of 78.50%. These findings highlight the ensemble model's superior capability in handling noisy market data and non-linear patterns. This comparative analysis offers practical insights for traders and researchers designing robust algorithmic trading strategies in emerging markets.

title: Real-Time Road Accident Prediction in Smart Cities using a Hybrid Random Forest–LSTM Model
authors: J. Krishna, Jaya Jain, Arun Raj S.R, P. Joel Josephson, G. Pavan Kumar, P. Dileep Kumar Reddy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Traffic collisions consistently provide substantial challenges to urban safety, resulting in considerable human and economic costs. Conventional accident prediction techniques frequently fail to identify complex patterns in real-time urban traffic settings. The proposed study handles the issue by presenting a hybrid model that combines Random Forest for feature importance evaluation and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks for sequential accident forecasting. The suggested method captures essential variables including traffic volume, weather conditions, and geolocation data, which are subsequently preprocessed and sorted utilising Random Forest. The highest-ranked characteristics are subsequently converted into temporal sequences to train the LSTM, enabling the model to identify trends before accident occurrences. Experimental analysis on synthesised real-world datasets reveals substantial improvements in performance compared to conventional models. The hybrid RF–LSTM model attains 96.2% accuracy, 94.8% precision, 95.6% recall, 95.2% F1-score, and 0.981 AUC-ROC, outperforming the performance of Logistic Regression, SVM, and Vanilla LSTM baselines. The suggested study presents a scalable, high-precision framework appropriate for real-time implementation in smart city systems. The model's resilience and predictive capability can greatly aid metropolitan authorities in proactive traffic management, thus minimising the probability and severity of road accidents. These results confirm the practical feasibility and superiority of the proposed method in improving road safety.

title: A Wigner-Based Migration Technique for Target Detection and Localization
authors: Davide Santagata, Maria Antonia Maisto, Raffaele Solimene
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel imaging method for target detection and localization based on the Wigner transform. The mathematical formulation of the proposed technique is outlined and a preliminary study to evaluate the achievable performance is conducted. More in detail, the effectiveness of the proposed method is assessed through numerical simulations relative to a two-dimensional scenario and point-like objects.

title: A Stochastic Approach to Frequency Reserve Modeling Using Artificial Neural Networks
authors: Erik-Anant Stedjan Narayan, Sigurd Hofsmo Jakobsen, Kjetil Obstfelder Uhlen
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper presents a framework for formulating and training artificial neural networks (ANNs) to learn a representation of primary frequency reserves in power systems from stochastic operational data. There is growing concern regarding the frequency quality of power systems. This has led some transmission system operators to implement prequalification requirements for primary frequency reserve units that describe a series of tests aimed at mapping the characteristics of the potential reserve providing unit. However, in their current form, these tests are costly and few, if any, published alternative approaches currently exist. To address this, we present a method of determining the relevant characteristics—e.g., droop—from ordinary operational data. We train an ANN to approximate the unit behavior by matching the predicted and data-estimated moments of active power, using the unscented transform. We demonstrate the method on a standard test system and investigate its robustness. This method not only provides a potentially cheaper and less invasive identification method for primary frequency reserves, but also a more expressive, stochastic description of reserve providing units, compared to the deterministic methods currently in use.

title: Deep Learning-Based Prognostic Modeling for Alzheimer's Disease
authors: Meeradevi, Maria Rufina P, Harshitha B, Swara Sameer Pawanekar, Rohith R, Neelam Bind
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: This is an extensive project centered on classifying stages of Alzheimer's disease through the application of sophisticated artificial intelligence (AI) methods to brain MRI scans. This disease causes loss of memory deterioration in cognitive function. It is marked as progressive neurodegenerative condition. Timely identification and precise diagnosis are essential for successful intervention and treatment. The proposed model utilizes novel approach by using machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) algorithms to handle and interpret MRI images, with the goal of offering a dependable and effective diagnostic resource for healthcare practitioners. title: Collaborative Control System of Photovoltaic Station Intelligent Cleaning System Supported by Internet of Things Technology
authors: Qujie Chan, Xuanming Liu, Wei Hong, Le'an Yi, Yusong Cai, Haoming Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of low cleaning efficiency and high cost of traditional photovoltaic stations, this paper designs a photovoltaic station intelligent cleaning system collaborative control system supported by Internet of Things technology. Models such as the relationship between dirt accumulation and power generation efficiency and cleaning task scheduling optimization are constructed. The simulation environment is built through simulation software, and various simulation scenarios such as photovoltaic stations with different weather conditions and different scales are designed. Performance evaluation indicators such as cleaning efficiency and power generation efficiency improvement are set. The experimental simulation results show that compared with the traditional cleaning method, the cleaning efficiency of the system is improved by 42 %, the power generation efficiency of photovoltaic panels is improved by an average of 38 %, and the energy consumption is reduced by 27 %. In the comparative experiment under different model parameters, when the cleaning task scheduling weight coefficient is set to 0.7, the system has the best comprehensive performance. Compared with single-device operation, the collaborative operation of multiple devices shortens the cleaning task completion time by 55 %. The experimental results show that the designed collaborative control system can effectively improve the cleaning operation efficiency and power generation efficiency of photovoltaic stations, and provide a new solution for the intelligent operation and maintenance of photovoltaic stations.

title: Exploration on the Application of Artificial Intelligence in the Operation and Maintenance of Power Grid Metering Automation System
authors: Zhenglei Zhou, Jun Chen, Zhiyong Zhang, Zhi Xu, Litao Tang, Wei Wei
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: The application of artificial intelligence technology in the operation and maintenance of power grid metering automation systems has become a key research direction for the construction of smart grids. By analyzing the characteristics and requirements of metering automation system operation and maintenance, the basic architecture of metering operation and maintenance enabled by artificial intelligence has been constructed, realizing the transformation from “passive maintenance” to “active prediction”. Deep learning algorithms have shown significant effects in equipment status monitoring, data anomaly identification and fault prediction. The implementation of technologies such as intelligent inspection robots, knowledge graph decision support systems and augmented reality remote maintenance has greatly improved the efficiency and quality of metering operation and maintenance. Big data-driven asset management optimization and artificial intelligence-guaranteed power metering accuracy have significantly improved economic benefits. In the future, emerging technologies such as edge computing, cognitive computing and blockchain will promote the intelligent operation and maintenance of metering automation systems to develop in the direction of self-diagnosis, self-repair and selfoptimization.

title: Research on the Calculation Method of Transformer Discharge Fault Probability
authors: Shanru Lu, Yangchun Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: The current methods for evaluating the condition of transformers are overly subjective, and the evaluation results are discretized, making it difficult to accurately assess the equipment status. In this regard, this paper proposes a fault probability calculation method based on the stress-strength interference model to quantitatively describe the reliability level of transformers and support the risk assessment and digital and intelligent operation and maintenance of transformers. Taking the discharge fault as an example, the effectiveness of the proposed method is proved.

title: Thena: Torus Fully Homomorphic Encryption on Energy-Efficient Heterogeneous Architecture
authors: Yanze Wu, Md Tanvir Arafin
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) enables privacy-preserving computations on encrypted data with strong security guarantees. Torus-based FHE (TFHE) emerges as a promising candidate among FHE variants due to its efficient Boolean logic operation and unlimited computational depth. However, it heavily relies on bootstrapping, a computationally intensive technique. Although there has been significant progress in improving the throughput and latency of the bootstrapping process, there exists a gap in the energy efficiency research of this process without compromising its speed. Also, energy-efficient implementation of TFHE is a key requirement for its application in energy-constrained systems. This work introduces THENA, an energy-efficient bootstrapping accelerator for TFHE built on a heterogeneous Versal adaptive system on chip (ASoC) platform to address this gap. THENA partitions the bootstrapping workload into different parts of ASoC: the serial operations are handled by the processing system (PS), the compute-intensive torus multiplications are mapped to the adaptive intelligent engine (AIE), and the memory and communication operations are allocated on the programming logic (PL). THENA derives a wavefront arraybased energy-efficient multiplier, achieving a higher <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(2 \times)$</tex> improvement in throughput over a similar implementation (SaberNTT, TCAS '23). THENA uses this multiplier to deliver an end-to-end bootstrapping accelerator on the Versal VCK-190 platform. THENA delivers <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7 \times$</tex> better energy efficiency for bootstrapping than GPU-based CuFHE (RTX 3090) and outperforms existing complete FPGA designs, such as YKP (HPEC '22) by demonstrating 17.5%, and 35.6% decrease in latency and energy consumption. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first PS+PL+AIE-based heterogeneous TFHE accelerator on Versal ASoCs. THENA's code and experimental artifacts are published at https://github.com/SPIRE-GMU/tfhe-aie/.

title: Design and Implementation of a Low-Cost Foot Pressure Sensor for Lower-Limb Exoskeletons: The Case of HERMES EXO
authors: Christos Belogiannis, Ioannis Giannoulas, Christos Vrakatselis, Konstantinos Oikonomopoulos, Athanasios Zounidis, Antonios Papantoniou, Georgios Vontzos, Fotios Plessas
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: Robotic exoskeletons, which are wearable systems crafted to enhance or recover human mobility, have garnered substantial interest in diverse fields such as industry, military applications, and healthcare sectors. In this paper, we examine the feasibility and effectiveness of low-budget force sensors embedded in a sole for use in lower-limb exoskeletal systems, to enhance its motion control. Four widely available sensors were investigated in order to decide which of these sufficiently met our requirements: Velostat Sheet (VS), Force Sensitive Resistor (FSR), Piezoelectric (PE) Sensors, and the F-Scan System (FSS). The FSR enables real-time pressure detection, posture correction, and personalized movement adjustment, enhancing user - environment interaction. This work contributes to enhancing the capabilities of robotics research and prototyping, providing a methodology for easy access to high-quality custom applications with sensors.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning Models in Stock Market Forecasting: A Review
authors: Naman J. Shah, Dr. Kamal Sutaria, Brijesh Vala
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Stock Market is volatile and unpredictable from the beginning. But after the COVID-19, people understand the importance of investment in life. Due to the high returns, investors are attracted towards to the stock market. This review paper studied historical stock data as well as real-time stock data. A few years back investors used traditional methods such as Auto Regressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) and Technical Indicators. Researcher also used Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), Gated Recurrent Neural Network (GRU). These models also gave good result, but they still they raised concerns about market stability because of the overfitting problem of traditional deep learning models. Now, researcher is exploring other advance deep learning models such as Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) and Transformer pre-trained models. Researcher also exploring internal and external factors. Internal factor is political stability and External factors are political events and market sentiment.

title: Graph Neural Network-Based Modeling Study of the Molecular Mechanisms of Intestinal Metaplasia-to-Gastric Cancer Transformation Under the Action of mRNA Vaccines
authors: Zhixian Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data and Intelligent Medicine (BDIMed)
abstract: Gastric cancer is a common malignancy with a poor prognosis, and intestinal metaplasia (IM) is an important precursor to its development. Currently, there is a lack of systematic modeling and prediction methods for the molecular mechanisms of action of mRNA vaccines in the transformation of IM to gastric cancer, which limits the development of precise prevention strategies. This article constructs a molecular mechanism modeling framework based on advanced computational intelligence and graph neural network (GNN) technology. First, mRNA expression profiles, protein interaction networks, and immune-related signaling pathways are integrated in a multi-omics database to encode feature vectors of key genes. Second, a deep graph convolutional layer is used to mine topological dependencies between genes, and an attention mechanism empowered by machine learning is used to achieve weighted learning of immune regulatory signals. A time series prediction module utilizing temporal deep learning algorithms is then used to model the dynamic trajectory of intestinal metaplasia to gastric cancer transformation. Finally, the model is optimized through cross-validation driven by high-performance computing. Results showed that the model achieved an AUC (Area Under Curve) of 0.91 in target prediction tasks, with an average accuracy of 87.6%. It also identified 12 transcription factors (such as STAT3 and NF-κB) and three key signaling pathways (PI3K-AKT, Wnt, and MAPK) significantly associated with mRNA vaccine responses.

title: Preliminary Analysis of a Microwave Imaging System for Detecting Inclusions in Non-Planar Hosting Media
authors: A. Cuccaro, A. Fedeli, R. Marcelli, C. Ponti, E. Proietti, A. Randazzo, G. Schettini, R. Solimene
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Microwave Imaging (MI) for detecting inclusions and inhomogeneities within an object penetrable to electromagnetic fields is considered. The system is tailored for objects with non-flat boundary by employing a conformal antenna array arranged in a multistatic/multiview configuration. The development of a non-invasive MI system for objects with non-canonical shapes requires addressing several challenges ranging from hardware design to forward and inverse-scattering algorithms. In this work we present the preliminary steps in the design of such a system, with a particular focus on the system architecture and, more specifically, the antenna layout.

title: Optimization Strategy for Microgrid Operation Based on Unsupervised Dynamic Feature Selection Algorithm
authors: Jieying Su, Xin Zhou, Songtao Zeng, Yue Li, Chendi Li, Yazhi Tan, Dongping Hu, Zichong Zhang, Yunfei Han
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: With the wide access of distributed energy sources, microgrids are faced with the challenges of high-dimensional dynamic data and uncertain operation scenarios, and the traditional static control strategy is difficult to balance stability, economy and robustness. To address this problem, this paper proposes a fuzzy rough set-based unsupervised dynamic feature selection algorithm (UDFS), which quantifies data ambiguity by constructing a fuzzy information system, and combines with a particle swarm optimization algorithm to achieve adaptive screening of microgrid operation features. On this basis, the scenario-based control strategy is designed: the fuzzy control algorithm is utilized to dynamically adjust the control logic for typical scenarios. Simulation results show that compared with the traditional control strategy, this paper's method can reduce the maximum frequency fluctuation from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{\pm 0. 7 H z}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{\pm 0. 3 H z}$</tex> in islanding mode, and the abandonment rate from 22 % to 5 %, which verifies the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: Epilepsy Detection and Localization using EEG Signals
authors: A. Shahina, Saravanan Alagarsamy, Harini V, Harshini D, Shalini B, Gayathri K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: A persistent neurological condition known as epilepsy is typified by aberrant electrical activity in the brain, or seizures. Electroencephalogram (EEG) methods are used to record these. It takes a lot of time and is prone to inaccuracy to manually detect and localize seizure activity. The seizure EEG dataset from Temple University Hospital (TUH) is used in this investigation. We developed a Long-term Recurrent Convolutional Network (LRCN) model for seizure detection, which achieved 97.5% accuracy. Furthermore, the TUH dataset's channel-wise information is utilized to help locate epileptic areas. Metrics like the confusion matrix and precision were used to evaluate the models. The study shows how effective deep learning techniques are in identifying seizures and identifying the epileptogenic zones in EEG data.

title: TF-DiffEEG: High-Fidelity iEEG Reconstruction from Scalp EEG via Dual-Domain Diffusion
authors: Yihang Dong, Kim-Fung Tsang, Shuqiang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Product Compliance Engineering - Asia (ISPCE-ASIA)
abstract: Electroencephalography (EEG) is widely used for noninvasive brain monitoring, but its spatial resolution is low. Intracranial EEG (iEEG) provides high-fidelity signals at the expense of invasive implantation. Reconstructing iEEG from scalp EEG remains challenging due to its attenuation and nonlinear properties. We propose TF-DiffEEG, a novel diffusion model that employs a parallel Transformer encoder to jointly model temporal and spectral features, with a fusion module guiding cross-domain alignment. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance in terms of reconstruction accuracy and spectral consistency, providing an effective approach for noninvasive, high-resolution brain activity monitoring.

title: RF Effects and Coupling Simulation for Biological Systems
authors: Robert L. Gardner
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This paper explores simulation techniques for RF effects and coupling for systems in a variety of domains. The purpose is to develop means to predict system failures from electromagnetic field illumination for classes of systems and avoid resorting to the millions of source/target effects tests currently used to establish system hardness or lethality. The work primarily uses Modelica ® as an object - oriented, cyber - physical, multi domain, equation - based language as a foundation, although there are many other simulation platforms available. A wide range of radio - frequency threats are considered, including electromagnetic compatibility, electromagnetic pulse, lightning, electromagnetic interference, intentional electromagnetic interference and quasi - static fields using several field parameters and modulations. We will first develop basis functions (classes) for system simulation and use biological systems as instances for those classes. Biological time scales are more than three orders of magnitude slower than those for typical electronics systems. For example, it will be shown that pulse - repetition frequency should also be used for electromagnetic - compatibility standards in addition to the usual field/frequency skyline.

title: An Optimized Carrier-Based Modulation for Circulating Currents Reduction in Parallel-Operated Inverter Fed FESM
authors: Xudong Zhang, Qinghu Zhang, Chun Gan
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: Parallel-operated inverters (POI) can achieve superior output performance, making them suitable for driving flywheel energy storage motors (FESM). However, the inherent interleaved switching states of the POI cause high-frequency circulating currents (HFCC), which undermines current balance among POI and degrades the output quality. To address this issue, this paper proposes an optimized carrier-based modulation strategy for three-level POI, aiming to mitigate both HFCC and common-mode voltage (CMV). Firstly within the integrated five-level plane, low-CMV vector sequences are selected in each sector to suppress the slope of HFCC. Secondly, by injecting specific zero-sequence components into the reference signals and applying the carrier phase-shift strategy according to different sectors, the selected sequences can be synthesized with low computational burden. Finally, compared with several existing modulations, a series of simulations and experimental validations on a 300-kW POI fed FESM demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy.

title: PIM-SUM: Fast and Reliable In-Memory Summation for Recommendation Systems
authors: Fan Li, Ruizhi Zhu, Huize Li, Di Wu, Xin Xin
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Embedding aggregation in large-scale recommendation systems creates severe memory bandwidth bottlenecks, as each query sums many high-dimensional vectors. Bitwise-operation-based PIM can exploit subarray bandwidth, but traditional designs struggle with summation because long carry propagation limits parallelism. We propose PIM-SUM, an in-DRAM summation primitive for Sparse Length Sum (SLS) in recommendation workloads. PIM-SUM reformulates vector summation as column-wise accumulation via popcount, truncating carry propagation and avoiding redundant in-DRAM computation. This enables highthroughput summation using native DRAM bitwise primitives. PIM-SUM integrates a Reed-Solomon-inspired error correction at the DRAM row level. Its linearity supports parity propagation, enabling integrity checking and multi-bit error correction with low overhead. On DLRM workloads, PIM-SUM achieves up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.14 \times$</tex> speedup, logarithmic I/O reduction, and large energy savings. It also reduces silent data corruption by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1778 \times$</tex> and improves detection by over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$170 \times$</tex>. These results show PIM-SUM is a scalable, fault-tolerant, and energy-efficient solution for memory-bound inference at data center scale.

title: Analysis of User Experience in Virtual Reality Court for Supporting Succesful of Legal Education
authors: Yohanes Priadi Wibisono, Febriliyan Samopa, Erick Sorongan, Arif Wibisono
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: The integration of Virtual Reality (VR) technology in legal education offers immersive learning experiences, yet its efficacy depends heavily on user experience (UX). This study evaluates the UX of a VR court simulation application at Atmajaya University Yogyakarta (UAJY) using the User Experience Questionnaire (UEQ). A quantitative survey of 36 law students revealed positive ratings for attractiveness (mean=1.46) and perspicuity (mean=1.41), indicating an engaging and intuitive design. However, pragmatic qualities like efficiency (mean=0.97) and dependability (mean=0.47) scored lower, highlighting technical limitations. Hedonic qualities (stimulation: 1.41; novelty: 1.37) suggest emotional engagement but lack consistency. These findings underscore the need for optimizing performance and reliability to ensure VR's effectiveness in legal education. The study contributes to UX research in educational VR by identifying key areas for improvement, such as reducing latency and enhancing interactivity.

title: Assessing the Influence of Grid-Forming Wind Power Plants and Battery Energy Storage on Dynamic Cascading Failures in Power System
authors: Akshay Kumar, Mathaios Panteli
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The high penetration of wind power plants (WPPs) has increased uncertainty in the operations of power systems. The lack of voltage and frequency support from WPP raises significant concerns about system stability and can result in more severe cascading failure propagation following a system disturbance. A promising approach to solving this problem is the grid-forming inverters, specifically based on the virtual synchronous machine inverter (VSMI) principle, which however are still largely unexplored. Moreover, integrating the modeling of VSMI-based WPP into a dynamic cascading simulator has been largely ignored by existing studies. Hence, this article presents a dynamic cascading failure analysis under different penetration levels of VSMI-based WPP to accurately reflect the failure propagation. Furthermore, the impact of battery energy storage systems (BESSs) in case of insufficient system support from VSMI-based WPP is investigated. Contingency analyses for N-1 and N-2 scenarios, with and without BESS, are carried out on a modified IEEE 39-bus system to demonstrate the propagation of failures at various penetration levels of WPPs. Integrating BESS with VSMI-based WPPs offers an effective solution to suppress system oscillations and significantly reduce load shedding by 8% in N-1 and 9% in N-2 contingency scenarios compared to scenarios without BESS.

title: Adaptive Multimodal Biometric Authentication for Secure and Inclusive Access
authors: R. Dhivya, Navdeep K, Premnath J K, Ranjith Kumar M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Biometric authentication increasingly replaces passwords across sectors such as banking, education, and e-governance. Yet unimodal solutions (face-only or voice-only) are vulnerable to replay, presentation, and synthetic media attacks, and may exclude users with temporary or permanent impairments. This paper presents an adaptive multimodal framework that fuses facial and vocal evidence at feature level, augmented by runtime random phrase prompting, multi-cue liveness detection, and a lightweight deepfake screening step. A policy engine uses input-quality signals to adapt fusion weights and to select inclusive fallback paths when a modality is unreliable. We describe the architecture, algorithms, and a simulated evaluation using public datasets, and discuss deployment, privacy, fairness, and SDG alignment. Results indicate improved recognition with substantially greater spoof resilience relative to unimodal baselines.

title: Beam Position Measurement Algorithm Based on Robust Moving Total Least Squares Method
authors: Run An, Xiaojuan Wei, Pengcheng Zhao, Maoyuan Zhang, Yunfeng Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Beam position monitoring (BPM) is a crucial diagnostic technique used in synchrotron operation. In the context of measurement data fitting, the moving least-squares and moving total least-squares (MTLS) techniques are commonly employed. A common vulnerability to outliers exists in both methods, arising from their respective strategies used to compute local approximation coefficients. This susceptibility can result in significantly distorted estimates. To circumvent the subjective assignment of small weights or predefined thresholds while mitigating the impact of outliers and random errors across all variables, this paper introduces a robust MTLS (RMTLS) method. The proposed method utilizes an improved least trimmed squares (ILTS) technique to derive local approximations within the influence domain. Experiments demonstrate that, under periodic sinusoidal noise, RMTLS achieves positional mean values comparable to conventional TLS, but with a higher standard deviation, indicating its superior preservation of central tendency. Under uniform quantization noise, RMTLS exhibits a significantly lower standard deviation than TLS, yielding smoother fitting curvesproof of its enhanced ability to suppress discrete noise. RMTLS offers a more robust solution for high-precision beam diagnostics.

title: Detection of Model Poisson Attack in Federated Learning System Using AAE in IIoT Systems
authors: L. Natrayan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Industrial Internet of Things is a system where the data is non-IID and contains sensitive information. A centralized system requires the entire raw data for the decisionmaking process. Hence, the Federated learning system gains concentration where the raw data information is not shared in the network. It exhibits high security and data integrity characteristics; however, there is a chance that a model Poisson attack can occur in both the local and global models, leading to misclassification and falsified decisions. It is observed that the malicious models are injected randomly. The proposed work employs the Adversarial Autoencoder in the global model, which uses the discriminator network to identify anomaly patterns and updates the FedMA approach to reject those gradients. In this way, the proposed work achieved a detection rate of 92.23% with a high detection rate of 96.4%. The proposed work utilises three different datasets based on industrial settings from Kaggle to demonstrate the system's handling of diversified data.

title: Analysis of Public Sentiment Towards the 2025 Budget Efficiency Policy on Social Media X Using Naïve Bayes and Support Vector Machine
authors: Hariyanto, Annisa Ramadhani, Sunny Arief Sudiro
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: The 2025 budget efficiency policy initiated by the Indonesian government triggered various responses from the public, especially on social media X (previously Twitter). This research aims to analyze public sentiment towards the policy using two machine learning algorithms, namely Naïve Bayes Classifier (NBC) and Support Vector Machine (SVM). Data was obtained through a crawling process of Twitter posts with the keyword “government efficiency” in the period August 1, 2024 to May 13, 2025. The analysis process is carried out through the stages of text preprocessing, manual labeling, model training, and evaluation using confusion matrix. The test results show that the SVM model provides higher and stable performance in various data proportion scenarios (highest accuracy 81.03%) compared to Naïve Bayes (highest accuracy 70.26%). This finding confirms that SVM is more reliable in handling data imbalance and negative sentiment classification. This research provides a data-driven picture of public perception, which can form the basis of a more effective policy communication strategy in the future.

title: Optimization of IoT-Based Hybrid Solar-Battery Microgrids Using Modified Firefly Algorithm
authors: Chitra Kiran. N, Veeresha K B, Shubhi Jain, V. Shanmugasundaram, K. B. Venkata Brahma Rao, S. SriRagavi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Solar photovoltaic and battery-based microgrids are rapidly emerging as a primary source of electrification of remote population, although it is hampered by the variations in the sun radiation and capacity of the storage facilities. The paper will present a hybrid microgrid model based on IoT that incorporates real time monitoring in conjunction with advanced optimization model. An energy dispatch is scheduled with the help of the Modified Firefly Algorithm (MFA) that addresses the problem of load balance, battery degradation minimization, and minimize the unmet demand. The algorithm can introduce adaptive attractively and chaotic randomization to it and makes it more effective in convergence speed and search ability compared to conventional Firefly Algorithm (FA) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithms. Experimentally, the proposed framework is demonstrated to have the potential of reducing the procedure of deep battery discharge by 13.7 percent, and enhancing deep-sea solar utilization by 9.5 percent relative to the control framework based on the regulations. These conclusions validate that the optimization of MFA through IoT is a reliable, affordable, and sustainable access path of the management of the microgrids.

title: A Reinforcement Learning Simulator for Multi-UAV Based Network Coverage Problem
authors: Dorian Tonnis, Loïc Desgeorges, Isabelle Guérin Lassous, Laëtitia Matignon
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: UAV-based wireless networks can be deployed to provide a network coverage to users who have no or poor network connection. Unlike traditional model-based approaches that require predefined assumptions before UAV deployment, reinforcement learning (RL) offers a promising alternative but requires a realistic simulator for training the proposed strategies. None of the existing open-source simulators provide both realistic wireless communications while enabling the training, in a cluttered environment, of multi-UAVs movement strategies using RL. Thus, in this paper, we present a simulator where we focus on improving the modeling of the network access part, i.e., the communications between the UAVs and the users, by integrating signal propagation, physical rate adaptation and medium access sharing models. We evaluate the performance of a standard independent RL algorithm trained in our simulator across various use case scenarios, and compare the results obtained using different learning objectives. Results show that the classical formulation, commonly found in the literature and based on a a simplified wireless network model, underperforms in terms of communication quality.

title: Intelligent Robot Path Planning Performance Optimization and Control Strategy Integrating Reinforcement Learning and AlphaEvolve
authors: Shengji Gu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: In the context of intelligent robotics, this study proposes a novel framework that integrates reinforcement learning and the AlphaEvolve algorithm. This framework is specifically designed for optimizing and controlling intelligent robot path planning performance. This strategy addresses the shortcomings of traditional algorithms in terms of convergence speed and optimality in complex dynamic environments. The proposed framework consists of three core modules: Module 1: a monocular bird's-eye view (BEV) environment modeling and feature extraction module; Module 2: a dual-strategy reinforcement learning control module combining PPO and LLM-DQN; and Module 3: the AlphaEvolve global optimization module. This framework enhances environmental representation through a semantic cross-attention mechanism. Then, the AlphaEvolve's segmented encoding and prioritization strategies enable global evolutionary optimization of the policy network parameters and path node selection. This enhances the global robustness and planning quality of the path. In the experimental phase, this study constructed two typical scenarios, sparse static obstacle scenarios and dense static obstacle scenarios, and compared them with baseline algorithms, including A *, MsAACO, BAPFACO, Dueling DQN+DDQN-APF, PPO, and AlphaEvolve. The results showed that in the sparse obstacle scenario, the proposed method reduced path length by 0.095 m (approximately 0.93%, t-test p=5.828e-07) compared to AlphaEvolve, significantly reduced energy consumption (p=3.763e-06), and achieved a planning time lower than that of the pure evolutionary strategy while maintaining a near-l000/0 success rate. In the dense obstacle scenario, the proposed method reduced path length by 0.594 m (approximately 2.58%, p=1.219e-38) compared to AlphaEvolve, significantly reducing energy consumption (p=3.235e-38), while it also improves the success rate to 98.20%.

title: IGET-- A Knowledge Transformation Model Considering Generative AI
authors: Shuichiro Yamamoto
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: Advances in digital technology are changing the way knowledge is created within organizations. The emergence of intra-company SNSs has already made knowledge creation more efficient by circulating fragmented knowledge among employees. The author names the knowledge circulating on intra-company SNSs as Intermediary knowledge and models the knowledge creation process through intra-company SNSs using Intermediary knowledge. The recent emergence of generative AI has also led to the creation of new knowledge in various organizations. However, the relationship between the knowledge generated by generative AI and tacit knowledge and explicit knowledge has not been clear. In this paper, we call the knowledge generated by generative AI the generative knowledge and propose a transformation model between tacit and explicit knowledge using the intermediary knowledge model. We also clarify the effectiveness of the proposed model through case studies.

title: Transfer Learning Approach in Optimizing CNN-Based Javanese Script Classification
authors: Widya Amelia Putri, Ismi Nurul Na'imah, Dyah Aruming Tyas
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Applying a transfer learning approach has proven effective in optimizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) for Javanese script classification. With Javanese script being a significant cultural heritage facing digitization challenges, integrating advanced CNN architectures, such as VGG16, VGG19, and InceptionResNetV2, enhances classification accuracy beyond 90%. Rigorous preprocessing, hyperparameter optimization, and performance evaluation demonstrate that VGG19, with a learning rate of 1×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−4</sup>, achieves 96% accuracy on testing data, outperforming other models. These results highlight the potential of transfer learning to preserve cultural assets by enabling efficient and accurate digital solutions, contributing to the sustainability of Indonesia's cultural heritage in the technological era.

title: Evaluation of Polynomial-Based Approximate S-Box for AES under Paillier Partial Homomorphic Constraints
authors: Septafiansyah Dwi Putra, Sarwono Sutikno, A. Sumarudin, Nelmiawati, Imam Asrowardi, Antoni Haikal
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: The integration of symmetric encryption algorithms such as the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) into Partial Homomorphic Encryption (PHE) frameworks remains a challenging task, particularly due to the computational incompatibility of the AES substitution box (S-Box) with additive-only schemes like Paillier. The traditional S-Box, based on inversion in GF(2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">8</sup>) and affine transformation, requires operations that cannot be directly executed in Paillier PHE, while a lookup table (LUT) approach incurs substantial memory overhead-especially in Internet of Things (IoT) contexts with constrained resources. This study proposes and evaluates a degree-4 polynomial-based approximation of the AES S-Box, designed to be compatible with the additive homomorphic operations supported by Paillier. The proposed method aims to reduce memory requirements and computation complexity while enabling efficient non-linear substitution in the encrypted domain. Results provide insights into the trade-offs between security and efficiency for implementing AES under Paillier PHE constraints, offering a potential pathway for secure and resource-efficient cryptography in IoT environments.

title: Optimizing Image Dehazing with Balanced Loss and Feature Map Enhancement
authors: Trung-Nam Bui-Huynh, Atsuo Yoshitaka
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: Image dehazing, a low-level task in computer vision, aims to estimate haze-free images from their corresponding degraded counterparts and has demonstrated substantial performance improvements through deep neural networks. However, several limitations persist, including an insufficient loss function, underutilization of channel relationship information, and a suboptimal integration of convolution operations, all of which may decrease its performance. To address these challenges of image dehazing, we introduce a novel approach, DEA-Net-CR-LapSE, which enhances the state-of-the-art Detail-Enhanced Attention Network (DEA-Net) through several contributions. First, we integrate an additional loss, named Laplacian Pyramid Loss (LPL), into the total loss function to enhance the efficacy of Difference Convolutions (DCs) in capturing high-frequency information. Second, we adjust the channel attention within the DEA-Net to mitigate the influence of spatial attention outputs on the channel attention outputs. Third, we propose an alternative fusion strategy that combines four DCs and one Vanilla Convolution (VC) to improve the stability of feature maps. Comprehensive experiments conducted on various benchmark datasets demonstrate the superior performance of DEA-Net-CR-LapSE, surpassing the original model, through PSNR, SSIM, and LPIPS metrics.

title: Adaptive Two-Layer Inspection Framework for Mitigating Security Risks in Large-Scale Vertical Domain Language Models
authors: Wei Liang, Zhengkai Guo, Junqiang Li, Xiaocui Li, Junfeng Yang, Yangyan Zeng, Xiaokang Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Product Compliance Engineering - Asia (ISPCE-ASIA)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are trained on large amounts of data with diverse and imbalance distribution, therein leading to capability bottlenecks. In vertical domains, incremental domain-specific pre-training has become a common method to capability enhancement. However, without subsequent safety alignment, injecting domain data can perturb the base model’s distribution and increase jailbreak success rates, which may increase the risk of security vulnerabilities in LLMs. Prior work largely emphasizes domain performance gaining from fine-tuning or incremental pre-training, with limited attention to safety risks induced by distributional shifts. In this study, we address this gap by proposing an adaptive twolayer inspection framework that enforces safety checks at both the input and output token levels. On the input side, semantic embeddings and clustering-based intent tagging drive dynamic rule injection against adversarial prompts. On the output side, a speculative decoding guard performs per-token safety classification with thresholding and resampling-based fallback. Experiments on open-source LLMs demonstrate that our framework reduces Attack Success Rate (ASR) under multiple temperatures and remains effective after domain-specific post-training, mitigating Boundary Risk Exposure (BRE) fragmentation while preserving task utility.

title: Corporate Social Responsibility Activity and Reporting in Singapore Hospitality Sector
authors: Abhishek Bhati, Eunsun Ryu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) has become increasingly important in the global hospitality sector, with Singapore emerging as a unique context for understanding its implementation. This research examines CSR activity within Singapore’s hospitality industry,employing a content analysis involving a review of websites and sustainability reports on the websites from 159 member hotels of Singapore Hotel Association. The study explores the different dimensions of CSR,focusing on stakeholder influences,initiative scopes,and implementation challenges. The research reveals that only 9% of properties provide comprehensive sustainability reports,indicating a limited CSR maturity. Key CSR activities include energy conservation,water management,and environmental protection,predominantly driven by governmental regulations and international sustainability standards. Alignment with Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) demonstrates a strategic approach to CSR,with significant emphasis on economic growth,responsible consumption,and climate action. The findings highlight Singapore’s distinctive top-down governmental approach to CSR,characterized by financial incentives,regulatory support,and a tripartite stakeholder engagement model. The research contributes critical insights into CSR practices in an Asian context,identifying challenges such as inconsistent reporting,measurement difficulties,and limited comprehensive engagement. By revealing these nuances,the study provides a foundational understanding of CSR evolution in Singapore’s hospitality sector and offers recommendations for more effective reporting of sustainable business practices.

title: A Review of Lumbar Disc Herniation Classification on Deep Neural Network Approaches
authors: Jaymin Patel, Chintan Thacker, Kush Bhushanwar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Lumbar disc herniation (LDH) is a common spinal condition that negatively impacts patients' quality of life and requires accurate diagnosis and classification to be effectively treated. Deep neural network (DNN) advancements have demonstrated potential in automating LDH categorization by learning intricate features from MRI and CT scans, among other medical imaging modalities. The current level of DNN-based categorization of LDH is criticized in this paper, which also briefly discusses the models' features and architecture, performance measures used for evaluation, and limitations. In particular, the study discusses recent advancements in transformer-based frameworks, hybrid models, recurrent neural networks (RNNs), and convolutional neural networks (CNNs) used in this field to enhance the manual intervention and diagnosis quality. The research also clarifies the obstacles related to class imbalance, generalizability, and restricted annotated datasets, opening the door for future context for the development of strong, clinically useful deep learning LDH classifiers.

title: Sensor Deployment in mm-Near Field Monostatic Radar Imaging
authors: Mario Del Prete, Maria Antonia Maisto, Raffaele Solimene
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: In this paper, we address the problem of sensor arrangement in near-field radar imaging. By leveraging the warping strategy to collect the field with a non-uniform distribution of the antennas, it is possible to reduce the number of the elements compared to the conventional quarter-wavelength deployment, without any loss in resolution. Numerical examples are included to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Semantic-Aware Learning-Driven Multimodal Night Vision Image Fusion Framework
authors: Can Zhao, Shuai Jiang, Jun Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: In night vision environments, visible-light images often suffer from limited detail information, while infrared images may exhibit issues such as low contrast, resulting in blurred and indistinct target edges. This leads to a mismatch between infrared and visible-light information, and the use of a single data source fails to provide comprehensive feature coverage, making it difficult to adapt to complex and dynamic environments. To address these challenges, we propose a semantic-aware learning-driven multimodal night vision image fusion framework. Our approach begins by constructing and training a semantic segmentation network. Subsequently, a nested densely connected fusion network is built and guided by the pre-trained semantic segmentation network during its training process. This enables the fusion network to apply region-specific fusion strategies, achieving fine-grained control over the fusion process. By emphasizing the texture details and pixel intensity of target regions, the fusion results align more closely with the semantic information of different areas in the image. Compared to mainstream encoder-decoder-based fusion methods, our proposed method achieves an average improvement of no less than 3% in evaluation metrics such as Entropy (EN) and Standard Deviation (SD) on the MSRS dataset.

title: Hyperparameter Optimization Algorithm for Satellite Clock Bias Prediction Model Based on Deep Learning
authors: Yinhong Lyu, Zhijun Meng, Mingkai Liu, Enqi Yan, Suyang Liu, Xianbin Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Satellite clock bias prediction represents a pivotal technology for enhancing the accuracy of time-frequency synchronization and autonomous operation capabilities in satellites. While conventional prediction models are limited in their ability to process strongly nonlinear time series data, deep learning-based models demonstrate superior capability in capturing complex temporal patterns. However, their performance remains critically contingent upon optimal hyperparameter configurations. Addressing the computational inefficiency and suboptimal resource allocation inherent in existing hyperparameter optimization methods, this study proposes a dynamic resource allocation strategy based on the Hyperband algorithm to optimize Transformer-based satellite clock bias prediction models. The proposed methodology intelligently explores and exploits the hyperparameter space through a dual-loop mechanism (comprising outer resource allocation and inner early-stopping screening), integrating geometrically progressive resource budget allocation with successive halving strategies. Experimental results demonstrate three key findings: (1) The Hyperband algorithm achieves an 86.5% reduction in required training epochs compared to conventional grid search under equivalent computational resource constraints; (2) Validation loss decreases to 0.206 using optimized configurations; (3) Model dimensionality emerges as the dominant hyperparameter influencing prediction accuracy. This optimization framework significantly enhances hyperparameter search efficiency, providing a novel technical solution for hyperparameter tuning in high-dimensional deep learning models.

title: A Novel RT-DETR Based Framework for High-Precision PCB Defect Detection: Implementation
authors: Gengyang Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: With the advancement of industrial automation and increasing complexity of electronic devices, the PCB manufacturing industry urgently requires enhanced accuracy and efficiency in defect detection to meet stringent quality control standards. Traditional manual inspection methods suffer from inherent limitations including low efficiency, restricted accuracy, and high susceptibility to human error, failing to meet demanding requirements of modern high-volume production environments. This paper presents an innovative PCB defect detection system based on the PaddlePaddle deep learning framework, employing RT-DETR (Real-Time Detection Transformer) as its core detection algorithm with sophisticated hybrid encoder design that decouples intra-scale interaction and cross-scale fusion operations, and an IoU-aware query selection strategy that aligns classification confidence with localization accuracy. Comprehensive experimental validation on a specialized dataset containing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 3 8}$</tex> PCB samples demonstrated exceptional performance with a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 0.449, real-time processing at 17.12 FPS, detection accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$91-95 {\%}$</tex> across various defect categories, and substantially reduced false positive (2.1%) and false negative <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(3.4 \%)$</tex> rates compared to traditional methods and competing frameworks including YOLOv5 and Faster R-CNN. The system integrates modern web technologies with Vue.js frontend, Flask backend services, and MySQL database management, providing intuitive user interface supporting result visualization, historical record retrieval, and seamless integration with existing manufacturing execution systems, demonstrating high stability and excellent scalability suitable for various industrial production environments and offering an effective solution for enhancing PCB manufacturing quality control and operational efficiency.

title: Detection of Phishing Websites using Feature Selection and Image Embeddings
authors: M. Sunitha, K. Guru Raghavendra Reddy, K. Radhika, A Swathi, K Lalitha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Phishing, a cyber threat originating in 1996, has evolved into a sophisticated and pervasive attack vector that exploits deceptive emails and counterfeit websites to steal sensitive information. Despite various preventive and detection strategies, a comprehensive solution remains limited. This study explores the application of machine learning to enhance phishing detection using a dataset of both phishing and legitimate URLs. We evaluate multiple models, including Decision Tree, Linear Regression, Random Forest, Naive Bayes, Gradient Boosting, KNN, and Support Vector Classifier. Additionally, we introduce a visual comparison technique using image embeddings and cosine similarity to refine detection accuracy, particularly for borderline cases. Performance is measured using accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and cosine similarity.

title: Semantic Pathway: An Interactive Visualization of Hidden States and Token Influence in LLMs
authors: Mithilesh Kumar Singh, Klaus Mueller
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: Transformer-based language models have demonstrated remarkable capabilities across various tasks, yet their internal mechanisms—such as layered representations, distributed attention, and evolving token semantics—remain challenging to interpret. We present Semantic Pathway, an interactive visual analytics tool designed to reveal how token representations evolve across layers in autoregressive Transformer models such as GPT-2. The system integrates layerwise semantic trajectories, attention overlays, and output probability views into a unified interface, enabling users to trace how meaning accumulates and decisions emerge during generation. To reduce visual and interaction complexity, Semantic Pathway incorporates attention-based influence filtering, optional nearest-token projections, and a Compare Mode for analyzing divergence across alternate outputs. The design prioritizes interpretability and usability, supporting both fine-grained inspection and high-level exploration of sequence modeling behavior. This work contributes to ongoing efforts to make language models more interpretable, educationally accessible, and open to diagnostic insight.

title: Optimizing Virtual Power Plant Participation in Demand Response Events Using Aggregated Member Battery Capacities
authors: Ricardo Faia, Pedro Faria, João Alves, Vitor Lopes, Pedro Salomé, Zita Vale
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper presents a methodology for optimizing the participation of a virtual power plant in demand response events making use of the distributed battery storage capacities of its members. The proposed approach models a two-step framework consisting of a member’s model and a virtual power plant model. This proposed model optimizes individual energy usage, providing the baseline of import and export actions. The virtual power plant model coordinates to the collective response the demand response events while ensuring operational feasibility. A case study involving a virtual power plant with ten members, using real-world solar generation and load profiles, demonstrates the effectiveness of the approach. Results show that a coordinated centralized use of member battery storage significantly improves the ability of virtual power plant to meet demand response event requirements while maintaining individual member constraints and increasing revenue for its users.

title: Pixel-DNA: Increasing Robustness of Approximate DNA Storage for Images by Using Hierarchical Deduplication
authors: Alex Sensintaffar, David Du, Bingzhe Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: DNA is a high-density long-lasting storage medium that has the potential to keep up with the ever-increasing data storage needs. However, DNA storage is incredibly error-prone. The more nucleotides stored in the DNA strand the greater the chance of data loss. Moreover, DNA storage faces a specific phenomenon called error propagation due to its encoding from binary to nucleotide, resulting in an even higher error rate. When the majority of relevant data is stored inside the DNA strand error propagation is limited to the single strand. Reducing the overall data stored in DNA allows for more error correction and error protection. In this paper, we propose an isolation and deduplication scheme called Pixel-DNA for images. PixelDNA uses specific properties of DNA and DNA strands to implement multiple levels of deduplication while maximizing the data isolation. Also, a data segmentation scheme is applied to further increase the density of DNA storage. Based on the experimental results, Pixel-DNA allows for increased robustness and recoverability of images while increasing the density of DNA storage capacity.

title: LAURA: A Legal Agent Using Reasoning and Acting for Vietnamese Law
authors: Van-Khanh Tran, Van-Hieu Nguyen
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: Accessing legal information in Vietnam is fraught with challenges, primarily due to the sheer volume of legal documents and the complexity of legal language. While Large Language Models (LLMs) present a potential solution, they are often hindered by issues of ‘hallucination’ and outdated knowledge. To overcome these obstacles, this paper introduces LAURA (A Legal Agent Using Reasoning and Acting), a novel agent-based question-answering system tailored for Vietnamese law. LAURA operates on an agentic workflow, leveraging an LLM as its core reasoning engine. The system is built on the ReAct paradigm, which synergizes reasoning with the use of retrieval tools to process legal queries effectively. To enhance accuracy and minimize errors, a custom retrieval module was developed, combining Reciprocal Rank Fusion (RRF) with the BM25 sparse retriever and the multilingual-e5 dense retriever. Furthermore, LAURA integrates Tavily Search to access the latest legal information from external sources in real-time. This integrated approach demonstrates the significant potential of combining agentic reasoning with multi-source retrieval to create an accurate and interpretable legal question-answering system for the Vietnamese language.

title: Scope Meets Screen: Lessons Learned in Designing Composite Visualizations for Marksmanship Training Across Skill Levels
authors: Emin Zerman, Jonas Carlsson, Mårten Sjöström
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: Marksmanship practices are required in various professions, including police, military personnel, hunters, as well as sports shooters, such as Olympic shooting, biathlon, and modern pentathlon. The current form of training and coaching is mostly based on repetition, where the coach does not see through the eyes of the shooter, and analysis is limited to stance and accuracy post-session. In this study, we present a shooting visualization system and evaluate its perceived effectiveness for both novice and expert shooters. To achieve this, five composite visualizations were developed using first-person shooting video recordings enriched with overlaid metrics and graphical summaries. These views were evaluated with 10 participants (5 expert marksmen, 5 novices) through a mixed-methods study including shot-count and aiming interpretation tasks, pairwise preference comparisons, and semi-structured interviews. The results show that a dashboard-style composite view, combining raw video with a polar plot and selected graphs, was preferred in 9 of 10 cases and supported understanding across skill levels. The insights gained from this design study point to the broader value of integrating first-person video with visual analytics for coaching, and we suggest directions for applying this approach to other precision-based sports.

title: A Nonuniform Meshing Scheme for a FDTD in Spherical Coordinates
authors: Steven Perry, Clint Snider
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: A non-uniform spherical coordinate FDTD is derived with varying step sizes for the spherical coordinates, while maintaining the simplicity of the Yee update scheme. This allows reduced eccentricity at the poles, and increased resolution along areas of interest like the surface of the Earth. We simulate a simple Earth-ionosphere waveguide model and show a match with experimental values of the Schumann Resonances. We describe our future intent to apply modified absorbing boundary conditions, plasma effects at the ionosphere, anisotropic corrections at the poles, graphics processing unit (GPU) parallelization, and more.

title: Evaluation of Measurement Uncertainty for Vertical Elevation Angle of Wind Direction of Three-dimensional Positive-definite Ultrasonic Anemometer
authors: Taocheng Zhou, Mingming Wei, Debin Zheng, Jie Miao, Rui Jin, Zongpei Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: This study aims to establish a method for evaluating the measurement uncertainty of the vertical elevation angle of wind direction for three-dimensional positive-definite ultrasonic anemometers. Based on the GUM guidelines, a measurement model was constructed to quantify each source of uncertainty. Through experiments, ultrasonic flight time data at a wind speed of 10 m/s were measured, and the calculated vertical elevation angle was 0.379°. The uncertainty primarily originates from the repeatability of ultrasonic flight time measurements and equipment resolution. The combined standard uncertainty is 0.00325 radians (0.19°), and the expanded uncertainty (k = 2) is 0.19°. The study indicates that improving the stability of transducers and timing accuracy can optimize instrument performance. This evaluation method provides a pathway for instrument optimization and a basis for data reliability assessment in applications such as meteorology and wind energy, particularly requiring consideration of angle errors in wind field analysis under complex scenarios. Future research will expand to wide operating conditions to improve the applicability and accuracy of the evaluation model.

title: Early Pancreatic Cancer Detection using Hybrid Stacking Ensemble Model
authors: Bellamgubba Anoch, Gujjarlamudi Mahesh Babu, G. Jeevana Manikanta, Ramula Uttham Sai, Kavuri Divya Sumanvitha, Katumala Keerthana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Pancreatic cancer is still one of the most deadly cancers because it doesn’t show any signs of illness until it has already spread quickly. Early detection is very important for improving survival rates. This study introduces a hybrid stacking ensemble model that combines XGBoost and a Multi Layer Perceptron (MLP) as base learners, with logistic regression serving as the meta learner for the early prediction of pancreatic cancer utilizing urinary biomarkers from the PCRF TB dataset. To rectify class imbalance, the data was preprocessed using the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE), median imputation, outlier removal, one hot encoding, and feature scaling. Precision and recall values for the cancer class were above 96%, and the model’s accuracy on the test set was 98.21%, with a cross validated accuracy of 92.24%. These findings highlight how biomarker analysis and ensemble learning can be combined to produce a reliable, non invasive, and clinically applicable decision support tool for the early detection of pancreatic cancer.
