title: Traffic Light Surveillance Management using YOLOv12
authors: Modadugu Sai Yaswanth, Lanka Srinivasa Rao, Kaja Harshitha Naga Kutumbam, V. Srilakshmi, Gurrampati Ramana Reddy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: As urban traffic volumes rise, fixed timing methods for signal control frequently cause congestion at intersections and increase environmental and economic costs. This work proposes an adaptive traffic light management system that uses YOLOv12-s, a deep learning architecture, for lane-wise real-time vehicle detection and signal optimization. The detection model is trained on a substantial Roboflow 2022 dataset, which includes 18,939 detailed traffic images representing various modern urban scenarios. By combining fast video analytics, lane counting, and dynamic phase calculation, the system reduces waiting times and improves traffic flow, setting a new standard for intersection management. Experimental results show a mean average precision (mAP) of 48.0% and real-time performance that exceeds 92 FPS on a RTX 3080 GPU. The design’s modularity, speed, and measurable improvements support large-scale use in future intelligent transportation systems, though challenges such as occlusion, nighttime conditions, and multi-intersection coordination remain.

title: An Early Warning Application for Detecting Low-Frequency Oscillations in Power Systems
authors: Maurits Sørensen Molberg, Kjetil Obstfelder Uhlen, Aldrich Zeno
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Low-frequency oscillations, triggered by significant disturbances, can threaten grid stability if not damped quickly. This article presents a method and application designed to connect to phasor measurement units (PMUs) and continuously monitor data to provide early warnings for low-frequency oscillations in electric power systems. The implemented Python application — OscilloWatch — uses the Hilbert-Huang transform (HHT) to analyze PMU data in time segments, creating a Hilbert spectrum that represents frequency over time. The application combines rows in the spectrum to detect oscillating modes, estimating each mode’s damping by fitting a decaying exponential curve to its amplitude. If a mode shows low damping, the application raises an alarm to alert operators to potentially unstable oscillations. The application has been tested on real and simulated PMU data, demonstrating promising accuracy and robustness against noise. As a proof of concept, OscilloWatch lacks a user interface, but the source code has been released under an open license, with the goal of future development into a fully operational tool for grid operators.

title: The Bistability Phase Diagram for Quantum Dot Supercrystals Subject to Continuous Radiation
authors: Ian Neuhart, Carlo Piermarocchi, Christopher L. Baldwin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Quantum dot supercrystals (extended periodic arrays of few-level quantum dots) are known to exhibit optical bistability at sufficiently high densities - continuous-wave incident light has multiple distinct scattering patterns, which can be switched between using short control pulses. Past works have explored nonlinear effects such as this in the dense limit (quantum-dot separations much smaller than incident wavelength), while others have investigated collective linear effects at lower dot densities. Here we bridge these studies by mapping out the occurrence of bistability as a function of quantumdot separation and other parameters such as laser detuning, for a variety of level structures. We find that separation is by far the most important parameter in determining whether bistability (or multistability) will manifest, although detuning is also relevant, with bistability possible at larger separations for smaller detunings. We further observe that while bistability is rather insensitive to the level structure, other quantities such as reflection and transmission coefficients show a dramatic difference between different structures.

title: Towards Low-Latency and Adaptive Ransomware Detection Using Contrastive Learning
authors: Zhixin Pan, Ziyu Shu, Amberbir Alemayoh
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Ransomware has become a critical threat to cybersecurity due to its rapid evolution, the necessity for early detection, and growing diversity, posing significant challenges to traditional detection methods. While AI-based approaches had been proposed by prior works to assist ransomware detection, existing methods suffer from three major limitations, ad-hoc feature dependencies, delayed response, and limited adaptability to unseen variants. In this paper, we propose a framework that integrates self-supervised contrastive learning with neural architecture search (NAS) to address these challenges. Specifically, this paper offers three important contributions. (1) We design a contrastive learning framework that incorporates hardware performance counters (HPC) to analyze the runtime behavior of target ransomware. (2) We introduce a customized loss function that encourages early-stage detection of malicious activity, and significantly reduces the detection latency. (3) We deploy a neural architecture search (NAS) framework to automatically construct adaptive model architectures, allowing the detector to flexibly align with unseen ransomware variants.

title: Integrating Human Feedback and Unsupervised Fine-Tuning in Open-Domain Short-Answer Grading: A Scalable HITL Architecture
authors: Retno Kusumaningrum, I Made Kresna Arya Wiguna, R. Damanhuri, Sutikno Sutikno, Khadijah Khadijah, Aris Sugiharto, Adhe Setya Pramayoga
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: Learning evaluation is a systematic process for assessing student learning outcomes, now supported by digital technology for efficiency. MCQs still dominate despite their inability to measure conceptual understanding in depth. In contrast, open-ended questions, such as SAQs, are more comprehensive in assessing understanding but are less popular due to their greater time and resource requirements. Previous research on Automatic Short-Answer Grading (ASAG) has generally been limited to closed domains and specific datasets such as ASAP or SciEntBank. It has not addressed more complex open domains. However, developing an ASAG system in an open domain context faces challenges in accuracy, generalization, and efficiency, particularly in terms of data selection, semantic representation, and the limited availability of labeled data. Therefore, this study develops an ASAG architecture based on the Human-in-the-Loop (HITL) approach, which combines unsupervised fine-tuning strategies and human intervention to ensure efficient and accurate assessment in an open-domain context. The proposed architecture comprises five layers: the input layer, preprocessing layer, sampling engine layer (SEL), HITL layer, and AI grading layer. The most important layer in the proposed architecture is SEL, where the experiment results show that the initial scoring of $20 \%$ of students’ answers by the teacher as a form of human-in-the-loop is able to produce good score predictions, with SMAPE values ranging from $\mathbf{1 0 \%}$ to $\mathbf{2 0 \%}$. Adjusting the input representation to match the characteristics of students’ answers and setting the hyperparameters of the neural network architecture are necessary to enhance the performance of the score prediction model and prevent overfitting. The final results show that the SMAPE values for the employed datasets (Dataset A, B, and C) are 13.23%, $14.23 \%$, and $19.71 \%$, respectively. These results indicate that the application of the HITL mechanism in ASAG can overcome real-world implementation problems related to the need for a system that is adaptive to the assessment topic while maintaining the efficiency of the assessment process carried out by teachers.

title: An Explainable AI Framework Combining Multi-Task GCN and Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Feeding and Animal Health Management in Dairy Farming
authors: Seema S, L.Ramesh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Interweaving simulation modelling with XAI based frameworks like Multi-Task Graph Convolutional Networks (Free-Range-Learning, where Deep Reinforcement Learning shown here using Genetic Algorithms &SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) to improve decision-making to produce XAI to dairy farm management. Despite the difficulty inherent to such a large dataset of over 10,000 animal-days of multimodal sensor data input, the developed framework attained highly impressive predictive performance including a classification accuracy of 92.3% along with 90.1% precision and 90.5% recall. For the regression tasks MSE of 0.038 and R² of 0.87 were obtained. Furthermore, the DRL component, trained using Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO), was able to make a 25% improvement in feed efficiency and 12.4% decrease in cost of feeding. by/via GAs led to a 9.7 percent increase in sustainability score. SHAP-based interpretability enabled an average user trust score of 4.3/5 and interpretability score of 88.5% accuracy, demonstrating both the transparency and applicability of this framework to the real world. Collectively, these results highlight the framework’s potential for providing high-quality, low-cost, interpretable solutions suitable for adoption in precision dairy farming paradigms.

title: A RoBERTa-Centric Hybrid Approach using LSTM and BiGRU for Sentiment Analysis of Online Reviews
authors: Sumanth Mulla, Shaik Mahaboob Subhani, Nitesh Kumar, Yella Sai Krishna, Guntanala Venkata Krishna, R. Lalitha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Because of the explosive growth of e-commerce, user-generated product reviews have become a vital source of data for understanding consumer sentiment. However, because these reviews are often noisy, highly unbalanced, and unstructured, automated sentiment classification is challenging. In this study, we present a hybrid deep learning framework that blends transformer-based contextual embeddings with recurrent sequence modeling. Specifically, our architecture employs a bidirectional GRU stack to capture sequential dependencies, an LSTM layer to preserve long-term contextual information, and RoBERTa for contextualized feature extraction. To further increase robustness, we employ a preprocessing pipeline that consists of class-imbalance handling via focal loss, subword tokenization, and text normalization. The model is trained using AdamW optimization, mixed precision, and regularization techniques like dropout to improve generalization. We test our method on extensive datasets of Amazon product reviews and show consistent gains over baselines such as standalone LSTMs, fine-tuned RoBERTa, and TF-IDF with logistic regression. According to experimental results, our approach has strong generalization to complex review patterns like negation and achieves higher macro F1-scores and AUC, especially on minority sentiment classes.

title: AI-Powered Threat Detection and Response System for Next-Gen Cyber Defense
authors: Ayushi Vinod Telrandhe, Diksha Nishane, Chetan Puri, Unnati Gayaki
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: The accelerated pace of digital technology evolution has drastically increased the cyber threat space, making cybersecurity the cornerstones of contemporary infrastructure. The spread of IoT, 5G, and cloud computing has multiplied attack surfaces, making conventional defenses powerless against highly evolved threats. This has driven the evolution of smart, adaptive, and autonomous security systems, with artificial intelligence (AI) becoming a revolutionary technology. This synthesis review aggregates 15 recent AI-based studies of emerging cybersecurity issues, featuring machine learning, deep learning, adversarial learning, and swarm intelligence in intrusion detection systems, real-time fraud discovery, automated Security Operations Centers (SOCs), and dynamic firewalls. Methodology, goals, and results are compared, including quantitative measures such as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 2 - 9 8 \%}$</tex> detection accuracies. Results show AI's significant benefits in speed, accuracy, and automation but ongoing challenges such as explainability, scalability, and adversarial robustness. Future systems need to focus on ethical, resilient, and intelligent AI architectures to lock down dynamic digital environments.

title: Human Head Exposure to Bluetooth Frequency - Thermal Response
authors: H. Dodig, K. Vidjak, M. Škiljo, D. Poljak
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This paper presents the computation of the steadystate thermal response of the IEEE-recommended computational phantom due to time-harmonic electromagnetic fields at bluetooth frequencies. The computation consists of three steps: solving the inhomogeneous electromagnetic (EM) scattering problem to obtain the electric field distribution, computing the specific absorption rate (SAR), and solving Pennes' bioheat equation. The inhomogeneous EM scattering problem is addressed using a hybrid boundary element/finite element method (BEM/FEM) with edge elements-a computationally expensive approach. However, this study demonstrates that significant reduction in computational cost can be achieved by carefully crafting the computational model. Once the electric field distribution is known, it serves as a volumetric heat source in Pennes' bioheat equation, which is then solved using FEM. As expected from EM theory, the results indicate that at bluetooth frequencies, EM heating is predominantly localized at the surface of the phantom.

title: AI-Driven Security for Hierarchical Edge Computing: Combining D2D, WRR, and Queue-Based Load Distribution
authors: Deepa Bhadana, Thanjaivadivel M, R. Lakshmana Kumar, T. Kalaikumaran, Thinagaran Perumal, Rajermani Thinakaran
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: This paper proposes an AI-driven framework for Hierarchical Edge Computing (HEC) that integrates Device-to-Device (D2D) communication, Weighted Round Robin (WRR) scheduling, and queue-based load distribution to improve efficiency, scalability, and security in Internet of Things (IoT) environments. The objective is to minimize latency, balance workloads, and enhance secure task allocation across hierarchical edge layers. The methodology combines AI-based anomaly detection for security, WRR for fair resource allocation, and queue-based scheduling for dynamic load balancing. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that the proposed framework achieves 95% accuracy, 94% recall, and 20 ms latency, outperforming existing CoAP, SDN, and hybrid mesh networking models. The findings indicate that the integration of AI with D2D and WRR significantly improves real-time processing, throughput, and resource utilization, ensuring a scalable and secure IoT infrastructure.

title: Addressing the Radio Frequency Interference Problem Through Characteristic Mode Analysis
authors: Xu Wang, Xiaoping Li, Xinglin Sun, Tingting Liu, Shiming Qin
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Advanced Interconnects (WAI)
abstract: Noise generated by digital circuits leads to radio frequency interference problems. The physics-based dipole moment model and the transfer function method are commonly used for interference analysis and mitigation. Herein, the characteristic mode is used to derive the short-circuit noise current on the antenna port in the transfer function calculation. Through use of the simplified modal weighting coefficient formulation for dipole moment excitation, the interaction between the noise source and the characteristic modes can be quantified according to the modal analysis results. Decomposing the induced short-circuit current on the antenna port into the contributions of different modes enables identification of the critical mode in the interference. Mitigation strategies are then proposed on the basis of the modal near-field information.

title: Next-Generation Women's Security using IoT and Geofencing
authors: Mohanaprakash T A, V C Ranganayaki, Cinthuja K, S. Irin Sherly, Nalini Subramanian, S. Hemamalini
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: The ESP32 microcontroller serves as the central processing unit, acquiring motion data from the MPU6050 gyroscope to detect abnormal movements indicative of falls or physical altercations. Simultaneously, a GPS module provides continuous geolocation updates, which are transmitted to the Blynk Cloud via Wi-Fi, enabling remote monitoring. In emergency scenarios—such as a detected fall or manual activation of an emergency button—the system promptly transmits an alert containing the user’s real-time location to pre-registered emergency contacts through the Blynk mobile application.This implementation demonstrates a cost-effective, real-time, and efficient safety system tailored for women, leveraging the integration of IoT devices and cloud-based services. The synergy of motion detection, GPS tracking, and remote alert mechanisms significantly enhances situational awareness and facilitates timely emergency responses, contributing to proactive personal security.

title: QuFi: Adaptive Tiled Gustavson Output Reuse for Edge Sparse DNN Accelerators
authors: Adrián Navarro, José Cano, José L. Abellán, Manuel E. Acacio
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: In recent years, a myriad of Deep Neural Network (DNN) accelerator architectures have been proposed targeting efficient Sparse Matrix-Sparse Matrix Multiplication (SpMSpM) for the edge. Most focus on the dataflow, i.e., the order in which processing elements perform multiply-accumulate operations, while overlooking the influence of memory structures. For Gustavson-based dataflows, which have been proven to be the most efficient for the mid-sparsity scenarios exhibited by sparse DNN workloads, we find that the memory structure's organization storing partial results significantly affects performance. Different DNN models, even layers within the same model, impose diverse requirements on this structure. Rigid designs, commonly assumed so far, often cause frequent merging operations that degrade performance. In this work, we advocate for the necessity of providing adaptability at this memory structure and propose QuFi, a configurable merging memory structure designed for easy integration into any Gustavson-based accelerator and tailored to edge devices. Implemented as a collection of queues across multiple memory banks, QuFi supports reconfigurability through queue fusion and dynamic clustering while providing high bandwidth. Through a detailed evaluation that considers its inclusion into a state-of-the-art accelerator design for the edge, we show that QuFi provides an average speedup of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.64 \times$</tex>, up to 73 % reduction in off-chip memory traffic, and leads to total accelerator area savings of 17 %.

title: Android Application for Bill Splitting and Expense Tracking Using Google Cloud Vision Optical Character Recognition (OCR) and Gemini AI
authors: Nurwahyu Alamsyah, Chlunidia Putri Kieswendha, Aprilia Kurnianti, Reza Giga Isnanda, Eko Prasetyo, Hafiez Sofyani
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: In the era of financial technology (fintech), the development of applications capable of automatically splitting bills and recording expenses within a single platform has emerged as a solution. To address this need, an Android-based application was developed using Flutter, integrating Google Cloud Vision Optical Character Recognition (OCR) to extract text from receipts and Gemini AI to classify products and prices. The development process followed the Agile methodology using the Serum framework, carried out in iterative sprints that included planning, daily serums, reviews, and retrospectives. Functional testing was conducted using the Black Box Testing approach, in which all test scenarios were successfully passed. Furthermore, usability was evaluated using the System Usability Scale (SUS), yielding a score of 70.35. Overall, the application provides a solution for automated bill splitting and expense tracking.

title: Comparison of Fourier Transform, Windowed Fourier Transform, and Wavelet Transform Methods for Phase Extraction in Tilt Moiré-Fringe-Based Lithography Alignment
authors: Feifan Xu, Jie He, Haojie Xia
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: High-precision alignment between the wafer and mask is crucial for efficient lithography manufacturing. This study introduces a novel alignment mark combining a circular grating with differential linear gratings. Leveraging interference imaging to generate Moiré fringes, the proposed method enables high-precision measurement of angular displacement misalignment. The circular grating supports coarse alignment, while the linear grating facilitates fine alignment. The Moiré fringe phase at different positions is extracted using fast Fourier transform (FFT), windowed Fourier transform (WFT), and wavelet transform (WT) algorithms. The results demonstrate that WFT and WT outperform FFT in angular displacement measurements, with WT achieving the highest precision.

title: Antenna Near-Field Reconstruction from Far-Field Data Using Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Sahar Bagherkhani, Jackson Christopher Earls, Franco De Flaviis, Pierre Baldi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Electromagnetic field reconstruction is crucial in many applications, including antenna diagnostics, electromagnetic interference analysis, and system modeling. This paper presents a deep learning-based approach for Far-Field to NearField (FF-NF) transformation using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). The goal is to reconstruct near-field distributions from the far-field data of an antenna without relying on explicit analytical transformations. The CNNs are trained on paired farfield and near-field data and evaluated using mean squared error (MSE). The best model achieves a training error of 0.0199 and a test error of 0.3898. Moreover, visual comparisons between the predicted and true near-field distributions demonstrate the model's effectiveness in capturing complex electromagnetic field behavior, highlighting the potential of deep learning in electromagnetic field reconstruction.

title: Power Quality Assessment of EV Fast Charging Systems Using AFE-PSFB Topology
authors: Amirali Mahjoob, Muhammad Annas Jawed, Thomas Glotzbach, Andreas Ulbig
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The rapid deployment of Electric Vehicle (EV) fast charging stations imposes significant power quality (PQ) and stability challenges on distribution grids, especially in weak low-voltage networks. This paper presents a comprehensive simulation-based analysis of a two-stage EV charger comprising an Active Front-End (AFE) and a Phase-Shifted Full-Bridge (PSFB) DC-DC converter. A detailed MATLAB/Simulink model, including dq-axis current control, SVPWM, and root locus–tuned PI regulation, is developed to capture converter-grid interactions. Simulations were conducted under varying short-circuit ratios (SCR), X/R ratios, and islanding scenarios. Results show that under nominal grid conditions (SCR = 6), the charger maintains IEEE 519-2014 compliance, with current THD below 5% and stable voltage regulation. However, with SCR reduced to 2, current THD exceeds 10%, and voltage deviations surpass acceptable limits. Highly resistive grids (X/R = 0.1) further amplify harmonic distortion. In the islanding case, the system exhibits negative impedance behavior, leading to controller instability and voltage collapse within milliseconds after disconnection. These findings highlight the critical role of integrated converter control design and underscore the need for grid-forming capabilities and advanced damping strategies to ensure robust EV charger operation in weak grid environments.

title: Optimization Configuration Method of Distributed Energy Storage for Enhancing the Hosting Capacity of Distributed Network
authors: Yunfei Xu, Xiulu Zhang, Guojun Lan, Xia Miao, Yiqiong He
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: The large-scale integration of renewable energy, like wind and solar power, necessitates more advanced methods for evaluating distribution networks' hosting capacity. Assessing and improving the distribution network's hosting capacity has become a critical challenge for the evolving power grid. To enhance the hosting capacity for distributed renewable energy, this paper develops a method for optimizing the configuration of distributed energy storage systems. First, a multi-faceted evaluation system is proposed to assess the hosting capacity for distributed renewables in the distribution network. This study further developed a hybrid weighting scheme for hosting capacity assessment, employing an improved Analytic Hierarchy Process for subjective weights and the CRITIC method for objective weights. Subsequently, a model was constructed to enhance the distributed photovoltaic hosting capacity through energy storage capacity optimization. The GA-CPSO algorithm was applied to solve this formulated model. The simulation results verify that the proposed method for evaluating distributed photovoltaic hosting capacity contributes to enhanced power quality, reduced system losses, and increased economic benefits for the distribution network.

title: Hybrid Machine Learning Approach for Early Detection of Ovarian Cancer using SVM and KNN Models with Feature Selection
authors: Vijaya Kumari B, Swetha Kora, Vishwanath Bijalwan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Early and accurate detection of ovarian cancer remains a significant challenge in clinical practice. This study proposes a hybrid machine learning model combining Support Vector Machine (SVM) and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) to enhance the detection of ovarian cancer by integrating biomarkers and physiological features. We systematically evaluate feature selection techniques, including Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) and statistical methods, to identify the most relevant predictors. The study uses biomarkers (e.g., CA-125, HE4) and physiological data (e.g., age, BMI) to create a multi-modal dataset. The features are tested individually and in combination to assess their impact on model performance. The hybrid model integrates predictions from SVM and KNN using majority voting, leveraging the strengths of both algorithms in global and local classification. The model is evaluated using various metrics, including accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and AUC, demonstrating improved detection accuracy. Results show that incorporating both types of features significantly enhances predictive performance, underscoring the potential of multi-modal data integration for developing robust diagnostic tools for ovarian cancer.

title: Efficiency Improvement of Wireless Charging System Based on Double-layer Multi-transmitters
authors: Chunlong Li, Xin Wang, Hui Huang, Zhidong Gao, Weiqiang Liu, Yanling Li
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: In this paper, a double-layer multi-transmitter (TXs) and its activation strategy with high transmission efficiency and misalignment tolerance are proposed for a wireless charging system. Firstly, the TX features a two-layer coil staggered arrangement, providing a relatively uniform magnetic field and low leakage flux, which effectively enhances its anti-misalignment performance. The receiving coil (RX) is designed with a minimum outer radius to ensure the rated power pickup. Then, the optimal transmission efficiency condition is derived, which is related to the TX's current, mutual inductance, and the activated TXs number. Based on the optimal efficiency condition, TX's activation strategy is determined by further detecting the voltage and current on the primary side and the load to identify mutual inductance. An experimental prototype is carried out to validate the proposal. The results show that the proposed system can transmit a constant power of 500W in the presence of misalignments, with a maximum efficiency of 91%.

title: Edge-Aware AI-Model: A Lightweight Deep-Learning for Mapping of Child Growth
authors: Hen Hen Lukmana, Muhammad Al-Husaini, Iseu Siti Aisyah, Lilik Hidayanti, Luh Desi Puspareni, Vito Hafizh Cahaya Putra, Muhammad Sidiq Asyaky
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Childhood growth faltering remains a public-health challenge in Indonesia, yet risk mapping is still dominated by coarse administrative summaries that obscure local heterogeneity. This paper introduces a lightweight Geo-AI pipeline that merges routinely collected public health records with spatial and socio-economic layers to generate fine-scale risk surfaces for Tasikmalaya City. After basic cleaning and feature engineering, 1824 case points (2020–2023) from 27 health centres were modelled using a two-layer Multi-Layer Perceptron (32-32-1, ReLU, 0.20 dropout). The network achieved an in-sample mean absolute error of 6.9 ± 3.1 cases and explained 87 ± 6 % of inter-annual variance across 92 facility-year combinations. Predictions are served through a Streamlit-Folium dashboard that allows users to filter years, overlay covariates, and query individual facilities, enabling rapid identification of high-risk clusters. While forecast validation with chronological hold-outs is still required, the platform already demonstrates how inexpensive edge-deployable models can enrich city-level nutrition planning with evidence-driven, sub-district insight.

title: Electromagnetic Applications of Machine Learning in Space Technology
authors: Christos G. Christodoulou, Edl Schamiloglu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Machine learning (ML) is revolutionizing various scientific and engineering fields by enabling intelligent, datadriven decision-making and pattern recognition. Its integration into electromagnetics (EM) is especially transformative for spacerelated technologies, where traditional computational methods are often resource-intensive. This presentation will introduce examples of how ML enhances electromagnetic simulations, optimizes satellite communications through techniques like beamforming and angle of arrival detection, and fosters innovations in adaptive antenna systems. These advancements not only streamline design and operational processes but also significantly improve system resilience against interference and high-power microwave signals.

title: Convolutional Neural Network-Based Transfer Learning for Indonesian Wind and String Instrument Image Classification
authors: Kadek Tania Taragita Yundra, Chrysant Makmur, Abdul Haris Rangkuti, Yasi Dani, Evawaty Tanuar, Mohammad Erdda
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Indonesia is a country that has a variety of cultural heritages, including traditional musical instrument that reflect the uniqueness of a region. However, interest in traditional musicals instrument has decreased and is difficult to accept in society due to lack of knowledge and information about it. To overcome this, image classification of traditional musical instruments based on deep learning, especially with its derivative Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), to recognize traditional Indonesian musical instruments in several regions. This study focuses on the classification of wind and string instruments through several CNN models, such as VGG16, VGG19, ResNet50V2, ResNet101V2, ResNet152V2, InceptionV3, Xception, and MobileNetV2. By applying transfer learning, this study develops an image recognition technique for traditional Indonesian musical instruments. The dataset used includes images of musical instruments from various regions in Indonesia, where the recognition process is preprocessed such as resizing, grayscale, cropping, background removal, and data augmentation to improve model performance. Based on the experiment, the VGG16 model showed the best performance, with the highest accuracy and showed effective learning with minimal up to 100% followed by the ResNet50V2, VGG 19 and Inception V3 models which have an average accuracy of 98%. This shows that the approach process to recognize several Indonesian musical instruments has been running well.

title: Optimized Centralized vs Distributed BESS: Techno-Economic-Environmental Comparison in UK LV Networks
authors: Xuan Wu, Desen Kirli
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The integration of intermittent renewable generation into low-voltage grids poses economic and operational challenges, especially as the UK targets net-zero emissions by 2050. Battery energy storage systems (BESS) address these challenges, yet optimal deployment (centralized vs. distributed) under dynamic pricing remains unclear. Here we show that centralized storage combined with mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) optimization reduces annual costs by 62% compared to photovoltaic-only systems, achieves a 9-year payback period that critically exceeds its projected 8-year lifespan, while also providing an additional 7% of monthly Self-Consumption Ratio (SCR) compared to distributed systems. MILP optimization leverages aggregated load profiles for maximum arbitrage revenue but accelerates battery degradation through frequent cycling. Our findings highlight a critical trade-off between economic optimization and battery lifespan, underscoring the need for balanced, multi-objective frameworks to support high renewable penetration in low-carbon grids.

title: Sampled Data-Based Observer and Resilient Event-Triggered Controller Design for Cyber-Physical Systems to Mitigate Bounded Mixed Cyber Attacks
authors: Xiaohang Li, Binrui Wang, Yueying Wang, Weidong Zhang, Mohammed Chadli
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics
abstract: This article addresses the secure control problem for cyber-physical systems (CPSs) subject to energy-bounded mixed network attacks, which comprise both false-data-injection (FDI) attacks and denial-of-service (DoS) attacks occurring simultaneously. To cope with transmission constraints and the unavailability of full state measurements, we design a novel sampled-data observer that concurrently estimates system states and reconstructs FDI attacks, thereby enabling effective attack compensation within the control loop. Moreover, we introduce a resilient event-triggered mechanism (ETM) capable of tolerating energy-bounded DoS attacks. By integrating this mechanism with the proposed observer, we construct an observer-based event-triggered controller that ensures system stability without requiring detailed attack information. The controller guarantees asymptotically bounded convergence under mixed attacks while avoiding restrictive assumptions in the existence analysis. Numerical simulations conducted on a three-tank system and an inverted pendulum system validate the effectiveness and superior performance of the proposed approach compared to existing methods.

title: Power line energy harvesting system for GaN transistors monitoring
authors: Vlad Marsic, Soroush Faramehr, Isha Maini, David A. J. Moran, Iain G. Thayne, Petar Igic
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Gallium nitride (GaN) transistors are a highly promising technology, with applications in high-frequency, high-temperature, and high-efficiency power systems. However, they are susceptible to various electromagnetic hazards. As a result, in-situ state-of-health (SOH) active monitoring of the device during operation is necessary, with various efforts focusing on non-invasive approaches. This study presents the design and testing of a complete, in-situ, non-invasive monitoring system powered by energy harvested from the GaN transistor’s power line (PL). Experimental results show that an external low-power load of approx. 3.6 W, such as a standard server fan, is sufficient to generate approximately 16 μW and 64 μW (i.e., for two different GaN transistors) of radiated power at the transistor’s drain connection with the PL. This emitted energy, harvested using a 100 mH inductor, is capable of powering a remote SOH monitoring system consisting of a Microchip PIC24F 16-bit microcontroller, three MCP9700 temperature sensors, and an MRF89XA 868 MHz transceiver. The resulting system is able to collect sensor data and, after a brief energy accumulation period (the system’s warm-start charging cycle), wirelessly transmit it to a base station. To further illustrate the practicality of the proposed SOH monitoring solution, the two GaN transistors were intentionally driven into a thermal runaway regime while operating in low-power mode on a 12 W load. Under these conditions, the harvested energy/emmited radiation increased to approximately 620 μW and 3,216 μW, representing about 38 and 50 times the values observed in the previous low-power demonstration, respectively.

title: Small-Object Detection at the Edge: A Pareto-Efficient Benchmark of Lightweight YOLO Models on UAV and Overhead Datasets_supp2-3648968.docx
authors: Bijay Shakya
publish: N/A
abstract: Small-object detection plays a critical role in real-time aerial, Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV), and satellite vision systems, as well as many other domains, where hardware constraints and deployment environments demand high accuracy, low latency, and energy efficiency. Although numerous lightweight object detectors have been proposed, there exists a lack of rigorous, cross-platform benchmarks that evaluate these models under consistent conditions for small-object-focused applications. This paper presents a comprehensive comparative evaluation of eight recent lightweight You Look Only Once (YOLO)-based models, including YOLOX-Nano and YOLOv6–v12 variants. Models are trained using a unified pipeline and evaluated on three representative datasets: VisDrone2019, DOTA-v1.5, and xView. Performance is assessed on both cloud GPUs (NVIDIA A100) and an edge AI platform (Jetson Orin Nano), using PyTorch and TensorRT (FP16) runtimes. The evaluation metrics include mAP@0.5, mAP@0.5:0.95, F1-score, latency, FPS, memory footprint, and energy consumption (via VDD_IN telemetry). Experimental results demonstrate that YOLOv8-Nano and YOLOv9-Tiny achieve leading accuracy across datasets, while YOLOv6-Nano and YOLOv10-Nano offer favorable trade-offs in speed and memory. TensorRT optimization yields 3×–5× speedup over PyTorch. Energy draw ranges from 7.6 W to 10.4 W, depending on the model and configuration. Pareto frontiers reveal that no single model dominates across all objectives. The study highlights the importance of multi-objective benchmarking in edge AI and provides practical guidance for selecting detectors based on deployment-specific constraints. The findings support theory-driven and application-oriented advancement of efficient detection architectures for real-time, resource-aware computer vision systems.

title: A Survey on Edge-Aware Graph Learning Methods
authors: Wagner A. Junior, Fábio Ramos, Alex B. Vieira, José Augusto M. Nacif, Ricardo S. Ferreira
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have gained popularity as an efficient choice for learning on graph-structured data. However, most methods are node or graph-centered, often overlooking valuable information that can be encoded in edge features and relations. In this survey, we present a comprehensive review and a novel taxonomy of Edge-Aware Graph Learning Methods, i.e., models that explicitly leverage edge information in the learning process. We trace the evolution of these methods from classical approaches through random walks to modern GNN architectures, including the emerging paradigm of Edge-Aware Graph Transformers. Through a comparative analysis, we demonstrate the consistent performance gains of these models over traditional node-centric approaches across a wide range of real-world applications and benchmarks. However, many challenges arise in this field. As such, we provide an explicit discussion of key limitations, particularly the scalability issues and computational overhead associated with many current architectures. Finally, by synthesizing the state-of-the-art and identifying open problems, this survey provides a clear roadmap to guide future research toward developing more efficient, scalable, and robust edge-aware models.

title: HARMONY: A Holistic Auto-scaling Resilient Model for Multi-Objective Adaptation in Microservices using HPPNs - A Case Study on E-Business Platforms
authors: Souheir Merkouche, Chafia Bouanaka, Elhadj Benkhelifa, Chirine Ghedira Guegan
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Modern microservice architectures face significant auto-scaling challenges due to dynamic workloads, heterogeneous resource demands, and competing quality objectives like performance, cost, and reliability. Existing solutions often adopt either centralized (bottleneck-prone) or decentralized (conflictprone) architectures, rely on single-metric threshold-based adaptations, and lack formal guarantees on system behavior. To address these limitations, we propose HARMONY, a holistic auto-scaling framework that ensures both hierarchical coordination, multi-objective adaptation, and formal verification for microservices. The layered MAPE-K architecture of HARMONY enables coordinated adaptation between individual microservices and the overall system through shared knowledge and distributed quality adaptation mechanisms. The Pareto-based planning strategy of HARMONY dynamically selects compromise scaling actions that balance system-wide objectives with microservice-level constraints. HARMONY formalizes adaptation behaviors using Hierarchical Parallel Petri Nets (HPPNs), enabling rigorous verification of deadlock freeness, boundedness, and correctness. We implement HARMONY through the ScopeNet framework and evaluate it through a realistic e-business case study. Results show that HARMONY: (1) autonomously coordinates cross-service adaptations, (2) optimizes trade-offs among conflicting objectives, and (3) ensures reliable behavior under diverse runtime conditions. These capabilities represent a significant improvement in the state of the art for scalable, verifiable, and adaptive microservice auto-scaling.

title: Motion Reproduction System for Environmental Impedance Variation via Data-Driven Identification of Human Stiffness
authors: Akira Takakura, Kazuki Yane, Tomoya Kitamura, Shuichi Adachi, Takahiro Nozaki
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: The motion reproduction system (MRS) transfers human dexterous motion skills to robots. Compared with other machine learning-based methods, it has an advantage in terms of the number of data points and hyperparameters. However, it may fail when the actual object of motion differs from that of acquired human motion. Conventional studies consider human stiffness, which characterizes the intention of human motion. Although they performed better than the original MRS with variable objects, they estimated human impedance using linear interpolation. Linear interpolation is insufficient for generating novel, human-like motions that are nonlinear and time-variant. In this article, more sophisticated motions were generated by fitting the relationship between environmental stiffness and position, velocity, and force nonlinearly using Gaussian process regression, which requires a smaller amount of data compared to machine learning-based schemes. Through experiments, the data number and error reduction between the true human motion and actual motion were confirmed by comparing the original and conventional MRS and the imitation learning. Therefore, the proposed method can generate motion for variable objects more precisely with a small amount of human motion data.

title: The Characteristic Values of Negative Imaginary Systems and Their Riccati-Balanced Representation
authors: Luigi Fortuna, Giovanni Garraffa
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: This paper introduces the definition of the Characteristic Values for Negative Imaginary (NI) systems and proposes a Riccati-based Model Order Reduction (MOR) procedure specifically tailored for this class of systems. The approach provides a balanced state-space representation that preserves the NI property in the reduced models, ensuring reliability and robustness even for very high-order systems. A formal connection with the Positive Real (PR) and Bounded Real (BR) formulations is remarked, revealing structural analogies that enable NI systems to be expressed in a PR-balanced framework. The resulting procedure combines the theoretical rigor of Riccati equations with the wellknown robustness of balancing truncation methods, offering a practical and structure-preserving tool for NI model reduction. The effectiveness of the proposed framework is verified through numerical examples, confirming its accuracy and its advantages over conventional optimization-based MOR techniques.

title: Bicycle Sensor Platform (BSP) for Road Anomaly Detection using a Physics-based and Machine Learning aided approach
authors: Yash Mehta, Boby George, Chinthaka Gooneratne
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Preserving road quality is challenging due to adverse weather, heavy traffic, and routine wear. Traditional road surveys are costly and periodic, while smartphone-based sensor methods, using accelerometers and GPS data inside motor vehicles, suffer from signal damping due to suspension systems. This paper introduces a Bicycle Sensor Platform (BSP) as an alternative, leveraging three key advantages: (1) the growing emphasis on cycling as a sustainable, healthy, and low-carbon urban mobility option, (2) bicycles can access both roads and cycling paths, especially in narrow streets where small vehicles are the only frequent and viable transit option, and (3) BSPs potential role in smart cities, mobility, and citizen-driven sensing. Using the smartphone’s accelerometer sensor placed in a cyclist’s backpack, combined with a novel analytical and machine learning model, we demonstrate that the BSP can accurately detect road irregularities such as manholes, bumps, and rumble strips, along with their physical characteristics (e.g., height/depth). Results highlight the BSP as a low-cost, scalable, and mobile sensor system that offers a novel approach to urban road anomaly detection. The continuous data stream from the BSP can help transportation authorities to quickly identify road defects, optimize maintenance schedules, and enhance infrastructure management.

title: Optimal Quantization for Matrix Multiplication
authors: Or Ordentlich, Yury Polyanskiy
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Theory
abstract: Recent work in machine learning community proposed multiple methods for performing lossy compression (quantization) of large matrices. This quantization is important for accelerating matrix multiplication (main component of large language models), which is often bottlenecked by the speed of loading these matrices from memory. Unlike classical vector quantization and rate-distortion theory, the goal of these new compression algorithms is to be able to approximate not the matrices themselves, but their matrix product. Specifically, given a pair of real matrices A,B an encoder (compressor) is applied to each of them independently producing descriptions with R bits per entry. These representations subsequently are used by the decoder to estimate matrix product A⊤B. In this work, we provide a non-asymptotic lower bound on the mean squared error of this approximation (as a function of rate R) for the case of matrices A,B with iid Gaussian entries. Algorithmically, we construct a universal quantizer based on nested lattices with an explicit guarantee of approximation error for any (non-random) pair of matrices A, B in terms of only Frobenius norms ∥Ā∥F, ∥B∥F and ∥Ā⊤B∥F, where Ā, B are versions of A,B with zero-centered columns, respectively. For iid Gaussian matrices our quantizer achieves the lower bound and is, thus, asymptotically optimal. A practical low-complexity version of our quantizer achieves performance quite close to optimal. In addition, we derive rate-distortion function for matrix multiplication of iid Gaussian matrices, which exhibits an interesting phase-transition at R ≈ 0.906 bit/entry, showing necessity of Johnson-Lindestrauss dimensionality reduction (sketching) in the low-rate regime.

title: Peak Age of Information Analysis for Real-Time Status Update Systems Based on Martingale Theory
authors: Hangyu Yan, Xuefen Chi, Wanting Yang, Zehui Xiong, Zhu Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: In this paper, we propose a martingale-based method to analyze the peak age of information (PAoI) in real-time status update systems. Specifically, we establish the relationship between the PAoI and the inter-arrival time as well as the service time of status update packets. Martingales are then constructed for the inter-arrival time and service time to capture their stochastic characteristics. Utilizing the constructed martingales, we derive a closed-form expression for the upper bound of the PAoI violation probability under the First-Come-First-Served scheduling policy. It is worth emphasizing that the proposed method is applicable where the service time of status update packets is independently and identically distributed or follows a Markov process. Numerical results verify the accuracy and generality of the proposed method in analyzing PAoI.

title: SFOM-PPO: An SINR-Aware Feature Optimization Mechanism-Driven Resource Allocation Scheme for Semantic Spectral-Efficient Image Transmission
authors: Shuhan Yang, Bin Shen, Xiaoge Huang, Qianbin Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: With the evolution of 6G technologies, spectrum scarcity has emerged as a critical challenge. Semantic communication, as a content and task-oriented paradigm, offers a promising solution to alleviate spectrum limitations. We propose a novel resource allocation scheme based on a signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR)-aware feature optimization mechanism (SFOM) for dynamic semantic image transmission (DSIT). To better characterize semantic transmission efficiency, we define a new performance metric, image semantic spectrum efficiency (ISSE), which employs semantic features as information conveyors rather than traditional bit-level representations. To maximize ISSE under image quality constraints, we formulate a joint optimization problem involving multiple discrete variables, including compression ratio (CR), channel assignment, and power allocation. To address this problem, we develop an SFOM-driven proximal policy optimization (SFOM-PPO) algorithm that evaluates the significance of semantic feature channels and models the nonlinear relationships among the peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR), CR, and SINR, enabling adaptive semantic feature selection and optimal resource allocation under dynamic communication conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed SFOM-PPO significantly outperforms baselines in ISSE performance, achieving an effective balance between image transmission quality and resource efficiency. This work provides initial insights into semantic spectral-efficient resource management and suggests a potential framework for future wireless semantic image transmission systems.

title: Attention-Augmented LSTM for Short-Term Wind and PV Power Forecasting
authors: Rongchuan Xu, Kun Yuan, Yulong Jin, Tao Zheng, Kun Xu, Ying Wang, Kaifeng Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: This paper proposes a self-attentive LSTM (LSTA) model for short-term forecasting of wind and photovoltaic (PV) power and investigates the operational impact of forecast errors on coordinated wind–PV–battery scheduling. Historical 2024 generation and load data from a North American region (15-minute resolution) are used to train and evaluate the models. The LSTA integrates an attention module into the LSTM gate structure to emphasize temporally salient features in volatile renewable generation series. Predicted 24-hour profiles are incorporated into a day-ahead scheduling model that minimizes total system cost (curtailment, storage investment and charge/discharge cost). Compared with a baseline LSTM, the proposed LSTA reduces wind RMSE from 895.67 to 324.67 MW and solar RMSE from 109.58 to 58.24 MW. When used in the scheduling stage, LSTA forecasts lower the wind–solar curtailment rate (from 10.9% to 3.1%) and decrease total operational cost relative to the LSTM-based schedule. Results demonstrate that embedding attention into LSTM improves forecast fidelity for highly variable renewable outputs, which in turn yields measurable reductions in curtailment and system cost in coordinated dispatch. Key contributions include the gate-level attention design, the end-to-end prediction-to-scheduling evaluation, and a quantitative assessment of forecasting accuracy on dispatch outcomes.

title: Analysis of Transmission Line Effect of Dynamic Capacitive Power Transfer System With Long Transmitting Plates
authors: Qiang Zhang, Yifei Zhang, Feng Xiao, Yiwei Sun, Wei Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: The EC-WPT technology has the advantages of low eddy current losses, low cost, lightweight and is suitable for mobile devices. It can be used to address the issue of insufficient battery life for mobile power-consuming equipment. However, the segment size of the long transmitting plate in the dynamic EC-WPT system is close to the high-frequency excitation wavelength. This proximity significantly affects the system due to the long-line effect. Besides, the system experiences new phenomena such as uneven spatial distribution of the coupling electric field and significant fluctuations in voltage/current, and these would pose a huge challenge to the stability of the system’s output voltage. This paper proposes a mathematical model for the dynamic EC-WPT system with a long transmitting plate based on transmission line theory, and presents a constant voltage output method for the dynamic EC-WPT system with a long transmitting plate under the influence of the long-line effect. The correctness of the system model and control method is verified through simulation.

title: Intelligent Substation Energy Allocation for Regenerative Braking by Reinforcement Learning
authors: Yuanxiang Meng, Yongjiang Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: In the face of fossil fuel depletion, improving energy efficiency is crucial to sustainable development. In AC electrified railway systems, the efficient allocation of Regenerative Braking Energy (RBE) is important to improve the energy efficiency and realize low-carbon transportation. Its level of optimization directly affects the system’s energy recovery efficiency and economic viability, making it highly significant for the development of sustainable transportation. However, current research in this field remains relatively limited, so it requires further exploration of more intelligent energy allocation strategies. To improve the utilization efficiency of regenerative braking energy in AC electrified railway systems, this paper proposes a power allocation method for substations based on Q-learning. The method first involves discretized modeling of the substation's energy state. At the same time, this paper has designed the action space according to the operational characteristics of the power distribution unit and introduced an ε-greedy strategy combined with an energy-saving-oriented reward function. All the above can guide the agent to progressively learn the optimal energy allocation policy through interaction. Simulation verification was conducted using a typical three-substation system. The results show that the Q- table effectively converges. And the learned policy exhibits good energy utilization efficiency and system adaptability in dynamic environments. The overall utilization rate of regenerative braking energy reaches 60%, verifying the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed method in improving energy recovery efficiency

title: Design of Accounting Resource Sharing Platform Based on Data Mining and Cloud Computing
authors: Feng Gu, Hongqi Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: This paper designs an accounting resource sharing platform based on data mining and cloud computing, and proposes a hybrid data protection algorithm based on homomorphic encryption and differential privacy. The experiment builds a simulation environment containing 8 cloud servers and 1,500 simulated users, and uses a company's 5-year real accounting data (a total of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> records) as the experimental data set. The algorithm in this paper is compared with the traditional homomorphic encryption algorithm and differential privacy algorithm. The results show that in terms of privacy protection, the algorithm in this paper reduces the risk of data leakage by 68 %, which is 52 % higher than the traditional homomorphic encryption algorithm and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 3 \%}$</tex> higher than the differential privacy algorithm; in terms of data processing efficiency, the encryption and decryption time is reduced by 61 %, and the data mining analysis speed is increased by 48 %. The platform performance test shows that the average response time for resource retrieval is 0.7 seconds, the data throughput reaches <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$135 \text{MB} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>, and it can support large-scale concurrent access. The experimental results verify the effectiveness of the platform and algorithm in ensuring the security of accounting data and improving resource sharing efficiency, and provide an innovative solution for the digital development of the accounting industry.

title: Random Forest Machine Learning Model for Prediction of Compressor Failure Using Intelligent Controller
authors: Satish Bojjawar, Hariharan N, Amutha A, P. Palpandian, M. Nirmala, C. Mohan Raj
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Predictive management system plays a vital role in industry. Increasing the production rate of an industry is achieved by reducing the down time of the machine. Since the industrial machines are interconnected, faults in any one of the machine leads to massive production loss in the system. Apart from the incipient fault like short circuit due to surge voltage and over voltage, other faults like loss of break down strength of insulation medium due to ageing, mechanical bearing failure in machines due to vibrations, motor's winding insulation failure in motor due to core and copper losses are early predictable. In this article, prediction of air compressor failure is achieved by using the Random Forest (RF) Machine Learning algorithm with FX5U-32MT-ESS Programmable Logic Controller. Various sensors like CT/PT, temperature sensor (RTD), vibration sensor and encoders sensor data are fed to the FX5U controller. The RF ML model is trained by the training data set in colab platform. The training data is obtained from the compressors which are running in the industry and compressors which are in fault due to various above said reasons. The SD card mounted with the FX5U controller records the compressor data like current, voltage, power usage, temperature, vibration and speed. These data are used as a training and testing data for prediction of fault. The instantaneous values from the FX5U controller is fed to the RF algorithms as a test data for prediction.

title: An Autonomous Network Positioning Technique for B5G/6G Applications
authors: Zhaoliang Liu, Liang Chen, Xibei Zhao, Ruizhi Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Wireless positioning technology represents an essential constituent of Location-Based Services (LBS), serving as a critical enabler for spatial data acquisition and real-time location tracking in diverse application domains. Both the broadest application of Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) and the emergent indoor positioning system, which can not be separated from the support of wireless positioning technology. Based on the demand for ubiquitous LBS from a wide range of users and the popularity of 5G networks in recent years, this paper develops an autonomous network positioning technology for B5G/6G applications. The development of the method ensures the performance of the positioning while lowering the cost of deployment, and breaks through the boundaries of 5G/6G applications. The field tests were carried out in an indoor large-scene environment to evaluate the performance of the developed system. It is shown that a Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of the positioning system based on the autonomous network developed in this paper can be less than 1.4 m, based on the field test results.

title: Design of High-Precision Aqueous Solution Conductivity Meter
authors: Dong Yang, Yonggang Luo, Xiaobing Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: In response to the demand for water quality monitoring in daily life and industry, a water solution conductivity measurement instrument is designed. The sensor probe of this instrument adopts a four-ring electrode structure a Pt100 temperature sensor is built into the metal wall at the back of the probe head for temperature acquisition and compensation. The system uses an STM32 microcontroller to output a PWM wave to control the excitation signal, eliminating the influence of polarization effects. The return signal is differentially sampled by the AD chip after passing through the measurement circuit, and temperature compensation is achieved through the measured value of Pt100. Test results show that the relative error of this design is 0.5%, with a measurement range of 1-1000000 μS/cm,and it has high practical value.

title: Influence of acidic products on the oxidation stability of synthetic ester insulating oil
authors: Siwei Pan, Qing Wang, Yihua Qian, Lei Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: Synthetic ester insulating oils are renewable, biodegradable, and possess high flash and ignition points, making them promising alternatives to mineral oils in power transformers. However, their acid value increases significantly during aging, compromising insulation performance. This study synthesized two ester oils—trimethylolpropane caprylic-nonanoic acid ester (TCNE) and pentaerythritol caprylic-nonanoic acid ester (PCNE)—via vacuum esterification, and investigated the effects of three representative acids (formic acid [C1], octanoic acid [C8], and nonanoic acid [C9]) on their oxidative stability. Results show that PCNE exhibits better thermal-oxidative resistance than TCNE. All acidic substances reduced the oxidation onset temperature and apparent activation energy, which accelerated degradation in insulation performance. C1 had the most significant impact, attributed to its strong polarity, acidity, and hydrophilicity.

title: Personalized Tonal Harmony Parsing via Scoring-Based Tree Selection
authors: Daichi Hoshikoshi, Shun Sawada, Kouichi Katsurada, Satoshi Tojo, Hidefumi Ohmura
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: This study addresses individual differences in the harmonic analysis of chord progressions. We hypothesize that these differences arise from personal analytical preferences and propose a personalized analysis system based on a Generative Syntax Model (GSM). For a given progression, the GSM generates all possible parse trees via context-free grammar rules and scores them along multiple axes-syntactic conciseness, tonal consistency, frequency of typical progressions, and key consistency. Users subjectively set the weightings of these axes to reflect their own preferences, enabling personalized tonal harmony parsing. Experiments under various weighting conditions confirm the system's potential for personalized analysis.

title: Cross-Attentive Autoencoder Framework for Multimodal Data Fusion in Internet of Vehicles Systems
authors: Natrayan L, Ramya M, Keshavani R
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: The Internet of Vehicles (IoV) generates massive heterogeneous data from vehicles, roadside infrastructure, and sensors, requiring efficient fusion for accurate decision-making in intelligent transportation systems. Traditional fusion techniques struggle with high-dimensional, noisy, and redundant data, leading to increased computation and reduced reliability. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a Cross-Attentive Autoencoder (CAA) framework for multimodal data fusion in IoV environments. Autoencoders compress and denoise input data, providing latent representations, while the cross-attention mechanism establishes inter-feature correlations by leveraging query, key, and value mappings across modalities. This enhances contextual feature alignment and improves fusion accuracy. Experiments conducted on the Kaggle Passive Vehicle dataset and car parts image dataset demonstrate a 35% reduction in data size, while maintaining robust feature representation. Visualization through heatmaps and latent embeddings confirms the interpretability of fused outputs. The proposed model outperforms conventional approaches by achieving effective noise reduction, efficient compression, and accurate fusion for IoV applications. Future work will focus on extending the framework to advanced autoencoder variants and integrating it with 6 G -enabled IoV architectures for real-time, scalable deployment.

title: MH-SpGEMM: Efficient Sparse General Matrix-Matrix Multiplication on Modern GPUs via Masking and Hashing Cooperative Optimization
authors: Shuang Yang, Yaobin Wang, Ling Li, Qian Peng, Qiong Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Sparse General Matrix-Matrix Multiplication (SpGEMM) is a core operation in high-performance computing applications such as algebraic multigrid solvers, machine learning, and graph processing. Traditional hash-based SpGEMM methods face several challenges, including frequent hash table accesses during the symbolic phase, high-overhead sorting operations in the numeric phase, and imbalanced workload distribution across threads. To address these issues, we propose a highly optimized SpGEMM method-MH-SpGEMM. Unlike conventional approaches, MH-SpGEMM introduces a mask-based storage format for matrix <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$B$</tex> during the symbolic phase and uses bitwise OR operations to efficiently calculate the number of nonzeros in the result matrix. In the numeric phase, a bitonic sort algorithm is employed for rows with many nonzeros to improve sorting efficiency. Furthermore, MH-SpGEMM incorporates a finer-grained load balancing strategy. We conduct a comprehensive evaluation of MHSpGEMM against four state-of-the-art SpGEMM methods (HSMU-SpGEMM, OpSparse, nsparse, and cuSPARSE) on two NVIDIA GPUs(Ada Lovelace, Ampere). The results demonstrate that MH-SpGEMM consistently outperforms existing methods in terms of performance.

title: Development of the Ambipolar Electric Field in a Compressed Current Sheet with and without a Guide Field
authors: Ami M. DuBois, Chris Crabtree, Emily Lichko, Gurudas Ganguli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Current sheets are important to space and laboratory plasmas, and particularly to the Earth's magnetotail, where during active periods the solar wind compresses the magnetosphere creating thin current sheets. As a current sheet with a reversed magnetic field configuration is compressed, magnetic reconnection can occur. This process can affect the plasma state of the magnetotail, driving space weather and injecting energetic particles into the radiation belts, which impacts Earth orbiting satellites.

title: A Reproducible Framework for Rooftop PV Segmentation Using ResNet-50 and Mini U-Net on Google and IGN Imagery
authors: Juan Carlos Cortez, Luiza Higino S. Santos, Sergio Augusto A. Christoforo, Letícia Rittner, Marcos J. Rider, Renato Da Rocha Lopes
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The growing deployment of rooftop photovoltaic (PV) systems reinforces the need for accurate identification of installed capacity to support energy planning, grid operation, and policy decisions. Once PV panels are segmented, satellite imagery can provide relevant information about their location and surface area. Deep learning (DL) algorithms enable the detection of complex patterns and the automated segmentation of such objects at scale. This study presents a DL framework for semantic segmentation of PV panels using a ResNet-50 encoder pre-trained on ImageNet and a Mini U-Net decoder. The framework is designed to be computationally efficient and adaptable to different regions and image domains. The model is evaluated on publicly available imagery from Google and French National Institute of Geographical and Forestry Information (IGN), covering different spatial resolutions. The proposed approach achieves Dice scores of 0.905 on Google and 0.777 on IGN, significantly outperforming a baseline U-Net trained from scratch by 6.9 % and 22.6 %, respectively. The full code and workflow are made publicly available to ensure reproducibility and support further development.

title: Fake Number Plate Detection Using Vehicle Image Analysis: A Robust Verification System
authors: Unnati Gayaki, Om Nishane, Nikhil Warkad, Sneha Bansod
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: The problem of increasing number of crimes that concern cars has increased the demand of Automatic License Plate Recognition (ALPR) systems capable of locating forged or fake plates. The objective is to present a robust vehicle verification system that combines contour and cascade-based plate detection, pattern-aware OCR with error correction for Indian plates, K-Means clustering for dominant color extraction, and database validation with plate text and color features. The system solves OCR ambiguities through variant generation and deletion support, enhancing detection accuracy in real-world contexts. Key findings include over 90% accuracy for fake plate detection across diverse conditions, with 95% for authentic plates and 92% for fake plates in clear weather, 88% in low light, and 85% in rainy occlusion. The multi-modal approach and flexibility to regional formats make it a promising tool for traffic management and law enforcement, with potential for scalability and deep learning integration.

title: Sensor Data Fusion and Intelligent Monitoring System for Concrete Pile Construction
authors: Aocong Zhang, Hongsheng Qiu, Huiyang Xu, Tianyuan Luo, Qikun Wei
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: In order to improve the level of structural safety and quality visualization during the construction of concrete cast-in-place piles, this paper constructs an intelligent monitoring system that integrates distributed optical fiber temperature measurement and ultrasonic imaging. The system adopts a U-shaped optical fiber layout scheme to achieve high-resolution acquisition of the temperature field, and combines phased array ultrasonic imaging to obtain the echo characteristics of the internal structure of the pile. On this basis, a multimodal fusion diagnosis algorithm based on Bayesian inference and lightweight convolutional network is proposed to realize the positioning and recognition of potential defects and credibility assessment. The field test results show that the constructed system performs well in defect recognition accuracy, timeliness and spatial consistency. The F1 score of the fusion model reaches 0.935, which has good engineering applicability. This study provides a replicable technical path for pile foundation construction quality monitoring and lays the foundation for the subsequent integration of multi-source perception and intelligent construction.

title: Investigating the Impact of Electrical Disturbances on the Dynamics of Coupled Electrolyzer-Compressor Systems
authors: Amin Salehi, Mahyar Tofighi-Milani, Sajjad Fattaheian-Dehkordi, Matti Lehtonen, Janne Seppänen, Mahdi Pourakbari-Kasmaei
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Dynamic studies of the components involved in the interconnected power and hydrogen (H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) sectors are crucial for ensuring the security and stability of both sectors. The connection between electrolyzer plants and electric-driven compressor stations (EDCSs) is a key interaction between these sectors. This work, for the first time, explores the dynamics of a coupled electrolyzer-EDCS system. The developed model analyzes the dynamics of the integrated system when the compressor station is faced with power grid disturbances. Simulation outcomes reveal that the coupled electrolyzer-EDCS system works perfectly in normal conditions. However, the system is unable to appropriately respond to unexpected changes when the EDCS faces a disturbance from the power sector side. The identified issue is due to the lack of a proper control link between the electrolyzer and EDCS. To enable the electrolyzer for regulating its H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> production when the EDCS is disturbed, there is a need for designing of an effective control mechanism. Our verified developed system can be used for this purpose.

title: Sentiment Analysis on the JMO Application Using Random Forest with Grid Search Optimization
authors: Yudi Ramdhani, Nina Kurnia Hikmawati, Rizki Tri Prasetio
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: User-generated reviews in mobile service applications provide valuable insights for evaluating customer satisfaction and system performance. However, effective sentiment analysis remains challenging due to issues such as class imbalance, limited data, and the need for robust model optimization. Jamsostek Mobile (JMO), which facilitates BPJS Ketenagakerjaan services in Indonesia, has recently integrated advanced features such as facial recognition for identity verification and streamlined claim processing, making the understanding of user sentiment increasingly important. This study aims to enhance sentiment analysis for the JMO Mobile app by employing a systematic approach. The Random Forest algorithm is applied to two datasets containing 2,000 and 20,000 user reviews, respectively. Key steps include resolving class imbalance, optimizing hyperparameters, and assessing how dataset size influences model accuracy. The best performance, 92% accuracy, was attained with a 10% validation split on the larger dataset. In addition to accuracy, evaluation metrics such as precision, recall, and F1-score were also analyzed to provide a comprehensive assessment of model performance. The results highlight Random Forest's effectiveness in sentiment classification and offer practical recommendations for improving similar applications. This research contributes by demonstrating how Random Forest can efficiently evaluate user sentiment in large-scale app reviews, providing implications for the development of sentiment analysis methods and future improvements in mobile-based public services.

title: SSM-RDU: A Reconfigurable Dataflow Unit for Long-Sequence State-Space Models
authors: Sho Ko, Kunle Olukotun
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Long-sequence state-space models (SSMs) such as Hyena and Mamba replace the quadratic complexity of self-attention with more efficient FFT and scan operations. However, modern accelerators like GPUs are poorly suited to these non-GEMM workloads due to rigid execution models and specialization for dense matrix operations. This paper proposes architectural extensions to a baseline Reconfigurable Dataflow Unit (RDU) that efficiently support FFT-based and scan-based SSMs. By introducing lightweight interconnect enhancements within compute tiles, the extended RDU enables spatial mapping of FFT and scan dataflows with less than 1% area and power overhead. The resulting architecture achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times-5.95 \times$</tex> speedup over the NVIDIA A100 GPU and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.95 \times$</tex> speedup over the baseline RDU for Hyena, and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.12 \times$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.75 \times$</tex> speedup over the A100 GPU and baseline RDU, respectively, for Mamba.

title: Design and Simulation of RSRA Resonator Sensor for Adulteration Detection in Milk
authors: Shyam D. Bawankar, Rajanish Kumar Singh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
