abstract: In this paper, a Rectangular Spiral Ring Aperture (RSRA) resonator, configured as a band-stop filter for detecting water adulteration in milk, is designed to operate in the frequency range of approximately 3 GHz to 4 GHz. The proposed sensor effectively detects changes in the dielectric constant caused by water adulteration in milk, which leads to measurable shifts in resonance frequency and variations in signal magnitude. Multiple resonant modes are exploited, with higher-order modes exhibiting enhanced sensitivity to low-level adulteration. CST Microwave Studio is used for performing the time domain analysis of the sensor, and the obtained result is also validated by the equivalent circuit model. Further, we focus on the electric field distribution of the proposed sensor for deeper analysis. The current work gives an efficient, compact, and non-invasive solution for real-time monitoring of quality milk.

title: V2X Message Multi-Label Classification: A Deep Learning Approach
authors: Chrisjonpane F. Lazaga, Marife A. Rosales, Gerhard P. Tan
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ICoAIT)
abstract: This is a simulation study created to provide insights into using deep learning models to improve Vehicle-To-Everything (V2X) communications security by classifying the types of messages transmitted or received. The dataset is provided in the IEEE Data Port, pre-processed by one-hot encoding, tokenizer, post-padding, and embedding layer. After text preprocessing, the dense vectorize values are inputted into these four deep learning algorithms: Bidirectional Recurrent Neural Network (BRNN), Convolutional – Bidirectional Recurrent Neural Network (CNN-BRNN), Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BLSTM), and Convolutional Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (CNN-BLSTM). Researchers use the TensorFlow and Keras python libraries using their default parameters of these models. A flatten and dense layer with a Softmax activation function is also used in its output layer for multilabel classification. The results of the classification metrics observed that the CNN-BRNN produced a superior performance than the rest of the models using the V2X Dataset, having an accuracy of 90%, precision of 98.46%, recall of 80.12%, f1-score of 84.49%, and loss value of 0.45. It has also been observed that BRNN has a better performance than BLSTM models with or without Convolutional Layers.

title: Impact of Orthogonal Signal Characteristics in Orthogonal Distance Regression Algorithm on Time Base Jitter Compensation for Broadband Sampling Oscilloscopes
authors: Jiangmiao Zhu, Kaige Man, Kejia Zhao, Weibin Xie, Chaoxian Fu, Yun Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Time base jitter in broadband sampling oscilloscopes affects the accuracy of precision measurements. The Orthogonal Distance Regression (ODR) algorithm can estimate this jitter by using a pair of orthogonal sinusoidal reference signals. This study verifies through simulations how the characteristics of orthogonal signals influence the ODR algorithm’s performance, evaluated by the time base jitter of the measured signals. The results lay a foundation for practical applications.

title: Quantum Cryptography and Key Distribution for Secure Communication in the Post Quantum World
authors: Sai Srinivas Vellela, Pothuguntla Anusha, Nagagopi Raju Vullam, Jeevan Jala, Venkata Subbaiah Bellapu, A. Shri Vindhya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Quantum computing is posing a serious risk to classical cryptographic tools such as RSA and ECC as sophisticated quantum algorithms are able to crack their mathematical foundation in a time bound that is a a polynomial in the number of repetitions. In this paper, we will describe the process of integrating Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) and Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) into a hybrid approach to secure communications in the post-quantum world. The suggested methodology is a combination of the computational efficiency and scalability of PQC and the information-theoretic security and eavesdropping detection abilities of QKD. Simulation observations indicate that PQC-only systems are both faster in generating keys and scalable, but do not have a strong eavesdropping detection. On the other hand, non-conditional security is only a feature of systems based on QKD, but it is also highly overhead and slows down key rate. The hybrid PQC-Q KD model provides a balanced performance, high resilience, high authentication, high confidentiality, and realistic deployability. On balance, this discussion demonstrates that the hybrid approach is better than standalone methods and can provide a strong solution to protect against new quantum threats. The large-scale network protocol can be optimized, resources and further integration with other emerging technologies, such as 5G/6G, IoT or cloud computing, can be directed in future research.

title: A Machine Learning Framework for Predicting Wind Turbine Active Power from Multivariate Sensor Data
authors: Uman Ahmed Mohammed
publish: 2025 IEEE 19th International Conference on Open Source Systems and Technologies (ICOSST)
abstract: Consistent prediction of wind energy power is essential towards optimization of renewable integration, grid stability, and operational efficiency in managing wind farms. This paper introduces a powerful machine learning architecture that can offer prediction of active power of wind turbines based on multivariate time series sensors. The method incorporates data preprocessing, correlation of features, resampling over time and an advanced ensemble regression based on gradient boosting. The model takes a nonlinear dependence and dynamic behavior of wind energy systems by engineering statistical and temporal features of raw sensor streams. The measures of performance are used to evaluate the effectiveness of the framework in making precise and generalizable predictions by the use of standard regression measures. The suggested system will provide a scalable system to monitor turbines in real-time, energy dispatch planning, and predictive maintenance in contemporary renewable energy infrastructures.

title: Qualitative Multimodal Diagnostic Assessment of PV Installations: Field Results from the PROMISE Second Advanced School in Malta
authors: Vlad Costea, Carlos Meza, Sophia Jarhreis, Siwoo Lee, Hugo Sánchez, Zonghan Jiang, Carmel Azzopardi, Brian Bartolo, Miquel Ezquer-Mayo, Aritz Legarrea-Oyarzun, Rita Ebner, Bernard Kubicek, Brian Azzopardi, Austeja Mockeviciute-Azzopardi, Ioannis Tsanekas
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper presents the technical outcomes of a multimodal diagnostic assessment conducted during the PROMISE Advanced School in Malta. Attendees of the school utilized a suite of complementary measurement techniques, ranging from electrical characterization to advanced imaging techniques such as drone infrared (IR), magnetic field imaging (MFI) and electroluminescence (EL). These were applied to four residential photovoltaic (PV) installations. By leveraging the strengths of each method, the study demonstrates how multimodal assessments enable a more accurate and comprehensive understanding of module degradation, electrical anomalies and electrical failures. Faults such as microcracks, inactive cell areas, broken interconnects and semiconductor failures were identified and cross-validated across techniques. For instance, MFI confirmed current path disruptions identified using current-voltage (I-V) tracing, and EL-detected semiconductor breakdowns were linked to IR hotspots. This approach improves ambiguity in fault attribution. The findings of this study applied to residential PV installations provide actionable insights for reliability analysis, predictive maintenance, decommissioning and quality assurance of PVs.

title: A Study on Microgrid System Planning for Convenience Stores Considering Energy Storage Dispatch Potential
authors: Chung I-Hua, Lee Kuo-Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: To address the challenges of global climate change and energy transition, the government of Taiwan has announced its commitment to achieving carbon neutrality by 2050, with a planned installation capacity of 20 GW for solar power and 5.6 GW for offshore wind. However, the integration of a high share of intermittent renewable energy sources poses significant threats to grid stability. To mitigate systemic risks, Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) has implemented various measures, including the launch of an electricity trading platform in 2021. This initiative encourages private investment in energy storage systems and participation in demand response programs, particularly to mitigate anticipated evening peak loads and prevent supply-demand imbalances. In northern Taiwan, where population density is high and land availability for power plant construction is limited, the traditional strategy has relied heavily on south-to-north power transmission. Nevertheless, the localized nature of renewable energy installations is gradually steering the power system toward distributed generation. Microgrid technologies have thus emerged as a key solution, offering advantages such as reduced line losses, enhanced energy autonomy, and decreased dependence on the main grid. Under conditions of heavy reliance on imported fuels, microgrids also play a crucial role in mitigating energy risk. Additionally, microgrids can feed power back to the main grid when necessary, functioning as backup systems to support grid stability while generating revenue from the sale of electricity. This study investigates the feasibility of implementing a microgrid system in a convenience store setting, integrating solar PV, wind power, and energy storage. Using the Homer software platform for renewable energy simulation, both technical and economic analyses are conducted to assess the system’s applicability in commercial electricity usage scenarios. The goal is to provide practical strategies and empirical insights to support Taiwan’s ongoing energy transition.

title: Investments in Residential Solar Panel-, Battery-and Energy Management Systems: Insights from the Belgian Market
authors: Steven De Meyer, Lies Debruyne, Cas Lavaert, Simon Ravyts, Jan Cappelle
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper presents a financial optimization framework for residential photovoltaic (PV), battery energy storage (BESS), and energy management systems (EMS), applied to 2,400 real-world Belgian household profiles with 15-minute resolution. For each profile, the PV and BESS sizes that maximize net present value (NPV) are determined, considering investment costs, technical constraints, and realistic tariff structures, including capacity-based charges.Thirty scenarios are evaluated in total, including 27 combinations of electricity tariffs and EMS configurations, as well as 3 scenarios with alternative BESS cost assumptions. Results show that PV is financially viable for most households without existing installations (90.9% at default prices), while BESS profitability is limited and highly cost-sensitive. EMS integration substantially improves NPV by shifting flexible loads and reducing peak demand, often eliminating the need for BESS.The findings support a phased investment strategy and highlight the importance of EMS functionality in enhancing the economic viability of residential energy systems.

title: IC Fault Diagnosis Using Bayesian Network and Simulated Annealing
authors: Linhan Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Fault diagnosis in integrated circuits (ICs) has become increasingly challenging due to the growing complexity of modern circuit designs, particularly in the presence of defects caused by scaling and environmental factors. Our approach begins with the construction of a Bayesian Network to model the probabilistic relationships between various components of the IC, capturing the dependencies and uncertainties inherent in the fault diagnosis process. Bayesian Networks provide a flexible framework for reasoning under uncertainty, which is essential for diagnosing faults in complex IC systems where diagnostic data is often incomplete or noisy. Once the network structure is established, Simulated Annealing is used to optimize the model's parameters, focusing on improving the fault localization accuracy and reducing the diagnostic errors. These datasets include various types of faults, ranging from stuck-at faults to open and short circuits, and they allow for a comprehensive evaluation of the proposed approach in both digital and analog fault diagnosis scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that our hybrid method achieves significant improvements in diagnostic performance compared to baseline techniques. Specifically, our method improves diagnostic accuracy by an average of 10 percentage points, with notable gains in fault localization precision and robustness under noisy conditions. Further analysis shows that the proposed model not only outperforms traditional methods, such as fault tree analysis and machine learning-based techniques, but also provides better scalability and computational efficiency, making it suitable for large-scale IC systems. In particular, the combination of Bayesian Networks and Simulated Annealing helps to overcome local optima, ensuring global optimization of the diagnostic process. The model's ability to handle uncertainty and incomplete data, coupled with its optimization-driven fault localization, provides a promising solution for real-time IC fault diagnosis in industrial applications. The proposed hybrid approach is capable of addressing the complexities of modern IC designs and offers a robust solution for both digital and analog fault diagnosis, making it a valuable contribution to the field of integrated circuit testing and maintenance.

title: A Secure Framework for Geofenced Data Encryption via Cryptographic Hashing and Multi-Channel Steganography
authors: Swati Jadhav, Adnaan Momin, Tejas Abhang, Akshat Gupta, Nirwani Adhau
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: This paper proposes a secure framework for geofenced data encryption that integrates cryptographic hashing and multi-channel steganography to enforce location-bound decryption. The system ensures that encrypted data can only be accessed when the user is physically present at authorized geographic coordinates, validated through cryptographic hash comparisons. A master encryption key is fragmented and concealed across multiple media files image, audio, video using least significant bit (LSB) steganography, while GPS coordinates are hashed with PBKDF2-HMAC-SHA256 and embedded within the image metadata. During decryption, the framework verifies the user’s location by comparing real-time GPS hashes with stored values and reconstructs the key only if all fragments are retrieved from the distributed steganographic carriers. The system demonstrates defense-in-depth security through three layers: geofencing via cryptographic hashing, key fragmentation, and multi-modal steganography. Experimental results show robust resistance to brute-force attacks, steganalysis, and location spoofing, making it suitable for applications requiring stringent physical-logical access control, such as military communications, IoT device security, and confidential document sharing.

title: Polymatroidal Representations of Aggregate EV Flexibility Considering Network Constraints
authors: Karan Mukhi, Alessandro Abate
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The increasing penetration of electric vehicles (EVs) introduces significant flexibility potential to power systems. However, uncoordinated or synchronous charging can lead to overloading of distribution networks. Extending recent approaches that utilize generalized polymatroids, a family of polytopes, to represent the aggregate flexibility of EV populations, we show how to integrate network constraints into this representation to obtain network-constrained aggregate flexibility sets. Furthermore, we demonstrate how to optimize over these network-constrained aggregate flexibility sets, and propose a disaggregation procedure that maps an aggregate load profile to individual EV dispatch instructions, while respecting both device-level and network constraints.

title: Optimization of Catenary Maintenance Using Multi-Strategy Improved Dung Beetle Optimization Algorithm
authors: Jie Chen, Shibin Gao, Long Yu, Yigu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: With the aging of catenary components, maintenance faces growing challenges. Addressing the lack of theoretical support and over-reliance on empirical maintenance scheduling, this paper proposes a dual-objective optimization model for imperfect maintenance strategies. A hybrid failure rate model describes reliability under imperfect maintenance, while opportunistic maintenance is introduced to establish the cost function. The dual-objective model minimizes maintenance cost and maximizes reliability by optimizing opportunistic maintenance reliability thresholds. An Multi-Strategy Improved Dung Beetle Optimization algorithm incorporating Bernoulli mapping, improved sine strategy, nonlinear convergence factors, and Gaussian-Cauchy mutation is developed for solution. Case studies demonstrate the model and algorithm effectively formulate economical and reliable maintenance plans, significantly improving strategy flexibility and practicality.

title: Integration with AI ML-Smart Decision Making Framework Enhanced Operational Efficiency, Flexi Integrate Optimization
authors: Jagadeesh Varrey
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Integration of Machine-Learning (ML) and Artificial-Intelligence (AI) into decision-making processes represents a paradigm shift in organizational operations, enabling data-driven insights at unprecedented speeds and accuracy. The paper presents the comprehensive framework of implementing AI/ML technologies to enhance decision-making across various industries. We examine the architectural components necessary for effective integration, including data preprocessing, model selection, and computational infrastructure. The proposed approach incorporates a novel query fragment caching algorithm that optimizes real-time decision support systems by reducing latency by up to 40% while maintaining 99.7% accuracy. Performance evaluation demonstrates that organizations implementing our framework achieve an average of 35% improvement in decision speed and 28% enhancement in outcomes compared to traditional methods. The paper also addresses critical challenges such as data quality, algorithmic bias, and computational complexity, offering solutions to mitigate these concerns. This research contributes of the evolving literature in intelligent systems by providing the practical architecture for leveraging AI/ML to transform decision-making processes in complex, data-rich environments.

title: Review of the flexibility potential in positive energy districts: opportunities and challenges
authors: Ville Sihvonen, Salla Annala
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Positive Energy Districts (PEDs) are an important part of urban areas' transition towards climate neutrality by promoting energy efficiency and integrating renewable energy sources, energy storage technologies, and load aggregation and management. This paper reviews the flexibility potential of PEDs, showing how they can provide important services to both the power and heat sectors. PEDs can participate in various energy and flexibility markets, offering benefits like better grid stability, peak demand management, and improved renewable energy integration. However, challenges like regulatory barriers, high initial costs, and the need for advanced technology and stakeholder coordination remain. This paper highlights successful practices from existing PED projects and proposes policy recommendations to overcome these challenges, aiming to support the wider adaptation of PEDs and further contribute to the EU's climate goals.

title: Classifying Adverse Voltage Control Interactions in Active Distribution Networks: A Brief Survey
authors: Hanchen Ge, Xiongfei Wang, Stefan Stankovic
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: With the increasing penetration of various voltage regulation devices in active distribution networks, the misalignment of control and modeling can lead to adverse voltage control interactions. To categorize these interactions and identify the existing challenges, this work presents a concise survey and proposes a classification scheme based on four key dimensions: modeling approaches, control strategies, timescales, and types of perturbations. First, the modeling and control methods of commonly used voltage regulation devices are reviewed and categorized. Next, the resulting adverse voltage control interactions are classified based on timescales and perturbations. Finally, the paper highlights research challenges and directions for researchers. It also serves as a reference for selecting proper stability assessment and control design method for grid operators.

title: Optimizing the Operating Strategy of Over-Installed Renewable Plants With Battery Storage Systems
authors: Lysandros Tziovani, Lenos Hadjidemetriou, Stelios Timotheou
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Producers of renewable plants can enhance their profits by submitting accurate production profiles to the day-ahead energy markets. However, potential deviations between day-ahead forecasts and actual power generation result in power imbalances, which are penalized in the balancing market. To address this issue, this work proposes an operating strategy for over-installed renewable plants with battery energy storage systems (BESSs) to reduce power imbalances and thereby enhance the profits of producers. Specifically, a linear optimization scheme is developed to minimize power deficits during real-time operation by scheduling the charging and discharging power set-points of the BESS. The proposed scheme is implemented within a model predictive control framework using updated renewable forecasts. Moreover, a secondary controller is integrated into the proposed approach to store the renewable generation that exceeds the maximum export limits, eliminating power generation curtailments. The proposed strategy is applied to a wind power plant using real data. Simulation results demonstrate the capability of the proposed operating strategy to yield high-quality solutions under power generation uncertainty, enhancing profits by 4.2% and reducing power imbalances by 17.8%.

title: Physics-Informed Neural Networks for Efficient Electric Field Modelling in Deep Brain Stimulation
authors: Timur Almeev, Jan Philipp Payonk, Sascha Spors, Ursula Van Rienen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: We propose a physics-informed neural network (PINN)-based framework for solving the electro-quasistatic field problem arising in deep brain stimulation (DBS) with high computational efficiency. Our approach achieves similar accuracy compared to conventional finite element simulations, offering significant potential for real-time prediction and parameter exploration. This makes it a promising tool for future applications in patient-specific DBS planning and hardware optimization.

title: Ensemble Model for Prediction of Protein Backbone Torsion Angles
authors: Srushti C S, Prathibhavani P.M, Venugopal K.R
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: The precise prediction of torsion angles in proteins is a critical aspect of understanding protein structure and function. The two rotational angles that correspond to the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{C} \alpha-\mathrm{N}$</tex> bond (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Phi$</tex>) and the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{C} \alpha-\mathrm{C}$</tex> bond <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\psi)$</tex> are identified as torsional angles within the protein backbone. The backbone geometry of proteins can be established using these two angles because of the planarity of the linked rigid peptide bonds. Deep learning is one of the computational techniques developed to anticipate the prediction of the torsion angles. However, the training time increases due to the increased processing requirements of these heavyweight approaches. The model EnsembleResnetFold which is an ensemble of Resnet_v2 architecture with Depth 20 and Depth 56 is trained. The Pearson coefficient between cosines of both angles (true values and predicted ones) are <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\operatorname{Cos}(\phi)$</tex> is 0.64 and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\operatorname{Cos}(\psi)$</tex> is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 7 3}$</tex>.

title:
CO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Conversion via Magnetic Field Stabilized Glow Discharge
authors: Zuixin Zeng, Yanzhao Ning, Xueqing Zhao, Yuexi Liu, Chuncheng Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: Currently, the conversion of CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> plasma faces challenges such as declining conversion rates under high flow velocities, poor stability, and the difficulty in balancing energy efficiency with processing capacity. This study introduces a magnetic field to the conventional gliding arc (GA) discharge and finds that the magnetically stabilized gliding arc (with the magnetic field oriented along the -x axis) significantly enhances both the CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> conversion rate and disturbance resistance. The conversion rate increased by over 40% compared to the traditional GA and by more than 15% compared to the magnetically accelerated gliding arc (with the magnetic field along the +x axis). This research offers a feasible approach to address the issues of stability and scalability in CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> conversion, contributing to the industrialization of plasma-assisted carbon conversion technology.

title: High efficiency, cost effective, current source inverter for microgrid photovoltaic generators
authors: Salvatore Foti, Gioele Baia, Danilo Campagna, Salvatore Morello Baganella, Giacomo Scelba, Antonio Testa, Gaetano Turrisi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper proposes a two-stage current source inverter designed for photovoltaic generators operating in microgrids. Zero current switching for the IGBTs of the inverter is achieved through a synergistic coordination between their operation and that of a SiC MOSFET used in the step-up DC-DC converter interfacing the PV modules and the inverter. This is tasked of maximum power point tracking and to stabilize the inverter input current. The proposed architecture is evaluated through simulations and compared with three traditional configurations: one fully based on IGBT devices and two using SiC MOSFETs. The results indicate that the proposed configuration represents a promising alternative for high-efficiency, cost-effective photovoltaic generators for applications in microgrids.

title: Research and Design of Portable Heart Rate Detection System Based on STC89C52
authors: Qiyuan Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: This design takes the STC89C52 single-chip microcomputer as the core controller and cooperates with the LM016L liquid crystal module to achieve real-time heart rate and threshold display. The alarm threshold can be set through the key circuit. When an abnormal heart rate is detected, the buzzer will sound an alarm. In the software design, a three-level anti-interference algorithm of “continuous three-pulse confirmation - continuous detection - threshold alarm” was introduced, which effectively improved the measurement accuracy and anti-interference ability. The feasibility of the system was verified by using Proteus simulation, and it demonstrated low error and high repeatability stability under different environmental conditions in physical tests. This design is small in size, low in cost and easy to carry, making it suitable for heart rate monitoring in daily environments.

title: Assessment of “Reduced Basis” Formulations for Electromagnetic Finite Element Tearing and Interconnecting (FETI) Frequency Sweeps Simulations of Large Reconfigurable Transmit Arrays Antennas
authors: André Barka, François Xavier Roux, Alessandro De Oliveira Cabral
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Electromagnetic simulation in the frequency domain of large arrays using metamaterials can be extremely computationally expensive if the frequency sampling required is very fine. We explore here the benefits of the Reduced Basis (RB) algorithms to address problem sizes that are inaccessible with commercial solvers as CST Microwave Studio of HFSS, and even more so for simulations with a very fine frequency discretization (Fig. 1). The FETI-2LM domain decomposition methods (DDM) developed at ONERA for electromagnetic wave problems (FACTOPO_FEM-FETI code) have recently been enhanced by advances in the use of RB algorithms. We will briefly present the theoretical foundations of the reduced basis method and focus our presentation on FETI-2LM simulations of high-gain circularly polarized (CP) transmit-array (TA) antennas in the X and Ka bands. The benefits of RB will be examined in the context of frequency sweeps during gain and axial ratio calculations.

title: Intelligent HVAC Monitoring for Energy Efficiency via LSTM Autoencoder-Based Outlier Detection Model
authors: Lakshmaiya N
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: The estimation of energy consumption by Heating. Ventilation, Air conditioning systems (HVAC) in smart buildings account for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 0 - 5 0 \%}$</tex>. The energy efficiency of the energy consumed plays a significant role in reducing operational costs, greenhouse gas emissions, and overall system costs. Inorder to find the energy draining issues in the HVAC systems, the deviations are need to be carefully notice in the real time measuring parameters. Therefore, innovative HVAC systems that integrate the Internet of Things (IoT), intelligent decision-making algorithms, and decision support systems are necessary for this purpose. Hence, the proposed system focuses on improving the energy efficiency of Smart HVAC systems through real-time data analysis and anomaly detection using the LSTM Autorencoder. LSTM-Autonecoder efficiently detects deviations in real-time series data by computing the reconstruction error and validating it against a threshold value. The proposed work is validated using the HVAC anomaly detection dataset from Mendley, which achieved 94.6% precision accuracy with an AU-ROC of 0.964, and resulted in an energy optimisation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0. 5 \%}$</tex> more efficient than traditional models.

title: Home Energy Management using End-to-End Learning
authors: Patrick J. Hernandez Ureña, Esmeralda M. Kramer, Jordan C.J. de Windt, Reinier L. C. van der Horst, Flin Verdaasdonk, Marco E. T. Gerards
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Home Energy Management Systems (HEMS) are used to control devices in households to improve among others efficiency, costs, and comfort. This paper investigates the use of an end-to-end learning pipeline to operate a HEMS that controls a battery to minimize costs. The end-to-end pipeline optimizes forecasting neural networks to minimize the objective of a downstream linear program. The end-to-end pipeline is compared against a classical pipeline which is trained solely to minimize forecast error, as well as against the optimal performance computed assuming perfect forecasts. The result of this comparison shows that end-to-end learning reduces the gap between traditional forecasting and the optimal performance using perfect forecasts by 9.25%, while also being more stable. This demonstrates the potential of end-to-end learning in the context of Home Energy Management.

title: Remote-Controlled Autonomous Weed Detection and Elimination using Deep Learning
authors: Srihari Krishna, Rachana GB, Harshith PVS, Revathi GP, Prasad B Honnavalli
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Weed infestations in agricultural fields is a major factor contributing to reduced crop yields and increased production costs. With recent advancements in smart farming and automation, machine learning techniques along with IOT have emerged as powerful tools for precision agriculture. Weed presence in agricultural lands is one of the main reasons for lost productivity and efficiency for the growth of plants. Unfortunately, current methods of weed detection and elimination are not accessible to most farms or too expensive to replicate. This paper presents a remotecontrolled weed detection and elimination system designed specifically for potato crops. By utilizing low-cost components such as Raspberry Pi and Arduino we minimize the cost as well as make the system more scalable. To enhance real-time weed detection, we employ YOLOv4 and YOLOv5 models comparing their accuracy and precision. Additionally, we also conduct a literature-based performance review of Faster RCNN and YOLOv3 models highlighting the trade-offs in speed and accuracy.

title: Performance Evaluation of Classification Multi Algorithms on Small Dataset: A Comparative-Based Analysis
authors: Agus Wantoro, Zulkifli, Panji Bintoro, Tahta Herdian Andika, Ferly Ardhy, Arif Nurul Al Aziz
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: This research aims to evaluate and compare the performance of various classification algorithms under conditions of small dataset quantity. Six algorithms were tested, namely NaÏve Bayes, Support Vector Machine (SVM), Decision Tree, Random Forest, AdaBoost, and k-NN against three small-scale public datasets from different domains. The experiments were conducted using cross-validation techniques (k-fold=5), and evaluations were performed based on the confusion matrix for performance accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, AUC, and model computation time. The results of the study show that the Naive Bayes algorithm excels in all feature number datasets. The SVM and Random Forest algorithms excel in all feature text, while Random Forest and Naive Bayes excel in mix feature. Each user should choose an algorithm that is tailored to the data used. Additionally, the use of Cross-Validation has proven to provide a more reliable performance estimation. This finding provides practical recommendations for researchers and practitioners in selecting effective classification algorithms for small-scale datasets, as well as highlighting the importance of validation techniques and data processing in improving model generalization under data limitations.

title: Leveraging k-Weighted Dominating Set for Graph Sparsification
authors: Zamrud Mahfur Abdillah, Lucia Ratnasari, Adi Wibowo, Bayu Surarso
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: As real-world networks grow in size and complexity, large graphs present significant computational challenges. Graph sparsification is a common strategy for addressing this by reducing the number of edges while preserving the essential structure. Existing methods are mostly edge-centric and rely on global metrics such as edge connectivity. This paper proposes a vertex-centric framework that preserves dominant neighborhoods using the k-Weighted Dominating Set (k-WDS) approach. Our approach retains all edges incident to the selected set, with the Iterated Greedy (IG) heuristic used to approximate the NP-hard minimum k-WDS problem. Theoretical analysis shows that k-WDS sparsification maintains connectivity and provides formal bounds on feasible <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex> values. Experiments on the Cora and PubMed datasets demonstrate that this method offers a tunable and effective preprocessing step for graph neural networks.

title: Scattering of TM- and TE-Plane Waves Obliquely Incident on Slotted PEC Cylinders with Surfaces Parameterized by the Super-Ellipse Equation
authors: Elena D. Vinogradova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: The super-ellipse equation defines contours with a wide variety of shapes of practical engineering interest. This paper examines electromagnetic wave scattering by infinitely long, perfectly electrically conducting cylinders, of constant crosssection given by the super-ellipse equation, in which a slot is opened. Both polarizations are considered. The rigorous Method of Analytical Regularization is employed to produce solutions of guaranteed accuracy and to determine the associated complex eigenvalues. The effect, on both reflectivity and the complex eigenvalues, of shallow and more pronounced corrugation in these classes of structures is examined.

title: Private Returns on Technology Adoption
authors: Shane Greenstein
publish: IEEE Micro

title: An Urban Data Management Platform for Bridging Trusted Ecosystems, Dataspaces, and Digital Twins
authors: Iason Sotiropoulos, Ioannis Karvelas, Elissaios Sarmas, Stamatia Rizou, Vangelis Marinakis
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: In the domain of smart cities, Urban Data Platforms can enable the operation of digital services that rely on heterogeneous data sources, with the goal of enhancing the experience and well-being of citizens, as well as promoting sustainability and economic prosperity. In the present work, we demonstrate the Urban Data Management Platform, an orchestration of multiple software components that provides mechanisms related to the effective data and metadata management and storage, user authentication, while also aligning with interoperability standards. The demonstrated work provides a conceptual architecture of the platform and a technical implementation. In particular, we provide a high level architecture for the emerging urban data ecosystem, encompassing the links between urban data platforms, data spaces and urban digital twins. The implementation of the proposed Urban Data Management Platform leverages open source components, covering aspects related to data storage, user authentication and data space compliance. The resulting platform is tested as a core data enabler for urban geo-spatial services and digital twin applications in the context of the BUILDPSACE project. Future work on the platform will focus on interoperability and further alignment with data space principles.

title: Smart and Ready? A Comparative Analysis of Seven EU Countries' Preparedness for Adopting the Smart Readiness Indicator Scheme
authors: Alexandros Xenakis, Apostolos Arsenopoulos, Georgios Maximos Paliatsos, Iason C. Dimitriou, John Psarras
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: The European Union's climate and energy policies, including the European Green Deal and the European Climate Law, emphasise the urgent need for building sector transformation to meet greenhouse gas emission reduction targets. Smart buildings, enabled by Information and Communication Technologies, play a crucial role in enhancing energy efficiency, user comfort, and grid flexibility. The Smart Readiness Indicator, introduced under the revised Energy Performance of Buildings Directive, is a tool for evaluating a building's capacity to promote energy performance, respond to the needs of occupants, and interact with the energy grid. This study explores the readiness of seven European Union countriesr—Greece, Spain, Czechia, Latvia, Bulgaria, Romania, and Croatia—to adopt and implement the Smart Readiness Indicator framework. A Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis approach, specifically the TOPSIS method, is employed, incorporating social, political, economic, and technological indicators, in order to rank these countries in terms of their SRI readiness level. The Smart Readiness Indicator assessment methodology is examined in depth, highlighting its structure, scoring process, and evaluation techniques. Through a coherent set of criteria and comparative analysis, this research identifies the strengths and barriers in each country's legislative framework, public awareness, and renewable energy engagement. The results aim to support policymakers and stakeholders in tailoring national strategies for the effective rollout of the Smart Readiness Indicator and broader smart building initiatives.

title: FedSAE-HS: Hybrid Anomaly Scoring for Semi-Supervised Federated Intrusion Detection
authors: Linh Chu Thi, Van Thi Bich Pham, Trung Ngo Van, Ly Vu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising paradigm for collaborative network intrusion/anomaly detection in distributed systems, particularly under privacy constraints and data decentralization. Recent semi-supervised FL approaches with autoencoders (AEs) have shown strong potential in this setting. Nevertheless, many of these methods rely on only a single scoring signal, such as reconstruction error (RE) or latent representation z, which often results in unstable detection. To address this, we propose an enhanced federated anomaly detection framework named as Federated Learning with Hybrid Scoring based Shrink AutoEncoder (FedSAE-HS) that applies both RE and latent vector z for calculating an anomaly score. The hybrid scoring strategy allows the model to be sensitive to subtle anomalies, improving detection stability and generalization. We evaluate FedSAE-HS on two benchmark IDS datasets, N-BaIoT and WSN_DS, against four existing federated anomaly detection frameworks. Experimental results show that FedSAEHS achieves superior performance in AUC, Precision, Recall, F1-score, and False Positive Rate, while converging more stably, confirming the effectiveness of the proposed hybrid scoring strategy for semi-supervised federated anomaly detection.

title: Hallucinations in Generative AI: Epistemic Risks for Learners in Educational Applications
authors: Maria Virvou, George A. Tsihrintzis, Evangelia-Aikaterini Tsichrintzi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: Hallucinations in generative AI refer to outputs that are linguistically well-formed but factually incorrect. In educational contexts, such content poses a critical epistemic risk, as it may be mistakenly accepted as accurate, especially by learners and, to a lesser degree, by instructors. This paper introduces a formal Venn-theoretic framework to model the interaction among four knowledge domains: factual knowledge (D), AI-generated content (G), and student's knowledge (S). The model identifies user-centred epistemic states, such as when learners learn and assimilate hallucinated content, which constitute what we term as epistemic risks that are due to Generative AI hallucinations within the educational process. These states are formalised as distinct regions within the Venn space, supporting both descriptive modelling of observed behaviour and normative analysis of ideal conditions. By focusing on the human-AI interface in educational use, the framework offers a structured approach to analysing how misinformation propagates through cognitive and instructional flows. It also informs the design of mitigation strategies, including instructor oversight, content verification, and alignment with emerging regulatory risk frameworks.

title: Smart Choices for Industrial Decarbonization: Impact of Electricity Grid Connection on Risk and Sizing of Photovoltaic-Electrolyzer Systems
authors: Stefan Niederhofer, Marcus Rennhofer, René Hofmann
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Industrial decarbonization and the transition to sustainable energy sources present a critical challenge. This study addresses the fundamental trade-off between energy independence and system efficiency in photovoltaic (PV)-electrolyzer systems. We investigated the impact of electricity grid connection on the risk and sizing of PV-electrolyzer systems for industrial energy supply. A multi-method approach was applied, combining fault tree analysis of grid-connected and stand-alone configurations with a system sizing model based on an industrial demand profile. Results revealed that grid fault contributed minimally to total system risk, whereas off-grid configurations demanded oversizing of PV and electrolyzer capacities — up to 17× and 6× the average demand, respectively. The findings suggest that while off-grid systems are technically feasible, their complexity and cost (levelized cost of hydrogen ~ 15 $/kg H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) raise questions about practicality under standard conditions. This study provides guidance for strategic decisions around grid dependency, system robustness, and sustainable design in industrial decarbonization.

title: AI-Driven Back Support Exoskeletons for Agricultural Workers: A Comprehensive Review of Biomechanical Load Reduction and Intelligent Control Systems
authors: Gurjeet Kaur, Irshad Qureshi, Ashutosh Bagde
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Agricultural work involves extensive manual labour with a high prevalence of work-related musculoskeletal disorders (WMSDs), particularly low back pain (LBP) affecting 58% of farm workers globally. Integrating artificial intelligence (AI) with wearable robotic systems presents a transformative opportunity to address occupational health challenges while enhancing agricultural productivity. This comprehensive review synthesises recent advancements in AI-driven back support exoskeletons specifically designed for agricultural applications, evaluating their biomechanical efficacy in reducing lumbosacral loads during farm-specific tasks. The analysis covers intelligent control strategies, machine learning (ML)-based adaptation algorithms, sensor fusion techniques, and real-time biofeedback systems integrated into modern agricultural exoskeletons. Multiple studies demonstrate significant electromyographic (EMG) reductions ranging from 17% to 65% in laboratory settings and 35% to 56% in field trials. AI-driven systems show superior adaptation to varying agricultural tasks compared to conventional designs. The review reveals that intelligent exoskeletons with crop-specific programming, terrain adaptation, and predictive load assistance significantly reduce injury risk while maintaining productivity in farming operations. The convergence of AI technology and wearable robotics represents a critical advancement toward sustainable, worker-centric farming practices.

title: Methodology for Managing Medical Images, based on the DICOM Standard
authors: Juan Carlos Gálvez-Canchari, Wilver Auccahuasi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Information and communications technologies are enabling the use of various devices in medical diagnostic processes. Proof of this can be seen in the various devices currently available that record images used to aid in the diagnosis of conditions such as skin cancer, using optical cameras that record the affected area, Thermal images are recorded using thermal cameras that capture the thermal behaviour of the accepted area, as well as fundus images, which are widely used in the diagnosis of pathologies present in the retina, such as diabetic retinopathy. In this article, we develop a methodology that can manage fundus, thermal, and skin cancer-related images using the recommendations of the DICOM standard, which consists of including metadata such as data on the equipment used to record the image, data on the doctor who recommended the examination, data on the image record, data on the image request, and data on the date of the image record. This data is generated in an application so that it can be stored in a PostgreSQL database, designed to fulfil the functionality of a PACS medical image server, Using optimisation and data storage management techniques, we present the database structure, image management processes such as image registration, storage and retrieval, demonstrating the operability and practicality of the proposal. As conclusions, we present how the methodology can be exploited, enabling the configuration of PACS servers in private or low-resource health centres to purchase commercial licences, as well as integration and interoperability with commercial PACS systems.

title: Inferring Surface Susceptibilities for Mask-Based Metasurface Beam Shaping Using Deep Learning
authors: Chen Niu, Mario Phaneuf, Puyan Mojabi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This work presents a deep learning-based framework for the macroscopic design of transmissive metasurfaces to enable the transformation of a given incident wave into a farfield power pattern that resides within a user-defined mask. This neural network then directly generates the required metasurface properties, known as surface susceptibilities, that (i) satisfy reciprocity, losslessness, and passivity conditions, and (ii) result in high transmission efficiency. An important part of this neural network is a fast metasurface forward solver, known as the implicit IE-GSTC method, that combines the generalized sheet transition conditions (GSTCs) with the integral equation (IE) formulation to calculate the metasurface scattering response. The achieved macroscopic designs show promising results under the ideal zerothickness scenario. However, the far-field performance degrades as the zero-thickness model is converted into a finite-thickness three-layered model. This discrepancy may be attributed to the assumption of perpendicular wave propagation in the generation of our utilized finite-thickness metasurface model.

title: Explainable DeepFake Detection: Comparative Analysis of CNN and Transformer Architecture with XAI
authors: Muhammad Kamran, Muhammad Usman Ghani
publish: 2025 IEEE 19th International Conference on Open Source Systems and Technologies (ICOSST)
abstract: The development of DeepFake media poses a significant danger to digital safety, citizen trust, and the precision of the forensics. The fix to the problem is to possess a performance of detection that is high enough and trust to the process. In this paper, the ResNet50 and the Vision Transformer (ViT) would be compared in image detection of DeepFake using two existing datasets. To help in the interpretability of the model predictions, we apply explainable AI (XAI) models LIME and SHAP to discover what areas of the face mattered in the model predictions. The results of the experiment indicate that ResNet50 achieves the accuracy of 99.15, F1-score of 99.15, and the area under the curve (AUC) of 99.9. ViT also works even better with $99.3 \%$ accuracy, $99.9 \%$ F1-score, and $99.9 \%$ AUC. After the analysis of the confusion matrices, it was found that ViT was more resistant to subtle changes, which may be explained by its self-attention mechanism, which helped it consider relationships between faces on a global scale. Another level of confidence was also used, which XAI represents the fact that the models were examining meaningful facial locations, enhancing model interpretability and user trust. In general, the presented work reflects a detection framework, which is credible and clear-cut in its methodology, which eventually results in the state-of-theart findings in a key consumer trust application, which connects performance and explanation.

title: Reconstruction of Objects at Cell Scale from Microscope Images with Inverse Scattering Algorithm
authors: Yingying Qin, Yu Zhong, Krishna Agarwal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Reconstruction of biological samples from microscopic images by solving inverse scattering problem poses significant computational challenges in real applications. We propose an efficient inversion strategy that utilizes off-axis illumination to capture dark-field images from multiple angles. To manage the computational burden, the region of interest is divided into subregions, where Born approximation provides an initial guess. Nonlinear inverse algorithms are then used in each subregion, incorporating the influence from neighboring subregions. Additionally, computational efficiency is enhanced by truncating the far-field Green's function when the transverse distance between the source and observation points is large, transforming the scattered field calculation into a convolution operation. This approach can reduce memory usage while maintaining inversion performance. which makes large-scale inverse scattering simulations more practical for biological imaging applications.

title: Loop Radius Optimization for High-Efficiency Wireless Power Transfer System
authors: Zhou Na, Zhengliang Fu, Junxi Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: Wireless power transfer (WPT) offers practical solutions in modern power systems for electric vehicle(EV) charging, smart grid integration, and consumer electronics by providing efficient and contactless energy delivery. This paper focuses on designing a high-efficiency WPT system based on magnetic resonance coupling (MRC). While conventional studies improve efficiency by adjusting the distance between the driving loop and the transmit coil, this paper highlights a novel method of enhancing efficiency through radius optimization of the driving loop. By tuning the loop radius according to different transfer distances, the system achieves improved coupling coefficient and higher efficiency. Experimental results confirm that the proposed method achieves a relative improvement of approximately 38% over the baseline system efficiency, while maintaining consistent performance across various transmission distances. The proposed radius-tuning approach provides a simple yet effective means of optimizing coil geometry without requiring complex control strategies or system modifications, offering promising applicability for wireless charging of electric vehicles and consumer electronics.

title: Acceptance of AI in Philippine Higher Education: Exploring the Role of Perceived Interactivity, Satisfaction, and Value on ChatGPT Use Among Manila Undergraduates
authors: Lianna Wijaya, Lourdes Lasian, Sudip Wagle, Shiyrah Theosebes Sela, Aries Aries, Sylvia Samuel
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) platforms, such OpenAI's ChatGPT, are currently being integrated into educational environments, offering customized assistance, improved efficiency, and engaging learning experiences. This study aims to examine the determinants influencing undergraduate students' intention to utilize ChatGPT and its subsequent impact on actual usage behaviour. The research focuses on four constructs: Perceived Interactivity, Perceived Innovativeness, Perceived Satisfaction, and Perceived Value, along with their relationship to Intention to Use and User Behaviour. A quantitative research methodology was employed for obtaining responses from 256 undergraduate students in Metro Manila. The data was evaluated using SmartPLS to assess the measurement and structural models, confirming validity and reliability through indicators including factor loadings, Cronbach's alpha, composite reliability, and AVE. Results indicate that Perceived Innovativeness, Satisfaction, and Value substantially affect the tendency for using ChatGPT, although Perceived Interactivity does not. Furthermore, the intention to use is a robust predictor of actual user behaviour. This study extends the literature on AI adoption by broadening the UTAUT framework within a generative AI setting and provides practical insights for educators, developers, and institutions to optimize the integration of ChatGPT for enhanced educational outcomes.

title: Plasma Signatures of Small Orbital Debris in LEO
authors: Gian Luca Delzanno, Pedro Resendiz Lira, Salomon Janhunen, Justin Holmes, Daniil Svyatsky
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: A modeling study of the plasma signatures of an orbital debris moving at hypersonic velocities in low-Earth orbit is presented. Our findings highlight the importance of accurately describing debris-plasma interaction (i.e. debris charging) and kinetic damping physics.

title: Data-Driven Compute Overlays for Interactive Geographic Simulation and Visualization
authors: Patrick Komon, Gerald Kimmersdorfer, Adam Celarek, Manuela Waldner
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: We present interactive data-driven compute overlays for native and web-based 3D geographic map applications based on WebGPU. Our data-driven overlays are generated in a multi-step compute workflow from multiple data sources on the GPU. We demonstrate their potential by showing results from snow cover and avalanche simulations, where simulation parameters can be adjusted interactively and results are visualized instantly. Benchmarks show that our approach can compute large-scale avalanche simulations in milliseconds to seconds, depending on the size of the terrain and the simulation parameters, which is multiple orders of magnitude faster than a state-of-the-art Python implementation.

title: Student Grade Prediction Through GitLab Logs
authors: Vasiliki Karamerou, Dimitrios J. Vergados, Angelos Michalas, Dimitrios D. Vergados
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: Predicting the final grades of university students during the semester, is believed to be an important tool for implementing timely interventions, such as interviews by the professors or the academic mentors, that may lead to an improvement of the academic performance, and in a decrease in the student failure rate. The topic of grade prediction has been studied in the literature, using various machine learning methods. This paper focuses on grade prediction, and its originality stems from the use of a dataset from the GitLab server that was used by the students for uploading and automatically grading the assignments, along with the corresponding grades. The dataset includes a sample of 375 students enrolled in the “Web Programming” course in the Department of Informatics, University of Western Macedonia, Greece. The results show the performance of different machine learning algorithms in terms of the accuracy of the predicted grades, which is approximately 1.5 in scale of 10 in terms of mean absolute error, indicating that the use of the above methodology is has promising potential.

title: CMT-BMC: A Convolutional Multi-Head Transformer Model for Bone Marrow Classification
authors: Arthi C S, Chellaswamy C, Nallathambi A, Umamaheswari K, Thiruvalarselvan P, Raja E
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Bone marrow classification is essential for diagnosing hematological diseases such as leukemia. However, traditional methods rely heavily on expert analysis, making them timeconsuming and inconsistent. Deep learning models, particularly Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), have improved classification accuracy but often struggle to capture both the global dependencies and local cellular structures in complex bone marrow images. To resolve these issues, we propose CMTBMC, a Convolutional Multi-Head Transformer model that combines the powerful multi-head attention mechanism of Transformers with the feature extraction capabilities of CNNs. Our approach effectively captures fine-grained details while maintaining contextual relationships across the image. We evaluate CMT-BMC on the AML-Cytomorphology labeled dataset, consisting of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 8, 3 6 5}$</tex> bone marrow cell images covering multiple leukemia subtypes. Using transfer learning and data augmentation, our model achieves an precision of 97.1 %, recall of 96.4 %, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score of 95.8 %, surpassing existing CNNbased and Vision Transformer models. Additionally, the multihead self-attention mechanism enhances interpretability by highlighting diagnostically relevant cellular features. The results demonstrate that CMT-BMC significantly improves classification performance, offering a robust and efficient AIdriven solution for automated bone marrow analysis. This advancement has the potential to enhance early leukemia diagnosis and assist hematologists in clinical decision-making.

title: Exposing ToS-Based Traffic Manipulation with Deep Learning Models
authors: Christos Christodoulou, Emmanouil Mavrikos, Christos Kalloniatis, George Tsekouras
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: Contemporary Ethernet networks rely on traffic classification techniques based on packet labeling fields such as the Type of Service (ToS). These mechanisms, while effective in prioritizing latency-sensitive flows, are vulnerable to manipulation. Malicious actors can falsely label low-priority traffic as highpriority (e.g., Voice or Video), thereby gaining unfair access to bandwidth and degrading network fairness. This study introduces a machine learning approach for anomaly detection, leveraging behavioral attributes of packets-such as size, interarrival time, and protocol port-to identify suspicious misclassifications. A comprehensive dataset was generated using the D-ITGBox traffic creation tool, emulating audio (G.721), video (H.264), background (ICMP), and best-effort (HTTP/Telnet) flows. Additionally, two anomalous datasets were synthesized by modifying the ToS fields of background and best-effort traffic to falsely represent them as voice and video, respectively. Three deep learning models-Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLP), and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks-were trained and evaluated across 50 randomized iterations. Performance metrics including accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score were analyzed. To validate performance differences, non-parametric statistical tests (Friedman and Wilcoxon) were applied. Results revealed that LSTM achieved superior recall and F1-score, indicating robust detection of sequential anomalies, while MLP excelled in precision. CNN demonstrated balanced but more variable performance. The findings advocate the application of deep learning models for Ethernet-based anomaly detection and set the groundwork for hybrid approaches and deployment in real-time environments.

title: An Analytical Model for Electromagnetic Force of PMSM with Auxiliary Slot
authors: Fan Wang, Caiyong Ye, Yunfeng Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: Radial electromagnetic force waves are a primary cause of noise in Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor (PMSM). Introducing auxiliary slots into the stator teeth can weaken certain harmonic of electromagnetic force (EMF). However, calculating the EMF for PMSM with auxiliary slots is complex. For this problem, the finite element (FE) method requires a large amount of computing resources and time. This paper establishes an analytical model of the EMF for PMSM with auxiliary slots. First, the auxiliary slot subdomain is added. By combining the vector field general solutions of each subdomain and listing the boundary conditions, the calculation formulas for EMF are obtained. Then, the calculation results of the proposed model are compared with the FE simulation results to systematically verify the accuracy and applicability of the model under different working conditions. Finally, the effects of auxiliary slot parameters are studied in combination with the proposed model. The research in this paper provides theoretical basis and technical reference for effectively suppressing the electromagnetic vibration and noise of PMSM.

title: Application of Artificial Intelligence Technology in Electromagnetic Research of High-Speed Maglev Trains
authors: Shi Xiao, Zhiqiang Zhang, Qingpeng Feng, Yongxia Liu, Jinbao Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: With the continuous advancement of high-speed maglev train technology, electromagnetic environment modeling and electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) optimization have become critical to ensuring system stability and operational safety. Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology, renowned for its powerful data processing, pattern recognition, and optimization capabilities, has demonstrated significant potential in the field of electromagnetic research. Based on the Shanghai highspeed maglev experimental project, this paper investigates the application of AI technology in electromagnetic research, with a focus on its roles in electromagnetic environment modeling, EMC optimization, interference immunity design, and electromagnetic radiation impact analysis. Through an in-depth examination of experimental data acquisition equipment installation and sensor wiring layout, the study further explores how AI can enhance design optimization and improve testing accuracy. Research findings show that AI technology can substantially enhance the efficiency of electromagnetic environment modeling and interference source analysis, offering broad prospects for application in this domain.

title: Global Extrema Bias Perception and Recall of Average Data Values in Line Charts
authors: Tejas Savalia, Andrew Lovett, Cristina Ceja, Rosemary Cowell, Cindy Xiong Bearfield
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: Experiments in visualization perception demonstrate that people can perceive positions highly accurately. However, position encodings can be susceptible to systematic biases depending on the intrinsic properties of the visualized data, such as its shape and cognitive processes of memory and perception. Using line charts as a case study, we investigate how the shape of data, such as local and global extrema, can bias the perception and recall of average data values. In two studies, participants estimated the average data values in a line chart by adjusting a slider with their mouse. We found that participants’ estimates were systematically biased toward the direction of the global extremum. When multiple salient extrema were present, estimates appeared influenced by several extrema simultaneously but ultimately leaned toward the global extremum. Notably, the strength of this bias varied depending on whether participants were perceiving or recalling the mean. This work advances our understanding of how extrema influence perception and memory, potentially exaggerating or underestimating critical trends and contributing to a skewed interpretation of data. These findings offer valuable guidance for the design of narrative visualization tools and data storytelling strategies.

title: Integration of User Interface, Usability, and User Experience Evaluation Methods in Software Development Life Cycle: A Conceptual Model
authors: Hafidza Safara Zahratunnisa, Harry B. Santoso, Panca O. Hadi Putra
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: In software development, the evaluation of the user interface (UI), usability, and user experience (UX) plays a critical role in creating a successful implementation for the user. However, the assessment of these aspects often remains fragmented, causing a significant gap between comprehensive academic theories and the pragmatic, resource-constrained practices of industry professionals. This research aims to bridge this gap by developing a conceptual model that systematically integrates UI, usability, and UX evaluation methods into the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC). We adopted a qualitative approach, beginning with a literature review and strengthened by semi-structured interviews with ten industry experts to gain an understanding of current practices. The proposed model addresses these issues by mapping specific evaluation types to holistic assessments by distinct SDLC phases. This model consists of two principles: attitudes and behaviors, which operate in a continuous, iterative cycle. While this model provides a strong foundation, we recommend further validation through real-world case studies to enhance its reliability and practical utility.

title: Development of Interactive Online Magazine Based on Data Visualization with Google Data Studio in Tulang Bawang Regency
authors: M. Fauzi Rais, M. Fitrah Ramadhan, M. Yashlan Iskandar, M. Said Hasibuan
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: This research aims to develop an interactive online magazine based on data visualization using Google Looker Studio as a means of presenting regional statistical information that is informative and easily understood by the public. This online magazine presents regional profiles, economic potential, education, health, tourism, and public services in the form of dynamic dashboards and attractive visuals. The system development method uses a prototyping approach, including needs analysis, interface design, dashboard implementation, and testing by respondents. Evaluation was conducted using the System Usability Scale (SUS) and User Experience Questionnaire (UEQ) methods to 30 respondents from various backgrounds. The SUS evaluation results show an average score of 79.75, falling into the Excellent category, while the UEQ results show that all dimensions of attractiveness, clarity, efficiency, reliability, stimulation, and novelty received positive scores, although some still require improvement, especially in the aspects of design and innovative features. This responsive dashboard can also be accessed through mobile devices and is designed to improve local government data transparency as well as community participation in development. This research makes a real contribution to the utilization of data visualization technology for e-government and regional digitalization.

title: Smart E-Vehicle Charging Station Finder Integrated using GPS, LSTM Model and Battery State Prediction
authors: Suganya D, Vaishali P S, Saparna S, Gomathi V, Santhosh R, Naveen C S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: The growth of Electric Vehicles (EVs) over gasoline-powered vehicles can be directly attributed to global efforts to eliminate carbon emissions and advancements in automotive technology. Most approaches commonly rely on State of Health (SOH) and State of Charge (SOC) methods to estimate battery storage. A significant problem was identified: when the battery level is low, there is no reliable method to identify the nearest charging station. In order to get around this restriction, a new function was added that uses GPS tracking to direct users to the nearest charging station in real time. In a situation where people driving on bypass roads use GPS to locate the best EV charging stations. The main objective is to provide a model that offers a live guide for finding the closest EV charging station. When applied in paired with traffic simulations, the method can be extremely helpful for service providers, allowing them to efficiently optimize the positioning of charging stations through model performance and assessment.

title: Vehicle-to-Grid Power Exchange Optimization for Sustainable Electric Vehicle Charging Operations
authors: G. Ramkumar, P. Arun Nambi, B. Pattabhi Ram, Maram Y. Al-Safarini, Sumana Das, Ramya M
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: The rapid rise of electric vehicles (EVs) has drastically raised the requirement for effective charging infrastructure that has put a lot of stress on the power grids we have now. Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) technology could be the answer because it lets energy flow in both directions between EVs and the grid. This assists in keeping the grid stable while making it simpler to use energy from the sun and wind. The current study aims to enhance V2G power transmission for prolonged EV charging operations through the implementation of intricate time scheduling, load management, as well as energy trading algorithms. To keep the battery healthy, a framework over multi-objective optimization is made to minimize peak demand, lower charging costs, and to make the most of renewable energy. The proposed system employs real-time information about the grid, predictions of how much renewable energy will be generated, and dynamic pricing structures to keep the flow of electricity balanced. The simulation results show that the optimization technique makes the grid considerably more dependable, cuts down on expenses, and helps cut down on carbon emissions when compared to standard unidirectional charging systems. The results demonstrate that optimizing based on V2G could be a key part of making energy ecosystems smarter and more sustainable. This would help make cities smarter and more eco-friendly, as well as make electricity networks stronger.

title: Handling Multi-objective Problems On Hybrid Komodo Mlipir Algorithm and Circle Search Algorithm Using Non-dominated Sorting Approach
authors: Alifya Fatimah Ariyanto, Aina Musdholifah
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: In everyday life, many problems require optimization, often involving multiple conflicting objective functions that must be addressed simultaneously. For example, a phone company wants to improve the camera quality while trying to minimize the production cost at the same time. Numerous algorithms have been proposed to address multi-objective optimization problems. However, the “No Free Lunch” theorem states that no single algorithm can solve all problems equally well. KMA and CSA are two algorithms that have shown effectiveness in solving optimization problems; however, their applications remain limited to single-objective problems. This study presented a hybrid Komodo Mlipir Algorithm and Circle Search Algorithm using non-dominated sorting approach (KMA-CSA-NDS) for solving multi-objective optimization problems. The algorithm is designed to take advantage of the Komodo Mlipir algorithm's (KMA) quick convergence ability while also incorporating the Circle Search algorithm's (CSA) strengths in exploring the solution space and avoiding local optima, and it utilizes non-dominated sorting as a multi-objective approach. In the experimental phase, five ZDT functions are utilized. KMA-CSA-NDS successfully approached the Pareto front (PF) and produced minimal GD values for four ZDT functions.

title: Design and Analysis of Optimized Low Power Dual-Edge-Triggered Pulse Latches
authors: Srujan Prasad, Vrinda V. Patil, Thejas V., Premananda B.S.
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Pulse generators are often used in timing control circuits. The traditional pulse generators consume more power due to the redundant switching activities. With a signal transition from high to low or low to high, more energy is drawn from the power supply, resulting in frequent switching across the internal circuitry and higher energy dissipation. This work proposes three dual-edge-triggered pulsed latch (DET PL) designs to minimize the power and transistor count. The proposed designs are modified with and without a pseudo-nMOS transistor in the pulse generation circuitry, along with the inverters at the input and output of the main latch. The use of pseudo-nMOS transistors along with inverters ensures that the pulse signal and the output are stable. The circuits are realized in Cadence Virtuoso at the CMOS 90 nm technology node and simulated using Cadence Spectre with a supply voltage of 1.2 V. The proposed design-I (DET PL-I) achieves a power reduction of 19.8 %, while the proposed design-II (DET PL-II) and proposed design-III (DET PL-III) achieve a 30.24 % and 13.49 % reduction in power, respectively, compared to the existing DET circuits. Apart from reducing the power, the proposed designs also minimize the area, resulting in more efficient integration into the present systems.

title: Absolute Imaging for Electrical Impedance Tomography with Calderón’s Method
authors: Benyuan Sun, Yanhong Li, Hangyu Zhong
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: As a radiation-free, rapid, and real-time imaging modality, electrical impedance tomography (EIT) has been applied to pulmonary ventilation monitoring.
