Inverse problems have long been a research focus in the field. Compared with traditional sensitivity-based algorithms, Calderón’s method offer several advantages, including the absence of sensitivity priors, non-iterative imaging, robustness to modeling errors, and the capability for fast absolute imaging. This study investigates in detail the influence of electrode number, target conductivity, and the size of the target region on the accuracy of absolute imaging with Calderón’s method. The results demonstrate that all these factors significantly affect the accuracy of the reconstructed images. Furthermore, to address modeling errors arising during pulmonary respiration, the robustness of Calderón’s method under boundary perturbations is examined. The findings indicate that Calderón’s method exhibits superior robustness compared to traditional sensitivity-based algorithms.

title: AtmoNeuro: A Hybrid 3D-Spatio-Temporal Neural Framework for High-Resolution Probabilistic Global Weather Forecasting
authors: Koteswararao B, K. Sailaja
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Global weather forecasting remains one of the most complicated scientific problems due to the non-linear, chaotic, and multiscale dynamics of the atmosphere. Conventional numerical methods dominate the weather forecasting world, but they are not only very computationally expensive, they frequently cannot capture small-scale features in space and time especially in medium-to-long range forecasts. Recent developments in deep learning provide new opportunities; however, existing models seldom consider hierarchical spatio-temporal dependencies, quantify predictive uncertainty, or efficiently produce situationally aware, high-resolution climate forecasts. This work offers the AtmoNeuro model - a novel, hybrid neural model combining three-dimensional convolutional networks to capture localized spatial dynamics with spatio-temporal attention transformers (that are in part inspired by hierarchical Swin architectures), to model long-range atmospheric dependencies, and stochastic representation learning modules to produce probabilistic forecasts and uncertainty. The model framework also includes diffusion-based refinement methods to improve the spatial resolution of the predictions, along with enhancing the physical realism of the predictions. In extensive experiments on large-scale global atmospheric datasets, we find that AtmoNeuro consistently outperformed state-of-the-art models in predictive accuracy, robustness, and reliability in out-of-distribution scenarios. This research will not only advance performance improvements in forecasts and models, it provides a foundation for interpretable, scalable, and high-fidelity weather modeling which will be valuable for a diverse range of scientists and practitioners. AtmoNeuro bridges traditional meteorological insights with modern neural architectures, paving the way to explore multi-modal climate modeling, real-time probabilistic forecasting, as well as developing AI-based decision support systems for environmental and disaster response planning.

title: Comparison of different co-located renewables and storage energy management schemes within an energy community
authors: Abhimanyu Kaushal, Anibal Sanjab, Tom Cuypers, Pieter Backx, Bram Van Dun
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Energy cooperatives in Belgium play a vital role in the energy transition by installing renewable energy capacity at customers’ premises and ensuring its efficient operation. These cooperatives typically sell the electricity they generate to their customers through pay-as-produced power purchase agreements. However, the increasing frequency of low and negative electricity prices can incentivise customers to curtail their offtake from the cooperative, posing a financial risk to the cooperative’s business model. The deployment of Battery Energy Storage Systems is proposed as a mitigation strategy in such contexts. This paper investigates various BESS ownership and operational models, quantifies the associated cost savings, and assesses the potential reduction in curtailment volumes. The findings indicate that integrating BESS can significantly lower power offtake costs and reduce energy curtailment. Furthermore, the study examines how different operational strategies influence total energy costs and highlights the need to investigate profit-sharing mechanisms between cooperatives and BESS owners.

title: An Efficient Method for Mining Closed Frequent High Average-Utility Occupancy Patterns
authors: Thang La, Khanh Tran, Hai Duong, Bac Le, Anh Tran
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: Discovering all Frequent High Average-Utility Occupancy Itemsets (FHAUOIs) in quantitative transaction databases has emerged as a promising direction in pattern mining. By integrating both average-utility occupancy and frequency, these itemsets are better aligned with real-world applications, as they not only represent the preferences of the majority of users but also contribute significantly to the total utility of input transactions in which they appear. However, the set of exploited FHAUOIs can be extremely large, especially when dealing with dense or large-scale datasets, or when low minimum threshold values are used. This can make it difficult for users to interpret and utilize the results effectively. To overcome this challenge, the paper designs a novel algorithm called C-FHAUOIM for mining Closed FHAUOIs (CFHAUOIs). The algorithm leverages a newly designed upper bound on average-utility occupancy to efficiently reduce the database by eliminating low-average-utility occupancy items. In addition, it introduces a novel weak lower bound, along with associated pruning strategies, to effectively discard non-closed FHAUOIs early in the mining process. These theoretical advances are integrated into an efficient algorithm for discovering CFHAUOIs. Experimental evaluations conducted on multiple synthetic and real quantitative databases reveal that the proposed method achieves superior performance compared to the baseline, particularly in execution speed, memory efficiency, and scalability.

title: Federated Learning-Based Res Forecasting in Smart Grids by Feature Fusion Using Cross Attention Mechanism
authors: Lakshmaiya N, R. Jayashri, Ramya M
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Growing demand for the smart grid system involves different renewable energy systems into action. As the Renewable Energy Systems (RES) produce energy from other natural resources, there is a discrepancy in combining the energy in the innovative grid systems. The intelligent grid systems act as the central server where all the data regarding the RES units needs to be updated for efficient functioning of the integrated RES units. Condition monitoring is an essential application of intelligent systems, where the functionality of different RES units is subjected to failures, maintenance, repairs, etc. It is a necessary aspect on which the final and overall efficiency of the intelligent grid system relies. Therefore, the proposed system approaches the innovative grid system using the decentralised approach by utilising the Federated learning method, where the aggregation of information of heterogeneous types are fused using the cross-attention mechanism. The proposed work was validated with the RES of solar, wind and hydro power plants dataset from Kaggle, resulting in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 6. 2 \%} \mathbf{F 1}$</tex> score and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 5. 4 \%}$</tex> precision accuracy.

title: Research on Facial Expression Recognition Based on Computer Vision
authors: Jin Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: This paper proposes a fusion of the Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) and the Support Vector Machine, the facial expression recognition model based on SVM and Principal Component Analysis (PCA) - Support Principal Adversarial Network (SPAN). This method first uses principal component analysis to perform dimension reduction processing on the original face image, extract the most representative feature vectors, and reduce the interference of redundant information on classification. Subsequently, the generative adversarial network is introduced to enhance the training samples. To enhance the model's generalization capability, the dataset is augmented by creating realistic and varied expression images. Subsequently, a support vector machine is employed to classify and model the feature space, with the aim of boosting the accuracy of expression recognition. The experimental outcomes demonstrate that SPAN achieves impressive performance in the facial expression recognition task. Compared with traditional methods, it can recognize various expressions more accurately, proving the reliability of this method and providing a new technical path for facial expression recognition.

title: Coordination Framework for Active and Reactive Power Provision in Curative Schemes
authors: Carsten Thomas Gatermann, Nadja Isabelle Belz, Steffen Schlegel, Dirk Westermann
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Inherent thermal reserves of high-voltage direct current cables have been found to be a viable option for curative congestion management. With the ongoing decommissioning of conventional power plants, increased load flows in direct proximity to the converter nodes may lead to voltage control issues. This work proposes a coordination framework for the provision of active and reactive power during curative congestion management, combining existing and novel system operation concepts to enhance system reliability. It combines optimized utilization of available thermal asset reserves and reactive power potentials from sub-transmission grids.

title: Evaluating the Reproducibility of Machine Learning Models on Healthcare Datasets
authors: Gopu Rachel Rejoice Reddy, P. Joyce Beryl Princess
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Although it is still difficult to achieve across contexts, reproducibility is a fundamental component of trustworthy machine learning research. In this paper, two benchmark datasets—Diabetes and Breast Cancer—are used to illustrate a reproducible experimental process. Preprocessing, several classifiers (Logistic Regression, Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, and Gradient Boosting), and consistent assessment criteria are all part of our methodology. We confirm the same results regardless of the computational environment by doing experiments on several devices running Docker containers, CPUs, and GPUs. Moreover, multiple runs with different random seeds produce consistent results with very little variation. For clarity, every outcome is methodically recorded, combined, and displayed. In order to achieve reproducible machine learning, this work emphasises the significance of containerisation, visible preprocessing, and controlled randomisation. In applied machine learning research, the framework can be used as a starting point for reproducibility reporting.

title: PCB Stack-Up Recognition Using LLMs
authors: Jie Li, Shiming Qin, Tingting Liu, Yuyu Zhu, Haoran Li, Cailiang Fu
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Advanced Interconnects (WAI)
abstract: With the increasing integration of electronic products, printed circuit board (PCB) are evolving toward higher speeds and more layered structures. However, the diversity of stack-up rules has led to significant challenges in the interoperability of design simulation and manufacturing processes across different vendors and users. To address this issue, this paper proposes an intelligent stack-up recognition method based on large language models (LLMs), which automatically converts PCB stack-up information into a standardized format defined by users or manufacturers. Experimental results demonstrate that online LLMs with over 500 billion parameters achieve a high recognition accuracy, exceeding 92%. In scenarios demanding data confidentiality or facing computational constraints, locally deployed lightweight models are a preferable alternative. However, models with no more than 8 billion parameters exhibit a significantly lower accuracy of below 37%, which is insufficient for practical purposes. Therefore, further investigation is essential to improve the viability of local lightweight models for this application.

title: User-Driven Co-Design Framework for Building Energy Management Systems Services
authors: Sokratis Divolis, Georgios Korbakis, Alexios Lekidis
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: Building Energy Management Systems (BEMS) play a crucial role in optimizing energy efficiency, reducing operational costs, and enhancing sustainability in modern buildings, as they account for 40% of the overall energy consumption. However, the integration of diverse technologies, heterogeneous data sources, and varying communication protocols and mechanisms presents significant challenges, which restrict BEMS system adoption. In this paper, we explore these challenges, including interoperability issues, data standardization, cybersecurity/data privacy concerns, and scalability constraints. To tackle these challenges, we propose a co-design framework architecture that 1) facilitates seamless communication between different energy management services and 2) integrates components based on Internet of Things (IoT), Artificial Intelligence (AI), and cloud computing technologies. The framework also allows for addressing the challenges of BEMS systems, as well as provides a usercentered approach for increasing BEMS adoption, towards the development of energy-efficient smart buildings.

title: Soft-Actor-Critic-based Anti-Sway Control for Port Crane Systems with Bounded Disturbances
authors: Zhenxiang Wang, Yilian Zhang, Weimin Xu
publish: IECON 2025 – 51st Annual Conference of the IEEE Industrial Electronics Society
abstract: This paper proposes an intelligent control strategy based on Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) to address the payload anti-sway problem in port crane systems during dynamic operations. Firstly, a discrete linear parameter varying (LPV) model is established based on the system dynamics to characterize the nonlinear behavior of the crane. Meanwhile, the external and internal uncertainties of the system are modeled as unknown bounded (UB) disturbances. Secondly, a novel SAC-MPC collaborative anti-sway control framework is designed. The framework incorporates the constraint-handling capability of MPC and the self-optimizing nature of SAC to enforce state constraints and generate optimized control signals. Besides, an SAC training paradigm with state space noise injection is introduced to enhance the control policy’s adaptability to environmental uncertainties. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed approach in suppressing payload oscillations.

title: Validation of VIIRS Sea Ice Concentration Product in Baffin Bay
authors: Kavita Mitkari, Richard Dworak, Yinghui Liu, Xuanji Wang, Jeff Key
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Sea ice concentration (SIC) is an essential climate variable, and is useful in determining other vital climate variables, such as sea ice extent and ice volume. In addition to climate application, SIC maps are useful in assisting ship traffic, fisheries, and other marine operations to determine potentially passable regions. This study evaluates the Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) SIC product in the Baffin Bay area with the high-resolution Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) Normalized Radar Cross Section (NRCS) composite images. Comparative analysis suggests a well matching between VIIRS SIC when validated with NRCS composites.

authors: N/A
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)

title: Vision-Based Policy Learning for High-Speed Autonomous Racing: A Two-Phase Learning Paradigm_supp1-3639812.mp4
authors: Qinyuan Ren
publish: N/A
abstract: Motion planning for autonomous vision-based car racing is a challenging task in robotics. Classical racing systems divide the task into numerous submodules, undermining computational efficiency and leading to error propagation. Previous studies have demonstrated impressive reinforcement learning (RL) results for end-to-end autonomous driving. However, RL exhibits poor scalability on high-dimensional data, such as images, and it is challenging to learn optimal racing behaviors due to the lack of global information about the environments. To address these issues, a two-phase learning paradigm is proposed in this work to train a vision-based racing policy. First, RL trains a teacher policy that integrates progress maximization with collision avoidance in the reward function and utilizes privileged information (P.I.) about the racetrack to achieve high-performance racing. Then, a student policy, relying only on an ego-centric depth camera for perception, is trained by distilling racing knowledge from the teacher policy. The student policy achieves high-speed drive, high success rate, and smooth control in vision-based racing games. The proposed approach is validated in the simulation and on a real-world 1/10-scale race car, showing that the approach outperforms previous model-based and learning-based baselines.

title: Mechanism–Data Fusion Modeling for High-Frequency Vibration Prediction in PWM-Driven Active Magnetic Bearings
authors: Longyuan Fan, Zicheng Liu, Rongpei Zhu, Dong Jiang, Ronghai Qu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: This article presents a novel mechanism-data fusion modeling approach for predicting high-frequency vibrations in active magnetic bearings induced by pulse-width modulation (PWM) power supply. First, an analytical method is developed to characterize the spatial distribution of circumferential electromagnetic force waves in the air gap, and a spatial-order-based transfer function is constructed to describe the mechanical vibration response. Building upon this, a mechanism-informed neural network architecture is proposed, incorporating prior knowledge into a self-supervised framework, with constrained hidden nodes and learnable edge activation functions. This hybrid design enhances both prediction accuracy and model interpretability. Experimental results demonstrate that the mechanism-informed architecture achieves over 98% prediction accuracy on experimental data sets. Moreover, the model provides interpretable insights into vibration transmission mechanisms, offering guidance for interaction analysis and collaborative optimization of variable PWM control parameters.

title: A 2.7–15.5 GHz Programmable Bandwidth Continuous-Time Active Filter in 65 nm CMOS
authors: Mayank Anupam, Imon Mondal
publish: IEEE Journal of Solid-State Circuits
abstract: The article proposes and demonstrates bandwidth (BW) enhancement techniques for wideband and widely programmable active filters operating with a fixed and a single supply voltage. Fully differential transconductors having voltage-biased nMOS transistors form the input differential pair with a pair of pMOS transistors forming the active load. The gyrators’ common-mode (CM) response is kept under 0 dB at low frequencies by CM feedback (CMFB) loops. A pair of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\approx }300$</tex-math> </inline-formula> pH inductors and a capacitor, strategically shared among all transconductors, are used to sense and reject the high-frequency CM currents through the filter and provide CM stabilization at high frequencies. This extends the CM stability of the gyrators beyond the unity-gain bandwidth (UGB) of the CMFB loops. Another technique to relax the capacitance budget of the heavily loaded resistively terminated node of a leap-frog architecture is introduced. Background servo loops ensure automatic tracking and stabilization of the (trans) conductances across changes in ambient conditions. The efficacy of the proposed schemes is demonstrated through a singly terminated third-order Chebyshev low-pass filter implemented in a standard 65 nm bulk CMOS process operating with a fixed supply voltage of 1.1 V. The filter achieves a maximum −3 dB BW of 15.5 GHz, improving the state of the art by <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\gt } 1.5{\times }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. The filter’s BW is tunable from 2.7 to 15.5 GHz while faithfully preserving its response shape. Its measured signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) varies between 38 and 44 dB while consuming 31–291 mW of power between its minimum and maximum BW settings, respectively. Furthermore, the filter can also be reconfigured as a bandpass, with tunable center frequencies between 2.5 and 13.4 GHz.

title: Evolutionary Dynamics of Pairwise and Group Cooperation in Heterogeneous Social Networks
authors: Dini Wang, Peng Yi, Gang Yan, Feng Fu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Understanding how cooperation evolves in structured populations remains a fundamental question across diverse disciplines. The problem of cooperation typically involves pairwise or group interactions among individuals. While prior studies have extensively investigated the role of networks in shaping cooperative dynamics, the influence of tie or connection strengths between individuals has not been fully understood. Here, we introduce a quenched mean-field based framework for analyzing both pairwise and group dilemmas on any weighted network, providing interpretable conditions required for favoring cooperation. Our theoretical advances further motivate us to find that the degree-inverse weighted social ties – reinforcing tie strengths between peripheral nodes while weakening those between hubs – robustly promote cooperation in both pairwise and group dilemmas. Importantly, this configuration enables heterogeneous networks to outperform homogeneous ones in fixation of cooperation, thereby adding to the conventional view that degree heterogeneity inhibits cooperative behavior under the local stochastic strategy update. We further test the generality of degree-inverse weighted social ties in promoting cooperation on <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$30, 000$</tex-math></inline-formula> random networks and 13 empirical networks drawn from real-world systems. Finally, we unveil the underlying mechanism by examining the formation and evolution of cooperative ties under social ties with degree-inverse weights. Our systematic analyses provide new insights into how the network adjustment of tie strengths can effectively steer structured populations toward cooperative outcomes in biological and social systems.

title: Fabrication of an Optimized Low-loss DNANF Used for Visualization of Poled Domain in PPLN
authors: Jingrui Gong, Zelin Zhang, Yu Qin, Fei Chen, Jie Zhu, Lin Li, Limin Xiao, Kebin Shi
publish: IEEE Photonics Technology Letters
abstract: We fabricated an optimized double nested anti-resonant nodeless fiber (DNANF) for the visualization of poled domain in periodically poled lithium niobate (PPLN). Through optimized structural and fabrication processes, the optimized DNANF achieved a low transmission loss below 3×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-3</sup> dB/m at 920-1040 nm. The femtosecond laser with a central wavelength of 1034 nm and a repetition rate of 34 MHz was coupled with the optimized DNANF in second-harmonic generation (SHG) imaging system. It can be used to achieve a high-resolution three-dimensional (3D) imaging of poled domains in PPLN, with a field of view (FOV) of 102.4 μm × 102.4 μm and a lateral resolution of 0.815 μm. In future, this DNANF will provide a stable, high-efficiency, and simple method of femtosecond laser propagation for the 3D precision characterization of poled domains in materials such as ferroelectric crystals and liquid crystals, as well as two-photon neuroimaging.

title: Design and Implementation of ROS2 Security Module for Performance and Security Harmonization
authors: Jeong Hyeon Park, Hong Seong Park
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The security of the Robot Operating System 2 (ROS2) is crucial to ensure the safety of individual robotic systems and the reliability of the environment in which they operate. Although Secure ROS2 (SROS2) enhances security via Data Distribution Service Security for authentication, access control, and data encryption, it has several limitations. The complexity of managing security artifacts and the degradation of communication performance are two primary concerns. To address these challenges, we propose the ROS2 Security (ROS2Sec) module, which enhances ROS2 security while minimizing communication performance degradation. ROS2Sec introduces centralized authentication management and group-based access-control, thus reducing the number of security artifacts from seven for SROS2 to only three, thereby simplifying management. Additionally, ROS2Sec employs the Advanced Encryption Standard in Galois/Counter Mode at the ROS2 message level to optimize data confidentiality while minimizing overhead. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed ROS2Sec prevents unauthorized access from malicious ROS2 nodes, reduces the mean communication latency by approximately 9% compared with SROS2, and maintains stable performance even as the number of subscribers increases. These findings confirm that ROS2Sec balances security and communication performance and is a practical solution for secure and efficient ROS2-based robotic systems.

title: Key Nodes Prediction and Cascading Failures Mitigation in Dynamic Traffic UASNs Via a GCN-LSTM Model
authors: Yifan Yuan, Xiaohong Shen, Lin Sun, Yongsheng Yan, Shilei Ma, Haiyan Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Underwater acoustic sensor networks (UASNs) have attracted significant attention due to their potential applications in military surveillance and disaster early warning. However, due to the low data rate, high latency, and instability of underwater acoustic communication, UASNs are highly vulnerable to cascading failures triggered by the malfunction of key nodes, which can lead to network collapse. To address this challenge, we establish a cascading failure model tailored for dynamic traffic UASNs and propose a multi-criteria key node prediction (MC-KNP) algorithm based on the novel finding that nodes exhibit varying importance levels under different network traffic conditions. Although experimental results demonstrate that MC-KNP algorithm outperforms others approaches (e.g., degree, betweenness, and load) in accurately predicting key nodes for dynamic traffic UASNs, it suffers from high computational complexity. To address this limitation, we propose a key node prediction framework named KNP-GL, which integrates a graph convolutional network (GCN) to extract features that reflect both the structural roles of nodes and their potential impact on cascading failures, and a long short-term memory (LSTM) module to capture the temporal dynamics of cascading failures. Furthermore, based on the prediction results of KNP-GL framework, we design a mitigation strategy leveraging capacity expansion to improve network resilience against cascading failures. Experimental results show that KNP-GL framework achieves approximately 90% accuracy while reducing execution time from tens of seconds to tens of milliseconds. The proposed mitigation strategy further enhances network robustness, providing both theoretical insights and practical guidance for the development of high-reliability UASNs.

title: Design of High Voltage Power Supply Grounding Protection System for Upgrading Pulsed High Magnetic Field Facility in WHMFC
authors: Weilin Chen, Hongfa Ding, Xiaotao Han, Jiangtao Shi, Jianfeng Xie, Liang Li, Tonghai Ding
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: The high voltage power supply system for the pulsed high magnetic field facility at the Wuhan National High Magnetic Field Center (WHMFC) will be upgraded to a 167 MJ capacitor bank system comprising 73 modules. This system will serve 27 magnet experimental stations over the next five years. The capacitor bank system is located on the second floor of the Pulsed Building, while all experimental stations occupy the first floor; each floor covers approximately 2000 square meters. The 27 experimental stations are divided into four independent zones. Each zone is supplied by dedicated capacitor bank modules and features an independent grounding system. This configuration ensures that operators in unaffected zones are not exposed to hazards during high voltage or high magnetic field experiments conducted in another zone, requiring evacuation only from stations within the active zone. Consequently, this design significantly improves experimental efficiency and greatly enhances overall facility utilization.

title: VAE-GAN-Based Semantic Communication for High-Quality Image Transmission
authors: Naoki Omi, Shun Kojima, Chang-Jun Ahn
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: In semantic communication systems, deep learning-based joint source-channel coding (DeepJSCC) has demonstrated superior performance, particularly in low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) scenarios and under limited bandwidth conditions, compared to traditional communication technologies. However, most existing studies rely on communication models based on autoencoders (AE), where the distribution of transmission symbols is treated as a complete black box, causing inefficient use of limited transmission symbols. Moreover, many existing methods for image transmission focus on optimizing pixel-wise metrics, without considering the semantic information of the images. This pixel-level optimization often compromises the semantic fidelity and perceptual quality of the reconstructed images. To address these problems, we propose a novel semantic communication system that combines a variational autoencoder (VAE) and a generative adversarial network (GAN). Specifically, a VAE is used to arbitrarily control the distribution of transmission symbols according to channel conditions, while a GAN is used to maximize the similarity of semantic information. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method improves the perceptual quality of the reconstructed images compared to conventional approaches.

title: Integrated Super-resolution Sensing and Symbiotic Communication with 3D Sparse MIMO for Low-Altitude UAV Swarm
authors: Jingran Xu, Hongqi Min, Yong Zeng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: Low-altitude unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) swarms are expected to play important role for future intelligent aerial systems due to their great potential to cooperatively accomplish complicated missions effectively. However, there are important challenges to be addressed to enable their efficient operation: the large-scale nature of swarms usually leads to excessive spectrum consumption, and ultra-low-cost requirements for individual UAVs renders it necessary to develop cost-effective communication modules. In addition, the densely located swarm UAVs require high resolution for localization and sensing. In order to address the above challenges and simultaneously achieve spectrum- and energy-efficient communication and accurate sensing, we investigate low-altitude UAV swarm with integrated super-resolution sensing and symbiotic communication technology. Specifically, one leading UAV may act as a primary transmitter (PT) to transmit communication signals to the base station (BS), and the remaining nearby UAVs in the swarm act as passive backscatter devices (BDs), which can modulate their information by efficiently backscattering the radio frequency (RF) signals from the PT without consuming extra spectrum or power. In addition, to achieve efficient three-dimensional (3D) super-resolution sensing for the densely located UAV swarm, 3D sparse multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) technology and super-resolution signal processing algorithms are further exploited, where both L-shaped nested array (LNA) and planar nested arrays (PNA) are considered at the BS. To evaluate the communication and sensing performance for the UAV-symbiotic radio (SR) system, the achievable rates of UAV swarm are derived and the beam patterns of sparse LNA, PNA and the benchmarking compact uniform planar array (UPA) are compared. Furthermore, efficient channel estimation methods assisted by super-resolution sensing are proposed. Simulation results are provided to demonstrate that 3D sparse MIMO with both LNA and PNA can provide significantly better sensing and communication performance than conventional compact MIMO for UAV-SR systems.

title: Negative Voltage Active Turnoff Characteristics of RB-IGCT and Its Low Loss Application in Hybrid Commutated Converter
authors: Wenwen Zhang, Xiaoguang Wei, Guangfu Tang, Jingfei Wang, Yaohua Wang, Xinling Tang, Naihang Lyu, Jinyuan Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: The hybrid commutated converter (HCC) replaces thyristor with reverse-blocking integrated gate commutated thyristor (RB-IGCT) has been demonstrated to realize low extinction angle with lower reactive power compensation compared with the line commutated converter (LCC). Gate driver voltage of RB-IGCT is controllable compared with the thyristor, which creates favorable conditions for reducing device losses. Negative voltage active turnoff means gate drive voltage turn to $\textbf{-}$ 20 V when device current decreases but not reaches to zero during bridge arm current commutation. This article firstly proposes a forward turnoff method (FTM) which can extract electronics of P base region ahead by gate drive, and then gate driver extracted electronic quantity with different active turn-off current and excess carrier extraction mechanism by ac grid voltage during the whole reverse recovery process are analyzed in detail. Based on this, an optimized experimental verification platform is proposed and voltage characteristics under different active turn-off current and forward current with different extinction angle ( $\boldsymbol{\gamma}$ ) are conducted. Finally, calculated active turnoff current with reducing 65.1% reverse recovery charge of RB-IGCT compared with self-turnoff method (STM) is verified and the whole turnoff loss of RB-IGCT will reduce 38.4% with $\boldsymbol{\gamma}$ setting 0.8°, which are significant contributions to the application of HCC.

title: Cascade Observer Design for a Class of Disturbed Nonlinear Systems with State and Output Delays
authors: F. Ramírez-Rasgado, M. Farza, O. Hernández-González, M. M'Saad, C.M. Astorga-Zaragoza
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control
abstract: This paper provides a cascade observer design framework for a class of disturbed uniformly observable systems with arbitrary long (constant and known) time-delays in both output and state variables. Two fundamental design features are worth to be mentioned to better appreciate the involved contribution of the paper. Firstly, a basic cascade observer is designed assuming that the structure of the system nonlinear dynamics is triangular with respect to the actual and delayed states and that the system linear dynamics is delay free. Secondly, the proposed design is extended to the case where the state delays are also involved in the linear dynamics. Such an extension is achieved by deriving a suitable cascade observer design model allowing thereby to recover the modelling requirement of the proposed basic cascade observer design. The observer convergence analysis is performed using an adequate Lyapunov approach and its performance and main properties are illustrated through probing simulation results.
