title: ML-based Intelligent Threat Identification for Phishing and SQL Injection Attacks
authors: Vutukuri Pranavi, Padmalaya Nayak, Bondili Rithika Singh, Yarlagadda Meghana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: A cyber threat refers to many malicious acts that seek to damage data, steal data, or disrupt digital life in general. There are many common threats, including phishing, malware, ransomware, and SQL injection attacks. Ensuring early detection of cyber threats is essential for securing digital systems. Traditional defence mechanisms often struggle against phishing and SQL injection attacks. But they have drawbacks as they typically rely on signature-based filters, rule-driven firewalls, and manually updated rule sets. A few of the existing solutions are Imperva Web Application Firewall and Google Safe Browsing API. In this study, we focused on two common and impactful attack types—Phishing and SQL Injection—due to their high prevalence and ability to bypass traditional defenses. A lightweight, dual-layered detection framework is employed that incorporates machine learning (ML) heuristic rules and pattern analysis to identify threats early with minimal resource requirements. We have randomly selected three ML algorithms, i.e., XGBoost, BiLSTM + Attention, and CNN+BiGRU, to identify threats related to Phishing and SQL Injection attacks. For phishing detection, we analyze URLs and HTML features, such as domain age, HTTPS usage, and anchor tags. For SQL Injection Detection, we tokenize queries and detect anomalies for deeper analysis. After extensive experiments, we found that XGBoost performs well for Phishing attacks while BiLSTM + Attention is a better fit for SQL Injection detection. The evaluation metrics are generated and presented in an interactive user interface that helps in identifying phishing and SQL Injection attacks.

title: Computing-in-Memory Dataflow for Minimal Buffer Traffic
authors: Choongseok Song, Doo Seok Jeong
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Computing-In-Memory (CIM) offers a potential solution to the memory wall issue and can achieve high energy efficiency by minimizing data movement, making it a promising architecture for edge AI devices. Lightweight models like MobileNet and EfficientNet, which utilize depthwise convolution for feature extraction, have been developed for these devices. However, CIM macros often face challenges in accelerating depthwise convolution, including underutilization of CIM memory and heavy buffer traffic. The latter, in particular, has been overlooked despite its significant impact on latency and energy consumption. To address this, we introduce a novel CIM dataflow that significantly reduces buffer traffic by maximizing data reuse and improving memory utilization during depthwise convolution. The proposed dataflow is grounded in solid theoretical principles, fully demonstrated in this paper. When applied to MobileNet and EfficientNet models, our dataflow reduces buffer traffic by 77.4-87.0%, leading to a total reduction in data traffic energy and latency by 10.1-17.9% and 15.6-27.8%, respectively, compared to the baseline (conventional weight-stationary dataflow).

title: ReVise: A Human-AI Interface for Incremental Algorithmic Recourse
authors: Kaustav Bhattacharjee, Jun Yuan, Aritra Dasgupta
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: The recent adoption of artificial intelligence in socio-technical systems raises concerns about the black-box nature of the resulting decisions in fields such as hiring, finance, admissions, etc. If data subjects—such as job applicants, loan applicants, and students—receive an unfavorable outcome, they may be interested in algorithmic recourse, which involves updating certain features to yield a more favorable result when re-evaluated by algorithmic decision-making. Unfortunately, when individuals do not fully understand the incremental steps needed to change their circumstances, they risk following misguided paths that can lead to significant, long-term adverse consequences. Existing recourse approaches focus exclusively on the final recourse goal but neglect the possible incremental steps to reach the goal with real-life constraints, user preferences, and model artifacts. To address this gap, we formulate a visual analytic workflow for incremental recourse planning in collaboration with AI/ML experts and contribute an interactive visualization interface that helps data subjects efficiently navigate the recourse alternatives and make an informed decision. We present a usage scenario and subjective feedback from observational studies with twelve graduate students using a real-world dataset, which demonstrates that our approach can be instrumental for data subjects in choosing a suitable recourse path.

title: Global Trade Pattern Analysis Using DBSCAN: Identification of Country Groups Based on Export and Import Trends
authors: Brandon Enrique Kurniawan, Alexander Agung Santoso Gunawan
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ICoAIT)
abstract: Understanding how global trade works is important for shaping good economic policies and making accurate forecasts. However, many existing methods still struggle to capture the full picture, especially when it comes to subtle regional patterns or countries that do not follow typical trends. This study introduces a clustering approach designed to give a clearer view of how national economies relate to each other, using merchandise trade data from the World Trade Organization between 2013 and 2023. The method is a systematic framework built around the DBSCAN algorithm leveraging recent optimizations in density-based clustering. We extract 87 trade-related features for each country, including export and import levels, trade balance, growth trends, volatility, and economic complexity to form the input space. To find the best clustering setup, we apply a multi-metric evaluation framework incorporating the Silhouette Score, Calinski-Harabasz Index, and Davies-Bouldin Index as implemented in scikit-learn and we employ t-SNE alongside classical multidimensional scaling for two-dimensional visualization. The findings reveal distinct regional behaviors: Europe forms a highly connected cluster (Silhouette Score: 0.580), Asia exhibits a hub-and-spoke structure with dominant central players and several outliers (Silhouette Score: 0.411), Africa displays a heterogeneous mix of resource-based economies and emerging sub-regional linkages (Silhouette Score: 0.201), and South America and Oceania appear more fragmented with weaker overall cohesion. Overall, this framework not only highlights major trade groupings and outlier countries but also provides a structured, visual methodology for analyzing global trade networks, offering valuable insights for policy design, market strategy formulation, and risk assessment, as well as a foundation for future research in international trade analysis.

title: Implementation of Fair Chance Round Robin Arbiter and its Comparative Analysis
authors: Anuradha Shenoy, Anika Kirana Venkat, Adithya S Chakravarty, Smitha Gayathri D
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Efficient arbitration is highly necessary in digital systems where multiple requesters compete for shared resources. Traditional methods such as priority-based and round-robin arbiters which are simple to implement but either suffer from starvation or lack the adaptability required to provide for fair access. This paper presents the design and implementation of a novel arbitration scheme Fair Chance Round Robin (FCRR) which combines the structure of priority arbitration with a dynamic masking mechanism to ensure fair access. This is developed using Verilog HDL and tested on the Zybo-Z7 FPGA platform where FCRR addresses the shortcomings of static arbiters by integrating return-to-zero latches that temporarily blocks previously served requesters. And the comparative synthesis and simulation analysis demonstrate that FCRR achieves improved fairness with minimal hardware overhead. It achieves competitive performance, optimal logic resource utilization and reduced risk of starvation, making it a viable option for real-time systems, Network-on-Chip (NoC) designs and embedded systems.

title: Heterogeneous Algorithm for Ship Detection Based on Feature Fusion of PConv Combined with SAM
authors: Qi Xiangming, Wang Xinyao
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of low accuracy and high missed detection rate in ship inspection due to the diverse types of targets and complex environments, a feature fusion ship inspection repeated classification algorithm combining PConv and SAM is proposed based on YOLOv10n. Firstly, the inverted residual structure in MobileNetV3 is utilized in combination with the SE attention mechanism for feature extraction to reduce the number of parameters and complexity of YOLOv10n feature extraction and improve the speed of feature extraction. By reusing the Neck and Detect parts of YOLOv10 for feature fusion and feature classification, and introducing PConv and SAM at the starting position of the Neck and trimming off PAN, the target detection capability is enhanced and the accuracy of feature fusion is optimized. The loss function Inner-Wise-MPDIoU is constructed to replace the loss function CIoU in YOLOv10n, improving the positioning accuracy and convergence speed. Ablation experiments and comparison experiments were conducted on the self-made dataset ZizhiShips. Compared with the two baseline algorithms and the algorithms in the recent references, the mAP, Precision, Recall, IoU and FPS on YOLOv10n increased by 2.7 %, 3.6 %, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.8 \%, 4.4 \%$</tex> and 7.8 M respectively. The Parameters value only increases by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 1 M}$</tex> compared to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3. 1 M}$</tex> of YOLOv10n, indicating that the algorithm in this paper performs well.

title: Enhancing Supply Chain Resilience Through Federated Learning and Distributed Edge Intelligence for Real-Time Decisions
authors: K. Sathish, M. Ramkumar Prabhu, Manikandan B
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: There are increasing cyber security threats for heterogeneous cloud systems and traditional security measures find it hard to protect them because their infrastructure is always evolving and complex. Because security solutions are not very clear and flexible, it becomes hard to spot attackers and address new threats as they happen. It suggests using both CNNs and LSTMs in a deep learning solution to better respond to changes in threats. Machine learning AI scores use attention mechanisms and facilitate the use of LIME explanations, allowing continuous analysis of network traffic, system logs and behavioral patterns across AWS, Azure and Google Cloud. The accuracy the system showed was 97.3 % for threat detection, 94.8 % for spotting anomalies and 96.1 % in recognizing zero-day attacks, while it brought false positives down by 89.2 % compared to traditional methods. The explainability part contributed to an interpretability level of 92.7 % for security decisions. Using explainable deep learning, cybersecurity defenses perform well and allow security professionals to know and rely on the actions carried out by machines.

title: Clustering and Association Rule Data Mining for Student Performance Optimization in Free Nutritious Meal Programs Using the Apriori Algorithm and K-Means
authors: Relita Buaton, Novriyenni, Anton Sihombing, Ida Ria Royentina Sidabukke
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: The Free Nutritious Meal Program aims to create excellent human resources, as children who receive adequate nutrition will develop better cognitive abilities. Conversely, malnutrition can cause learning difficulties, poor memory retention, and weak concentration. Stunting significantly affects brain intelligence in children; therefore, it is crucial to minimize this problem. The central research question is how to identify and uncover the relationship between nutritional intake and the improvement of students' academic achievement through the Free Nutritious Meal Program, in order to reveal patterns and correlations in cognitive enhancement, brain development, and reasoning skills to improve student performance. The problem-solving approach employed in this study is the application of the Apriori algorithm to discover association rules, combined with clustering techniques to analyze academic improvement based on the Free Nutritious Meal Program implemented in schools. Academic performance data were compared before and after the program. The dataset consisted of students' report card scores at four educational levels elementary, junior high, senior high, and vocational school, covering odd and even semesters of the 2024/2025 academic year. The distribution of the dataset was elementary <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=136$</tex>, junior high <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=626$</tex>, senior high <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=207$</tex>, and vocational school <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=392$</tex>, for a total of 1,361 students. The results indicate a clear correlation in the improvement of students' scores before and after the Free Nutritious Meal Program. Social Studies improved from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{B}+$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{A}+$</tex> with 39% support and 80% confidence. English improved from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{B}+$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{A}+$</tex> with 33 % support and 80% confidence. Religious Studies (A) correlated positively with Social Studies <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{A}+)$</tex> with 33 % support and 80% confidence. Mathematics <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{B}+)$</tex> correlated with improvements in English and Social Studies <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{A}+)$</tex> with 33% support and 80% confidence. However, there was no significant correlation in the direct improvement of Mathematics scores. Although there were improvements in Social Studies, English, and Religious Studies, numerical and formal logical aspects in Mathematics appear less influenced by the Free Nutritious Meal Program. Notably, junior high school students demonstrated the most positive response, with their average scores increasing from 90.87 before the program to 92.51 after the program. This suggests that students at the junior high school level benefited most significantly from the Free Nutritious Meal Program, can be concluded that while previous studies stated that nutritional status did not have a significant effect on academic achievement and even reported a significant negative correlation between nutrient intake and academic performance, this study shows that the Free Nutritious Meal Program improved academic achievement, particularly in social studies and English subjects, with a support value of 33 % and a confidence level of 80%. The average score increased from 82.91 to 84.97. Furthermore, testing with Spearman correlation indicated no significant relationship between nutritional status and academic achievement. However, by applying machine learning techniques, it is possible to identify correlations between nutrition and academic performance.

title: Extended Boundary Condition Method for Wave Scattering by Dielectric Cylinders in Planar Layered Medium
authors: M. Enes Hatipoğlu, Fatih Dikmen, Aytaç Alparslan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: The convenience of image theory to obtain the closed form Green's function of Helmholtz equation obeying an addition formula has a straightforward continuation when the planar layered medium is studied via discrete complex image method (DCIM). The extended boundary condition method (EBCM) for the mentioned medium is then at avail using thus constructed Green's function. As an outcome, the regularized T-Matrix approach for the planar layered medium is derived to express the electromagnetic field scattering from dielectric cylinders buried therein. The capability and stability issues will be discussed and demonstrated with respect to a boundary integral equation (BIE) solver for the same problem having the list of DCI provided for a medium with three planar layers.

title: Wavelet-Enhanced Hybrid Deep Neural Network for Robust Phonocardiogram Classification Using PhysioNet 2016 Challenge Dataset
authors: Selvakumarasamy, V. Jyothi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Phonocardiogram (PCG) signal processing for signal analysis is of utmost value in early diagnosis and follow-up of cardiovascular diseases (CVDs). The variability inherent in real recordings of heart sounds and contamination with noise present serious challenges to accurate automated classification. This paper proposes WH-HeartNet, a novel hybrid deep learning model that integrates discrete wavelet transform-based time-frequency feature extraction with a multi-branch ensemble of pre-trained convolutional neural networks, including ResNet50 and EfficientNet models (B1, B4, and B6). The proposed architecture effectively extracts multi-scale cardiac sound features by processing scalogram representations with different backbones, followed by feature fusion and dense classification. Trained on PhysioNet Challenge 2016 database containing 3,126 PCG recordings from different auscultation sites, WH-HeartNet yields a superior accuracy of 99.84%, precision of 99.70%, recall of 99.72%, and F1-score of 99.71%, outperforming individual baseline models significantly. These results demonstrate the robustness of the framework against noise and variability in clinical recordings, signifying its promise in real-time, non-invasive identification of cardiac abnormalities. Future efforts will revolve around integrating multi-modal physiological information and model optimization for deployment in resource-limited healthcare environments.

title: Ablation Characteristics of Contact Wires in the Pantograph–Catenary System under Successive Arcing Events
authors: Xiaokang Wang, Shijie Fan, Zhenzu Liu, Yang Song, Fuchuan Duan, Zhigang Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: Offline arc is a characteristic phenomenon in the dynamic interaction of the pantograph–catenary (PC) system, and its repeated occurrence leads to pronounced ablation of the contact wire surface. This significantly compromises current collection stability and shortens the service life of the PC system. Unlike previous studies that mainly focused on a single separation event, this work investigates the ablation characteristics of the contact wire under successive dynamic separations. First, a finite element–based dynamic model of the PC system was established using a three-mass model to capture the trajectories of multiple separation events between the slide and the contact wire. Then, a multi-physics coupled model of arc discharge was developed based on magnetohydrodynamic theory. Considering latent heat exchange during material phase transitions, an ablation model of the contact wire was further constructed using the apparent heat capacity method. Finally, based on a simulation platform, the effects of different separation stages and current intensities on contact wire ablation under successive dynamic separations were analyzed. The results indicate that compared with a single separation event, three successive separations increase the ablation area from 0.18 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> to 5.89 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Moreover, higher current intensities further aggravate ablation severity. In addition, due to cumulative arc heating effects, the third stage of successive separations becomes the dominant interval contributing to material damage of the contact wire.

title: A Deep Learning Model for Real-Time On-Device Marine Oil Spill Detection
authors: Rupadharshini Ramkumar, Bharath Ram, Sakthi Abirami Balakrishnan, Aishwarya N
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Marine ecosystems are endangered by oil spills, so quick detection is vital for effective response. This paper introduces an automated, portable oil spill detection system that uses the You Only Look Once Version 8 (YOLOv8) segmentation model (YOLOv8-seg). First, the study evaluates and compares YOLOv5, YOLOv8-seg, U-Net, and Mask RCNN on the dataset from RobOflow. We look at the trade-offs between segmentation accuracy and computational efficiency. Mask R-CNN and U-Net provide higher boundary precision but have slow inference speeds, which restrict their use in real-time situations. In contrast, YOLOv8-seg is 79% faster than U-Net and 91.6% faster than Mask R-CNN, achieves a favorable balance between accuracy and inference speed, making it suitable for edge computing applications. The model is deployed on the low power Grove Vision AI module, which demonstrates real-time, on-site oil spill detection capabilities. This setup enables immediate data processing, enabling quicker environmental responses and supporting ecological monitoring efforts. The findings suggest that YOLOv8-seg offers an effective balance between precision and efficiency, making it a practical solution for automated marine oil spill monitoring in resource-limited, field-ready contexts.

title: Jitter Decomposition Based on Dual-Dirac Model: A Two-Stage Limited-Sampling Algorithm
authors: Jing Peng, Zihao Li, Qihang Sun, Zhihui Qi, Data Pan, Tonggang Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: With the increasing demand for timing accuracy in electronic systems, jitter control has emerged as a critical challenge in high-speed digital communications. To effectively suppress jitter, decomposition methods based on equivalent- time sampling oscilloscopes are employed to identify its sources. However, jitter decomposition often requires extensive sampling points, leading to prolonged measurement times that fail to meet the stringent real-time requirements of online testing and adaptive clock recovery. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a two-stage jitter decomposition algorithm based on dual-Dirac model, which decomposes deterministic jitter and random jitter. The proposed method employs a two- stage decomposition process: (1) an initial coarse estimation using maximum a posteriori-based gradient descent, followed by (2) Markov chain Monte Carlo-based parameter refinement. Experimental results demonstrate superior performance, with Kullback-Leibler divergence reduced to 0.0356 at 64 sampling point, provides a 17.21º/o improvement in accuracy compared to Gaussian mixture model and a 63.19º/o enhancement over kernel density estimation, while the relative bias of parameter significantly outperforming baseline schemes across different number of samples.

title: GAN-Based Image Inpainting and Their Applications in Medical Image Inpainting
authors: Guoliang Li, Ruipeng Wang, Yibin Li, Haiying Liu, Qianqian Li, Rui Song
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Image inpainting technology based on Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) recovers semantic content and visual features of occluded areas in damaged images through generative models. GAN-based medical image inpainting aims to recover anatomical structures and tissue textures in occluded regions. Current research focuses on enhancing structural rationality in restored areas, strengthening textural realism, and ensuring global consistency of the repaired image while guaranteeing that the restored content conforms to anatomical and pathological prior knowledge. Major challenges include adaptive modeling of complex occlusions, effective utilization of multi-scale contextual information, and ensuring semantic validity of generated content. Mainstream approaches employ attention mechanisms, multi-stage generation strategies, crossmodal guidance, and edge-aware constraints to address issues such as local-to-global feature alignment and sharpening blurred occlusion boundaries. Although existing techniques perform well in restoring regular occlusions, deficiencies remain in dynamic occlusion modeling, blurred edge recovery, and robust cross-domain generalization capabilities, which constitute key directions for future improvement.

title: Computational Modeling of a Microstrip Antenna and Measurements with a Nano VNA
authors: Kenedy Marconi G. Santos, Lucas S. Ribeiro, Marcelo B. Perotoni, José Alberto D. Amado, Crescencio L. R. Neto, Tagleorge M. Silveira
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Advanced Interconnects (WAI)
abstract: This article presents the results of measurements, simulations, and calculations for a commercial microstrip antenna. CST Microwave Studio software was utilized for the modeling. The primary objective was to characterize a commercial antenna using a NanoVNA (a portable Vector Network Analyzer) and subsequently model it in CST Studio. This allowed for verification of the correlation among NanoVNA measurements, computational modeling, and theoretical calculations. Following this, simulations were used to investigate the influence of different dielectric materials on the antenna’s resonant frequency. Through both measurements and simulations, Rogers Corporation RO 3003 was identified as a suitable dielectric for designing a similar microstrip antenna. A strong correlation was observed among the measured, simulated, and calculated values.

title: Identifying and Locating Tree Decline and Dieback in DoñAna Biological Reserve with Venus VM5 Images
authors: Díaz-Delgado Ricardo, Zang Xu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Global forest decline is been observed across different ecosystems. Time series of Earth Observation images are very useful to detect and locate sudden drops of vegetation greenness. However, the increasing frequency of disturbances linked to global change (drought, pests, etc.) can lead to a scattered response by each individual tree. Hence, evidence of tree decay becomes harder to show due to constraint posed by sensors spatial resolution. In this work, we leverage images collected by the Venus VM5 satellite mission during more than 2 years over Doñana National Park. In situ observations have reported during 2022 a significant dieback of old tall trees which has been more dramatic for remnant Cork Oaks. Most of these trees are found isolated or small patches with a maximum crown area below the spatial resolution of available optical time series of Earth Observation images. In this work we test the enhancement of spatial and temporal resolution provided by Venus VM5 to detect and locate trees or stands undergoing canopy decline leading to subsequent dieback. We compared different vegetation indices and applied time series analysis to detect declining trends and assessed accuracy according to tree species and canopy size. Additionally, aerial images provided by Google and Bing were used for validation. Overall, NDVI and EVI enabled to identify most of the affected individuals being limited by small canopy sizes. Among the different methods, monotonic and median trends yielded accurate estimates of total affected area. The method developed is intended to be applied with Sentinel-2 images in order to evaluate the limitations of spatial resolution, after decommissioning of Venus VM5 satellite.

title: Research on Dual-Frequency Miniaturization Multifunctional Coding Metasurface Based on Transmission and Reflection Integration
authors: Wenfeng Wang, Yiming Wang, Song Tian, Juan Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: We present a dual-frequency miniaturized multifunctional coding metasurface equipped with RCS reduction and eddy current occurrence functions based on transmission and reflection integration in this paper. The upper design of the metasurface consists of symmetrical splitting rings and cutting lines, and the lower design has a c-type groove. By changing the phase difference of the crystal cell, the regulation of linear polarization wave (LP) and circular polarization wave (CP) can be realized, and then the function of RCS reduction and vortex beamogenesis can be completed. The proposed digital-encoded metasurfaces provide an efficient way to improve the channel capacity with potential applications in communication systems.

title: IoT-based Home Automation System for Energy Conservation
authors: Abhishek Kumar Ray, Karan Das, Lalsiemkam Ngente, Raju Nunia, Satyajit Das, Debajit Sarma, Kamal Hassan Laskar, Pranjal Barman, Dhrubajyoti Boruah, Arunima Dutta, Brian Azzopardi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The growing global emphasis on sustainable development and energy conservation has led to the emergence of intelligent technologies that optimize resource consumption in residential environments. This paper focuses on the design and implementation of an IoT-based home automation system aimed at enhancing energy conservation while maintaining user convenience and comfort. At the core of the system lies the ESP32 microcontroller, selected for its powerful dual-core processing capabilities, integrated Wi-Fi, and extensive GPIO support. These features make it ideal for managing both web server functions and sensor-actuator communication in real-time. The system operates in two primary modes: manual control through a locally hosted web interface and automatic control based on environmental parameters. This prioritization mechanism ensures that the system respects user intent while still promoting energy-saving behaviors when no manual inputs are active.

title: Toward Resilient and Sustainable Energy Systems: Assessment of Networked Microgrids for Disaster-Prone Regions in Indonesia
authors: Mahshid Javidsharifi, Hamoun Pourroshanfekr Arabani, Najmeh Bazmohammadi, Juan C. Vasquez, Josep M. Guerrero
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The resilience performance of networked microgrids (NMGs) in disaster-prone areas, using a real-world testbed located in Lombok, Indonesia is explored in this paper. Given the increasing environmental pressures and energy security concerns in Indonesia, it is vital to improve the robustness and sustainability of decentralized energy infrastructures. We propose an optimization-based energy management framework to address supply interruptions in NMGs, particularly during grid failures and loss of inter-microgrid connectivity caused by natural disasters (NDs). The model evaluates system performance by measuring unserved energy under varying fault scenarios. Results highlight that while NMGs manage grid outages with 31.7 kWh of unserved load, full inter-MG disconnection results in a sharp increase to 366.3 kWh, emphasizing the critical role of microgrid interconnection in ensuring operational resilience.

title: AnnoLens: Exploration and Annotation through Lens-Based Guidance
authors: Franziska Becker, Steffen Koch, Tanja Blascheck
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: Annotation is often a time-consuming but fruitful activity in data analysis contexts. The manual labor required to create useful annotations is a barrier that keeps users from documenting their analysis, especially intermediate results. To address the needs of exploration and annotation alike, we propose integrating annotation with lens-based interactions, combining both with guidance. We investigate the exploration-annotation requirement space, identifying challenges and extracting five design requirements for annotation in exploration contexts. Based on this investigation, we designed ANNOLENS—a concrete instantiation of such a system that lets users explore and annotate dimensionality-reduced multivariate data. It employs a dual-lens approach for contrastive exploration, using guidance to steer users toward interesting data subsets and attributes. Annotation is directly integrated into the lenses, letting users quickly annotate hunches and discoveries. Automated merging and linking serve to simplify annotation management and reduce disruptions. In a pilot study, we conducted a preliminary evaluation of our approach, which indicated that users find it easy to annotate data and were able to incorporate their knowledge and unique perspective into the process. A free copy of this paper and all supplemental materials are available at https://osf.io/zpu6c/.

title: Regularized Solution of 2D Scattering from Impedance-Loaded Cavities: The TE-Case
authors: Paul D. Smith, Elena D. Vinogradova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: The two-dimensional (2D) scattering from an infinitely long cylinder of arbitrary cross-section in which an aperture has been opened is studied. The surface of the cylinder is of finite conductivity so that it is appropriate to enforce the Leontovich boundary condition on the surface. The incident magnetic field is parallel to the cylinder axis, so all fields are transverse electric (TE) to this axis. An integral equation (IE) with a hypersingular kernel is obtained for the surface current. The IE is ill-conditioned and must be regularized to obtain reliable numerical solutions. The process of analytical regularization employing the Abel integral transform method is described. Numerically computed scattered fields and their dependence on the impedance will be examined.

title: Optimization of Power Configuration Based on the Combined Algorithm of Simulated Annealing Particle Swarm
authors: Yihan Chen, Sibo Wang, Guangyuan Zou
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: To overcome the slow convergence and inadequate global search capabilities of traditional algorithms in high-dimensional nonlinear multi-objective power system optimization, this study develops a hybrid SA-PSO algorithm merging simulated annealing and particle swarm optimization. The innovation lies in synergizing SA's global perturbation with PSO's swarm intelligence through three mechanisms: integrating SA's Metropolis criterion to dynamically accept suboptimal solutions during PSO iterations, employing an exponential cooling strategy with a 0.95 temperature decay coefficient for adaptive search control, and designing a dual iterative process that alternates between SA-driven perturbation and PSO-based swarm updates. Experimental results reveal a threefold expansion in solution search range alongside 0.5% convergence error and 46% efficiency gains compared to conventional methods. In practical grid operations, the algorithm achieves 12% higher energy storage efficiency, maintains transmission coordination deviations within ± 0.8%, and reduces thermal power adjustment time. Economically, it lowers generation costs by 15.8% while environmentally cutting carbon emissions by 23.4%. By mitigating premature convergence in high-dimensional spaces and balancing exploration-exploitation dynamics, the approach demonstrates superior capability in coordinating cost-effectiveness, operational flexibility, and sustainability objectives, offering a systematic framework for complex power system optimization challenges.

title: Optimizing SDN Controllers with Huffman Coding for Smarter Flow Management
authors: Sampath Kumar Tallapally, Dandugudum Mahesh, Mohammad Sohail, Anusha Kandukuri, P Srinivas
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Software-Defined Networking (SDN) offers a flexible way to manage networks by separating the control plane from the data plane, but scalability remains a major challenge. As the number of flows in a network grows, SDN controllers struggle with increasing memory usage and slower rule processing. To address this, we present an optimization technique that applies Huffman coding to flow table management. The idea is simple: by using frequency-based encoding for commonly repeated match fields and actions, we can compress flow entries, reduce storage requirements, and speed up rule lookups. We tested this approach using Mininet and the Ryu controller, and the results show clear benefits lower memory consumption, faster rule retrieval, and improved network throughput compared to traditional methods. These findings suggest that Huffman coding provides a lightweight and effective way to enhance the scalability and performance of SDN controllers, making it a promising solution for future network architectures.

title: Using Dust Plasma Interactions to Shed Light on Magnetic Field Aligned Electron Density Structures in the Magnetized Dusty Plasma EXperiment (MDPX)
authors: Saikat Chakraborty Thakur, E. Price, S. Bachoti, J. Avritte, E. Thomas
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: In the Magnetized Dusty Plasma eXperiment (MDPX), we observe signatures of magnetic field aligned elongated density structures in capacitively coupled plasmas. These elongated filamentary structures appear in the low density, low temperature plasmas at high magnetic fields, under conditions where the electron and ion gyro-radii are smaller than their respective neutral collision mean free paths. Perpendicular to the magnetic field direction, these filamentary structures can have different shapes such as circular and multiarm spirals (resembling azimuthal modes). Fast imaging reveals various complex spatiotemporal dynamics such as translation and rotation of individual filaments, transformation between the various azimuthal modes/morphologies, formation and destruction of filaments due to interactions with background plasma turbulence, and emergence of the individual filaments from azimuthally elongated zonal flow like structures. Novel radial confinement schemes allow us to isolate and investigate some of these spatiotemporal dynamics in more detail. This presentation will give an overview of recent experimental efforts to understand the complex spatiotemporal dynamics of these filaments, as well as the use of charged dust grains to probe the 3-D structures and the electrostatic properties of these magnetic field aligned elongated filamentary density structures.

title: A 5.8 GHz Antenna Radiation Pattern with Four-Leaf Clover for Vehicular Communications and Sensing
authors: Vinicius Uchoa Oliveira, Amit Kumar Baghel, Pedro Pinho
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: The proposed antenna, optimized using a genetic algorithm (GA) to operate at 5.8 GHz, features a four-leaf clovershaped radiation pattern with a uniform gain of 3.5 dBi in the North, South, East, and West directions. This characteristic makes it suitable not only for vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communication but also for applications in vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) networks, intelligent sensor systems in urban and highway environments, traffic monitoring, asset tracking in logistics, and mesh networks for emergency communications. Additionally, its well-defined directional lobes enable its use in direction-sensing applications, such as angular position estimation and localization in wireless networks. The balanced gain distribution can also benefit IoT systems and surveillance drones, ensuring efficient connectivity without the need for multiple antennas or active beam-steering mechanisms.

title: Design and Implementation of a Solar-Powered Analog RF Jammer for Drone Interception at 2.4 GHz
authors: Dhruti Upadhyaya, Apurva Ashok Patil, Ananya I Shirol, Avani Ramesh, Sahana B, Usha Rani K. R
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: The widespread utilization of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) across various domains, coupled with the decreasing costs and advancing functionalities of UAV technology, presents a notable challenge to societal safety and the security of critical infrastructure. Consequently, there is a pressing need for the development of robust and adaptable systems capable of jamming drones effectively. This paper presents a solar-powered radio frequency (RF) jamming based drone interceptor system targeting 2.4 GHz Industrial, Scientific and Medical (ISM) band frequency. This solarpowered design enables autonomous operation in off-grid areas, ensuring effective disruption of drone-controller communication links. A detailed simulation analysis in LTSpice and a prototype has also been developed to assess the operational effectiveness of the proposed jamming system. The results demonstrate that the proposed system effectively generates jamming signals with sufficient power to neutralize unauthorized drones operating within the 2.4 GHz ISM band, validating its practicality, sustainability, and effectiveness as a countermeasure against drone-based threats in off-grid or tactical environments.

title: Simulation and Test of 112Gbps SerDes Power Noise
authors: Lingyun Liu, Jianguo Zhang, Bin Yu, Shuangman Xie, Erling Pan, Zhijun Long
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Advanced Interconnects (WAI)
abstract: Compared with traditional parallel transmission technology, serial transmission technology can fully utilize the channel capacity of communication channels, improve communication speed, and significantly reduce communication costs. SerDes (Serializer/Deserializer) is an integrated circuit technology that converts parallel data into high-speed serial data (transmitter) and restores serial data into parallel data (receiver), used to solve timing, noise, and distance issues in high-speed data transmission. Noise cannot be completely eliminated, and interference sources include circuit design, layout and wiring, as well as electron and hole characteristics. As the signal frequency increases, the impact of noise becomes greater, and the need to minimize noise becomes stronger. Based on practical project experience, this article introduces the noise simulation and testing of SerDes interface from the perspective of power supply noise simulation and testing principles. The noise simulation error of digital power supply and analog power supply is less than 3mV, achieving high-precision noise simulation consistency alignment.

title: Cell-specific network-based cell type prediction via graph convolutional network using transcriptomics profiles
authors: Joung Min Choi, Heejoon Chae
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 9th International Conference on Medical and Health Informatics
