title: YOLOv8-based Agricultural Robots for Precision Pollination and Yield Prediction
authors: Monikapreethi S K, Geetha D, Narayana Moorthy G, R. Jagadeesh Kannan, Monisha R, C Srinivasan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Precision agriculture uses advanced technology to enhance agricultural yield and sustainability. This research presents a YOLOv8-based agricultural robotic system for precise pollination monitoring and production forecasting. The system incorporates high-resolution cameras and IoT-enabled sensors to identify flowers, monitor pollinators, and evaluate fruit growth in real time. Utilizing YOLOv8's deep learning framework, the system attains exceptional detection accuracy, with an average precision (AP) of 99.4% for flower identification and 98.7% for pollinator tracking. The obtained data is analyzed using a cloud-based machine learning framework, which facilitates yield prediction with 99.4% accuracy, surpassing conventional human estimation techniques by 22.8%. Experimental findings from tomato greenhouse research indicated a 25.6% enhancement in pollination efficiency, resulting in improved fruit set and increased yield. The AI-driven robotic system improves precision agriculture via real-time monitoring, less labor reliance, and enhanced decision-making capabilities. It highlights the potential of YOLOv8-enabled agricultural robots to transform smart farming via precise pollination monitoring and accurate production prediction. Future work will concentrate on scalability for open-field crops and real-time adaptive pollination strategies to enhance agricultural efficiency.

title: Adaptive Model Compression for Lightweight Paper AI
authors: Anshjyot Singh Wadhwa, Mohit Chaudhary, Nitin Kumar Goyal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel prepruning compression scheme for ensemble-based Paper AI models, addressing the challenge of high memory consumption and slow inference times in contemporary large-scale datasets and resource-constrained environments. We present a feedback-driven mechanism for iteratively constructing compact yet accurate models by globally optimizing node selection and weights while maintaining local split decisions. This approach leverages an internal feedback loop to guide the iterative deepening of the ensemble, ensuring efficient resource utilization and competitive predictive performance, often surpassing larger, uncompressed models. Our methodology, adaptable for various predictive tasks, emphasizes a continuous feedback cycle for model refinement, offering a significant advancement towards deployable, high-performance Paper AI solutions.

title: Tracking Elbow Angles with Printed Dipole Antennas Through the Passive Extraction of $\mathrm{S}_{11}$ Parameter and Resonant Frequency: A Pilot Study
authors: J. Seignard, M-A. Petit, F. Moissenet, J-Y. Beaulieu, D. Bechevet, G. Déprès, N. Reverdy-Bruas
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This study explores a battery-free method for monitoring elbow flexion using a printed dipole antenna as a passive sensor. The antenna's resonant frequency and reflection coefficient <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(S_{11}\right)$</tex> change in response to bending, thus offering an innovative alternative to traditional sensor-based systems that require active power. Electromagnetic simulations were performed using CST Microwave Studio over several frequency bands (0-10 GHz, 1.2 – 1.6 GHz, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-4 \text{GHz}$</tex>) while varying the elbow angle from 0° to 150° in 5° increments. The results indicate that the resonant frequency varies continuously with the flexion angle, especially in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.5-2.5 \text{GHz}$</tex> band, where high stability and sensitivity were observed. Notable singularities at angles such as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0^{\circ}, 45^{\circ}, 90^{\circ}$</tex>, and 135° suggest complex electromagnetic interactions that merit further investigation. Repositioning the feed point proved critical, with optimal measurements obtained on the arm, at 5 mm away from the elbow. These findings confirm that printed dipole antennas can function as passive sensors for joint movement, paving the way for seamless integration into wearable textiles or direct skin applications. Future work will integrate human body models into the simulation, advance prototype development, and incorporate sophisticated signal processing to enhance gesture recognition. This approach represents a promising leap toward lightweight, durable, and energy-efficient wearable sensor technologies.

title: A Multimodal Approach for Detection of Preeclampsia Risk Analysis using Reinforcement Learning and Agentic AI
authors: Premanand Ghadekar, Swami Malode, Mrunmai Girame, Himanshu Patil, Hiteshi Patil, Tanishka Jagtap
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Preeclampsia, a hypertensive condition during pregnancy, affects <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5}-\mathbf{8\%}$</tex> of pregnancies worldwide and can cause serious problems for both the mother and the foetus. It's complicated pathophysiology and non-specific diagnostic indicators, like proteinuria and blood pressure, make early detection extremely difficult. In order to improve preeclampsia diagnosis and risk assessment, this study presents a novel multimodal AI-based framework that integrates clinical, genomic, organ-specific, and imaging data. Gene expression is examined for biomarker identification and pathway relevance, and machine learning models, such as Random Forest and a modified VGG16 with attention mechanisms, process structured and ultrasound data. Although current performance suggests room for improvement, a Deep Q-Network (DQN)based reinforcement learning module simulates treatment strategies in a customised gym setting. By utilising Lang Chain and keyword-driven logic, an agentic reporting system produces organ-specific insights on its own, improving interpretability for medical professionals.

title: Graph Neural Networks for Heart Disease Prediction: A SAGEConv Based Approach
authors: Pravir Mishra, Kamal Verma, Rashmi Kumari, Subhranil Das, Raghwendra Kishore Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Growth of advancements in machine learning have enabled better analyses of healthcare data. Having the ability to predict heart disease, a major cause of death, is fundamentally important for the timely diagnosis and treatment of an individual. In this research, we present a framework that uses graph neural networks (GNNs) to model relationships among patient characteristics and predict heart disease outcomes. We implement the SAGEConv architecture for graph convolutions, along with feature normalization and dropout techniques to enhance learning robustness. With training-validation-test splitting and neighbor sampling, we made sure the test was performed on a balanced-testing. To interpret the results, visualization techniques, including heat maps, graph splits, and confusion matrices, were performed. The model gave a test accuracy of 84.47 % and inspired confidence in identifying patterns from the patient data. Our findings illustrate the immense promise of GNNs for the predictive aspects of healthcare, showing their capacity to effectively model complex relationships. The framework proves important as a starting point for integrating graph-based learning into significantly high-stakes medical decision-making, with room for further improvements.

title: AI-Powered Monitoring System for Analog kWh Meters Using Digital Image Processing and OCR
authors: Phisca Aditya Rosyady, Mohamad Anom Purwo Wijaya
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ICoAIT)
abstract: Manual reading of analog kWh meters remains common in many regions, but it is inefficient, error-prone, and unsuitable for large-scale monitoring. This study proposes an AI-powered monitoring system that integrates digital image processing and Optical Character Recognition (OCR) to automatically read analog kWh meters without replacing existing devices. A webcam or smartphone camera captures frontal images of the meter display, which are processed on a Raspberry Pi using Tesseract OCR. The system was evaluated across three scenarios—printed digit tests, photographs, and live analog meters—achieving 100% accuracy for printed digits and live meter readings, and 54% accuracy for photographs. The results highlight both the feasibility and challenges of applying OCR in real-world conditions, such as lighting and reflections. This work contributes a low-cost and non-intrusive solution for automatic meter reading and intelligent energy management, while future improvements will focus on enhancing robustness through advanced preprocessing and deep learning-based OCR.

title: Variance-Weighted Centroid: A Centroid Estimation Approach for High-Dimensional Data Clustering
authors: Efori Bu'ulolo, Poltak Sihombing, Sutarman, Mohammad Andri Budiman
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Clustering high-dimensional data faces major challenges due to noisy and irrelevant features that weaken conventional methods like K-Means. This paper proposes the Variance-Weighted Centroid (VWC), a novel approach that leverages intra-cluster feature variance to assign dynamic weights during centroid estimation. Features with lower variance, which are more representative, are emphasized to produce accurate centroids without explicit dimensionality reduction. The method includes six steps, starting with KMeans++ initialization and iterative refinement using weighted distances. Experiments on synthetic and benchmark datasets show that VWC consistently outperforms K-Means, K-Medoids, Hamiltonian Formulation, and AIMK-RS in terms of SSE, Silhouette Score, execution time, and outlier detection. For instance, VWC achieves 94.6% stability in four iterations on the balance scale dataset, records the lowest SSE of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.2 \times 10^{-5}$</tex> on the ionosphere dataset, and reaches a Silhouette Score of 0.957 on the dna dataset. VWC ensures accuracy, efficiency, and stability, making it a promising clustering solution

title: DualSpar: A Dual-Granularity Memory Framework with Adaptive Sparsity for Efficient LLM Inference
authors: Yujuan Tan, Jiayi Guo, Zhuoxin Bai, Sanle Zhao, Yujiao Wang, Zongjie Wang, Ao Ren, Kan Zhong, Lin Huang, Jun Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: The block-based inference engine, powered by noncontiguous key-value (KV) cache management, has emerged as a new paradigm for large language model (LLM) inference due to its efficient memory utilization. However, in large-batch, longcontext workloads, the substantial demand for KV cache remains a major bottleneck in inference performance. Existing research leverages the sparsity of the attention mechanisms by removing non-critical tokens to limit the KV cache size. However, we observe that in block-based inference engines, current sparse methods require defragmentation after token removal to maintain tensor continuity, incurring significant overhead. Additionally, we find a correlation between request length and sparsity potential, yet existing methods apply a uniform sparsity strategy at batch level without dynamic adjustment. To address these, we propose DualSpar, a novel sparse KV cache framework with dual-granularity memory and adaptive sparsity strategy. First, it binds token importance to KV cache block granularity, achieving low-overhead pre-consolidation. Second, it incorporates system load and request length into sparsity decision, fully exploiting the sparse potential of different requests while reducing the queuing latency in large-batch processing. Evaluations show that DualSpar achieves up to a 3.16× throughput improvement, a 3.75× faster time-to-first-token (TTFT), and an 87.2% reduction in defragmentation overhead while maintaining high accuracy.

title: Instantaneous temperature estimation during short time overload operation of an IGBT
authors: Justin Xuereb, Reiko Raute, Alexander Micallef
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: In certain applications, such as motor soft starters, power electronic devices are required to operate only for brief durations. In low-cost product designs, the smallest component sizes are selected and temporarily overloaded during short intervals to minimize component costs and sizes. This paper delves into the current overload performance of an IGBT over a 2-second period. While the temperature of the die rises rapidly, the case temperature increase is delayed due to its thermal impedance, avoiding the possibility of a direct die temperature measurement from the case. This study utilizes the emitter PN junction of the IGBT for detecting the die temperature. The paper will provide a summary of the laboratory setup and experimental results to validate the testing methodology.

title: Contactless Biometric Authentication for Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Diya M Hande, Mallikarjun Yeshlur, Venkata Sravani Revuri, Roopa Ravish
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Contactless biometric authentication offers a promising solution for enhanced security in autonomous vehicles, addressing the growing vulnerabilities of traditional key-based systems to theft and unauthorized access. Recent advances in biometric technology have revolutionized security measures across various sectors, including the automotive industry, making biometric authentication systems, which leverage unique physical characteristics, a more secure alternative. Our study investigates the application of machine learning techniques, particularly convolutional neural networks for palm print recognition as a robust and contactless biometric identifier. Palm prints, which consist of unique patterns of principal lines, wrinkles, and other features, offer a robust and reliable method for user identification. By eliminating the need for manual feature engineering, CNNs automatically learn and extract distinctive features from palm print images. The proposed Visual Geometry Group(VGG16) based CNN model achieved an accuracy of 97.74% in identifying individuals based on their palm prints, demonstrating its potential for secure vehicle access. This proposed model is an alternative for fingerprint authentication which deals with issues such as lack of recognition of damaged finger prints and high error rates under extreme cold or heat.

title: Optimization Accuracy of Crop Yields Soil Fertility Prediction using Machine Learning
authors: Chandrika Rajput, S. Veenadhari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Agriculture accounts for a sizable amount of the Indian economy. Climate and soil quality have a huge impact on agriculture, so progress in these areas is essential. A common issue that Indian farmers there is a paucity of knowledge among farmers about appropriate crops that match there is soil requirements, which could affect output. This issue might be resolved through precision agriculture. CYP is a difficult undertaking in the agricultural industry. CY has many different aspects variable affected by a number of variables, including their environment, genetics, and interactions. A significant issue in agriculture is CYP. Numerous public and private institutions have a wealth of data pertaining to agriculture that must be analyzed in order to extract the important information needed to advance the field. The information on weather, production, and non-weather variables such as Temperature, precipitation, humidity, soil, and other factors are all highly helpful in analyzing crop trends. In this paper, soli analysis for CY using ML is present. Important studies in this area have focused on applying ML techniques to enhance the accuracy of agricultural yield forecasts.

title: Evaluation of Network RTK and Post-Processed Loosely and Tightly Coupled GNSS/IMU Solutions in Vehicle Dynamics
authors: Yen-Ru Lai, Szu-Pyng Kao, Ching-Ming Lai, He-Chin Chen, Wan-Leng Ke, Yuan-Hung Chiang, Ming-En Syu, An-Ting Chang, Ching-Mei Tseng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: Accurate and reliable positioning of vehicles is critical for advanced driver-assistance systems (ADAS) and autonomous driving. In this study, we evaluate five navigation strategies-network-based real-time kinematic (Network RTK), GNSS-only post-processed kinematic (PPK), and three GNSS/ IMU integration modes: loosely coupled (LC), tightly coupled single-pass (TC-SP), and tightly coupled multi-pass (TC-MP) by using Synchronous Position, Attitude and Navigation (SPAN) system from NovAtel. Experiments were conducted along a 1.2 km loop in Yuetian Park, Taichung, with various environmental conditions, including open-sky segments, light canopy coverage, a tree-shaded S-turn, and a short underpass. Two static GNSS stations provided reference observations for relative positioning: Base A, located within the park, and Base B, approximately 3 km away. Simultaneously, the rover received Network RTK corrections from the e-GNSS system via the Virtual Reference Station (VRS) service. The TC-MP solution using Base A served as the ground-truth trajectory. Across all methods, LC and TC-SP significantly improved horizontal accuracy compared with GNSS-only solutions, achieving sub-decimeter performance when a nearby base was available. Over longer baselines, TC-SP maintained centimeter-to-decimeter accuracy, while TC-MP achieved centimeter-level precision after batch processing. The results confirm TC-SP and TC-MP as robust, high-accuracy solutions for vehicle navigation.

title: Energy Flow Management in Smart Homes via Pontryagin Minimum Principle
authors: Stefano Leonori, Roberto Rocca, Marco Ricci, Fabio Massimo Frattale Mascioli, Luigi Martines
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper presents a study on the application of the Pontryagin’s Minimum Principle algorithm for energy flow scheduling in a prosumer smart home equipped with Photovoltaic generation and a Battery Energy Storage System. The optimization objective is to minimize the cumulative quadratic deviation of grid exchange with respect to the daily net energy demand, thereby promoting load balancing and reducing grid stress. The proposed method provides a flexible and effective alternative to Rule Based solutions, showing substantial improvements. Valuable insights are also provided through a comparison with a Dynamic Programming solution used as benchmark. Compared to complex solvers, the proposed method is easy to implement, computationally lightweight, and versatile. Moreover, the approach can be extended to add other devices and/or accommodate multi-objective optimizations.

title: An Enhanced Semi-Supervised Gaussian Fuzzy C-Means Clustering Algorithm for Remote Sensing Image Data Analysis
authors: Le Tuan Anh, Dinh Sinh Mai, Ha Thi Lien Doanh
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: Satellite image data has many advantages for mapping and assessing land cover changes, environmental monitoring, and urban planning. However, remote sensing image data often contains noise and outliers. Traditional clustering algorithms often encounter challenges in processing this data. This paper proposes an enhanced semisupervised Gaussian fuzzy c-Means clustering algorithm for remote sensing image analysis (ESS-GFCM). The proposed algorithm integrates Gaussian membership functions with semi-supervised learning constraints and a boosting mechanism to improve land cover classification performance from remote sensing imagery. The proposed method can use some labeled or known data to aid the clustering process, incorporate Gaussian kernel weights to better model class distributions, and apply boosting updates to stabilize convergence. Experiments performed on Sentinel-2 and Landsat-8 datasets demonstrate that ESS-GFCM outperforms FCM, Gaussian FCM, and Semi-supervised FCM algorithms in terms of classification accuracy, robustness to noise, and computational speed.

title: Optimizing Battery Storage Operation in the MIBEL: Integrating Price Forecasting and Degradation Models
authors: João Alves, Vítor Lopes, Jennifer Teixeira, Alexander Eeles, Pablo Montesino, Pedro Faria, Zita Vale, Pedro Salomé
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The increasing volatility of electricity markets, driven by the growing integration of renewable energy, poses challenges for energy consumers seeking cost-effective energy management strategies. To minimize energy procurement costs in the Iberian Electricity Market (MIBEL), this study proposes an integrated framework combining long-term price forecasting and battery degradation-aware optimization. Based on historical market data from 2019 to 2024, a linear regression model forecasts hourly prices up to 2030, incorporating projected growth in solar and wind capacities. The optimization model evaluates the operational strategies for two lithium-ion battery chemistry types: Lithium Manganese Oxide (LMO) and Lithium Nickel Manganese Cobalt Oxide (NMC). It incorporates degradation costs directly into its objective function during operational planning, dynamically accounting for the effects of cycling. The degradation impact is incorporated using semi-empirical models capturing both calendar and cycling ageing mechanisms. Results demonstrate that including degradation in the optimization process significantly alters operational patterns, leading to lower energy costs and extended battery lifetime. Additionally, a comparative analysis highlights the superior performance of NMC batteries under projected market conditions. This framework provides valuable insights into energy storage planning in evolving electricity markets and lays the groundwork for future advancements in degradation-aware optimization strategies.

title: Feasible Operating Region-Based Sampling for Representative OPF Datasets
authors: Sarra Bouchkati, Luke Kampmann, Luis Böttcher, Andreas Ulbig
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The increasing interest in data-driven approaches for solving the AC Optimal Power Flow (ACOPF) problem has highlighted the importance of representative datasets. These datasets are crucial for benchmarking the surrogate models, particularly under realistic and previously unobserved grid conditions. However, generating such datasets remains a significant challenge due to the non-convexity of the ACOPF problem, as well as limitations related to data availability, privacy, and confidentiality. In this work, we present a novel constraint-guided exploration of the Feasible Operating Region (FOR), aimed at efficiently identifying and sampling regions where system constraints become active. To generate corresponding load profiles, we employ an OPF-based disaggregation method that ensures physical and operational feasibility. We validate the proposed approach on SimBench benchmark grids, demonstrating its effectiveness in capturing active constraint regions when compared to random sampling methods.

title: Efficient Modeling of Multi-Purpose Dual-Band Reflectarray Cells Using Support Vector Regression
authors: Daniel Martinez-de-Rioja, Jesus A. Lopez-Fernandez, Juan Córcoles, Manuel Arrebola
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: The design of large reflectarray antennas usually demands a high computational cost for the accurate analysis of the printed elements on the reflectarray surface. The use of approximations to reduce the computational workload impacts on the design accuracy by introducing errors in the phase of the reflected field that can result in increased side lobe levels and loss of gain. In contrast, surrogate modelling of the reflection coefficients of the reflectarray cell might provide sufficient accuracy without significantly reducing the design accuracy. The high gain antennas embarked on satellites require large antenna apertures, accurate beam shaping and optimal aperture efficiency, which prevents the use of general design approaches to reduce the computational cost. In this work, a single-layer multi-purpose reflectarray cell is characterized using Support Vector Regression (SVR) to speed up the electromagnetic analysis of large reflectarray antennas with dual-band and dual-polarization operation, without compromising accuracy.

title: Measurement of Fifth Overtone Quality Factor of Quartz Crystal Piezoelectric Sensor with Asymmetric Ring Electrodes
authors: Jianguo Hu, Hao Li, Yangbin Wei, Zhigang Wang, Guangkun Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: The fifth overtone quality factor (Q<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</inf>) of quartz crystal piezoelectric sensors with asymmetric ring electrodes is investigated in this paper. Fifth overtone quality factor is a critical parameter for asymmetric ring electrode quartz crystal piezoelectric sensors operating in the fifth overtone mode because it closely associated with dynamic variations and stability during detection processes. Considering that the nominal fundamental resonance frequency is different from the actual fundamental resonance frequency. Similarly, the nominal fifth overtone resonance frequency is also different from the actual fifth overtone resonance frequency. Therefore, it is essential to distinguish between the actual fifth overtone quality factor and the nominal fifth overtone quality factor (Q’<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</inf>). We calculated the Q<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</inf> and Q’<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</inf>, and the results demonstrate that the actual Q<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</inf> values are 2–4 times higher than the nominal Q’<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</inf>. Furthermore, we calculated the fundamental frequency mass sensitivity and fifth overtone mass sensitivity of these sensors. The results revealed that the fifth overtone mass sensitivity is fivefold greater than its fundamental frequency mass sensitivity, indicating that operating quartz crystal piezoelectric sensors with asymmetric ring electrodes in the fifth overtone mode significantly enhances their mass sensitivity. This research will not only inspire novel applications of quartz crystal piezoelectric sensors with asymmetric ring electrode in the fifth overtone mode but also advance their utilization in sensing and detection technologies.

title: Quantum LSTM with Ant Colony Optimization for Protein Mutation Detection
authors: Shakthi Priya V, Shalini M, Uma Maheshwari P
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: A key component of the comprehending genetic variants and their biological effects is the rapid identification of protein mutations. For mutation classification, a novel machine learning framework is used in this study that combines quantum and classical deep learning techniques. Protein sequence data from the National Centre for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) is used and undergo preprocessing, artificial mutation simulation, and one-hot encoding to convert sequences into numerical representations. Feature selection is performed using Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) to reduce dimensionality and enhance computational efficiency. The classification process uses a Quantum Long Short-Term Memory (QLSTM) network with linear, variational quantum circuit (VQC), fully connected, dropout, and output layers. The hybrid model successfully separates mutant and non-mutated protein sequences and the hybrid methodology's overall accuracy was 95%, according to experimental assessment, providing a viable approach for bioinformatics applications that make use of quantum computing.

title: A Method For Monitoring Intracranial Hemorrhage Based On Electrical Impedance Tomography Technique
authors: Gang He, Chengwei Li, Xingyu Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Intracranial hemorrhage is a serious neurological emergency, and rapid and accurate monitoring is essential to avoid brain damage. Electrical impedance tomography (EIT) is a non-invasive, radiation-free medical imaging technique. Therefore, this paper combines some related circuit designs to develop a portable impedance measurement device and designs an impedance tomography image reconstruction algorithm with multi-channel information fusion. The EIT reconstruction algorithm, which encodes the measured voltage matrices of different construction methods, the dilated convolution that is not involved in the encoding process to obtain more feature information, which is subsequently fused into the decoding stage to realize a more accurate reconstruction of the bleeding point. This method can realize the monitoring of intracranial hemorrhage points more rapidly and accurately, and react to the magnitude of the bleeding degree.

title: An Integrated AI Framework for Tomato Leaf Disease Detection and Severity Assessment
authors: Logeshwari D, Shivaraj D, Shankar Navneeth R R
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Tomato crops are Tomato plants are especially prone to a wide range of leaf infections, which often result in lower harvest yield as well as poor fruit quality. It catches the problem so quickly and in a very accurate manner, which would be the key to keeping losses low. This study would put a framework which is efficient and that blends advanced neural networks with computational learning methods to analyse and diagnose the diseases in the leaves. A model which is very advanced learning model which is used to classify the different disease, and the U-Net framework handles precise the pixel-level segmentation to the mark the exact affected areas which is very efficient. From the marked areas or in other words the segmented areas, features like the percentage of infected tissue, texture patterns, and the various colour variations are extracted. The features which are extracted are fed into an XGBoost algorithm, which analyse how much serious the disease is. This method would achieve the accuracy of 96% accuracy in classification, the score of the Dice of 0.91 for segmentation, and an R2 value of 0.93 for the estimation of the severity. It is built to run on the mobile and the edge devices, thus this system provides a very clear visual results and practical treatment methods, supporting the real-time planning in the correct farming methods.

title: A Computational Intelligence Approach Using Fuzzy Tsukamoto for Investment Feasibility Assessment Based on Financial Ratios
authors: Anna Hendri Soleliza Jones, Suwanto, Dwi Normawati
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ICoAIT)
abstract: Redundancy in manual data processing, limited investor knowledge, and difficulty in evaluating financial statements are challenges frequently faced in investment decision-making on the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX). This study proposes a web-based Decision Support System (DSS) that applies the Fuzzy Tsukamoto method to evaluate investment feasibility based on four financial ratios: current ratio, net profit margin, return on assets (ROA), and return on equity (ROE). The system categorizes investment feasibility into three classes: Not Feasible, Partially Feasible, and Feasible. Experimental results using data from 163 companies across eight industrial sectors achieved an average accuracy of 96%, as validated by expert judgment through Spearman’s rank correlation. These results demonstrate the potential of the proposed system as a reliable tool for assisting investors in making informed investment decisions.

title: Measurement of Underwater Electrical Explosion Shock Wave and Bubble Pulse
authors: Tianshun Lin, Gang Wan, Honge Luo, Chundong Xu, Minjie Wan, Xiaofang Kong
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: A set of test systems is designed and constructed to study the propagation characteristics of underwater electrical explosion shock wave and bubble pulse. A high-voltage current is applied to an aluminum wire submerged in water, causing it to explode under the influence of a strong electric field and release energy instantaneously, thereby exciting a shock wave and triggering a bubble pulse. To obtain pressure wave characteristics at different propagation distances, two piezoelectric pressure sensors of different models are deployed at positions 46 cm, 56 cm and 86 cm from the explosion center for independent measurements. A high-speed camera with the powerful light source is used to record the image sequences of bubble evolution. Experimental results show that the shock wave at various distances exhibits typical characteristics of rapid rise and decay. The peak pressure decreases significantly as the propagation distance increases. Bubble pulses display a low-amplitude, long-duration sinusoidal structure. Waveforms measured by the two sensors at the same locations are highly consistent, showing similar peak decay trends and indicating that the measurement system has good stability and repeatability. This study provides data support for understanding the propagation behavior of underwater electrical explosion pressure waves.

title: AI Agent Architecture for Decentralized Trading of Alternative Assets
authors: Ailiya Borjigin, Cong He, Charles Cc Lee, Wei Zhou, Cheng Yao Song
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: Decentralized trading of real-world alternative assets (e.g.,gold) requires bridging physical asset custody with blockchain systems while meeting strict requirements for compliance,liquidity,and risk management.We present a research- oriented architecture,GoldMine OS,that employs multiple specialized AI agents to automate and secure the tokenization and exchange of physical gold into a blockchainbased stable coin (“OZ").Our approach integrates on-chain smart contracts for critical risk controls with off-chain AI agents for decision-making,combining the transparency and reliability of blockchains with the flexibility of AI-driven automation.We detail the design of four cooperative agents (for Compliance,Token Issuance,Market-Making,and Risk Control) and a coordinating core,and we evaluate the system through both simulation and a controlled pilot deployment.In experiments,the prototype achieves on- demand token issuance in under 1.2 s,a speed-up of over $100 \times$ compared to traditional manual workflows.The integrated Market-Making agent provides tight liquidity (spread often $\lt 0.5 \%$) even under volatile market conditions.Through fault injection tests,we demonstrate the system’s resilience: an oracle price spoofing attack is detected and mitigated within 10 s,and a simulated vault misreporting triggers an immediate halt of issuances with minimal impact on users.The architecture scales at least $\mathbf{5,0 0 0}$ transactions/s with $\mathbf{1 0,0 0 0}$ concurrent users in our benchmarks.Our results indicate that an AI-agent- based decentralized exchange for alternative assets can meet rigorous performance and safety requirements.We discuss the broader implications for democratizing access to traditionally illiquid assets and outline how our governance model (multi- signature agent updates and on-chain community voting on risk parameters) ensures ongoing transparency,adaptability,and formal assurance of system integrity.

title: On the Design of Mobility-Aware Systems: A Tourist’s Perspective
authors: Douglas L. L. Moura, Andre L. L. Aquino, Antonio A. F. Loureiro
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: The design of effective mobility-aware systems requires a deep understanding of how different user groups navigate and interact within urban environments, enabling the development of services and infrastructures that adapt to dynamic movement patterns. Tourist mobility patterns, in particular, offer valuable insights into the spatial and social dynamics that influence system design decisions for smart cities, recommendation engines, and urban planning applications. This work presents a comprehensive approach to modeling urban mobility networks by examining tourist behavior through network analysis techniques. Using Rome as a case study, we leverage a large dataset of Foursquare check-ins collected over 18 months to construct a co-visitation graph where nodes represent points of interest and edges reflect shared visits by the same users. Through network analysis of Rome’s tourist mobility, our work identifies clear structural differences between visitor types: long-term visitors form cohesive, highly clustered mobility networks, while short-term visitors create more fragmented interaction patterns. Key points of interest (especially transportation hubs and cultural landmarks) serve as essential connectors shaping network flow, following preferential attachment dynamics. Mobility-aware systems play a crucial role in leveraging such insights to design adaptive, data-driven services that respond to varying mobility behaviors, ultimately enhancing urban efficiency and user experience.

title: Parameterizing Nonlinear Behavior of Short Circuit Current with Inverter-Based Resources
authors: Zahid Javid, Firdous Ul Nazir, Ahmed Aboushady, Mohamed Galeela
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The integration of renewable energy sources (wind and solar farms etc.), introduces inverter-based resources (IBRs) into the power grid. These resources exhibit unique and nonlinear fault current characteristics. This research aims to develop a simulation environment utilizing a steady-state short circuit solver to analyze and parameterize the short circuit response of a large-scale network with IBRs. The focus is on employing an improved data fitting technique to enhance accuracy. The effectiveness of the proposed solver is demonstrated on a 120 kV test system. A variety of fault scenarios are simulated to generate a comprehensive dataset, which is subsequently used to parameterize the nonlinear behavior of short circuit current induced by IBRs, utilizing higher order polynomial data fitting technique. The proposed solver, with the improved current limiting strategy, achieved a comprehensive dataset with 100% convergence for balanced faults and 99.97% for unbalanced faults Furthermore, the employment of a higher-order polynomial data fitting technique yields 96% more accurate on average compared to locally weighted scatterplot smoothing (LOWESS) data fitting methods proposed in literature. This comparison highlights the enhanced performance of the proposed methodology, showcasing significant improvements in both efficiency and accuracy.

title: Coordinated Control of an Electric-Hydrogen based DC Microgrid for green transportation
authors: John Licari, Salah Eddine Rhaili, Cyril Spiteri Staines, Maurice Apap, Alexander Micallef
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The global push towards carbon neutrality has amplified interest in integrating renewable energy systems with sustainable transportation. This paper presents the design, modelling, and coordinated control of a DC microgrid that uses an electro-hydrogen hybrid energy storage system to facilitate green transportation within an industrial facility. The proposed system integrates photovoltaic (PV) generation, a battery energy storage system (BESS), a Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM) electrolyser, and electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure. A centralized supervisory controller coordinates power flow to maximize onsite energy self-consumption and eliminate grid power injection. The microgrid performance is tested using realworld solar irradiance and load data from an actual manufacturing facility, enabling a realistic validation of its control behaviour. Simulation results demonstrate the system’s effectiveness in managing energy resources, maintaining voltage stability, and enabling green hydrogen production for transportation applications under realistic operating scenarios.

title: Research on Online Traffic Identification Technology in Satellite Networks
authors: Qingrui Guo, Ling He, Xuerang Guo, Huiting Yang, Ya'nan Xin
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: With the advancement of global informatization, satellite networks play an increasingly vital role in global communications due to their wide coverage and geographical independence. However, challenges such as dynamic topology, constrained resources, and complex environments hinder efficient traffic identification. This paper proposes a lightweight and adaptive online traffic identification method based on SDN architecture, utilizing a GEO-centric OpenSAN framework and coordinated ground-space deployment. A satellite network testbed and identification system are developed to validate the proposed approach. Through three experiments on two datasets, we evaluate the DATI algorithm in terms of accuracy, latency, and resource usage. Results show DATI outperforms k-means, FS-Net, and LNN, demonstrating high adaptability and efficiency, and confirming its feasibility for real-world satellite network applications.

title: Research on Computer Vision in Rooftop Photovoltaic Terrace Area Behavior Recognition System
authors: Shuyin Duan, Jiapeng Chen, Lei Yu, Jianhua Xiao, Xinhao Lin, Rong Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: With the rapid development of rooftop photovoltaic industry, it is very important to use computer vision to realize intelligent recognition of terrace area behavior. This paper proposes a behavior recognition algorithm based on multimodal feature fusion and dynamic spatiotemporal attention. By improving the YOLO network to extract small target features of visible light images, combined with thermal features of thermal infrared images, an adaptive weighting strategy is adopted to fuse multimodal information; the Transformer structure is introduced to construct a dynamic spatiotemporal attention module, and the weight is adjusted dynamically according to the scene. A behavior recognition system is built and experiments are carried out. The experimental data set contains 2000 annotated images, which are divided into training set, validation set and test set according to 7:1:2. The results show that the recognition accuracy of the algorithm on the test set is 96.5%, the recall rate is 95.8%, and the F1 value is 96.1%. Compared with the traditional CNNbased method, the accuracy rate increased by 12.3%, the recall rate increased by 11.7%, and the F1 value increased by 12.0%; compared with YOLOv5, the accuracy rate increased by 7.2%, the recall rate increased by 6.8%, and the F1 value increased by 7.0%, showing good recognition performance and robustness in the rooftop photovoltaic terrace scenario.

title: A Zero-Shot Framework for Automated Media Framing Analysis using Large Language Models
authors: Esther Alice Mathew, Angelin Jeba
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: The framing of information in news media profoundly influences public perception, yet its analysis at scale remains a significant challenge. Traditional computational methods, such as sentiment analysis, are often insufficient as they fail to capture the nuanced narrative angles that define media frames. This paper introduces a novel, zero-shot framework for the automated classification of news headlines into predefined media frames using a large language model (LLM). A codebook of four primary frames—Economic Consequences, Human Interest, Conflict, and Ethical & Moral—is established, and a structured prompt is engineered to guide the LLM's inferential process. The framework is validated through a proof-of-concept, applied to a curated set of headlines concerning the topic of Electric Vehicles (EVs), which demonstrates the model's capacity to consistently identify the dominant narrative frame and provide a coherent justification for its classification. This work represents a step towards the development of more sophisticated, scalable, and accessible tools for computational media analysis, enabling researchers to move beyond simple sentiment and explore the deeper structures of media discourse.

title: Compact $6 \times 6$ Nolen Matrix with Lumped Elements in UHF Band
authors: Cristina Ramos, Mariano Baquero, Fernando Carrera-Suárez
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This article presents a beamforming network based on <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \times 6$</tex> Nolen matrix using lumped elements throughout the entire matrix, on a single layer in the UHF band. The methodology for designing branch-line couplers and phase shifters is based on the equivalence between transmission lines and lumped elements. The large number of ports implies more accurate design considerations and optimizations, which are explained in detail first. The matrix was designed on Roger 4003 substrate using SMD-type lumped elements in a 1005 package. The design's central frequency is 922 MHz, but the operating frequency is guaranteed to be between 905 and 930 MHz, which is within the ISM band. The simulated results are in agreement with the ideal values for the differential phase, with a maximum dispersion of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm \mathbf{1 5}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$</tex>. The maximum insertion loss is 2.6 dB due to the lumped elements. The radiation patterns at the output ports indicate good results in terms of beam scanning. The overall matrix size is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10.9 \times 5.8 ~\text{cm}$</tex>. Hence, this feeding network exhibits the correct behavior for a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \times 6$</tex> Nolen matrix, and its footprint is eleven times smaller than it would be if implemented using microstrip lines.

title: DCAE: An Attention-Guided Denoising-Andclassification Autoencoder for Brain-Tumor MRI with CBAM and Skip Connections
authors: Youzhi Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Robust denoising is imperative for brain-tumor MRI, where stochastic noise and artefacts can obscure subtle lesions and compromise computer-aided diagnosis. This study sought to establish a unified model that encompasses noise suppression and tumor recognition across four distinct categories, namely glioma, meningioma, pituitary and nontumor. In this study, a public Kaggle dataset (comprising 7,023 slices) was utilised, with the standardisation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$256 \times 256$</tex> inputs and the training of a Denoising-and-Classification Autoencoder (DCAE) being the primary focus. The architecture of the DCAE comprised a convolutional encoder-decoder with CBAM attention on the encoder, symmetric skip connections to preserve high-frequency structure, and a lightweight MLP branching from the 512-dimensional bottleneck for classification. The training process incorporated synthetic Gaussian noise injection, in conjunction with a joint objective and label-smoothed cross-entropy (weights <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$a_{1}=1.0, a_{2}=0.55$</tex>). The training dataset was partitioned into an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 5} \boldsymbol{/} \mathbf{1 5}$</tex> stratified split for validation purposes, and an untouched Kaggle test set was utilized for reporting outcomes. In the test set, the attention-only variant demonstrated the optimal diagnostic performance (Accuracy 98.25 %, Macro-F1 98.20 %), exhibiting an enhancement of approximately 0.85 percentage points over the baseline. CBAM+Skip exhibited a close second position <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{(} \mathbf{9 8. 0 9} \boldsymbol{\%} \boldsymbol{/} \mathbf{9 8. 0 4 \%} \boldsymbol{)}$</tex>, while exhibiting the lowest terminal reconstruction loss and most stable descent. These findings lend support to the hypothesis that attention-guided denoising, coupled with shared representations, enhances both fidelity and diagnostic reliability.

title: Exploratory Study of Deployment of Demand Reduction Through Voltage Control
authors: Chloé Couturier, Jianing Li, Ana Radovanovic, Naomi Morrow, Abdullah Emhemed
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Demand reduction through voltage control has been seen as a promising alternative to costly traditional network reinforcements required for creating additional capacity in electricity networks. This paper presents the aggregated load models of distribution substations developed based on real-life measurement data based on field trial as well as analysis of the variation in static exponential load model parameters over a year. The field measurements were taken from various types of voltage reduction technologies and scenarios including the decrement of the tap position on distribution transformers. The load modelling analysis is carried out for three representative 33kV/11kV substations where a correlation is found between the amount of demand reduction and the results of the static exponential load model. These load models can aid future analyses of networks in terms of the potential for demand reduction through voltage control.

title: A Real-Time GCN and AI Agent Framework for Sustainable Supply Chain Management Under Disaster Scenarios
authors: Premanand Ghadekar, Parth Musne, Indrakumar Naragude, Mrunmai Girame
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel framework integrating graph-based deep learning with multi-modal data fusion to analyze sustainability in supply chains. The system uses Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) to model supply chain entities as nodes with carbon footprint, labor efficiency, and revenue attributes. Edges represent logistical relationships. A hybrid approach combines real-time climate data, disaster simulation, and tabular machine learning to predict risks, optimize recovery, and estimate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> emissions. The framework includes an agent-based recovery module and a comparative analysis of ML models (XGBoost, Random Forest) on merged datasets. Experimental results demonstrate 85.7% accuracy in risk prediction using GCNs and a 22% reduction in economic losses during disaster recovery. Future work will expand the dataset and integrate reinforcement learning for dynamic optimization.

title: An Enhanced Deep Learning and Radiomics-based Software Pipeline for Uterine Fibroid Detection in MRI
authors: Kavya N, Anita Rose J T, Reeba Rose L
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Uterine fibroids, or leiomyomas, are the common benign tumor of the female reproductive system. With uterine fibroid diagnosis, there can be many manifestations may be associated like heavy bleeding, pelvic pain, or pressure, infertility, or even malignant transformation, therefore making it a diagnosis worth reviewing due to its clinical significance. It is important to get an early and correct diagnosis of uterine fibroids, as it will directly affect the management of the condition and potential overall improvement in the patient's outcomes. In this study, here present a reproducible hybrid pipeline that integrates deep learning and radiomics for the automatic detection of uterine fibroids in MRI. The hybrid framework includes a U-Net based segmentation module to locate uterine fibroids, a ResNet-18 based region of interest (ROI) classifier to predict benign vs malignant, and PyRadiomics to extract handcrafted radiomics features. A LightGBM meta-learner was employed to perform feature-level stacking with the deep learning CNN embeddings and radiomics descriptor features. Tested the framework on datasets with uterine myoma data (Uterine Myoma Dataset (UMD)) and TCGA-UCEC. Shown that the hybrid framework achieves better performance than the single-paradigm models with U-Net Dice scores of 0.91 for segmentation and prediction accuracy of 95.1% and AUC of 0.97. In the framework, compared our hybrid setup against CNN-only, radiomic-only, and transformer-based approaches, to show the advantages of stacking. The pipeline was designed using PyTorch, and made the study reproducible by providing open-source scripts available on GitHub, to encourage future research efforts around gynecological AI. The framework has promise in the clinical environment as a supportive decision tool for radiologists and gynecologists that can assist in the early diagnosis of uterine myomas and help in treatment selection.

title: Active Harmonic Compensating Power Supply for Primary Circuits of Power System
authors: Qiancheng Zhao, Xiwen Chen, Bing Lu, Gaoning Nie, Miao Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: There are currently numerous technologies available for conducting online measurements of power grid equipment. However, the impact of primary-side load current on online measurement results cannot be ignored. To eliminate this influence, the operating principle of an active harmonic compensation power source for primary-side lines was first determined based on the concept of active noise control. Subsequently, a synchronous modulation power source capable of offsetting the primary load current was successfully developed, utilizing synchronous modulation and self-current-sharing techniques. Test results show that the proposed power source can adapt to field conditions with high harmonic content and rapid changes in load current.

title: Research on Network Intrusion Detection Algorithm Based on Deep Learning
authors: Jidong Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: As the network security situation becomes increasingly complex, the effectiveness of network intrusion detection systems is crucial. This paper proposes an adaptive fusion feature convolutional recurrent neural network (AFFCRNN) algorithm for network intrusion detection. The algorithm organically combines the local feature extraction capability of convolutional neural networks with the processing advantages of recurrent neural networks for sequence data, and uses the adaptive feature fusion mechanism to dynamically adjust the weights of features at different levels according to data features. In the experimental simulation phase, the study selected two representative data sets, KDD Cup 99 and CSE-CIC-IDS2018. On the KDD Cup 99 data set, the AFF-CRNN algorithm showed excellent performance, with an accuracy rate of up to 98.5 % and a false alarm rate of only 1.2 %. Compared with traditional deep learning intrusion detection algorithms, the accuracy rate increased by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3-5 \%$</tex> and the false alarm rate decreased by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2-3 \%$</tex>. On the CSE-CIC-IDS2018 data set, its accuracy rate reached <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 6. 8 \%}$</tex> and the false alarm rate was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 1 \%}$</tex>, which was also significantly better than the comparison algorithm. The experimental results fully prove that the AFFCRNN algorithm greatly improves the accuracy and reliability of network intrusion detection, and injects strong impetus into the network security protection system.

title: A Mathematical Framework for Digital Twins of Cyber-Physical Energy Systems
authors: Juan Camilo López, Jacco Reuling, Gerwin Hoogsteen, Johann L. Hurink
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper introduces a mathematical framework for designing digital twins (DTs) for cyber-physical energy systems (CPESs). Hereby we move beyond ad-hoc methods by employing physics-informed dynamic models and state-space representations. The framework encompasses key DT functionalities: state and parameter estimation, forecasting, prognosis, control, and system design, all underpinned by mathematical formulations. The practical applicability of this framework is demonstrated through a case study of an industrial power grid within a business park in the Netherlands, thereby focusing on a battery energy storage system (BESS). The case study illustrates how the DT architecture facilitates error detection, system design considerations, and supervisory control strategies by analyzing real-world operational data and estimating crucial BESS parameters like charging/discharging efficiencies and self-discharge rates. The dynamic and iterative nature of the proposed DT architecture, continuously updated with new data, ensures a close replication of the physical twin (PT).

title: Malware Detection Analysis Using Gated Graph Neural Networks and Graph Convolutional Networks
authors: I Made Budhi Harta Kusuma, Abba Suganda Girsang
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ICoAIT)
abstract: The exponential growth of malware threats has created an urgent need for adaptive and accurate detection methods. This paper introduces a practical malware detection framework that transforms memory-dump features into graph structures and analyzes them using a sequential hybrid architecture combining Gated Graph Neural Networks (GGNN) and Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN). Unlike approaches that require binary disassembly or CFG extraction, our method constructs graphs efficiently via feature similarity, enabling scalable deployment. On a balanced dataset of 58,596 samples (29,298 malware and 29,298 benign) collected in 2023–2024, the hybrid model achieves 98.20% accuracy, 97.55% precision, 98.88% recall, 98.21% F1-score, and AUC-ROC ≈ 0.999 (PR AP = 1.00). These results outperform single-architecture baselines and recent methods while preserving practical applicability. Our contributions are: (i) an efficient graph construction pipeline from tabular memory dumps, (ii) a sequential GGNN→GCN hybrid that leverages complementary inductive biases, and (iii) thorough empirical validation with ablations, comparisons, and diagnostic visualizations. Limitations (scalability, dataset bias, and adversarial robustness) are discussed together with avenues for future work.

title: Detection of Data Center Load Loss Event with Wide-Area-Monitoring-System
authors: Qian Liu, Xinlan Jia, Sun Biao, Saurav Dulal, Chong Shen, Yu Liu, Chujie Zeng, Yuru Wu, Yilu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The rapid increase in load from data centers and cryptocurrency mining facilities in the United States, poses significant risks to power grid stability and challenges to balancing authorities. This paper proposes a novel approach for the identification of data center load loss events using FNET, a wide-area monitoring system that delivers real-time event information. The methodology focuses on analyzing voltage patterns and further comparing these events with similar characteristic occurrences, such as those observed in pump storage systems. The proposed solution aims to assist power regulatory agencies in improving grid stability and response effectiveness.

title: Smart HVAC System Controllers Addressing Preservation Requirements in Historic Buildings
authors: Carlos Faubel, Lakin Casey, Antonio Martinez-Molina, Cristina Nichiforov, Miltiadis Alamaniotis
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: This study explores the use of intelligent heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) controllers to improve environmental conditions in heritage buildings, balancing conservation needs and occupant thermal comfort while simultaneously reducing energy demand. Most heritage buildings rely on traditional on/off HVAC controllers with fixed temperature setpoints that fail to account for relative humidity variations and occupancy levels. This study develops and evaluates two intelligent HVAC system controllers based on artificial neural networks (ANN) and fuzzy inference systems (FIS), which regulate indoor air temperature and relative humidity while accounting for building occupancy patterns. Using real-world datasets taken from a UNESCO World Heritage site in San Antonio, Texas, USA, results indicate that smart controllers, particularly FIS model, enhance building performance by improving thermal comfort and indoor environmental conditions for building and artwork conservation while reducing HVAC operation time by up to 30% compared to conventional on/off controllers. The study highlights the advantages of smart controllers in enhancing both energy efficiency and preservation efforts in historic buildings while maintaining optimal thermal comfort.

title: XDMA: A Distributed, Extensible DMA Architecture for Layout-Flexible Data Movements in Heterogeneous Multi-Accelerator SoCs
authors: Fanchen Kong, Yunhao Deng, Xiaoling Yi, Ryan Antonio, Marian Verhelst
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: As modern AI workloads increasingly rely on heterogeneous accelerators, ensuring high-bandwidth and layout-flexible data movements between accelerator memories has become a pressing challenge. Direct Memory Access (DMA) engines promise high bandwidth utilization for data movements but are typically optimal only for contiguous memory access, thus requiring additional software loops for data layout transformations. This, in turn, leads to excessive control overhead and underutilized on-chip interconnects. To overcome this inefficiency, we present XDMA, a distributed and extensible DMA architecture that enables layout-flexible data movements with high link utilization. We introduce three key innovations: (1) a data streaming engine as XDMA Frontend, replacing software address generators with hardware ones; (2) a distributed DMA architecture that maximizes link utilization and separates configuration from data transfer; (3) flexible plugins for XDMA enabling on-the-fly data manipulation during data transfers. XDMA demonstrates up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$151.2 \times / 8.2 \times$</tex> higher link utilization than software-based implementations in synthetic workloads and achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.3 \times$</tex> average speedup over accelerators with SoTA DMA in real-world applications. Our design incurs <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<2 \%$</tex> area overhead over SoTA DMA solutions while consuming 17% of system power. XDMA proves that co-optimizing memory access, layout transformation, and interconnect protocols is key to unlocking heterogeneous multi-accelerator SoC performance.

title: Deep Learning-Based Image Retrieval of Crab Species Through Analysis of Shape Characteristics
authors: Abdul Haris Rangkuti, Nurul Hidayat, Lasmedi Afuan, Albert Kurniawan, Melanie Gabrielae, Alicia Tandianto
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Crabs are a highly sought-after and globally traded fishery commodity. Five species of crab are offered by numerous producers worldwide and are a leading commercial product. The high diversity of crab species means there are a wide variety of crab species worldwide, each with distinct physical characteristics, habitats, and ecological roles. This research is needed to accurately identify and differentiate these species, especially for researchers and observers. Farmers need an efficient way to identify and record crab species in specific habitats, such as mangrove forests. An automated data capture system accelerates the inventory and data analysis process. In this study, five CNN models and four confusion matrix methods were used, namely Manhattan, Euclidean, Cosine, and Menkowski. After testing, the MobileNetV2 and DenseNet169 models achieved average accuracy of 88% and 82% in detecting 10 crab species, respectively. The best confusion matrix method was Manhattan distance, followed by Cosine. This research can be further developed using deep learning architecture and other crab types.

title: Modal Analysis and Suppression of Sub-synchronous Oscillation in Doubly-fed Wind
authors: Yongjin Yu, Chongyang Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: To address the "curse of dimensionality" inherent in traditional sub-synchronous oscillation (SSO) analysis methods and to effectively mitigate SSO, we propose a damping ratio regression model alongside the design of a sub-synchronous damping controller (SSDC). Initially, the TLS-ESPRIT algorithm was employed to extract the principal modes of SSO. Subsequently, a damping ratio regression model was established using the principal component analysis (PCA)-random forest (RF) algorithm. The regression model was assessed to identify the dominant factors influencing SSO in wind farms. Thereafter, the SSDC was integrated into the static var generator (SVG) and optimized via a genetic algorithm (GA). Finally, a double-fed wind farm simulation model was implemented in PSCAD. The results demonstrate that the damping ratio regression model effectively identifies the dominant factors influencing SSO. The optimized sub-synchronous damping controller effectively resolves the issue of traditional SSDCs failing to provide positive damping under varying operating conditions and exhibits rapid suppression capabilities.

title: Root-Cause Assessment of Interactions Caused by Controllers of Inverter Based Resources
authors: Josue Andino, Milan Prodanović, Javier Roldán-Pérez
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Impedance-Based stability methods are emerging as an alternative way to assess inverter-based resources (IBRs) connected to the grid. These methods are based on the study of the eigenvalues of the minor loop that represents the product of the grid impedance and the IBR admittance, both measured at the connection point. However, the link between the shape of the eigenvalues and the admittance terms that cause instability is not straightforward to determine. As a consequence, redesigning control loops to improve stability margins is a challenging task. In this paper, a methodology to determine the influence of IBR controllers on the stability margins is proposed. This methodology is based on analytical derivations that help understand how the minor loop eigenvalues are affected by the different terms of the impedance/admittance. Then, a compensation loop is designed to stabilise the system. The proposal has been validated by using numerical simulations performed in MATLAB/Simulink of an IBR connected to a weak power grid.

title: Dynamic Graph Neural Networks for Uncertainty-Aware Residential Photovoltaic Power and Load Disaggregation
authors: Lorance Helwani, Tarek AlSkaif, Wilfried van Sark
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: As residential rooftop photovoltaic (PV) adoption increases, more local solar output becomes hidden behind-the-meter (BTM). Moreover, the stochastic and volatile nature of PV generation, combined with its invisibility, increases the variability and unpredictability of overall energy demand. Disaggregating BTM PV generation from actual net load is essential for reliable distribution grids operation. This paper presents an uncertainty-aware dynamic graph variational framework that disaggregates BTM PV generation and load using only smart-meter net load measurements. Using a dynamic graph, we represent 100 PV-equipped Dutch households as nodes, where edges encode correlations among their net demand time series. The Graph Attention Recurrent Neural Network encoder processes this graph with graph convolutions, self-attention, and recurrent layers to capture spatial relationships and temporal dynamics. A multi-quantile gated recurrent unit decoder then infers each home’s separate solar and load time series, outputting probabilistic estimates that quantify uncertainty in each output. Designed for real-time inference, it enables online distribution network level monitoring. We validate the method on real data demonstrating accurate disaggregation and reliable uncertainty quantification.

title: Penetration Testing in Wind Farms: Detection and Impact Analysis
authors: Can Ozkan, Dave Singelée, Amirreza Jafari Anarjan, Rick Loenders, Hakan Ergun
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Wind farms are critical cyberphysical infrastructures that require robust security measures to withstand cyber threats. This paper simulates real-world cyber-attack scenarios that target wind turbine stability by manipulating pitch angle and yaw control systems operated through Programmable Logic Controllers. Four different cyber attacks are executed as part of penetration testing exercises against wind turbines, three of which are developed using the pyModbusTCP library, while the last is leveraged using the mbtget tool. Furthermore, the detection capabilities of three widely adopted network-based intrusion detection system (IDS) solutions are evaluated. Then, we propose IDS signatures to enhance the detection capabilities of IDS solutions against these specific cyber attacks that alter wind speed data, potentially manipulating the pitch angle and causing physical impacts on the power system. Moreover, case studies assess the physical impact of cyber-attacks on wind turbine stability and power system performance. The findings revealed that signature-based IDS solutions are insufficient for detecting the modeled attacks, which could result in physical instability in wind turbines. Therefore, refined signatures should be developed and deployed in modern IDS solutions to enhance the resilience of infrastructures like wind farms.
