title: Multi-factor spatial downscaling of satellite precipitation based on vegetation index and elevation
authors: Zhaozhao Zeng, Nadav Peleg, Haonan Chen, Li Zhuo
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Many environmental applications, such as hydrological and agricultural studies, require high spatial resolution and accurate precipitation data. In many places, ground observations of precipitation are unavailable. Therefore, data on precipitation are often obtained from satellite remote sensing. Unfortunately, precipitation estimates from remote sensing products are often too coarse in space and require further downscaling to match the required spatial resolution. We developed the Landcover similarity and Distance Weighted Regression with Residual correction model (LDWRR) that incorporates a vegetation index based on an adaptive lag phase and topography, and also includes a residual correction procedure that is combined with ground observations. The performance of the model is assessed by downscaling precipitation data obtained from the Integrated Multi-satellitE Retrievals for Global Precipitation Measurement (IMERG) from 10 km to 1 km spatial resolution over the Pearl River Basin in Southern China from 2010 to 2019 at daily resolution. Validation of the downscaled precipitation is done using ground observations. The LDWRR model is able to reproduce the precipitation pattern at high resolution, and it provides improved precipitation accuracy compared with the original coarse precipitation data. The correlation coefficients of the precipitation downscaled using LDWRR are larger than 0.7 at daily resolution. Moreover, the accuracy improved by more than 4% on average compared with IMERG. The LDWRR model is general and can be used in other regions and on any remote sensing device to spatially downscale precipitation data.

title: Dynamic Event-Triggered Optimized Backstepping Control for Strict-Feedback Nonlinear Systems With Communication Constraints_supp1-3649129.pdf
authors: Yuan Fan
publish: N/A
abstract: In this work, a dynamic event-triggered optimized backstepping control approach based on neural networks is proposed to address communication limitations in strict-feedback nonlinear systems. Neural networks are employed to approximate the unknown system uncertainties, with their parameters updated via a gradient descent algorithm. To enhance the communication efficiency of both control inputs and neural network parameters, a dynamic event-triggering scheme is devised. This mechanism adaptively modifies its threshold parameters in real time, depending on the system’s tracking performance. Additionally, a disturbance observer is incorporated to mitigate the influence of external perturbations. By formulating a barrier-type performance index for subsystem optimization and integrating observer–actor–critic structures, both virtual and actual optimal controllers are derived within an inversion-based control framework. Lyapunov theory is utilized to demonstrate that all signals in the closed-loop system are uniformly ultimately bounded. Finally, the effectiveness and practicality of the control strategy are verified by numerical simulations and an application case of an electromechanical system.

title: GFS-edge: Graph Fuzzy System for Edge Prediction_supp1-3649146.pdf
authors: Zhaohong deng
publish: N/A
abstract: Edge prediction (EP) is a long-standing and fundamental task in graph-structured data analysis, and has served as a key driver in the advancement of graph learning. Traditional EP methods can be broadly classified into three major categories: heuristic approaches, embedding-based methods, and graph neural network (GNN)-based techniques. While each category has achieved notable performance improvements, these methods often fall short in handling uncertainty and generally lack robust interpretability. These limitations highlight an urgent need for novel approaches that can effectively address uncertain EP tasks while offering strong interpretability and rich feature representations. To tackle these challenges, we propose a novel graph fuzzy system (GFS) for edge prediction, termed GFS-edge, and systematically introduces its core concepts, model architecture, and construction methodology. Specifically, we first define key concepts of GFS-edge, including rule bases, fuzzy sets, and edge consequent processing module (ECPM). We then present a general modeling framework for GFS-edge, detailing the formulation of rule antecedents and consequents. Subsequently, a learning framework is introduced, in which edge-based clustering is employed for antecedent generation, while a linear variational graph auto-encoder (LVGAE) is adopted as the ECPM to facilitate consequent learning. Extensive experiments are conducted on 12 benchmark datasets to evaluate the performance of GFS-edge. The results consistently demonstrate that GFS-edge outperforms existing methods from all three traditional EP categories, showcasing superior performance while effectively addressing uncertainty modeling and interpretability challenges.

title: Benchmarking Explainable Argumentation Dialogue via Freeman’s Theory
authors: Yang Sun, Geng Tu, Wenpeng Lu, Min Yang, Erik Cambria, Ruifeng Xu
publish: IEEE Intelligent Systems
abstract: Argumentative dialogue involves structured exchanges of claims and supporting evidence, yet progress in building effective dialogue systems is limited by the scarcity of high-quality datasets. To address this, we introduce CMV-AD, a baseline dataset derived from the ChangeMyView corpus, designed for modeling structured argumentative interactions. We further propose FTCoT, a Freeman’s Theory-based Chain-of-Thought framework that enhances interpretability and reasoning in dialogue generation. FTCoT represents each dialogue turn with a structured quadruple: Dialogue Summary, User Argument, Assistant Argument, and Response Reasoning. We construct FTCoT using large language models (LLMs), leveraging their capabilities in reasoning and data annotation. Extensive automatic and human evaluations demonstrate the effectiveness of FTCoT in improving both the interpretability and quality of generated responses.

title: FocusPatch AD: Few-Shot Multi-Class Anomaly Detection with Unified Keywords Patch Prompts
authors: Xicheng Ding, Xiaofan Li, Mingang Chen, Jingyu Gong, Yuan Xie
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Industrial few-shot anomaly detection (FSAD) requires identifying various abnormal states by leveraging as few normal samples as possible (abnormal samples are unavailable during training). However, current methods often require training a separate model for each category, leading to increased computation and storage overhead. Thus, designing a unified anomaly detection model that supports multiple categories remains a challenging task, as such a model must recognize anomalous patterns across diverse objects and domains. To tackle these challenges, this paper introduces FocusPatch AD, a unified anomaly detection framework based on vision-language models, achieving anomaly detection under few-shot multi-class settings. FocusPatch AD links anomaly state keywords to highly relevant discrete local regions within the image, guiding the model to focus on cross-category anomalies while filtering out background interference. This approach mitigates the false detection issues caused by global semantic alignment in vision-language models. We evaluate the proposed method on the MVTec, VisA, and Real-IAD datasets, comparing them against several prevailing anomaly detection methods. In both image-level and pixel-level anomaly detection tasks, FocusPatch AD achieves significant gains in classification and localization performance, demonstrating excellent generalization and adaptability.

title: SPTM: A Transformer-Mamba Decoder with Superpoint Pooling for Semantic Segmentation of Power Tower Point Clouds
authors: Li Wu, Renping Yu, Wanli Cai
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Semantic segmentation of three-dimensional (3D) power tower point clouds is a key technology for smart grid inspection and digital modeling of transmission corridors. However, slender structures such as power lines are sparse and discontinuous, and susceptible to occlusion in unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) light detection and ranging (LiDAR) point clouds, resulting in insufficient segmentation precision for existing methods. To address this issue, a novel 3D power tower semantic segmentation method, superpoint transmamba (SPTM), is proposed. Firstly, a sparse 3D U-Net is used as the backbone network, and a superpoint pooling layer is used to aggregate features in locally geometrically consistent regions. Then, a hybrid query decoder that fuses the Transformer and the Mamba state-space model is introduced in the decoding stage to balance local geometric details with the modeling of global long-range dependencies. Finally, a series of experiments are conducted on a dataset of power tower point clouds collected by UAVs to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method. Experiments demonstrate that SPTM outperforms existing mainstream methods (such as Point Transformer, Stratified Transformer, and 3DSwin Transformer) in metrics such as mean intersection over union (mIoU) and mean accuracy (mAcc), achieving significant improvements in power line classification. Ablation experiments further validate the complementarity and effectiveness of superpoint pooling and the Mamba module in identifying slender structures. This method provides an efficient and accurate solution for 3D point cloud semantic segmentation in complex power transmission scenarios.

authors: Libin Hu, Xiaofeng Wei, Lei Shu, Fang Wang, Hongxin Zhang, Duoli Li, Xuwen Liang, Xiaojing Li, Bo Li
publish: IEEE Electron Device Letters
abstract: This work introduces a novel post-fabrication electromagnetic pulse (EMP) injection technique for optimizing the on-resistance–breakdown voltage (R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ON</sub>-BV) trade-off in bulk lateral double-diffused MOSFETs. Experimental results demonstrate significantly higher BV modulation efficiency in devices with thick gate oxides compared to thin gate oxide counterparts with unchanged on-resistance (R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ON</sub>). This comparative analysis combined with AI-assisted TCAD simulations conclusively identifies the unique distribution of trapped charges within the gate oxide as the dominant mechanism responsible for BV shift. These findings demonstrate that the post-process EMP-induced BV enhancement without typical degradation in R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ON</sub> provides a new approach for overcoming the fundamental R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ON</sub>-BV trade-off in power semiconductors.

title: AGILE-6G: Agentic AI for Autonomous Management of 6G Network/Application Services
authors: Angelos Antonopoulos, Elli Kartsakli, Nikolaos Bartzoudis, Dimitrios Brodimas, Dejan Vukobratovic, Dimitris Tsolkas, Ferran Diego, George Roumelas, Lechosław Tomaszewski
publish: IEEE Network
abstract: As mobile networks evolve beyond 5G, the convergence of cloud, edge and network domains renders siloed orchestration unsustainable. Achieving the adaptability and autonomy required by 6G requires an intelligence layer capable of reasoning, coordination, and continuous learning across distributed systems. While Generative AI (GenAI) and Large Language Models (LLMs) have introduced cognitive automation, the next step is Agentic AI, where autonomous agents reason, negotiate and act collaboratively. This article introduces two key contributions: 1) a blueprint for Domain Agentic Systems (DASs), i.e., composite, scope-bounded subsystems that combine multiple agents, service engines and a communication bus to deliver specific orchestration functionalities, and 2) the AGILE-6G framework, a next-generation orchestration paradigm that embeds an agentic intelligence layer above traditional management systems. AGILE-6G organizes DASs across end-to- end (global) and specialized domains (e.g., Radio Access Network), enabling context-aware decision-making, self-healing and adaptive service management through agent collaboration. Two representative use cases illustrate how AGILE-6G achieves automatic reconfiguration of network and application services, highlighting its potential to realize scalable and trustworthy orchestration in 6G systems.

title: Hybrid Attention Lagrangian Variational Autoencoder With Latent Representation Disentanglement for Fault Diagnosis Under Time-Varying Operating Conditions
authors: Rourou Li, Tangbin Xia, Feng Luo, Yujun Zhou, Xinge Zhang, Guojin Si, Lifeng Xi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Reliability
abstract: Effective fault diagnosis for industrial robots is critical to ensure their operational availability and reliability in safety-critical applications. Proprioceptive signals from robot servo drive systems provide a nonintrusive and promising solution for practical in situ diagnosis. While their exhibited significant multisensor heterogeneity and nonstationarity caused by time-varying operating conditions challenge existing diagnostic methods in identifying fault-induced intrinsic signatures. Concurrently, inadequate prior knowledge integration limits data-driven approaches in physical consistency, leading to outputs that may not adhere to fundamental physical principles, such as the laws of motion derived from Lagrangian mechanics. Thereupon, a hybrid attention Lagrangian variational autoencoder with latent representation disentanglement is proposed for industrial robot diagnosis under time-varying conditions using multivariate proprioceptive signals. Specifically, a hybrid attention-based encoder is devised for composite modeling of interseries association patterns and intraseries temporal variations, encoding multimodal spatiotemporal complementary information into condition-independent latent spaces. A Lagrangian mechanics-embedded decoder with structured network topology ensures latent spaces with critical information reservation and nonstationary disturbance isolation by physics-constrained state reconstruction. Concurrently, the dual-regularized latent disentanglement strategy separates fault-specific latent space from fault-invariant contexts through the variational evidence lower bound-driven posterior alignment and the explicit supervision from adversarial and diagnostic classifiers. Hereinto, the Gaussian mixture prior is imposed on the fault-specific latent space to promote interclass separability and intraclass compactness. The developed physics-embedded framework effectively decouples intrinsic fault patterns from nonstationary inference. Comprehensive case studies using both simulated and real-world industrial robot datasets are conducted to demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method.

title: Evaluating Large Language Models for Line-Level Vulnerability Localization
authors: Jian Zhang, Chong Wang, Anran Li, Weisong Sun, Ceng Zhang, Wei Ma, Yang Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering
abstract:
Recently, Automated Vulnerability Localization (AVL) has attracted growing attention, aiming to facilitate diagnosis by pinpointing the specific lines of code responsible for vulnerabilities. Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown potential in various domains, yet their effectiveness in line-level vulnerability localization remains underexplored.

In this work, we present the first comprehensive empirical evaluation of LLMs for AVL. Our study examines 19 leading LLMs suitable for code analysis, including ChatGPT and multiple open-source models, spanning encoder-only, encoder-decoder, and decoder-only architectures, with model sizes from 60M to 70B parameters. We evaluate three paradigms—few-shot prompting, discriminative fine-tuning, and generative fine-tuning—with and without Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA), on both a BigVul-derived dataset for C/C++ and a smart contract vulnerability dataset.

Our results show that discriminative fine-tuning achieves substantial performance gains over existing learning-based AVL methods when sufficient training data is available. In low-data settings, prompting advanced LLMs such as ChatGPT proves more effective. We also identify challenges related to input length and unidirectional context during fine-tuning, and propose two remedial strategies: a sliding window approach and right-forward embedding, both of which yield significant improvements. Moreover, we provide the first assessment of LLM generalizability in AVL, showing that certain models can transfer effectively across Common Weakness Enumerations (CWEs) and projects. However, performance degrades notably for newly discovered vulnerabilities containing unfamiliar lexical or structural patterns, underscoring the need for continual adaptation. These findings offer practical guidance for deploying LLM-based AVL systems in realistic software security workflows.

title: Multimodal Smart Glove System Based on Flexible Optical Fibers and Inertia Sensor Hybrid
authors: Zihan Hao, Jing Xie, Yue Zhang, Qiang Wu, Juan Liu, Hong Yang, Yingying Hu, Bin Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: Hand motion capture devices are widely used in sign language translation, virtual reality (VR) motion reconstruction, and human–computer interaction. However, current devices often suffer from limited hand information collection due to the use of single sensor types, large sizes, and unreasonable layouts. To address these issues, we propose a smart glove based on the fusion of optical fibers and inertial sensors, which consists of nine polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) flexible optical fiber sensors and an inertial sensor. The flexible optical fiber sensors detect finger joint bending, while the inertial sensor captures spatial hand information. The system employs a multimodal fusion algorithm to enable both gesture recognition and human–computer interaction. Dynamic gestures of the 26 English letters and common English words consisting of two to five letters can be recognized using long short-term memory (LSTM) or bidirectional long short-term memory (BiLSTM) models combined with an attention mechanism. The gesture prediction accuracy for the 26 English letters and common English words reaches 99.76% and 97.66%, respectively. Additionally, the glove system wirelessly transmits data to a computer via the ESP32S3 chip’s Wi-Fi module, where UE4 software uses C++ programming to achieve VR motion restoration. By encoding the glove data in Python and transmitting it to a robotic hand, real-time control of the robotic hand can be achieved.

title: Stage Division of GNSS Spoofing Code Phase Traction and Loop Response Analysis
authors: Zongmin Liu, Chao Ma, Jiawen Zhou, Mei Hu, Guangming Wang, Chao Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) has been widely applied, but the impact of navigation spoofing has become increasingly severe, making it urgent to enrich and develop relevant defense measures. Starting from the influence of spoofing signals on the tracking loops of navigation terminals, analyzing their effect on loop states is an effective approach to fundamentally analyze the abnormal working states of receivers caused by spoofing signal intrusion. This paper constructs a model of the code phase pulling process of spoofing signals, divides the code phase pulling process into three stages according to the distortion characteristics of the Cross-Correlation Function (CCF), derives the state-space model of the code loop filter using forward Euler discretization, obtains the recursive relationship between phase discrimination error and local code phase adjustment, and analyzes the code phase pulling process of spoofing signals based on an open-source GNSS receiver. The results show that the transient responses in the CCF separation stage directly determine the success or failure of spoofing attacks.

title: TAYLORS: A Fast, Scalable Yet Lightweight Protocol for Resilient Synchronization of WSN
authors: Benoît Perroux, Jérôme Ermont, Katia Jaffrès-Runser
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: As of today, wireless sensor networks (WSNs) are regularly deployed to monitor physical phenomena. This is made possible by the collection of time-stamped data building on synchronized sensor clocks. Some applications benefit from a temporary deployment of the network. This is for instance the case for the instrumentation of an aircraft during flight tests using connected microphones and accelerometers. In this case, the clock synchronization protocol must converge fast and in a bounded time. In this paper, we propose TAYLORS, a distributed and thus robust synchronization protocol for WSN that offers a fast bounded convergence and that keeps a stable clock even in dynamic settings. TAYLORS combines both max-consensus at initialization and average-consensus over the long term. This work provides as well a novel mathematical model to derive a worst-case bound on convergence of low memory average-consensus protocols, that is leveraged to motivate the design of TAYLORS. Experimental results show that the proposed solution is simple, fast and suitable for very basic microcontrollers.

title: Wheat Seed Orientation Detection Method Research for Mirco-invasive Sampling by Improved Deep-learning Framework
authors: Haijun Luo, Weibin Guo, Lifu Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: This study addresses the problem of wheat seed pose detection prior to slicing and proposes an improved YOLO-WP (YOLOv8-WheatPose) model. Built upon the YOLOv8n framework, the method detects seed embryos and awns, calculates the embryo orientation vector from bounding box centers, and determines pose angles using the arctangent function. To enhance performance, we integrate the C2fFaster module for optimized cross-stage connections, employ an Efficient Multi-scale Attention (EMA) mechanism for improved feature representation, and redesign the neck network with a Bidirectional Feature Pyramid Network (BiFPN) for effective multi-scale fusion. Experimental results show that YOLOv8- WP achieves 81.8% AP in embryo and awn detection, reduces parameters by 23.33%, maintains a model complexity of 6.1 GFlops, and achieves an average angular error of less than 2°.

title: SmartAid: Adaptive AI-Driven System for Merit-Based Scholarship Forecasting
authors: SivaKumar Depuru, Bollavaram Rakesh Kumar Reddy, Bodanapu Rahim, Bellam Raghuram, Dodda Venkata Yogeswara Rao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Prediction in scholarship is an important component in selecting the student who is apt and also in equal allocation of funds to education. The conventional selection methods, which are highly reliant on humans’ assessments, are time consuming, subjective and have a high likelihood of biasness. This research introduces the Hybrid Deep Learning Framework (HDLF) that will help select scholarship beneficiaries more accurately and without any bias, thus overcoming the drawbacks of the manual and bias selection processes. It uses Natural Language Processing (NLP) to screen the contents of applications, Gradient Boosting to predict performance and attention-based neural networks and adaptive weighting of features to provide a dynamic adaptability to eligibility criteria. On a real-world test-set of 10,000 applications the model produced 92.8 percent accuracy, 91.6 percent precision, 90.9 percent recall, 91.2 percent F1-score and 93.5 percent ROC-AUC; outperforming both Logistic Regression (76.5 percent) and Random Forest (89.3 percent) by more than 15 percent in accuracy. Explainability of AI (XAI) prevents blackbox decision making by using feature attributions to explain decisions. The suggested solution is scalable, unbiased, and interpretable, being an efficient approach to allocating scholarship efficiently and having a chance to be implemented in a global arena.

title: Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis of Indonesian Football Team's Instagram Comments using Naive Bayes
authors: Gregorius Dendy Setiadi, Eduardus Hardika Sandy Atmaja
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: The Indonesian national football team is one of the most followed sports entities in Indonesia, particularly on social media platforms like Instagram. During the third round of the 2026 World Cup Qualifiers, their official Instagram account received thousands of public comments, expressing diverse sentiments. This study aims to analyze these Instagram comments using the Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis (ABSA) approach. A total of 6.600 comments were collected via web scraping from six match-related posts with 6.216 comments remaining after preprocessing. Aspect extraction was performed using Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA), yielding three main aspects: “Dukungan & Semangat Nasional,” “Performa Tim & Lawan,” and “Hasil & Situasi Pertandingan:” These aspects were subsequently validated by linguists. Sentiment labeling was conducted using the InSet lexicon. Comments were then vectorized using TF-IDF and classified with the Multinomial Naive Bayes algorithm, which was optimized using GridSearchCV and validated through Stratified K-Fold cross-validation. The classification results showed the highest accuracy for the “Performa Tim & Lawan” aspect (81.44%), followed by “Dukungan & Semangat Nasional” (80.70%), and “Hasil & Situasi Pertandingan” (79.37%), culminating in an average accuracy of 80.50%. These findings suggest that ABSA can provide detailed insights into public opinion regarding key performance areas of the national team.

title: Attention-Enhanced CNN for Motor-Impaired Handwritten Alphabet Recognition with Explainable AI
authors: Kayalvizhi K R, Fayaz Ahamed B, Harshan Kumar K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Motor impairment conditions like Parkinson's disease and essential tremor largely impact handwriting legibility, posing challenges to automated recognition systems. This paper presents an advanced CNN architecture with attention mechanisms tailored to adaptive handwritten alphabet recognition for motor impairment. A baseline CNN was developed achieving 81.3% accuracy, then integrated an advanced multi-head attention mechanism that incorporated channel and spatial attention blocks, Grad-CAM++ explainable AI was also utilized for visualizing model decision-making processes. Extensive ablation studies confirmed that the attention-enhanced model achieved 97.3% accuracy, which was a 16.0% improvement over the baseline. The explainable AI component efficiently pinpointed the most important regions affecting alphabet predictions. The proposed approach has great potential for building accessible handwriting recognition systems for individuals with motor impairments, with explainable AI ensuring transparency essential for assistive applications.

title: OXGCGN: Optimized Explainable Deep Learning for Lung Cancer Detection using CT Images
authors: Bhavesh B Digey, Shirish Shankar Kulkarni, Uttam Popat Waghmode
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: In recent times, the major cause of the increased number of health issues and mortality is due to the unnoticed abnormal cell growth, causing cancer. Among these, lung cancer is regarded as the main reason behind increased death across the globe. Significantly, lung cancer is identified using the various screening techniques, of which Computed Tomography (CT) Scan images are widely considered due to their increased resolution. Nevertheless, existing detection techniques are prone to increased complexity in handling intricate data patterns. Therefore, this research seeks to design an enhanced approach for accurately identifying lung cancer through the analysis of CT scans. To achieve enhanced detection, an Optimized Explainable Gradient Convolution Gated Network (OXGCGN) model is designed, which enables better detection. Furthermore, deployment of Explainable Gradient Boosting Machine (XGBM) enables rectifying the errors, reducing the computational complexity, and loss value. XGBM is the integration of the gradient boosting technique, comprising various decision trees, offering simple, understandable outcomes, and facilitating effective lung cancer detection. The OXGCGN model performance is implemented using the Lung-PET-CT-Dx Dataset and achieves 97.23% of accuracy, 96.65% of F1-Score, 95.11%of precision, and 98.24% of recall, with a training percentage 80%, respectively, therefore providing better detection of lung cancer, enabling proper treatment facilities.

title: Enhancing Forensic Face Construction with Realtime Recognition using Deep Learning and OpenCV
authors: Asfiya Firdouse, Monisha Murthy, Sowmya B K, R C Ravindranath, Nayana Rani S, G K Dhanush
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Forensic sketching is crucial in criminal investigations, helping law enforcement identify suspects based on witness descriptions. However, traditional methods rely on skilled artists and are often subjective, making it difficult to integrate with automated facial recognition systems. The proposed methodology introduces a forensic tool with a drag-and-drop interface for composite sketch creation, reducing dependence on expert sketch artists while improving accessibility. Many automated forensic sketch retrieval techniques struggle with large-scale subject databases. Our system addresses this challenge by leveraging deep learning, specifically Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), to enhance image detection and classification. Unlike traditional approaches that focus only on sketch-based retrieval, our system incorporates real-time facial recognition from CCTV streams. This allows law enforcement agencies to crossreference live video feeds with suspect databases for efficient criminal identification. Real-time processing enables rapid suspect detection and tracking, significantly improving investigation speed and accuracy. By integrating deep learning models with forensic sketch matching, our system enhances modern biometric systems, making them more practical for large-scale deployments. This approach bridges the gap between forensic sketching and real-time recognition, making it a valuable tool for crime prevention and law enforcement.

title: Designing for Simplicity: Lessons from a Minimalist EV Charging App
authors: Toni Garcês, João Pedro Taveira, Larissa Montefusco, Cindy P. Guzman, Lucas Pereira, Hugo Morais
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This article reflects on the development of a minimalist electric vehicle (EV) charging mobile application created as part of the EV4EU research project. Initially designed with a single core feature, the app aimed to demonstrate a focused experience that emphasized simplicity. However, as development progressed and feedback was gathered from early users, it became clear that minimal functionality was not enough to meet real-world expectations. The application underwent several iterations, eventually incorporating critical features such as real-time charging status updates, user account management, vehicle registration, and smart charging. These additions significantly improved the app’s usability without overwhelming its interface. Feedback from users revealed the need for personalization, intuitive flows, and transparency in energy usage. The development process highlighted the value of early user engagement and the importance of balancing minimalism with essential user needs. By reflecting on this journey, we propose a system that aligns with the needs of modern EV drivers and contributes to smarter energy usage and a more sustainable future.

title: Data Clustering for Tax Incentives Determination: A Hybrid Manhattan Frequency K-Means and Particle Swarm Optimization Approach
authors: Irfanur Ilham Febriansyah, Bilqis Amaliah, Ahmad Saikhu
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ICoAIT)
abstract: Motor Vehicle Tax (PKB) plays a crucial role in financing regional development in Indonesia. However, the application of data science to support the determination of tax rates and related incentives remains limited. This study implements a hybrid approach that combines Manhattan Frequency K-Means (MFKM) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to automatically determine the optimal number of clusters for large-scale, categorical PKB datasets. The novelty lies in applying this combination—one of the earliest implementations of MFKM-PSO in large-scale tax data analysis in Indonesia—to a complex fiscal challenge, where existing methods struggle with both accuracy and efficiency. The resulting clusters are then interpreted to inform the design of more targeted and data-driven PKB incentive policies. Using 208,157 PKB records, the proposed method successfully identified three optimal clusters, supported by a Davies-Bouldin Index (DBI) of 0.9072 and a Silhouette Score of 0.5312, within 38.53 seconds of computation time. Cluster interpretation and simulation of a rule-based incentive policy revealed potential for a 2.87% reduction in PKB loss, indicating practical relevance for fiscal decision-making.

title: Optimization of Space-Time Coding Metasurface by a Quantum Annealing-Inspired Algorithm
authors: Shuai S. A. Yuan, Yutong Jiang, Wei E. I. Sha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Space-time coding metasurfaces introduce a new degree of freedom in the temporal domain, enabling advanced control of electromagnetic (EM) waves, particularly at different harmonic frequencies. However, optimizing these metasurfaces becomes computationally expensive due to the large spatial and time dimensions. To address this, we propose a quantum annealing-inspired optimization framework. We map the scattering behavior of the metasurfaces to a binary spin model, encoding each meta-atom's phase as spins, and optimize using a simulated bifurcation (SB) algorithm. Our method demonstrates a significant improvement in optimization efficiency, reducing computational time by nearly 1000 times compared to genetic algorithms (GA).

title: Optimal Inertia Procurement in Future Synthetic-Inertia-Dominated Power Systems: A Public Goods Game Approach
authors: Mahyar Tofighi-Milani, Sajjad Fattaheian-Dehkordi, Matti Lehtonen
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The growing integration of renewable energy sources is transforming power systems, leading to a significant decline in system inertia. To mitigate the resulting stability challenges, synthetic inertia—enabled through advanced control systems and fast responsive resources—has emerged as a promising solution. However, determining and procuring the optimal amount of synthetic inertia remains a critical challenge. This paper addresses the problem of synthetic inertia procurement by introducing a Public Good Game (PGG)-based optimization framework for power system utilities. The proposed approach determines the optimal inertia level by maximizing societal benefits while considering individual agent payoffs. Key frequency stability metrics—Rate of Change of Frequency (RoCoF) and Nadir Point—are incorporated to evaluate the impact of inertia on system stability. Additionally, a mathematical formulation is developed to estimate the nadir point for different inertia levels within a typical power system. The study also examines the optimal cost of synthetic inertia and its allocation among system agents. A 500 MW power system is simulated to validate the proposed model's effectiveness in cost-efficient inertia procurement.

title: Quantifying the Effects of Long-lasting Unavailabilities due to Extreme Events on Power System Adequacy
authors: Emanuele Ciapessoni, Diego Cirio, Andrea Pitto
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Extreme weather events may cause serious damage to power system infrastructure, determining long-lasting unavailabilities of both transmission and generation assets. This may jeopardize the ability to satisfy customers’ energy requirements thus affecting system adequacy. The paper proposes a methodology to extend conventional adequacy analyses, accounting for long-lasting unavailabilities due to extreme events. To this aim, models and methodologies developed within the scope of resilience analyses are exploited, in particular allowing an efficient enumeration of relevant N-k unavailabilities. The extreme event analysis is then integrated by a conventional Monte Carlo Simulation (MCS) method to consider independent unavailabilities under ordinary operation. The application to a test system shows the capability of the proposed method to compute adequacy metrics (EENS and LOLE) due to long-lasting N-k unavailabilities caused by extreme events and compare them to ordinary unavailabilities.

title: Towards Transferable Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies with high Post-Deployment Performance in Smart Grids
authors: Cristian Cubides, Camilo Amaya, Markus Duchon
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Reinforcement learning controllers trained in ideal smart-grid simulators fail to operate on real networks due to mismatches in underlying operational dynamics, e.g. battery efficiencies are often neglected or some charge sensors introduce random noise and biases. Our proposed two-layer transfer learning framework bridges this gap without requiring prior knowledge of the physical system (model-agnostic approach). We use an on-the-run trainable domain classifier, which reshapes the reward function to discourage actions that lead to unlikely situations in the target domain while training, and thus, steering learning towards optimal behaviors valid for the real domain. In parallel, a recurrent denoising autoencoder, trained with offline data extracted from scheduled operation, eliminates systematic and stochastic errors from the observation space before control decisions are made. The method was tested on a microgrid system, composed by a photovoltaic module, an electrical load and a battery, under three different efficiencies conditions and 10 random seeds. Our combined method achieved energy cost savings of up to 2.6% when the real efficiency is 80%, 17.5% for efficiency 65% and 10.2% for 50%, while maintaining safety voltage limits in the system. The method shows reliable simulation-to-reality transfer for energy networks proved by statistical significance tests. The overall transfer learning approach was designed to be extendable to grids with more nodes and different optimization objectives.

title: Thermal Wildlife Image Segmentation Using Hybrid Vision Transformers for Smart City Applications
authors: Derian Mowen, Miltiadis Alamaniotis
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: Wildlife-vehicle collisions cost North America over $ 8 billion annually and remain a key challenge for smart-city initiatives that target zero-fatality road networks. Long-wave-infrared (LWIR) cameras can detect animals day and night by sensing body heat, yet segmentation is difficult because distant wildlife occupy only a few low-contrast, noise-corrupted pixels. We introduce the Road-Thermal Deer dataset—160 expertly annotated frames expanded to 1600 im-age-mask pairs—and present the first systematic benchmark of hybrid CNN-Transformer encoders for roadside animal segmentation. A Vision Transformer (ViT-Base) branch is fused with five CNN backbones (MobileNetV2, DenseNet121, EfficientNet-B3, ResNet101, ResNeXt101) to study accuracy-efficiency trade-offs. The mid-capacity EfficientNet-B3 + ViT hybrid attains 41.2% IoU and 58.0% F1 while sustaining 21.3 fps at sub- 50 ms latency on an RTX 3080 and staying under 2GB peak VRAM—outperforming both the lightest hybrid (MobileNetV2 + ViT, 30.6 % IoU) and the heaviest (ResNeXt101 + ViT, 40.4% IoU). The dataset and code are publicly released, offering a reproducible baseline for integrating real-time wildlife perception into connected transportation infrastructure and enhancing roadway safety in future smart cities.

title: Efficient English Text-to-Speech Voice Cloning Using Limited Speaker Data
authors: Emaan Abid, Muhammad Kamran, Muhammad Waseem, Muhammad Usman Ghani Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE 19th International Conference on Open Source Systems and Technologies (ICOSST)
abstract: In the fields like virtual assistants, smart technology, and automotive systems, voice is becoming a primary means of communication. The demand for personalized and realistic sound synthesis is increasing. This requirement is fulfilled by voice cloning, which makes the duplication of a person’s voice using just a few seconds of sample audio. This study presents a voice cloning text to speech application created with the Coqui TTS framework, using HiFi GAN to produce high quality waveforms and Tacotron 2 to generate spectrograms. The system can produce realistic cloned voices that closely mimic the target speaker’s voice with little training data. The model is evaluated using the LJ Speech dataset, achieving a Mean Opinion Score (MOS) of 4.3 and a speaker similarity rate of 85%. It is implemented on Google Colab for efficient real time inference. A Gradio driven interface is developed for users to interact easily. This study illustrates an effective technique for voice cloning.

title: Federated Learning Architectures for Mental Health Data: A Systematic Review of Privacy-Preserving Approaches and Clinical Efficacy
authors: Poonam Hadke, Sonali Patil
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Mental-health information are sensitive by nature but need to be aggregated to train robust machine-learning models capable of detecting depression, anxiety, PTSD, and bipolar disorders at scale. Federated learning (FL) is a privacy-safeguarding paradigm in which the models are locally trained and shared only via gradients or distilled parameters; however, plain vanilla FL continues to leak patient data via model weights or memorisation. From 2022 to 2025, the space quickly coalesced around differential-privacy (DP)-enabled FL, secure-aggregation methods, and customized federated fine-tuning for balancing high privacy budgets (ϵ ≤ 1) with clinical effectiveness. We conducted a systematic review of 43 peer-reviewed papers that deployed FL for mental-health prediction or monitoring on human data. Across depression, PTSD, bipolar, and stress tasks under stress, depression, PTSD, and bipolar conditions, privacy-hardened FL attained a pooled AUC of 0.87 ± 0.03, or a mean reduction of only 1.2% (95% CI 0.9–1.6%) compared to centralised baselines below the 3% non-inferiority threshold accepted by regulatory bodies for model equivalence. Perhaps most encThisagingly, multimodal wearable-to-text pipelines and large-language-model-based therapy chatbots provided the biggest privacy utility improvements when paired with adaptive DP budgets and LoRA-style parameter-efficient fine-tuning. Deployment issues persist non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data heterogeneity perturbed 91% of studies, and communication bottlenecks were encountered in 72%. We advocate a roadmap that integrates OMOP-CDM harmonisation, fairness constraints, and open-sThisce benchmarking to speed clinical translation. This results suggest that, through stringent privacy calibration, federated mental-health analytics can satisfy both ethical–legal requirements and clinical performance benchmarks, laying the foundation for population-scale yet privacy-preserving digital psychiatry.

title: Research on Photovoltaic Power Prediction Method Based on Multi-Task Deep Learning
authors: Yutang Ye, Jianing Wang, Daoyuan Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of smart grids and renewable energy systems, accurate and generalizable photovoltaic (PV) power forecasting has become a critical topic in the field of computer-aided energy prediction. This paper proposes a novel deep learning framework named PatchTST-BiLSTM-MTL, which integrates local temporal slicing and multi-head attention (PatchTST), bidirectional temporal dependency modeling (BiLSTM), and cross-site feature sharing via multi-task learning (MTL). The proposed model effectively captures nonlinear, periodic, and multi-scale patterns in multi-station PV time series. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that the framework outperforms traditional regression models and mainstream deep neural architectures in RMSE, MAE, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> metrics. The proposed approach offers high robustness, accuracy, and scalability, providing a promising solution for data-driven forecasting in intelligent energy systems from a computer science perspective.

title: A Modular Predictive System for Modeling Financial Toxicity in Patients Receiving Complex Gastrointestinal Surgery
authors: Ruth Bahre, Alex Masterson, Gitonga Munene, Zachary D. Asher, Sahar Abedzadeh, Alvis Fong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: In oncology, financial toxicity (FT) is a term that describes the financial distress experienced by cancer patients as they undergo expensive clinical treatment. FT has been shown to have a negative effect on cancer patients’ well-being. The effects of FT can be especially pronounced when patients must undergo complex surgery as part of their treatment to promote survivability. Despite the prevalence of multiple forms of gastrointestinal (GI) cancer, few studies have been conducted to evaluate the impacts of complex GI surgery on FT. Building on recent advances in this important subject, we propose a system to mechanize and streamline the process of FT modeling and prediction in the context of complex GI Surgery. Our aim is to provide healthcare professionals with an easy-to-use and intuitive system to proactively help them develop a personalized GI cancer treatment plan that also mitigates the risks associated with FT for individual cancer patients. We take a modular approach to system design that also includes futureproofing by adopting a plug-in mechanism for the critical machine learning (ML) module. This means the system can readily benefit from, and be in sync with, future advances in ML techniques. This paper describes the technical design of such a system. It demonstrates versatility of the system by exploring application of two popular ML methods for predicting FT formulated alternatively as classification and regression problems. Experimental results show promise in advancing ML for FT modeling and prediction.

title: PrO-MSConvNet: Progression Optimized IoT-Based Precision Agriculture Using Morphable Schema Convolution Network
authors: Achsah Susan Mathew, L. Kannagi, R. Sandhiya, N. Arockia Rosy, M. Sakthivel, K. Malathi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Precision agriculture arrived as a new method of farming using IoT to enable data-driven and real-time decision-making. The intersection of sensor networks and analytics has enabled crop and environmental condition monitoring, resource optimization, and increased sustainability. Despite these advances, conventional models are not capable of handling large volumes of heterogenous agricultural data, leading to inefficient resource allocation and inconsistent crop yields. The need for adaptive and intelligent solutions has grown in response to these limitations. This research proposes PrO-MSConvNet: Progression Optimized IoT-Based Precision Agriculture Using Morphable Schema Convolution Network, a robust methodology that begins with real-time data collection from IoT-enabled sensors measuring soil moisture, temperature, humidity, and crop growth. These inputs are transmitted through Wi-Fi, Zigbee, or LoRaWAN, depending on the scale and connectivity needs of the farm. The data is processed using a Morphable Schema Convolution Network (MSConvNet), which employs deformable convolution and pooling layers, as well as specialized regularizers, to model complex agricultural patterns and make preliminary predictions. These outputs are further refined by the Progression Optimizer (PrO), which dynamically fine-tunes recommendations for irrigation, fertilization, and pesticide application through multi-agent evolutionary optimization. The proposed system achieves 99.5 % accuracy in predictive modeling, 99.8 % efficiency in resource allocation, 99.3 % yield estimation accuracy, 99.6 % disease identification accuracy, and 99.7 % recommendation precision. In conclusion, PrO-MSConvNet offers a significant advancement in IoT-based smart farming by enhancing productivity and sustainability through precise and adaptive resource management strategies.

title: Increasing Firm and Non-Firm Hosting Capacity in Power Grids Using Battery Energy Storage Systems
authors: Mahsa Azarnia, Math H. J. Bollen, Jin Zhong
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper investigates the potential of battery energy storage systems to increase the hosting capacity of power grids for integrating new production or consumption. A decision-making framework is proposed, using curtailment as a performance index to assess hosting capacity. The performance of the grid equipped with battery is analyzed for both firm hosting capacity, where no curtailment is allowed, and non-firm hosting capacity, where an acceptable level of curtailment is agreed upon. Simulation results show that the battery energy storage system contributes to higher firm hosting capacity and lower wind curtailment under non-firm HC conditions. Moreover, the analysis highlights the potential of battery energy storage systems to defer major infrastructure investment needs and to improve energy utilization through higher efficiency. This work offers valuable insights for planning in renewable-rich networks.

title: Relaxation Techniques for Optimisation of Irrigation Systems as Flexible Energy Storage
authors: Pau García-Motilla, Sergi Costa-Dilmé, Oriol Gomis-Bellmunt, Eduardo Prieto-Araujo
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Flexible energy storage systems are indispensable for the integration of renewable energy sources in modern power systems. We propose large irrigation systems as an innovative solution to provide energy storage services, while maintaining their irrigation role. This work focuses on the optimisation of these systems. To upgrade the system to provide these services, we formulated a sizing and scheduling optimisation as a MINLP problem. However, non-linearities and binary variables inherent in hydraulics systems negatively affect the convergence and execution time. We present and test relaxation techniques for the pumped storage hydropower optimisation problem and compare different solving algorithms in real case scenarios. Relaxations improve the convergence of the solution, reduce execution times up to one order of magnitude and have close to no effect on the objective value. The ability to find a solution still depends on the initialisation values, so further development is required.

title: Hybrid State Estimation for Networks with FACTS via Bayesian Inference
authors: Vitor H. P. de Melo, Gustavo M. Hebling, Julio A. D. Massignan, Joao B. A. London
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Flexible AC Transmission Systems (FACTS) devices are valuable assets for improving a power system’s performance, providing rapid control of network variables. However, their effective deployment requires Power System Operators (PSOs) to monitor how these devices interact with the rest of the network, which is the Power System State Estimation (PSSE) goal. While existing studies embed FACTS in state estimators (SEs), few proposals address this issue under mixed measurement environments. Therefore, this paper uses Bayesian Inference to propose an SE formulation capable of tackling the temporal uncertainties that arise when combining traditional SCADA measurements with high sampling-rate Phasor Measurement Units (PMUs) measurements. The proposed approach can leverage sparse PMU information to improve estimation accuracy and access fast events driven by FACTS. Results on a modified version of the IEEE 14 bus with FACTS demonstrate superior performance compared to traditional hybrid approaches.

title: A Self-Directed Framework for Optimizing Career Pathways and Forecasting Competencies using Neuro-Linguistic and Behavioural Analytics
authors: Edwin Joel J, Kalyana Kumar P, Yadhuveer Vinayak M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Traditional models of education and work are changing at such a pace it is impractical to fix an explanation of a student, let alone a job seeker. This paper puts forward a new model of Career and Learning Advice within an Artificial Intelligence (AI) framework, based on Behavioural Analytics and Neuro-linguistic programming to offer flexible and continually changing career and learning advice. The model will make use of transformer-based models, including BERT to establish key skills and goals of users from their resumes and other natural language inputs, experimental behaviour clustering of behavioural data to create psychometrical profiles of the users, modified A* search to refine the user intended learning path, and XGBoost, or Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) to predict when an individual is ready to be acknowledged for a competence persistently. The model will provide a range of development opportunities for students, professionals, and institutions; offering users ample information and tools to develop a career and learning pathway in real-time.

title: YOTO: End-to-End Multi-Object Tracking from a UAV Perspective
authors: Xiaojun Guo, Hanxiang Qian, Xiaoyong Sun, Shaojing Su, Runze Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Multi-Object Tracking is an important part of Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) platform earth observation missions and is widely used in traffic monitoring, animal protection, and security. Multi-object tracking from a UAV perspective faces many challenges. For instance, objects are often small and exhibit large scale variations, which complicates detection and the extraction of Re-ID features. Another challenge is that the computing power of UAV is usually limited at the edge, and an efficient and real-time tracking algorithm is urgently needed. Based on the above motivation, this paper proposes an end-to-end tracking algorithm: You Only Track Once (YOTO). Compared with the widely used tracking by detection algorithm, our algorithm directly adds a Re-ID branch to the YOLOv11 framework, which effectively uses the features extracted by the backbone network and saves the consumption of computing resources. In addition, we also propose a multi-scale target enhancement module. By introducing deep convolution in the neck of the detection network, we can extract clues of different scale features, so as to improve the detection ability of small targets from the perspective of aviation. According to experiments on two widely used UAV multi-object tracking datasets, VisDrone and UAVDT, our method surpasses many classical algorithms, achieving a MOTA of 44.5% and 51.2%, respectively.

title: Deep Learning Based Multi-Object Waste Detection and Tracking in Dynamic Scenes
authors: Abdul Ahad, Manoranjan Dash, A Mallikarjuna Reddy, P S Abhishek, O Prakyath Rao, B Leorah
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: With increasing awareness about the need for sustainable waste management, automatic waste detection and tracking systems are becoming a crucial part of waste sorting and recycling processes. In this work, we present an object detection and tracking based waste identification system that extends previous work on waste classification with the ability to localize, detect, and track multiple waste objects in real-time. We also gain an insight as to various issues that such systems may face in the real world upon deployment. Unlike classification models that predict only a single label per image, our approach leverages state-of-the-art object detection architectures to identify waste items in both images and video streams, ensuring more effective waste monitoring and management. We evaluated different state-of-the-art object detection models for waste detection on our dataset. The dataset was manually annotated using various labelling tools and converted to appropriate formats depending upon the model. We eventually selected YOLO v12m for deployment after evaluating on a wide range of metrics including real-time inference speed and detection accuracy. To improve the performance of video-based waste detection, we added object tracking algorithms so that the system can keep track of the object identities across frames. This not only reduces the redundant detections but also improves the efficiency and helps to monitor the waste movement over time.

title: DC Side Voltage Disturbances During a DC Line Fault Recovery Sequence of a VSC-HVDC Link
authors: Martin Pettersson, Math Bollen
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Interoperability between equipment from different HVDC vendors is an important subject for a multi-terminal HVDC grid. During dynamic events, such as a DC line fault recovery sequence, temporarily increased disturbance levels are unavoidable. Field measurements from such an event are analyzed in both the time, frequency and time-frequency domain. A model is developed to compare the frequency domain findings in the measurements. Theoretical arguments on influences of the DC side voltage disturbances are presented. Lastly, possible impacts related to DC side voltage disturbances in a multi-terminal HVDC grid are elaborated upon.

title: Fidelity Analysis of Reverse Amplifiers Under High-Frequency Condition
authors: Zhenyu Wang, Peng Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: This article analyzes the fidelity of the inverting operational amplifier under high-frequency conditions, primarily evaluating it from three aspects: gain characteristics, phase shift, and total harmonic distortion (THD). Simulink was used to build models of ideal and non-ideal inverting operational amplifiers, with simulations conducted at frequencies of 1 kHz, 1 MHz, and 100 MHz. By introducing parasitic capacitance and inductance of resistors, the effects of gain shift, signal transmission delay, and harmonic distortion were calculated and verified. The results indicate that at low (1 kHz) and medium (1 MHz) frequencies, the gain error of the inverting operational amplifier is relatively small, and the frequency response remains stable. However, at high frequency (100 MHz), parasitic effects lead to a gain reduction of about 0.8 %, a phase shift of 7°, and an increase in harmonic distortion to 3.06%. The study shows that the inverting operational amplifier can still maintain high fidelity within 100 MHz. However, at higher frequencies, the impact of parasitic parameters must be considered to optimize circuit design and enhance operational amplifier performance.

title: Dynamic Energy-Aware Deep Learning Framework using Adaptive Neural Architectures for Sustainable AI
authors: Ismath Jahan, Mahveen Sultana, Afiya Naaz, Mohammad Pasha, Mohd Umar Farooq, Nazia Tabassum
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: As deep learning models push performance boundaries, their high energy consumption poses a critical challenge to sustainable AI deployment, especially in resourceconstrained environments. This paper presents a Dynamic Energy-Aware Deep Learning Framework (DyEADLF). The framework adapts the network according to the power consumption during training and inference by fusing adaptive neural network topologies with real-time energy tracking. It employs Neural Architecture Search (NAS) to adjust the network structure based on available energy and monitors energy use using tools like NVIDIA NVML and Intel RAPL. Ensuring the model achieves the best balance between accuracy and energy efficiency. Testing the framework using well-known benchmarks like CIFAR-10 and ImageNet-lite, showing that it maintains high accuracy while using less energy. The system is also evaluated in cloud, edge, mobile environments, making it suitable for real-world applications where energy resources are limited.

title: Vehicle Trajectory Forecasting Using Temporal Fusion Transformers and Feature Selection
authors: Igor Fontes, Fabiane S. Queiroz, Andre L. L. Aquino
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: Accurate trajectory prediction is a fundamental component for the development of intelligent transportation systems and autonomous vehicles. In this work, we propose a novel trajectory prediction approach based on the Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT) architecture, designed initially for multi-horizon time series forecasting. Our model integrates spatio-temporal patterns, vehicle dynamics, and static contextual information to anticipate future positions with high precision. We adapted the TFT to handle multimodal sequential data, leveraging temporal encodings and attention mechanisms to capture complex interactions and nonlinear trends in vehicle movement. From the results obtained on the I-80 dataset, comparing state-of-the-art models like TrajectoFormer, we observed that the proposed model achieved improvements of up to 5.51% in RMSE and up to 8.39% in ADE for medium and long-term prediction horizons. These results highlight the model’s ability to capture more complex motion patterns and provide more accurate predictions over extended time horizons.

title: An Experimental Study of Linear Attention in Multi-Agent Transformer
authors: Xuan Duy Ta, Vu Minh Le, Viet Cuong Ta
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: Transformers have shown great promise in MultiAgent Reinforcement Learning through architectures like the Multi-Agent Transformer (MAT), which leverages the selfattention mechanism to model complex inter-agent interactions. However, the quadratic complexity of Softmax attention hinders scalability in environments with large number of agents or long episodes. To reduce the complexity in standard MAT, we propose to integrate the Linear attention into the standard MAT instead of the Softmax attention. The Linear attention is able to reduce the quadratic complexity in large number of agents thanks to having linear complexity via a kernel based operator. Moreover, the proposed linear operator is expected to better adapt to the dynamics in multi-agent interactions than the Softmax implementation. Through extensive experiments on benchmark MARL environments including MPE, MA-MuJoCo, and SMACLite, we show that the Linear attention architecture achieves competitive performance to its Softmax counterpart. Our findings suggest that Linear attention is a viable drop-in alternative for efficient sequence modeling in MARL, laying the groundwork for future progress in lightweight MARL architectures.

title: Innovative Fabrication Techniques for Transmitarray and Printed Lens Antennas
authors: Yahya Rahmat-Samii
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: In Advances in antenna performance have spurred innovation in fabrication techniques, enabling complex electromagnetic structures such as lens and transmitarray antennas. Lens antennas, based on geometrical optics (GO), use shaped dielectrics to refract EM waves and achieve wide bandwidth and high directivity. However, their thickness increases with aperture size, often reaching several wavelengths. Transmitarray antennas use sub-wavelength unit cells to introduce phase shifts for wavefront control, maintaining a thin profile independent of aperture size. While their bandwidth is narrower due to resonant elements, transmitarrays offer advantages in compactness and integration. This invited paper reviews key developments in fabrication—from mechanical and PCB processes to 3D printing and multi-material additive manufacturing. Case studies highlight the impact of these advances on antenna design and applications across various frequency ranges.

title: A Method for Improving the Edge Magnetic Field of Eddy Current Septum Magnets
authors: Wenlei Fu, Bing Zhu, Xulong Wang, Xihao Liu, Jie Sun, Jun Yang, Kuanjun Fan
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: The Super Tau-Charm Facility (STCF), a high-luminosity electron-positron collider under preliminary research in China, demands high injection efficiency for its injection system. As a key component of the STCF collider ring injection system, the eddy current septum magnet’s edge magnetic field uniformity is critical to improving injection efficiency. This paper systematically investigates the rectangular shimming method in traditional pole face shimming and proposes an innovative eddy current enhanced septum plate structure. Simulation results show that it reduces edge magnetic field non-uniformity to less than ±0.1%. The structure is engineering-feasible, offering a new approach for magnetic field optimization of such septum magnets in STCF’s injection system.

title: Probabilistic Time Slot Leasing in TDMA-Based IoT Networks for Enhanced Channel Utilization
authors: Hicham Lakhlef, Mohamed Ali Zormati, Khaled Abid, Toufik Ahmed
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: In large-scale resource-constrained wireless networks, such as those prevalent in the Internet of Things (IoT), efficient communication scheduling remains a critical challenge. Among the various approaches, Time Division Multiple Access (TDMA) protocols have been widely adopted for their structured and collision-free communication capabilities. Nevertheless, despite extensive research in this area, current solutions often exhibit suboptimal performance, particularly in dynamic environments where node activity levels fluctuate over time.This paper introduces a novel fully distributed TDMA-based scheduling protocol that intelligently maximizes the utilization of communication resources. The proposed approach adaptively reallocates underutilized time slots, originally assigned to temporarily inactive nodes, to those experiencing higher communication demands. This dynamic reallocation not only improves channel utilization but also reduces idle periods, thereby enhancing overall network efficiency. To further enhance performance, we incorporate a lightweight probabilistic mechanism that governs the temporal leasing of unused slots. This mechanism balances the trade-off between slot availability and transmission reliability, minimizing packet loss while preserving fairness and stability within the network.Simulations across a range of network scenarios demonstrate that our protocol significantly improves throughput, latency, and reliability in resource-constrained environments. These results highlight the protocol’s potential as a robust and scalable solution for adaptive and energy-efficient scheduling in next-generation IoT networks.

title: S-Band Tunable Impedance Matching Network with Varactor Diodes
authors: Zhou Han, Xiong Chen, Bin Han
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Advanced Interconnects (WAI)
abstract: In this paper, we designed an impedance matching network works at a frequency of 2.4 GHz, which is the representative frequency of the S-band, and based on the three-stub impedance matching network. A varactor diode is added at the end of each stub serving as the tunable components. When there are some changes in the surrounding environment and causes mismatch, we can re-match it by adjusting the reverse bias applied to the varactor diode. The simulation results show that for a load of 120+j50Ω, when the bias voltage of the three varactor diodes is set to 2V, S11 at 2.4GHz can be reduced to less than -15dB. When the bias voltage is set to 2.3, 1.3, and 1.8Vrespectively, S11 can be reduced to less than -40dB at 2.4GHz. When the real part changes between 40~200Ω, or the imaginary part changes between -150~150Ω, S11 at 2.4GHz can also be reduced to below -40dB by giving an appropriate voltage to achieve impedance matching.

title: Design of In-Situ Calibration Device for Shipborne Exhaust Emission Detector and Research on Emission Prediction Algorithm
authors: Yiyang Jiang, Cunbin Zhao, Jianwen Shao, Mengchun Qiu, Zhenzhou Ye, Lei Luo, Qiao Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: As the core equipment for ship emission supervision, shipborne exhaust emission detectors face difficulties in traceability and calibration during offshore navigation of ships. This article designs an in-situ calibration device for shipborne exhaust emission detectors, which realizes in-situ online data communication and metrological calibration of shipborne exhaust emission detectors. At the same time, a data self migration method for predicting emissions from different types of ships is proposed to predict the emissions of ships at the next moment. The experimental results of ship emission prediction show that the proposed method has better prediction effect than the traditional algorithm, and the in-situ calibration device works stably, which can meet the requirements of the traceability of ship borne exhaust emission detector.

title: AI Agents in Power System Operation: Application Results and Future Potentials
authors: Kevin Schäfer, André Kummerow, Sandipan Paul, Muhammad Bilal, Dennis Rösch
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The increasing complexity of distribution grid management demands innovative solutions for system operators. This paper presents a novel approach for a distribution grid operator assistants using Large Language Models. We implement an LLM agent that autonomously analyzes grid states, identifies problems, and implements corrective measures to maintain grid stability. The agent leverages the ReAct (Reasoning and Acting) framework to combine reasoning capabilities with power system analysis tools to support distribution grid management. First experiments using simulation models demonstrates the agent's ability to consistently resolve line loading issues through grid topology reconfigurations or transformer tap adjustments. The results show that the agent successfully addresses thermal constraints, voltage rise, and reactive power challenges across multiple operational scenarios with high consistency in decision-making. The approach offers a promising solution to the increasing complexity of distribution grid management in the context of renewable energy integration and sector electrification while maintaining transparency in the decision-making process.

title: Power Estimation Framework for Power Consumption Analysis of SoC with Multiple Operating Modes and Supply Domains
authors: Siddharth Katare
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: Accurate power estimation in System-on-Chip (SoC) designs is a persistent challenge due to increasing architectural complexity, multiple power domains, and dynamic operating conditions. Traditional spreadsheet-based methods are often inadequate for capturing the nuanced behavior of hierarchical systems, especially when components operate under varying voltage, temperature, and process scenarios. As SoCs scale in size and functionality, the need for a flexible, scalable, and precise power modeling framework becomes critical. Designers require tools that can simulate real-world operating modes, support iterative development, and provide actionable insights into power distribution across the chip. This paper introduces a Python-based framework that addresses these challenges by integrating a graphical user interface (GUI) with backend computational logic for hierarchical power estimation. The framework employs a master-instance methodology. Higher-level master cells instantiate lower-level cells, forming a scalable hierarchy that accurately models power behavior across multiple levels of abstraction. Each instantiated cell retains its own power mode configuration, enabling accurate power estimate under varying conditions. Results are visualized in a hierarchical tree format, offering clear insights into power distribution across domains and components. This structure supports drill-down analysis, allowing designers to identify power-intensive modules and make informed decisions about redesigns or optimizations.

title: A Unified Deep Learning Approach for Multi-Class Classification of Poultry Fecal Images
authors: Tooba Pervaiz, Ayesha Azam, Muhammad Usman Ghani Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE 19th International Conference on Open Source Systems and Technologies (ICOSST)
abstract: Livestock farming is the backbone of any country’s economy. However, some outbreaks of poultry diseases have occurred relatively recently and present breeders and farmers with great challenges. The detection of poultry diseases is done by physical inspection of posture, feathers, cockscombs, feces, and audible sounds. This is time-consuming, labor-intensive, and requires daily routine examination. We proposed a deep learning method to identify and classify poultry diseases based on poultry fecal images using an open-source dataset of four categories. Following the data balance, the model uses the ResNet-50 architecture for multi-class classification, and has achieved 97.3% accuracy with 97% precision, 97% recall, and $97.25 \%$ F1-Score. Further, the YOLOv9 model was employed for detection and localization, achieving an average precision of $72 \%$ during testing. These results highlight the potential of deploying AI-powered diagnostic tools for real-time poultry disease monitoring, enabling early intervention and improved farm management.

title: Machine Learning-Based Real-Time Power Quality Disturbance Classification using Kalman Filter Segmentation and Deep Learning
authors: Markus Stroot, Rui Wang, Amirali Mahjoob, Andreas Ulbig
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The growing complexity of electrical grids necessitates robust methods for monitoring power quality (PQ) disturbances in real-time. This work presents a complete framework for PQ classification that integrates signal processing, intelligent segmentation, and machine learning models. Central to this framework is the application of a Kalman Filter (KF), which serves as an adaptive event detection and signal segmentation tool, enabling the isolation of transient and non-stationary events from continuous voltage waveforms. Four feature extraction techniques—FFT, STFT, WT, and ST—are combined with Support Vector Machine (SVM) classifiers and benchmarked against a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) operating on Hilbert-transformed signal envelopes. Results demonstrate that the CNN, combined with Kalman-filter-based segmentation, outperforms traditional methods both in accuracy and in computational efficiency for real-time deployment. This highlights the practical viability of integrating adaptive filtering with AI for future smart grid monitoring systems.

title: Impact of Device Geometry in Phasar Array using Triangular Region for Channel Selection Control in WDM (Wavelength Division Multiplexing) Networks
authors: Sheela D, Bhavani N.P.G
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: This work investigates the impact of geometric modifications and refractive index tuning on the performance of Wavelength Division Multiplexing (WDM) phasar arrays, particularly focusing on the SA, SAS and ASAS-90° device geometries. A triangular region is introduced within the phasar array to enable wavelength-selective switching through controlled refractive index variation. Simulation results show that for different angular parameters, light coupling behavior varies significantly. The appropriate change in wavelength redirects light to the required output channel. In SAS structure, light enters the appropriate output channel similarly to SA (Straight–Arc), but with reduced electric field intensity. This reduction is attributed to the more gradual transition in SAS geometry, which allows the electric field lines to reorganize more uniformly after the arc, minimizing local maxima and suppressing field peaking. However, the ASAS-90° structure, while offering field intensity comparable to SA, exhibits sporadic distribution and consistent deflection to the left channel due to asymmetrical bending and structural discontinuities. Precise tuning of the length increment (ΔL) between the phasar array waveguides enables optimal phase matching, compensates for asymmetries, and enhances channel-selective performance.

title: Wavelet-Based Compressive Reconstruction for Real-Time IGBT Switching Time Monitoring
authors: Weiye Wang, Xiaotian Zhang, Menglong Wu, Jingwei Zhang, Zechao Liu, Chao Gong
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: Insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBTs) are critical in high-power systems, where reliable monitoring of switching transients is essential for condition assessment. Conventional approaches require high sample-level acquisition, leading to high cost and data burdens. This paper proposes a wavelet-optimized orthogonal matching pursuit (WO-OMP) framework for compressive reconstruction of IGBT switching transients.
