By leveraging wavelet-domain sparsity and adaptive reconstruction, the method reduces sampling rates while maintaining fidelity. Experiments on a double-pulse test platform show that WO-OMP achieves nanosecond-level accuracy in turn-off time toff, with relative errors below 1% under compression ratios up to 100. Performance metrics including RMSE, PRD, and PSNR further verify that waveform fidelity and timing precision are preserved under sub-Nyquist sampling. The results demonstrate the feasibility of cost-effective and real-time IGBT monitoring.

title: SAR Deceptive Jamming Identification via Stft-Residual Diffusion Models
authors: Xu Zhao, Jiang Qian, Haitao Lyu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Deceptive jamming poses a significant threat to synthetic aperture radar (SAR) systems by introducing time delays and phase modulations to create false scenes. As deceptive jamming techniques become increasingly sophisticated, effective methods for identification are essential. This paper presents a novel approach for deceptive jamming identification in single-channel SAR using a short-time Fourier transform residual diffusion model (STFT-RDM). We first develop a frequency-shifted forwarding deceptive jamming signal model and analyze the distinctions between real SAR echo signals and deceptive jamming signals in the time-frequency domain. The proposed STFT-RDM algorithm applies a short-time Fourier transform to the range-compressed signal, processes the real and imaginary components through a diffusion network with residual learning to extract jamming features, and performs an inverse transform to obtain the results of deceptive jamming identification. Experimental validation using simulated data from a drone-mounted single-channel SAR demonstrates that STFT-RDM effectively identifies deceptive jamming signals from real echoes, significantly enhancing the ability of SAR systems to recognize deceptive jamming.

title: Benchmarking Deep Learning Architectures for Static Chess Position Classification
authors: Muhammad Zainal Muttaqin, Fatma Indriani, Muliadi, Andi Farmadi, Triando H. Saragih
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Static chess position classification enables fast evaluation in analysis pipelines, tutoring systems, and other lowlatency applications that cannot rely on deep search. We present a comparative study of three deep learning approaches for static position classification, using a uniform and compact <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 8 \times 18$</tex> board encoding derived from Forsyth-Edwards Notation (FEN) data. The dataset comprises <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1,530,000$</tex> chess positions with balanced distribution: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 1 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> White Advantage, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 1 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> Balanced, and 510,000 Black Advantage positions, sourced from a comprehensive Kaggle chess evaluations dataset containing Stockfish evaluations at depth 22. The task assigns each position to one of three strategic outcomes based on engine evaluations using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm \mathbf{1 5 0}$</tex> centipawn thresholds. Models are trained and tested with 900,000 training, 180,000 validation, and 450,000 test positions using random sampling with seed 42. Performance is measured using accuracy and macro-averaged precision, recall, and F1score, with detailed per-class and confusion matrix analysis. Among the evaluated models, a Custom ResCNN delivers the strongest results, outperforming an Adapted ResNet-12 and a Baseline CapsNet. The benchmark highlights trade-offs between model families under compact inputs and offers a reference point for future research on richer feature sets and architectural refinements.

title: Robust Control Strategy for Stable Flight of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles Under Wind Conditions based on Adaptive Algorithm
authors: Guo Kailiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: UAVs are used in many applications. But the stability of UAVs under windy conditions is a major issue of concern. This paper presents an effective control approach for wind disturbance compensation through an adaptive control algorithm for improving flight performance. The suggested approach is based on the real-time wind evaluation and the adaptive gain control for better stability and the flight paths control. Based on the aerodynamic modeling and machine learning approaches, the algorithm adapts the control parameters according to the changes in the environment to maintain stability and accuracy. The results of the various simulation studies indicate that this nonlinear control approach offers enhanced tracking of desired trajectories, reduced energy consumption, and better rejection of disturbances as compared to the conventional control techniques. In addition, a proof of concept implementation in a quadcopter UAV is utilized to establish the effectiveness of the proposed method through reallife experimentation under different wind conditions. It was found that there is a significant decrease in deviation errors and enhanced flight stability.

title: On Transferring, Merging, and Splitting Task-Oriented Network Digital Twins
authors: Zifan Zhang, Minghong Fang, Mingzhe Chen, Yuchen Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: The integration of digital twinning technologies is driving next-generation networks toward new capabilities, allowing operators to thoroughly understand network conditions, efficiently analyze valuable radio data, and innovate applications through user-friendly, immersive interfaces. Building on this foundation, network digital twins (NDTs) accurately depict the operational processes and attributes of network infrastructures, facilitating predictive management through real-time analysis and measurement. However, constructing precise NDTs poses challenges, such as integrating diverse data sources, mapping necessary attributes from physical networks, and maintaining scalability for various downstream tasks. Unlike previous works that focused on the creation and mapping of NDTs from scratch, we explore intra- and inter-operations among NDTs within a Unified Twin Transformation (UTT) framework, which uncovers a new computing paradigm for efficient transfer, merging, and splitting of NDTs to create task-oriented twins. By leveraging joint multi-modal and distributed mapping mechanisms, UTT optimizes resource utilization and reduces the cost of creating NDTs, while ensuring twin model consistency. A theoretical analysis of the distributed mapping problem is conducted to establish convergence bounds for this multi-modal gated aggregation process. Evaluations on real-world twin-assisted applications, such as trajectory reconstruction, human localization, and sensory data generation, demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of interoperability among NDTs for corresponding task development.

title: YOLOv8-Powered Helmet Detection for Intelligent Roadside Safety Monitoring
authors: Vinston Raja R, M.Balasubramani, Rajakumar M P, M. S. Malchijah Raj, Devi R, M. Robinson Joel
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: In Previous Papers Wearing safety helmets can effectively protect workers safety on construction sites. However, workers often take off their helmets because of weak security-consciousness and discomfort, then hidden dangers will be brought by this behavior. Workers without safety helmets will suffer more injuries in accidents such as falling human body and vertical falling matter. Hence, detecting safety helmet wearing is a vital step of construction sites safety management and a safety helmet detector with high speed and accuracy is urgently needed. However, traditional manual monitor is labor intensive and methods of installing sensors on safety helmets are difficult to popularize. Therefore, this paper proposes a deep learning-based method to detect safety helmet wearing at a satisfactory accuracy with high detection speed. Our method chooses YOLO v5 as the baseline, then the fourth detection scale is added to predict more bounding boxes for small objects and the attention mechanism is adopted in the backbone of the network to construct more informative features for following concatenation operations. In order to overcome the defects caused by insufficient data, targeted data augmentation and transfer learning are used.Helmet detection plays a critical role in ensuring road safety by effectively identifying whether a person is wearing a helmet or not. By analyzing images or video footage, the system can swiftly identify offenders who neglect to wear helmets while riding. This technology not only aids in enforcing safety measures but also contributes to reducing the number of accidents and injuries caused by inadequate head protection. Moreover, the integration of YOLOv8 in helmet detection systems enhances the overall effectiveness and reliability of enforcing helmet-wearing regulations on roadways, ultimately fostering a safer environment for all road users.

title: Energy Optimization and Techno-Economic Assessment of Renewable Energy Communities: An Italian Case Study
authors: Sarah Winkler, Manuel A. Pérez Estévez, Massimiliano Renzi, Marco Montali, Jacopo C. Alberizzi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The recent introduction of Energy Communities into European legislation is set to change the paradigm of energy production and consumption. Multiple users can now aggregate to form groups of so-called prosumers, a term that identifies entities which are both producers and consumers of energy. Prosumers share loads, renewable energy production, and storage resources within the energy community, thereby achieving environmental and economic benefits. One of the objectives of introducing energy communities is to stimulate a hybrid form of distributed generation systems based on renewable energy technologies. These energy systems share a connection to the national power grid, but at the same time, they are encouraged to produce and consume their energy locally; to alleviate the stress and potential stability problems that a high share of renewable energy can cause on the power grid. However, due to the complexity of these energy systems and the high number of variables involved, the creation of such communities must overcome several challenges to be effective and to generate benefits for their members. For example, the fluctuating nature of renewable energy sources, such as solar power, introduces a component of unpredictability that must be addressed with storage systems. Moreover, the possibility of injecting a portion of the self-produced energy into the grid may generate additional revenues by exploiting periods of high electricity prices. In this context, one of the most significant challenges is the management of the community's assets—such as controllable loads and battery storage systems—to ensure optimal exploitation of renewable energy sources and maximum economic gain. To this end, this work analyses the case study of a photovoltaic energy community located in Northern Italy, composed of eight prosumers, and proposes an optimization strategy for the allocation of controllable assets, such as loads and battery systems, with the objective of maximizing economic benefit. The results demonstrate the technical and economic feasibility of these renewable energy system solutions. The energy community has been modelled in a Python programming environment, and an optimization tool based on a Mixed-Integer Linear Programming solver has been developed.

title: Construction of a Prediction Model for Geriatric Rehabilitation Nursing by Fusion of Multimodal Data
authors: Jieyao Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data and Intelligent Medicine (BDIMed)
abstract: To improve the prediction accuracy of geriatric rehabilitation nursing indicators, this paper constructs a Multimodal Attention Fusion Network (MAFN). This model addresses the heterogeneity of multimodal data in geriatric rehabilitation by using a dynamic attention mechanism to adaptively assign modal weights. It also mitigates fusion bias through multi-scale feature extraction and distribution calibration. Experiments are based on data from 1,000 elderly patients at a tertiary hospital (covering physiological signals, imaging, clinical text, and behavioral data). The dataset is partitioned into training, validation, and test sets in a 7:1.5:1.5 ratio. Performance is compared with five comparison models. Results show that MAFN achieves an RMSE of 3.25±0.42, a MAE of 2.18±0.31, and an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.92 in predicting FIM score improvement, representing improvements of 15.3%, 12.6%, and 4.5 percentage points, respectively, compared to the Transformer fusion model. In predicting recovery days, the RMSE is 2.87±0.36, the R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> is 0.89, and the single-sample inference time is 42.6ms, achieving both accuracy and real-time performance. Ablation experiments validate the effectiveness of dynamic attention and multi-scale feature extraction, while modality loss experiments demonstrate the model's robustness. This study provides an efficient multimodal fusion solution for prognosis assessment in elderly rehabilitation.

title: Relaying Volcanic Plume Measurements in Real Time by Using a Balloon-Borne Multi-Gas and Particles Sensors System
authors: Stefano Corradini, Salvo Marcuccio, Riccardo Biondi, Francesco Ciancitto, Alessandro Filippeschi, Matteo Gemignani, Gaetano Giudice, Lorenzo Guerrieri, Linda Lambertucci, Irene Marsili, Luca Merucci, Camilo Naranjo, Simona Scollo, Dario Stelitano
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Volcanic emissions are composed of particles (ash, water droplets, sulphates) and gases (mainly <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}, \text{CO}_{2}, \text{SO}_{2}, \text{HCl}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{S}$</tex>). Their presence in the atmosphere can produce serious implications on environment, climate, life on Earth, human society and aviation [Delmelle et al., 2002; Robock 2000; Casadevall, 1994]. The detection and retrievals of volcanic emissions is generally carried out by using satellite and ground based remote sensing systems that have advantages and drawbacks. The satellite systems are characterised by high density, large spatial coverage and are irreplaceable for volcanic monitoring on a global scale, while ground-based systems, offer real-time, continuous, high spatial and temporal coverage.

title: Deep Learning-Driven Autonomous Generation of Descriptive Textual Annotations for Visual Data
authors: G. Sowmya, Nemala Jayasree, B. Mamatha, Anuradha Anumolu, Talari Meena, G. Aishwarya
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: In computer vision and natural language processing, autonomous picture captioning, the process of producing descriptive textual annotations from visual data, has drawn a lot of interest. This invention talks about a system that creates captions for images on its own. It uses deep learning bringing together CNNs and LSTMs. Traditionally, to generate image captions or descriptions of it, it requires manual labeling or limited rule-based approaches which may not concentrate on the entire actual descriptions of the images. The proposed model would reduce the complexity and ensure that it enhances the quality of descriptions generated, especially using ResNet50 and LSTM. CNNs are the primary component in the proposed model as they have the ability to capture and extract detailed and hierarchical features from images. When image is given as input, then CNN processes it by isolating patterns like edges, textures, and objects. Input image is then transformed into a feature, rich representation. The features generated are of high dimensional vector. These features are then fed into LSTM, which interprets the spatial and semantic meaning within these features. The CNNLSTM combination allows the model to identify objects and their relationships within images.

title: Investigation on Propagation Characteristics of Low-Frequency Radio Signal During the Geminid Meteor Shower
authors: Fan Zhao, Feng Zhu, Xin Wang, XiaoQian Ren, Ping Feng, Yu Hua
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: During the Geminid meteor shower in 2024, the Chinese BPC radio time signal will be received in the Northern China region using a calibrated LF receiver at a frequency of 68.5 kHz. During the peak activity period of the meteor shower predicted by the International Meteor Organization (IMO), by recording the signal field strength and phase values, it was found that the enhancement of the signal field strength increased by approximately 1 dBμV/m at noon during the day, and the field strength at night was up to 4 dBμV/m higher. The phase values showed a relatively stable phenomenon during the meteor shower. The results support the fact that meteors have an effect on the ionosphere in the atmosphere, enhancing the field strength value of the LF signal. Experiments also show that LF can be a powerful tool for detecting meteor showers during the day, exploring the influence mechanism, extent and future applications of meteors on low-frequency radio communications.

title: An Adaptive Multi-task Learning Framework for Traffic Speed Prediction
authors: Jiwei Hu, Ruitao Sun, Gaofeng Tong, Lin Li, Jingling Yuan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Product Compliance Engineering - Asia (ISPCE-ASIA)
abstract: The prediction of traffic speed based on historical data has garnered significant attention in the field of urban computing. For speed predictions in multiple traffic scenarios, knowledge contained in a traffic scenario can be leveraged by similar others, with the hope of improving the generalization performance of speed prediction models. Our key observation is that the shifts of temporal dynamics among traffic speed flows may bring misleading knowledge sharing. To this end, we propose an Adaptive Knowledge Sharing framework based on multi-task learning that autonomously determines when to share knowledge, tailored to prevailing spatial-temporal states, with the goal of improving traffic speed prediction. Experiments on two real-world datasets clearly demonstrate the superiority of our framework over the state-of-the-arts in terms of MAE and RMSE.

title: Real-Time Co-Simulation of an EMT-EMT Multi-Domain Power System
authors: Louis Birkner, Lorenz Graf, Ravinder Venugopal, Timo Wagner, Gert Mehlmann, Matthias Luther
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper investigates real-time co-simulation, focusing on coupling two electromagnetic transient (EMT) domains. As coupling algorithm, Distributed Parameter Line (DPL) is implemented, achieving a stable coupling. For local real-time co-simulation, a fiber-optic communication interface is used to ensure fast and reliable data transmission. The performance and accuracy is shown by electromagnetic transient simulations, demonstrating the advantages of real-time co-simulation in distributed systems. Offline simulations served as a reference to assess the coupling algorithms’ stability across EMT domains. In local real-time co-simulation via FPGA and fiber-optic communication, the DPL model achieved sufficiently stable coupling.

title: Structural Design of Self-Balancing Anti-Shake Binocular Vision Detection Device
authors: Shan Zhi, Zhenyuan Yang, Fengyu Li, Haoming Wang, Shuangchao Ge, Jianyu Zhai
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: In this paper, aiming at the situation that the positioning accuracy of the vision detection system in a dynamic environment is easily reduced due to vibration interference, a self-balancing anti-shake binocular vision detection device with mechanical vibration suppression and automatic compensation function is designed. During the mechanical structure design process, the overall structure design of the device is completed using SolidWorks 3D modeling software. With the mechanical transmission scheme that combines the worm and worm gear transmission mechanism and the incomplete gear mechanism, the flipping motion function of the system in the XOY plane is achieved. The ball screw transmission mechanism is used to control the lifting motion of the working platform along the axis. On this basis, the strength analysis and verification calculation of key components are carried out using the SolidWorks Simulation module.

title: Optimal Capacity Allocation of Pumped Storage Power Stations Considering Flexibility Requirements in Electricity Markets
authors: Ning Mi, Tong Li, Xin Qi, Gang Liu, Qiuting Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: Pumped storage plays an important role in enhancing new energy consumption and guaranteeing the safety of power grid operation, but the problems of large investment and difficult cost recovery have led to the low motivation of pumped storage construction. Based on this, a method of optimizing the capacity allocation of pumped storage power plant considering the flexibility demand in the market environment is proposed.The upper layer model takes into account the time cost associated with the capital for pumped storage construction and develops an optimization allocation model aimed at maximizing return on investment.The lower layer simulates the involvement of pumped storage in both the electric energy and ancillary service markets, establishing a market clearing model focused on minimizing grid operation costs.Based on the value of services provided by pumped storage, such as peak shifting, frequency shifting, and standby capacity, the revenue generated from participation in the spot market is calculated.This revenue is then fed back to the upper layer to facilitate further optimization of the pumped storage capacity.The revenue is returned to the upper layer so that the allocation of pumped storage capacity can be further optimized.

title: Method for a robust allocation of System Needs for Inertia in the Continental European Power System
authors: Mourad Kharrat, Felix Mühl, Albert Moser
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: A decline in inertia poses substantial challenges to power system stability, particularly during large-scale grid separation events. To address this issue, this work proposes a three-stage framework for the regional allocation of system needs for inertia. The approach begins with the identification of critical grid separation topologies. Next, composite demand areas for inertia are defined through the superimposition of these topologies. In the final stage, a linear optimization problem is formulated and solved to minimize the total system-wide inertia, ensuring that the inertia needs of each composite demand area are satisfied and then appropriately allocated across predefined regions. Applied to a exemplary scenario, the proposed method reveals regional disparities in the spatial distribution of system needs for inertia across Germany. The results also indicate that, while inertia needs generally remain moderate throughout the year, a limited number of critical hours are characterized by significant demand peaks.

title: Correlation Analysis of DC Charging Station Usage Rates and Traffic Volumes Based on Open Data
authors: Tuomo Mutru, Otto Räqisänen, Samuli Honkapuro, Ville Tikka, Ville Naumanen, Helin Güler
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Recent advancements in both EVs increased range and rapidly expanded charging infrastructure has made everyday travels with EVs increasingly convenient. Based on the mobility patterns of the EV fleet, local electricity networks experience increasing spatio-temporal variation in electricity demand. In the worst case, this could impose more stress on the local electricity networks. To detect, which locations experience highest power increases from EVs, more detailed analysis is needed. This paper proposes an open data based correlation analysis, in which several selected DC charging station usage rates are compared to the nearby traffic volume measurements. The objective of the analysis is to increase understanding on how accurately current traffic volumes correlate with DC charging station usage rates in different locations. Because traffic volumes typically follow rather easily predictable patterns, the correlation could be used to predict power demand at DC charging stations in the near future. With presented open data-based methodology, case study from Finland analyzed the correlation at 13 different locations. The results found strongest correlations along TEN-T core network, highlighting highest average correlation (0.86) in Heinola. Additionally, average correlation on regular (0.59) and holiday weekends (0.61) were found to be stronger than correlations on regular (0.46) and holiday weekdays (0.54), indicating increased DC charging demand relative to the traffic volumes.

title: POTENTIAL: Privacy-Oriented Task Offloading via Context-Aware Risk Estimation in JCAS-Enabled Edge Networks
authors: Mahshid Mehrabi, Vincent Latzko, Stefan Köpsell
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: Joint Communication and Sensing (JCAS) enables User Equipment (UE) to offload computational tasks to nearby peer devices or edge servers over context-aware wireless links. While this improves latency and resource utilization, the dual usage of the wireless spectrum for communication and environmental sensing introduces novel privacy risks, particularly for tasks involving location-sensitive or contextual data. This paper introduces a novel offloading framework that leverages real-time environmental information sensed by JCAS base stations to dynamically estimate the privacy risk associated with each offloading link. Based on these context-aware risk estimates, UE selects among local, Device-to-Device (D2D), or edge execution modes to minimize a composite cost function balancing privacy leakage and delay. A lightweight greedy scheduler is applied to solve the offloading decision problem efficiently under deadline constraints. Simulation results demonstrate that our method significantly reduces effective privacy leakage with negligible latency overhead, consistently outperforming context-agnostic baseline strategies.

title: Leukemia Classification Using Ensemble Deep Learning Models
authors: Aluri Ruthwik Sai Somanadh, Nikhilesh Rachabattula, Rajkumar Yesuraj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Early detection of leukemia plays a vital role in ensuring timely treatment and improving survival rates. However, the manual inspection of peripheral blood smear (PBS) images is often labor-intensive and prone to human error. To overcome these challenges, this work explores deep learning-based automation for leukemia detection. We propose an ensemble approach that integrates three well-established convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures: VGG16, VGG19, and EfficientNetB4. Leveraging transfer learning, these models are fine-tuned on PBS image data, and extensive augmentation is applied to improve robustness. Experimental findings reveal that the ensemble model achieves a validation accuracy of 98.76%, outperforming individual models: VGG16 (97.00%), VGG19 (96.94%), and EfficientNetB4 (95.20%). The results demonstrate the effectiveness of combining complementary architectures, yielding a reliable and scalable solution for medical diagnostics.

title: LAMedNet: Lightweight Graph Memory Network for Medication Safety
authors: Yonggui Wang, Mengqi Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data and Intelligent Medicine (BDIMed)
abstract: Drug combination recommendation seeks to generate safe and personalized treatment plans for patients with complex or comorbid conditions. Existing approaches, such as GAMENet, integrate electronic health records (EHRs) and drug– drug interaction (DDI) graphs to enhance prescription safety, yet their models often remain computationally heavy and fail to capture temporal patterns effectively. In this work, we present LAMedNet, a lightweight graph-enhanced memory network designed for efficient and safe medication recommendation. The model replaces conventional graph convolution layers with a parameter-free LightGNN module for compact drug embedding, and employs a dual-path LSTM encoder with an attention mechanism to model long-term dependencies across diagnosis and operation sequences. Moreover, a dynamic DDI-aware loss is introduced to jointly optimize accuracy and safety during training. Experiments on real-world EHR datasets demonstrate that LAMedNet achieves higher Jaccard and F1 scores, reduces DDI incidence, and substantially decreases the number of model parameters compared with current state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Formulation and Optimization of Power Flow Computation Algorithms for Flexible DC Traction Power Supply Systems
authors: Yuxiao Fan, Yong Li, Yuhang Liu, Shunpan Liu, Zhengyou He
publish: 2025 IEEE China International Youth Conference on Electrical Engineering (CIYCEE)
abstract: The flexible DC traction power supply system has lower losses and higher efficiency compared with the traditional AC railway electrification system. Meanwhile, it has the advantages of easy access to new energy and energy storage equipment. However, increased new energy and energy storage ports will be directly coupled with traction substations and locomotives through the DC traction network, and there are dynamic changes in the position of multiple locomotives. This will significantly increase the complexity of power flow analysis and the computing time. Thus, in this paper, an optimized power flow computation algorithm is proposed. Firstly, the mathematical model of the flexible DC traction power supply system is established for the power flow algorithm. Then, the advantages of the parallel computing method are analyzed. The computation model is validated by comparison with simulation results. Besides, considering the limitations of the parallel computing method, an optimization method for the algorithm iteration process based on fuzzy neural network (FNN) is proposed in this paper. According to the calculation results, the computation time is reduced from 3.214 seconds to 2.673 seconds under the FNN-based method.

title: Blockchain-based Certificate Verification System with AI-Assisted Content Validation using Hyperledger Fabric
authors: Mala K, Varun Yadav S T, C P Shankara, Lokesh H T, Manoj K V, Darshan B T
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Educational institutions increasingly issue certificates for academic achievements, workshops, and competitions in today's digital landscape. Manual verification processes are time-intensive and error-prone, creating significant authentication challenges. This research proposes an automated certificate verification framework integrating Hyperledger Fabric blockchain technology with AI-powered content validation. The system employs a Python-based AI module for analyzing uploaded certificates, identifying key identifiers including institution names, departments, and program details. Only validated certificates generate SHA-256 hashes for immutable blockchain storage, ensuring tamper-proof record management. Each verified certificate incorporates a QR code linking to blockchain verification endpoints for instant third-party authentication. Testing on a dataset of ten samples demonstrated perfect classification accuracy across all evaluation metrics. This approach combines blockchain immutability with artificial intelligence to deliver a transparent, scalable, and secure certificate validation solution that minimizes fraud risk while maintaining operational efficiency.

title: Multi-Scale Attention U-Net for Real-Time Object Detection in Complex Scenes
authors: Haixu You, Jun Xing, Xinzhe Wang, Bing Han, Jianchao Fan
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Information Science and Technology (ICIST)
abstract: Molten steel recognition has a significant impact on the quality of produced castings. However, complex molten steel pouring scenarios, such as irregular splatter spots and local overexposure from high-temperature radiation, hinder detection and recognition. To address high-temperature molten steel detection, this paper proposes a multi-scale attention U-Net (MSA-Unet). With an encoder-decoder structure, it integrates a multi-Scale feature fusion module (MFFM) using parallel dilated convolutionsand a squeeze-sxcitation (SE) attention mechanism. MFFM captures multi-scale features of molten steel, while SE enhances relevant features and suppresses noise. Evaluated on a self-built dataset of images from converter steel tapping and continuous casting scenarios, MSA-Unet outperforms traditional methods in segmenting molten steel regions and handling complex conditions. Ablation experiments verify the synergistic benefits of MFFM and SE. This approach offers an efficient solution for industrial molten steel detection, with the potential for dynamically adjusting dilated convolution parameters in future research.

title: IoT Solutions with Edge Computing in Industry 4.0: A Review
authors: Rodrigo Aparecido Silva Maia, Adler Diniz de Souza, Bruno Guazzelli Batista
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information, Intelligence, Systems &amp; Applications (IISA)
abstract: The demand for Edge Computing in Industry 4.0 is significant, especially in production environments where rapid decision-making is essential. However, implementing Edge Computing solutions in an industrial Internet of Things (IoT) network poses substantial challenges, including scalability. This paper presents a systematic literature review on IoT solutions with Edge Computing in Industry 4.0, aiming to support software architects in acquiring empirical data necessary for the development of new reference architectures (RAs). By employing systematic literature review methodologies, this study was able to identify important artifacts in the literature for the development of new architectures, such as non-functional requirements, software solutions, middleware, and other RAs. Additionally, it provides a methodology for empirical data acquisition and an introduction to the topic.

title: Backpack-LoRa: Energy-Efficient Multi-Hop Networking for LoRaWANs
authors: Daniel Szafranski, Moosa Sharafeldin, Andreas Reinhardt
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: The rising popularity of the Internet of Things and wireless sensing applications calls for energy-efficient and scalable communication protocols. LoRaWAN is one of today’s most prominent choices for this purpose, as it features long communication ranges and high energy-efficiency. However, a major drawback is its limitation to being operated in a star topology. Thus, data originating from nodes outside of the single-hop neighborhood of a gateway cannot be received. We overcome this limitation by presenting Backpack-LoRa, an extension to LoRaWAN which enables multi-hop uplink communication while being compatible with existing deployments. Instead of simply re-transmitting overheard frames entirely, however, Backpack-LoRa nodes extract and buffer only the relevant frame content for later decryption and append it to their own frames, which are transmitted during the next regular transmission slots. To address the limitation of most commodity transceivers – only being able to listen on one out of multiple available channels – we propose a pseudo-random channel allocation algorithm based on time and device address for Backpack-LoRa. We implement our approach in a real-world outdoor deployment consisting of four nodes and gateways. Subsequently, we analyze the improvements in network coverage, packet reception rate, and energy overhead. Our results show that Backpack-LoRa enables nodes to reach gateways which were unreachable for standard LoRaWAN and increase the packet reception rate by up to 54.9 %. As compared to a simple re-transmission approach, Backpack-LoRa can reduce the energy overhead by 28.8 %.

title: Optimal Management of a Port considering Shore-side Power and Electrical Vessels
authors: Afonso Barradas, Manuel Neto, Pedro B. Costa, Sheikh Shanawaz Mostafa, Lucas Pereira, Hugo Morais
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Maritime ports play a vital role in global economic activity and international trade, with shipping being the most efficient and widely used method for cargo transportation. Given this significance, the sector is facing increasing challenges due to national and international decarbonization targets. One of the key solutions being implemented is the Shore-Side Power (SSP)—the connection of ships to the Port's electrical grid while docked—which fundamentally transforms the role of seaports and demands new approaches to power and control infrastructure. This paper proposes linear optimization considering two scenarios. Both scenarios address energy management within a port, incorporating SSP alongside internal distributed energy resources such as controllable loads, photovoltaic (PV) generation, battery energy storage systems (BESS), and a fleet of electric vehicles. The scenarios differ in the number of ships that are docked in the Port. In the first Scenario, it is assumed that three cruise ships are docked (full capacity). In the second scenario it is assumed that no cruise ships will use tthe port The scenarios were developed considering the application in Port of Funchal in Portugal.

title: High-Accuracy, Low-Cost DR Classification: MobileNetV2 Enhanced by Lesion-Aware Teacher Distillation
authors: M Praveen Kumar, V Khanaa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: This study presents a novel lightweight convolutional neural network (CNN) framework for automated diabetic retinopathy (DR) classification, optimized for real-time deployment on portable devices. While deep learning has significantly advanced DR detection, most state-of-the-art models remain computationally intensive and unsuitable for widespread clinical use in resource-limited settings. Our approach introduces a lesion-aware knowledge distillation strategy that enhances the student model's ability to recognize critical DR biomarkers by aligning attention maps from a high-capacity teacher model. In addition, a temperature-scaled divergence mechanism improves the transfer of fine-grained class relationships, addressing the limitations of traditional knowledge distillation methods. The proposed model achieves 93.7% accuracy and a 0.912 F1-score, closely matching the teacher model's performance while using 88% fewer parameters and delivering a 5.8×speed-up in inference. Importantly, it demonstrates substantial gains in early-stage DR detection and lesion-specific sensitivity, enabling timely intervention and supporting human-AI collaboration in clinical settings. These results establish a practical path toward scalable, accurate, and efficient DR screening.

title: Predicting Molecular Properties With Quantum Kernels: a Study on the Qm9 Dataset
authors: Sonam Khattar, Harshit Kumawat, Aryan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: Predicting molecular properties is a cornerstone of drug discovery, materials science, and quantum chemistry, where accuracy and speed are critical. Classical machine learning mod- els offer rapid predictions but often fail to capture the intricate quantum interactions governing molecular behavior. Our team investigated quantum kernel methods to predict properties of the QM9 dataset, a widely recognized benchmark containing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 3 4, 0 0 0}$</tex> organic molecules with diverse chemical structures. By encoding molecular features into quantum circuits, we mapped classical data into highdimensional Hilbert spaces to enhance prediction accuracy. Our pipeline encompasses data preprocessing, quantum circuit design, model training with support vector regression, and evaluation of ten key molecular properties. The quantum kernel approach delivered promising results, achieving mean absolute errors of 0.13 Debye for dipole moment and 0.08 eV for HOMOLUMO gap, even when executed on noisy quantum devices. This work provides a comprehensive, reproducible pipeline, benchmarks quantum and classical models, and discusses practical challenges, contributing significantly to the field of quantumenhanced computational chemistry.

title: Democratizing Quantitative Finance: Tradesimx for Accessible, Accurate, and Modular Strategy Testing
authors: Sharath K M, Syed Faisal, Tanushree Kilari, Vidya R Rathod, Sheelavathy K V
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: TradeSimx is an open source modular framework, aiming at democratizing algorithmic trading by providing developers with an intuitive and extendible simulation environment. TradeSimx does not necessarily use the traditional sites with a high level of coding skills or a proprietary infrastructure; the platform is also a chatbot-based interface and offers a visual drag-and-drop strategy builder that allows the user to define the trading strategy, backtest it, and analyse it with little to no technical overhead. This design is especially designed for students, teachers, and individual researchers to make quantitative finance engaging and easily accessible. Its system allows simulation of historical market data, pluggable order executions logic, and automatic performance analysis based on major financial performance measures including Sharpe Ratio, Maximum Drawdown, and Profit Factor. TradeSimx is seen to perform well competitively, ergonomically, and flexibly, verifying its valid comparison to both Backtrader and QuantConnect, in a variety of strategies. Its architecture enables research level experimentation and enhances accessibility in algorithmic strategy design by offering interpretability and scalability.

title: Exploring Smart Learning Environment Maturity Factors Through Topic Modeling with Latent Dirichlet Allocation and Qualitative Content Analysis
authors: Della Maulidiya, Harry Budi Santoso, Ratnah Lestary, Zainal Arifin Hasibuan
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: The shift toward Smart Learning Environments (SLE) constitutes a key aspect of digital transformation in education, requiring systematic approaches for maturity assessment and development. However, a research gap remains, the construction of factors and dimensions in existing SLE maturity models has predominantly relied on qualitative analyses of conceptual frameworks, which limits the generalizability and scalability. While quantitative bibliometric techniques offer computational efficiency, they are typically restricted to processing metadata-such as titles, abstracts, and author keywords-without accessing the full semantic depth of the literature. To address these methodological limitations, this study applies a corpus-based mixed-methods approach. Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) topic modeling was used to analyze a dataset of 375 full-text scientific articles, resulting in the identification of 55 latent topics. These topics were further examined through qualitative content analysis using facets and quotations to extract 17 maturity factors. These factors were classified into five conceptual dimensions: technology-based supporting system, student profiling system, teacher development system, teaching and learning system, and technology-based educational management. The fivedimensional conceptual model encapsulates the complexity of SLE development and offers a structured basis for evaluation and continuous enhancement. The model will guide the next development phase for assessing SLE maturity, with future work focusing on benchmarking against established frameworks (e.g., CMMI), model, and instruments to validate its robustness.

title: Challenges & Opportunities with LLM-Assisted Visualization Retargeting
authors: Luke S. Snyder, Chenglong Wang, Steven M. Drucker
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: Despite the ubiquity of visualization examples published on the web, retargeting existing custom chart implementations to new datasets remains difficult, time-intensive, and tedious. The adaptation process assumes author familiarity with both the implementation of the example as well as how the new dataset might need to be transformed to fit into the example code. With recent advances in Large Language Models (LLMs), automatic adaptation of code can be achieved from high-level user prompts, reducing the barrier for visualization retargeting. To better understand how LLMs can assist retargeting and its potential limitations, we characterize and evaluate the performance of LLM assistance across multiple datasets and charts of varying complexity, categorizing failures according to type and severity. In our evaluation, we compare two approaches: (1) directly instructing the LLM model to fully generate and adapt code by treating code as text inputs and (2) a more constrained program synthesis pipeline where the LLM guides the code construction process by providing structural information (e.g., visual encodings) based on properties of the example code and data. We find that both approaches struggle when new data has not been appropriately transformed, and discuss important design recommendations for future retargeting systems.

title: Volumetric Visualization of the Genome
authors: Roxana Bujack, David H. Rogers, Cullen Roth, Eric Small, Banerjee Shounak, Vrinda Venu, Shawn R. Starkenburg, Christina R. Steadman
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: Within the nucleus of a cell, the genetic material (DNA) is condensed, supercoiled, and wrapped around proteins called histones, so to form chromatin. Unlike its traditional visualization, the organization of chromatin is 3D and can be measured with whole-genome sequencing technologies such as Hi-C sequencing, the results of which are often graphically represented as flat 2D heat-maps or a 1D curve that looks like a hairball. Here we discuss a novel approach to represent these and other genomic data by transforming the visualization of the genome from a 1D curve embedded in 3D into a structured 3D volume. This abstraction prioritizes 3D spatial proximity of chromatin and enables advanced techniques like clipping, thresholding, and contouring. Our method allows for multi-variable encoding, thereby enhancing our ability to interpret multivariate relationships, offering a more complete and effective representation of genomic structures, chromosome organization, and data relationships.

title: Visualizing on the Wrist: Impact of Motion, Dial Shape and Visualization Type on Smartwatch
authors: Zhouxuan Xia, Fengyuan Liao, Jinyuan Du, Yu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: Smartwatches increasingly serve as daily data analysis tools, yet their visualization designs face unique challenges: small screens, diverse dial shapes (round/square), and mobile usage contexts (sitting/walking). These factors may interact in unexpected ways, potentially compromising data readability during real-world use. Through a controlled experiment (N=32) comparing bar vs. radial visualizations across dial shapes and motion states, we found: (1) walking significantly reduces estimation accuracy, (2) bar charts consistently outperform radial variants by better supporting linear perception, and (3) radial bar graphs on square dials create particularly poor affordances than other combination. Our work provides the empirical evidence for how smartwatch dial factors, usage contexts and visualization design jointly impact data interpretation, offering concrete design guidelines for smartwatch visualization. Supplemental material is available at https://osf.io/k7fa3/.

title: A Diagonal Scaling-Based Discrete-Time Gradient Neural Network for Time-Varying Constrained Nonlinear Optimization
authors: Juliang Wang, Haoen Huang, Zhigang Zeng
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Information Science and Technology (ICIST)
abstract: Time-varying constrained nonlinear optimization problems are widely encountered in various engineering fields. Existing solutions primarily rely on continuous-time models, but their ubiquitous matrix inversion operations significantly increase computational complexity. To avoid matrix inversion, a diagonal scaling (DS) gradient processing method is proposed in this study. Building upon this method, three discrete-time gradient neural network models are constructed: the DS momentum acceleration (DSMA) model, the DS gradient integration (DSGI) model , and the DS recurrent neurodynamics (DSRN) model. Among them, the DSGI model exhibits the best performance. Furthermore, a sufficient condition is then established to ensure that the DSGI model generates a solution converging to the optimal solution. Finally, evaluations on one numerical experiment demonstrates that the DSGI model not only satisfies all constraints but also surpasses other existing discrete-time gradient models in terms of comprehensive performance and computational efficiency.

title: A Theoretical Proposal for a Unified Modeling Approach for Superconducting Parametric Amplifiers
authors: Yongjie Yuan, Özüm Emre Aşırım, Michael Haider, Christian Jirauschek
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: In this paper, we present a unified theoretical framework for analyzing nonlinear superconducting element-based quantum amplifiers. These amplifiers may be implemented either in nonlinear resonant geometries for reflection-based amplification or transmission lines for traveling-wave, transmission-based amplification. At the core of our approach is a general black-box quantum description of the dynamic system, which incorporates a flexible system-bath coupling formalism to accurately model diverse dissipation mechanisms in superconducting circuits. This framework enables a systematic evaluation of the amplification performance across various device architectures, offering a versatile tool for the design and optimization of quantum amplifiers.

title: An ACDC Security-Constrained Optimal Power Flow for Great Britain HVDC Integration
authors: Sam Hodges, Waqquas Bukhsh, Keith Bell, Andreas Grothey, Ken McKinnon, Shangen Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: As Great Britain integrates more offshore wind energy and point-to-point links, High Voltage DC (HVDC) systems will be essential for connecting offshore generation. These HVDC networks must be planned and operated alongside the existing High Voltage AC grid. This study presents a mathematical formulation of a Security-Constrained Optimal Power Flow (SCOPF) for coordinated ACDC dispatch. The SCOPF uses Bender’s Decomposition to handle the complex ACDC optimal power flow and contingencies. The model accommodates both point-to-point HVDC links and multi-terminal HVDC grids, considering linear and non-linear power flow formulations. Its effectiveness is demonstrated on extended IEEE test cases, with AC networks ranging from 6 to 57 buses with HVDC networks from 1 to 9 terminals.

title: Towards Proactive Grid Management: Weather-Aware Predictions for Power Disruptions
authors: Jasmine Garland, Kyri Baker, Ben Livneh, Ian Christie
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: An increase in the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events related to climate change threatens power system reliability. Creating an opportunity to harness the potential of machine learning for accurate forecasting of weather-induced power outages to aid in improving grid resilience, emergency preparedness, and public safety. This study develops and evaluates machine learning models (Random Forests, Extreme Gradient Boosting, Multi-layer Perceptrons, Recurrent Neural Networks, and Transformers) to forecast hourly power disruptions using publicly available weather and power outage data across two geographic regions: Los Angeles County, CA (city-level), and the state of Colorado (county-level), representing different climatic regimes, geographies, spatial granularity, and population density. Weather variables leading up to 12 hours of outage occurrence are considered. The Recurrent Neural Network is the best performing model among both regions, with a testing accuracy of 0.92 for Los Angeles County and 0.89 for Colorado. A real-time forecasting tool that integrates weather forecasts to predict future outages is also deployed using the knowledge from the models trained on historical data. This work contributes a scalable, topology-agnostic, and interpretable framework for power disruption forecasting.

title: Adaptive Resource Allocation and Service-Level Optimization for Efficient Cloud Computing Performance
authors: Veeru Malothu, D. Ramesh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: The shortcomings of cloud computing computation performance are usually poor resource distribution and the inability to sustain service-level agreements (SLAs) with dynamic and unpredictable workloads. Current solutions like metaheuristic optimization, machine learning, clustering and reinforcement learning have been promising. As a case example, whale optimization and hybrid NSGA-II task scheduling algorithm efficiency reduced task latency by up to 20% and 12-18 % energy efficiency, and load balancing based on reinforcement learning minimized violations of SLA by 15 %. Likewise in cloud fog IoT systems, machine learning predictions of workloads reduced provisioning errors by 22%, and energy-sensitive scheduling reduced energy use by almost 10 to 25%. Nonetheless, the majority of these solutions are performance optimized or energy usage optimized in isolation, they do not consider their interaction in a heterogeneous and multi-tenant workload. To close this gap, the paper presents an Adaptive Dual-Layer Resource Allocation Framework (ADRAF), which combines proactive workload prediction based on a hybrid machine learning-reinforcement learning framework with multi-objective metaheuristic resource allocation optimization decision-making. Simulations indicate that ADRAF can reach a 25% SLA compliance and 30% energy savings, as compared to existing plans. A fresh development of this is introduction of context aware migration policies which allow work to move dynamically between cloud, fog and edge tiers depending on latency and energy compensation, thereby enhancing sustainability and adaptability to next-generation applications.

title: iTestLayout: An Automatic Pagination Algorithm for Print-Ready Examination Papers
authors: Thanh Le Dinh
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: In educational institutions, especially during highstakes assessments, preparing well-formatted printed exam papers is a critical yet time-consuming task. Traditional methods of exam layout creation require significant manual effort and are prone to formatting inconsistencies. This paper proposes an efficient algorithm for automatic pagination and layout generation of exam papers, designed to meet practical constraints such as spacing, question grouping, and optimal page utilization. The algorithm is implemented in the iTest system, which is currently deployed across multiple universities and testing centers. Through experimental validation on real-world datasets, the proposed method demonstrates high layout quality, correctness, and runtime efficiency. A public deployment is made available for reproducibility and live demonstration.

title: Extending the MPIE Galerkin MoM Thin Wire Formulation to Include Curvilinear Wires
authors: David B Davidson, Donald R. Wilton
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This work extends a previous paper to include a general curvilinear geometrical description, using second order polynomials. The piecewise linear description for the wire current is retained. The use of a singularity-canceling transform scheme for the potential integrals in the curvilinear case is described. The paper concludes with a number of results, verifying the implementation by comparing with published results and results computed using the commercial code FEKO.

title: NutriCaneNet: A Deep Learning Framework for Sugarcane Micronutrient Deficiency
authors: Pradip P Ghorpade, Pankaj Dashore
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Deficits of micronutrients in sugarcane, especially of zinc (Zn), iron (Fe), manganese (Mn), copper (Cu), boron (B), and molybdenum (Mo), have a profound impact on output and recapture of sucrose. Detecting such shortcomings in the field proves difficult because the symptoms are similar to those of pests, diseases, or abiotic stress, and laboratory tests are expensive and time-consuming. This research paper aims to establish a robust and explainable deep learning model for accurately and promptly identifying micronutrient deficiencies in sugarcane. We present a new system, NutriCaneNet, that uses four major modules: (i) Stage-Aware Normalization to reduce variability in colour expression across growth stages, (ii) Distilled Segmentation to extract leaf regions precisely and cheaply, (iii) Fusion of Image and spectral-texture in a growth-conscious manner, and (iv) Energy-Based Guardrails to measure the uncertainty of prediction and detect confounding non-nutrient stresses. The models were trained and evaluated on a curated dataset of annotated leaf images, in combination with a laboratory tissue assay. Site- and season-based splits ensured strong generalisation. In a comparative experiment, NutriCaneNet is characterized by a macro-F1 score of 0.82, whereas Support Vector Machine (0.61), Random Forest (0.65), CNN-ResNet (0.73), EfficientNet-B0 (0.76), and Swin Transformer (0.78) are characterized by a lower score. Through these results, it is evident that NutriCaneNet can serve as a valuable decision-support tool for managing sugarcane precision nutrient management.

title: Characterization of Switch Voltage Unbalance Issue in WBG-Based Diode Clamped Multilevel Inverters
authors: Ali Halawa, Kangbeen Lee, Mikayla Benson, Jinyeong Moon, Woongkul Lee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: Wide bandgap (WBG)-based multilevel inverters are gaining widespread attention due to their superior switching speed, efficiency, and power density. In particular, the integration of low-voltage gallium nitride (GaN) devices into neutral-point clamped (NPC) three-level inverters offers significant performance improvements but also introduces new challenges. One critical issue observed is voltage unbalance across the switching devices, which occurs independently of dc-link capacitor voltage imbalance. This phenomenon originates from high frequency switching transients. It persists even after the system reaches steady-state operation. However, accurately identifying the root cause of this unbalance is nontrivial. This difficulty arises from the complex interaction of multiple high-frequency current paths and parasitic couplings within the NPC topology. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a unit-cell-based analytical model that captures the switch voltage unbalance behavior in diode-clamped multilevel inverters. The model is developed using state-space analysis applied to a simplified unit cell. This cell consists of two voltage sources, two switches, and a clamping diode. The simplification reduces circuit complexity while isolating the dominant dynamics responsible for the observed behavior. The analysis reveals that the fundamental cause of the voltage unbalance is a resonant interaction that charges the output capacitance of the clamping diode, leading to a non-zero residual voltage. Furthermore, the study identifies key parasitic parameters—specifically, device output capacitance, parasitic inductance, and switching dv/dt—as major contributors to the severity of the voltage unbalance. Among these, the parasitic inductance at the neutral point is found to have the most significant impact. The validity of the proposed model is verified through LTspice simulations. Experimental results are obtained from a hardware setup comprising a single NPC inverter module built using two GaN-based half-bridge units. These results confirm the existence and characteristics of the voltage unbalance under varying conditions of dv/dt, device capacitance, and load. The findings further validate the analytical predictions.

title: Domain-Adaptive Representation Learning for Multimodal Deepfake Detection
authors: Ijaz Ul Haq, Khalid M. Malik
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: The rise of deepfakes poses a significant threat to public trust in digital content, particularly when presented on social media platforms where fabricated videos of political leaders, influencers, or celebrities can rapidly go viral. These convincing manipulations fuel misinformation, distort public opinion, promote scams, and challenge the integrity of content on social media. Additionally, with the recent shift from unimodal to multimodal deepfake generation, detection systems face increasing difficulty when identifying forgeries that combine both visual and audio manipulation. Traditional detection methods often fail to generalize across unseen manipulations or domains, limiting their practicality on dynamic, real-world social media content. To address this challenge, we propose domain-adaptive representation learning (DARL), a novel framework that leverages the inherent correlation between the audio and visual modalities using a deep canonical correlation analysis network. DARL effectively learns robust audio–visual representations by integrating knowledge from speech recognition domains, enhancing its ability to detect both LipSync and face-swap deepfakes. Our approach demonstrates improved accuracy and generalization across five benchmark datasets, along with a locally collected real-world deepfake advertisements dataset that features audio–visual deepfake social media content, highlighting its potential as a reliable defense mechanism against the spread of deepfake-induced misinformation on social media platforms.

title: Branch-MFA-TDNN: A Parallel Branch Speaker Verification Model for Voice IoT
authors: Guoyuan Lin, Jinbing Deng, Wei Chen, Zehua Wang, Na Xu, Fei Richard Yu, Victor C. M. Leung
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: The security of voice control in the Voice Internet of Things (Voice IoT) heavily relies on the fast and accurate authentication of the command issuer. In this work, we focus on the critical application scenario of Voice IoT in underground coal mines, where voice commands typically last 4–10 seconds. Speech in this scenario typically consists of short, imperative utterances and faces challenges from environmental noise and device heterogeneity. The limitations of traditional speaker verification models in temporal modeling restrict their performance in such scenarios. To address this, this paper proposes a three-dimensional attention module (Branch-MFA) designed for Voice IoT. This module employs a dual-parallel branch architecture: the MFA branch is responsible for extracting attention in the frequency and channel dimensions, and its multi-scale nature enables it to effectively focus on speaker-discriminative frequency bands that remain stable under noise and different collection devices, thereby enhancing the model’s environmental robustness; the GLTA branch, through its innovative grouped variable-length attention mechanism, specifically models the temporal structure of these short voice commands, addressing the challenge of sparse temporal information in short utterances. By integrating the dual-branch outputs through a fusion module, we construct the Branch-MFA-TDNN model. Experiments on the Cn-Celeb dataset show that this model significantly outperforms baseline models in short-utterance verification tasks, particularly for the challenging 4–10 second duration relevant to mine communications, providing an identity authentication solution for Voice IoT that combines high security and real-time performance. We have also released the code<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup> for future comparison.

title: From Perceived Design Affordance to Fear Reduction: A Mediation-Guided Generative Design Framework for Pediatric Medical Toys
authors: Jiahe Wang, Pufan Song, Yifei Li, Yalan Zhang, Tianbao Wu, Biao Zhou
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This study addresses children’s fear of medical toys through perceived design affordance (PDA) and develops a mediation guided pathway from interpretable design variables to generative optimization. We constructed 9 dimensions, 5 level semantic space (Color, Material, Humanization, Environmental Interaction, Structure, Function orientation, Sound, Scale, Customization) around five core medical elements to generate 45 scene images. In 151 children (3–12 years) with matched parent and observer reports, mixed effects and mediation analyses support the chain Design → PDA → Fear → Approach/Cooperation. The child PDA composite shows good internal consistency (Cronbach’s α = 0.85) and converges with the parent proxy scale (α = 0.96; r = 0.93). Observer hesitation aligns with fear (r = 0.80) and cooperation aligns with PDA (r = 0.71). Dimension wise, moderate color and sound intensities increase affinity, whereas extreme scale and dense sound cues elevate fear. Approach/cooperation is sensitive to PDA (β = 0.70), while fear’s direct effect becomes nonsignificant once PDA enters the model. These parameters inform an interpretable reward function that, combined with safety constraints and persona weights, trains predictors of PDA and fear to re rank generated designs. Compared with an aesthetics only baseline, the proportion of high PDA/low fear candidates in Top k lists and ranking concordance improve while constraint violations decrease. Rather than claiming a fully behaviorally validated evidence-guided pipeline, the study demonstrates a bridge from mediation estimates to generation and offers actionable rules: within safety bounds, use moderate intensity, harmony, and legibility to build an “affordance plateau,” then layer light customization and interactivity to reduce fear and promote cooperation.

title: Trajectory Generation and Extended High-Gain Observers Based Output Feedback Control for an Underactuated Flying Inverted Pendulum
authors: Weiming Yang, Joel Reis, Gan Yu, Linghuan Kong, Carlos Silvestre
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper presents trajectory generation and output-feedback control strategies for an underactuated Flying Inverted Pendulum (FIP) system operating under unknown time-varying disturbances. The proposed approach introduces a novel scheme that employs two Extended High Gain Observers (EHGOs) to efficiently estimate the inverted pendulum’s linear and angular velocities, as well as the unknown disturbances, independently. The control strategy integrates a nonlinear hierarchical Lyapunov-based framework with EHGOs to tackle complex trajectory-tracking missions. Leveraging the differential flatness property of the FIP system, a versatile trajectory generation method is developed for window-crossing maneuvers. This work marks a step toward achieving closed-loop integration of trajectory generation and nonlinear control for the aggressive maneuvering of an underactuated FIP. The robustness and effectiveness of the proposed algorithms are validated through numerical simulations and experimental tests, using an underactuated aerial vehicle as a benchmark.

title: Text-Assisted Multi-Modal Adaptive Registration and Fusion Classification Network
authors: Yufei He, Bobo Xi, Guocheng Li, Tie Zheng, Yunsong Li, Changbin Xue, Ming Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Due to inherent sensor discrepancies, hyperspectral image (HSI) and LiDAR data in fusion classification tasks often suffer from spatial misalignment and limited high-quality annotations, which severely constrain classification performance. While some recent methods attempt to address these issues by introducing semantic alignment strategies or contrastive learning (CL), challenges such as inconsistent cross-modal representations and limited semantic generalization still persist. To address these issues, we propose a novel text-assisted adaptive registration and fusion classification network (TARCNet). First, we develop a feature adaptive alignment (FAA) module, which adaptively adjusts LiDAR features to alleviate semantic inconsistency under misregistration. Second, we introduce a text-assisted contrastive learning (TCL) module, which leverages linguistic priors to strengthen cross-modal consistency and improve the discriminability of the learned representations. Third, we incorporate a multi-loss joint optimization (MLO) module to ensure consistent and stable optimization across heterogeneous modalities. Extensive experiments conducted on three HSI-LiDAR datasets with misregistration and limited annotations demonstrate that our method outperforms several state-of-the-art approaches, validating its effectiveness and generalization capability.

title: AI-Based Intrusion Detection Enabling Cyber-Resilience in Grid Forming Inverters
authors: Uzair Asif, Reza Behnam, Ahmed Kouzou, Mohammad B. Shadmand, Haitham Abu-Rub
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: This work proposes an event-triggered strategy to detect false data injection (FDI) cyber-attacks that impact the dynamic frequency behavior of a grid-forming inverters (GFMIs) network. The proposed approach employs an artificial intelligence (AI) technique to enable a hidden detection strategy (HDS) that triggers based on variations in system frequency and optimal power sharing commands (OPSC). The developed approach is tested on multiple attack vectors, including a data-driven coordinated FDI attack to manipulate the OPSC and voltage measurements in the communication lines between primary and supervisory control layers, and a malware attack to manipulate inertia and damping coefficient (IDC) values in the primary controller. The proposed method enables real-time estimation of system trajectories, specifically frequency and rate of change of frequency (ROCOF), under system variations and disturbances. These trajectories are used to assess system dynamics and detect the presence of attacks. The proposed AI-IDC-HDS is validated on a modified 9-bus IEEE system. Furthermore, a small-scale hardware setup is used for experimental validation.

title: On-Device Machine Learning Model Adaptation for 6G Communications: From Standardization to Over-The-Air Prototyping Experiments Based on Beam Prediction
authors: Qiaoyu Li, Manish Rana, Mariko Tatsumi, Armand Ahadi-Sarkani, Amanjit Dhillon, Arumugam Kannan, Parag Kanade, Serag Gadelrab, Tao Luo
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Adapting pretrained artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML) models for on-device inference across diverse environments is challenging due to the extensive offline data collection and training required. This highlights the necessity for online model training or adaptation, where devices locally process training data and perform adaptation via on-device engines. Such capabilities and technologies are essential for various wireless AI/ML features requiring on-device inference to be considered in the upcoming Third Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) 6G standardization works. For battery-powered devices, model adaptation must be efficiently executed in real-time with well-designed timelines, as environmental conditions can change rapidly and vary significantly across locations. In this paper, we present results from over-the-air (OTA) prototyping experiments using handset devices to demonstrate the practical effectiveness of real-time on-device adaptation. We use AI/ML based beam prediction, as outlined by 3GPP 5G-Advanced standards, as an example. Our OTA results show that on-device model adaptation can be completed within 30 seconds in an unfamiliar environment to achieve benchmark performance, strongly supporting the feasibility of real-time on-device model adaptation in 6G communications. The findings and methodologies discussed in this paper can be extended to benefit various other wireless and non-wireless real-world scenarios.

title: Efficiently Ensuring Traffic Rule Compliance of Motion Plans by Incorporating Scenario Knowledge
authors: Florian Lercher, Paul Reisenberg, Matthias Althoff
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Autonomous vehicles must obey the rules of the road to safely participate in road traffic. To enforce these rules during motion planning, they are often formalized in temporal logic. Such formalizations need to be very general to cover all possible traffic situations, resulting in large and complex logic formulas. During motion planning, however, we are usually confronted with a concrete scenario in which parts of the formulas may be irrelevant. Since specification-compliant motion planning under complex specifications is computationally challenging, we aim to simplify the traffic rules by removing these irrelevant parts. To this end, we first present a general algorithm that augments linear temporal logic formulas with scenario-specific knowledge. Then, we provide a method for extracting knowledge from traffic scenarios to augment traffic rules. We can formally guarantee that the augmented specification is equivalent to the original formula in the given scenario. Therefore, subsequent motion planning modules that handle temporal logic specifications need only consider the augmented formulas. We benchmark our approach in recorded real-world scenarios to demonstrate that it can significantly accelerate specification-compliant motion planning.
