title: FB-ASC+: Improved Fog-Blockchain Assisted Certificateless Aggregate Signcryption Scheme
authors: Zhiyuan Sui, Yaxing Zha, Yujiao Sun, Meijiao Duan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: Smart grids enable two-way communication between control centers and smart meters. However, this capability introduces security and privacy risks and has consequently prompted extensive research. Liu et al. proposed a fog-blockchain-assisted certificateless aggregate signcryption (FB-ASC) scheme to achieve confidentiality and unforgeability in smart grids. Our research demonstrates that their signcryption design achieves neither confidentiality nor unforgeability, and we show that the supporting lemmas in their paper do not hold. Under the same system models, we presented effective attacks on their scheme and consequently proposed the FB-ASC+ scheme that provides provable security guarantees against the aforementioned attacks. Comparison results further illustrate its performance advantages over pairing-based alternatives in typical smart-grid scenarios.

title: Time-Varying Optimization on Multiplex Networks: A Novel Two-Stage Distributed Preset-Time Approach
authors: Siyu Chen, Yongduan Song
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control
abstract: This study investigates distributed time-varying optimization on multiplex networks, presenting a more comprehensive framework than single-layer ones. By leveraging the supra-Laplacian matrix, time-regulator function and zero-gradient-sum method, we develop an innovative two-stage distributed algorithm with preset-time convergence to address the time-varying optimization problem on multiplex networks. The initial stage of the algorithm is devoted to reaching the optimal solution of all local time-varying cost functions within the preset time. Subsequently, the second stage of the algorithm aims to reach the global optimal solution within the preset time, while ensuring that the sum of all gradients remains zero. The validity and efficacy of our theoretical results are substantiated through a series of numerical experiments.

title: Synthesis of Wideband Coupling Matrix With Predefined Reflection Zeros and Its Application in Coupled-Line Filters
authors: Yuqiang Xie, Zihang Qi, Xiuping Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: In this article, the bandpass responses with predefined reflection zeros (PRZs) are synthesized directly in the bandpass domain and then used to extract the wideband coupling matrix (WCM). Since different parameter combinations of the bandpass responses result in different transversal topologies, 18 different cases are systematically enumerated and analyzed here for the first time. Among them, ten new cases of WCMs with distinct residual parts emerge with the introduction of PRZs. The equal-ripple bandpass responses with PRZs are synthesized by modifying the Remez iteration. The responses with different numbers of PRZs are compared to illustrate the influence of PRZs. The results show that introducing PRZs can enhance the rectangular coefficient of a filter under the same number of in-band reflection zeros (IRZs). To implement the WCM with PRZs, the conversion equations of WCM components to coupled-line components are derived. Two design examples are given to demonstrate the applications, one is a two-IRZ wide-stopband filter, and the other one is a six-IRZ wide-passband filter. In the two-IRZ example, the traditional coupling matrix (TCM) method is compared with the WCM method to highlight the limitations of TCM. In addition, the responses with zero, one, and two PRZs are compared, showing that the two-PRZ case provides an extra transmission zero (TZ) at infinity frequency under the same topology compared with the non-PRZ case. Finally, both designs are fabricated as stripline filters, and the measured results agree well with the simulations, validating the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Signal Detection for User-Centric Network Massive MIMO System
authors: Rui Sun, Linfeng Song, Chen Sun, Ding Shi, Xiqi Gao, Xiang-Gen Xia
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the signal detection for user-centric network (UCN) massive multi-input multi-output (mMIMO) system. We consider that the users are divided into multiple user groups (UGs). For each UG, leveraging the interference sparsity, we reveal that the performance of the minimum-mean-square-error (MMSE) detector can be guaranteed in the network mMIMO system by using the matched filtering (MF) outputs of the intra-group and interfering users. Then, with the base station (BS) connection sparsity, we reveal that the detection performance of each UG is primarily determined by a limited number of associated BSs. To facilitate practical application, we propose a straightforward user grouping method and outline the process for determining interfering users and associated BSs for each UG in UCN mMIMO systems. Then, we propose a user-centric detection method that decouples the detection process for each UG into two stages. In the first stage, local MF is performed at each associated BSs using local information. In the second stage, group-wise interference cancellation (IC) is carried out to obtain detection results at the primary serving BS (PSBS) of each UG, with information exchanged from auxiliary serving BSs (ASBSs). Simulation results confirm the effectiveness and computational efficiency of our proposed user-centric detection for the UCN mMIMO system.

title: Emerging Power Electronic Converters for Hydrogen Energy Storage Systems in Smart Cities: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Kotb B. Tawfiq, Hatem Zeineldin, Ahmed Al-Durra, Ehab F. El-Saadany
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: The global revolution in the direction of renewable energy sources is reforming modern energy systems, with hydrogen energy storage systems (HESSs) evolving as one of the most promising solutions to energy storage and decarbonization challenges. HESSs play a vital role in the vision of zero-carbon smart cities by offering flexible responses to renewable energy variability and enabling sustainable, long-term energy storage. As the hydrogen economy advances, power electronic converters are becoming increasingly important where they enable efficient energy conversion, control, and integration. This paper presents a comprehensive review of recent developments in power electronic converter technologies that support the operation of HESSs in smart cities, highlighting their designs, associated challenges, and opportunities for future research. Different types of power converters for both hydrogen production and utilization are discussed and critically analyzed.

title: A 240 Elements Matrix Probe with Aberration Mask for 4D Carotid Artery Computational Ultrasound Imaging_supp1-3648199.pdf
authors: Yuyang Hu
publish: N/A
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) ultrasound provides enhanced visualization of the carotid artery (CA) anatomy and volumetric flow, offering improved accuracy for cardiovascular diagnosis and monitoring. However, fully populated matrix transducers with large apertures are complex and costly to implement. Computational ultrasound imaging (cUSi) offers a promising alternative by enabling simplified hardware design through model-based reconstruction and spatial field encoding. In this work, we present a 3D cUSi system tailored for CA imaging, consisting of a 240-element matrix probe with a 40 × 24 mm² large aperture and a spatial encoding mask. We describe the system’s design, characterization, and image reconstruction. Phantom experiments show that computational reconstruction using matched filtering (MF) significantly improves volumetric image quality over delay-and-sum (DAS), with spatial encoding enhancing lateral resolution at the cost of reduced contrast ratio. LSQR-based reconstruction was demonstrated to further improve resolution and suppress artifacts. Using both Hadamard and 16-angle plane wave transmission schemes, the system achieved high-resolution images with reasonable contrast, supporting the feasibility of 4D CA imaging applications.

title: A novel hybrid price prediction method using multimodal deep learning and LLM for new energy power raw materials
authors: Xuhui Zhu, Muzi Li, Pingfan Xia, Hao Lei, Zhanglin Peng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: Accurate prediction of raw material prices helps enterprises optimize procurement, control costs, and enhance profits. Yet, the interplay of factors such as supply and demand imbalances, market volatility, and abrupt disruptions still poses a significant challenge. To address these challenges, we propose a novel hybrid framework for price prediction, called EFD-CBGT, that combines deep learning and Large Language Model (LLM). First of all, we leverage LLM's internalized rich knowledge and contextual reasoning capabilities to generate high-quality textual data using interactive querying. The textual data is then converted into low-dimensional, high-value features using FinBERT and Deep Sparse Autoencoder. Second, we employ Empirical Wavelet Transform to create stationary numerical series from the most strongly correlated features of raw material prices. Finally, by incorporating Feature-wise Attention Module, we use four deep learning models to extract local, bidirectional temporal, temporal, and global features. We conduct comparative experiments, ablation studies, significance tests, and robustness analyses on three real datasets from a leading lithium-ion battery manufacturer in China. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of EFD-CBGT.

title: TinyEdge: TinyML-Driven Secure Edge Computing Framework for Industrial IoT in 5G Networks
authors: Rimmi Sharma, Kathan Panchal, Shivanshi Bhatt, Lakshin Pathak, Shimoly Shah, Rajesh Gupta, Sudeep Tanwar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference for Women in Innovation, Technology &amp; Entrepreneurship (ICWITE)
abstract: The Tiny Machine Learning (TinyML) model performance evaluation in Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) intrusion detection systems forms the core subject of this paper. The TinyML model shows better accuracy and smaller model footprint than usual deep learning models which makes it workable for resource-restricted edge systems. TinyML demonstrates validation accuracy of 98.22% with test accuracy of 97.86% and it operates from a model size that reaches just 0.06 MB. The model proves excellent for IIoT systems since it delivers optimal performance combined with minimum resource usage requirements. TinyML presents itself as an optimized solution to IoT edge-to-cloud applications because it has a compact design that can execute rapidly and handles systems with minimal memory requirements. The study presents TinyML as an excellent solution for IIoT intrusion detection because it delivers both high performance levels and compact model dimensions which surpass traditional models including LSTM and GRU within resource-limited environments.

title: Exploring Small Hydropower Potential Sites Based on GIS
authors: Yu-Feng Chung, Tai-Chuan Yu, Tzu-Lung Liao, Chih-Hsun Hsueh, Yi-Fang Chu, Shang-En Chiang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: This study integrates Geographic Information System (GIS) and multiple hydrological models to assess Small hydropower (SHP) potential in the Beinan River watershed, Taitung, Taiwan. SWAT was used for streamflow simulation, and QGIS for slope and head calculations, guiding turbine selection. Site and flow velocity analyses were conducted in Sub-basins 5 and 29, demonstrating the method’s practicality for rapid screening of potential sites, enhancing local energy self-sufficiency.

title: Optimized Feature Selection for Rhizome Image Classification: Evaluation of CFS, ReliefF, and L1-SVM
authors: Nani Sulistianingsih, Siti Agrippina Alodia Yusuf, Fitri Astutik, Muhammad Imam Dinata
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ICoAIT)
abstract: Image classification of rhizome plants plays a crucial role in supporting agriculture, the herbal industry, and biodiversity conservation. However, the high visual complexity-resulting from variations in shape, texture, and lighting conditions- presents significant challenges in the classification process. This study aims to optimize the accuracy of rhizome image classification by applying and comparing three feature selection methods: Correlation-Based Feature Selection (CFS), ReliefF, and L1-regularized Support Vector Machine (L1-SVM). The dataset comprises texture and shape features extracted from rhizome images using the Local Binary Pattern (LBP) technique and descriptive statistical analysis. Each feature selection method is integrated with the Support Vector Machine (SVM) classification algorithm and evaluated using accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and area under the ROC curve (AUC). The experimental results demonstrate that the ReliefF method outperforms the others, achieving a test accuracy of 89% and an average AUC of 0.97, followed by L1-SVM and CFS. These findings confirm that appropriate feature selection significantly improves classification performance while reducing model complexity. This study offers practical insights into the selection of feature selection techniques for machine learning based plant image classification systems.

title: Performance Analysis of Beidou Common View Time Comparison based on PPP-B2b Service
authors: Dandan Li, Hang Yi, Xueyun Wang, Juncheng Liu, Shengkang Zhang, Jun Ge
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Beidou common view time comparison is a commonly used method for achieving high-precision time-frequency comparison between stations, which can meet the user's demand for nanosecond level comparison accuracy. At present, the Beidou common view time comparison method uses code pseudo range observations for time difference calculation, and its accuracy is affected by the accuracy of code pseudo range observations. In addition, it requires post exchange of time difference data, which results in poor realtime performance. Based on this, It proposes a Beidou common view time comparison method based on PPP-B2b service. The method adopts a dual frequency ionosphere free combination model, and constructs observation equations using carrier phase observation and code pseudo range observation. After high-precision data processing such as carrier phase cycle slip detection and correction, error correction, parameter estimation, etc., a high-precision inter station comparison time difference can be calculated and obtained. By building an experimental platform, conducting remote high-precision time-frequency comparison experiment, and analyzing the experimental data, the analysis results show that this method not only meets the real-time needs of users, but also significantly improves the uncertainty of time measurement.

title: Combating Deepfakes: A Transformer - Obtained and Explainable Frameworks for Robust Video Integrity Verification
authors: Lavanya T, C. Pandeeswaran, L. Steffina Morin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: A The fast-growing development of deepfake technology poses serious threats to digital trust, media integrity, and information authenticity. Current detection methodologies may be effective but often struggle with issues of generalization, computational expense, and a lack of interpretability. a novel framework, "Countering Deepfakes: A Transformer-Informed and Explainable Framework, for Robust Video Integrity Verification," which adopts a hybrid convolutional neural network (CNN) and transformer-based architectures to model local spatial aspects and long-range temporal aspects of video information. Additionally, multimodal analysis, through visual and audio consistency checks, significantly contributes to detection reliability. To meet the interpretability challenges, Here applies a gradient-based interpretability methodology to identify facial manipulation regions for forensic overlay. Empirical evaluation of our framework on established benchmark deepfake datasets shows promise for comparably higher accuracy, cross-data-set generalization, and adversarial robustness compared to prior CNN–RNN-based deepfake methodologies. This reduced a computational demands and enabled ~real-time™ deployment, in a version suitable for digital media forensics, social media engagements, and digital information cybersecurity. Our work extends the state of the art in video integrity detection by offering a robust, interpretable, and scalable solution to counter deepfakes in a rapidly changing digital environment.

title: Edge-Based Missing Value Imputation For IoT Platforms: Towards Artificial Intelligence of Things
authors: Alexandru Cioca, Pau Ferrer-Cid, Jose M. Barcelo-Ordinas, Jorge Garcia-Vidal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: Recently, the use of Internet of Things (IoT) technologies has been widely adopted, enabling large-scale monitoring and data acquisition. Together with the so-called artificial intelligence of things (AIoT), data-driven models are to be executed close to the data source. Nevertheless, one potential problem is the quality of the data used to feed these models. Data loss is a common issue in these systems and can hinder the use of monitoring data and the application of artificial intelligence (AI) models. This paper evaluates a set of missing value imputation techniques, emphasizing their application in an edge setting. Specifically, offline and sliding window variants are evaluated to meet data availability and computational complexity criteria. The benchmarking has been performed using the data of a real IoT air quality monitoring platform. The results demonstrate that the windowed variants can approach the offline performance using reduced sliding windows of 25 to 100 samples per sensor.

title: Data-Driven State-Space Modeling for Small-Signal Stability Analysis of Black-Box Power Converters
authors: Luis A. Garcia-Reyes, Eduardo Prieto-Araujo, Vinicius A. Lacerda, Josep Arévalo-Soler, Oriol Gomis-Bellmunt, Macarena Martin-Almenta, Edgar Nuño-Martínez, Javier Renedo
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This article introduces a data acquisition-based methodology to construct a state-space model of black-box Voltage Source Converters (VSCs) for application in small-signal stability analysis in modern power-systems using the Component Connection Method (CCM). The proposed approach determines the fitted state-space (FSS) model through the frequency-domain (FD) admittance matrix of the VSC, identified via the input-output responses of voltage and current at the point of connection (POC). By applying a multiple single-input single-output (SISO) vector fitting array, a stable FSS representation is determined with high accuracy. Order reduction methodologies such as Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) and Balanced Realization (BR) are then employed to generate the minimal representation of the VSC, eliminating redundant states and reducing computational burden. The presented approach is validated through pole analysis and comparison with electromagnetic transient (EMT) simulations for a grid-following (GFL) converter. The effectiveness and applicability of the methodology are further demonstrated through a small-signal analysis of a test system based on the IEEE 9-bus benchmark, incorporating a black-box VSC model.

title: Focusing by Leaky-Wave Bessel-Beam Launchers: Principles, Design, and Applications
authors: Edoardo Negri, Stella Ventucci, Walter Fuscaldo, Paolo Burghignoli, Alessandro Galli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Thanks to the remarkable focusing, limiteddiffraction, and self-healing features, the generation of Bessel beams has recently attracted renewed interest for various applications in different frequency regions. In particular, the exploitation of the versatile leaky-wave paradigm has allowed us to characterize and design simple yet effective Bessel-beam launchers in planar technology, for focusing applications ranging from microwaves to submillimeter waves. This contribution aims to outline the working principles and design rules, while also showing the practical potential of such radiators.

title: Pneumonia Diagnosis using Deep Learning Optimized with Generative AI for Analysis, Intelligent Report Generation and Recommendations
authors: Sri Ram Ganesh M, Dhiliphan Rajkumar T, Suresh Kumar N, A.K.Anith, Srirama Suvetha M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Pneumonia continues to be one of the leading causes of respiratory illness worldwide and accurate and timely diagnosis is an important part of improving patient outcomes. This study explores optimized hybrid deep learning models that integrate conventional CNN models and advanced architectures. Specifically we applied ResNet50, MobileNetV3, DenseNet121, and VGG16 for the detection of pneumonia from chest X-ray and CT data. We developed a systematic preprocessing pipeline, including high pass filtering (HPF), Gaussian smoothing, normalization. To improve results, image augmentation methods were combined with advanced optimizers, including AdamW, adaptive learning rate, dropout, and batch normalization, and significant image augmentation techniques to address class balance and improvement in performance. The experimental findings indicate that on the balanced chest X-ray dataset, CNN+ResNet50 and CNN+DenseNet121 produced the highest accuracy with a perfect 98% while CNN+MobileNetV3 achieved the highest accuracy on the multimodal dataset (i.e., image modalities included MRI) with 96% accuracy. Further, a generative AI module was included to automatically generate structured diagnostic reports. This systematic non-analytical approach to increase the interpretability of the diagnosis and potentially improve clinical decision support was novel to this application. Overall the findings confirm that optimized hybrid deep learning frameworks and generative AI offered a reliable, accurate, and scalable approach to pneumonia diagnosis across different imaging modalities.

title: Vision-Based Navigation for Intelligent Rescue Vehicles with Scene Content Analysis
authors: Xuemin Bu, Lei Zhang, Songhua Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Aided Education (ICISCAE)
abstract: Scene interaction is of critical importance in the operation of field rescue apparatus. To maximize the effectiveness of rescue devices, the system must be capable of rationally and effectively distinguishing between different identified objects within the environment. Addressing this practical requirement, this study proposes an inspection method integrating a rotation matrix adapted for rescue operations into YOLOv12. The method employs partitioning into sub-regions for localized analysis, thereby enhancing the detection capability for small objects and objects at various orientations. Theoretical analysis and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method is well-suited for practical applications in field rescue vehicles. The recognition performance for objects at different angles is significantly enhanced, effectively improving the navigation control methodology for such vehicles.

title: Comparing Pre-attentive Visual Variables in a Target Identification Task for Glanceable Visualizations
authors: Fairouz Grioui, Yasmin Amira Amzir, Nina Doerr, Tanja Blascheck
publish: 2025 IEEE Visualization and Visual Analytics (VIS)
abstract: In this paper, we evaluated the use of three pre-attentive visual variables, namely, area, color hue, and flicker, to highlight elements on four charts: bar chart, line chart, linear progress chart, and radial progress chart. We exposed 48 participants—using short time lapses of 250 ms—to a set of stimuli showing one of the four charts with the three visual variables. Then we examined the accuracy of their answers in identifying the highlighted target element under sedentary and walking conditions. Our results show that all three visual variables can be perceived with a medium to high accuracy rate, though performance varies depending on the mobility condition, the visual variable, and even the chart type. Among the visual variables, color and flicker yield the best target identification accuracy rates, while the area proves to be the least effective. The findings from our first investigation contribute to the design of efficient smartwatch micro visualizations that support glanceable and in-motion data reading. Supplemental material is available here.

title: Hammering the Diagnosis: Rowhammer-Induced Stealthy Trojan Attacks on ViT-Based Medical Imaging
authors: Banafsheh Saber Latibari, Najmeh Nazari, Hossein Sayadi, Houman Homayoun, Abhijit Mahalanobis
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Vision Transformers (ViTs) have emerged as powerful architectures in medical image analysis, excelling in tasks such as disease detection, segmentation, and classification. However, their reliance on large, attention-driven models makes them vulnerable to hardware-level attacks. In this paper, we propose a novel threat model referred to as Med-Hammer that combines the Rowhammer hardware fault injection with neural Trojan attacks to compromise the integrity of ViT-based medical imaging systems. Specifically, we demonstrate how malicious bit flips induced via Rowhammer can trigger implanted neural Trojans, leading to targeted misclassification or suppression of critical diagnoses (e.g., tumors or lesions) in medical scans. Through extensive experiments on benchmark medical imaging datasets such as ISIC, Braib Tumor, and MedMNIST, we show that such attacks can remain stealthy while achieving high attack success rates about 82.51% and 92.56% in MobileViT and SwinTransformer, respectively. We further investigate how architectural properties, such as model sparsity, attention weight distribution, and number of features of the layer, impact attack effectiveness. Our findings highlight a critical and underexplored intersection between hardware-level faults and deep learning security in healthcare applications, underscoring the urgent need for robust defenses spanning both model architectures and underlying hardware platforms.

title: Spatio-Temporal Graph Neural Networks for Multi-Period Optimal Power Flow
authors: Ali Rajaei, Olayiwola Arowolo, Jochen L. Cremer
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: The increasing integration of renewable energy sources (RES) and the inter-temporal constraints of generation units necessitate real-time solutions to the AC multi-period optimal power flow (MP-OPF) problem. RES exhibit spatiotemporal correlations due to their geographically distributed nature and time-varying generation patterns. This paper proposes a novel graph recurrent neural networks (GRNN)-based approach to learn an optimization proxy for the AC MP-OPF problem. The proposed approach: (i) uses a graph attention mechanism to extract grid topology features, enhancing scalability for larger networks and improving topology adaptiveness; (ii) uses a recurrent structure to capture temporal correlations, and enable scalability for longer prediction horizons; and (iii) jointly consider spatial and temporal dependencies in end-to-end learning to improve prediction accuracy. Additionally, a feasibility restoration layer minimizes constraint violations during training and ensures feasibility during testing. Numerical results on the IEEE 118-bus and PEGASE 1354-bus systems demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed GRNN over the baseline neural architectures, achieving up to 50% lower prediction error, minor optimality gap of 0.5%, and 2-4 orders of magnitude speed-ups. Under N-1 line outages, the GRNN approach reduces the optimality gap by 4.5%, showcasing its robustness to topology changes. These results highlight the GRNN-FR as a promising approach for real-time applications in large-scale power networks, whether for fast warm-start initialization or rapid solution of numerous MP-OPF instances.

title: Polynomial Calibration and Temperature Drift Compensation of 3D-Hall Magnetic Field Sensors for Enhanced Accuracy and Stability
authors: Wittapong Klaykabil, Taylor Yan, Heiko Bouquet, Woosik Gil, Khanchai Khosonthongkee, Jiraphon Srisertpol
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: This study presents a calibration methodology for 3D Hall-Effect magnetic field sensors using a custom-built 3D Helmholtz coil system to generate a highly uniform reference magnetic field. The proposed method employs polynomial fitting to correct non-linearities in the sensor response and compensates for temperature-induced drift using a magnitude-only correction approach. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in measurement accuracy, with the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) reduced by up to 96% across all axes. While the linearity of the sensor outputs remained consistently high before and after calibration, the calibration process effectively reduced both systematic and random errors. Additionally, temperature drift errors were effectively minimized, resulting in a sTABLE output over the tested temperature range of 17 °C-28 °C. The overall uncertainty of the calibration process, considering both field generation and measurement accuracy, is estimated to be within ±0.15%, ensuring the reliability of the proposed calibration method for high precision magnetic field measurements.

title: Design and Performance Analysis of a High-Gain DC-DC Converter Employing an Active Switched Network
authors: Kcanandhan, V. Gowri Shankar, K. Muthuvel, A. Pradeep, P. Karthikeyan, P. Karputha Pandi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: High step-up DC-DC conversion is a critical requirement in applications such as renewable energy systems, electric vehicles, and DC microgrids, where low-voltage energy sources including photovoltaic arrays and fuel cells must be efficiently elevated to higher voltage levels. Conventional boost converter topologies, however, encounter limitations associated with extreme duty-cycle operation, elevated voltage stress on semiconductor devices, and deteriorated efficiency at higher gain conditions. To mitigate these challenges, this study proposes a high-gain DC-DC converter architecture founded on an active switched network (ASN). The configuration integrates coupled switched-inductor and switched-capacitor cells, enabling substantial voltage amplification under moderate duty ratios, thereby alleviating device stress and ensuring continuous input current characteristics. A comprehensive steady-state formulation in continuous conduction mode (CCM) is developed, followed by a systematic methodology for sizing both active and passive components. The dynamic performance is further assessed through the implementation of open-loop and closed-loop control schemes, validated via MATLAB/Simulink simulations, and subsequently verified on a 100 W hardware prototype. Comparative assessment against conventional and state-of-the-art converter structures demonstrates that the proposed ASN-based topology achieves a superior gain-to-component ratio along with enhanced efficiency, recording 86% under rated loading conditions. The outcomes establish the proposed converter as a viable candidate for renewable energy integration, fuel cell-powered systems, and distributed DC microgrid infrastructures.

title: Multi-Agent Conversational System for Automated Stock Market Analysis and Decision Support Toward Inclusive Economic Growth
authors: Samuel Andreas Bangun, Bryan Oflahertys, Aditya Ramadhan, Alexander Agung Santoso Gunawan
publish: 2025 1st International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ICoAIT)
abstract: This research explores how to support investors in processing large amounts of real-time stock data for better decision-making. The paper introduces a Multi-Agent System that uses Large Language Models and the CrewAI framework to support more accurate stock prediction. The system uses an Intent Agent to classify queries and specialized agents for fundamental, technical, and macroeconomic analysis via APIs. Specifically, fundamental and technical data are sourced from the Yahoo Finance (yFinance) API, while macroeconomic data is retrieved using the EconDB API. A Summarizer Agent combines the results into clear and concise insights, which are delivered through a chatbot interface built with Streamlit. This architecture supports real-time, interactive communication, making advanced stock analysis more approachable for retail investors. To quantitatively evaluate agent performance, we validated system-generated recommendations against actual market movements across multiple Indonesian stocks within 30-day intervals. Result show that the Fundamental Agent achieved 75% directional accuracy, correctly identifying stock trends through indicators such as revenue growth, profit margin, and debt levels. The Technical Agent attained 50% accuracy, capturing momentum through MACD, RSI, and price-volume dynamics. These findings highlight the superiority of fundamental analysis for short-term prediction, while also emphasizing the limitations of relying on a single analytical dimension. Both agents demonstrated the ability to generate explainable investment suggestions, and the combined multi-agent approach provides a flexible, transparent, and scalable platform for decision support in finance. It also supports SDG 8 by promoting inclusive financial access and channeling investment toward sectors that foster growth and decent work.

title: Dynamic T-SQL Based Query Fragment Caching Algorithm (QFCA): An Adaptive Approach to Database Query Optimization
authors: Anita Padhy
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Electronic Circuits and Signaling Technologies (ICECST)
abstract: Efficiently answering database queries plays a crucial role in many data-driven applications, with widespread adoption of architectures that generate Dynamic T-SQL scripts. Despite extensive research into query optimization, relatively little attention has been devoted to efficient caching of query fragments. These fragments—constituted by complete SQL statements or subsets thereof—serve as data views, filtering criteria, or join relationships. Caching them reduces computational overhead and latency when participating in multiple, semantically similar queries. This article proposes the Query Fragment Caching Algorithm (QFCA) for adaptive, dynamic caching of frequently accessed fragments. QFCA harmonizes advanced query parsing, semantic analysis, and intelligent fragment identification to achieve significant performance improvements. Experimental results demonstrate that QFCA achieves an average cache hit rate of 78.5% and reduces query execution time by 42.3% compared to traditional full-query caching approaches. The algorithm shows effectiveness in environments with high query complexity and moderate to high query similarity patterns.

title: The PEOS E-Infrastructure Prototype: Natural Hazard Monitoring Through Earth Observation From Space
authors: Carlo Marcocci, Emanuele Pica, Massimo Viola, Nicola Guglielmi, Giampaolo Sensale, Marco Spina, Christian Bignami, Federica Pardini, Vincenzo Romano
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: The Platform for Earth Observation from Space (PEOS) is a cutting-edge e-infrastructure developed at the Istituto Nazionale di Geofisica e Vulcanologia (INGV), Italy. It embraces research areas related to seismology, volcanology, space weather and geodesy, integrating heterogeneous products for Earth Observation, natural hazard monitoring and surveillance which leverage space data acquired from satellites and ground-based platforms. PEOS' goals are twofold: first, to provide an integrated, flexible environment for hosting, executing, and orchestrating scientific algorithms while managing the whole data-product lifecycle; second, to ensure the dissemination of FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) data to the scientific community and support products provision towards operational services.

title: High-Precision Modeling and Low-Complexity Simulation Optimization for 3GPP TDL Channel Models
authors: Jialong Mo, Jiawei Yuan, Jianyun Chen, Zhi Qu, Chao Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: Wireless channel simulations with high computational resolution are crucial for the hardware implementation of 3GPP TDL models in 5 G systems. This paper proposes a novel framework that integrates a fractional delay filter based on the Farrow structure with a correlated tapped delay line (TDL) channel model, effectively resolving the trade-off between delay precision and hardware efficiency. The core motivation lies in constructing a highly accurate and scalable channel emulator to significantly reduce the reliance on noisy, time-consuming, and difficult-to-implement field tests. The framework adopts a three-stage optimization strategy: First, each multipath component is modeled using a Farrow filter to achieve high-precision delay simulation for individual paths. By optimizing the delay filters for each path, the number of filters is reduced by 80%. Next, the relative attenuation of each path and the Doppler power spectral density (PSD) conforming to the Jakes model are implemented. The Jakes model is optimized using the FFT method, which reduces computational complexity by over 10 times compared to direct time-domain superposition. Finally, the TDL-A to TDL-E channel model framework is realized using FIR filters in a time-varying filter system, lowering hardware complexity. Simulation results demonstrate precise modeling of TDL channels while reducing computational complexity and hardware implementation difficulty. This work provides practical guidance for designing low-cost, low-hardware-complexity channel emulators with guaranteed fidelity.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Prompt-Based Tuning Strategies for Indonesian Business Activity Classification
authors: Isnaeni Noviyanti, Indra Budi, Rizal Fathoni Aji
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: Classifying business activities according to the Indonesian Standard Industrial Classification (KBLI) involves several challenges, including short text descriptions, a large number of classes, and limited labeled data. To handle these challenges, particularly in few-shot data scenarios, prompt-based learning represents a new paradigm. This method uses templates and verbalizers to provide additional contextual information to the language model. In this study, we compare various tuning strategies in classifying business activities based on KBLI using prompt-based learning in a few-shot scenario. Experimental results show that the fixed-prompt LM tuning approach, combined with an automatic verbalizer, achieved the highest average F1-macro score of 70.8% across all shot settings. This is 3.6% higher than the promptless fine-tuning approach. Our findings highlight the importance of selecting the appropriate tuning strategy and verbalizer to optimize model performance.

title: House energy management optimization considering the particle swarm optimization algorithm
authors: Ricardo Faia, Pedro Faria, Zita Vale
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: This paper presents an approach to optimize house energy management systems using the particle swarm optimization algorithm. By integrating particle swarm optimization into the energy management system, the proposed method aims to optimize energy usage, considering various factors such as electricity demand, photovoltaic generation, load shifting, and electricity tariffs. Through simulation studies and real-world case scenarios, the effectiveness and performance of the particle swarm optimization-based optimization strategy are evaluated, highlighting its ability of metaheuristics to solve problems regarding energy utilization at the household level. The optimization problem is formulated as a non-linear programming model. To validate the efficacy of this approach, simulations are conducted using real-world data from a residential house

title: Water Based Frequency Selective Surface Acting as an Absorber
authors: Catalin Pescari, Andrei-Marius Silaghi, Aldo De Sabata, Ladislau Matekovits
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: Absorbers are used for selective enclosure screening and stealth technology. This paper proposes a cost-effective frequency selective surface (FSS) that functions as a narrow-band absorber, utilizing spherical water resonators within the unit cell as absorbing elements. A strong and sharp absorption resonance is achieved at 3.38 GHz for a unit cell size of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$15 \times 15 \text{mm}^{2}$</tex>. The surface demonstrates stability with respect to polarization, incidence angles up to 60°, and temperatures between 5° C and 45° C. Its operation is evaluated through simulations, with field images provided to offer insight into its performance.

title: MoPFNs: Probabilistic Radio Map Construction via Mixed Transformer-Trained Gaussian Process Regressions
authors: Toma Tsuchino, Toshiro Nakahira, Shoko Shinohara, Takeru Fukushima, Yusuke Asai, Kenji Ohira, Hideyuki Shimonishi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: Real-time and reliable wireless communication is increasingly vital for applications like remote robot control. To support such needs, radio environment maps (REMs) showing metrics like signal strength at each location in the area have gained attention. However, their values are affected by noise, fading, and positioning errors, so representing only the mean is insufficient; their full probability distribution is needed. While Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) is commonly used to build REMs, it often struggles to capture distribution shapes and is inefficient at scale. To address these challenges, we build on Probabilistic Feature Networks using Prior-Data Fitted Networks (PFNs), which utilize a transformer trained on GPR, and propose the Mixture of PFNs (MoPFNs) to model the probability distribution as a mixture of Gaussian distributions. Experimental results in a 28 GHz millimeter wave (mmWave) environment show that the proposed method reduces the average error in estimated mean RSRP to less than 10 dB, accurately captures variations in distribution shape across locations, and improves execution time by approximately 92.5%.

title: Transitions in Multilayer PCB Technology for mmWave Low Loss Transmission Lines
authors: Simone Gaetano Ballaera, Jorge Daniel Martinez Perez
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: This paper presents a transition from coplanar waveguide to stripline capable of operating over the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{DC}-67 \text{GHz}$</tex> frequency range. The proposed structure is a vertical throughvia transition, fabricated using PCB technology and designed for on-wafer probe measurements. Full-wave electromagnetic simulations have been performed to evaluate the S-parameters of both the single transition and a back-to-back configuration including a 30 mm stripline section. In the back-to-back configuration, the measured insertion loss is less than 2.2 dB, while the return loss exceeds 20 dB across the entire frequency band of interest.

title: Real-Time Skeletal Tracking for Smart Rehab Remote Physiotherapy using Deep Learning and Pose Estimation
authors: Deepika Dattatraya Walanjkar, Sreelalitha Talluri, Navpreet Kaur, Vaneet Kumar, Sudeshna Baliarsingh, G. Sajiv
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Recent advances in artificial intelligence offer unprecedented flexibility in the delivery of rehabilitative services beyond clinic walls. This work introduces Smart Rehab, a skeletal-tracking platform that executes noise-resistant pose estimation for remote physiotherapy through a tandem of deep-learning models. Employing a compact, hybrid 2D/3D convolutional architecture, the framework monitors articulation across all major joints in real time, overlaying context-sensitive instructive prompts throughout prescribed rehabilitation. Comprehensive tests yield a mean-per-joint position error of 6.8 mm, a task-specific recognition accuracy of 96.7%, and sustained frame-wise processing of 28 ms, confirming the module’s capacity to reliability out-distance commercial gold standards. Comparative evaluation against lab-grade infrared motion sensors and biomechanical markers establishes equivalent fidelity, underlined by an operational expense less than one twentieth of present–day penal sensors while evading time-intense lab visits. By merging unmatched fidelity, clinical-grade dependability, and streamlined deployment management, Smart Rehab emerges as a compelling, extensible, and economically justifiable tele-rehabilitation platform, granting remote, real-time observation and adaptive case moderation by physiotherapy professionals, thereby preserving clinical trajectories in a context of fragmented portfolio care.

title: Vector-Based Similarity for Personalized Recommendation Systems
authors: Tran-Diem-Hanh Nguyen
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Knowledge and System Engineering (KSE)
abstract: Personalized Recommendation Systems (RS systems) have been gaining popularity among researchers in data science as the systems help users search for products that satisfy their preferences. Likewise, the systems also provide benefits to companies who desire their products to be known to more future customers. Although a wide ranges of methods and techniques have been proposed to boost RS systems performances recently, the significant contributions of this kind of systems are always needed in this information age when more e-commerce platforms are available. In this article, two groups of methods including (1) basic prediction methods and (2) vector-based similarity methods combined with KNN are compared in this study. In particular, the basic prediction method employed Min, Max and Average of the user's ratings to predict the missing values. On the other hand, the vector-based methods employed the combination of KNN and vector-based similarity including Pearson and Cosine to predict the missing ratings. The experiments were carried out using the datasets MovieLens 100 K. The evaluation metrics includes Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Cohen's Kappa metric (KAPPA), and Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) to compared the performances of the models. The vector-based similarity using Pearson similarity combines with KNN provided better performance than the other models for the metrics including RMSE and MAE.

title: Adaptive Robust Optimization Approach for Energy System Optimization Models
authors: Lina Fischer, Lucas Kerber, Albert Moser
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Climate policy goals require massive expansion of renewable energy plants as well as transmission capacities and sector-coupling technologies. Although this requires a fundamental transformation, the energy system must be able to reliably supply future energy demand, especially for electricity and gas. In this context, Energy System Optimization Models (ESOMs) provide recommendations on future energy system designs. However, these models rely on deterministic assumptions about future developments. This reduces the robustness and validity of their findings in the context of uncertainty, especially with respect to future energy demands. To address this issue, Robust Optimization methods offer promising approaches to enhance the resilience of the optimized energy system designs by explicitly accounting for uncertainty in model inputs.In this context, this paper introduces an Adaptive Robust Optimization framework to consider uncertainty in future energy demands and applies it to a state-of-the art ESOM. The resulting model can be used to identify robust capacity expansions of generation and transmission infrastructures, that protect against the uncertainty across various scenarios.

title: Shear Alfvén Wave Antennas in the Large Plasma Device
authors: Stephen Vincena, Walter Gekelman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
abstract: SHEAR Alfvén waves are a fundamental, low-frequency mode in magnetized plasmas. They can accelerate both ions and electrons since the waves possess electric field components both perpendicular and parallel to the mean magnetic field, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{B}_{0}$</tex>. They have important implications from understanding the solar coronal heating problem, to auroral electron acceleration, to the expulsion of fast ions from fusion devices—to name a few. It is thus of great interest to study their fundamental properties in controlled laboratory environments and, in large part, this means using antennas to launch the waves. In this talk, we present a brief history of antennas used in the Large Plasma Device (LAPD) at UCLA, their construction, and select plasma physics topics they enabled.

title: Aliasing Distortion Correction Method in the Arbitrary Waveform Generator Based on FT-DAC
authors: Wenhao Zhao, Houjun Wang, Ke Liu, Zaiming Fu
publish: 2025 IEEE 17th International Conference on Electronic Measurement &amp; Instruments (ICEMI)
abstract: As electronic technologies continue to evolve, conventional arbitrary waveform generators (AWGs) are increasingly unable to meet the growing bandwidth demands. To address this limitation, interleaving architectures, including frequency-interleaved DAC (FI-DAC) and time-interleaved DAC (TI-DAC) have been proposed to improve the performance of AWG via multiple DACs. TI-DAC suffers from bandwidth constraints due to the magnitude roll-off characteristics of DAC. Therefore, the FI-DAC offer a more promising approach for bandwidth enhancement at the current DAC technology level. FI-DAC operate by decomposing and reconstructing signals in the frequency domain and require extensive use of analog components such as mixers and filters. However, the filters cannot fully suppress image components outside the passband of the sub-channel, leading to aliasing distortion in the reconstructed output signal. To address this issue, this paper develops a mathematical model of aliasing distortion and proposes a multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO)-based correction method. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is demonstrated through simulation results, confirming its potential to significantly reduce aliasing and improve output signal quality.

title: Knowledge Distillation Model for Resource-Constrained Iris Segmentation in Biometric Systems
authors: Arief Andy Soebroto, Wayan Firdaus Mahmudy, Anto Satriyo Nugroho, Nurul Hidayat, Indriati, Agi Putra Kharisma
publish: 2025 Tenth International Conference on Informatics and Computing (ICIC)
abstract: The country requires a digital identification system that is reliable, secure, efficient, and resistant to forgery. Iris biometric systems offer a promising solution due to the unique and lifelong stable patterns of the iris, which are difficult to replicate. The use of deep learning technology has improved the accuracy of iris biometric systems, but often results in models with high computational demands. The knowledge distillation approach provides a solution by reducing model complexity without significantly compromising performance. This study utilizes DeepLabV3 as the teacher model and Lightweight U-Net as the student model for iris image segmentation. The evaluation focuses on segmentation performance using IoU, precision, recall, and F1-score metrics, as well as model efficiency based on parameter count, model size, and inference time. The experimental results show that the student model achieves an IoU of 0.8823, precision of 0.9691, recall of 0.9078, and F1-score of 0.9374. Efficiency evaluation shows that the student model contains only 118,913 parameters, has a model size of 0.48 MB, and an inference time of 1.17 milliseconds. A comparison with the teacher model reveals that knowledge distillation reduces the number of parameters by 99.7 percent, the model size by 99.68 percent, and accelerates inference time by 50.21 percent. The reduction in segmentation accuracy is relatively small, with a 2.97 percent decrease in IoU, 0.41 percent in precision, 2.67 percent in recall, and 1.59 percent in F1-score. These findings confirm that knowledge distillation is an effective approach for producing lightweight and efficient segmentation models suitable for deployment on devices with limited computational resources.

title: Using EAST to develop design recommendations for a context-dependent energy support system
authors: Sophie G Hart, Victoria Steane, Katherine Plant, Mark S Young
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Recent Advances in Systems Science and Engineering (RASSE)
abstract: Automation and rigorous safety procedures have enabled commercial aviation organizations to operate with relatively low incident rates. Even so, the few incidents reported in 2024 continued to cite crew decision-making during the landing phase of flight as a contributory factor. Crew decisionmaking was also highlighted as a contributory factor in the Asiana 214 accident in 2013 that culminated in a crash following an unsafe and destabilized approach. This suggests that more needs to be done to support pilots in the landing phase of flight. The current work uses the Event Analysis of Systemic Teamwork (EAST) framework to understand why pilots present during the Asiana 214 incident continued to land the aircraft in an unsafe and destabilized configuration. Interrogation of the information networks enabled the identification of design recommendations for a novel contextdependent energy support system. Such systems tailor the presentation of information based on the current operational environment and the state of the vehicle. The potential utility of this novel decision support system was then examined by integrating the design recommendations within the information network to explore its potential impact on the system.

title: FlashMP: Fast Discrete Transform-Based Solver for Preconditioning Maxwell's Equations on GPUs
authors: Haoyuan Zhang, Yaqian Gao, Xinxin Zhang, Jialin Li, Runfeng Jin, Yidong Chen, Feng Zhang, Wu Yuan, Wenpeng Ma, Shan Liang, Jian Zhang, Zhonghua Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE 43rd International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD)
abstract: Efficiently solving large-scale linear systems is a critical challenge in electromagnetic simulations, particularly when using the Crank-Nicolson Finite-Difference Time-Domain method. Existing iterative solvers are commonly employed to handle the resulting sparse systems but suffer from slow convergence due to the ill-conditioned nature of the double-curl operator. Approximate preconditioners, like SOR and Incomplete LU decomposition (ILU) provide insufficient convergence, while direct solvers are impractical due to excessive memory requirements. To address this, we propose FlashMP, a novel preconditioning system that designs a subdomain exact solver based on discrete transforms. FlashMP provides an efficient GPU implementation that achieves multi-GPU scalability through domain decomposition. Evaluations on AMD MI60 GPU clusters (up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0 0 ~ G P U s}$</tex>) show that FlashMP reduces iteration counts by up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$16 \times$</tex> and achieves speedups of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.5 \times$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.9 \times$</tex> compared to baseline implementations in state-of-the-art libraries Hypre. Weak scalability tests show parallel efficiencies up to 84.1 %.

title: IoT-Integrated Intelligent Transformer Protection And Monitoring System with Automated Cooling And Multi-Fault Detection using ATmega328p
authors: Paneesh A, Pavan K, Jaividhya S, Sri Vidhya D
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sustainable Communication Networks and Application (ICSCN)
abstract: Power transformers are important in efficient transmission and distribution of electrical energy. Real-time monitoring and protection is necessary to make them last longer and avoid any unexpected failure. The paper will describe a smart transformer monitoring and protection system that was designed with the help of the Atmega328P microcontroller. The system connects several sensors in order to constantly monitor certain important parameters like temperature, voltage, and current. It can identify many kinds of faults such as line-to-line fault, line-to-ground fault, and double-line fault as well as overvoltage. A temperature sensor automatically turns on a cooling fan through a relay once safe thermal levels are surpassed and thus prevents overheating of the transformer. A current sensing module detects irregular current flow which can be an indication of overload or short circuit and a relay system is used to safely de-energies the transformer in the case of critical faults. On-site monitoring is presented by the display of all real-time information, e.g., fault types and sensors readings on an LCD display and sent in parallel to a cloud-based IoT system to be accessed remotely and provide alerts. This two-layer monitoring system improves the reliability of the system, reduces loss of time, and promotes proactive maintenance. The suggested system offers an affordable scalable solution that can be implemented in smart grid systems and rural and urban power systems.

title: Federated Learning with Reliability-Aware Workload Allocation in Distributed Edge Computing
authors: Fatemeh Mirhakimi, Bahman Javadi, Rodrigo N. Calheiros, Adel N. Toosi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Wireless and Mobile Systems (MSWiM)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) enables collaborative model training across various distributed devices without sharing raw data. Client failures, variable energy availability, and outages of edge servers contribute to unreliable training participation, incomplete model updates, and failures at the system level during the aggregation process. In this study, we introduce a reliability-aware workload allocation FL framework (FedRAW) aimed at improving system reliability in failure-prone edge computing systems. Our approach dynamically modifies client workloads based on their failure history and integrates a lightweight backup mechanism to maintain aggregation continuity during edge server failures by backup servers handling. Additionally, we employ Bayesian optimization to fine-tune workload parameters, achieving improved energy efficiency. Experimental results reveal that our proposed method improves model accuracy while reducing energy consumption compared to recent federated learning algorithms.

title: Very Long Term Load Forecasting at Grid Supply Points with Limited Historical Load Data Availability
authors: Airam Perez Guillen, Jovica V. Milanović, Shengji Tee
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference Europe (ISGT Europe)
abstract: Very long-term load forecasts (VLTLFs) spanning 15 to 25 years are indispensable for strategic electricity infrastructure planning. These forecasts are even more challenging when the historical load data is scarce in addition to uncertain future load growth. This paper presents a methodology to generate seasonal peak load forecasts for grid supply points (GSPs) until 2050, despite having limited years of available recorded data. This is demonstrated with two real UK GSPs with 5 years of available data. First, macroeconomic and demographic variables (regional GDP and household statistics) are mined and interpolated to match seasonal resolution. A transfer-learning backcasting step employs ridge regression, which is compared and selected for its superior performance in reconstructing historical GSP loads. The exogenous variables are first forecasted using ARIMA, and the extended dataset then feeds into seasonal ARIMAX models to project future load peaks. Finally, projected additional demand from electric vehicles and heat pumps is incorporated based on DSO’s Distribution Future Energy Scenarios (DFES). For the first GSP considered, the 2035 and 2050 peak forecasts differ from DFES’ Electric Engagement scenario by 15% and 17%, respectively, while for the second one, the analogous differences are 12% and 8%. The methodology delivers robust, explainable VLTLFs with quantified uncertainty, demonstrating its suitability where load data availability is limited.
